description: exigency \ek-s-jn(t)-se, ig-zi-jn(t)-\ noun

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 2, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Fire Is Set at the Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
description: The F.B.I. is leading an investigation into a fire that was set Wednesday night at the main entrance of the Chinese Consulate General in San Francisco, the authorities said Thursday. No injuries were reported.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Dialect Map of the United States
description: The map above is linked to an interactive quiz called How Yall, Youse and You Guys Talk. Take the quiz and pay attention to the map that will display on the left of the screen as you go in order to answer the following questions. You may need to return to certain quiz questions a second time, choosing different answers, in order to display the information needed for some of the questions.

title: Chinese Copter Rescues 52 From Ship in Antarctic Ice
description: LONDON  In a dramatic operation displaying unusual international harmony in one of the worlds most remote and inhospitable places, a red-and-white Chinese helicopter on Thursday rescued 52 passengers trapped for more than a week aboard an icebound Russian research ship in Antarctica, ferrying them a dozen at a time to an Australian icebreaker.

title: A Speck in the Sea
description: Looking back, John Aldridge knew it was a stupid move. When youre alone on the deck of a lobster boat in the middle of the night, 40 miles off the tip of Long Island, you dont take chances. But he had work to do: He needed to start pumping water into the Anna Marys holding tanks to chill, so that when he and his partner, Anthony Sosinski, reached their first string of traps a few miles farther south, the water would be cold enough to keep the lobsters alive for the return trip. In order to get to the tanks, he had to open a metal hatch on the deck. And the hatch was covered by two 35-gallon Coleman coolers, giant plastic insulated ice chests that he and Sosinski filled before leaving the dock in Montauk harbor seven hours earlier. The coolers, full, weighed about 200 pounds, and the only way for Aldridge to move them alone was to snag a box hook onto the plastic handle of the bottom one, brace his legs, lean back and pull with all his might.

title: Photographing Hiroshima, Fukushima and Everything in Between
description: Kikujiro Fukushimas life in photography took off when he promised to avenge the Hiroshima bombing. It was 1952, and Mr. Fukushima  a watchmaker, volunteer social worker and photographer  met Sugimatsu Nakamura, a 43-year-old fisherman, who was gravely ill from the atomic bombs effects.

title: Portraits of a Rust Belt Mill Town
description: Zoe Strauss loves monumental undertakings. She embarked on her first photographic project, Under I-95  spanning a decade and encompassing literally everything  without knowing anything about making pictures. Her new project, Homesteading, is similarly all-encompassing, tracing the history and socioeconomic topography of Homestead, Pa., the site of a fabled Carnegie-owned steel mill that closed in 1986.

title: What Hobbies Have Been Passed Down in Your Family?
description: As the holiday break comes to a close, think about how you spent your time. Did you see a movie, attend a sports event, take a hike or enjoy other favorite activities? Where, when and with whom did you first do those things? What about now? What role did family members play in shaping the hobbies and pursuits that are today a big part of your life?

title: For Messi, the Best Medicine Is Time
description: Welcome back, Lionel Messi, when you are good and ready.

title: New York Today: Big Snowstorm
description: Updated 12:20 p.m.

title: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
description: Updated, 10:01 a.m. The red-and-white Chinese helicopter with dual rotors hovered over the ice, then settled gently on a flat patch at one of the earths southernmost points. At least seven men in puffy orange jackets clambered out and onto the Antarctic polar cap.

title: Times Minute | Milestone for Obamacare
description: On the Minute, the impact of the Affordable Care Act on patients, physicians and the political landscape.

title: Times Minute | Milestone for Obamacare
description: In the Video

title: Musharraf Is Hospitalized, Delaying His Day in Court
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The former Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf was taken to a military hospital on Thursday over concerns about an unexplained heart condition, Pakistani officials said, derailing for a third time a scheduled court hearing in treason proceedings against him.

title: Daily Report: Two Views on the E-Book Reading Experience
description: As e-books gain in popularity  and as many of us download new e-books on our shiny, new tablets  two authors consider whether reading through technology affects the experience of reading.

title: Delhi Grocers Recall 50 Years of Changing Indian Tastes
description: These days, its easy to find once-exotic foods like spaghetti and Parmesan cheese at grocery stores in India. For that, food lovers can thank the proprietors of Steakhouse in central Delhi, one of the first stores that catered to a certain aesthetic of consumerism in India, where an aspiring and growing middle class sought the opportunity to partake in a slice of Western culture.

title: Body of Former Rwandan Spymaster Is Found in Johannesburg Hotel
description: JOHANNESBURG  The South African police said on Thursday that they had opened a murder investigation into the death of an exiled former spy chief from Rwanda, who was found dead in a hotel room with signs of possible strangulation.

title: Fiat Gaining Full Ownership of Chrysler
description: The Italian carmaker Fiat said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to take full ownership of Chrysler, the smallest of the three American automakers, in a $4.35 billion deal with the United Automobile Workers retiree health care fund. The deal to buy out the trusts 41 percent stake, expected to close on Jan. 20, would make Fiat the worlds seventh-largest automaker, Jaclyn Trop reports in The New York Times.

title: Shanti Atkins, on the 30-Second Approach to Decision-Making
description: This interview with Shanti Atkins, president and chief strategy officer of Navex Global, which handles ethics and compliance issues, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Life Goes On, at Long Last
description: NEWBURY, England  We have raged against fate and come through our stages of grief. We have accepted that no matter how much we miss him  his limpid blue eyes, his good sense in marrying Lady Mary after his tiresome fiance finally succumbed to the flu  Matthew Crawley is never coming back. He is dead, having been hit by a truck while driving inattentively in the waning moments of last season on Downton Abbey.

title: Repsol Completes Sale of Natural Gas Assets to Shell
description: LONDON  The energy company Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it had completed its $5.4 billion acquisition of Repsols liquefied natural gas business outside North America, a deal originally announced last February.

title: Obama's Golfing Style
description: The president plays a slow and methodical game of golf, taking multiple practice swings and spending up to six hours on the course.

title: A Smile Defuses Subway Wrath
description: Dear Diary:

title: Tribalism, Biology, and Macroeconomics
description: Im a bit late to this party, but Pew has a new report about changing views on evolution. The big takeaway is that a plurality of self-identified Republicans now believe that no evolution whatsoever has taken place since the day of creation  let alone that evolution is driven by natural selection. The move is big: an 11-point decline since 2009.

title: App Smart: Resolutions
description: A selection of great apps to help you keep your new year's resolutions.

title: Jehane Noujaim on Filming History as It Happens
description: The Egyptian-American director Jehane Noujaim had already made several prize-winning documentaries about Egypt when massive protests against the dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak erupted in Cairo in January 2011. She knew she had to remain there to chronicle the uprising, and spent the next two and a half years filming The Square, which has won awards at festivals from Sundance to Dubai and has been shortlisted for the Oscar for best documentary feature.

title: A Winter Weekend in the North Fork
description: Its free to watch the sun set over the wetlands that fringe the causeway connecting East Marion and Orient, near the eastern tip of Long Islands North Fork. If the weather has been dry enough in this wine country just across the bay from the Hamptons, theres a good perch on the marshy land near Latham Farms, by a little cabin on stilts known locally as the crab shack. The wine is also free, if your friend Jeanny Pak happens to have brought along a bottle of malbec and some plastic cups without telling you.

title: Why Walk?
description: The Old Ways: A Journey on Foot by Robert Macfarlane caps off a trilogy of books that examine the subtle links between landscape, history and the imagination. Having already ventured into wilds, high and low, this third book focuses on the ancient routes and countless communal pathways that mark the world, connecting people to places, one another and the landscapes they inhabit.

title: Image of the Day: January 2
Disinformation on Inequality
description: Miles Kimball catches Bret Stephens pulling a fast one on Wall Street Journal readers  but its much worse than Kimball says.

title: Deadly Bombing in Beirut Suburb, a Hezbollah Stronghold, Raises Tensions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The second deadly car bomb to strike the Beirut area in less than a week exploded on Thursday in a southern suburb of residential apartment buildings that is home to top Hezbollah offices and heavily populated with the groups supporters.

title: Father Requests Forgiveness for Teenage Shooter Who Killed Daughter
description: The father of Claire Davis, the 17-year-old Colorado girl who was shot and killed by a fellow student at Arapahoe High School last month, asked people during a New Years Day memorial service to honor his daughter by forgiving the gunman and showing empathy and compassion to troubled individuals.

title: In Our Pages: January 3
description: 1914: Aeroplane Line Inaugurated

title: Avoiding the Midwinter Back to School Slump
description: Its back-to-school time again. No, not the exciting September return, with all its newness and promise, but the other one, the January return. The one that arrives not with a bang but a whimper.

title: Missing a Cancer Diagnosis
description: Stories of misdiagnoses circulate throughout the testimonies of people contending with all sorts of cancers. Such errors, made by patients as well as doctors, bring in their wake a sense of betrayal, self-recrimination and anger. Should we accept them as inevitable?

title: Poetry Pairing | Ode
description: The first Poetry Pairing of 2014 features Ode, a poem written by Arthur OShaughnessy in the mid-1800s, and the article The Revolution Will Have Live Music by Colin Moynihan.

title: A Kings Counselor, Whittled to Size
description: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England  When Hilary Mantel was writing Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, her best-selling novels about the court of Henry VIII, she was so scrupulous about accuracy that she created a card catalog of dates and events to ensure that her characters were never out of joint with the past. But when the Royal Shakespeare Company began cutting her 500-page books into two-and-a-half-hour plays, Ms. Mantel had to act as the history police, as she put it.

title: New York Times to Unveil Redesigned Website Next Week
description: The New York Times said on Thursday that it would launch its redesigned website on Jan. 8.

title: Video of Second Bombing in Beirut in Less Than a Week
description: As my colleague Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, a large explosion hit the southern suburbs of Beirut on Thursday in an area populated by supporters of Hezbollah. It appeared to be the latest in a spree of bombings over Hezbollahs support for the government of neighboring Syria in that countrys civil war.

title: Concern Over an Increasingly Seen Gesture Grows in France
description: PARIS  No one seems to know just what is meant by the quenelle, the vaguely menacing hand gesture invented and popularized by a French comedian widely criticized as anti-Semitic, but it is clearly nothing very nice, and it appears to be spreading.

title: Trying to Sing Their Way to the Oscars
description: The singers of 20 Feet From Stardom took to the stage of the Rose Bowl on Wednesday to perform a four-voiced rendition of the national anthem. It was part of a campaign by Radius, the division of the Weinstein Company that distributed that documentary about backup singers, to inject some more verve into the movies chances with Academy members.

title: Michael Counts to Join 3-Legged Dog Theater Company
description: Michael Counts, a director and visual artist known for his imaginative multimedia opera and theater productions, is joining the avant-garde theater company 3-Legged Dog as creative director of the 3LD Special Projects Group. The company, which specializes in immersive productions and installations that combine live performance and video, announced the appointment on Thursday.

title: Times Minute | A Pair of Rescues
description: Also on the Minute, married fashion photographers redefine themselves as a lifestyle brand and Capitol Hill in 2014.

title: Times Minute | A Pair of Rescues
description: In the Video

title: The Waves From Up On High
description: Shots taken using the Phantom 2 Vision Photo Drone from DJI.

title: Kerry Quietly Makes Priority of Climate Pact
description: WASHINGTON  As a young naval officer in Vietnam, John Kerry commanded a Swift boat up the dangerous rivers of the Mekong Delta. But when he returned there last month as secretary of state for the first time since 1969, he spoke not of past firefights but of climate change.

title: Art and Life on the Border
description: Artists explore gang violence and the politics of immigration on the Mexican border.

title: A Vale of Terror, Transcended
description: MATAMOROS, Mexico  The artist Patricia Ruiz-Bayn recently met with three migrants in a shelter in this ravaged border city and invited them to take part in one of her performance works. The piece, 70+2..., commemorated an act of extreme brutality that continues to traumatize the region: a 2010 massacre of 72 migrants in nearby San Fernando that the Mexican authorities say was carried out by the Zetas criminal gang.

title: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
description: BAGHDAD  Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda threatened Thursday to seize control of Falluja and Ramadi, two of the most important cities in Iraq, setting fire to police stations, freeing prisoners from jail and occupying mosques, as the government rushed troop reinforcements to the areas.

title: Distracted Drivers and New Drivers a Perilous Mix
description: An inexperienced driver who reaches for a cellphone increases the risk for a crash by more than 700 percent, a new study found.

title: Blast Inquiry in Prague Finds Weapons
description: BERLIN  Officials investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic on Wednesday at his residence in Prague found illegal weapons in a search of the compound, the Prague police chief said Thursday.

title: Russell Banks: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of A Permanent Member of the Family steers clear of any book described as fantasy, which to me says, Dont worry, Reader, Death will be absent here.

title: Joseph Lieberman Joins Private Equity Firm
description: Over lunch in Manhattan several months ago, Brendan Carroll, a partner and co-founder of the private equity firm Victory Park Capital, had a proposition for his former boss, Joseph I. Lieberman, the former senator from Connecticut and onetime vice-presidential candidate: Would Mr. Lieberman be interested in joining his firm?

title: Chrysler Deal Puts Fiat Chief in the Fast Lane
description: Sergio Marchionne could not have wished for a better start to 2014.

title: Bratton Takes Helm of Police Force He Pledged to Change
description: Minutes after the bagpipes faded and he took the oath of office on Thursday, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton signaled that he intended to shift the nations largest police department away from an aggressive style of patrolling New York City that had alienated many minority residents.

title: Leonardo DiCaprio Explains Wolf of Wall Street
description: Leonardo DiCaprio has been on a charm offensive, or maybe defensive, explaining to many awards-watchers why the brutally divided reaction to The Wolf of Wall Street has been all wrong, or at least slightly premature.

title: Castoffs Become Keepers as the Suns Defy Expectations
description: PHOENIX  This is how Phoenix is eclipsing expectations: with a 3-point shooter who once won an N.B.A. dunk contest, a gaptoothed defender who is a former Israeli Super League most valuable player, a center who has recorded as many blocked shots this season as he had minutes in 2012-13, and a two-headed monster of a backcourt.

title: The Gun Report: January 2, 2014
description: Today we return from our holiday break. Here are some notable shootings that occurred while we were gone:

title: Bodyguard of Zombies, Counterattack by Cockroaches
description: The bit about the WSJs continuing denialism on rising inequality brings to mind a point I think Ive made before, but which seems especially appropriate for recent debates. It is this: Todays right wing never gives up on a politically convenient argument, no matter how thoroughly it may have been refuted by analysis and evidence. It may downplay that argument for a while  though often even that doesnt happen  but it always comes back.

title: In North Carolina, an Earl Scruggs Museum
description: The bluegrass legend Earl Scruggs, whose three-finger banjo-picking technique became known as Scruggs style, is celebrated at a new museum near his childhood home of Flint Hill, N.C., in the foothills of the Blue Ridge mountains. The Earl Scruggs Center, in the restored 1907 Cleveland County courthouse in downtown Shelby, covers the life, time and community of the musical innovator, who died in 2012 at the age of 88.

title: Newark Recalls Its Lustrous Metals Past
description: NEWARK  Artisans specializing in precious metals largely left this city decades ago, and their buildings have been razed, renovated beyond recognition or converted into apartment complexes with names like Tiffany Manor.

title: Probabilities in Wild-Card Round: Close-Up on Chiefs-Colts
description: When the Colts host the Chiefs on Saturday in the first of this weekends four wild-card games, each team will feel as if it is looking into the mirror. The two teams are nearly statistically identical and tend to play disciplined, low-risk, ball-control football while letting their opponents make mistakes.

title: Producers Pick Their Top 10
description: The Producers Guild of America has unveiled nominees for its top prize, the Darryl F. Zanuck Award. Its a list filled with much-discussed titles:

title: Bruno Mars Tops Illegal Download Chart
description: It is a dubious distinction, as chart listings go, and no doubt an infuriating one: Bruno Mars was the musician whose work was illegally downloaded the most in 2013, according to a study that was prepared by Musicmetric. The company, based in London, analyzes consumer behavior, and its report has been published in Billboard.

title: Battle for Survival May Yield the Rain Forests Diversity
description: The diversity of a tropical rain forest can be hard to fathom for people who have not seen one. Three acres of jungle may be home to more than 650 species of trees  more species than grow in the entire continental United States and Canada combined.

title: Weeks in the Making, an Editorial on Snowden May Go Beyond What Is Realistic
description: Most newspaper editorials dont generate a great deal of heat. Even fewer can be considered newsworthy.

title: Allowed to Join the Bar, but Not to Take a Job
description: LOS ANGELES  As a teenager in Northern California, Sergio Garcia worked in the almond fields and in a grocery store, earning his way through college and then law school. He passed the California bar exam on his first try, something just half of all candidates do.

title: Diving Into the Wreck
description: Watching a talented writer take a risk is one of the pleasures of devoted reading, and On Such a Full Sea provides all that and more. Its a wonderful addition not only to Chang-rae Lees body of work but to the ranks of serious writers venturing into the realm of dystopian fantasy. Colson Whitehead, Cormac McCarthy and Margaret Atwood (in her recently concluded MaddAddam trilogy) have all tackled this genre. Doris Lessings Mara and Dann is a classic, as is Anthony Burgesss Clockwork Orange. Further back in time, one has only to think of Orwell, Huxley and Wells, even Jack London and Mary Shelley. As the author of such carefully realist fiction as Native Speaker and A Gesture Life, Lee has always been preoccupied by the themes of hope and betrayal, by the tensions that arise in small lives in the midst of great social change. His marvelous new book, which imagines a future after the breakdown of our own society, takes on those concerns with his customary mastery of quiet detail  and a touch of the fantastic.

title: Mr. Shteyngarts Planet
description: Early in his hilarious and moving memoir, Gary Shteyngart reveals that his mothers post-collegiate nickname for him is Little Failure, which would seem more insulting if his father didnt already call him Snotty. In this Russian Jewish family  the Shteyngarts moved from Leningrad to Queens in 1979, when Gary was 7  barbed jokes, or shutki, are tokens of love: weird, hostile tokens, but tokens nonetheless. The shutki continue to fly in Shteyngarts direction even after  or maybe especially after  he becomes a successful novelist (The Russian Debutantes Handbook, Absurdistan, Super Sad True Love Story). Treating his parents to dinner at the revolving restaurant atop the Marriott Marquis to celebrate his mothers birthday, Shteyngart is a sitting duck as his father fires off this one: I read on the Russian Internet that you and your novels will soon be forgotten. While that may not sound exactly like a joke, its riotous compared with what he tells his son at another dinner: I burn with a black envy toward you. I should have been an artist as well.

title: A Girl Named Ruby
description: Start with the voice, which seems to have been around since the world began: lush, weary, tender, worldly, skeptical, ranging nimbly between hard and soft. It could be metallic, mannish and brittle or gentle as a down pillow, sometimes within the same film, as befits an actress who was at ease in every genre, from womans melodrama to the western, with noir and screwball comedy in between. Though film buffs have treasured her for years, Barbara Stanwyck has burned less brightly among general moviegoers for whom a higher voltage is synonymous with stardom.

title: Emergency Visits Seen Increasing With Health Law
description: Supporters of President Obamas health care law had predicted that expanding insurance coverage for the poor would reduce costly emergency room visits because people would go to primary care doctors instead. But a rigorous new experiment in Oregon has raised questions about that assumption, finding that newly insured people actually went to the emergency room a good deal more often.

title: Lawyer Is Fined for Revealing Rowling as Author of Detective Novel
description: Chris Gossage, the lawyer whose indiscreet chatter led to the public unmasking of J. K. Rowling as the author of The Cuckoos Calling  the detective novel that she published under the pseudonym Robert Galbraith  has been fined 1,000 (about $1,645) by the Solicitors Regulation Authority for breaking the authoritys client confidentiality rules. Mr. Gossage, a partner at Russells Solicitors, also received a written rebuke. The ruling was issued by the authority on Nov. 26, but was not made public until this week.

title: Letters: Norman Rockwell, New Yorker
description: A Larger Understanding

title: The Getting Was Good
description: The very day I turned 66, 177 of you wished me well on a decision to take the advice Id been giving others: To leave a house I loved as one loves something animate, not merely a construction of clapboard and stone, before the inevitable crisis that would make it too hard to live there and also too hard to leave under my own steam.

title: New Director Named for Newark Museum
description: Steven Kern has been appointed director and chief executive officer of the Newark Museum, the museum announced Thursday. Mr. Kern, who is currently the executive director of the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse, will take up his new position in February. He succeeds Mary Sue Sweeney Price, who retired in May.

title: A Plea for Patience as Plows Fan Out Across the City
description: A menacing storm that had charted a relentless course across the Midwest churned into the New York region on Thursday evening, delivering an overnight barrage of heavy snow and high winds.

title: Alicia Keys Leaves Job With BlackBerry
description: While grappling with a $4.4 billion loss in its last quarter, the smartphone maker BlackBerry has fired several senior executives, including its chief executive, and is in the midst of laying off about 40 percent on its employees. On Thursday, the musician Alicia Keys also left the company, where she had been global creative director.

title: Ugandas Antigay Bill vs. a Documentary on Homophobia
description: The Square and Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer are not the only Oscar-shortlisted international documentaries that have run into trouble at home. God Loves Uganda, about the role of American evangelicals in stirring up homophobia in that African country, has suffered an arguably even more difficult fate. On Dec. 20, the nations Parliament passed a strict antigay bill, which mandates life in jail for engaging in aggravated homosexuality, as well prohibiting any form of same-sex contact. Though it has yet to be signed into law by the countrys president, it also carries harsh penalties for anyone promoting or even discussing gay material like that covered by the film, and demands that Ugandans inform on gay people or risk jail themselves.

title: Beyonc Closes Out Year on a High Note
description: At the end of the year the music charts belonged to Beyonc.

title: Gone Guy (Personal)
description: Just FYI: No columns tomorrow or Monday. Taking a break from deadlines.

title: Clip: 'Kill Your Darlings'
description: A scene from John Krokidas's film.

title: A Snow Day Coming? Dantes Friends Want to Know
description: Being the son of a mayor unquestionably has its advantages. Dante de Blasio will have four years or more to learn what those advantages are, and to decide how he will play them. But it has taken just one day  the one frozen and overcast day since his fathers inauguration on  to experience the drawbacks.

title: Wheelies: The Moose-Proof Jeep Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A Seasons Worth of Cheap Thrills
description: By its very nature, the vocation of the Weekend Miser entails a certain myopia, a laserlike focus on discrete three-day periods. To kick off the new year, lets switch things up, shall we, with a more seasonal view of free or nearly free things to do in New York City: a Winter Miser, if you will.

title: Lauren Luloff: Recent Paintings
description: Show Room Gowanus

title: Edward Steichen in the 1920s and 1930s: A Recent Acquisition
description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: Aaron Curry: Melt to Earth
description: Josie Robertson Plaza,

title: Helmut Federle: The Ferner Paintings
description: Peter Blum

title: Raqib Shaw: Paradise Lost
description: Pace Gallery

title: Eureka: William Wegman Photographs 1970-1975
description: Craig F. Starr Gallery

title: Ebullience Over 2013 I.P.O. Market Spills Into New Year
description: The next 12 months may not prove as rich for initial public offerings as the last year. But to Wall Street bankers, 2014 still promises an abundance of opportunity.

title: Clip: 'Before Midnight'
description: A scene from Richard Linklater's film.

title: Regulator Plans to Increase Visibility of Its BrokerCheck Website
description: Financial industry regulators are hoping to enact a rule this year that would make it easier for investors to find out if a broker pushing to sell them a stock, bond or other investment product has a clean record.

title: A Puppy Predicament
description: I am in my late 20s and have devoted my adult life to saving homeless animals. I work at a shelter, volunteer and even started a rescue organization. I strive to prevent animals from being euthanized. One of my best friends just bought a puppy from a breeder. She has no allergies or any reason not to have adopted a dog. I feel betrayed and angry, and find it tone-deaf when she sends me pictures of the puppy. She knows I weep over animals I cant save. Am I right to think were not compatible as friends?

title: Clip: 'Enough Said'
description: A scene from Nicole Holofcener's film.

title: Shingles Can Increase Heart Attack Risk
description: A British study has found that having shingles can increase the risk for heart attacks.

title: FireEye Computer Security Firm Acquires Mandiant
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a deal that may have broad repercussions for companies and governments fending off sophisticated hackers and state-sponsored digital attacks, FireEye, a provider of security software, has acquired Mandiant, a company known for emergency responses to computer network breaches.

title: Clip: 'Her'
description: A scene from Spike Jonzes film.

title: Cooking for the Cold
description: Weather is a terrific source of cooking inspiration. Stock up before the snow accumulates and put something warm and comforting on the stove.

title: A Trans-Atlantic Romance Continues
description: The Sopranos was once the quintessential American television show. Now, its Downton Abbey.

title: What Should Happen to Edward Snowden?
description: Theres not much appreciation for nuance in the public discussion about Edward Snowden.Our editorial today tried to avoid the usual hero/traitor dichotomy of the cable news debates, saying that the public service value of his leaks outweighed the crime he committed by revealing to journalists the abuses of the National Security Agency. We called for some form of reduced punishment  a plea bargain or clemency  though we didnt say he should be given a presidential pardon or a medal.

title: New Ad Campaign Criticizes Senators for Support of Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  A conservative advocacy group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers said Thursday it will spend $2.5 million on television advertisements targeting three vulnerable Democratic senators who supported President Obamas health care law.

title: The Hard-Won Lessons of the Solitary Years
description: When my then-boyfriend Mark lost the lease on his Brooklyn apartment, moving in together made good sense. We were in our 40s, both battle-scarred from decades of romantic unhappiness, and had finally found the relationship we had longed for our entire lives. So even though the timing was bad (we had been dating for only six months), we knew where this was headed. Why wait?

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, Central African Republic, South Sudan and Antarctica.

title: Theres Room for One More Aboard the R.V.
description: Promises, promises. While color palettes and canaps are deliberations made months before a wedding, a couples vows can sometimes sound like a tired recitation of have, hold, sickness and health.

title: De Blasio Defends His Inaugurations Sometimes Harsh Tone Toward Bloomberg
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Thursday that he had no qualms about the harsh words directed at his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, at Mr. de Blasios inauguration ceremony.

title: Smoked Barbecue, for Every Appetite
description: Barbecue is a personal thing, and every style has its partisans, but Tennessee Jeds in Wantagh has all the bases covered. For Texans who think barbecue means beef, the menu has brisket, beef ribs and smoked beef sausages. Those who go for the more typical pork barbecue will find Memphis baby back ribs, St. Louis-style ribs and Carolina pulled pork. Every table has four bottles of house-made sauce: regular, sweet, hot and mustard. The classic North Carolina vinegar-based sauce was dropped because of a lack of popularity, according to Julie Gonzalez, the co-owner with her husband, Francisco, speaking on the phone after my visits.

title: Karzai Is Warned Over Release of Detainees
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American senators visiting Kabul on Thursday intensified pressure on President Hamid Karzai to sign a long-term security deal with the United States. And responding to a new crisis between the allies this week, they warned the Afghan government away from plans to summarily release dozens of detainees accused of attacking American forces.

title: Phantasms of an Analog Twilight
description: If youre of a certain age and reading this, you probably grew up watching educational filmstrips and going to the movies, where you would witness the occasional projector malfunction or celluloid meltdown. The rise of digital technology and the waning of analog film  which wasnt even called analog until digital came along  made these problems largely disappear. But at the very onset of films decline, artists embraced it as a medium  particularly 16-millimeter film.

title: Sanity of Psychologists Killer Is Again at Issue
description: The mental health of a man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office was once again in question on Thursday, just as a judge in Manhattan was about to set a date for a new trial because the first one ended in a hung jury.

title: Should Schools Cancel Based on the Forecast?
description: Im betting on school being canceled Friday. Betting on it so hard that Im not making lunches, Im not setting alarms, and Ive already made promises and plans for a snow day.

title: The Silent Totems of a Restless Quest
description: There is always more to be learned about the hard-won, groundbreaking and singular art of the American sculptor David Smith (1906-65). The latest schooling is The Forgings, a revelatory exhibition of 10 narrow, adamantly vertical sculptures from 1955 that are on view at the Gagosian Gallery.

title: Myanmars Leader Backs Change to Constitution
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars president said Thursday that he backed changing the countrys Constitution to allow any citizen to become president, apparently a reference to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate whose political ambitions have been thwarted for decades by the military.

title: Eons Before the Yoga Mat Became Trendy
description: WASHINGTON  Pain is a problem. So is pleasure, which causes pain  discontent, confusion, depression  when it ends, as it always does. Escape from this cycle has been a goal of spiritual disciplines universally. And one of those disciplines is the subject of an immensely pleasurable exhibition called Yoga: The Art of Transformation at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery here.

title: Egyptian Puppet Called Terrorist Mouthpiece
description: Egypts crackdown on support for the Muslim Brotherhood turned surreal this week as prosecutors agreed to investigate the allegation that a puppet that babbles nonsensically in an advertisement for a multinational phone company was in fact sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists.

title: Putting His Stamp on England
description: William Kent: Designing Georgian Britain, at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery, should thrill Anglophiles as least as much as the return of Downton Abbey. Brimming with art and antiques from some of Britains most storied estates, it surveys an important but underappreciated 18th-century artist, adviser, designer, illustrator and architect of buildings and landscapes through his work over four decades (1709-48). And it brings to life the social and political machinations of the Georgian era, most of all the new elites cementing of power and status through Italianate country houses filled with Grand Tour souvenirs. Britain fancied itself a New Rome, and Kent aspired to be its Raphael Secundus, or second Raphael.

title: Heritage in All Its Rich Hues
description: BRIGHT colors pop against the white walls at Renaissance Fine Art, a gallery in Harlem. M. Tony Peraltas Reconnected exhibition is on display, and the Caribbean seems to wash through the space.

title: Turning an Easy Mark Into a Street Fighter
description: MOVE slowly, the instructor cautioned as students of the Krav Maga Institute, grouped in twos, moved menacingly toward each other. We dont want to hit our partner.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: nail polish dangers, distracted driving, and vitamin E for Alzheimers disease. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: With the New Year, New Consumer Protections on Mortgages
description: NEW rules for consumers seeking home loans are arriving in the new year. And if you already have a mortgage, new borrower protections take effect for you, too.

title: Tweaking Hot Chocolate With Wild Flavors
description: It may not sound like the best thing that could ever happen to a cup of hot chocolate, but those who know Maricel E. Presilla might be inclined to take her advice when she suggests dunking cheese into the chocolate served at Zafra restaurant in Hoboken.

title: Martha Stewart Living and Macys Settle Dispute and Keep Partnership
description: Macys and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have ended their legal battle over whether J. C. Penney had the right to sell certain Martha Stewart branded housewares.

title: Big Portions, Not-So-Big Checks
description: In an atmosphere that hints at the sumptuous, with crystal chandeliers, linen-draped tables and bottles of wine displayed ornamentally, El Pulpo and Tapas Bar, in Southington, serves well-prepared Spanish cuisine that is, happily, very modest in price.

title: Table for Two (Countries)
description: When the game of table tennis became the focus of diplomatic efforts to defuse Cold War tensions between the United States and China, no detail was too small to warrant careful scrutiny. As Nicholas Griffin demonstrates, in a book filled with well-chosen examples, the Chinese team visiting Colonial Williamsburg in 1972 was comfortable eating apple pie and singing Home on the Range. But Row, Row, Row Your Boat was dicier: the line life is but a dream was politically incompatible with the teachings of Chairman Mao. Thanks to some fancy footwork on the part of a translator, the line quickly turned into life is full of steam.

title: Little Praise for Former Mayor
description: After 12 years in office, former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sat through an hour of subtle attacks on his policies before hearing kind words from former President Bill Clinton at the mayoral inauguration.

title: McSorleys for Food
description: One of the oldest taverns in New York City offers a simple but satisfying menu.

title: Comfort From the Cold Winds
description: Traditionally speaking, you dont go to McSorleys for the food.

title: New Orleans and New York, Onstage
description: The time machine was set on shuffle for Henry Butler with Steven Bernstein and the Hot 9 on Wednesday night at Jazz Standard, where they are performing together through Sunday. Their collaboration is both historically aware and fully prepared to cut loose.

title: A Blender of Genres Squeezes More Juice
description: Before midnight on New Years Eve at Barclays Center, in his first Brooklyn concert since he played in a Long Island garage band, Billy Joel sat at a Steinway grand between two guitarists. He wore a dark suit and tie, sang clearly and evenly, and spoke to the audience by announcing the name of a song, the album it came from, the year it was released. About a third of those songs, going back to his first record from 1971, were not hits, and he hadnt performed some of them much or at all in recent decades. At least for the first hour  before the concert grew looser and more obvious  he seemed consumed by the task of generating new value, and he was formidable, no joke at all.

title: Mob Machinations Crueler Than Pain
description: The men in Takeshi Kitanos latest yakuza drama, Beyond Outrage, are not ones for closure. While professionals in less bloody careers try to move from strength to strength, these mobsters in suits tend to move from outrage to outrage as part of their daily business. In this relentless, insular sequel to Mr. Kitanos 2011 hit, Outrage, actual physical violence is often less shocking than the scheming and betrayal that routinely shake up the traditional hierarchies behind these criminal enterprises.

title: Within This Chapel, Many Gods May Appear
description: When the score of Marc-Antoine Charpentiers La Descente dOrphe aux Enfers was rediscovered in the French National Library, The New York Times reported the news in a brief article in 1930 that ended with an assessment of the works quality: It is, we are told, worthy of the composer.

title: Fiats Challenge Is to Improve Performance in Italy and Asia
description: PARIS  The Fiat boss, Sergio Marchionne, has finally won complete ownership of Chrysler and can begin trying to realize his dream of building a world-class carmaker to compete with the industry leaders Toyota, General Motors and Volkswagen. At the top of the to-do list: Stanch the deterioration in Fiats home market and fix a glaring hole in its Asia business.

title: Harmonic Complexity That Moved Its Maker
description: Even the most gifted composers have been insecure about the merit of their works, with Rachmaninoff among the self-doubting contingent. But he felt confident about his glorious Vespers; after the first performance in 1915, he was so moved he told the singers that he could never imagine having written such a piece, even in his dreams.

title: In Legislature, Swaps of Names but Not Parties
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: Creating Neon Poetry With a Patient Camera
description: Now considered among the very best of the New York School street photographers, and a leading exponent in the artistic use of color film, Saul Leiter came to this acclaim rather late. While much of his most powerful work was made in the 1950s, it wasnt truly rediscovered until nearly a half-century later.

title: CMAX Solar Technology
description: A diagram provided by Ford illustrates its new solar technology.

title: Heating Up From the Inside Out
description: In these frosty months, Westchester diners might keep cozy by following the diets of those who call the icy, rocky terrain of the Himalayas home. When winter stings your cheeks, turn to hot chilies, meat proteins, grains and breads. Go for mouth-tingling curry, vindaloo so spicy that tears come to the eyes and large bowls of searing chicken soup crammed with noodles. Think about stopping into Jewel of Himalaya in Harrison, sister restaurant to the Yorktown Heights original, for dinner or a sampling from the new lunch buffet. The food here is to climb mountains by.

title: When Spidey Flies No More, Will Business?
description: BROADWAY today is an international brand, drawing audiences from around the world for some razzle-dazzle and, ideally, plenty of pre- and post-show spending. But each Broadway theater is also a local business, whose seasonal ebb and flow leaves its mark on the neighborhood.

title: From Ford, a Plug-In That Tracks the Sun
description: If Stonehenge had been built with a visitors parking lot, the spaces might have looked something like what Ford proposes for its C-Max Solar Energi, a plug-in hybrid with a rooftop solar panel.

title: Paying for Foreclosure Delays
description: The long foreclosure timelines in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut may translate into slightly higher borrowing costs for consumers in those states.

description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Near Singapores Concrete, an Oasis of Nature
description: After cycling a half-mile along a soggy clay track that sliced through a corridor of rubber trees, tailed by an electric-crimson-colored dragonfly, arches of bamboo creating a canopy, I emerged by a small, silty lake. A dilapidated jetty reached out into the water, a mint-green fishing boat loosely tied to it; a splintery, whitewashed wooden sign nailed to a sea grape tree announced Cold Drinks.

title: From Chicago to Boston, Winter Storm Creates Havoc for Travelers
description: Updated, Friday, Jan. 3, 4:00 p.m. A winter storm that brought bitter cold, strong winds and two feet of snow to parts of New England overnight snarled air travel across the country Friday and created treacherous road conditions for motorists from Chicago to Boston.

title: Photography on the Move
description: At a glance, The Itinerant Languages of Photography at the Princeton University Art Museum looks like a handsome, if compact, survey of photography from the Spanish and Portuguese diaspora. There are 19th-century Brazilian photographs and modernist classics like Tina Modottis Mexican Workers Parade (1926); masterpieces of Spanish street photography; and works by contemporary artists like Graciela Iturbide and Joan Fontcuberta.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 3-9
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Raising a Pole on the Islands of the People
description: The ocean grew choppy and storm clouds darkened the southern sky as we paddled the final miles toward an abandoned Haida village site at the heart of a wedge-shaped archipelago 175 miles in length, 70 miles off the northwest coast of British Columbia. Until recently, this remote chain of islands was known as the Queen Charlotte Islands, but three years ago, the Haida Nation returned that colonial name to the provincial government, in a ceremony using the same style of bentwood box that once housed the remains of the dead. The place is now Haida Gwaii (pronounced HI-duh GWY)  Islands of the People  both officially and, unquestionably, in spirit.

title: A Fresh Eye on Fall River, Mass.
description: About 50 to 300 visitors a day descend on the Lizzie Borden Bed & Breakfast Museum in Fall River, Mass., a three-story Victorian with dark green shutters and the site of one of Americas most infamous  and most aggressively researched and marketed  murder cases. At times, tourists arrive by the busloads, from all over the world, said the houses co-owner, Lee-Ann Wilber.

title: In Your Seat but on Your Toes
description: TRUE aficionados of inventive theater know exactly where they need to be every January: far Off Broadway. Despite the bitter cold of this post-holiday period, there is an abundance of off-kilter theater in important festivals that have become annual events on the cultural calendar. And each year, it seems, more presenters and organizers are joining the fray.

description: Three Kings Day Celebrations (Monday) In the Bible, the three kings traveled to Bethlehem to bestow gifts on the baby Jesus. In present-day Manhattan, they will visit East Harlem and the Lower East Side for assorted festivities.

description: Edith Whartons corpulent great-aunt Mary Mason Jones served as one of the most memorable inspirations in literary New York: the model for Mrs. Manson Mingott in Whartons novel The Age of Innocence.

description: The New York Times movie critics on "Lone Survivor," "Grudge Match" and "47 Ronin."

title: 21st Century Fox Sells Stake in Chinese TV Company
description: The television, cable and movie conglomerate owned by Rupert Murdoch, 21st Century Fox, said on Thursday that it would sell its 47 percent stake in Star China TV. The move was the latest step the company has taken to reduce its position in China.

title: Farms Arent Going Away, but a Lot of the Little Ones Are
description: SPEARMAN  Inside Mike Skinners house in this town in the northern part of the Texas Panhandle is a cage with finches and parakeets  the only livestock he has left, he says, smiling, now that he has sold the family farm.

title: A Tablet for Children That Comes With Its Own Penguins
description: GLENDALE, Calif.  DreamWorks Animation first captivated children in movie theaters. Then it branched into TV, piping cartoons based on hits like Madagascar and How to Train Your Dragon into homes through outlets like Nickelodeon and Netflix.

title: Bob Grant, a Combative Personality on New York Talk Radio, Dies at 84
description: Bob Grant, the right-wing talk radio host whose testy, confrontational manner made him a dominant voice during the drive-time hours in New York for decades, died on Tuesday in Hillsborough, N.J. He was 84.

title: George Jacobs, Memoirist and Valet for Sinatra, Dies at 86
description: George Jacobs, a former valet whose memoir revealed his longtime employer, Frank Sinatra, to be both a hero and a villain, died on Dec. 28 in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 86.

title: Risky Work in Indonesias Gold Fields
description: A cottage industry uses mercury to refine the metal, with alarming effects on the environment and human health.

title: Small-Scale Gold Mining Pollutes Indonesian Lands
description: CISITU, Indonesia  In the remote mountains of West Java, workers like 15-year-old David Mario Chandra are an integral part of Indonesias gold industry.

title: Mercury Trade Eludes International Controls
description: JAKARTA  Tracking illicit mercury imports into Indonesia is all but impossible, officials say. But data clearly shows that far more is being carried into the country than is officially recorded, even as the United Nations and other groups try to halt its use globally.

title: Walk to Train Essential
description: By the time Gary Kuchta moved to New York two years ago for a new job, he had owned three houses  two in Chicago, his hometown, and one in Los Angeles. I kind of just believe in owning, he said.

title: Micky Lay, a Source for Jerusalem, Dies at 73
description: Micky Lay, a bibulous retired builder who helped Mark Rylance craft his performance in Jez Butterworths hit play about British outcasts, Jerusalem, for which Mr. Rylance won a Tony, died on Friday in the village of Pewsey, Wiltshire, England. He was 73.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Snapchat Breach Exposes Weak Security
description: Updated, 7:25 p.m. |This post now includes Snapchats response to a request for an interview.

title: Tracing Oysters Path From Plentiful to High-Priced
description: If you ingest a medium-size oyster  as many revelers did during the holiday season  you get about 10 calories, 1 gram of protein and the pleasure derived from savoring a luxurious treat. If you take in the oyster exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, you miss out on the calories, the protein and the cost, but you still get to enjoy a treat. Oysters, Pearls of Long Island Sound is a fascinating stew of oyster lore, oyster science, oyster commerce and oyster history  not to mention a bit of oyster porn, in the brief but vivid video of several bivalves in turn spraying clouds of eggs and sperm into the water.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Fired? Speak No Evil
description: I WAS fired the other day. I believe the preferred phrase is terminated, which is how my former employer, Byliner, a digital publishing company and subscription service in San Francisco, put it. I was informed that our burn rate was too high, that we needed to show investors that we were serious about reducing it, and that while my loss of a job was unfortunately going to be a part of that reduction, this had nothing to do with the quality of my work. Soon thereafter, an email arrived from the companys founder and chief executive saying how much he had enjoyed working with me.

title: Events on Long Island for Jan. 5-11
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Since the Time of the Shogun and the Samurai
description: Land of the Rising Sun: Art of Japan, the current exhibition at the David Filderman Gallery of Hofstra University Museum, does not lack for ambition. Its 41 works, all from the museums permanent collection, explore the cultural evolution of Japan from the 16th to the 20th century.

title: Without Jury, Judge Warned That Stop-and-Frisk Ruling Would Be Disputed
description: With the trial over the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk practices just months away, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin expressed concern at the decision by the lawyers who had filed the suit to have her, not a jury, decide the case.

title: Delivering an Opinion Is Tebows New Test
description: When he was introduced to the news media by ESPN as its newest analyst on Tuesday, Tim Tebow suggested through his remarks that he might be the nicest, politest, humblest person ever to hold a microphone.

title: Can Animals Help Limit Concussions?
description: CINCINNATI  THE N.F.L. playoffs start tomorrow. During the regular season, the conversation about traumatic brain injuries in sports among doctors, players, league officials, politicians and parents seemed to gain in volume and intensity with each passing week. New revelations from retired N.F.L. players who announced that they had the progressive neurodegenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., helped fuel these discussions.

title: As the Working Poor Become More Common in Britain, So Does Hunger
description: HULL, England  To her colleagues at the day care center, Charlotte Burton is an independent woman who works full time and manages just fine. They admire her for biking to work at this time of year, when chilly winds blow and the River Hull swells with rainwater, intermittently swallowing parts of this northeastern city.

title: Food Need Grows Among Britains Working Poor
description: In Britain, sluggish growth and rising prices have left a mark: earnings have stagnated while the cost of living has gone up by almost 20 percent.

title: Disrespect to Bloomberg, or Truth to Power?
Houston and Its Strip Clubs Call a Truce
description: HOUSTON  As 2013 wound down, this city appeared to finally free itself from one of its longest-running legal battles.

title: Johnny Orr, Coach Who Turned Iowa State Into Contender, Dies at 86
description: Johnny Orr, who chose more money but far less prestige when he gave up his high-profile role as basketball coach at the University of Michigan to coach lowly Iowa State  and went on to lead the Cyclones to multiple appearances in the N.C.A.A. tournament  died on Tuesday in Des Moines. He was 86.

title: Saving New Jerseys Coast
description: Hurricane Sandy made a direct hit on New Jersey just over a year ago, killing 34 people and devastating much of the states Atlantic coast. Now, communities that want to build sand dunes to provide protection when (not if) another storm hits are being thwarted by landowners who have refused to allow the dunes to be built on their property. Areas with dunes fared better in the storm than those without them.

title: Fearless Fullback Makes Sure Auburn Has Room to Run
description: Auburns Jay Prosch had an inelegant style as a boy and would sometimes forget about the basics, he said, like common sense. He would take any dare from friends in Saraland, Ala., like building the highest tree fort, hurtling over the biggest dirt piles with his bike, or back flipping into any pool of water he could find. He was muscular and unyielding.

title: Hey, Is That a BMW Racing Down the Bobsled Course?
description: THE last time the United States mens team won an Olympic gold medal in the two-man bobsled competition was 1936, when Franklin D. Roosevelt was in the White House and a gallon of gas cost 10 cents.

title: Scoutings Incomplete Evolution
description: The new year brings a positive change in the membership practices of the Boy Scouts of America. In May, delegates attending the Boy Scouts national convention voted to allow openly gay boys to participate in the groups activities. That overdue step toward inclusion went into effect on New Years Day, a welcome  though incomplete  turn for an organization that until quite recently rejected any change in its discriminatory ways.

title: Ezra Klein Is Said to Plan to Leave Washington Post
description: Ezra Klein, an analyst, columnist and television commentator who runs The Washington Posts Wonkblog, is making plans to leave the newspaper after failing to win support for a new website he wanted to create within the company, according to four people with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: When a 2nd-Term President and a Divided Congress Made Magic
description: The modesty of last months federal budget deal, and the difficulty of achieving even that, make Washingtons more ambitious 2014 goals appear out of reach.

title: While Kerry Pushes Peace Talks, Israeli Leader Airs Criticism
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivered a harsh assessment of his Palestinian counterpart and implicitly the prospect of a Middle East peace agreement as Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here on Thursday to intensify his push for a framework accord that would define the principles of a comprehensive treaty.

title: Regulator of Wall Street Loses Its Hard-Charging Chairman
description: Gary Gensler squeezed into a Washington auditorium last month, mingling with the 300 guests at his farewell party and basking in the attention as a whos who of finance recounted his campaign to rein in Wall Street risk-taking.

title: Rewriting the Citys Record on Prisons
description: First to the microphone at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, Harry Belafonte got 60 seconds into his talk before grievously mangling history.

title: No Burden on Religion
description: The Justice Department is expected to file a brief on Friday in opposition to Justice Sonia Sotomayors perplexing decision to issue a temporary injunction against requiring an order of Colorado nuns to fill out paperwork required by the health care reform laws contraception mandate.

title: Mayor de Blasio Looks Forward
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio took charge of New York City on Wednesday with a forceful Inaugural Address and pledged to begin the head-on attack on the inequality crisis as he had promised. He repeated the bullet points from his campaign, but insisted that progressive talking would now give way to progressive governing, without dilution or dithering. We wont wait, Mr. de Blasio said again and again. Well do it now.

title: Snowfall So Far in the Northeast
description: Map showing which areas got the most snow.

title: Weed: Been There. Done That.
description: For a little while in my teenage years, my friends and I smoked marijuana. It was fun. I have some fond memories of us all being silly together. I think those moments of uninhibited frolic deepened our friendships.

title: At Work, de Blasio Finds Full Plate of Headaches
description: In a hectic first full day as New Yorks mayor, Bill de Blasio introduced himself to a wary police force on Thursday, navigated unfamiliar hallways with a skeletal staff and confronted an imminent winter storm that might have rattled even the most experienced municipal manager.

title: Central African Republic: Violence Forces Aid Group to Curtail Work
description: Doctors Without Borders, the international medical charity known for its resilience in some of the worlds most inhospitable crisis zones, said Thursday that it had drastically curtailed operations at an airport encampment in the Central African Republic, where violence has imperiled about 100,000 displaced people taking refuge. The group said in a statement that its clinic at the airport in Bangui, the capital, which had been treating more than 100 wounded people a day, would now treat only the most severe cases with an emergency crew. It was an unusual but not unprecedented retreat for the group, which has remained active in the country throughout a growing political and sectarian crisis, and will continue to work in two hospitals and two other camps in Bangui. Last August the organization completely withdrew from Somalia after having worked there for 22 years, attributing the decision to repeated attacks on its staff.

title: High Above the Water, but Awash in Red Tape
description: It seemed ingenious at the time: Elevate the deck of the existing Bayonne Bridge to accommodate the giant cargo ships that will begin passing through the Panama Canal in 2015 after the project to widen and deepen it is scheduled to be finished. Building a new bridge or tunneling under Kill Van Kull would have been much more expensive and would have required years of regulatory reviews.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 2, 2014
She Once Worked on a Roller Coaster, and Now Her Life Resembles One
description: Sharae Turner did not care much for roller coasters before she took a job at an amusement park in Florida. But since her job required it, she managed to strap herself into one every day for a test run.

title: Chemistry Lab Fire Injures 2 at a Manhattan High School
description: A teachers chemistry experiment exploded during a demonstration at Beacon High School in Manhattan on Thursday, creating a fireball that burned two 10th graders, one severely, according to Fire Department and school officials.

title: Steroids and Sports in India
description: Nearly 500 athletes from India have tested positive for banned substances since 2009, when the countrys National Anti-Doping Agency became fully functional.

title: Banned Substances Claim an Outsize Role in Athletics in India
description: PATIALA, India  The crumbling Old Moti Bagh Palace houses the National Institute of Sports, the training ground for Indias best athletes. One sweltering spring afternoon, the sprinter Ashwini Akkunji ran laps around its sprawling grounds, past broken fountains, a murky pool and monkeys that occasionally charged people with bared teeth. She and the palace, once home to Patialas royal family, had seen better days.

title: Concern Over Safety Grows as More Oil Rides the Rails
description: WASHINGTON  Safety officials have worried for years about hazardous materials carried on trains, but concern has intensified recently as a drilling surge in remote oil fields has generated heavy traffic on North Americas aging rail-freight networks.

title: In a State of Nirvana
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Just gorgeous, not really a misstep in the entire grid. This is what a Friday puzzle should be. The entries in todays puzzle are so nice that you just want to say them out loud as you fill them in.

title: Anthony Hits Roof, Then Hits Court for Knicks
description: SAN ANTONIO  Seconds after Carmelo Anthony capped Thursday mornings shootaround at AT&T Center by plopping down on a courtside folding chair, a trainer rushed over to wrap ice packs around both his knees. His knees were not really the problem, though.

title: Without Lopez, Nets Redefine Strategy and Go With a Smaller Lineup
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The Nets have faced an identity crisis since last summers expensive roster overhaul.

title: Hezbollah Moving Long-Range Missiles From Syria to Lebanon, an Analyst Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Amid the chaos of Syrias civil war, Hezbollah has been moving long-range missiles to Lebanon from bases where it had stored them inside Syria, including long-range Scud D missiles that can strike deep into Israel, according to an Israeli national security analyst.

title: Coach of Giants Offense Retires After Dreary Year
description: Three days after the Giants co-owner John Mara called the teams offense broken, the longtime offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride announced his retirement Thursday.

title: What You Need to Know About the Snowstorm
description: The National Weather Service estimates that up to nine inches of snow will accumulate in the city, New Jersey and Westchester County by Friday. The mix of wind and snowfall will create limited visibility throughout the region, and motorists can expect slippery, snow-covered roads. Winds of up to 35 miles an hour are expected to create a windchill as cold as 20 degrees below zero. Residents were urged to stay indoors, but those who must go outside were advised to dress warmly, carry emergency supplies and use public transportation. The Red Cross has advice for staying safe in such weather.

title: Support for Gay Rights Led to Harassment, Ex-Viking Says
description: The free-agent punter Chris Kluwe, whose outspoken views on gay rights and other issues of equality have drawn widespread attention, accused a Minnesota Vikings assistant of harassment and homophobia in a first-person account published Thursday on the website Deadspin.

title: U.S. Military Ship Readied for Mission to Destroy Syrias Chemical Weapons
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va.  Months after diplomats declared that they had come up with a plan and a timetable to dispose of Syrias lethal chemical weapons  and with the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to the weapons inspectors  the centerpiece of the mission, a workhorse American military ship that will ferry the weapons to sea for destruction, remains here in port, waiting like a sad bride for her groom.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 3, 2014
description: Theres a lot to celebrate. I can open my own law firm and thats exactly what I intend to do. Theres no law in this country restricting entrepreneurs.

description: ORANGE BOWL PREVIEW

description: Brandon Jacobs, a fourth-round draft pick of the Giants nine years ago who became one of the franchises most charismatic running backs, announced his retirement on his Twitter account late Thursday.

description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

description: aria \r-e-\ noun

title: Attack on Chinese Consulate Puts U.S. on Defensive
description: A New Years Day arson attack at the Chinese Consulate in San Francisco continued to reverberate on Friday, with Chinese state media faulting both United States security efforts and American attitudes toward China, while United States officials vowed to apprehend anyone connected with the attack.

title: Manhattan Real Estate Market Surging at Years End
description: The Manhattan real estate market continued a yearlong trend, ending the final quarter of 2013 with a scarcity of listings and surging sales, while prices remained relatively flat.

title: Key Plays by Shumpert Help Knicks Shock Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO  Iman Shumpert recognized that everyone was focused on Carmelo Anthony. It had never been more apparent than when Anthony took a baseline jumper late in the fourth quarter Thursday night at AT&T Center, and when the ball caromed off the back of the rim, Shumpert saw his opening.

title: Johnson Beats Buzzer, and Nets Pull Off a Stunner
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Paul Pierce was in his late-game flow. Deron Williams showed a swagger he had lacked all season. But when the game was on the line Thursday night, it was clear who would get the ball.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10:15 P.M. (TCM) A BEAUTIFUL MIND (2001) Russell Crowe, above, in a role for which he received an Oscar nomination, portrays John Forbes Nash Jr., the gifted mathematician who battled schizophrenia for decades before going on to win the Nobel in economic science. Jennifer Connelly won for best supporting actress as Alicia Larde, the M.I.T. student who became Nashs wife. And Ed Harris plays Nashs contact for a government project. The paradox of this film (which won for best picture), directed by Ron Howard from a script by Akiva Goldsman, and the emotions it elicits is that the story is almost entirely counterfeit, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Still, Mr. Crowe, with his superhuman powers of concentration, shows us a man who dwells almost entirely in an inner world, and he dramatizes that inwardness as if nobody were watching. In the end, Mr. Scott added, the governing dynamic of A Beautiful Mind is sentimentality of a familiar and not altogether unwelcome kind. The movie can  indeed, should  be intellectually rejected, but you cant quite banish it from your mind.

title: A Hunting Community in Nagaland Takes Steps Toward Conservation
description: DOYANG, Nagaland  In the fall of 2012, the people in this northeastern state, which is known for its hunting traditions, killed about 150,000 federally protected Amur falcons, the highest number recorded in India, as the birds made their annual flight from Siberia at the end of October to stay in the Doyang reservoir for the month of November on their way to southern Africa.

title: Workers Face Police Gunfire Amid Unrest in Cambodia
description: HONG KONG  Military police officers on Friday fired on protesters demanding higher wages for Cambodian garment workers, killing at least three people, officials said, as protests against the decades-old rule of Prime Minister Hun Sen entered a volatile new phase.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Rescue on the Ice
description: In Helicopter Rescues 52 Passengers From Ship Trapped in Antarctic Ice, Alan Cowell and Edward Wong write about an operation displaying unusual international harmony in one of the worlds most remote and inhospitable places.

title: U.S. Orders Evacuation of Staff Members From Embassy in South Sudan
description: The United States on Friday ordered a further reduction of American Embassy staff members in strife-torn South Sudan and said it would cease to provide consular services for its citizens as of Saturday, apparently reflecting a somber assessment of the countrys prospects even as its warring factions were reported to have opened preliminary indirect talks in neighboring Ethiopia.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Jan. 3, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Otto Schenks Opera Stagings Still at Home in Vienna
description: VIENNA  While operagoers in New York spent New Years Eve coming to grips with Jeremy Samss new staging of Johann Strausss Die Fledermaus at the Metropolitan Opera, which replaced a 1986 production by Otto Schenk, operagoers here still seemed to be enjoying an even older Schenk staging of the work, which dates from 1979, at the Vienna State Opera.

title: What Words or Phrases Should Be Retired in 2014?
description: What words or phrases were overused in 2013? What expressions, catchphrases, neologisms or slang do you hope never to hear again in 2014? Why?

title: Q. & A.: David Der-wei Wang on C.T. Hsia, Chinese Literary Critic
description: C.T. Hsia, the Chinese literary critic who died in New York on Dec. 29, aged 92, had a legendary career as a true cosmopolitan, shrewd, critical and brilliant, says David Der-wei Wang, the Edward C. Henderson Professor of Chinese Literature at Harvard University, in an interview on the significance of the life and work of his mentor and friend.

title: New York Today: Live Snowstorm Updates
description: Updated 12:13 p.m.

title: Police Raid Fortress of Drug Production in South China
description: The police in the southeastern province of Guangdong raided a village they called a fortress of methamphetamine manufacturing that was protected by local Communist Party and law enforcement officials and criminals armed with assault rifles. Three tons of methamphetamines were seized along with more than 100 tons of methamphetamine ingredients and 260 kilograms, or 570 pounds, of ketamine, they said.

title: Times Minute | Destroying Syrian Weapons
description: Also on the Minute, doping in Indian sports and "Downton Abbey" returns.

title: Prime Minister Rules Out Third Term
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said Friday that he would not be Indias next prime minister if the Congress Party-led United Progressive Alliance wins the national elections scheduled for this spring.

title: Times Minute | Destroying Syrian Weapons
Thatcher Debated Using Military in 1984 Miners Strike
description: LONDON  As striking miners challenged her grip on power in 1984, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher secretly considered calling out the British military to transport vital supplies of food and coal around the country and declaring a state of emergency to bolster the government in one of the defining confrontations of her tumultuous years in office, according to previously classified documents released on Friday.

title: Daily Report: A DreamWorks Tablet for Children, With Penguins
description: DreamWorks Animation first captivated children in movie theaters. Then it branched into TV, piping cartoons based on hits like Madagascar and How to Train Your Dragon into homes through outlets like Nickelodeon and Netflix. Now, Brooks Barnes reports, DreamWorks has partnered with a technology company, Fuhu, on an even more immediate way to reach itty-bitty eyeballs, a highly coveted audience: a tablet computer for children that the studio will be able to program much like a cable channel. We could push out a new character moment every day of the year, said Jim Mainard, head of digital strategy and new business development for DreamWorks.

title: Paris Embraces Einstein Again
description: PARIS  Einstein on the Beach, the avant-garde opera composed by Philip Glass and directed by Robert Wilson, is nearing the end of a two-year revival tour with its arrival here. And the city has rolled out the red carpet for Mr. Wilson.

title: N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
description: Chiefs (11-5) at Colts (11-5)

title: Books, Just Like You Wanted
description: Anyone can publish a book these days, and just about everyone does. But if the supply of writers is increasing at a velocity unknown in literary history, the supply of readers is not. That is making competition for attention rather fierce. One result: ceaseless self-promotion by eager beginners.

title: German, Jewish and Neither
description: Laupheim, a small town in southern Germany, once boasted a large Jewish community and named a prominent street after one of its Jewish sons: Carl Laemmle, who went on to found Universal Studios. But all of that changed in the 1930s. By 1992, when I started fifth grade, Laemmles name had long since been removed from the map, and my mother and I were the only Jews in town.

title: Shocking Truth About Piranhas Revealed!
description: In the languid news week after Christmas, hungry media outlets swarmed over a report of piranhas attacking swimmers on a river in Argentina. Massive Piranha Attack cried The New York Post. 70 Christmas Day Bathers Are Savaged added The Daily Mail, promising the truth about the fish with a bite more powerful than a T. rex. ABC News called it a Christmas Day feeding frenzy. In fact, the injuries ranged from minor cuts to at least one missing finger part  not exactly as newsworthy as, say, the 800,000 Americans who require medical treatment for dog bites each year.

title: Teenagers in The Times | December 2013
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson Teaching With Teenagers in The Times.

title: Fighting to Kick the Habit
description: LAS VEGAS  ITS the time of year for resolutions. Lose 20 pounds, get to the gym, eat healthier, be more productive, whatever. But in a few months, many people will let these goals fall by the wayside, to be revived next year. I belong to a group who cant afford to make pledges we dont keep. Im an addict.

title: Gensler Bids Farewell to Trading Commission
description: GENSLER BIDS FAREWELL TO TRADING COMMISSION | Gary Gensler, who steps down on Friday as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, leaves his agency at an inflection point, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. His aggressive streak thrust the once-obscure agency into the front lines of reform, but it also maddened colleagues and complicated his legacy. Now, Wall Street is hoping for a friendlier regulator.

title: Babaru Memories
description: Lots of talk about China lately; and its still very worrisome. I am, however, mostly on vacation. But a brief note: what I havent seen many people mentioning is the obvious parallel, which is not so much to the US in the last decade as to Japan in the 1980s.

title: After Antarctic Drama, Chinese Rescue Ship Is Threatened by Ice
description: BEIJING  One day after a Chinese icebreaker played a central role in the rescue of 52 passengers from an icebound research vessel in Antarctica, crew members on the Chinese ship said it might itself become trapped by ice, according to Australian officials on Friday.

title: A Well-Trained Guide Dog
description: Dear Diary:

title: Iraq Fighters, Qaeda Allies, Claim Falluja as New State
description: BAGHDAD  Black-clad Sunni militants of Al Qaeda destroyed the Falluja Police Headquarters and mayors office, planted their flag atop other government buildings and decreed the western Iraqi city to be their new independent state on Friday in an escalating threat to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose forces were struggling to retake control late into the night.

title: Storm Slams East Coast, Leaving a Trail of Havoc
description: New York City joined its new mayor on Friday in digging out from a substantial but not overwhelming snowstorm that closed schools for the day and highways for hours, stranded travelers and left a chilly trail of disruption across the Northeast.

title: U.N. Says Aid Crisis Worsens in Central African Republic
description: GENEVA  The number of people displaced by fighting between Muslim and Christian militias and vigilantes in the Central African Republic has more than doubled in the past month, and increasing violence is making it harder to deliver humanitarian relief, the United Nations warned on Friday.

title: A Killer Whale, a Dogged Filmmaker
description: In 2010, Tilikum, a bull orca, or killer whale, performing at SeaWorld in Orlando, Fla., killed his trainer, Dawn Brancheau, at the end of a show. Like many other people, the director Gabriela Cowperthwaite read news stories about the incident and wondered how it could have happened; unlike everyone else, she decided to investigate, and kept at it until she had finished a film, Blackfish, which has now been shortlisted for the Oscar in the documentary feature category.
