title: An Update for On This Day
description: Men Walk on Moon.

title: After Fleeing Violence, Many Indian Muslims Refuse to Return Home
description: LOI, India  Mohammed Akhtars former neighbors keep stopping by to tell him that it is time for him to come home, that there is really nothing to be afraid of.

title: Despite Protests in Thailand, Vote Will Go On, Panel Says
description: BANGKOK  Thailands Election Commission ignored the demands of antigovernment demonstrators on Friday and said elections scheduled for next month would go ahead despite continuing efforts to sabotage them.

title: Jerry Goodman Is Dead
description: Jerry Goodman, better known under his nom de plume Adam Smith, has died of complications related to cancer. His son Mark contacted me with the news. He was a good friend, and I will sorely miss him.

title: Resolved: The Best Moment of 2014? This One
description: When it comes to New Years resolutions, I fall firmly in the love em camp. I sit down every January with my notebooks and calendars to try to work out what would make my life better, happier, simpler in the year to come. Some things work: Ive become more organized. Im late far less often. My closet adheres firmly to the one in, one out rule.

title: Audis Sport Quattro Concept Will Have Laser Eyes
description: Just when the last of Detroits automakers were hopping on the LED lighting bandwagon, Audi had to one-up everyone again. The German automakers distinctive LED daytime running lights have become a trademark of sorts over the better part of the last decade, but it has added something new: lasers.

title: Image of the Day: January 3
Megan Ellisons Good Day, Harvey Weinsteins Difficult One
description: The Academy opened voting for Oscar nominations just last week, so awards prognosticators are paying extra-close attention to the Producers Guild nominees, announced Thursday. Their 10 picks often dovetail with the Oscar best picture field, which means that Harvey Weinstein may be sweating now.

title: In Our Pages: January 4
description: 1889: Taxis Foot Heaters Lethal

title: Video Reviews of Lone Survivor, 47 Ronin and Grudge Match
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Lone Survivor, Grudge Match and 47 Ronin. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Tomorrows Valhalla
description: Twice in the last decade, I attended premieres at the Royal Opera in London and left the house exhilarated, convinced that a major new work had been introduced to the repertory. The first time was in 2004, at a performance of The Tempest, Thomass Adss magical and musically audacious adaptation of the Shakespeare play.

title: Im Here, Im a Carpenters Fan, Get Used to It
description: In the basement of my childhood home, there are stacks of old Billboard magazines, dating from the mid-70s. Recently I rooted through them to find the issue of Jan. 5, 1974. At the top of the album chart inside is the greatest-hits collection by the Carpenters, No. 1 40 years ago this week.

title: Ronan Farrow, Reluctant TV Star
description: Ronan Farrow had a cold. Probably from a source, he joked. It wasnt clear who gave it to him  the big pop star in L.A. or the Minnesotans fighting against terrorist recruitment in their community. Farrow had been out of town reporting pieces on both, and his voice was almost shot.

title: The 12.22.13 Issue
The Christies Auctioneer Jussi Pylkkanen on Working the Room
description: In November, you auctioned off a record-breaking $691 million worth of postwar and contemporary art in a sale for Christies. Is there a bubble in the art market?  We used to see high prices for our old-master paintings. We sold Van Goghs Sunflowers here in London in 1987 for $40 million, which was a record at the time. Really, over the last five years we have seen a steady march toward high prices in postwar art. At the same time, new buyers are entering the market from the Middle East, Asia, Russia and elsewhere.

title: Back to the Future in Algeria
description: An appreciation of the architect Oscar Niemeyer.

title: Can Data Be Evil?
description: Some knowledge about hypothermia comes from brutal Nazi medical experiments conducted on prisoners of war. Considering the data came from the destruction of others lives, are there ethical issues when modern-day scientists use it? Could it be considered a form of collaboration with the Nazis? Or does the origin of the data matter if the data is useful? Declaring the data off-limits could lead to preventable deaths, while using the data seems coldheartedly clinical. ISAAC MAYER,SAN DIEGO

title: My High-School Hoax
description: I had cut ninth-grade percussion class three weeks straight. But the top-floor music room overlooked the court where I was foolishly playing basketball, and my teacher summoned me from the window.

title: Who Made That Nigerian Scam?
description: The Nigerian scam may seem like a scourge of the Internet age, but it actually predates email. Before we started getting all-caps proposals in our inboxes, con men in West Africa plied their trade by fax and paper letter. Some of the first scams to make their way to Western Europe arrived by telex in 1989 and 1990, when businessmen in Britain started hearing that a wayward tanker of Nigerian crude could have its cargo claimed for bargain prices  in exchange, of course, for some cash upfront. Before then, Nigerian fraudsters aimed their grifts at locals. One scheme was the wash-wash, a literal money-laundering in which the mark is shown a valise of supposed bills blackened with Vaseline and iodine and promised a cut if he pays for an expensive cleaning agent.

title: No Comment Necessary: Rob Ford, the Best Mayor Ever
description: Rob Ford, the notorious mayor of Toronto who admitted to having smoked crack cocaine probably in one of my drunken stupors, is running for re-election.

title: Food, Genes and the Feeling of Risk
description: Updated below, Jan. 4, 4:57 p.m. | Six months ago, Nathanael Johnson, the author of All Natural and food blogger for Grist, an unabashedly liberal website, took on the task of digging deep on the risks and rewards of genetic modified organisms in agriculture. Grist summarized the results this way:

title: Man on Fire
description: The brothers David Henry and Joe Henry (the former a screenwriter and the latter a songwriter and singer) open this unorthodox paean to the legendary comedian Richard Pryor with a brief description of one of the most horrific incidents in their subjects life.

title: Richard Pryor, Thespian
description: This week, Mel Watkins reviews Furious Cool, the new book about Richard Pryor by the brothers Joe and David Henry.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE TRIP TO ECHO SPRING: On Writers and Drinking,  by Olivia Laing. (Picador, $26.) A charming and gusto-driven look at the alcoholic insanity of six famous authors, among them Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Cheever.

title: Paperback Row
description: TOMBSTONE: The Great Chinese Famine, 1958-1962,  by Yang Jisheng. Translated by Stacy Mosher and Guo Jian. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) Yang, a historian and veteran journalist in Beijing, estimates that 36 million Chinese starved to death during the Great Leap Forward. A landmark study of the disaster and the delusions and cruelties of Communist Party leaders, Tombstone is also a memorial for the uncle who raised Yang like a son and died of starvation in 1959.

title: Cities
description: FLOATING CITY  A Rogue Sociologist Lost and Found in New Yorks Underground Economy  By Sudhir Venkatesh  Penguin Press, $27.95.

title: A Ramshackle Modernity
description: Were having a particularly good season for literary discoveries from the past, with recent publications of Volumes 1 and 2 of Ahmad Faris al-Shidyaqs Leg Over Leg (1855), the marathon translation of Giacomo Leopardis 2,600-page Zibaldone (1898) and now The Time Regulation Institute (1962), the second great novel from Ahmet Hamdi Tanpinar. They arrive, such books, in a category all their own, in one sense new, in another sense old, as if to remind us that this thing called literature is much larger than our own little moment.

title: Heal Thyself
description: Its ingrained in human nature to look at ourselves with a weary awareness of all thats wrong within, and the optimism that someone, somewhere can tell us how to fix it. As Jessica Lamb-Shapiro points out in her ambitious if unfulfilling new memoir-cum-odyssey, Promise Land, weve been gobbling up self-help advice for nearly as long as the written word has existed, devouring it in the ancient Egyptian Sebayt writings and the Book of Proverbs. But our contemporary mania for the wisdom of Dr. Phil is different from what generations past gleaned from Epictetus or even Dale Carnegie, and Lamb-Shapiro aims to explain how. Along the way, shes on a quest to fix herself.

title: Regret to Inform
description: One covets a gold star as a small child (chores done!), a student (great work!), an entrepreneur (superior service!). For a military spouse, however, gold star status is anathema, for it is a gold star, edged in blue and floating on a field of white bordered in red, that forms the flag indicating a family member has died during service. A gold star wife, like the author Artis Henderson, is a widow.

title: The Brainteaser
description: You can construct a Mbius strip from a piece of paper. You cut a strip, say, an inch wide and two feet long, twist one end 180 degrees, and join that to the other end with rubber cement. You now hold a physical paradox: If you trace a pencil line continuously down the middle of your strip, you end up with one continuous line down the middle of both sides. This proves that the paper has only one side, even though, when you pinch it between your fingers, you can feel both sides at the same time. Your intellect collides with your senses, and the result, if you are Martin Gardner, is inspiration.

title: Mummy Dearest
description: Is it possible nowadays for otherwise intelligent Americans to reflect on England without thinking first of Downton Abbey? To put it another way: Can beleaguered American publishers expect to sell any English author without promising  however absurdly  a tie-in with Julian Fellowess opulent confection? I wonder. But in the case of Catherine Baileys stylish new book about one of Englands grandest dynasties, the link proves apt.

title: Bad Marks
description: Frederick Taylors The Downfall of Money promises, on its jacket, to deliver an economic horror story. A horror it was: Weve all seen the photos from Germany with the wheelbarrows full of cash or the children playfully stacking bricks of worthless bills (by late 1923 the mark had deteriorated from a value of 4.2 to the dollar in 1914 to over 4 trillion). The monetary crisis was so traumatic that to this day, it renders the German people thoroughly allergic to price increases.

title: Beautiful Minds
description: What does the genius have that the rest of us lack? What is that special something that sets him apart? Thats easy. Its a little spirit, or daimonion, that takes over his mind, like the one that possessed Socrates. Or perhaps it has something to do with the birthday god that shapes a mans personality, like the genius (from the Latin for to beget) who watched over Augustus Caesar.

title: The Spy Who Came Into the Fold
description: The main thing to know about Company Man, John Rizzos memoir of his three decades as a C.I.A. lawyer, including seven years as the agencys chief legal officer, is that its title is not the slightest bit ironic.

title: You Wouldnt Want to Live There
description: All the heavy hitters, from Michael Connelly in Los Angeles to Joyce Carol Oates in suburban New Jersey, came out for USA NOIR (Akashic, cloth, $29.95; paper, $16.95), an important anthology of stories shrewdly culled by Johnny Temple, Akashics editor in chief, from dozens of volumes of regional crime fiction published since 2004 under the Noir banner. Although theres hardly a dud in the pack, some do elbow their way to the front.

title: Greener Pastures
description: One of the most remarkable developments in social science in the past decade has been the emergence of happiness as a subject of serious scholarship and experimental study. This has been largely the work of behavioral economists, many of them psychologists by training, who have set out to investigate the everyday decisions people make and the repercussions those choices have on their future lives.

title: The Year in Jazz
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the notable artists and themes in jazz in 2013.

title: Inside the List
description: Best of the Best, Part II: Last week, this space featured reading recommendations from some of the authors of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2013, and promised more to come. Here now, a promise kept.

title: Movie Review: '47 Ronin'
description: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews "47 Ronin."

title: Movie Review: Grudge Match
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Grudge Match."

title: Banksy Works Defaced Near Site of Sundance Festival
description: It may be time for Banksy, the anonymous British graffiti artist, to consider television. A sitcom, perhaps, or a detective show, or maybe reality TV. His politically pointed satirical stencil works seem to be everywhere in Britain and the United States, after all, and things are always happening to them.

title: Jos. A. Bank Amends Its Poison Pill
description: Jos. A. Bank Clothiers tightened its poison pill requirements on Friday, the latest move in its continuing takeover battle with Mens Wearhouse.

title: Movie Review: 'Lone Survivor'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lone Survivor."

title: Two Who Got 2013 Right See 2014 as Much the Same
description: After a banner year for stocks and a rocky one for bonds, market forecasters are remarkably consistent in their forecasts for 2014: more of the same.

title: Justices Are Asked to Reject Nuns Challenge to Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration urged the Supreme Court on Friday to reject a lawsuit filed by the Little Sisters of the Poor, an order of Roman Catholic nuns challenging requirements for many employers to provide health insurance coverage for birth control or face penalties under the new health care law.

title: Carjacker Steals Truck From Owner Shoveling Snow in West Village
description: The superintendent of an apartment building in the West Village was carjacked Friday morning as he was shoveling snow, the police said.

title: Football, War and the Workplace
description: I spend my days trying to make workplaces more humane, but recently Ive been thinking a lot about why people would voluntarily choose to work in one that is dangerous, debilitating and often lethal. Actually, I have two in mind.

title: Times Minute | Scenes From the Snowstorm
description: Also on the Minute, deadly clashes in Cambodia and yoga before it was trendy.

title: Apartment for Sale, Taste Included
description: Cindy Gallop lives in a black lacquer box of a loft. The walls and ceiling are painted glossy black. There is black carpeting galore, black cabinetry in the kitchen, black mosaic tile in the master bath, and a black curtain closing off the sleeping area. The singular look is courtesy of the specific instructions she gave her design team for the 3,800 square feet of raw space she bought a decade ago: When night falls I want to feel Im in a Shanghai nightclub  the Glamour Bar, to be precise, where her desire to live in that kind of space crystallized as she sipped her second martini.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Chang-rae Lee
description: This week, Chang-rae Lee discusses his latest novel, On Such a Full Sea; Victoria Wilson talks about her new biography of Barbara Stanwyck; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Times Minute | Scenes From the Snowstorm
description: In the Video

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: On Such a Full Sea
description: This week, Chang-rae Lee and Victoria Wilson.

title: Popcast: The Year in Jazz
description: This week, starting from the top of our Top 10 lists and moving downward and outward, Nate Chinen and I look back on jazz in 2013.

title: The Gun Report: January 3, 2014
description: Mass shootings have tripled in recent years, from five a year between 2000 and 2008 to 16 a year from 2009 to 2012, according to anew studyobtained by Yahoo! Newsyesterday. The authors, who are from the Advanced Law Enforcement Rapid Response Training Center at Texas State University, define mass shootings as incidents where a gunman opens fire in a public place with the motivation of killing many.

title: In Your Ears: Covering Peter Gabriel
description: The original plan, Peter Gabriel explained, was for two records to be released simultaneously: one of him singing songs that other artists had written, and another consisting of those same performers interpreting songs of his. Scratch My Back, with Mr. Gabriel singing and an orchestra backing him, was released in 2010, but And Ill Scratch Yours is only coming out this week. So why the delay?

title: Shoring Up Hamptons Beaches, and Prices, Too
description: Though waterfront usually sells at a premium, sometimes real estate prices in the Hamptons ebb and flow with the shifting sands. In Sagaponack, for instance, the price on Billy Joels four-bedroom six-bath shingle-style home with 145 feet of sandy beach was raised to $23.5 million recently, from $16.75 million in 2012.

title: Big Ticket | Two Faces of Luxury, $15.5 Million Each
description: In a photo finish for the most expensive residential sale in the final week of 2013, the two winning properties, built in different centuries and in different genres, are similar only in their abundance of luxury amenities. An impeccably renovated Upper East Side townhouse and a two-bedroom condominium at the predictably prestigious 15 Central Park West both traded for $15.5 million, according to city records.

title: Not Quite All Spoonfuls of Sugar
description: For nearly 50 years, moviegoers have embraced Mary Poppins as a whimsical Disney classic about a magical English nanny, a twinkly chimney sweep and a London bankers fractured family. But the new Disney film Saving Mr. Banks, written by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, shares two less cheerful tales. In flashback, it reveals the Mary Poppins author P. L. Traverss sad past as an Australian girl with a hard-drinking father and a suicidal mother. The other story is of two weeks in 1961 when Walt Disney (Tom Hanks), who had been trying to secure the film rights from Ms. Travers (Emma Thompson) for nearly 20 years, finally lured her to California, where Disney staff composers, the Sherman Brothers (Jason Schwartzman and B. J. Novak), struggled to collaborate with her.

title: Storm Shows Off a Less Stoic Mayor Now in Charge
description: He trudged out with a shovel soon after sunrise, scraping the snow from his sidewalk and reminding New Yorkers to lift with your knees.

title: Are Sugary Drinks Fattening? Depends Who You Ask
description: Are there good scientific studies that show that drinking sugar-sweetened soda increases the risk for obesity? The answer may vary depending on who is paying for the study.

title: Knowing When to Compromise
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Book Review Podcast: Diving Into the Wreck
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Sean Greer reviews Chang-rae Lees new novel, On Such a Full Sea. Mr. Greer writes:

title: Music Becomes a Real Game Changer
description: The composer Austin Wintorys office in Burbank, Calif., contains a desk, a chair and a life-size model of R2-D2. A windowless adjoining room, with an electric piano and two computers, is where Mr. Wintory, 29, says he spends up to 14 hours a day working on his music.

title: A Makeover for the Affinia 50 in New York
description: Affinia 50, a 10-year-old hotel property in Manhattans Midtown East neighborhood, has undergone a $20 million transformation. The 10-month renovation included an overhaul of the 251 guest rooms and public areas like the lobby, corridors and second-floor Club Room, which is a social space for guests.

title: Divining a 5-Year Investment Strategy
description: FIVE years ago, it would have been easy to predict that the stock market would be higher today than it was then. But no one would have paid attention. Stocks were in a free fall and wouldnt hit bottom for two more months.

title: Its Just How He Carries Himself
description: A year before the actor Chiwetel Ejiofor, born in England to a Nigerian immigrant family, began filming 12 Years a Slave, he was in Savannah, Ga., making another movie when he signed up for a tour of the city. One stop left a deep impression on him: a 19th-century slave pen, used to hold newly arrived Africans before they were sent to auction, and had, he recalled, a sequence of bolts high on the wall.

title: Barberry and Orange Tea
description: I have in my pantry a rather large bag of dried barberries, bought at my Persian market, and I had been using them up slowly. Now I know where much of what remains of these sour, zingy vitamin C-rich dried fruits will go.

title: Meyer Lemon and Ginger Infusion With Turmeric and Cayenne
description: There is a lot going on in this lovely infusion, with the tart lemon and pungent ginger. Turmeric contributes beautiful color, along with its nutritional benefits  it has been shown to have powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant attributes  and the tiny pinch of cayenne packs a small punch. If you feel a sore throat coming on I highly recommend this tea.

title: Dried Apricot, Cherry and Cranberry Infusion
description: Whenever I soak dried fruit in hot water, to plump it for another recipe, I am always reluctant to throw out the soaking water because it tastes so good. I decided to simmer dried fruit with sweet spices and orange to obtain a delicious infusion that I would decidedly not throw out. A great beverage for a snowy day.

title: Coconut Ginger Tea With Lime, Honey and Turmeric
description: I love the fair trade teas produced by Zhenas Gypsy Tea, especially her Coconut Chai. Inspired by the perfume of coconut in that tea, I infused shredded coconut and ginger and added a little fresh lime juice, honey and a smidgeon of turmeric. The idea of making a turmeric and honey paste comes from Heidi Swansons 101cookbooks.com.

title: U.S. Winter Training Camp Tilts Toward M.L.S.
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national soccer team, named a 26-man roster for the teams January training campon Friday, giving a mix of veterans and newcomers one last chance to make a case for a roster spot for next summers World Cup in Brazil.

title: Is 2014 the Year of the Connected Home?
description: Tech companies have been talking for years about the so-called connected home, in which home appliances and accessories connect to the Internet. Judging from Christmas with my family  as well as the news expected at the International Consumer Electronics Show next week  this year it might become a reality.

title: Justin Timberlake Album Was the Top Seller in a Diminished Market
description: The year-end chart news is mixed for Justin Timberlake. On the bright side, The 20/20 Experience (RCA), the comeback album he released in March, was the top selling album of 2013, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

title: Back to the Future in Algeria
description: The legacy of Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect who died in 2012 at the age of 104, is most familiarly seen in the Modernist buildings he designed for Brasilia, the planned city that became the countrys capital in 1960. But his work in Algeria  not nearly so well known  has also enhanced his reputation as one of the 20th centurys great architects. Niemeyer, a Communist who fled to France following the military takeover of Brazil in 1964, designed several buildings in Algeria in the late 1960s (as well as a library in recent years that is still being built). The plan for one, La Coupole, a sports arena in Algiers, which can be seen in the slide show here, was made on a napkin. Mekki Damerdji, an architect and professor in Algiers, says Mentouri University (shown here), in the city of Constantine, is a favorite of his for its stark contrast to the more traditional buildings that dominate the countrys landscape. Were not used to seeing this shape in our country, Damerdji says. We havent anything like this in Algeria. Its very beautiful. Its like a bird.Julie Bosman

title: What I Love | Jill and Jimmy Haber
description: The couples 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side boasts six fireplaces and an indoor basketball court.

title: A Fine-Feathered Family Nest
description: Jill and Jimmy Haber love every square inch of their five-story, 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side. Brimming with pride and a palpable sense of contentment as they stand in their foyer with its welcoming fireplace, they worry only about whether to commence a visitors tour on the bottom or the top floor.

title: Abortion Restrictions Passed by States
description: State legislatures enacted 70 restrictions on abortion in 2013; over the past three years, they passed more of these laws than they did from 2000 to 2010.

title: In a Mans Mind, Anything Goes
description: This is the week when television comes back to life after the holidays. New series like CBSs Intelligence make their debuts. Shows that had their premieres this past fall, like Marvels Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. on ABC and Almost Human on Fox, start their winter seasons: i.e., new episodes after a spate of reruns. A few shows even have season finales, like CBSs Hostages.

title: Unemployed in Europe Stymied by Lack of Technology Skills
description: DUBLIN  Week after week, newspapers issue a stream of hopeful headlines: Microsoft, PayPal, Fujitsu and scores of other companies are expanding their investments in Ireland, creating thousands of jobs as unemployment hovers near record highs.

title: Festival Opens With Soviet Tale
description: It seems apt that the New York Jewish Film Festival should open with a joke. This one, at the beginning of Friends From France, the opening-night film on Wednesday, goes like this:

title: Captured in Time: A Certain New York
description: Unfettered optimism was the unofficial religion of the United States in the early 20th century, but the photographer Lewis Hine (1874-1940) declined to buy in, refused to be steamrollered by our natural cultural euphoria, as the retrospective Lewis Hine at the International Center of Photography clearly shows. The exhibition includes Hines earliest work, from Ellis Island (1905), and includes selections from his later major photographic essays, including those on immigration, child labor, working men and construction of the Empire State Building.

title: Political Torment, Teenage Angst
description: Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, an ambitious festival started in January 2013 by Beth Morrison Projects and the Here Arts Center, returns on Wednesday for a second season, with four principal shows and a bevy of side attractions.

title: Gems of Jazz for Winters Night
description: This years edition of Winter Jazz Festival runs five nights instead of two. It was already a significant jazz event in New York  now even more so. The first three nights are self-contained, concerts at Le Poisson Rouge and Town Hall: the drummer Bobby Prevites all-star group, Terminals, on Tuesday; a head-to-head, double-piano concert involving Jason Moran, Robert Glasper and their various associates on Wednesday; and the Revive Big Band on Thursday.

title: 20 Companies at Joyce and N.Y.U.
description: Every January, the Association of Performing Arts Presenters meets in New York, and one subject delegates are sure to ponder is the choosing of dance groups to present in coming months. No wonder dancers hope to attract attention by performing at conference time. Gotham Arts Exchange, which provides management assistance to artists, hopes to entice both presenters and the public with its Focus series at two theaters. Eight companies will appear at the Joyce Theater (opening Tuesday), and there will be 12 at the Skirball Center (opening Friday), with each performance offering at least two attractions.

title: Stranded Antarctic Ship Story, Like the Ice, Will Not Let Go
description: A team of rescuers from a Chinese icebreaker may need to be rescued themselves, soon after they plucked dozens of people from the Antarctic ice aboard a ship that had been stranded for more than a week.

title: Duck Dynasty Diversifies
description: Selling plain old duck calls  simple tools that lure prey with fake quacks  underpins the phenomenal financial success of Duck Dynastys Robertson clan, one of cables favorite families. Phil Robertson, the outspoken evangelical patriarch, got into trouble lately with some homophobic, fire-and-brimstone remarks, but after a brief suspension from the show, he was reinstatedin a fight between high-mindedness and ratings, ratings always win  and the duck calls kept selling by the millions. Actual hunters comprise a minority of sales, according to Willie Robertson, the family business executive who said most are bought by people who put it on their desk and toot on it.

title: Writers Guild Unveils Picks for Screenplay Categories
description: The Writers Guild of America has released its nominations for best screenplay. Heres a quick look at its picks. Stay tuned for the Baggers analysis.

title: Access to Abortion Falling as States Pass Restrictions
description: A three-year surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has altered the landscape for abortion access, with supporters and opponents agreeing that the new restrictions are shutting some clinics, threatening others and making it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.

title: AT&T Offers Customers Credit for Leaving T-Mobile
description: Updated | This post now includes a statement from the chief executive of T-Mobile US.

title: Daughter of Palestinian Envoy Killed in Czech Republic Suspects Foul Play
description: GAZA  The daughter of Jamal al-Jamal, 56, the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic who was killed this week in an explosion at his home in Prague, said Friday that she believed he was murdered.

title: World War II Bomb Kills One Person in Germany
description: BERLIN  The explosion of a World War II bomb in a town in western Germany killed one person and wounded at least 13 others on Friday, the police said.

title: Momentum Builds for Hustle and Dallas as Llewyn Lags
description: Not all Oscar-hopeful screenplays are eligible for the Writers Guild Awards: heavy hitters like 12 Years a Slave and Philomena didnt qualify (for lack of membership or other bureaucratic reasons), along with the indies Short Term 12 and Fruitvale Station. But several of the top contenders for the Little Golden Guy got nods today from the guild. There were surprises like the inclusion of Lone Survivor, the director Peter Bergs adaptation of a true story of a Navy SEAL mission gone terribly awry; and the omission of Inside Llewyn Davis, from the Coen brothers, whom the Writers Guild has favored before. (Perhaps the members were bothered by what the Coens themselves described as the films lack of a plot.)

title: Court Grants Secrecy for Memo on Phone Data
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday ruled that the Obama administration may continue to withhold a Justice Department memo that apparently opened a loophole in laws protecting the privacy of consumer data.

title: Israel and U.S. Test Interceptor Missile
description: JERUSALEM  The missile defense agencies of Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea on Friday, Israels Defense Ministry said in a statement.

title: Questions About Inmates Holiday Food, Orange Cabs and Bogarts Brooklyn Ties
description: Q. Did the inmates at Rikers Island get a special Christmas dinner? Im curious about the menu.

title: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
description: The song "Green Green Rocky Road" performed by Oscar Isaac in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

title: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
description: Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver perform "Please Mr. Kennedy" in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

title: Wooing Filmgoers Through Their Ears
description: LOS ANGELES  In the new film by Joel and Ethan Coen, a struggling folk singer, Llewyn Davis, plays a song for a music promoter. After listening intently, the promoter issues his review: I dont see a lot of money here.

title: Thrift Store Owner Finds His Calling and Salvation
description: Anthony Cody gained the nickname Tony Bargains after cleaning out a crack house on Boston Road in the Allerton section of the Bronx and opening Tonys Bargain Basement Thrift Shop.

title: A Lexicon of Instant Argot
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Millions watched and gossiped online as Miley Cyrus twerked on stage at MTVs video music awards in late 2013. Then, they rushed to Urban Dictionary to figure out what that was  making twerk one of the most-searched terms on the site all year.

title: Spinach Salad With Prosciutto
description: The addition of prosciutto, persimmon and croutons to a regular spinach salad makes light fare substantial enough for a full meal.

title: Bradley, Former U.S. and Egypt Coach, Joins Norwegian Club
description: The career of Bob Bradley, the former national team soccer coach for the United States and Egypt, took another interesting turn on Friday when he was formally introduced as the manager of the Norwegian club Stabaek. The two-year deal makes Bradley, 55, the first American head coach of a top-tier European team.

title: Obama Announces Gun Control Actions
description: Updated, 10:46 p.m. | HONOLULU  President Obama announced two new executive actions on Friday that nudge his gun control agenda forward by making it easier for states to provide information about people with mental illness to the federal background check system.

title: An Artistic Armchair Travel Platform That Visits the Worlds Most Amazing Places
description: Growing up in rural Maine, the brothers Darrell and Oliver Hartman learned to love the outdoorsy, adventurous life from their dad, who was the director of the states parks. Trips in early adulthood to places like Greece, Nicaragua and India ensured their passion for wanderlust, as did the jobs they pursued: Darrell, 32, is a lifestyle and travel writer; Oliver, 30, is a director for the production company North. Last year, the pair decided to combine talents to create a website that celebrates the kind of travel they like to do.

title: Chasing the Northern Lights in Alaska
description: We hurtled across the tundra in the dark. The old train chugged, rattled, occasionally whined. As the sun came up around 10 a.m., the world faded from black to cobalt to white and every shade between. All was snow; it was just a matter of how much, where, what shape. Black spruce trees draped in white rose up from the ground like crystals of hoarfrost.

title: Traveling While Black
description: As I walked through the Forbidden City, the majestic imperial palace at the center of Beijing, with a friend and her teenager, I scanned the crowd. In the maze of shrines and courtyards, there was no one quite like us: I am an African-American with long dreadlocks, and my friend, Maria, a Mexican-American, had her half-Dominican son in tow.

title: A Big Salad That Stands In for Dinner
description: Ive never been very good with New Years resolutions, especially the ones along juice-cleansing, teetotaling, diet-and-exercise lines. All those high expectations inevitably set me up to fail.

title: Aloof Felines
description: Reverend Run, king of (sheet) rock; dual showering, considered.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A home in Fairfield, Conn., with views of inlets on Long Island Sound; and one in Manalapan, N.J., with a heated pool and a hot tub.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Greenwich Village apartment with built-ins; an East Village home with exposed brick; and a Brooklyn Heights condo with harbor views.

title: Clip: 'Another Day Another Time'
description: Oscar Isaac, Marcus Mumford and the Punch Brothers perform Fare Thee Well in the documentary Another Day Another Time, which celebrates the music of Inside Llewyn Davis.

title: Cyberdeal Hits the Sweet Spot
description: At first glance, the latest cybersecurity deal looks like a breach of logic. FireEyes market value shot up by a third on Friday, a move worth $1.6 billion, more than it said it had spent to buy Mandiant. The deal marries FireEyes threat protection with its targets capabilities to respond to cyberattacks after they happen. Even with the industrial fit, the welcome from investors was unusually warm.

title: Annual Sales for American Automakers Reach a 6-Year High
description: DETROIT  It was the best year for American auto sales since 2007, and among the biggest winners were the car companies from Detroit.

title: Ballet Without Borders
description: At 45, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky and his work have become internationally ubiquitous.

title: In Britain, Housing Prices Rise the Fastest Since 2006
description: LONDON  Housing prices in Britain rose last year at the fastest pace since 2006, adding to fears that the countrys real estate market is overheating.

title: An App That Helps Users Cut Calories
description: New York Citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is proud of its technological prowess: The rotating banner of the agencys home page features a link to the four smartphone apps that the agency has created. One of those apps, CalCutter, would seem a great download for this time of year, both to celebrate the now-concluded tenure of that most health-conscious of mayors and to aid in that ubiquitous resolution for a healthier diet.

title: The de Blasios: A Simple Outfit
description: Inaugurations are a bit like weddings in that clothing choices on the in-law side are suddenly and harshly on display. So thats what they look like?

title: Bundling Up With Lamb
description: This is not the season for roast lamb. Wouldnt you rather have a warming stew during these bitterly cold days?

title: British Company Names Years Best Album Covers
description: Music collectors have long lamented the effect that miniaturization  the move from 12-inch LP jackets to 5.75-inch CD booklets, and then to thumbnail photos on digital downloads  has had on record jacket art. But Art Vinyl, a British company that makes frames for record covers, has been encouraging performers and collectors to think more carefully about cover art since 2005, when it established its annual Best Art Vinyl award, with the winners chosen through online voting.

title: Williams Continues Dominance of Sharapova
description: BRISBANE, Australia  Defying the conventional script, the two main characters in womens tennis faced off in the first scene of the 2014 season.

title: Steps Heard Round the World
description: The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is 45. Its safe to say that no choreographer in history at that age has made such pervasive inroads into the international ballet repertory. He has now created ballets for the leading companies of America, Australia, Britain, Canada, Denmark, France, Italy, the Netherlands and his native Russia. Most of those troupes, shopping around in the global supermarket of dance today, have also acquired other works of his. In 2013, he had no fewer than seven world premieres in five cities on three continents. It becomes increasingly evident that he is the most prolific choreographer alive, the most travel-hungry and the most historically conscious.

title: Claire Daness Fashion Choices
description: Ms. Daness style includes clean shapes and flirty prints.

title: Arctic Temperatures for Players and Fans, but No Blackouts on TV
description: The first winter storm of 2014 has largely come and gone, but it has left snow, frigid temperatures and untold delays in its wake. Caught in the mess are the thousands of N.F.L. players, fans and members of the news media trying to get to Cincinnati, Green Bay, Indianapolis and Philadelphia, where wild-card games will be played this weekend.

title: On Journeys of Discovery, One Is Cut Short
description: Doe B

title: How to Keep Your Resolutions
description: ITS that time of year again. Maybe its your waistline youre worried about, or maybe its the smoking habit you just cant seem to kick. To improve your chances of keeping your New Years resolutions, we offer four tips inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health. We focus on health, but our suggestions should help with other goals, too.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 3, 2014
description: Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioners departure.

title: With Crisis Behind Him, S.E.C.s Co-Chief of Enforcement Is Leaving
description: Updated, 8:08 p.m. |

title: Family and Football, With a Few Audibles, for Music Executive
description: Since the 1980s, when Lyor Cohen was one of the young executives who helped establish the business infrastructure of hip-hop, he has been one of the music industrys hardest-charging figures. The former head of Def Jam records and the recorded music division of the Warner Music Group, Mr. Cohen, 54, recently announced his new venture, a boutique music company named 300. But on weekends, he devotes himself to family  and football.

title: Dazzling, on Screen and Off
description: WHO Claire Danes

title: N.H.T.S.A Tells Child Seat Manufacturer to Conduct Recall; Chevrolet Pickups and Range Rovers Are Also Recalled
description: About 33,000 child safety seats are being recalled by Combi USA because the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says the restraining straps could break during a crash. The recall comes after the safety agency rejected Combis request that it be excused from a recall because the failure to meet the federal safety standard was inconsequential to motor vehicle safety.

title: More About Jerry Goodman
description: I see that Bloomberg has an obit up; still waiting on the Times. Im not going to do a proper life, just say a few things.

title: General Cleburnes Radical Plan
description: On Jan. 2, 1864, Gen. Joseph Johnston, the commander of the largest Confederate army outside Virginia, called an evening meeting of his subordinate generals in his headquarters in northwest Georgia. The purpose of the meeting was kept secret from all but a few. When they arrived, they found Gen. Patrick Cleburne, an Irish immigrant and one of Johnstons best division commanders, who presented a radical proposal: to enlist slaves as rebel soldiers in exchange for their freedom.

title: Videos of Fighters and Air Raids in Iraqs Anbar Province
description: Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda fought for control of Falluja and Ramadi on Friday, escalating a battle over the two cities that have increasingly become centers of Sunni extremism since American forces withdrew from the country at the end of 2011.

title: Evangelicals Find Themselves in the Midst of a Calvinist Revival
description: For those who are sad that the year-end news quizzes are past, heres one to start 2014: If you have joined a church that preaches a Tulip theology, does that mean a) the pastor bakes flowers into the communion wafers, b) the pastor believes that flowers that rise again every spring symbolize the resurrection, or c) the pastor is a Calvinist?

title: Bratton and Miller Back in Blue for Round 3
description: Minutes after the news conference last month announcing that he would serve a second term as New York Citys police commissioner, William J. Bratton and a group of close friends sat down over rigatoni and meatballs at Ferdinandos Focacceria, a subway-tiled Sicilian joint a few blocks from the docks in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The location and the lunch guests were classic Bratton. Gathered at a table in the back, under photos of Palermo and a stamped-tin ceiling, was a kind of kitchen cabinet: Mr. Brattons wife, his retired-detective bodyguards, some former aides from the Police Department, a few associates from his private security firm and the TV reporter John Miller.

title: The Alien Hunter as Lounge Lizard
description: Theres plenty of reason to be curious, even excited, about Space Dandy, a new anime television series beginning on Adult Swim on Saturday night. Shinichiro Watanabe, credited as the shows general director, is responsible for two of the best Japanese anime series to have made it to American TV in recent years, Cowboy Bebop (1998-99) and Samurai Champloo (2005-6). The animation studio behind it, Bones, has produced high-quality series like Fullmetal Alchemist and Eureka Seven.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Indonesia, Egypt and Cambodia.

title: Dominant in Dome, Saints Face Tough Road as They Try to Defy Trends
description: NEW ORLEANS  The New Orleans Saints victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in their final regular-season game Sunday featured their trademark passing game, key defensive stops and 70,000 rollicking fans fueled by brass bands and beer.

title: Reclaiming Fatherhood After Afghanistan
description: During my enlistment, I had the privilege to serve as an infantry rifleman, the primary infantry job in the United States Marine Corps. My role was to locate, close with and destroy or repel the enemy, by fire and close combat. As I advanced through my career, I learned valuable teamwork, communication and leadership skills that I continue to use.

title: A Circuitous Route to Outer Space
description: In a radio interview not long ago, Alfonso Cuarn compared his movies to ex-wives: Hes grateful, wishes them well, but has no desire to go back and visit. What he didnt say, but could have, was that none of these wives bears much resemblance to any of the others.

title: Ask About The House Edge
description: (Update: A post with the reporters replies has now been published.)

title: Reprising a Lindberg: Same Cast, New Date
description: For even the most successful and popular living composers, a truism exists: Its much easier to secure a world premiere, with all the first-night appeal and media attention such an occurrence brings, than to gain a second performance of the same work, once the hubbub has faded. Even the most well-received contemporary piece can take some time to resurface, if, indeed, it ever does.

title: Visual Portents of a Silent Bolt of Thunder
description: On Feb. 7, 1943, John Cage made his first New York public appearance at the Museum of Modern Art with a performance of percussion works that featured his wife, Xenia (whom he would divorce three years later), and Merce Cunningham (who would replace her as his life partner).

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 3
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioners departure.

title: In Praise of Art Laffer
description: No, really. Business Insider contacted him about his 2009 warning that soaring inflation and interest rates were just around the corner  and he not only admits that he was wrong, he admits that his error signified something wrong with his overall economic model:

title: Palestinian Teenager Dies of Wounds From Israeli Gunfire
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian teenager died on Friday after being wounded by Israeli gunfire near the Israel-Gaza border a day earlier, according to medical officials in Gaza.

title: Churro Shop Owner Serves Up a Spanish Tradition
description: It was a singular procession that filed into Le Churro on Lexington Avenue between 83rd and 84th Streets one recent afternoon. Eyes wide, riveted on the menu hung high above the counter, children buckling under their backpacks and harried mothers all seemed transfixed by the weight of the decision: Chocolate or caramel sauce?

title: Lightening the Load on an E.V.s Batteries
description: Small zero-emission city cars may have cute faces and small footprints, but they also pack more weight than you might expect, forcing engineers to come up with innovative diets.

title: Electric Service From $199 a Month
description: Electric cars are getting cheaper. Although purchase prices vary, the Chevrolet Spark E.V. and Smart Electric Drive Cabriolet can be leased for three years at $199 a month, and the Fiat 500e at $239. That means consumers are likely to weigh factors other than the bottom line when deciding which  if any  of these small, stylish battery vehicles to put in their driveway.

title: Cute, but Not Precious
description: The Fiat 500e, Chevrolet Spark and Smart Cabriolet, three tiny battery-powered urban runabouts, arent just fun, theyre fairly affordable.

title: An Underground Portfolio
description: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

title: A Night at the Opera, Lost in the Memory of Another
description: I was ready to end 2013 by looking in on a fancy New Years Eve party that was supposed to be unfolding in fin de sicle Vienna. The invitation was right there on a curtain that went up at the opening performance of the Metropolitan Operas new production of Die Fledermaus. But when the conductor walked into the pit and bowed, I was transported not to Vienna in 1899, but to Michigan in 1985.

title: Bringing the Underworld to Light
description: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

title: Qaeda-Linked Insurgents Clash With Other Rebels in Syria, as Schism Grows
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Deadly clashes were reported Friday in northern Syria between Sunni Islamist jihadists linked to Al Qaeda and insurgents in other alliances, punctuating a growing schism within the armed Syrian opposition over the power exerted by its religiously radicalized members, many of them from other countries.

title: Love, the Universal Scenario
description: Enough Said

title: Call Waiting ... and Waiting
description: Taylor Kitsch, star of NBCs Friday Night Lights and the new war movie Lone Survivor, doesnt field many phone calls when he is in Austin, Tex., where he lives alone.

title: German Politicians Rush to Lobbying Brings Scorn
description: BERLIN  If there is one hallmark of Angela Merkels chancellorship, it is that, despite her widely acknowledged tactical prowess and skill in winning, keeping and expanding her power, she is uninterested in the material trappings of office.

title: Feeling For | The Ultimate Vintage E-Shop for Fashion Fanatics
description: After the chaotic holiday months of planning the perfect gifts for others, its finally time to think about ourselves. For the fashion conscious, that means planning out your purchases for the upcoming season. But its hard to think of the future when you still havent crossed off dream items from wish lists of old, like, say those Balenciaga SS 2002 cargo pants or that black oversized Cline coat. Enter Resee, a website that helps track down coveted items that got away. Unveiled last fall by Sabrina Marshall, a former editor at Self Service magazine, and Sofia Bernardin, a Vogue advertising veteran, the secondhand e-shop specializes in vintage pieces by high-end designers like Alaa, Herms, Helmut Lang and Raf Simons. In addition to browsing the curated finds sourced from some legendary sources, including the Paris vintage shop Nella, which gave Resee all its inventory when it closed last year, and the closets of some of the worlds most stylish women  guests can even fill out a virtual want ad for particularly elusive items. The sites magazine-caliber design and photography is sure to suck you in for hours at a time  then send you forth into 2014 looking your very best.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
description: Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion.

title: Not All the Days Were Good
description: The eye rolls, the swivel, the gowns and the platinum hair: The singer Peggy Lee has been parodied so often, especially by drag performers, that it is easy to confuse the caricature with the complicated pop-jazz singer who died 12 years ago this month. Sorting out the contradictions of Lees life and career, Stacy Sullivans show at the Metropolitan Room, Its a Good Day: A Tribute to Miss Peggy Lee, paints an empathetic, melancholy portrait.

title: A Sleeping Beauty of Ferraris
description: SANTA MONICA, CALIF.  After being knocked out of commission in 1969 by an engine fire and then spending the next 44 years hibernating in Pennsylvania, a graceful 1967 Ferrari 330 GTS will come under the glare of spotlights on Jan. 18 when it is auctioned in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Fixes for Ticks, Clicks and Leaks
description: Audis needing new brake discs and Corvettes with low oil in their differentials are among the mechanical problems addressed in the latest technical service bulletins from automakers.

title: Adventures in the Sub-Luxury Category
description: In case Santa didnt give you everything you wanted, theres a new submarine in the water.

title: Opening Champagne With a Saber at the Baroness
description: On the eve of New Years Eve, one neighborhood bar was already celebrating  as usual. The Baroness, six weeks old, in a nearly 100-year-old building in Long Island City, was offering instruction in the French art of sabrage. That is to say, patrons could open their own Champagne bottles with a saber, after a quick lesson from Mlanie Lemieux, owner and sommelier.

title: A Mixed Message From the Boy Scouts
description: On New Years Day, the Boy Scouts of America began allowing openly gay boys to participate in its activities, while still prohibiting openly gay and lesbian adults from serving as troop leaders.

title: The Power of Three
description: THE GIST When trying to persuade, four claims are one too many.

title: Bisexual: A Label With Layers
description: Of course I still fancy girls.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
description: The holiday season ended with a blast of arctic air and several inches of snow, which hardly fazed the intrepid tourists in Times Square or the skaters at Rockefeller Center. Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion. The adventurous skied. The diligent shoveled. And winter showed its beauty, as in Bryant Park, where cascades of ice turned the fountain into art.

title: De Blasios Next Task Is Turning Passion Into Policy
description: A week after his election, the mayor-elect, a tall crane of a man, edged into a low-ceilinged conference room in Downtown Brooklyn to celebrate the citys progressive movement and its progressive victory, which happened to be his own.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook Privacy and Sharks on Twitter
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: The Woody Allen Genome
Inside the Tale of North Korea Execution by Ravenous Dog
description: Updated, 10:07 p.m. | BEIJING  There is no end to shocking stories from North Korea, many involving the myriad cruelties of the brutal police state as reported by defectors. But the latest tale  a news media report that the young North Korean leader might have had his uncle torn apart by ravenous dogs while he watched  may say less about the North than what outsiders have come to expect of it.

title: At Lincoln Center, a Marriage (but Not for Figaro)
description: By the time they decided to marry, neither Kristin Koslowski nor Holt Wilkins saw much appeal in a traditional wedding, particularly the part that often calls for spending a year in planning for that single day.

title: Once Labeled a Traitor, Korean Aims to Be a Hero
description: SEOUL, South Korea  HONG YOON-HEE had an extraordinary tale to tell, to anyone who would listen, about how he risked his life trying to save South Korea during a pivotal moment in the Korean War but was then condemned to death and had to flee to the United States.

title: Liz Goldwyn: Making a Name for Herself
description: LOS ANGELES  The Gala in the Garden, a benefit given every October by the Hammer Museum here, draws a reliably motley cross section of this citys art, fashion and film tribes. While those contingents mingled last fall on the museums third-floor balcony with some of the stiffness of the jocks, brains and beauties mixing at a high school dance, one guest navigated the crowd as effortlessly as a prom queen.

title: Preparing for Coldest Weather in 20 Years
description: After digging out from a winter storm that disrupted air travel across the country and created treacherous road conditions, people from the Upper Midwest to New England are now preparing for the coldest weather they have experienced in years.

title: Schools Chancellor Brings Joyful and Fierce Style
description: Late in the afternoon of New Years Eve, Carmen Faria was preparing to have 10 people over to dinner, a plan, she joked, she wouldnt have made had she known that the next day would mark the beginning of her tenure as the citys new schools chancellor. Perhaps out of a subliminal sense of premonition or foresight, or just grandmotherly efficiency, she had arranged for a caterer.

title: Times Minute | Displaced in South Sudan
description: Also on the Minute, the latest on contraception and the Affordable Care Act, and the marketing of "Inside Llewyn Davis."

title: Times Minute | Displaced in South Sudan
description: In the Video

title: Sending Artworks Home, but to Whom?
description: The paleontologist Richard Leakey has called their removal a sacrilege. Kenyan villagers have said their theft led to crop failure and ailing livestock. It is little wonder, then, that the long, slender wooden East African memorial totems known as vigango are creating a spiritual crisis of sorts for American museums. Many want to return them, but are not finding that so easy.

title: Quick, Get the Camera: Fidos Levitating
description: The Paranormal Activity franchise aims straight at its Latino fan base with the fifth installment of the series, The Marked Ones, and the changes  goodbye, white suburbia; hello, gritty diversity  recharge the batteries somewhat. But theres no escaping that the found-footage phenomenon has gone from fresh and original to just plain annoying.

title: Liberty Media Seeks Full Ownership of Sirius XM
description: Liberty Media already controls Sirius XM. Now, it wants to own the entire company.

title: Fear Keeps Thousands of South Sudanese on the Run
description: AWERIAL, South Sudan  As the city of Bor fell into chaos, Lual Alier watched a fellow teacher pick up a Kalashnikov rifle and kill a shopkeeper. Then the man turned and began firing at him, too.

title: Fleeing the Bombs in Aleppo, Syria, and Ending Up in New Jersey
description: PATERSON, N.J.  They had heard the bombs before, but never this close. They gathered whatever was at hand  a purse, a bag containing their passports  ran out of their house in Aleppo, in northern Syria and headed on foot to a quieter neighborhood. There, they figured, they would wait out the fighting and return home.

title: Sunday A/X Pairs at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
description: The winners of the Sunday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last Sunday were Janet and R. Jay Becker of New York City. They were one day shy of celebrating their first wedding anniversary.

title: Syrians Protest Assad and Islamist Militants
description: As my colleagues Hwaida Saad and Rick Gladstone report, Syrian opposition activists said that an alliance of seven rebel groups launched attacks across northern Syria on Friday against the jihadist militants who call themselves the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS  a powerful Qaeda affiliate that includes foreign fighters.

title: Make a Resolution to Budget? Here Are Some Apps to Help
description: Theres something brilliant, but also insidious, about services like Amazon Prime, where you dont have to reach for your credit card to pay. Spending is painless.

title: A Cult Motorcycle From India Takes On the World
description: NEW DELHI, India  The Royal Enfield Bullet, often described as the oldest continuously produced motorcycle in the world, is a cult product for enthusiasts who love it for its vintage feel as much as for the thrum of its engine.

title: Video and Images of the Crisis in South Sudan
description: As my colleague Nicholas Kulish reported, thousands of South Sudanese have fled their homes in recent days as fighting between forces loyal to the government of President Salva Kiir have fought against a rebellion led by his former vice president, Riek Machar, plunging the young nation into chaos.

title: Words to Banish From the New Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Let It Snow
description: The first snowstorm of 2014 left nearly a foot of slush in some neighborhoods Friday, with freezing wind. As snowplows cleared roads, there were subway delays, but many New Yorkers made it to work.

title: Testimony of the National Intelligence Director
description: To the Editor:

title: The Future of Broadband
description: To the Editor:

title: Employees and Arbitration
description: To the Editor:

title: Coughing at Concerts
description: To the Editor:

title: An Error Message for the Poor
description: WASHINGTON  MORE than two million people have signed up for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act, a tribute to the effectiveness of the tech surge the Obama administration deployed to overcome the highly publicized problems with HealthCare.gov that emerged in October. The websites initial rollout will long stand as a monument to how badly technology contracting can go wrong. But the remarkable recovery also demonstrates what a determined response to such bungling can achieve.

title: Brazil Is Abuzz About Snowden
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  When I visited China in June, my trip happened to coincide with the discovery that Edward Snowden was hiding out in Hong Kong. By then, Snowdens revelations about the voracious data-collection operation by the National Security Agency was front-page news all over the world. Snowden hadnt yet been charged for the leak of tens of thousands of pages of classified N.S.A. documents, but it was clear that it was coming. So it was only natural to ask  as many journalists did  would Hong Kong give Snowden asylum if he requested it?

title: Visits With School Pals Are a Touchstone on Presidents Trips to Hawaii
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has called Hawaii his refuge, and so it has been throughout his political life. In 2006, Mr. Obama used the family Christmas holiday there to decide whether to run for president. For the past two weeks, he has been recharging on Oahu after an unpleasant year in the job.

title: Susan Rasky, Award-Winning Reporter for The Times, Dies at 61
description: Susan F. Rasky, a former political reporter for The New York Times who won a George Polk Award for her coverage of the congressional budget crisis in 1990, died on Dec. 29 at her home in El Cerrito, Calif. She was 61.

title: Prosaic Pipe Stymied Seattles Big Bertha
description: SEATTLE  The unknown object buried beneath this city, big enough to stop the worlds largest-diameter tunnel-boring machine in its tracks last month and tantalizing enough in its mystery to set off a cottage industry of wispy romantic speculation, turns out to be an ordinary metal pipe, tunnel engineers said Friday.

title: Indoctrinating Religious Warriors
description: In 2009, the gap between the share of Republicans and Democrats who believed in evolution was just 10 percentage points, 54 percent and 64 percent, respectively.

title: Mystery in Hezbollah Operatives Life and Death
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As a little girl, Noor did not know exactly what her father, Hassane Laqees, did for Hezbollah, but even then, she knew she might lose him early. During his long absences, she recalled recently, she would gaze at a photo of him lying asleep and imagine that she was seeing his corpse.

title: Architects Sentence in Death of Firefighter Angers Fire Crews
description: LOS ANGELES  The blaze broke out in an opulent new Hollywood Hills home that was scheduled to be the set for a television series, Germanys Next Top Model, just a few days later. Flames escaped from a fireplace  designed for outdoor use, but installed indoors in violation of the fire code on the homes top floor by Gerhard Albert Becker, a wealthy German architect.

title: Solar Power Craze on Wall St. Propels Start-Up
description: The first inklings of the idea came to Elon Musk and a cousin in an R.V. heading to the Burning Man festival in 2004.

title: Pictures from The Week in Business
description: Latvia adopts the euro, small-scale gold mining in Indonesia poses risks and and the expansion of the Panama Canal may be halted.

title: George Goodman, Who Demystified the World of Money, Dies at 83
description: George J. W. Goodman, who demystified financial complexities in best-selling books and on a long-running public television program under the name of one of historys most famous economists, Adam Smith, died on Friday in Miami. He was 83.

title: Chaplains Plantation Reference at de Blasio Inauguration Gains Defenders
description: The Rev. Frederick A. Lucas Jr. stepped to the dais at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday as a pastor with impressive mainstream credentials. A Harvard-educated minister, he was on clergy committees for President Bill Clinton and President George W. Bush and serves as a chaplain for the Sanitation Department.

title: Tangled Role in G.O.P. War Over Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  In the year since he stepped down from Congress, Steven C. LaTourette, a Republican from Ohio, has emerged as one of the top generals in the establishment Republicans war against the Tea Party.

title: Auburns Offense Runs to a Hip-Hop Beat
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  It was early December, and Auburn had secured a berth in the national title game. The final minutes of the Southeastern Conference championship game ticked away. Two running backs stood together on the sideline.

title: Medical Center Hires Lhota as an Executive
description: As Bill de Blasio settles into City Hall, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican who ran against him for mayor, is also getting a new job.

title: The Ticking Mideast Clock
description: Five months into the latest American effort to nudge Israelis and Palestinians toward a peace agreement, the one party clearly committed to a deal is the United States. This week, Secretary of State John Kerry made his 10th trip to the region to get the two sides to stick the timetable he set forth when he started new negotiations last July.

title: School Experiment That Burned Boy Was Focus of Federal Warning
description: Only weeks before a chemistry experiment sent a plume of fire across a Manhattan high school science lab, engulfing two students and leaving one with life-threatening burns, a federal safety agency issued a video warning of the dangers of the very same experiment, a common one across the country.

title: Not Getting Their Moneys Worth
description: At first glance, two recent crises to hit the White House  the revelations about unlawful surveillance and the botched health care rollout  have nothing in common. But each is a reminder of the increasing extent to which government work has been contracted out to private-sector companies. Currently, Washington spends about $500 billion a year on private-sector contracts, more than twice the amount in 2000.

title: Stopping Mentally Ill Gun Buyers
description: Rebuffed by Congress on stronger gun safety laws, President Obama is wisely using use his executive powers in a more focused attempt to bar mentally ill people from eluding federal watch lists and purchasing firearms. Two sensible changes proposed for the background check system would allow states and mental health providers more discretion than they have now in reporting information about potentially violent people.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 3, 2014
Governor Cuomos Stingy Pardons
description: The power to grant clemency is a critical function of the executive branch. It serves as a last, case-by-case resort to remedy an unjustly long sentence, erase a wrongful conviction or show forgiveness where it is merited. But New Yorkers seeking clemency from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, either from within prison or after their release, have found virtually no consolation during the three years of his tenure.

title: Academy Ballots of Our Own
description: The critics make their Oscar choices.

title: U.S. Is Facing Hard Choices in South Sudan
description: WASHINGTON  South Sudan is in many ways an American creation, carved out of war-torn Sudan in a referendum largely orchestrated by the United States, its fragile institutions nurtured with billions of dollars in American aid. But a murky, vicious conflict there has left the Obama administration scrambling to prevent the unraveling of a major American achievement in Africa.

title: A Brain Is Dead, a Heart Beats On
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It started out as an operation to treat an increasingly common medical problem in America, childhood sleep apnea. It has become an anguished fight over the fate of a 13-year-old girl who, though pronounced legally dead by doctors, remains alive in the opinion of her religious parents.

title: Family of Caddies and Players Stays Close
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Long before the golfer Mallory Blackwelder was even a sparkle in their eyes, her mother, Myra, was playing on the L.P.G.A. Tour, and her father, Worth, was a professional tour caddie.

title: A Desperate River Crossing
description: Residents of Bor, a city in the Republic of South Sudan, fled deadly violence there by taking ferries across the White Nile to Awerial, where an estimated 76,000 displaced people are stranded.

title: Security Official Moves to White House
description: Rand Beers, a counterterrorism official at the Homeland Security Department, will leave the agency to work as a senior adviser to President Obama, administration officials said Friday. Mr. Beers will be a deputy assistant to the president on the National Security Council staff, the officials said. Mr. Beers served as acting secretary of homeland security for several months last year.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 4, 2014
description: For 63 years, I lived with the stigma of being a traitor. The truth is I helped save South Korea during one of its most critical times.

title: Corrections: January 4, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Offering Help in Passing
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I take back what I said yesterday about the question marks. There are quite a few of those today, but its O.K.; with those question marks comes a lot of fun wordplay.

title: Lower East Side Students Have a Gift of Uniforms, and Better Focus
description: The school day is over, yet the majority of students at Public School 188 will happily continue to wear their uniforms well into the early evening hours.

title: Once a Criminal, Hes Now a Victim, Shot Twice in a Year
description: New Years Eve, 2012: Richard Dunbar, 52, spent the night in Brooklyn with his sister and her family, two little-bitty nephews, he recalled. They watched the ball drop on television. Nice night.

title: Returning of Refugees to Bulgaria Worries U.N.
description: GENEVA  European countries should stop returning asylum seekers to Bulgaria, because they could face inhuman and degrading treatment in Bulgarias reception centers, which have been stretched thin by a rising number of arrivals, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday.

title: Modesty, With a Little Smoldering
description: I thought that if Nancy Reagan and Jackie Kennedy were the first ladies of the White House, then Gloria was the first lady of the Gaines house, said Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for Lee Daniels The Butler. Inspired by the real-life story of Eugene Allen, the film follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (portrayed by Forest Whitaker), and his wife, Gloria, as history, particularly the civil rights movement, unfolds over seven presidential administrations.

title: Deadly Violence Erupts During Rallies Across Egypt
description: CAIRO  At least 13 people were killed as violence broke out during Muslim Brotherhood marches in several Egyptian cities on Friday, health officials said, in the deadliest day of clashes in months.

title: Councilwoman Bruised Feelings in Zoning Fight
description: If she becomes, as appears likely, the next speaker of the New York City Council, Councilwoman Melissa Mark-Viverito of East Harlem has vowed to listen to all groups, treat everyone fairly and be a paragon of transparency.

title: Knicks Shumpert Rediscovers His Shot, and His Smile
description: HOUSTON  Even as Iman Shumpert was going scoreless against teams like the Toronto Raptors and the Boston Celtics in recent weeks, he tried to insulate himself from the noise.

title: Turning Point for Nets? Victory Over Oklahoma City Did Trick Last Season
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  It was hard to ignore the coincidence.

title: Gunman Fires at Moving S.U.V. in Queens, Killing One and Wounding Three Others
description: A gunman opened fire on an S.U.V. in Springfield Gardens in Queens on Friday afternoon, killing a longtime friend of the rapper 50 Cent and wounding three other people inside, according to the police and witnesses.

title: Mental Lapse at Finish Wastes 47 Good Minutes From the Knicks
description: HOUSTON  The Knicks had done what they could to survive against the Rockets for more than 47 minutes at the Toyota Center on Friday night. They had hustled. They had rebounded. They had defended, at least for stretches.

title: Juanita Moore, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 99
description: Juanita Moore, who earned an Academy Award nomination in 1960 for the single major film role she ever landed, then fell through the cracks of a Hollywood system that had little to offer a black actress besides small parts as maids and nannies, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 99.

title: Dr. W.V. Cordice Jr., 94, a Surgeon Who Helped Save Dr. King, Dies
description: On Sept. 20, 1958, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., then emerging as the leader of the civil rights movement, was autographing copies of his new book in a Harlem department store when a woman approached to greet him. He nodded without looking up. Then she stabbed him in the chest with a razor-sharp seven-inch letter opener.

title: Winter Wallop
description: Scenes from across New York City on Friday after a powerful storm brought snow, bitterly cold temperatures and heavy winds.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared in December
description: How the auto industry fared in December 2013.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey (above, seated) portrays Portia Nathan, a Princeton admissions officer who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of applicants aspiring to the universitys ivy-covered halls. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princetons place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted? A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. And I must confess that I dont know whether to be relieved or disappointed that Admission, which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment. Mr. Weitz lines up a target placed at the explosive intersection of class, race, region and every other source of societal anguish, and then does not so much miss as aim in another direction  or several  letting fly a volley of darts that land as lightly as badminton birdies. Still, Ms. Fey and Mr. Rudd are fun to watch, though not as much fun as they might have been in a riskier, crazier movie, he said, adding that the best scenes belong to Lily Tomlin, brilliantly cast as Portias mother, an unbowed second-wave woman warrior with a pair of borzois and a Bella Abzug tattoo.

title: Cambodia Cracks Down on Protest With Evictions and Ban on Assembly
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Seeking to quash one of the most serious challenges to the nearly 30-year rule of the countrys authoritarian leader, Cambodian authorities evicted antigovernment protesters on Saturday from a public square and banned all public gatherings as a court summoned two opposition leaders for police questioning.

title: Obama Urges Congress to Restore Unemployment Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, seeking the upper hand with Congress as he heads back from his Hawaiian vacation, insisted on Saturday that lawmakers make restoring unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are out of work their first order of business in the new year.

title: Do Animals Have a Sweet Tooth?
description: No preference is so quick to form, and none so hard to lose, as a babys love for sweets. Give a newborn a drop of sugar water when hes hours old, and hell suckle. At a dental school in Jerusalem in the early 1970s, a scientist named Jacob E. Steiner doled out sucrose to 175 infants before theyd had a drop of mothers milk and saw clear signs of satisfaction: The babies showed a marked relaxation of the facial muscle, he wrote, and a retraction of the mouths angles resembling a smile.  Then he tried the same experiment on several babies born without a cerebral cortex and found the same result. The joy of sugar needs no cogitation; it scarcely needs a brain.

title: In Fervent Support of the Gap Year
description: I wasnt enthusiastic when my daughter first floated her plan to take a gap year before college. As someone who couldnt wait to matriculate, I didnt see the point of delaying that great intellectual awakening. I felt vaguely disappointed that she wasnt more eager to embrace all those books and ideas and late-night conversations about the cosmos. And what if her gap year turned into a permanent crevasse and she never earned a degree?

title: Putin Eases Protest Ban in Sochi for the Olympics
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin on Saturday eased a sweeping ban on public protests in Sochi, Russia, starting on Tuesday and continuing through the Olympic Games next month and the Paralympic Games in March.
