However, any demonstrations will require approval in advance from the authorities.

title: Phil Everly, Half of a Pioneer Rock Duo That Inspired Generations, Dies at 74
description: Phil Everly, whose hits with his older brother, Don, as the Everly Brothers carried the close fraternal harmonies of country tradition into pioneering rock n roll, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 74.

title: TabTale Cranks Up Its Game-Making Machine
description: Youve probably never heard of a company called TabTale. But if youve ever used an iPad or smartphone to entertain young children (as many parents do), you may very well have downloaded one of its hundreds of animated games or interactive books on topics like virtual cupcake baking and doctors who heal zombies. (I personally wasted an enjoyable hour this week playing Santa Rescue Challenge, one of the companys recently released holiday titles.)

title: Boeing Workers Approve 8-Year Contract Extension
description: Boeing workers narrowly approved an eight-year contract extension, their union announced late Friday, in a move that will assure production of Boeings new 777X aircraft in the Puget Sound area.

title: Happy New Year?
description: Theres an alarming amount of optimism out there about US economic prospects for 2014. Let me make the situation even more alarming by saying that I basically share that optimism.

title: 1914: Amazingly Popular Dance Causes Widespread Social Controversy
description: Never has a dance been so much discussed, defended and denounced as has the tango, the extraordinary terpsichorean craze which has swept over the whole of Europe and the United States. Society leaders have condemned unsparingly, bishops have shuddered, royalty has expressed uncompromising disapproval, and the tango is still danced with fervor by tens of thousands. It cannot be denied that the tango in its original form would have shocked the most Bohemian society. The very name  tango, I touch has a significance which needs no comment. But it is a far cry from the original as it was danced in the most undesirable cafs of the Argentine to the severely Bowdlerized version tolerated in the modern ballroom. It is believed that the tango is of Spanish origin, and was taken to South America by Spanish settlers.

title: Spate of Injuries in N.H.L. Keeps Olympic Rosters in Flux Worldwide
description: Picking an Olympic roster is tricky enough, but a rash of injuries in the N.H.L. this season is making it harder than ever. Toronto Coach Randy Carlyle noted at the end of December that 108 players were out, 15 percent of the league. That number includes some of the biggest stars among the medal contenders for the Sochi Games, players like Canadas Steven Stamkos, Slovakias Marian Gaborik, Swedens Alex Steen and Russias Evgeni Malkin.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What A Good Year Wont Prove
description: A brief addendum to my last post. If 2014 is a year of relatively good growth, you know that many people will take that as somehow refuting Keynesianism  hey, didnt you guys predict that the economy would never recover without fiscal stimulus?

title: For Nets and Knicks Fans, a Midwinter Nights Dream
description: The Knicks fan and the Nets fan settled on the couch, in front of the television, on a snowy, frigid Thursday night. Each held a bottle of Pepto-Bismol, bracing for more stomach pain in a furiously retching season.

title: Afghanistans Worsening, and Baffling, Hunger Crisis
description: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan  In the Bost Hospital here, a teenage mother named Bibi Sherina sits on a bed in the severe acute malnutrition ward with her two children. Ahmed, at just 3 months old, looks bigger than his emaciated brother Mohammad, who is a year and a half and weighs 10 pounds.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 5
description: C.E.O.s can look forward and say, I dont see any near-term economic bumps.

title: How a First Career Enhanced a Second
description: What happens when the career you were born to pursue becomes the wrong career when you reach your mid-30s?

title: Variety: A Lost Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I have a love/oh-no-not-again relationship with diagramless puzzles. Theyre good for the ego in the sense that the clues are exceptionally easy, and the clues are easy because the main point is to figure out where the entries go. Thats the part thats not so much fun for me.

title: You Cant Take It With You, but You Still Want More
description: All work and no play may just be a result of mindless accumulation.

title: Ice Dancing, Adored and Mocked, Could Give Americans a Lone Gold
description: CANTON, Mich.  Olympic ice dancing is widely appealing to audiences, but it has been frequently mocked as a dubious competition, fraught with predetermined outcomes, almost impossible to judge objectively. An existential question lurks: Is rumba really a sport?

title: Afghanistans Child Hunger Crisis
description: Hospitals around the country have been swamped by a wave of malnourished children in the past year, but the causes are unclear.

title: Listen to Pandora, and It Listens Back
description: Pandora, the Internet radio service, is plying a new tune.

title: Afghanistans Unexplained Hunger Crisis
description: Throughout Afghanistan, there is what doctors call acute severe malnutrition. Most of the cases are seen in children under the age of 5.

title: Please, Theres No Need to Shout
description: The Haggler has been described by more than a few people as a congenital grump, and this is often framed in negative terms. The Haggler, though, believes that his congenital grumpiness is among his more appealing characteristics, right up there with this fondness for the word congenital.

title: Help the Working Poor, but Share the Burden
description: In a speech last month, President Obama brought renewed attention to economic disparities in the United States. The gap between rich and poor is indeed substantial  much larger than in most developed nations and much larger than it was 40 years ago. So what is the best way to help those struggling at the bottom of the economic ladder?

title: A Roadblock to Brawny Bank Reform
description: Regulators made some real progress last year attacking the risks of too-big-to-fail banks. The Volcker Rule and other Dodd-Frank reforms were completed, and, perhaps even more important,three big regulators devised a proposal for tougher capital rules intended to ensure that banks would never require a government bailout when their risky bets went bad.

title: Karen Abramson, on Going to the Front Lines
description: This interview with  Karen Abramson, chief executive of Wolters Kluwer Tax & Accounting, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Finding Her Teaching Voice
A Backward Rule and a Baseball Hall Backlog
description: It happens every winter. An overstuffed, unwieldy collection of voters, some much more qualified and conscientious than others, holds an election to bestow the highest honor of a cherished American institution. It is a secretive process in a world that, more and more, craves transparency.

title: Denvers McGee Not Just Any Tall Drink of Water
description: Explaining JaVale McGee to the uninitiated can be difficult.

title: A Marriott for the Hip Crowd
description: To lure a younger consumer Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.

title: Militant Tied to Bombings in Lebanon Dies in Jail
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The leader of a Lebanon-based affiliate of Al Qaeda who was arrested recently died Saturday while in custody in Lebanon, officials said.

title: Packers Fever Cools a Bit, and the Explanation Is Complex
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The Stadium View Bar & Grille, as the name implies, stands one long block from Lambeau Field, at the corner of Holmgren Way and Brett Favre Pass. Through large windows and behind a 20-foot-tall replica of the Lombardi Trophy, the brick facade of Lambeau rises in the distance down Armed Forces Drive, a sort of Champs-lyses for cheeseheads.

title: Qaeda-Linked Militants in Iraq Secure Nearly Full Control of Falluja
description: BAGHDAD  Sunni militants fighting under the banner of Al Qaeda appeared to make gains across Anbar Province on Saturday, using snipers and rocket-propelled grenades in heavy street fighting as they secured nearly full control of Falluja and captured the strategic town Karma. Government forces and the tribal militias fighting with them seemed unable to resist the militants advances.

title: But It Doesnt Look Like a Marriott
description: J.W. Marriott Jr., the 81-year-old chairman of Marriott International, flew to London in September to inspect his companys new jewel: Edition, a sumptuous boutique hotel intended to anchor a new 100-city chain  the next W, if Marriott has its way. But Mr. Marriott did not stay overnight at the London Edition, as the new property is known, with its laser-lighted nightclub and guest-room paintings of women wearing toilet-paper turbans. He bedded down at Grosvenor House, one of the companys more traditional luxury hotels.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Treating Mental Illness
description: Readers react to a call for better coverage for psychiatric care.

title: Making a Living (and a Life) Abroad
description: Some Americans have taken advantage of technology and a globalized economy to work and live in other countries.

title: The Roots Stay Strong at Auburn
description: AUBURN, Ala.  There is a tree sculpture inside the Auburn Art store, a replica of an oak that towered over the entrance to Auburn University for decades.

title: A College Football Fan Is Born a Weekend at a Time
description: NEW ORLEANS  When my wife, Betsy, and I walked out of our Canal Street hotel here Thursday night to head to the Sugar Bowl, we ran into a colleague of hers who happened to be in town for a wedding.

title: For Obama, a Real and Rare Vacation in Hawaii
description: KAILUA, Hawaii  After a two-week vacation on the windward side of Oahu, ensconced with his family in a private beachfront rental, President Obama prepared on Saturday to return to the chillier clime  both politically and weather-wise  of the nations capital.

title: Management Be Nimble
description: We aspire to be the largest small company in our space.

title: The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Reader
description: TO read a novel is a difficult and complex art, Virginia Woolf wrote in a 1925 essay, How to Read a Book. Today, with our powers of concentration atrophied by the staccato communication of the Internet and attention easily diverted to addictive entertainment on our phones and tablets, book-length reading is harder still.

title: Banished for Questioning the Gospel of Guns
description: BARRY, Ill.  The byline of Dick Metcalf, one of the countrys pre-eminent gun journalists, has gone missing. It has been removed from Guns & Ammo magazine, where his widely-read column once ran on the back page. He no longer stars on a popular television show about firearms. Gun companies have stopped flying him around the world and sending him the latest weapons to review.

title: Bracing for Carp in Great Lakes, but Debating Their Presence
description: After decades of increasingly dire warnings, countless studies and countermeasures, scientists are beginning to mull over hints of something that few of them wish to contemplate: The despised Asian carp may have finally arrived in the Great Lakes.

title: Moves to Curb Spying Help Drive the Clemency Argument for Snowden
description: WASHINGTON  To the prosecutors pursuing him, Edward J. Snowden has committed espionage by divulging national secrets. But the growing backlash against government surveillance has spurred a spirited debate about whether he should be forgiven.

title: Blast Hits Kabul Military Base, and Eastern Afghanistan Bombing Kills American
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An explosion hit one of the entrances to a predominantly American military base in the heart of Kabul on Saturday, hours after a separate suicide bombing in eastern Afghanistan killed an American service member  the first combat casualty of the year.

title: The Invisible Hand Award
description: One last Jerry Goodman post. My friend, classmate, and fellow joke-writer Irwin Collier of the Free University of Berlin sends me the program of the 1976 Adam Smith dinner and Jerrys writeup of his experience (both pdf).

title: De Blasios Long Odds
description: THIS much can be said for Bill de Blasios inauguration, which featured a concentration of left-wing agitprop unseen since the last time Pete Seeger occupied a stage alone: If the waning years of Barack Obamas presidency are going to be defined by a liberal crusade against income inequality, theres no more fitting place to kick it off than New York City.

title: Need-Blind Justice
description: WASHINGTON  FIFTY years ago, in Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court ruled that poor people accused of serious crimes were entitled to lawyers paid for by the government. But the court did not say how the lawyers should be chosen, how much they should be paid or how to make sure they defended their clients with vigor and care.

title: How Insecure Is Your Password?
Compromise: Not a 4-Letter Word
description: FORMER SENATOR ALAN SIMPSON likes to say that if you cant learn to compromise on issues without compromising yourself, you should not be in Congress, be in business or get married. It is amazing how many people violate that rule, but especially in Congress and especially among the Tea Party types, where calling someone a deal maker is now the ultimate put down. What makes it crazier is that in American education, innovation and commerce today, collaboration is being taught and rewarded as the best way to do anything big, important and complex. Indeed, in Silicon Valley, a collaborator means someone with whom youre building something great. In D.C., it means someone committing political treason by working with the other party. And that is why Silicon Valley is now the turbo-engine of our economy and D.C. is the dead hand.

title: First Up, Mental Illness. Next Topic Is Up to You.
description: THOSE of us in the pundit world tend to blather on about what happened yesterday, while often ignoring what happens every day. We stir up topics already on the agenda, but we falter at calling attention to crucial-but-neglected issues.

title: Stephen Kellert
description: Stephen Kellert is a social ecologist and senior research scholar at Yale Universitys School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. He has written several books and produced a documentary about so-called biophilic design, which goes beyond sustainability to integrate and connect people with the natural world.

title: One Marines Dying Wish
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  WE dont get any say about the kind of world were born into  about whether its prepared for the likes of us, whether it will open its arms. Hal Faulkner certainly didnt get the world he deserved. It was needlessly cruel to him, senselessly judgmental. For the most part, he made peace with that.

title: The Commish, the 2nd Time Around
description: BILL BRATTONS biggest problem right now might not be stop-and-frisk.

title: Can Upward Mobility Cost You Your Health?
description: Americans love a good rags-to-riches story. Even in an age of soaring inequality, we like to think that people can still make it big here if they work hard and stay out of trouble. The socioeconomic reality of most of the last four decades  stagnant wages, soaring income and wealth inequality, and reduced equality of opportunity  have dented, but not destroyed, the appeal of the American dream.

title: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
description: WASHINGTON  To many Americans, the war on poverty declared 50 years ago by President Lyndon B. Johnson has largely failed. The poverty rate has fallen only to 15 percent from 19 percent in two generations, and 46 million Americans live in households where the government considers their income scarcely adequate.

title: Path to Casinos Turns Messy in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  When Massachusetts finally gave in after decades of resistance and decided two years ago to legalize casino gambling, it seemed a relatively easy way to fill the states recession-battered coffers.

title: A Lonely Quest for Facts on Genetically Modified Crops
description: KONA, Hawaii  From the moment the bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced in May 2013, it garnered more vocal support than any the County Council here had ever considered, even the perennially popular bids to decriminalize marijuana.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 5
description: As lawmakers return to Capitol Hill this week, President Obama urged them to restore unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are without work. The program was cut in the two-year budget passed before the holidays.

title: Why Everyone Seems to Have Cancer
description: EVERY New Year when the government publishes its Report to the Nation on the Status of Cancer, it is followed by a familiar lament. We are losing the war against cancer.

title: Declining Lethality
description: Since 1958, the death rates from heart disease and stroke have declined more than those from cancer.

title: Warming Up for Australian Open, Williams Beats Azarenka in Brisbane
description: BRISBANE, Australia  Serena Williams began this season in the same pose she ended the last, her right heel lifted slightly off the ground, her arms high over her head, her hands grasping yet another trophy.

title: Why Do We Fear the Blind?
description: BRISTOL, R.I.  A FEW years ago, when I mentioned to a woman I met at a party that I was teaching in a school for the blind, she seemed confused. Can I just ask you one question? she said. How do you talk to your students?

title: Happy New Year, Politicians. Seriously.
description: GAIL COLLINS: Happy New Year, David! Im glad youre back and that were going to start conversing again. What are you expecting, politically speaking, for 2014? It doesnt really seem possible that things could get much worse.

title: Small Plane Makes an Emergency Landing on a Highway in the Bronx
description: A single-engine plane made an emergency landing on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon, officials said. No one was seriously injured.

title: Rampant Prosecutorial Misconduct
description: In the justice system, prosecutors have the power to decide what criminal charges to bring, and since 97 percent of cases are resolved without a trial, those decisions are almost always the most important factor in the outcome. That is why it is so important for prosecutors to play fair, not just to win. This obligation is embodied in the Supreme Courts 1963 holding in Brady v. Maryland, which required prosecutors to provide the defense with any exculpatory evidence that could materially affect a verdict or sentence.

title: Putting Drones to the Test
description: Drones will soon take to the skies across the United States in federally approved tests that are meant to clear the way for the commercial use of unmanned aircraft. But before that happens, lawmakers and regulators need to deal with a host of unresolved privacy and safety concerns.

title: The Marijuana Experiment
description: On New Years Day, government-licensed recreational marijuana shops opened in Colorado, the first place in the world to regulate the drug from seed to sale. Later in 2014, marijuana retailers will open in Washington State. As public opinion shifts away from prohibition, these two states will serve as test cases for full-on legalization. Heres what to watch for in the early stages of this experiment:

title: Health Care in America
description: Michael Moore called Obamacare both awful and a godsend. Readers offer their opinions.

title: 50 Years of Poverty
description: While government programs have kept millions of people, especially the elderly, from falling into poverty, rates remain high for many groups of Americans, including children, blacks and Hispanics.

title: 'Tony Bargains' Helps Bronx's Needy
description: Anthony Cody, a former inmate and homeless drug addict known as Tony Bargains, has turned a crack house on Boston Road into a thrift store for the needy.

title: New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws
description: ALBANY  Joining a growing group of states that have loosened restrictions on marijuana, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York plans this week to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of the drug by those with serious illnesses, state officials say.

title: Inside Llewyn Davis Gets Critics Societys Vote
description: Updated, 1:10 p.m. | The National Society of Film Critics crowned Inside Llewyn Davis as its best picture on Saturday, with the Davis filmmakers, Joel and Ethan Coen, taking the director prize.

title: Your Submissions for Most Neglected Topic
description: My Sunday column invites readers to submit the issues they believe are most neglected by the news media and that deserve more coverage in 2014. My own suggestion, which my column focuses on, is mental health. So if you have a suggestion for an issue that you think is of national or global importance but isnt getting adequate coverage, please post below and explain why. I hope to stitch together a column based on some of your best entries.

title: N.F.L. Wild Card Saturday
description: Highlights from Saturdays N.F.L. playoff games.

title: Clued In
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Wow. Look at that grid. Are you intimidated by that grid?

title: Harvey K. Littleton, a Pioneer in the Art of Glass, Dies at 91
description: Harvey K. Littleton, an artist who helped found the so-called studio glass movement in the United States, developing and teaching do-it-yourself techniques that freed glassblowing from the cumbersome protocols of factory production and made molten glass almost as easy to work with in the studio as wet clay, died on Dec. 13 in Spruce Pine, N.C. He was 91.

title: Ecuadorean Navy Delivers for Amazon Chief
description: The Ecuadorean Navy offered Jeff Bezos same-day shipping on an Amazon Prime package: Mr. Bezos himself.

title: Saul Zaentz, Producer of Oscar-Winning Movies, Dies at 92
description: Saul Zaentz, an acclaimed independent film producer who adapted literary works for the screen and won best-picture Academy Awards for One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest, Amadeus and The English Patient, died on Friday at his apartment in San Francisco. He was 92.

title: Opposition Party Boycotting Bangladesh Election
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  As Bangladesh prepared for general elections on Sunday, a truck driver named Nur Islam was trying to haul a load of potatoes to Dhaka, the capital, along a route he knew would be targeted by protesters allied with the opposition.

title: Home From Tour and Back on Ballot, Singer Finds a Reason to Campaign
description: MEDINA, Tex.  Kinky Friedman practiced his smile as he sat on the front porch of his cabin on a secluded Hill Country ranch in December, three dogs scampering around his legs. He said he had gotten an instructive tip from a former Miss Mississippi.

title: Tunes for the New Year From the Home Team
description: Less than a month ago, a guide to prominent 2014 releases from Texas artists would have begun with a long-rumored Beyonc album. Although she took that off the plate with her headline-grabbing stealth release on Dec. 13, a robust selection remains of Texans planning on ringing in the first part of the year with new albums. Our roundup  which ranges from a pair of Houston-based alternative rock acts to celebrated veterans branching out in new directions  hints at what the year may bring. And sets from Don Henley, the Austin rock band Spoon and the Old 97s, although still unscheduled, are on the horizon.

title: Texas Right to Life Criticized for Playing Politics With Ratings
description: A rift on how to regulate end-of-life care that broke out during last years legislative session has carried over into this years election cycle.

title: As Perry Exits, His Appointees Look for Havens
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: Saying Farewell to a Rock Icon
description: Phil Everly, as half of the Everly Brothers, inspired the Beatles, Linda Ronstadt, Simon and Garfunkel and many others who recorded their songs and tried to emulate their ringing vocal alchemy.

title: A League Less Nimble as Point Guards Go Down
description: When the Los Angeles Clippers Chris Paul came careening off a screen  as he does so often during a game  and crashed to the floor Friday night in Dallas, separating his right shoulder, he joined what has become a distinguished list: ailing N.B.A. point guards.

title: Donald H. Forst, Feisty Newspaper Editor, Dies at 81
description: Donald H. Forst, the feisty former top editor of New York Newsday, The Village Voice and The Boston Herald, died on Saturday in Albany. He was 81.

title: Overwhelmed Early, Colts Overcome Chiefs With Huge Comeback
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The ball flew from the arms of Indianapolis running back Donald Brown, and with it, perhaps, went the Colts season. The ball bounced, though, off the back of an offensive lineman and then, like a trained dog, returned to the feet of quarterback Andrew Luck. He scooped it up, hopped and lunged, arms outstretched, into the end zone for a fourth-quarter touchdown.

title: Webster Strengthens Grip on the Collegiate Game
description: The Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship highlighted Webster Universitys unchallenged dominance of collegiate chess.

title: After Decades of Unexplained Mood Swings, a Quiet Place to Call Home
description: For the first 54 years of her life, Cheryl McCray did not understand why she flew off the handle and suffered such violent mood swings.

title: Charred Body of Kidnapped Man Is Found on Long Island
description: The charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer who was kidnapped Thursday near his Brooklyn office has been found in a smoldering trash bin outside a Long Island gas station, the police said on Saturday.

title: South Sudan and Rebels Open Peace Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The South Sudanese government and representatives of rebel forces met for the formal opening of peace talks Saturday evening in Ethiopia, part of the diplomatic effort to halt weeks of fighting in the young nation.

title: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The images of recent days have an eerie familiarity, as if the horrors of the past decade were being played back: masked gunmen recapturing the Iraqi cities of Falluja and Ramadi, where so many American soldiers died fighting them. Car bombs exploding amid the elegance of downtown Beirut. The charnel house of Syrias worsening civil war.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 4, 2014
Plane Uses Bronx Highway for Runway
description: Bystanders described the scene after the pilot of a small plane pulled off a successful emergency landing on the northbound lane of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon.

title: A Struggle Over the Jordan Valley
description: As a strategic corridor along the West Bank border with Jordan, the Jordan Valley holds deep meaning for many.

title: Strategic Corridor in West Bank Remains a Stumbling Block in Mideast Talks
description: BARDALA, West Bank  The residents of this neglected Palestinian farming village in the northern Jordan Valley area of the West Bank say they get running water once every three days, which they store in bottles and cisterns.

title: New Year, New Nets With Back-to-Back Wins
description: After beating Oklahoma City on the road Thursday, the Nets returned home Saturday feeling about as pleased with themselves as they had since  well, lets say October, before the season, when hope and hype for the team were at an apex.

title: Elizabeth Goff and Russel Santillanes
description: Elizabeth Jeanne Goff and Russel Edward Santillanes were married Saturday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: AnnaRose King and Michael Telis
description: AnnaRose McLaughlin King, a daughter of the Rev. Alison T. Moore of Brookline, Mass., and the late Roger M. King, was married Saturday to Michael Charles Telis, a son of Karen A. Telis and Dr. Sherman H. Telis of Washington. The brides mother, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space in Brooklyn, with Rabbi Richard Davis assisting.

title: Rochelle Behrens and Sacha Litman
description: Rochelle Alexis Behrens and Sacha Frdric Litman were married Saturday evening at the Rancho Bernardo Inn and Resort in San Diego. Rabbi Deborah R. Prinz officiated, with Rabbi Marc Baker assisting.

title: Amira Ibrahim and Nathan Bliss
description: Amira Tumbaga Ibrahim and Nathan Joseph Bliss were married Saturday at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. The Rev. Constance Hulla, the pastor at the Coney Island Gospel Assembly Church, officiated.

title: Teammates, On Court and Off
description: Rachel Esther Rosenberg and Evan Stuart Levine were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Getzel Davis, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: Alexandra Andrews, Christopher Beha
description: Alexandra Drury Andrews and Christopher R. Beha were married Saturday at the James Burden Mansion in New York. Sarah Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the ceremony; James J. Beha II, the grooms twin brother, led the couple in their vows and exchange of rings.

title: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel
description: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Jay Spiegel were married on the evening of Jan. 4 in what the guests had been told was going to be the couples engagement party. Rabbi Esther Lederman led the surprise wedding ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Sina
description: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Daniel Sina were married Saturday at the Rincon Beach Resort in Aasco, Puerto Rico. Judge Rafael A. Ramos Senz of the municipal court in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, officiated.

title: Teresa LaBarbera, Brandon Dufour
description: Teresa Anne LaBarbera and Brandon John Dufour were married Wednesday at the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception in Waterbury, Conn. The Very Rev. John J. Bevins, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Daniella Rohr, Samuel Adelsberg
description: Daniella Esther Rohr, a daughter of Pamela L. Rohr and George Rohr of Manhattan, was married Tuesday to Samuel S. Adelsberg, a son of Rene Adelsberg and Steven Adelsberg of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ruben C. Gober officiated at Spring Studios, an event space in Manhattan.

title: A Romance Goes From Head to Heart
description: Barbara Catherine Galletly and Grant Olney Passmore were married Saturday by the Rev. Davis Bailey, a Presbyterian minister, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: After Long Wait, Good Things Come to Visiting Saints
description: PHILADELPHIA  The New Orleans Saints joined the N.F.L. in 1967 and did not make the playoffs for 20 years. It took the Saints another 13 years to win a playoff game. And Saturday night, 46 seasons after their debut in the N.F.L., they finally won a road playoff game.

title: Low on Funds, Spider-Man Dims Its Last Lights
description: It wouldnt have been a fitting final performance of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark if something hadnt gone wrong.

title: Corrections: January 5, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: On Tour of Mideast, Kerry Says Iran Might Play Role in Syria Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Iran might play a role at the peace talks on Syria in Switzerland this month.

title: Michelle Obama Extends Her Hawaii Vacation
description: HONOLULU  When President Obama departed Hawaii Saturday evening he left behind one notable thing  his wife, Michelle.

title: My Year of Mom Rage
description: Its time to put on pants, and my daughter is sprawled on the floor sobbing. I dont want them! she cries. I dont wike dem! My daughter is 2, and she refuses to wear anything except fancy dresses. Today she is wearing a white Easter dress with a green sash and a big pink flower. Never mind that its winter and we live in Iowa, where its 20 degrees outside. Ive tried reasoning and pleading with her, and finally we reach a compromise. She can wear the dress as long as she wears pants underneath and a sweater. I get the sweater on her. Its pink, so that helps. But not the pants.

title: American Dialect Society Chooses Because as Word of the Year
description: After a year dominated by upstarts like selfie, bitcoin and twerk, the American Dialect Societys Word of the Year honor for 2013 has gone to a seemingly old-hat vocabulary item: because.

title: Urban Dictionarys Next Phase: Global and Mobile
description: Urban Dictionary, the crowdsourced online dictionary, has slowly gained a cult following over the last decade and a half that has turned the bootstrapped site into the default dictionary for the Internet.

title: Jet Skids Into Snowbank at J.F.K. Airport
description: A plane skidded off a taxiway and into a snowbank at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Sunday morning, causing all domestic and international flights to be suspended for two hours while workers salted and sanded taxiways and runways, transportation officials said.

title: In Our Pages: January 6
description: 1914: Hotel Jewelry Thieves Arrested In Paris

title: Founder of Avant-Garde Theater Tackles a New Scene
description: I couldnt pay the rent, said Judith Malina, 87, the artistic director and co-founder of The Living Theater, explaining why a year ago she lost the site of her Lower East Side theater company and the commercial space above it, where she had lived for six years.

title: Low Turnout in Bangladesh Elections Amid Boycott and Violence
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Amid a deepening conflict between Bangladeshs two main political parties, the scene here in the capital as polls opened for the general elections on Sunday was ominous, with black-clad special forces units and soldiers in combat gear patrolling nearly empty boulevards.

title: U.S. Vessel to Aid Ships Stuck in Antarctica
description: TAISHAN, China  Australian officials have asked an American icebreaker to help with the rescue of Chinese and Russian vessels that are surrounded by ice floes off Antarctica, according to an announcement on Sunday by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY A fourth round of the writer Julian Fellowess sudsy British hit about aristocrats and their servants begins as Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery) mourns the death of her husband, Matthew, who was killed on the day of the birth of their baby, George, at the end of last season. But Mary finds motherhood to be scant solace, and Matthews death has left the estates financial future shaky, since he apparently did not leave a will. Meanwhile, Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael) appears to have at long last found love with the editor Michael Gregson (Charles Edwards); Lady Rose (Lily James), the niece of the Earl of Grantham (Hugh Bonneville), stirs things up with her newfound fondness for jazz and her particular appreciation for the singer Jack Ross (Gary Carr); and Isobel Crawley (Penelope Wilton) struggles with her place in the family, now that her son Matthew is no longer in the picture. (Sophie McShera, as Daisy, is above.) The narrative this time around is even more stretched, derivative and repetitive than Season 3s, but almost ingeniously so: It is both utterly predictable and surprisingly addictive, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. Downton Abbey is long past its sell-by date, yet is still remarkably palatable.

title: Eusebio, Who Represented the Best of Soccer and of Portugal, Dies at 71
description: Soccer fans called him the Black Panther, in the manner of the day, because he was from Mozambique, playing for Portugal, but there was little feline about Eusebio. He was big in the beams and solid around the middle even when he was 24 and, for a few magical weeks, the most captivating player of the 1966 World Cup.

title: As Deep Freeze Hits, Moviegoers Return Frozen to Box-Office Top Spot
description: Frozen became the rarest of hits over the weekend: Instead of shuffling off toward DVD, as most movies playing in wide release do after about a month, the Disney musical surged back to the top spot at the North American box office by selling an astounding $20.7 million in tickets. Frozen  benefiting from top-notch reviews, a shortage of family-friendly movies and, perhaps, the thematically appropriate extreme winter weather in much of the United States  has now taken in roughly $297.8 million over its six-week domestic run, for a global total of $639.9 million.

title: Senators Differ Sharply on Penalty for Snowden
description: WASHINGTON  A debate over whether Edward J. Snowden deserves lenience or the strict treatment the Obama administration has demanded for divulging a vast array of national secrets drew sharply opposing views on Sunday from two prominent senators.

title: Fire in Luxury High-Rise Kills One and Displaces Dozens in Hells Kitchen
description: A 27-year-old man was killed and dozens of residents were displaced Sunday in a three-alarm fire at a luxury high-rise building in Hells Kitchen, officials said.

title: Co-Pilot Killed in Plane Crash at Aspen Airport
description: A co-pilot was killed and two other people were injured after a private plane crashed as it tried to land at the Aspen airport in Colorado on Sunday afternoon, officials said.

title: Fresh Fare Is Served Well Chilled
description: Fourteen performers assembled on the old coffee barge under the Brooklyn Bridge during Thursday evenings blizzard for Bargemusics Here and Now winter festival of contemporary fare. With 14 pieces by 13 composers, the program felt somewhat like a potluck dinner where the few tantalizingly accomplished dishes are finished all too soon, leaving you to pick at multiple versions of baked macaroni.

title: U.S. Ambassador Renews Ties to His Ancestral Village
description: A light drizzle was falling on the village of Jilong on the afternoon of Dec. 17 when a large black sport utility vehicle pulled up to a parking area next to the pond. Out of it stepped Gary Locke, the American ambassador, who this month is expected to leave his post and return to his hometown of Seattle. This was Mr. Lockes fifth visit to his ancestral village in the Taishan region of Guangdong Province, and his third and possibly final one as ambassador to China.

title: In Love and Traffic
description: Teresa LaBarbera was the local traffic reporter at WTNH in Connecticut. Brandon Dufour was a driving instructor. When they met on-air during a news segment, the connection was immediate.

title: N.F.L. Wild-Card Sunday
description: Highlights from Sundays N.F.L. playoff games.

title: In Palm Springs, 2 Bonos and Many Hopefuls
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  You know its not a standard Oscar whistle-stop when Bono (BAHN-oh) is the less revered Bono (BONE-oh), Julia Roberts does her best to disprove the orchestras Oh, Pretty Woman introduction music, and your silver-haired table mate introduces himself like this: Hello. I have really bad sinuses.

title: De Blasio Holds Open House at Gracie Mansion, His New Home
description: Gracie Mansion, the buttercream-hued mayoral residence on a bluff overlooking the East River, has stood stately but mostly silent for more than 12 years, its elegant interiors reserved for the formal functions of a mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, who chose to live elsewhere.

title: Bengals Seek Respect, but Chargers Earn It
description: CINCINNATI  Here along the banks of the murky Ohio River, where a generation has wallowed in the futility of the beloved Bengals, the paradigm has shifted: Respect is gained not by reaching the postseason but by winning there.

title: Democrats Press Revival of Jobless Aid That Expired
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats continued on Sunday to argue for restoring long-term unemployment insurance for more than a million Americans who are out of work, days after the benefits lapsed, as lawmakers prepared to return from their recess.

title: A Double Dose of Chekhov
description: A century and a half ago, Anton Chekhov wrote a play while still a medical student. Never performed or published in his lifetime, it was discovered in a locked box years after his death. This sprawling 20-character work, left untitled, has subsequently appeared as Play Without Title, Without Fathers, A Country Scandal, Don Juan in the Russian Manner and as the film Unfinished Piece for the Player Piano.

title: Make It One for My Baby and One More for the Books
description: In The Sutton Place Story, John Cheever describes Deborah, not quite 3 years old, who, because of her home environment, had naturally come to assume that cocktails were the axis of the adult world. She made Martinis in the sand pile and thought all the illustrations of cups, goblets, and glasses in her nursery books were filled with old-fashioneds. Cheever and five other writers who had alcohol much on their minds (and in their livers) are brought together in Olivia Laings The Trip to Echo Spring, a combination of literary analysis, memoir and travelogue that is most beguiling and incisive when rambling through the work and lives of Cheever, Raymond Carver, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, Tennessee Williams and John Berryman.

title: Waltzing Right Past History in Austria
description: VIENNA  A year ago, in the days surrounding the Vienna Philharmonics internationally televised New Years concerts, the orchestra was surrounded by turmoil. This year, not so much.

title: Broken Bow Hairs, Puns and Idiosyncratic Style
description: It is increasingly common for adventurous musicians like Chris Thile to take a mix-and-match approach to programming. Instead of performing a Bach partita or complete sonata in reverential entirety, he might juxtapose movements with eclectic repertory to highlight unlikely connections.

title: A Satire With Targets Not So Well Remembered
description: If New York City did not have its very own Albert Bergeret, we would need to invent  or at least import  him. Since 1974, Mr. Bergeret, the artistic director of the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, has done yeomans work guarding and promoting the peerless operettas and traditions of the English duo for which his company is named. A life without opportunities to hear those witty, wise pieces performed faithfully is not something I care to think about.

title: An Actor Dons His Singer-Songwriter Hat
description: Jeff Danielss folksy monologue Recreational Vehicle is only half as long as its prototype, Arlo Guthries Alices Restaurant. But this rambling true story of a family road trip to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., in a 28-foot Jayco Winnebago driven by Mr. Daniels has a similar thread of absurdist, self-deprecating humor and is almost as funny.

title: Seeking Loved Ones, Including Themselves
description: The actresses Nora Woolley and Kim Katzberg bear a mild resemblance to each other, and that  along with a gift for writing their own material and quick-changing into an array of characters  make them suitable partners for Hip and Darkling, two audacious solo shows paired at the IRT Theater.

title: Strip-Squeezing at the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams
description: The Truscott Board-a-Match Teams competition was held on Dec. 29 and 30, the last two days of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan.

title: Eusbio, 71, Legend of Portuguese Soccer, Dies
description: London  Eusbio, the wonderful soccer player of the 1960s and 1970s, died on Sunday at the age of 71.

title: Bit of Cheesecake
description: Administrivial Cool Article Alert! Constructor extraordinaire Ian Livengood and his J.A.S.A. class were interviewed for DNAinfo New York. You can read more about the class and its members here.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 6
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: America and India
description: Reciprocity on diplomats rights just went out the window.

title: The Children of ThinkFilm
description: ThinkFilm was founded in 2001 as an independent art-house distributor by several former executives at Lionsgate. The company became known for award-winning films like Born Into Brothels and Half Nelson. After the company closed in 2008, many former ThinkFilm employees went on to lead new film businesses.

title: Does Immigration Mean France Is Over?
description: I.

title: Which Path to Control Drinking?
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Time for Congress to Restore Jobless Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Judgments on Edward Snowden and the N.S.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Food and Social Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Defends Shrine Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: Freed Russian Oligarch Leaves Germany for Switzerland With Family
description: BERLIN  Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon recently freed after a decade in prison in Russia, has left Berlin and arrived by train in Switzerland, where he and his wife will oversee their teenage sons return to school, according to a statement from Mr. Khodorkovskys aides, who called the trip a family matter.

title: Hawaii Makes Its Case for Obamas Library: Why Not Bring It to the Beach?
description: HONOLULU  When Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii was asked to appear in a video urging President Obama to make the state the home of his presidential library, the governors appeal was simple and, he said, reflective of the states Aloha spirit.

title: Federer Falls to Hewitt, but Australian Open Awaits
description: BRISBANE, Australia  This stage of Roger Federers career will primarily be measured by his success in fending off younger players, but he finished the first week of his 2014 season with a rare loss to an older foe.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 6
description: SAMSUNG EARNINGS 2014 will be a tough year for Samsung Electronics, the largest cellphone and television maker in the world. Its stock recently took a beating amid concerns of slowing profit growth from smartphone sales, and the company is under pressure to continue releasing innovative new products to compete with Apple and a crop of handset makers in China. On Tuesday, when the South Korean giant is expected to report earnings estimates for the fourth quarter, investors will keep a close eye on the companys sales of cellphones, televisions and other items during the holiday shopping season, the most lucrative time of year for electronics manufacturers.

title: Abolish the Corporate Income Tax
description: BOSTON  JOBS dont grow out of thin air, especially well-paying ones. They require, among other things, companies that are willing to operate where you live. Just ask the Seattle-based District 751 of the machinists union, which was worried that Boeing will build its new 777X airliner someplace far away where it is cheaper to produce. Last month the union offered contract concessions, as its president explained, to ensure the long-term success of Boeing in Washington State. And on Friday, Boeing machinists approved a contract with concessions to keep assembly of the plane in the area.

title: Spains Solar Pullback Threatens Pocketbooks
description: GUILAS, Spain  Six years ago, Justo Cruz Rodrguez, who runs a small business here designing signs, was looking for a way to generate a steady, if modest, pension for himself and his father.

title: Give Rose a Shot at the Hall
description: THE Baseball Hall of Fame will announce its new inductees on Wednesday  a burst of warmth in the cold, diamond-less winter  and the crop of potential inductees includes, for the second straight year, Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.

title: The Bubble Is Back
description: WASHINGTON  IN November, housing starts were up 23 percent, and there was cheering all around. But the crowd would quiet down if it realized that another housing bubble had begun to grow.

title: Two Decades of Change Have Boston Sparkling
description: BOSTON  During the 1988 presidential campaign, Vice President George Bush famously shined a spotlight on the open sewer that was Boston Harbor. He blamed his opponent, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, for failing to clean it up and called the harbor, which was choked with sludge and contaminated with chemicals, the dirtiest body of water in the country.

title: Crack Cocaine Limbo
description: President Obama earned a rare moment of bipartisan acclaim last month when he commuted the sentences of eight long-serving federal prisoners. Their crack cocaine offenses had resulted in the harsh penalties mandated by a sentencing formula that Congress repudiated when it passed the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010. The old formula, under which possession of a quantity of crack earned the same sentence as possession of 100 times that quantity of powdered cocaine, was now recognized as unjust, the president said.

title: In Bid to Be Council Speaker, a Tenants Champion Fights an Uphill Battle
description: In eight years on the City Council, Daniel R. Garodnick has pushed for police reform, rallied with labor leaders in support of paid sick days and fought to preserve middle-class housing in his district.

title: Acing the Course at Chapel Hill
description: Another shameful lesson in the multibillion-dollar entertainment industry euphemistically referred to as collegiate sports is playing out at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. A former professor was indicted on fraud charges last month after running dozens of bogus and no-show courses heavily enrolled with student athletes looking for easy academic credits.

title: Republican Disdain for the Jobless
description: One of the first votes the Senate plans to take when it returns Monday is on restoring unemployment benefits to 1.3 million people who lost them on Dec. 28. Its hard to imagine a more important action for those who have been out of work the longest and for the economy.

title: Iraqis Make Gains Against Militants in Key City
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security forces and their tribal allies made gains in heavy fighting on Sunday in Ramadi, reclaiming parts of the city from Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda, security officials and tribal leaders said.

title: Seminoles Tight Ends Competitive Drive Recalls His Grandfather Nicklaus
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  Nancy OLeary named her second son Nicklaus, her maiden name. She figured he could go by Nick but wanted to honor her parents, Jack and Barbara Nicklaus.

title: Another Step Forward on Okinawa
description: For nearly two decades, Japan and the United States have been mired in a dispute over the American military presence on Okinawa. Late last month,  the two sides took an important step toward resolving the issue when the Okinawa governor, Hirokazu Nakaima, approved a landfill permit clearing the way for construction of a new base on a remote coast of the island. There are still hurdles, but the permit was a significant breakthrough.

title: NBC Begins Swarm of Ads to Lift Today Back to Top
description: The Today show, so accustomed to winning, has grown impatient with losing.

title: $1 Billion as Milestone and Omen
description: Fab.com, an online retailer selling affordable high design, last year seemed as if it could be the next Amazon.

title: Before Signing a Strong Arm, Teams Should Heed Vicks Dark Past
description: PHILADELPHIA  Michael Vick, the quarterback known as much for his rap sheet as his athletic skill, watched the football tumble through the uprights not long before midnight on Saturday and knew his time was up.

title: ThinkFilm, a Short-Lived but Wily Distributor, Still Influences Industry
description: LOS ANGELES  In two weeks, the feisty operatives of an ever tighter, tougher independent film business will gather at the annual Sundance Film Festival.

title: A Developer Is Mourned and Vilified in Brooklyn
description: A day after the charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer was identified in a smoking trash bin on Long Island, more than a thousand mourners gathered for his funeral in the heart of Hasidic Williamsburg. They grieved for the man they called a pillar of his synagogue and his community, a father of eight who had been quick to donate and quick to lend.

title: Does the U.S. Need Another War on Poverty?
Print Starts to Settle Into Its Niches
description: Kevin Kelly is not a dumb guy  far from it actually. As the founding executive editor of Wired and one of the people who helped build The Well, among the earliest online communities, he has done a good job of seeing what is coming next for decades.

title: House G.O.P. Trims Agenda, Looking to Avert Election-Year Trouble
description: WASHINGTON  The do nothing Congress is preparing to do even less.

title: Zero Tolerance, Reconsidered
description: Schools across the country are rethinking zero tolerance discipline policies under which children have been suspended, even arrested, for minor offenses like cursing, getting into shoving matches and other garden-variety misbehavior that in years past would have been resolved with detention or meetings with a childs parents.

title: 49ers Feel Joy, if Not Their Toes
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The bitterly cold forecast for Sundays N.F.C. wild-card game at Lambeau Field concerned San Francisco 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh. So twice, on Saturday and again before kickoff, he asked his quarterback, Colin Kaepernick, to reconsider his plan to play in short sleeves and without gloves.

title: The Muslim Brotherhood, Back in a Fight to Survive
description: FAYOUM, Egypt  They hide in safe houses on the outskirts of this city, talk only fleetingly on cellphones and avoid the cafes where they used to meet. Heavy scarves obscure their identities when they venture out to join protests.

title: New Campaign Markets Activia to Wider Audience
description: A MUCH-NOTICED, much-parodied relationship between a star and a brand is ending as a campaign for Activia probiotic yogurt, scheduled to begin on Monday, replaces the actress Jamie Lee Curtis with three endorsers.

title: Wild-Card Weather Balmy, Compared With the Freezer Bowl
description: CINCINNATI  The Cincinnati Bengals commemorated the franchises 1981 team before the current squads 27-10 loss Sunday in an A.F.C. wild-card game against the San Diego Chargers.

title: Latin Jazz Stalwart Struggles to Make Sweet Sounds Again
description: The autographed posters and concert photos in Dave Valentins living room attest to his status as one of the pre-eminent flutists in Latin jazz. Tucked among 78s tacked to the wall, they show Mr. Valentin smiling alongside performers like Tito Puente and aficionados like Bill Cosby. Nearby, a bunch of All Access stage passes from concerts dangle from a nail like a good-luck charm.

title: Fog-Wreathed Paradise, Built by a Billionaire Under a Cloud
description: JIUZHAIGOU, China  Inside the hotels front entrance, a white mechanical yak nods and says Moo. Beyond it is the centerpiece of the compound: a vast glass atrium with a replica of a Tibetan and ethnic Qiang village filled with three-story stone and wood buildings, each housing a restaurant or bar. Corn husks sit atop the roofs.

title: Southwests Dwindling Water Supply
description: If Lake Mead drops below 1,000 feet above sea level, millions of people will lose their source of water.

title: Colorado River Drought Forces a Painful Reckoning for States
description: LAKE MEAD, Nev.  The sinuous Colorado River and its slew of man-made reservoirs from the Rockies to southern Arizona are being sapped by 14 years of drought nearly unrivaled in 1,250 years.

title: 16-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot on His Way Home From a Party in Brownsville
description: Iquan Williamss parents said they kept him close: an early curfew and no hanging out late at house parties. They knew what trouble could come to a 16-year-old boy at certain times in certain corners of the city. Days earlier a young gunman had fired into a group of teenagers in the lobby of a housing project in Brownsville, Brooklyn, wounding five, as a party thumped upstairs.

title: Democrats Quote the Pope
description: Democrats are using the words of Pope Francis in their speeches about poverty, income inequality and social justice.

title: O.J. Who? Rogues Vanish From Annals of Sport
description: Among college footballs many rituals, the annual Heisman Trophy presentation remains one of the highlights. Fans and coaches and former stars gather in Manhattan each December to honor the seasons outstanding player. This season, about two dozen former winners stood on the stage as another member was added to their exclusive club.

title: Popular Voice in the Capitol? Its the Popes
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly before leaving the Capitol for the holiday recess, Senate Democrats gathered behind closed doors to lay out an agenda for 2014. When the majority leader, Harry Reid, exhorted colleagues to deal with the issue of income inequality, the talk took a spiritual turn.

title: Sudans Lost Boys Are Drawn Into War at Home
description: AWERIAL, South Sudan  When Jacob Atem was just a young boy, his parents were killed during the long war for independence from Sudan, and he found himself among the legions of orphaned children known as the Lost Boys wandering hundreds of miles across this part of Africa.

title: Ireland Stirs Homegrown Flavor Into Tech Scene
description: DUBLIN  The Grand Canal Docks, an upscale business district here in the center of town, is a kind of home away from home for the big Silicon Valley companies like Google and Facebook. These international behemoths, in large part attracted by the low Irish corporate tax rates, have big presences here. And with their thousands of workers and bustling offices, they have long overshadowed the local start-up scene.

title: Study Suggests Recovery in U.S. Is Relatively Vital
description: PHILADELPHIA  Academic heavyweights have been debating whether the current United States economy is so sluggish because of too much government stimulus or not enough, or because slower growth had become the norm even before the recession.

title: JPMorgan Chase Nears a $2 Billion Deal in a Case Tied to Madoff
description: Working through a long list of legal problems, JPMorgan Chase is starting the new year with another steep payout to the government.

title: From Petraeus Scandal, an Apostle for Privacy
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jill Kelley still glances around for cameras before she leaves her large, six-columned house on Hillsborough Bay, and she rarely goes to the grocery store. Since November 2012, when the government released her name in connection with a scandal that brought down the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, Ms. Kelley has yet to return to her childrens schools, she said, and could not even summon the courage to go to their holiday plays.

title: Seeking Independence, Three Men Start in the Kitchen
description: Five men were playing pool recently in the sunny, airy lobby of the Next Generation Center in the South Bronx. One of the men offered pool tips to the others. Later, two men greeted each other with a tight hug.

title: With Marijuana Access on the Horizon, Patients Fear Potential Restrictions
description: Nancy Rivera, a cancer survivor, has a bag of pills in her night stand  white, gold and rust, big and little, antidepressants, antiemetics and tranquilizers  given to her by doctors. So it always seemed hypocritical to her that while she could possess such powerful mind-altering pharmaceuticals in fairly generous quantities, she was not allowed to legally smoke marijuana to relieve the nausea and pain of her cancer and chemotherapy.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 5, 2014
Out of the Wilderness and Into the Olympic Spotlight
description: Ask Carey Price how his hockey journey started, and he says, I grew up in a small town, like most Canadians, and laughs.

title: 14 Killed in Stampede in Northwest China
description: HONG KONG  Fourteen people were trampled to death in northwest China on Sunday as a crowd rushed to take offerings of traditional fried flat bread, the official news agency Xinhua reported Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 6, 2014
description: I dont want to see another generation of children go through what Ive gone through and what other children of my generation went through.

title: A Frozen, Fertile Ground for Developing Tennis Players
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Following tennis usually means chasing summer, with players training on sunbaked courts in Florida and California and traveling the globe in search of sunshine.

title: Corrections: January 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Knicks Display Their Newfound Resolve by Dispatching Mavericks
description: DALLAS  The Knicks arrived in Texas last week as a fragile, broken team. Two of their rotation players did not even make the trip because of injuries. Their starting point guard spent all three games in street clothes as he recovered from a strained groin.

title: The Road to the National Championship
description: Even by college footballs standards, this season was turbulent, taking more turns than a board game. Auburn was unranked when the season started; Florida State was 11th. The expected contenders Alabama, Oregon and Ohio State fell by the wayside. The Tigers survived on last-second victories, while the Seminoles won every game by at least 14 points. On Monday night, they meet in the national championship game, competing for the sports biggest prize.

title: Popular Demand
description: Advertising pages for weekly magazines fell 2 percent from 2012 to 2013, and biweeklies saw a 5.3 percent decline.

title: Smart TVs Are Next Bet for Makers as Sales Languish
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Big, bright, sharp and sophisticated, television sets have never looked better. But thats a problem. The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner.

title: Symptoms of Torn Artery Are Easy to Miss
description: Karin Satrom, a 35-year-old Brooklynite, had been feeling fine through 23 weeks of pregnancy when one night she said she became very, very dizzy, as if I were drunk. Her husband suggested that she lie down, but even with her eyes closed, the room continued to spin.

title: Word of the Day | ruffian
description: ruffian \r-fe-n\ noun

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: A Rising Team Faces a Top One
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: What Kind of Boomer Are You?
description: The baby boom generation can be seen as having two distinct halves. Where do you fall?

title: I May Be 50, but Dont Call Me a Boomer
description: There is no baby boom generation.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: ROBERT OSBORNE After 20 years as the networks host and interviewer, Mr. Osborne slides into the guests chair for a conversation with Alec Baldwin. Four of Mr. Osbornes favorite movies follow: The Third Man (1949), Carol Reeds thriller about a penniless American writer (Joseph Cotten) whose investigation into the death of a friend (Orson Welles, above) uncovers corruption in post-World War II Vienna, at 9:30; Libeled Lady (1936), Jack Conways screwball comedy in which a newspaper editor (Spencer Tracy), his fiance (Jean Harlow) and a former reporter (William Powell) try to compromise an heiress (Myrna Loy) before she can sue for libel, at 1 a.m.; William Dieterles Love Letters (1945), about a soldier (Cotten, again) who falls for the woman (Jennifer Jones) who may have killed his best friend, at 3 a.m.; and The Band Wagon (1953), Vincente Minnellis MGM musical with Fred Astaire as an aging star whose Broadway comeback is sabotaged by an overzealous director (Jack Buchanan) and his prima ballerina colleague (Cyd Charisse), at 5 a.m. Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz wrote the songs, which include Thats Entertainment!

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 30-Jan. 5
description: Often, fans will use head coverings to vividly declare their loyalties. At other times they merely serve as protection from the elements.

title: Downton Abbey':  Season 4 Begins
description: A year is a long time to spend in mourning. It is a period expansive enough to leave the dead in the past, and to forge new and renewed relationships with those still living.

title: For Cheney, Realities of a Race Outweighed Family Edge
description: WASHINGTON  Liz Cheneys short-lived Wyoming Senate campaign shows the perils of personal ambition outpacing a rationale for candidacy.

title: A.T.M. Makers See Opportunity in Long Lines at Rural Branches of Banks
description: MANGALI, Haryana  In Indian cities, getting cash from a bank is as easy as going to an A.T.M. around the corner. In the rural areas, however, those who have bank accounts have to withdraw money by visiting the bank, which could be miles away from where they live. Serpentine lines at the tiny bank of a village or district make the simple task of withdrawing money an ordeal.

title: South Korea Proposes Resuming Reunions of War-Divided Families
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas president proposed Monday that the two Koreas improve their tense relations by resuming the reunions of families separated since the Korean War, a humanitarian program that seemed close to being renewed last year but was scuttled as negotiations soured.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, Jan. 6, 2014
description: What four words fill in the blanks from this article about a Mexican holiday tradition?

title: Vegetable Shopping for a New York Kitchen
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Curious, and Continuing, Appeal of Mark Twain in China
description: There are few authors regarded as quintessentially American as Mark Twain. With his preternatural gift for capturing vernacular expression and his roguish wit, Twain is still widely seen as the founder of the American voice. More than a century after his death, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Twains most celebrated work, remains a mainstay of middle school and high school English classes. Ernest Hemingway famously declared it the book from which all modern American literature comes.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Challenges of Ending Poverty
description: In 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag, Annie Lowrey writes about the poverty rate in the United States, and how it has changed over time.

title: Photographing Spiritual Experience
description: When the Lens blog made its debut in 2009, the newspaper industry was in free fall, the outlets for serious photojournalism rapidly disappearing. There was a need to help promote photographers and photography in whatever way possible, said James Estrin, the blogs co-founder. We wanted to write about the photographers; photos dont happen by themselves.

title: When Do You Choose Making a Phone Call Over Sending a Text?
description: That device in your pocket used to text, access the Internet, play games and take pictures is called a phone. But how often do you use it to make and answer calls?

title: Times Minute | Democrats and the Pope
description: Also on the Minute, airbrushing sports history and the future of television.

title: Times Minute | Democrats and the Pope
description: In the Video

title: New York Today: Extreme Weather
description: Updated 10:25 a.m.

title: Sudans Leader Flies to South for Crisis Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan flew to South Sudan on Monday to discuss the crisis unfolding there with President Salva Kiir after the start of peace talks in Ethiopia failed to bring a halt to fighting.

title: Democracy in Peril in Asia
description: Street protests in three Asian countries  Cambodia, Bangladesh and Thailand  are a vivid reminder of the fragile state of democracy in many developing countries, particularly those that do not have independent judiciaries and professional police forces and militaries.

title: In a Hostile Bid, Mens Wearhouse Raises Offer for Jos. A. Bank
description: Updated, 8:14 p.m. |

title: German Leader Injured in Skiing Accident
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel has canceled most of her meetings for the next three weeks after doctors ordered her to rest in bed following a fall while cross-country skiing in Switzerland over the Christmas holiday, her spokesman said Monday.

title: China Destroys 6 Tons of Ivory
description: Over the past five years or so, as the poaching of elephants has swelled to record numbers, environmentalists and researchers have pointed a finger firmly at Chinas ravenous appetite for ivory as the main cause for what is now widely described as a crisis.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 6, 2014
description: Update: Jan. 7, 2013

title: Behind the Cover: Paul Tough on a Tale of Strategic Survival
description: Paul Tough, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about a fisherman named John Aldridge, who fell overboard 40 miles off the eastern end of Long Island last summer and survived nearly 12 hours in the water before being rescued by the Coast Guard. Toughs most recent book is How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity, and the Hidden Power of Character.How did you first hear about this extraordinary survival story?

title: The Information We Still Need to Manage Our Health Care
description: After writing eight posts on my search for health insurance, which generated more than 275 comment from readers, I was more than ready to move on. After all, I do have a day job  running my little factory  and I have other projects and problems to address. But my mind keeps returning to a scene I witnessed the week before Christmas.

title: YP, a Mobile Search Firm, Buys Sense Networks
description: YP, the local search and advertising company owned by Cerberus Capital Management and AT&T, said on Monday that it had acquired Sense Networks, a mobile ad company.

title: The Man Who Forgot He Was Prime Minister
description: NEW DELHI  In political life, perhaps there is no public reaction more denigrating than ridicule. Criticism is part of the terrain, but ridicule entails a deeper kind of humiliation, where the right to even be heard seriously has been taken away.

title: Polar Vortex Sends Shivers Across U.S.
description: Updated, 1:45 p.m. Wake up in Madison, Wis.? Mondays temperature was 18 degrees below zero. In Minneapolis, and Chicago, it was minus 15. And in Fargo, N.D., it was 23 degrees below zero.

title: Daily Report: Smart TVs in the Spotlight at Consumer Electronics Show
description: The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner, Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report. Crisp, high-definition TVs as big as 50 diagonal inches can be had for a few hundred dollars. Why bother upgrading or paying more for a fancy new one? Many people dont.

title: $20 Million Donation for Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced that Robert J. Appel, a financier and philanthropist, has pledged $20 million to benefit the organizations performance, education and broadcasting efforts. The gift, one of the largest single private contributions to date in support of jazz music, will also be used to help promote the centers global initiatives of audience development and jazz advocacy. Mr. Appel joined the Jazz at Lincoln Center board in 2008 and was appointed chairman in 2012.

title: At CES 2014, a Battle for the Next Generation of Computing
description: The International CES in Las Vegas, one of the largest technology trade shows in the world, is a reflection of the rapidly changing electronics industry.

title: G.E. to Buy Health Care Units From Thermo Fisher Scientific
description: General Electric said on Monday that it would acquire a gene modulation and magnetic beads business from Thermo Fisher Scientific for about $1.06 billion.

title: China Follows U.S., Crushing Tons of Confiscated Ivory
description: China on Monday used a loud, much-hailed ivory-crushing event to send a signal to consumers and criminals about the countrys intention to crack down on the smuggling and poaching that has devastated elephant populations. Bettina Wassener has the details in a post on TheNew York Times blog Sinosphere. Heres an excerpt and link:

title: Woody Allen and His Kin'; Alfonso Cuarn and His Bad Movie
description: Sure, by now youve probably taken the Youse, Yall and Yinz dialect quiz, but have you ever considered the connections between, say, Louis Armstrong, Richard Pryor and Noah Baumbach? A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis investigate the genealogy of Woody Allen, linking him to filmmakers, comedians, writers, even a fictional character or two, in this neat, graphic imagining of his family tree, part of the special Arts & Leisure Oscars issue.

title: Carlyle Hires Former F.C.C. Chairman for Buyout Group
description: Updated, 5:10 p.m. |

title: JPMorgan Near a Settlement in Madoff Case
description: JPMorgan Chase is starting the year the same way it ended the last one: by whipping out its wallet, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The bank is preparing to reach roughly $2 billion in criminal and civil settlements with federal authorities who claim that it ignored signs of Bernard L. Madoffs huge Ponzi scheme, bringing its settlement total to nearly $20 billion over the last year. The settlements come on the heels of a record $13 billion deal with the Justice Department in November related to the banks questionable mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis.

title: Nestl to Sell Frozen Pasta Business to Brynwood Partners
description: LONDON  The food giant Nestl is selling Josephs Pasta, a Massachusetts maker of frozen pastas, to the buyout firm Brynwood Partners.

title: Human Rights Chairman Said to Resign Over Harassment Accusation
description: NEW DELHI  A former Supreme Court justice resigned as chairman of the West Bengal Human Rights Commission on Monday over accusations that he sexually harassed a law intern, according to local news reports.

title: In One Image: Cold Snaps In Global Context
description: A useful image from Twitter conveys why debates over regional cold blasts have little relevance to discussions of human-driven climate change:

title: Last Night in Carroll Gardens
A Folkie Takes Issue With Llewyn Davis
description: Even before the Oscar nominations are announced next week, this has been a season rife with controversy, from the moral stance of Wolf of Wall Street to the religious one of Philomena. Incidentally, these brouhahas dont happen to hurt the marketing of the movies in question, since come see for yourself has been an irresistible tagline since the dawn of Hollywood, scandal or no.

title: In Our Pages: January 7
description: 1914: Telephones Used for Blackmail

title: The War on Poverty at 50
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Justices Halt to Gay Marriage Leaves Utah Couples in Limbo
description: SALT LAKE CITY  In a move that cast doubt over the marriages of roughly 1,000 same-sex couples in Utah, the United States Supreme Court on Monday blocked further same-sex marriages there while state officials appeal a decision allowing such unions.

title: Verso Paper to Buy NewPage Holdings
description: The Verso Paper Corporation announced on Monday that it would acquire NewPage Holdings, a specialty paper company that emerged from bankruptcy in 2012, in a deal valued at $1.4 billion.

title: BMW Is Recalling 51,000 Motorcycles for Fuel Leak
description: Following an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, BMW says it isrecalling almost 51,000 motorcycles because of a possible fuel leak, according to a report the automaker posted on the agencys website. Most of the recalled motorcycles are 2005-11 R and K series models.

title: Image of the Day: January 6
A Page of Beethoven May Fetch More Than $200,000
description: A rare Beethoven manuscript  actually, a leaf from a late-period sketchbook that the composer apparently tore out and carried in his pocket while composing the Missa Solemnis  will be auctioned on Jan. 15 at RR Auctions in Amherst, N.H. The leaf was unknown until 1996, when it was discovered among the papers of Anton Schindler, Beethovens friend and early biographer. It was authenticated and auctioned at Sothebys in London that year for $110,000.

title: New Rules for Workers From Europes East Prompt Xenophobia in the West
description: The European Unions easing of work restrictions for Romanians and Bulgarians on New Years Day has revived a continent-wide debate on immigration, spurring both irrational alarmism and a caustic backlash against the perceived anti-immigration mania.

title: London Fashion Week: Lou Dalton Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: A Little Help With the Luggage
description: Soon, passengers wont have to rely solely on the airline to track their luggage. FindEm Tracking, a thin Bluetooth tracking device that will be available in February, conveys location information when synched to a smartphone.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Fall 2014 Menswear
description: London

title: Knowing a Brain, Saving Sheep and Avoiding Laser Burns
description: We begin a new series that will dive deep into the human mind; helicopters with bags of bighorns  thats all we will say; the next time you go for laser hair-removal, here are some things to think about.

title: Solomon Northups Legacy, on Film and in Life
description: Chiwetel Ejiofor, the star of 12 Years a Slave, initially feared that he would not be able to do justice to the life of Solomon Northup, on whose memoir the film is based.

title: A Symbol of the Range Returns Home
description: BOULDER CITY, Nev.  The two-way radio crackled to life: Were coming in with three ewes and a young ram.

title: The Read Around: Nikki Giovanni
description: Poetry prevents everybody from feeling lonely, says Nikki Giovanni. Her latest book, Chasing Utopia, is a collection of poetry, recipes and short stories.

title: Times Minute | Polar Vortex at Work
description: Also in the Minute, Liz Cheney quits the Wyoming Senate Race and Spider-Man closes on Broadway.

title: Times Minute | Polar Vortex at Work
description: In the Video

title: AT&T Allows Advertisers to Sponsor Mobile Data
description: Say you want to watch a trailer for The Wolf of Wall Street on your smartphone. Why should you pay for the data required to display it when you are essentially viewing an advertisement?

title: Daniel Finkels Stained Glass Window Problem
