description: A federal jury will decide whether Mathew Martoma, the former hedge fund manager, cheated when he worked at SAC Capital Advisors, but theres no denying he cheated when he falsified his grades at Harvard Law School some 15 years ago.

title: Mercedes-Benz to Reveal AMG-Tuned GLA45 and Concept S-Class Coupe in Detroit
description: Mercedes-Benz will show several new models at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, among them the 2015 GLA45 AMG, the 2015 Concept S-Class Coupe and the 2015 C-Class.

title: After Apparent Food Stamp Deal, Dairy Rift Moves to Fore in Farm Bill Talks
description: WASHINGTON  Disagreements over a program to help dairy producers when milk prices drop have emerged as a major sticking point in negotiations on a new farm bill, which had been expected to be wrapped up this week. But lawmakers appear to have reached an agreement on cuts to the food stamp program, which is part of the farm bill and had been the most contentious issue in efforts to pass the legislation.

title: Today in Small Business: Disloyalty Cards
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Letters to the Doctor
description: When I entered the exam room to see my first patient of the day, a doctor from another department at my hospital, I found her sitting in the chair I usually occupy, typing away at the computer on the tiny desk.

title: Tempered Optimism for the Economy
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

title: E.U. Panel Invites Snowden to Testify on Privacy Breaches
description: PARIS  A European Parliament committee has invited Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has leaked classified government documents and is now in hiding in Russia, to testify via video link as part of an investigation into how to protect the privacy of European citizens.

title: Making Oprahs Gift Count
description: Ill never forget when Oprah Winfrey turned to me and said, We are going to build a school! This was my second time on her show, and Oprah had just named me her all-time favorite guest in 25 years of the show. As if that wasnt enough, she had just informed me that she was donating $1.5 million to build a school in my home village in Zimbabwe! When Oprah gave me the incredible news, my response  in the midst of overwhelming gratitude  was It is achievable! (Tinogona means it is achievable.) With that, Tinogona Foundation was born.

title: Skiing the Giant Slalom at Age 7
description: She was a happy little kid, Rika Moore, a youth coach at Vail, said of Shiffrin, but she was unbelievably focused on making perfect turns, one after another.

title: Signs of Future Slalom Success
description: Youth coaches saw an evolving star in Mikaela, but the Shiffrins still strived for normalcy.

title: Early Olympic Dreams
description: From unicycles to inline skates, Mikaela Shiffrin spent plenty of time off skis, as when she played in the garage with her brother at age 6.

title: Travel Site Will Emphasize Personal Advice
description: Virtuoso, the luxury travel network with close to a 1,000 hotels and 335 affiliated agencies globally, introduced a site this week that aims to marry technology with the human touch.

title: Christies Confrontational Style
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been accused of bullying political opponents. On YouTube, there are clips of his confrontations with critics.

title: Director of Britains National Theater to Form New Company
description: LONDON  Nicholas Hytner, the director of Britains National Theater, has announced plans to form a theatrical production company when he leaves his current position in 2015. (His successor is Rupert Norris, an associate director at the National Theater.)

title: Discovery of Bombs and Corpses Rattles Tense Caucasus Region
description: MOSCOW  The discovery of several improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men shot dead put security forces on higher alert in the North Caucasus region of Russia on Thursday and added new concerns about violence ahead of the Olympic Games planned for the nearby resort city of Sochi next month.

title: Bankers Bonus Blues
description: Investment bankers will have to look backward, not forward, for joy this bonus season. A mediocre fourth quarter means Wall Street and City practitioners are unlikely to improve on their total compensation from 2012. With industrywide revenue growth expected to be tepid at best for the next couple of years, the trend could persist. Bank share price performance, though, should help make up some of the difference.

title: Analyst Suggests UBS Spin Off Investment Bank and Revive Warburg Name
description: LONDON  As Swiss banks faces more pressure from regulators to wall off their riskier activities, UBS should consider spinning off its investment bank, an analyst at Mediobanca said on Thursday.

title: Bomber in Iraq Kills 22 Recruits Seeking to Fight Al Qaeda
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber detonated explosives on Thursday among a group of recruits who were joining the Iraqi Army to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province, the police said. Twenty-two recruits were killed, and 31 were wounded, officials said.

title: The Memi Smart Bracelet: Wearable Tech That Lets You Disconnect
description: If one of your resolutions this year was to put down your gadgets more often when youre with family, then the Memi smart bracelet, oddly enough, is a gadget that might make it easier to do just that.

title: Darkness On the Edge of Trenton
description: Im not sure how much there is to add to whats already being said about Chris Christies ongoing traffic study scandal, but now that his press conference has (I think) finally ended here are a few thoughts.

title: Lady and the Unicorn Tapestries Return to View in France
description: PARIS  After a nearly two-year absence and a thorough cleaning, The Lady and the Unicorn tapestries have gone back on view at the Muse National du Moyen Age here, their rich colors more vivid than ever.

title: Woman Says Lane Closings Were Not to Blame for Her Mothers Death
description: FORT LEE, N.J.  The daughter of a 91-year-old woman from Fort Lee, N.J., who died on the day of a major traffic jam precipitated by top aides to Gov. Chris Christie said on Thursday that she did not believe the inability of an ambulance to reach her mothers house was a factor in her death.

title: Claim Against Indian Diplomat Has Echoes of Previous Cases
description: Sangeeta Richard, the housekeeper whose accusations of employer mistreatment led to the arrest of Indias deputy consul general in New York and an international furor, is not the first domestic worker to take issue with a diplomat who hired her.

title: Questions for Christie
description: Gov. Chris Christies press conference on the manmade-traffic-jam lasted for almost two hours. He beat up on himself  he feels embarrassed and humiliated  and his staff  he called Bridget Anne Kelly stupid and deceitful  and did a pretty decent job of exhausting reporters, if not public interest in the story. A few questions remain that will likely play a part in the controversy going forward:

title: Tunisias Premier Resigns, Formally Ending His Partys Rule
description: TUNIS  Tunisias Islamist prime minister resigned Thursday, ending the two-year-old rule of his party, which has dominated the political scene since the popular uprising here that initiated the Arab Spring.

title: Apple and Samsung Chiefs to Meet a Mediator Ahead of Next Patent Suit
description: In March, Apple and Samsung Electronics are scheduled to go to trial again to fight over smartphone patents. But after discussing settlement opportunities earlier this week, the companies have agreed to meet with a mediator.

title: Blackstone Hires UBS Banker to Lead Energy Advisory Group
description: The investment banking arm of the Blackstone Group has hired a UBS executive to lead its energy and power advisory practice.

title: Chrysler Announces Mopar Custom Shop Display for Detroit
description: Although Mopar has been Chryslers parts and service moniker since before World War II, it was during muscle-car craze of the 1960s that it came to be identified with performance aftermarket parts. At the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, Chrysler will have a sizable Mopar display as part of its 5,500-square-foot spread, showing off several vehicles laden with aftermarket parts.

title: With Release of Prisoners, Afghan Leader Again Defies U.S. Wishes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Thursday ordered the release of dozens of prisoners accused of having American blood on their hands, saying there was not enough evidence to hold them and intensifying his showdown with Obama administration officials after weeks of warnings that he risked losing American troop support.

title: Jon Favreaus Chef to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
description: One more food truck will roll into Austin when Chef, a comedy written, directed by and starring Jon Favreau, has its premiere on opening night of the South by Southwest Film festival, organizers announced Thursday.

title: A Comic Book Team Gets the Green Light
description: The life of a freelance comic book creator is all about pitching and survival: looking for a publisher and hoping an audience will be there to sustain a series. For the writer-artist team Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips, things are about to get a little easier. Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips have made a five-year publishing deal with Image Comics, the home of their most recent collaboration, the supernatural noir series Fatale. Image will publish whatever the team can dream up and Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips will retain ownership of the property, a hallmark of the company.

title: JPMorgan Lost Madoff in a Blizzard of Paper
description: Did JPMorgan Chase deliberately cover up Bernard L. Madoffs fraud?

title: Old Breakfast Buddies, From Tarzan to Snoopy
description: ONE of the simple yet durable cultural traditions of the 20th century  a modest rite that transcended barriers of race and class  was the Sunday morning or afternoon spent lost in the newspaper funnies. There was always something for everyone: Flash Gordon, Prince Valiant and Terry and the Pirates for those craving pulpy adventure; Archie and Peanuts for laughs and chuckles; Gasoline Alley and Blondie for family life; and Krazy Kat and Pogo for the comic-strip intelligentsia.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: New York Transportation Etiquette

title: A Sweet History: Doughnuts in New York City
description: The Miser grew up just a few towns south of the birthplace of that symbol of American low cuisine, Krispy Kreme. So captivating were those confections sugary spell that it wasnt until adolescence that he was even aware of the existence of other doughnuts. Doughnuts, for all he knew, simply were Krispy Kremes, and vice versa. Dunkin Donuts, he assumed, was merely a figure of speech, not a rival purveyor.

title: National Park Proves a Hard Gift to Give
description: PATTEN, Me.  Lucas St. Clair pulled up to an overlook in Maines North Woods to a stunning vista of Mount Katahdin, the states highest peak and the endpoint of the Appalachian Trail. Stretched out below was a vast green carpet of pine and spruce flecked with golden aspens and blazing red maples; Millinocket Lake glistened in the distance.

title: Portraits From Clips and Bytes
description: When the visual artist and composer R. Luke DuBois was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in Washington to make a portrait of Googles founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, he elegantly co-opted Googles own technology for the job.

title: Early Chekhov, Framed Anew
description: The experimental designer and director Jay Scheib is offering audiences two ways to view his raucous contemporary rewrite of an unfinished early Chekhov play. You can see a live performance at the Kitchen in Chelsea, where it is called Platonov, the plays traditional title, or you can watch a live simulcast of the performance at one of several theaters in New York and elsewhere, where it goes by another name, The Disinherited.

title: Captain Phillips Gets Another Vote of Confidence
description: Is this another indicator that Captain Phillips is going to go far? The USC Libraries Scripter Award, a screenplay prize that includes the original material that adapted movies come from, announced finalists on Thursday, and the real-life captains memoir, along with the film version, made the list.

title: After Being Indicted, Diplomat Is Allowed to Leave the Country
description: The legal battle over an Indian diplomat whose recent arrest in New York caused an uproar in her home country took an unusual turn on Thursday when she was indicted by a federal grand jury in Manhattan but was then allowed to leave the United States.

title: Dish Shares Drop After It Withdraws Bid for LightSquared
description: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | For years, Charles W. Ergen had ambitions to buy LightSquared, the bankrupt broadband wireless company, to bolster his dream of creating a huge data services provider.

title: National Board of Review Gala Red Carpet
description: Celebrities like Adle Exarchopoulos and Leonardo DiCaprio attended the event.

title: Teju Cole Puts Story-Telling to the Twitter Test
description: 6:50 p.m. | Update: Teju Cole, who is in India, responded to my email after this post originally went live. His comments were added later.

title: Civil War Archive to Go on Sale
description: A BLACK REGIMENTS BATTLEFIELD STORIES

title: Rubio Demands States Right to Ignore the Poor
description: For a senator who likes to hold himself out as the future of the Republican brand, Marco Rubio has come up with a remarkably retrograde contribution to the partys chorus of phony empathy for the poor: Let the states do it.

title: As Seals Return to Long Island, So Do Watchers
description: In 2000, when the Riverhead Foundation for Marine Research and Preservation began running seal-watching cruises on Hempstead Bay, passengers would typically see one or two seals, according to Robert A. DiGiovanni Jr., a biologist and the groups executive director.

title: Philadelphia Museum Lands a Major Gift
description: Since the 1970s, Keith L. Sachs, the former chief executive of Saxco International, a packaging distribution company, and his wife, Katherine, have been major supporters of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, he as a longtime trustee and she in a number of roles, including adjunct curator.

title: Going Driverless at CES
description: Roy Furchgott explores the buzz around autonomous vehicles at this years International CES.

title: Survey of a Modern Form and a Friendship
description: You can tell by the primary colors and rectilinear grids in Harry Holtzmans paintings and sculptures that the artist was a disciple of Piet Mondrian, the Dutch founder of Neoplasticism, an aesthetic philosophy that sought spiritual balance through simplified formal structure. Mondrians legacy in the United States is even owed in large part to Holtzman, who was 40 years younger and became the sole heir to and executor of his estate. The story of Holtzmans work and their relationship, however, has been largely left untold. Harry Holtzman and American Abstraction at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn., offers a thorough and thoughtful recounting of that history.

title: A Conductor Wields a Baton Across Cultures
description: The conductor Rossen Milanov balances two approaches when leading an orchestra.

title: The Minds Jailer
description: Ive always responded to the history of my times, says the beleaguered narrator of Andrews Brain, almost ruefully, as if he wished it werent so. He has no choice, though: Responding to the history of ones times is the sworn duty of a character in a novel by E. L. Doctorow, who has in his half-century of writing fiction placed a remarkable number of people, both real and imagined, in their history just to watch them respond. At first Andrew, whose time is the bewilderingly eventful opening decade of this century, doesnt sound like much of a witness: A self-described freakishly depressive cognitive scientist klutz, he seems far more interested in the workings of his own mind than those of the world outside, and for a long time speaks  to someone he calls Doc  only of his messy private life and his largely fruitless research into the mysteries of the human brain. He cracks cynical jokes, tells parts of his life story in the third person, indulges in a fair bit of glib self-analysis (I am finally, terribly, unfeeling) and generally plays the fool. Andrews Brain is cunning. It isnt hard to figure out that Andrew is an unreliable narrator, but by the end of this sly book Doctorow has you wondering if theres any other kind.

title: I Read You Loud and Clear
description: I love book clubs. I love reading for them, I love talking to them, and if I had my choice Id probably do nothing but visit them to promote my books. Where else do you find people who have already made a commitment to read your book, and to read it closely enough to discuss it in a knowledgeable fashion with their friends? The best insights Ive ever been offered about my work have come from book club members. In a world full of readings attended by the inevitable, random 5-to-10 bookstore browsers and 20-year-old assistant night managers who consistently mangle the title of your work, book clubs are an oasis of intelligent thought and discussion.

title: Marvin Bileck: Thimbledon Bridge and Emily Nelligan: Drawings
description: Alexandre Gallery

title: Jury of 7 Women and 5 Men Chosen for Martoma Trial
description: A jury of seven women and five men was selected on Thursday to determine whether Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, is guilty of engaging in what the government has called the biggest insider trading scheme in history.

title: Panel Recommends Transferring Yemeni From Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  In the first results of a long-delayed Obama administration initiative to hold parole-like hearings at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a military panel has recommended transferring a Yemeni detainee who had been ordered held indefinitely without trial, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday.

title: Para-Real
description: 601Artspace

title: A Chef in the Field | Olive Oil
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Lucy Dodd: Cake 4 Catfish
description: David Lewis Gallery

title: The Feel, and Taste, of France
description: Saint George, a youthful new bistro that has taken the place of the beloved Buffet de la Gare, in Hastings-on-Hudson, is giving nervous loyal Gare patrons all kinds of reasons to take heart.

title: Attorney General Vows to Crack Down on Insider Trading 2.0
description: Asset managers arent the only ones who should worry about BlackRocks settlement with the New York State attorney general.

title: Sarah Crowner: The Wave
description: Nicelle Beauchene Gallery

title: Anke Weyer: Du
description: Canada

title: Looking Again at That Mars-Venus Thing
description: On HBO, its the guys who are airbrushed and Photoshopped, and the Girls who let their blemishes show.

title: At the End of a Strip Mall, a Surprise
description: Verona Restaurant is one of those proverbial gems, a first-rate traditional Italian restaurant in an unremarkable setting. Here, at the end of a strip mall that houses a Subway sandwich shop and a dry cleaner, ordinary dishes like eggplant rollatini and fried zucchini dominate. Prepared with skill and flair, they remind you why these standard items are beloved by so many diners.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: sleep apnea, torn arteries and Google searches. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Brazil and Turkey.

title: Beyond Beefcake in the Work of a Gay Pioneer
description: In 1951, Bob Mizer began Physique Pictorial, a magazine loaded with photographs of muscular young men wearing little more than posing straps  G-strings for men. Its imagery ostensibly illustrated health and fitness, but was really aimed at what was then an underground gay market. Mizer (1922-92) was a pioneer in making explicit the genres erotic appeal, enough so to attract attention from legal authorities. In 1947, he was convicted of contributing to the delinquency of a minor by taking nude pictures of a 17-year-old, and he spent a year in prison. In 1954, he was convicted of distributing obscene material through the mail. (That conviction was reversed on appeal a couple of years later.) Those speed bumps didnt stop Mizers enterprise as a commercial photographer and publisher from growing to the point at which it occupied four lots near downtown Los Angeles, like a Hollywood movie studio, earning him the nickname the Hugh Hefner of gay publishing. Mizer, evidently, was blessedly free of high-art pretension, but Physique Pictorial was nevertheless an inspiration for artists like David Hockney and Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: At Issue in 2 Wrenching Cases: What to Do After the Brain Dies
description: In one way, the cases are polar opposites: the parents of Jahi McMath in Oakland, Calif., have fought to keep their daughter connected to a ventilator, while the parents and husband of Marlise Muoz in Fort Worth, Tex., want desperately to turn the machine off. In another way, the cases are identical: both families have been shocked to learn that a loved one was declared brain-dead  and that hospital officials defied the familys wishes for treatment.

title: Hiding in Plain Sight
description: InThai Restaurant is handy for workers in several high-rise office buildings along Route 7 in Norwalk near the Wilton line, many of whom cross the road for a quick lunch or a takeout dinner. But even after three years in business, the restaurant is still something of a secret beyond that area, and those acquainted with its extremely low prices and good spicy Thai food may want it to retain its sleeper status a while longer.

title: Amiri Baraka, Polarizing Poet and Playwright, Dies at 79
description: Amiri Baraka, a poet and playwright of pulsating rage, whose long illumination of the black experience in America was called incandescent in some quarters and incendiary in others, died on Thursday in Newark. He was 79.

title: Christie and the Bridge Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Gary Shteyngart Offers Some Jokes, Some Self-Analysis
description: Gary Shteyngart was speaking on Wednesday night about the difficulties of recapturing his past on the page. There was one acid trip I wanted to write about, he said, and in interviewing five people, I realized it never happened.

title: Punk, Skirts, Balaclavas: A Russian Revolution
description: The problem with staging a show trial is that the main actor has little incentive to follow the script. Yet thats never tempered Russias thirst for judicial theater. In 1964, a Soviet court demanded to know who had given Joseph Brodsky permission to write poetry. That future Nobel laureates retort: I think that it ... comes from God, became a classic of artistic defiance.

title: Obama Announces Promise Zones in 5 Poor Areas
description: WASHINGTON  A year after promising to direct federal attention and support to needy areas across the country, President Obama said Thursday that the government would begin helping five economically hard-hit communities fight poverty and assist children.

title: Shes Hard as Nails, Hes Noir and Nasty
description: Theres more mystery in the grammatically anguished title of Cold Comes the Night than in this low-voltage thriller, which asks you to guess, if not for long or terribly hard, which is the tougher of two combatants: a young and lovely single mother or a Polish criminal. In one corner is Chloe (Alice Eve), a hardworking, hard-bitten beauty who runs and lives in one of those motels that rent rooms by the hour. In the other corner is Topo (Bryan Cranston), a very bad man who stops at the motel one evening  the presumably cold night of the title (she puts on a parka)  a stopover that leads to a face-off that ends pretty much how you might guess.

title: A Spot for Theatrics, or Serenity
description: The first thing to know about K60 Japanese Steak House is that this sprawling, neon-trimmed restaurant in a Lake Grove strip mall offers two entirely different dining experiences. The most popular, by far, is the raucous hibachi room, where flames leap, diners cheer (or cringe), servers scurry and impassioned chefs jump, juggle, chop and grill, all beneath the nonstop whoosh of overhead exhaust fans. And there is the adjacent, far quieter sushi room, as a hostess called it on a recent evening, with its sleek, sparsely populated tables and booths, serene sushi bar and attentive servers.

title: When There Was a Mock Plantation in Brooklyn
description: All up and down de whole creationSadly I roam,Still longing for de old plantation,And for de old folks at home.

title: I Remember Mama, the Pot Smuggler
description: In the opening moments of Free Ride, Christina (Anna Paquin), a young mother, impulsively flees her abusive boyfriend and dead-end factory job in an Akron, Ohio, suburb, to begin a new life in Florida. It is 1977, and the state, still in the throes of the blas anything-goes spirit of the post-hippie era, is awash in imported drugs.

title: Looking for the Hands-Free Driving Experience
description: At this years International CES, several automakers are showing off the latest and greatest technology in their vehicles, and much of the focus was on autonomous technology. Audi introduced a car that took steps toward self-driving, as did BMW and Bosch.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly Betty
description: When Michael Urie was cast in 2006 as Vanessa Williamss slavishly devoted assistant on the television series Ugly Betty, it meant a move to Los Angeles. Relocating is an actors lot, of course, but Mr. Urie desperately missed New York. Clever guy, he came up with an effective treatment for homesickness: the purchase of an apartment in a very tall building. Anytime friends came over, he recalled, they said, This is just like home.

title: What I Love | Michael Urie
description: The Midtown West home of Michael Urie and his partner Ryan Spahn.

title: Gillespie, Former Republican Chairman, Readies to Run for Senate in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON  Ed Gillespie, a former Republican National Committee chairman, has told senior members of his party that he will challenge Senator Mark R. Warner of Virginia and announce his candidacy as early as next week, giving Republicans a top-tier candidate in what has become one of the nations most competitive swing states.

title: Designing the Next Wave of Computer Chips
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Not long after Gordon E. Moore proposed in 1965 that the number of transistors that could be etched on a silicon chip would continue to double approximately every 18 months, critics began predicting that the era of Moores Law would draw to a close.

title: No Barbershops Here, Nor Violins or Cellos
description: At the start of Heather Kravass a quartet, the works four dancers stand in line like serious kids pretending to be a train. As they repeatedly bend forward and arch back, their collective motion  switching between unison, relay and counterpoint  takes on the aspect of a stationary machine. Then, as their pelvises rock, they add a word  want  which becomes a mantra. Accelerating, the sequence approaches the edge of comedy.

title: Coming-of-Age in Wartime
description: Eka and Natia , the 14-year-old best friends at the heart of In Bloom, live in a place that seems to be crumbling at the edges. Its 1992, and their homeland, the former Soviet republic of Georgia, is at war. The fighting, in the northern Abkhazia region, is far from the capital, Tbilisi, where the girls live, but the conflict pops up frequently in the adult conversations, at least when the grown-ups are not screaming and cursing about other things.

title: Shifting His Tectonic Plates
description: At the end of December, the PBS host Charlie Rose conducted a curious interview with Richard Serra about his new show in two locations of the Gagosian Gallery in New York, and it quickly became popular on the Internet. The conversation was notable mostly because it reached an uncomfortable deadlock over how to talk about Mr. Serras sculpture. (Mr. Rose thought one work in Mr. Serras new show looked like a cemetery; Mr. Serra disagreed. Repeat.)

title: Celebrating Age as Well as Attitude at a Record Labels Anniversary Party
description: An anniversary concert for a record label, like an anniversary edition of a music festival, always comes preloaded with a burden of intention. Whats implicit is some form of brand reinforcement  but an album catalog contains its own narrative, and an artist roster has its own identity, and the two may not naturally converge. So one question for any label at a milestone is what to celebrate most: a corpus or an ethos?

title: Ford Looks to Fiesta to Increase Sales in Japanese Market
description: TOKYO  Ford might be an auto giant in America, but odds are you will not spot one of its cars on Japans busy roads. Last year, the Detroit automaker sold all of 3,896 cars in Japan.

title: A Band of Brothers and Oddballs
description: Any man who was of a devil-may-care age in 1981 will, if interrogated long enough, eventually drop his intellectual facade and affirm that the greatest movie of all time is not Citizen Kane but Stripes, the boot-camp comedy from that year starring Bill Murray and Harold Ramis. Enlisted, a Fox sitcom that begins on Friday night, really, really wants to be Stripes, but it has none of its panache. Where Stripes was full of memorable misfits, Enlisted is full of mismatched ones.

title: E-Cigarette Shops Open Even as City Cracks Down
description: A half-dozen people were gathered around the tasting bar at the Henley Vaporium in SoHo on a recent Friday evening. Behind the bar, two vapologists in white lab coats stood before a selection of dozens of tiny bottles, each containing liquid nicotine. The customers, all students or young professionals, leisurely inhaled on their so-called vape pens. Clouds of mist curled upward and vanished. A slightly sweet smell lingered in the air.

title: Charting the Decline in Service at the I.R.S.
description: The national taxpayer advocate, the ombudswoman for the Internal Revenue Service, has released her annual report about the biggest issues facing the agency. One major concern that the advocate, Nina E. Olson, emphasized was declining customer service at the agency, driven by budget cuts.

title: No Heavy Lifting for These Gym Rats
description: Because the time is long overdue for a gross-out comedy about the absurdities of gym culture, the first few minutes of Dumbbells, set at a Los Angeles fitness center, raised my hopes that here at last was the satirical takedown this subject deserves.

title: After a Merger Falls Through, Patton Boggs Keeps Looking
description: For over a half-century, the Washington law firm Patton Boggs has been a significant player in the nations legal, lobbying and business worlds.

title: Times Minute | Chris Christie and 2016
description: Also on the Minute, dozens of Afghan prisoners will be released and this week's TV Watch.

title: Times Minute | Chris Christie and 2016
description: In the Video

title: Unfinished Works
description: The Metropolitan Museum is dotted with paintings that have been left incomplete.

title: The Fascination of the Unfinished
description: Unfinished paintings are enticing cracks in the facade of art history, lures along the path to a deeper understanding of artistic processes and impulses. For all the paintings that artists complete, countless others are left incomplete for any number of reasons  poverty or war, a change of plan or vision, the illness or death of the artist. While many of these works have been destroyed, and others forgotten, some are now recognized as significant works of art, accorded a special place in history and in an artists body of work, in part because they can bring us closer to understanding the mysterious process of painting, and, indeed, to paintings future. After all, nothing inspires a young artist like a close look at how an earlier one worked.

title: Apollo Secures $18.4 Billion War Chest for Private Equity
description: Leon D. Black, the head of Apollo Global Management, said last year that his firm was selling everything thats not nailed down.

title: Balenciaga
description: The prefall collection included tailored separates.

title: This Week's Movies: Jan. 10, 2014
description: The New York Times movie critics on "The Rocket," "Cold Comes the Night" and "In Bloom."

title: Aretha Franklin Postpones Radio City Shows
description: Updated, 6:50 p.m. |

title: Gabriel Snyder, Former Editor of The Wire, Joins Mobile News Start-Up
description: Gabriel Snyder, the former editor in chief of The Wire, a website owned by Atlantic Media, has joined Inside.com, a mobile news start-up founded by the web entrepreneur Jason Calacanis. It will start on Jan. 23.

title: The Very Model of a University
description: In designing his 1907 campus for the City College of New York at Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street, George B. Post must have felt like the ham in a sandwich. He was working between McKim, Mead & Whites lofty, imperial Roman-style Columbia College and their demure Renaissance-style campus for New York Universitys Bronx branch, now Bronx Community College.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: GoPro Gets Tiny
description: At the International CES in Las Vegas, The Timess Nick Bilton was impressed by a tiny, versatile camera made by GoPro.

title: Agency to Stream a Daily Show About the Sundance Festival
description: IT is unlikely that anyone has ever shouted on a set Lights! Streaming video! Action! But such a phrase might be heard during the 2014 Sundance Film Festival as the Sundance Institute teams with a giant public relations agency to stream a daily, hourlong show on the institutes channel on YouTube, at youtube.com/sff.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A World of Bitcoins and Unicorns, and the Anniversary of the iPhone
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Half of Congress Members Are Millionaires, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  It is hardly the kind of news that lawmakers in Congress would want to highlight during a week when unemployment benefits expired for more than a million Americans. But Congress has achieved something of a milestone.

title: Tech vs. Tyke
description: Unlike almost everyone we know, my husband and I do not allow our 3-year-old to watch TV or movies, or use smartphones, tablets or other devices. We feel that screen time is unhealthy, and so far, the policy has worked for our family. I avoid this topic with other parents because our choice implies a negative judgment about their choices. If the TV comes on at someone elses house, we quietly excuse ourselves. But what should I say when another parent asks me about this directly?

title: A Third Ring, Bearing the Most Important Truth
description: My first engagement ring, a diamond, was given to me by Glenn on my 27th birthday. Although we had been dating only 10 months, I suspected a proposal was coming. Little clues tipped me off: a cut-short phone call, his nervousness at the restaurant.

title: A Big Year for V.A. Loans
description: The number of loans guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs reached a record high in 2013, perhaps marking the peak of an upward trajectory that began after the housing market collapse.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Peoples Choice Awards Red Carpet
description: Looks from the red carpet at the 40th Peoples Choice Awards, with Justin Timberlake, Britney Spears, Sandra Bullock and more.

title: If Bad Things Happen, Blame the 10-Year-Old
description: A pretty, somewhat sleepy and finally strange once-upon-a-time tale, The Rocket is the story of a Laotian boy who transcends adversity, partly because, if were being honest, few moviegoers would probably want to watch a film about a boy who doesnt (unless it is a documentary). It opens with a villager, Mali (Alice Keohavong), giving birth to twins, one dead. An older relative, Taitok (Bunsri Yindi), wants to kill the surviving child because, she insists, twins are bad luck. Mali successfully begs for the boys life, and, after the dead newborn is clandestinely buried, the surviving child grows up to become the movies plucky 10-year-old hero, Ahlo (Sitthiphon Disamoe).

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Christie News Conference on Bridge Flap
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said he took no part in the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge.

title: And You Thought Cockfights Were Brutal
description: Somewhere between squalid exploitation movies and Tarantino brashness, Raze is lurking, waiting to slug you in the face.

title: How Should We Understand Palestinian Actions?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sudan Conflict and Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Being Top Nominee Can Be a Prize
description: LOS ANGELES  IN the chilly predawn here on Thursday, eager publicists will use their fingers and toes to count whose film got the most Academy Awards nominations. There once was a time when the mornings winner had all but locked up the best picture Oscar.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Giants David Wilson to Have Neck Surgery
description: Giants running back David Wilson will have surgery this month to repair a herniated disk in his neck, although it is expected that he will be recovered sufficiently to play next season, the team said Thursday. The Giants had been hoping that rest and treatment might alleviate the injury, which sidelined Wilson for most of the season. Surgery has instead become the recommended option.

title: Take Two Aspirin, Then Roll in the Mud
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: For PC Makers, the Good News on 2013 Is That It Is Over
description: The two leading analysis companies tracking the PC industry just delivered their reports on the fourth quarter of 2013, and it was bad.

title: No More Hall of Fame Votes for Dan Le Batard
description: The Baseball Writers Association of America on Thursday permanently stripped Dan Le Batard of his Hall of Fame vote for handing his ballot to Deadspin as a prank designed to mock the voting process.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: New Estimate Sharply Raises Death Toll in South Sudan
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  As fighting continued to rage across South Sudan on Thursday, a new estimate raised the death toll in the conflict significantly and a senior American official questioned the governments insistence that a coup attempt was responsible for setting off the violence and instability there.

title: An Unpleasant Surprise on Taco Tuesday
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Rev. Robert Nugent, Priest Who Counseled Gay Catholics, Dies at 76
description: The Rev. Robert Nugent, a Roman Catholic priest who spent more than 30 years counseling gay and lesbian Catholics and their families until the Vatican silenced him in 1999, died on Jan. 1 in Milwaukee. He was 76.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The War Over Poverty
description: Fifty years have passed since Lyndon Johnson declared war on poverty. And a funny thing happened on the way to this anniversary. Suddenly, or so it seems, progressives have stopped apologizing for their efforts on behalf of the poor, and have started trumpeting them instead. And conservatives find themselves on the defensive.

title: To Congestion-Bound New Jerseyans, Messing With Traffic May Be Ultimate Sin
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J.  By now, the people of New Jersey are well steeped in political scandal, shrugging off tales of sticky-fingered lawmakers and admitted embezzlers, ties to organized crime and, in at least one case, the attempted trafficking of human organs.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 10-16
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Even as Wages Rise, China Exports Grow
description: HONG KONG  Cheng Chunmeng, the general manager of a manufacturer of colorful childrens chairs in east-central China, gave his workers a 30 percent raise last year to keep them from leaving. His labor costs are rising even faster in dollar terms, as the Chinese currency slowly climbs against the United States dollar.

title: A Race for More Than the Mayor of Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  Engin Bayrak owns a hardware store near the shores of the Golden Horn waterway, where ferries connect the European and Asian sides of this vast city. He has witnessed for himself the vast improvements in services over the last decade as Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Islamist-rooted Justice and Development Party reshaped this city in their image.

title: A Proposal to Speed Up Action on Trade Accords
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders responsible for trade issues unveiled on Thursday bipartisan legislation essential to President Obamas ambitious plans for pacts with European and Pacific Rim nations, but the measure faces opposition from both parties.

title: Today, a Chicken Coop; Tomorrow, the World
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Japanese Begin to Question Protections Given to Homegrown Rice
description: AGA, Japan  For decades, Japan has defended its 778 percent tariffs on rice with a kind of religious zeal. Rice is a sacred crop, the government has argued, not open to trade negotiations. Its farmers are not just defenders of a proud agrarian heritage, but form the nations spiritual center as well.

title: French Far-Right Leader Aims for E.U. Parliament
description: PARIS  The leader of Frances far-right party laid out an ambitious plan to win seats this spring in the European Parliament, hoping to join other extremist parties in provoking a political crisis there.

title: City Study Tracks Transfers by Charter School Students
description: Addressing a common criticism of New York City charter schools, a study released on Thursday said that in general their students were not, in fact, more likely to transfer out than their counterparts in traditional public schools.

title: With Surplus in Hand, California Eyes Debt
description: LOS ANGELES  Ever since he came into office, Gov. Jerry Brown has promised to address what he has long called the states wall of debt built up over years. And now that the nations most populous state is looking at a multibillion-dollar surplus, Mr. Brown, in a $155 billion state budget proposal submitted on Thursday, is pledging to make good on that promise.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 10-16
description: Around Town

title: More U.S. Economists See Half-Full Glass
description: Record exports and the smallest trade deficit in four years. Healthier consumer spending, including the strongest annual increase in automobile sales since 2007, spurred by a booming stock market and an improving housing sector. And a slow but steady pickup in job creation that has pushed unemployment to its lowest level since 2008.

title: French Court Upholds Ban on Comedian Who Mocks Holocaust Commemoration
description: Last Updated, Friday, 8:15 a.m. | A French appeals court decided late Thursday to uphold a ban on performances by the stand-up comedian known as Dieudonn, who invented an obscene salute popular with anti-Semites and frequently sprinkles his act with diatribes against Holocaust remembrance.

title: Dotting the Parks, Monuments to the Famous or Forgotten
description: Remember the Walloon Settlers? The contribution to New Yorks history made by Eugene G. Putnam? Conrad Poppenhusen ring a bell?

title: Rev. Vincent J. Termine, Pastor Who Fought Racism in His Parish, Dies at 93
description: The Rev. Vincent J. Termine, a Roman Catholic priest who helped revive a dying parish in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, in the 1960s and 70s, then angered members of his predominantly white flock when he let black youths from another neighborhood participate in organized basketball at the church, died on Dec. 26 in Johns Island, S.C., where he had lived since 2009. He was 93.

title: Aw, He Seemed So Nice and Sexy
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Call to Honor Pakistani Boy in Fatal Tackle of a Bomber
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Aitzaz Hasan, a 15-year-old ninth grader, was late for school and rushing with two friends to make the morning assembly when they were stopped by a stranger wearing the same uniform as theirs, who curiously asked for directions. Aitzaz grew suspicious, and tackled the stranger as he tried to flee. Then the stranger blew himself up, killing them both.

title: Silver Thief Is Charged With Burglary, Again
description: ATLANTA  A silver thief who has been called the burglar to the stars for breaking into the homes of the rich and sometimes famous has been charged with eight counts of burglary.

title: Its a Jungle Out There, From Snakes to Mine Monsters
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 10-16
description: At the Kids Table With Sarah Lohman

title: Awards Shows Help Clark Productions Bounce Back
description: LOS ANGELES  For decades, Dick Clark Productions trundled along on televisions periphery, making a living by reheating chestnuts like New Years Rockin Eve and the American Music Awards.

title: And the Winner Is ... Award Shows
description: Dick Clark Productions has become more valuable as its product  live award shows  has become more attractive to TV networks desperate to ward off the dreaded DVR.

title: Everyones a Drag, Except That Cool New Neighbor
description: Opens on Friday.

title: For Greg Maddux, an Unassuming Presence Masked a Master of the Pitching Craft
description: On his first day in the major leagues, with the Chicago Cubs in September 1986, Greg Maddux found his locker and noticed the matchup he would see that afternoon. It was Jamie Moyer against Nolan Ryan. Finesse versus power. What a laboratory for an eager student of the craft of pitching.

title: Thomas V. Jones, Builder of Northrop Into Big Military Contractor, Dies at 93
description: Thomas V. Jones, who became chief executive of the faltering Northrop Corporation in 1960 and propelled it to the top tier of military contractors  in the process making and sometimes losing huge bets  died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

title: Obama Seeks Balance in Plan for Spy Programs
description: WASHINGTON  As he assembles a plan to overhaul the nations surveillance programs, President Obama is trying to navigate what advisers call a middle course that will satisfy protesting national security agencies while tamping down criticism by civil liberties advocates.

title: U.S. Mission in South Sudan Shows Limits of Military
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagons recent efforts to help evacuate Americans from strife-torn South Sudan and to bolster security at the United States Embassy there underscore the militarys ability to more quickly send crisis response forces to emergencies in Africa.

title: Searss Sales Fell 9.2% in Tepid Holiday Season
description: Sears Holdings released bleak holiday sales figures on Thursday, as year-end reports and company data from other retailers painted a disappointing picture of the overall season, with little growth over the year before.

title: Events on Long Island for Jan. 12-18
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Understanding New Rules That Widen Mental Health Coverage
description: Long-awaited improvements in insurance coverage for mental conditions and addictions are expected to become more widely available this year as a result of two major steps that the Obama administration has taken.

title: A Korean Whos More Than He Seems
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Robert Hess, 57, Dies; Led Homeless Services Under Bloomberg
description: Robert V. Hess, who as New York Citys commissioner of homeless services presided over a gradual decline in the homeless population until the recession of 2009 caused the problem to spike, died on Dec. 24 at his home in Egg Harbor Township, N.J. He was 57.

title: Movement on the Right
description: If you just listened to Republican politicians, youd have almost no sense that conservative thinking has changed much since Barack Obama beat Mitt Romney over a year ago. But if you hang around the conservative policy wonks, and read certain conservative magazines, the picture is quite different.

title: A Small, Versatile Way to Record Your Life
description: Among all the vast booths at the International CES displaying 4K televisions and devices by big names like Sony and Panasonic was GoPro, a versatile digital-camera maker that was mostly unheard of just a few years ago.

title: Government Owes 30,000 Indians Royalties for Land but Cant Find Them
description: DENVER  Ervin Chavez remembers hearing talk around the Navajo reservation when he was young of money owed to American Indian families by the federal government for land debts.

title: Not So Entertaining
description: IN New Jersey, we like our politicians to be entertaining.

title: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 12-18
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Why Bankers Have Gotten a Pass
description: In recent years, it has become increasingly clear that no prominent banker would be prosecuted for fraud in the run-up to the financial crisis. In the current issue of The New York Review of Books, Judge Jed Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan asks why.

title: Polio Vaccination Effort in Syria Appears to Have Some Effect
description: The first polio outbreak in Syria in 14 years, which caused alarm when detected last September in the war-ravaged country, appears to have been contained halfway through an emergency vaccination effort for millions of children in the Middle East, two top World Health Organization officials said Thursday.

title: Syria Militants Said to Recruit Visiting Americans to Attack U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Islamic extremist groups in Syria with ties to Al Qaeda are trying to identify, recruit and train Americans and other Westerners who have traveled there to get them to carry out attacks when they return home, according to senior American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.

title: Knicks and Heat Offer a Contrast in Franchises and Stars
description: LeBron James learned from his most publicized mistake; Carmelo Anthony ascertained next to nothing from Jamess and his own.

title: Buying Peace of Mind With a Pistol
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Fitful Progress in the Antismoking Wars
description: Fifty years ago this Saturday, on Jan. 11, 1964, a myth-shattering surgeon generals report on smoking and health brushed aside years of obfuscation by tobacco companies and asserted, based on 7,000 scientific articles, that smoking caused lung cancer and was linked to other serious diseases. Those findings expanded as more data was gathered.

title: Events in Westchester for Jan. 12-18
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: After Chris Christies Performance
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey issued repeated apologies Thursday for the abuse of office that now threatens to undermine his political future. Though he sounded remorseful  and clearly sorry that this scandal might sink his ambitions for national office  he blamed his staff for making him a victim. Unbeknown to him, he said, they shut down lanes to the George Washington Bridge to create a four-day traffic jam to punish a local mayor who failed to endorse him in last years election.

title: Sexual Assault Case Yields a Plea Deal in Missouri
description: MARYVILLE, Mo.  A former high school football player, under an agreement with a special prosecutor, pleaded guilty here on Thursday to a misdemeanor and was sentenced to two years probation in a sexual assault case that drew national outrage when an initial investigation two years ago ended with the sexual assault charges being dropped.

title: Pretty, Yes, but for Boats, Ice Can Be a Menace
description: It may not be the Akademik Shokalskiy, the Russian boat recently trapped by ice in Antarctica, but the Brooklyn, a 280-ton tour boat operated by the Circle Line, has had its own troubles with frozen water this week.

title: Splitsville, a Land of Diabolical Lawyers
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 12-18
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Reids Uncompromising Power Play in Senate Rankles Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  With his strong-armed change to the filibuster rule and an iron-fisted control of the Senate floor, Senator Harry Reid has engaged in the greatest consolidation of congressional power since Newt Gingrich ruled the House, unleashing a bitterness that may derail efforts to extend unemployment insurance.

title: U.S. Considers Resuming Nonlethal Aid to Syrian Opposition
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is considering the resumption of nonlethal military aid to Syrias moderate opposition, senior administration officials said on Thursday, even if some of it ends up going to the Islamist groups that are allied with the moderates.

title: Christies Apology for the Sins of His Aides and Appointees Leaves Out His Own
description: Another 900 pages of documents on the George Washington Bridge Tollgate-Gate are due to be published as soon as Friday, and early word is what they lack in punchiness  after all, what could top time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee?  they make up for in venom.

title: A Chilean Dictators Secret Book Collection: Heavy on Napoleon, Light on Fiction
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Augusto Pinochet Ugarte Library, on the manicured grounds of the military academy here, welcomes visitors with an oil portrait of the Chilean dictator himself in military regalia. The painting of General Pinochet, whose government killed or disappeared more than 3,000 people and tortured nearly 40,000 others, hangs above the librarians desk.

title: Deals Show M.L.S. Is No Longer an Afterthought
description: CARSON, Calif.  When Omar Gonzalez left the University of Maryland and was taken by the Los Angeles Galaxy as the third pick in the 2009 Major League Soccer draft, he had a plan: Learn the ropes of being a professional, develop his craft and, when his contract was up, head to Europe, where a bigger stage and payday awaited.

title: The Danish Prince and His Family Drama
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Fallujas Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
description: Adam Banotai was a 21-year-old sergeant and squad leader in the Marine Corps during the 2004 invasion of Falluja, a restive insurgent-held city in Iraq. His unit  which had seven of 17 men wounded by shrapnel or bullets in the first days of the invasion  seized control of the government center early in the campaign.

title: In a Rare Video, Fidel Castro Surfaces
description: Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, made his first public appearance in nine months on Wednesday night at the opening of a nonprofit art studio in the Romerillo neighborhood of Havana.

title: Promising Drug Trial Lifts Stock of Intercept
description: Shares of a small biotechnology company nearly quadrupled Thursday after a clinical trial suggested the firm might have the first effective treatment for a fatty liver disease associated with the nations epidemic of obesity.

title: If Opportunity Doesnt Knock
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLES  Ah, a grid with lots of white space. Theres nothing better than a grid with lots of room to stretch out, except possibly a Patrick Berry grid with lots of room to stretch out.

title: Wall Street Predicts $50 Billion Bill to Settle U.S. Mortgage Suits
description: Wall Street could pay nearly $50 billion to buy peace from federal authorities who are taking aim at the banks over their role in the mortgage crisis, according to interviews and a confidential analysis of the industrys potential legal exposure.

title: Illinois: Chicago Wants Six Months to Revise Rules on Gun Sales
description: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said Thursday that he would ask a federal judge who declared the citys ban on firearms sales unconstitutional to give lawmakers six months to adopt a new ordinance regulating gun shops. The judge, Edmond E. Chang of the Northern District of Illinois, signaled in his decision onMondaythat Chicago could still restrict gun transactions as long as they stopped short of a complete ban. Though I fully disagree, the city has little option but to follow the ruling of the court, Mr. Emanuel, who will not file an appeal, said in a statement. A status hearing is scheduled for next week.

title: Christie Brings His Remorse to an Inconvenienced Borough
description: FORT LEE, N.J.  Nobody had ever claimed that Mark Sokolich was one of the most powerful mayors in America. But on Thursday afternoon, Chris Christie, one of the most powerful governors in the country, flew to Mr. Sokolichs borough to deliver a personal apology.

title: Gmail Plans to Allow Google Plus Users to Send Anyone an Email
description: Google will soon allow people to send anyone an email, even if they do not have the persons email address, as long as both people have a Gmail and Google Plus account.

title: Andrew Luck Is a Fan of Two Types of Football
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Andrew Luck has been preparing all week for Saturdays A.F.C. divisional playoff game at New England against the Patriots. There have been game plans to dissect, film to study and practices to participate in to prepare for the wrinkles of a Bill Belichick defense. Then there was the football that had nothing to do with Tom Brady, Lucks Indianapolis Colts or the game at all.

title: More Naked Heathen Romps
description: You just cant keep a good pagan cult down, although sometimes it seems as if everything colludes to do so. Take Robin Hardys 1973 horror classic The Wicker Man, now having its Blu-ray debut in a Lionsgate Final Cut edition. The film  about a prudish policemans encounters with pre-Christian Celtic practices in a remote Scottish community  has weathered numerous twists and turns in its 40-year existence, including a remake, a quasi-remake and at least three versions of varying length. But its journey concludes on a positive note, even if the film itself does not. On second thought, the film can be a little ambivalent in that department.

title: Chemical Spill Fouls Water in West Virginia
description: More than 100,000 customers were without safe tap water on Thursday after a chemical used to clean coal leaked into the Elk River in Charleston, W.Va., officials said.

title: Christies Apology, Done His Way
description: He was, he said, heartbroken. Embarrassed. Sad. Disappointed. Humiliated.

title: Police Scrutinize Pensions; 6 More Arraigned in Fraud
description: As six more New York police officers were arraigned in state court on Thursday on charges that they feigned mental illnesses to bilk Social Security out of disability benefits, a police commander said the Police Department was scrutinizing the city pensions being paid to scores of retired officers accused in the scheme.

title: Delays in Bidding Help Put Focus on Masahiro Tanaka
description: It is not just that Major League Baseball changed its rules governing how Japanese players could join North American clubs. Masahiro Tanaka and his agent will be the beneficiaries of what is set to become an unprecedented bidding war because of delays, confusion, infighting, counterproposals and more delays.

title: Among Cuomos Proposals, a Tax Break for Renters
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos plan to create a tax credit for New York renters would only begin to address an imbalance in tax policy that historically has favored homeowners over tenants in the state, housing experts said.

title: Taking Responsibility for a Child, Then Raising Five More
description: Twenty-three years ago, in a hospital maternity ward, Bridgett Webb made a pivotal choice.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 9, 2014
Knicks Stun J. R. Smith and Then the Heat
description: During a timeout early in the second quarter, J. R. Smith left his spot at the end of the bench and stood outside the huddle. Way outside the huddle.

title: Jogger Found Unconscious in a Park Dies, but Not Before Being Identified
description: For a few days, it seemed that the strange tale of the unidentified jogger who had lain unconscious in a Brooklyn hospital for a week after collapsing in Prospect Park on New Years Eve would end happily.

title: 2 Paths to New Jersey Governors Office Differed, but Fate Is the Same
description: Bill Stepien was a fiercely loyal lieutenant of Chris Christie who inspired fear in Republican leaders across New Jersey.

title: Ask About New Yorks Monuments
description: Some 800 monuments  like busts and statues of people and animals; memorial benches; and historic plaques  are sprinkled throughout the five boroughs, memorializing the household names of the past. But their fame may have faded with time. Lisa W. Foderaro of The Times has written a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot the city.

title: Signs of Abuse in Toddlers Death, but Few Warnings
description: By age 4, Myls Dobson knew the dislocation of family court hearings and custody fights. He also knew the love of grandparents and aunts. His smiling face beamed from Facebook, a healthy toddler full of promise, dressed up in ties or posing by a courthouse in Manhattan.

title: Rafael Nadal Has Tough Path in Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The hearts of the officials overseeing the draw ceremony for the Australian Open seemed to sink by the time they had read just the first two lines of the mens singles draw.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 10, 2014
description: I am who I am. But I am not a bully.

title: Patriots Response as Teammates Fall: Next!
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The New England Patriots started the season without their five leading receivers from 2012. Two signed with other teams. One left to shoot a movie. One was hurt. One was in jail.

title: Hanging Onto Cruzs Coattails With a Tenuous Grasp
description: A year ago, two pugnacious Texas Republicans with very different backgrounds were sworn in as members of Congress.

title: Prokhorov Will See Different Nets Team in London Than in Brooklyn
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets owner, is planning to attend the teams game against the Atlanta Hawks next Thursday at O2 Arena in London, a club spokesman said. It will be the first time Prokhorov has attended a Nets game since Nov. 1, when he watched his teams home opener against the Miami Heat at Barclays Center. The Nets won that game, a misleading prelude given how the season has played out.

title: Michael Price to Retire From Goodspeed Musicals
description: Michael Price, who has led Goodspeed Musicals in Connecticut since 1968, producing more than 200 shows and sending 19 of them to Broadway, will retire at the end of the year, the theater companys board of trustees announced on Thursday.

description: Question:

description: gawk \gok\ verb

title: Devils and 76ers Are First in U.S. to Team With Online Gambling Firm
description: NEWARK  When Gov. Chris Christie signed a bill last year making New Jersey the third state to allow online gambling, he talked of embracing new ideas to fuel our reconstruction and continued prosperity.

title: Keeping Score While Holding the Cards
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: A Race in One District Draws Focus to Asian Voters
description: A Democratic state representative who is the only Vietnamese-American ever elected to the Texas Legislature has drawn two Vietnamese-American Republican challengers. The contest underscores the diversity of the Houston district in a state where Asian-Americans are the fastest-growing race or ethnic group.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting

title: Alternate-Side Parking Rules
description: Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in New York City in 2014.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) RICHARD TUCKER AT 100: AN OPERA CELEBRATION Isabel Leonard, above, the winner of the 2013 Richard Tucker Award, and a roster including Stephanie Blythe, Stephen Costello, Joyce DiDonato, Rene Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens perform works by Verdi, Rossini, Donizetti, Puccini and Offenbach, accompanied by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the New York Choral Society. Writing in The New York Times about this gala, held Nov. 17 at Avery Fisher Hall and presented here by Live From Lincoln Center, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim commended the stellar lineup, including the exquisite Ms. Leonard and the silken soprano of Ms. Fleming. She added, It was perhaps revealing of the confidence of both these artists  at very different stages of their career  that their repertory choices lay outside the operatic mainstream.

title: Q. & A.: The Wu-Force on Fusing the Sounds of China and the U.S.
description: The beauty of being dubbed a kung fu-Appalachian avant folk-rock group is theres little risk of feeling musically pigeonholed.

title: As Indian Diplomat Exits After Arrest, a Culture Clash Lingers
description: NEW DELHI  Two dozen revved-up television crews were clustered outside a V.I.P. exit at Indira Gandhi International Airport on Friday, waiting for the flight from New York. They had been in place for two hours, and every time a trickle of passengers came into view, they all jumped up and pressed their cameras against the glass.

title: Illiterate, but in Love With Books
description: On the banks of picturesque Dal Lake in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir, sits the only library in the neighborhood, run by a man who loves books but cannot read.

title: Corrections: January 10, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Coastal Provinces Fishing Rules Alarm U.S.
description: Updated, 3:47 a.m. ET | New fishing regulations issued by a Chinese province along the South China Sea have once again focused international attention on a complex territorial dispute and raised the question of what kind of power China will become.

title: Test Yourself | Editing, Jan. 10, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Christie Fires Aide in Bridge Scandal as U.S. Opens Inquiry
description: In Christie Fires Aide in Bridge Scandal as U.S. Opens Inquiry, Marc Santora and William K. Rashbaum report on a scandal engulfing the administration of Gov. Chris Christie.

title: The 12.29.13 Issue
description: THE LIVES THEY LIVED

title: What Snail Snot Can Do For You
description: Batali gets salty; Shinzo Abe or Abe Vigoda?

title: Who Made That Dial Tone?
description: Remove the Receiver from the hook, read a notice in The Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch in 1919, and listen for a steady humming sound, known as the Dial Tone. If you hear the dial tone, place your finger in the hole containing the first figure of the number to be called and pull the dial as far as it will go. . . . (An accompanying article described the noise as being like the buzzing of a bumble bee or other large insect.)

title: Jared Diamond: New Guinean Kids Are Not Brats
description: Your latest book, The World Until Yesterday, is about traditional societies and your research in New Guinea. Why is the acronym Weird central to the book?  In Weird  Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich and Democratic  societies we take these things for granted that just didnt exist anywhere in the world until a few thousand years ago. We encounter strangers, and its normal, and we dont freak out and try to kill them. We eat food that somebody else grew for us. We have a government with police and lawyers to settle disputes.

title: Is Ubers Surge-Pricing an Example of High-Tech Gouging?
description: At 10 p.m. on New Years Eve, I hailed a taxi outside my apartment in Adams Morgan and directed it to a friends apartment in Shaw, a nearby neighborhood, also in Northwest Washington. It took a mere minute to find an open car, and the traffic-clogged two-mile trip cost $13, including tip.

title: The Flying Tomato Would Rather You Not Call Him That Anymore
description: Shaun White sat in a lawn chair on the side of the mountain at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe, trying to think of a nice way to ask one of the young men grooming the hill to shovel some snow up onto the air bag, please. White was there in April to learn a triple cork 1440, a snowboarding trick that requires flipping three times in the air while moving through three different planes  horizontal, lateral and vertical  all while doing four 360-degree spins. Landing a triple cork is considered essential to winning slopestyle, a snowboarding event that will debut in the Olympic Games next month and that involves riding down a course filled with jumps and rails, sort of like those in a skateboard park. Because White had not yet mastered the triple cork, he needed to practice the trick by crash-landing into a giant yellow air bag. Judging from his emphatic cursing, the impact felt horrible.

title: Care of: My Wifes Lovers Neighbor
description: I received an envelope that was addressed to my home but did not include a name. I recognized the last name on the return-address label. I opened the envelope and realized it was intended for my neighbor, a woman I have known, along with her husband, for many years. The letter chronicled the dates and locations of an affair the sender claimed his wife was having with my neighbors husband. I regret reading the letter. Upon looking more closely at the envelope, I was able to discern my neighbors name (the wife) and the words private and confidential, but these were obscured by the postmark. It seems the sender intentionally sent the letter to my home to keep the husband from intercepting it, counting on me to deliver it to the wife. Now that the envelope is open, the neighbors will know that I have read the allegations. What is my obligation: To deliver the letter or to inform the sender that this plan didnt go as intended? NAME WITHHELD

title: We Didnt Eat the Marshmallow. The Marshmallow Ate Us.
description: In a series of famous experiments in the 1960s and 70s conducted by the Stanford psychologist Walter Mischel, preschoolers were invited to sit alone in a room furnished only with a small desk. On the desk sat two marshmallows (or equivalently tempting treats) and a bell. The researcher told each child that he had to leave, but that when he returned, she could eat both marshmallows. If she wanted one marshmallow before then, however, she could ring the bell and eat one, but not both. Then the researcher shut the door, leaving the child alone with the forbidden marshmallows.

title: No Puff Piece
description: A friend who almost never cooks recently made gougres  baked puff pastries with cheese. I could not believe how easy that was, he told me. In fact, I cant think of anything as impressive that needs so little work.

title: The Murderer and the Manuscript
description: Just before Labor Day in 2011, Toni Kirkpatrick, an editor at Thomas Dunne Books, an imprint of St. Martins Press, picked up her phone and called an unfamiliar number with a Southern California area code. She was hoping to deliver good news to a man named Alaric Hunt, the newest winner of a debut-detective-novel writing contest, jointly sponsored by Minotaur Books (another St. Martins imprint) and the Private Eye Writers of America. The contest has a good track record  a past winner, Michael Koryta, a 21-year-old phenom, has since published 10 successful thrillers  and it also comes with a substantial prize: a $10,000 advance and a guaranteed publishing contract for the book that has been submitted.

title: Fruits of the Loom
description: In 1776, America didnt have a single textile mill. There were no spinning mules, no water-powered looms. There were only rumors of what such things might look like and a few nonfunctioning models built from those rumors. Nearly every American woman, except the wealthiest, knew how to spin her own yarn and weave her own cloth, even as across the Atlantic women were moving out of the home and into millwork as England  bent on protecting its export market by safeguarding its trade secrets  industrialized the manufacturing of textiles.

title: Rosanne Cash Goes Home
description: On an icy December morning, Rosanne Cash was making tea in the kitchen of the Chelsea brownstone she shares with her husband, the producer-songwriter-guitarist John Leventhal, and their 14-year-old son, Jakob. Her 25-year-old daughter Carrie, also a singer and the youngest of three children that Cash had with her ex-husband, the singer-songwriter Rodney Crowell, was also staying there for a while. It was a full house, and Cash seemed to like it that way. Carrie appeared from a downstairs bedroom to ask Cash to help her find the save the date cards she wanted to get in the mail for her May wedding to Dan Knobler, a guitarist and producer. Mother and daughter moved around a partly finished jigsaw puzzle on a nearby table, and Cash began looking through a cabinet, pausing to answer a phone call from a close friend, the former New Yorker TV critic Nancy Franklin. Soon the cards were found, and Carrie was off to address them.

title: Big in Japan
description: You might not know me, but Im famous. Dont feel bad. Until recently, I didnt know I was famous either, and most days, even now, its hard to tell.

title: Pictures of Men, Friends or Lovers
description: Trent Kelley wondered how he could study the history of African-American gay men when so many of them had lived their lives in relative secrecy. He found his answer in vintage photographs  which he began to collect on eBay, at flea markets and at estate sales  which depict everything from urban dandies and workers to athletes and soldiers.

title: How Closely Do You Listen to Lyrics?
description: Do you often find meaning or inspiration in lyrics, or are you more interested in the music or beat?

title: Times Minute | Falluja Vets Watch Iraq
description: Also on the Minute, the poet Amiri Baraka dies and an influx of awards shows.

description: In the Video

title: Chinese Online Game Offers Chance to Blast Corruption
description: The website of Peoples Daily, the mouthpiece of Chinas Communist Party, has released Beat Corruption, an online game that allows players to fight graft by zapping greedy officials. Players win points by using their mouse to blast bad guys with a Taser and lose points by targeting virtuous police officers.
