description: Updated 11:07 a.m.

title: N.F.L. Divisional Playoff Matchups
description: Saints at Seahawks

title: The Well Smoking Quiz: Who Looks Older?
description: We know that smoking is bad for you, and that it ages you prematurely. Now, a study provides photographic evidence for this claim.

title: Striving to Be the Berkshire Hathaway of China
description: HONG KONG  Fosun International aspires to be Chinas answer to Warren E. Buffetts investment firm, Berkshire Hathaway, and it wants to be sure everyone knows it.

title: The Kugel Family: Big in Brazil
description: ITS not every day that your family photo appears on a 15-foot storefront sign in the Brazilian Amazon.

title: London Looks
description: As the fashion show season moves on to Milan, some images from the autumn 2014 shows in the British capital.

title: A Tie That Binds Across Cultures
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Ireland's Rebound Is European Blarney
description: DUBLIN  I was talking just before Christmas to a young man who sells shoes in a department store in Dublin. He told me that a television news crew had filmed interviews in the store the previous day. They wanted to know if sales were picking up during the vital holiday period, indicating that the battered Irish economy was, after five grim years, on the rise at last.

title: Daily Report: Seeking New Ways to Make Computer Chips
description: More than ever recently, industry pundits have been warning that the progress of the semiconductor industry is grinding to a halt  and that the theory of Gordon E. Moore, an Intel co-founder, has run its course, John Markoff reports.

title: Top Tennis Players Join Forces With Former Champions
description: Tennis royalty has coached tennis royalty before.

title: IPad Is an Artists Canvas for David Hockney
description: Stand before a huge image of Yosemite by David Hockney and see the artists rendition of wispy clouds hovering over midnight blue mountains. Look closer and see strokes drawn by a stylus on an iPad, and pixels from an inkjet printer.

title: British Regulators Said to Prepare Charges Against Ex-Trader
description: LONDON  British regulators are preparing to bring criminal charges against Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly four years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: New Detail Emerges About Bo Xilais Downfall
description: EversinceBoXilai,theCommunistPartyaristocrat,wasgivena sentenceof life in prison lastSeptemberonchargesofcorruption,verylittleinthewayof newdetailsabouthisdownfallhaveemerged.Butthis week,aChinese magazine,SanlianLife,publisheda31-pagecoverstoryonMr.Bos youngestson,BoGuagua,afavoritefocusofgossipinChina.Heiscurrently a first-year student at ColumbiaLawSchoolandhasbeenspottedatsocial gatheringsinManhattan.

title: The Zombie Confidence Fairy
description: OK, and Im more or less back on duty, although next week Ill be busy in Ireland. But time to weigh in again on a few things.

title: Mumbais International Airport Gets Modern Makeover
description: MUMBAI  For anyone who has traveled through the shiny airport hubs of Asia like Hong Kong and Singapore, flying into Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai can deliver quite a shock.

title: An Affair? France Shrugs, but Its Leader Calls for Privacy
description: PARIS  The photographs show a stout man of middling height striding out of an ordinary-looking Parisian apartment house, a helmet and a dark visor obscuring his face. He gets on a motorized scooter and zooms away into the Eighth Arrondissement.

title: The Medicaid Cure
description: Something really interesting is happening on the health-care front: costs are rising much less rapidly than anyone expected. This is good news for the budget; its also good news for Obamacare. There was much skepticism about promises that health reform would bend the curve, reducing cost growth; well, the curve is bending, and its likely that the cost control measures that are part of Obamacare (and have been in effect for several years) are part of the reason.

title: Changes in Windows 8.1, With Skype Replacing Messaging App
description: Meeting the New Messenger in Windows 8.1

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Central African Leaders Exit Sets Off Rejoicing in the Streets
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  Joyful crowds poured onto the streets of this capital on Friday after the president of the strife-torn Central African Republic resigned under pressure from regional leaders.

title: A Childs Vote for New York
description: Dear Diary:

title: Wong Kar-wai on The Grandmaster
description: The Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai is a global art-house favorite, best known for lushly photographed dramas about romantic loss or frustration, like In the Mood for Love. So there some oddity in the fact that when he finally made it onto the shortlist for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, it should be with a kung fu biopic called The Grandmaster.

title: Growth in Jobs Slows Sharply to 3-Year Low
description: Just when it seemed as if the economy was finally accelerating, the latest employment figures once again confounded expectations of better days ahead.

title: Banks Brace for Reckoning
description: When the dust has settled on investigations into the role of banks in the mortgage crisis, fines could total nearly $50 billion, and that does not include the $13 billion that JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. Put into context, the $50 billion would equal roughly half the total annual profit of large American banks in 2012.

title: The Making Of | Folkert de Jongs Synthetic, Sculptural Costumes for the Wooster Group
description: For the past decade, the Dutch artist Folkert de Jong has gained international recognition for eerily beautiful figurative sculptures made from materials like plastic, polyurethane and bronze. Hes shown at biennales in Sydney and Kiev, is in the permanent collection at theLos Angeles County Museum of Art, has a show through early April at Antwerps Middelheim Museum and will have his work on exhibit this year at the Armory Show and atJames Cohan Gallery. He also has upcoming solo shows in Paris, Milan and Wakefield, England.

title: Thousands Without Water After Spill in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  As 300,000 people awoke on Friday to learn that their tap water was unsafe for brushing teeth, brewing coffee or showering, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with an industrial accident with no clear end in sight.

title: In Blow to Peace Effort, Israel Publishes Plans for New Housing in Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government on Friday published plans to build 1,400 housing units in Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem and the West Bank, a move the chief Palestinian negotiator condemned as a slap to Secretary of State John Kerrys intense push for a Middle East peace deal.

title: For Target, the Breach Numbers Grow
description: Target on Friday revised the number of customers whose personal information was stolen in a widespread data breach during the holiday season, now reporting a range of 70 million to 110 million people.

title: Carlyle Hires UBS Executive for Market Strategies Group
description: The Carlyle Group, the big alternative investment firm based in Washington, has hired a UBS executive to bolster its capital markets expertise.

title: How Do You Motivate Your Teenager to Get Moving in the Cold?
description: If the polar vortex had you hibernating, how has it affected your teenager? The open discussion on the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming is how to get a teen who is disinclined toward activity to get moving, especially in the winter when outdoor fun may be less appealing. I asked parents who have successfully nudged a less-than-enthusiastic teenager out of the house and into exercise to weigh in.

title: The Employment Rates New Normal
description: The share of Americans with jobs did not increase in 2013. The economy added about 182,000 jobs a month, just enough to keep pace with population growth.

title: Suzanne Vega Has Her Own Issues With Llewyn Davis
description: The irate folkies  a group that actually exists  will be paying close attention to how Inside Llewyn Davis fares at the Golden Globes on Sunday, and on the awards circuit beyond. My hunch is that if the film gets a bunch of Oscar noms  especially if it gets a nom for best picture  the dust-up wont go away, wrote Christine Lavin, the singer-songwriter who has been on a mission to clarify some things about what she believes the Coen brothers portrait of the 1960s Greenwich Village folk scene got wrong. Maybe it will become a haboob? she added. Love that word.

title: In Our Pages: January 11
description: 1914: Bleak Week for Fleet Street

title: New York Times Features Every Teacher Should Know About
description: One example of the new Science Take video series.

title: In Life and Business, Learning to Be Ethical
description: LOTS of New Years resolutions are being made  and no doubt ignored  at this time of year. But theres one thats probably not even on many lists and should be: Act more ethically.

title: Paranoia Is the Mother-in-Law of Invention, Puppet Accused of Terror in Egypt Tells BBC
description: In an English-language interview with the BBC on Friday, the Egyptian puppet recently accused of acting as a terrorist mouthpiece protested her innocence. The puppet, Abla Fahita, rejected allegations from a pro-military blogger that unseen hands had manipulated her into sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists during an ad for a phone company.

title: Debating Why the Work Force Is Shrinking
description: People keep leaving the labor force. The share of Americans either working or looking for work sank to 62.8 percent in December, tying October for the lowest level since 1977  an era when women were much less likely to work.

title: Paperback Row
description: KURT VONNEGUT: Letters,  edited by Dan Wakefield. (Dial, $20.) Written over a 60-year period, these letters display all the hallmarks of Vonneguts fiction  smart, hilarious and heartbreaking. It includes chilling descriptions of the Allied firebombing of Dresden and Vonneguts time as a P.O.W.; wry dispatches from his years as a struggling writer; and words of commiseration and encouragement to contemporaries like Norman Mailer and Bernard Malamud.

title: Editors Choice
description: ON SUCH A FULL SEA,  by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Lee abandons realist fiction in this marvelous dystopian fantasy, set in an almost familiar future world. But he continues to grapple with themes of hope and betrayal.

title: Image of the Day: January 10
Hitting the Road
description: In Len Vlahoss debut novel, the Scar Boys are a punk band from Yonkers that hits the road riding a rusty van and working out personal problems while playing gigs in college towns as far south as Georgia. Music to the rescue, muses Harry, the books narrator. Playing and touring demand creativity and commitment, forcing the Scar Boys  actually three guys and a girl  to come of age in this wry, stylish tale.

title: The Making of the Presidents
description: Away back in my childhood, the earliest days of my being able to read, Abraham Lincoln nostalgically remembered on the eve of his first inauguration, I got hold of a small book. . . . Weems Life of Washington.  The future president never forgot its vivid accounts of the battles and heroes of the Revolutionary War, not to mention the causes for which the founders fought. I recollect thinking then, boy even though I was, he reminisced, that there must have been something more than common that those men struggled for. The books stories fixed themselves on my memory, he proudly added, acknowledging that these early impressions last longer than any others.

title: Unbridled
description: The cherished bond between humans and horses is celebrated in many beloved childrens books, from National Velvet to War Horse. But when the real connection is already palpable, why do writers take their horse stories deeply into the realm of the imaginary? Two new books for middle-grade readers use different approaches to the equestrian genre to explore these fantasies.

title: Line of Fire
description: Beginning with the publication of her award-winning young adult novel Speak in 1999, Laurie Halse Anderson has written with honesty and grit, bravely shedding light on such once-taboo topics as rape, eating disorders, suicide and addiction. In doing so, she has helped build the current landscape of contemporary young adult literature. Anderson writes the hard truth, stirring debate and discussion among both fans and objectors, and ultimately creating long overdue conversations about the real issues teenagers face every day.

title: Poems, Protests and Prayers
description: Over the next few weeks, we welcome three new writers to our roster of Bookends contributors: James Parker, Thomas Mallon and Leslie Jamison. Parker, who makes his initial appearance this week, is a contributing editor at The Atlantic, where he has written about everyone from Norman Rockwell and Martin Amis to Charlie Sheen and the lead singer of the 1980s hair-metal band Ratt. He was a staff writer at The Boston Phoenix and in 2008 won a Deems Taylor Award for music criticism from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

title: The Wolf Is Still Bending the Truth, Prosecutors Say
description: Jordan Belfort, the author of two books about his life as the rapacious Wolf of Wall Street and now a prominent motivational speaker, is sending mixed messages, federal prosecutors say.

title: Global Warming
description: THE CLIMATE CASINORisk, Uncertainty, and Economics for a Warming WorldBy William NordhausYale University, $30.

title: A Southern Landscape
description: Elizabeth Spencer published her first novel in 1948. Seven more followed, along with five volumes of short stories and the novella The Light in the Piazza. There would also be a play and an exquisite memoir. Now there is a new book of stories, Starting Over. Given that Spencer is 92, its tempting to call the title audacious, but since there seems to be nothing this extraordinary writer cant do, maybe shes just being realistic.

title: The Music Gene
description: Is it premature to talk of the Powers Problem? For the last three decades, Richard Powers has been bringing out hefty novels at the rate of one every 2.5 years: 11 in all. At his current age of 56, he is, as a novelist, midway on lifes path; presumably he has another 11 or so novels still in him. Powers has won a National Book Award and has been a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize; he has been the recipient of a MacArthur genius grant; he has elicited lavish praise from the critics  most of them, anyway. Two of the words most frequently employed in connection with his literary output are cerebral and ambitious. Cerebral refers to his tendency to lace his novels with scientific and scholarly themes, like artificial intelligence in Galatea 2.2, game theory in Prisoners Dilemma and musicology cum genetic recombination in The Gold Bug Variations. Ambitious refers to his penchant for fashioning narrative structures and symbolic networks on a heroic scale.

title: The There There
description: As a diminutive child growing up in the landlocked Illinois town of Moline, where John Deere built his plow-and-tractor empire, Diane Johnson (author of the popular novel Le Divorce, among other books about Americans abroad) dreamed of a life of adventure, preferably at sea, before the mast. She fled the Flyover (as coastal sophisticates call the Midwest), first to New York, where she was part of the same cohort of aspiring college students at Mademoiselle magazine that Sylvia Plath recorded in The Bell Jar, then to her first marriage to a doctor in California and finally to France, where she now spends much of her time. The one thing you, we, Americans, are not allowed to say is that there is somewhere better than America to live, she writes, confidently having found one of the better places.

title: Flying Through the Air
description: The snowboarder Shaun White practices at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe in preparation for the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia in February.

title: Life in Transit
description: Elisabeth de Waals posthumously published novel takes place in the aftermath of some of the 20th centurys greatest calamities, as it follows Austrian exiles returning to their homeland to encounter a dramatically altered physical and psychological landscape. By 1954, when the action of the novel begins, Vienna has witnessed not only the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire but the Anschluss and Hitlers reign of terror against the Jewish population, as well as repeated bombings during World War II and simultaneous occupation by four victorious foreign powers. Written during the late 1950s, The Exiles Return has an immediacy that makes de Waals readers feel the experiences of its characters in a visceral way.

title: Islanders
description: If there were a prize for ornery old men, the ornithologist Jim Kennoway in Alice Greenways novel The Bird Skinner would trounce every recluse in New England. Refusing help from his remarkably well-adjusted son and incredibly patient neighbors, hes drinking and smoking himself to death on an island in Maine. Trudging along in this Lear-like existence  Wintertime, Jesus Christ, he lived like a bear  hes taken by surprise by the ebullient Cadillac, a remarkable young woman from the Solomon Islands who comes to stay with him before studying medicine at Yale. (Thirty years prior, stationed in the Solomons during the Second World War, Jim befriended Cadillacs father, with whom he has since lost all contact.) If this premise sounds familiar  striking young woman brings hope to forsaken old man  the style with which Greenway weaves her tale of memory and loss is bracing in its restraint.

title: A Vengeful Fury
description: Between the early 16th century and the middle of the 19th, more than 12 million human beings were shipped against their will from Africa to the New World and sold into slavery. An untold number died at different stages of the journey  overland in Africa, during the middle passage at sea or soon after arrival. Among those who perished, most died of disease, some by suicide and still others from wounds or execution following failed revolts.

title: Mystical Pizza
description: In a not-too-distant future, in a world much like our own, a young man sits in a white room, answering a white phone, listening. In his world, fast-food chains and political philosophies are one. Jack-o-Bites chefs and Whiggery Piggery employees brawl with kebab sticks in the public square, and neo-Baconians keep safe houses to protect themselves from the Cathars at the Strawberry Parfait. At the center of it all, Leonard, a customer-service rep for a Pythagorean pizza company, must save the world by time traveling and speaking to historical figures through the Neetsa Pizza support line.

title: Dear Sasha, Dear Volodya
description: Contemporary Russia is short on pleasant surprises, but one is its formidable audience not only for the trashy novels prohibited by the Soviets but also for aggressively untraditional work. In the West, the phrase Russian literature typically conjures standard-bearers of realism  Tolstoy, Chekhov  but perhaps modern Russia is too real for realism. Imagine the madcap American fabulist Barry Yourgrau as an Oprah pick, and you have an inkling of the situation in Moscow, where bookstores are thick with nihilistic postmodern hallucinations by the likes of Vladimir Sorokin, perhaps best known for a sodomy scene between clones of Khrushchev and Stalin.

title: Campfire Girl
description: In her first published story for The New Yorker, Love Lessons Mondays, 9 A.M., Lara Vapnyar wrote about a painfully shy 18-year-old in Moscow, teaching sex ed to 10th-grade girls who have more experience than she does. By the end the young narrator is dating the school Lothario and laughing uncontrollably when one of her students asks why its just as arousing to kiss a boy she doesnt like as one she does. The narrators answer: I dont know!

title: How Arbitration Worked, and What Happens Next
description: Questions and answers in connection with Alex Rodriguezs arbitration case and the ruling, announced Saturday, that he would be suspended for the entire 2014 season.

title: Inside the List
description: Order Now: For the first time in three weeks, there are new names on the hardcover lists  although new may not be the best word to describe the thriller writers W. E. B. Griffin (Hazardous Duty, No. 3) and Jack Higgins (The Death Trade, No. 11). Higgins is well known for his audacious story lines: His 1975 breakthrough, The Eagle Has Landed, concerned a Nazi plot to kidnap Churchill, while his 1989 best seller A Season in Hell imagined smugglers transporting heroin in the corpses of drowning victims. By those lights, The Death Trade  about a nuclear scientist forced to work for the Iranian government  seems almost workaday. Higginss eating habits are less colorful. Im notorious for liking very simple food, he told Virgin Media in 2000. You can take me to some of the worlds top restaurants and Ill leave half of it on the plate. Food is not hugely important to me. Thats not to say Higgins never dines out  a restaurant near his home in the Channel Islands doubles as his office, he explained in the same interview. I go in at lunchtime, do two hours work, and then I eat, he said. And then in the evening Ill go in and do three hours and then Ill eat. Ill write by hand and I get so absorbed it doesnt bother me if the place is full or the musics playing. Its very common, particularly at night, for the waiters to come up and say, Look, its 10 oclock and you havent had anything to eat yet.

title: Teller on Penns Idea, Tims Hypothesis and Vermeers Painting
description: The Tim in Tims Vermeer, shortlisted for the Oscar for best feature documentary, is Tim Jenison, an inventor and friend of the illusionists Penn and Teller. The movie grew out of a conversation Mr. Jenison had with Penn Jillette in which he casually remarked that he thought he had figured out how the 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer was able to produce canvases so lifelike that they still mystify painters and art historians alike.

title: The Execution of David O. Dodd
description: On the afternoon of Jan. 8, 1864, a crowd of 6,000 soldiers and civilians gathered on the parade grounds in front of St. Johns Masonic College in Union-occupied Little Rock, Ark. Some of the onlookers perched in trees hoping for a better view of the days events: the public hanging of 17-year-old David O. Dodd, a convicted Confederate spy.

title: Chrysler to Recall Fire-Prone Jeeps to Add Trailer Hitches
description: After announcing a recall last June over a rear-impact collision fire hazard, Chrysler is finally preparing to recall nearly 1.6 million 1993-98 Jeep Grand Cherokees and 2002-7 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.'s. The fix the automaker is using to correct the problem  the vehicles fuel tanks are exposed to rear impacts  is controversial: Chrysler will install trailer hitches to protect the fuel tanks and reduce the chance of fires caused by rear-impact collisions.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Austria; California; Amsterdam
description: Mozart Week, Salzburg

title: A Desperate Plot to Boost Google Plus
description: When Google launched Gmail, Internet users quickly began using the service. Same with Google Maps. But the company has struggled to get people to try Google Plus, its answer to Facebook and Twitter.

title: Bookshelf: Friends in Fur
description: New picture books about bears include Cubs Big World, by Sarah L. Thomson.

title: Obama to Nominate 3 to the Board of the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to nominate three people to the Federal Reserves Board of Governors, including Stanley Fischer, former head of the Bank of Israel, as the Feds next vice chairman, the White House said on Friday.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Empire of Necessity
description: This week, Greg Grandin talks about Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Coral Davenport discusses new books about global warming; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: When Tourists Rescue Scientists in Antarctica
description: After I covered efforts to evacuate the participants in the ice-trapped Antarctic Spirit of Mawson expedition, an interesting comment was posted by Ted Cheeseman, the co-owner of Cheesemans Ecology Safaris, which runs frequent Antarctic tourist trips. He noted that tourist ships have come to the aid of scientists on occasion, and expressed concern that I was implying that tourists have no right to visit the region. I invited him to send a Your Dot piece building on his comment. Here it is (I added some contextual links):

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Empire of Necessity
description: This week, Greg Grandin and Coral Davenport.

title: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
description: Also on the Minute, a disappointing jobs report and Shaun White gets a makeover for Sochi.

title: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
description: In the Video

title: Detecting a New Season
description: The winter television season brings more significant new shows than ever this year, starting this weekend with HBOs True Detective and including that networks Looking; Foxs Greg Kinnear vehicle, Rake; Sundances Red Road; and USAs Sirens, from Denis Leary. But the big news is likely to be made by the shows that are coming back: The Following on Fox, The Americans on FX, Netflixs House of Cards and, perhaps best of all, the long-awaited third season of Sherlock on PBS.

title: U.S. to Recognize 1,300 Marriages Disputed by Utah
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday made the latest contribution to a fast-moving legal battle over same-sex marriage rights as the Justice Department said that the federal government would recognize as lawful the marriages of some 1,300 same-sex couples in Utah even though the state government is largely refusing to do so.

title: Now Starring as the Jerk You Can Feel For
description: CULVER CITY, Calif  In an early episode of the new Fox series Rake, the down-and-out defense lawyer Keegan Deane, a middle-aged mess of a human being played by Greg Kinnear, is asked by his ex-wife how the man she once loved, a brilliant advocate and caring father, ended up this way.

title: Air Rights: A Cash Bonanza?
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: The Hangover: Cantilevered Buildings of New York
description: Casting a glance skyward in Manhattan these days may include the risk of beholding not sky but horizontal appendages that curve and jut outward from the sides of residential towers and hover like geometric mutants above the roofs of vertically challenged neighbors, inhabiting space once occupied by open air.

title: An Odd Couple, Separated by 55 Years, but Not by Much Else
description: It was after midnight on a recent night at Sevilla, a Spanish restaurant in the West Village, and waiters wandered the aisles, watching the last two diners finish their second pitcher of sangria.

title: Idol Tries to Clean Up Its Act
description: Another season of American Idol begins Wednesday; perhaps you havent noticed.

title: Weill Named Chairman of Hamilton Insurance
description: Sandford I. Weill, the former head of Citigroup, is preparing for his third act in the insurance industry.

title: Ears for Opera, Eyes on the Future
description: On a bulletin board in her tiny, tidy Upper East Side apartment, Beth Morrison has displayed a quotation by the librettist and theatrical producer Oscar Hammerstein II since she first moved to New York City in 2005. Printed on a rumpled, coffee-stained scrap of paper, the note enumerates qualities that in Hammersteins view characterize the mysterious job of a theater producer: a hopeful innocent in fair weather, a stern pilot in stormy weather, a mathematician who prefers to ignore the laws of mathematics and trust intuition, a realist, a practical dreamer, a sophisticated gambler, a stage-struck child.

title: Playing With Tracks
description: The song When the Night Time Comes by NightBus is recorded in an unusual way  with two completely different, complementary versions of the song on the left and right channels.

title: A Window to Bone Disease in a Sharks Skeleton
description: An elephant sharks skeleton is made up largely of cartilage, not bone. Now, researchers have found a possible explanation that could help in the development of treatments for bone diseases like osteoporosis.

title: Negotiators Move Closer on Iran Nuclear Pact
description: Iran and a group of six world powers moved closer on Friday to carrying out the nuclear agreement reached in November, with the Iranian side saying all outstanding issues have been resolved.

title: Corporate Takeover? In 2013, a Lawsuit Almost Always Followed
description: These days, you can be sure that when a company announces it is being acquired, it will also be sued by a bevy of plaintiffs lawyers.

title: Husband-and-Wife Architecture Firms Compete for Vancouver Commission
description: As they find themselves at odds over the Museum of Modern Arts renovation announced this week, the architecture firms Diller Scofidio + Renfro and Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects now also find themselves competing over a new commission. (Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio are married to each other, as are Mr. Williams and Ms. Tsien.)

title: On French TV, No Twerking Before 10
description: Those French  they can be such prudes. The Conseil Superieur de lAudiovisuel, the body that oversees French broadcasting standards, has decided that the promotional video clips for Miley Cyruss Wrecking Ball and Britney Spearss Work Bitch should be effectively banished from daytime and early evening television in France.

title: John Zorn to Present Latest Installment in His Masada Project
description: John Zorn, the tirelessly prolific composer, organizer and genre-scrambler, will throw open the doors to yet another wing of his rambling musical estate this spring, with the premiere of John Zorns Masada Book Three: The Book Beriah. The work will be presented on March 19 at the Town Hall, in a concert involving roughly 20 ensembles, including the Masada String Trio, the Jamie Saft Trio, Fieldwork and Secret Chiefs 3. Mr. Zorn is scheduled to perform on alto saxophone with Aleph Trio, which includes Shanir Blumenkranz on bass and Ches Smith on drums. Tickets will be available on Monday through Ticketmaster and the Town Hall box office.

title: Lobster Stirs Up the Sauce
description: In Rome several years ago, at the all-fish restaurant Quinzi & Gabrieli, I was served a lobster pasta as a first course that haunts me still. Somehow the dish was simultaneously delicate and robust  wide, silky pappardelle noodles napped with a creamy yet intensely piquant sauce.

title: Utah Gay Marriages to be Honored by U.S.
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. says the United States will recognize same-sex marriages officiated in Utah, despite a decision by the state not to do so.

title: The Churchill War Rooms Greet Savile Row
description: Suzy Menkes visits the historic landmark where London's bespoke tailors displayed their finest.

title: Shimmery Orchestrations, With a Tinge of Philip Glass
description: Jherek Bischoff, a songwriter and arranger from Seattle, made his 2012 debut album, Composed (Brassland), with low-budget digital diligence. He built the albums orchestral arrangements by recording one instrument at a time on his laptop. He then drew on some impressive contacts to add vocals, among them David Byrne, Caetano Veloso, Nika Danilova (better known as Zola Jesus), Zac Pennington of Parenthetical Girls and the indie-pop songwriter Mirah Zeitlyn, along with drumming from Greg Saunier of Deerhoof. They recognized a fellow pop experimenter.

title: More Snow Days, Fewer Sick Days
description: The nonfarm payroll numbers for December came in much worse than expected. One possible reason, economists speculate, could have to do with unusually bad winter weather.

title: Google+ Hangout on Human Trafficking
description: Nick Kristof is doing a Google+ Hangout with leaders in the global fight against modern slavery. He will be talking with Rachel Lloyd, of Girls Educational & Mentoring Services, Gary Haugen, of the International Justice Mission, Dave Batstone, of Not For Sale, and Susan Bissell, of UNICEF about what 2014 holds for efforts to combat human trafficking worldwide. Tune in below, to what promises to be a thought provoking conversation.

title: Hold Up, Were Not Through With 2013
description: Lets postpone 2014 for the length of a Playlist  a handful of deserving 2013 albums that almost got away.

title: Money Flows to the Biggest Buyout Funds
description: In the world of private equity, it may help to be big.

title: All That Craft, and Now Some Abandon
description: Almost three years ago,Michele Wiles performed her final Swan Lake with American Ballet Theater. She kept the occasion so private that her partner didnt even realize what was going on. Driven by an urge to experience ballet in a new way, Ms. Wiles didnt so much retire from the company as slip away.

title: Book Review Podcast: Empire of Necessity
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews Greg Grandins Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World. Mr. Delbanco writes:

title: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Mens Wear Shows in London
description: The first round of mens fashion shows this year, London Collections: Men, have come to an end. From street-wear-inspired looks to the more refined and elegant clothing we expect from Englands capital, here are the five best shows from the Fall/Winter 2014 runways so far.

title: Role Reversals Emerge in Dispute Over Obamas Recess Appointments
description: WASHINGTON  C. Boyden Gray, the former White House counsel and ambassador, is among the conservative lawyers urging the Supreme Court to severely constrain the Obama administrations ability to fill executive branch vacancies during a Senate recess. Mr. Gray is exceptionally well versed in the subject, having received his own recess appointment in 2006.

title: Jobs Data Gives Hope for Benefits Extension
description: WASHINGTON  The surprisingly weak December jobs report might have strengthened Democrats hand in the current fight over emergency jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed even as it weakened the party in the larger midterm election battle.

title: House Votes to Increase Security Measures on Health Care Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Friday to strengthen security protections on the HealthCare.gov website, requiring all security breaches of the health insurance exchanges to be reported in a timely fashion.

title: W.V. Governor Issues Warning on Water
description: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin urged affected residents to avoid using tap water after a chemical spill in West Virginia.

title: Robert Gates Skewers the Ugliest Branch of Government
description: What are all those congressional hearing witnesses privately thinking as they face pompous inquisition from phalanxes of ambitious lawmakers tossing gotcha questions like grenades? Congress is best viewed from a distance  the farther the better  because up close, it is truly ugly, advises former Defense Secretary Robert Gates, in his new Washington tell-all, Duty: Memoirs of a Secretary at War.

title: Tonics and Teas
description: Last week, in the course of cleaning out my office and downsizing my cookbook library, I came across an interesting book called Tonics by Robert A. Barnett. The book is a collection of recipes, not just for liquid tonics, but for all sorts of dishes made with foods and herbs thought to improve well being.

title: 12 Years Will Win, No, Gravity, No ...
description: The Academy Award nominations will be announced Thursday, but Oscar pundits dont like to wait until the field is narrowed down to make their predictions. In fact, they often dont like to wait till the films have even been released. Nearly six months before the actual ceremony on March 2, predictions were already being made and second-guessed. Heres a look at how the best picture race has already been won and lost several times over, following the fortunes of 12 Years a Slave.

title: A Collectors Paradise
description: Rudys Hobby & Art in Astoria, Queens, has became a repository for many hard-to-find items, not just in Astoria but the entire city.

title: A Hobby Shop Endures Despite Changes Around It
description: Planes, trains and automobiles  and a colorful assortment of rosary beads.

title: Horror Thriller Has Major Bite in Israel
description: During a screening of Piranha 3D last year in Tel Aviv, the filmmaker Navot Papushado found himself near two girls who were clearly under-age and squirming at the graphic imagery. He escorted them from the room.

title: Big Ticket | A Photographers Refuge for $28.5 Million
description: The quaint collage of ivy-covered brick townhouses that the celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz assembled in the West Village a decade ago and eventually transformed into a leafy compound where she lived, worked and entertained guests, sold for $28.5 million in two separate deals to the same buyer and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Blood Ties and Crossed Wires
description: Years after the fact, two children are found to have gone home from the maternity ward with the wrong parents. They have grown up in very different circumstances, and their biological parents now face difficult choices. The premise for the ABC Family drama Switched at Birth? Yes, but it also describes Like Father, Like Son, an affecting film from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. In this story, the children are 6. One, Keita, has been raised in overprotective affluence, an only child. The other, Ryusei, grew up in humbler circumstances, with siblings and amid carefree chaos.

title: Reaction to Resignation of Central African Republic President
description: Residents in the Central African Republic celebrated the resignation of their president, Michel Djotodia, as a potential turning point in the recent fighting in their country. Many hoped it would signal an end to the violence between Mr. Djotodias Muslim rebel group, Seleka, and the Christian militia groups who oppose it.

title: Leaps and Bounds and Discoveries
description: The American Realness Festival is the kind of event that has descriptions of performances that say things like Taking inspiration from ballet, psychoanalysis, queer theory and Marxism ...  (Jillian Peas Polly Pocket) or, At a small-town tap studio, four dancers prepare for a competition (Tina Satters House of Dance). You never know what youre going to get at American Realness, running through next Sunday, which Ben Pryor started five years ago. If you are curious about the latest in contemporary dance, then wander through the scheduling madness of American Realness, dipping in and out at will. There are established names like Miguel Gutierrez, Ishmael Houston-Jones and Neal Medlyn; there are names less known to American audiences, like Marten Spangberg and Eszter Salamon; there are exhibitions (Sarah Maxfield, Ian Douglas, Mr. Medlyn and Fawn Krieger, Ann Liv Young); there are parties; there will be discoveries. (At the Abrons Arts Center and other New York City locations; americanrealness.com.)

title: The Gun Report: January 10, 2014
description: A federal judge has ruled that it is unconstitutional to prohibit licensed gun stores from operating in Chicago, the epicenter of the nations gun violence. The ruling would also make it legal for adults to transfer ownership of a firearm through a private sale as long as the recipient has a firearm owners identification card.

title: Off the Charts: Japanese Economy Shows Life
description: In 2013, the Japanese stock market rose at the fastest rate since 1972 as deflation appeared to end.

title: Back in the Pulpit After Losing His Church, and Still Supporting Gay Marriage
description: SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn.  Three below zero on a Minnesota morning, and the Rev. Oliver White stomps the snow off his boots as he enters the stucco edifice of Clark Memorial United Church of Christ to lead worship. He peels off an overcoat to reveal the kente-cloth vestments his wife made for him, which match the kufi hat he wears.

title: Bulls to Angels in Spanish Drawing
description: The Morgan Library & Museum has long been known for its extraordinary collection of drawings  nearly 12,000 of them from the 14th through the 21st centuries  especially examples of Italian, Dutch and French old masters. Less known and rarely shown, however, is a small but outstanding group of Spanish drawings.

title: High Culture, In the Basement
description: In town for concerts as part of his New York Philharmonic residency, the pianist Yefim Bronfman devotes Monday evening to Contact!, the orchestras new-music series. At the lower-level Greenwich Village space SubCulture, he will give the premiere of Passions, Reflected, a Schumann-influenced work for solo piano by Marc Neikrug, who has a long relationship with the Philharmonic. Joined by two of the orchestras string players, Mr. Bronfman will also perform Marc-Andr Dalbavies Piano Trio No. 1 (2008); others in the string section will play Poul Ruderss String Quartet No. 4 (2012). (7:30 p.m., 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, 212-875-5030, nyphil.org.)

title: Government Stimulus Lifts Japan
description: HAS Japan turned the economic corner?

title: Exclusive | 995 Fifth Avenue
description: An eight-room simplex on the 6th-floor is about to enter the market at $13.5 million. The building occupies a prime spot opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Museum Mile Elegance
description: A svelte eight-room simplex that blends classic Museum Mile elegance, European lan and the open-ended entertainment flow of a luxury downtown loft is poised to enter the market at $13.5 million.

title: Top Editor at People Magazine Leaving Time Inc.
description: Time Inc. shook up its management on Friday as it prepared itself to be spun off from the media conglomerate Time Warner into an independent company.

title: Shakespeare Double-Bill to Be Treated as Two Shows for Tony Eligibility
description: Contrary to the producers wishes, the Broadway double-bill of Shakespeares Twelfth Night and Richard III will be treated as two separate shows for the purposes of the Tony Awards, and not as a joint production, the committee that oversees Tony award eligibility ruled on Thursday.

title: The Racecar Driver at Rest
description: When Lucas Bize is not reading J. D. Salinger for his high school literature class, he is speeding around racetracks in his Mustang at up to 170 miles per hour. Mr. Bize, who lives on the Upper West Side, is a senior at the Professional Childrens School, also called P.C.S., and a professional racecar driver. At 18, he is the youngest driver on the Racers Edge Motorsports team. On Sundays before a race, besides sleeping in and then hanging out with friends, he will study as much as he can about a track. Occasionally he will go with his parents, Alex, 56, and Evelyne, 45, to their home in Montauk, N.Y., where he can practice using a racing simulator, a computer with a large monitor and a wheel attached. Mr. Bize learned to race by tagging along to tracks with his father, a former business partner of Jay Z in the clothing line Rocawear, and his brother, Dennis, 22; both race only for fun now. Mr. Bizes mother works as his manager. His sister, Natasha, 20, recently moved to Charlotte, N.C., for college.

title: 52 Places to Go in 2014
description: From No. 1 Cape Town all the way to No. 52 Niagara Falls, N.Y., explore the vibrant cities and spectacular coastlines, unexpected spots and new attractions that made our list this year.

title: Symphony Space Artistic Director Resigns
description: Laura Kaminsky, the artistic director of Symphony Space since 2010, and the overseer of its music programming since 2006, said on Friday that she had resigned her position. In a telephone interview, she described her departure as amicable, and said that she would stay on until March 30. But both she and a spokesman for the hall also said that they were parting ways because of differences in artistic vision for the future of the space. A press announcement said that the space would begin a search for Ms. Kaminskys successor immediately.

title: Deft Hands Keep Figure Skaters Looking Sharp
description: BOSTON  The United States figure skating championships had not yet opened Thursday when a skater had a wardrobe malfunction at ice dance practice. Not to worry.

title: American Man, After Jail Term in U.A.E., Says He Was Tried by Kangaroo Court
description: An American man who was accused of endangering national security in the United Arab Emirates  after making a satirical video about a fictitious combat school  said on his return to the United States on Friday that he was given the one-year jail term by a kangaroo court.

title: Pint-Size Players, Texas-Size Fervor
description: Theres no quitting in football. But theres plenty of blood, sweat and tears when youre a baby linebacker exhausted in 99-degree heat, and the coach orders you to bear-crawl across the field. I dont care how much pain youre in, bellows Charles Chavarria, a former Marine, at his team, the Junior Broncos. You dont quit.

title: Harking Back to Countrys Roots
description: For 10 days in the summer of 1927, the Victor Talking Machine Company set up shop in Bristol, Tenn., recording a hodgepodge of hopefuls for possible release. The Bristol Sessions, as we now know them, included the first commercial recordings of Jimmie Rodgers and the Carter Family, which is one reason the sessions are often described as the big bang of country music.

title: Can I Just Pick Your Brain?
description: This week in SundayBusiness, the Workologist  a column by Rob Walker that addresses workplace conundrums  tackles a topic that many business owners will find familiar. How do you handle requests for advice from aspiring entrepreneurs?

title: For the Couple That Loves Joe and Chai
description: Gifts for coffee and tea lovers.

title: Fighting Observation Status
description: Every year, thousands of Medicare patients who spend time in the hospital for observation but are not officially admitted find they are not eligible for nursing home coverage after discharge.

title: Your Comments on Places to Go in 2014
description: Each year we compile a list of places to go in the coming year. And each year we hear from readers: agreements, disagreements, celebration, anger, bewilderment.

title: How We Chose Our List of Places to Go in 2014
description: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after it runs, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. In order to add some clarity to the process, weve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our list of 52 Places to Go in 2014.

title: Bridge Scandal Papers Point to Cover-Up by Chris Christie Allies
description: Officials loyal to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey went to elaborate lengths to make it appear that the September closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge was part of a traffic study, even though their private communications suggest the move was purely political, according to documents released on Friday.

title: Wheelies: The Ford Is Watching Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: From Tweet to Ad to Mini Modern Scandal
description: If youve seen Inside Llewyn Davis, the latest movie by Joel and Ethan Coen, you know that it has an unusual narrative structure: The story unwinds along a loose, rambling path and then loops back on itself, catching hold of (if not quite swallowing) its own tail. The story Im about to tell has a similar shape. Its hard to say where it begins or ends and even more difficult to say what it all means.

title: An Anxious Sally Hawkins, Onstage and in Auditions
description: Sally Hawkins was visibly and audibly nervous presenting an award to her Blue Jasmine co-star Cate Blanchett at the New York Film Critics Circle ceremony on Monday  her hands were shaking as she turned the pages of her speech, which praised Ms. Blanchett for operating at a much higher vibration. So just imagine how terrified she was auditioning for Woody Allen.

title: A Scarcity of New One-Bedrooms
description: For decades, one-bedroom apartments have been a fixture of New York. But finding one going forward, at least in new developments, may become as hard as hailing a cab in a downpour.

title: London Mens Fashion Shows in Search of Direction
description: I SORT OF LOST INTEREST in the London mens collections once I had clicked through the first day or two of shows.

title: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Jackson
description: Yes, I know its only Friday afternoon in New York. But Im in Stockholm, where its 11 degrees and dropping fast, and I wanted something to make me think of warmer climes. And Rhiannon Giddens is always a good thing, especially when she fiddles as well as sings:

title: New York City F.C. Introduces a Philosophy Along With Its Coach
description: There was much talk about soccer philosophy and very little about actual soccer players when New York City F.C. introduced Jason Kreis as its first head coach on Friday. But it will have to be that way for a while.

title: Justices Take Case on Free TV Streaming
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to resolve a dispute between television broadcasters and Aereo, an Internet start-up that the networks say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.

title: Remembrance of News Past
description: WITHIN just over a year weve seen the Newtown shootings, the bombing at the Boston Marathon and the rescue of the kidnapped women in Cleveland. But which details of these events will you remember in a year? In five years? Will you remember the names of the perpetrators or the victims, the places where they happened, or the month and the year?

title: Women of a Higher Calling
description: More women are becoming pastors as denominations proliferate and churches form in nontraditional spaces, such as storefronts.

title: All December Job Gains Went to Women
description: American employers added 74,000 jobs in December on net. All of that employment increase was a result of new jobs filled by women.

title: Underlining the Recoverys Shortfall
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: In Brooklyn, Female Pastors on the Rise
description: Storefronts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick have given rise to many Christian congregations. Over the years, these nontraditional church spaces have been a launch pad for female pastors.

title: Video reviews of The Rocket, Cold Comes the Night and In Bloom
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on The Rocket, Cold Comes the Night and In Bloom. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: For Alex Prager, Its Lonely in a Crowd
description: The photographer Alex Pragers new solo exhibition, A Face in the Crowd, opened at the Chelsea and Lower East Side galleries of Lehmann Maupin last night. Using both still and moving images, the Los Angeles native riffs on the way individuals function in a large group: Physical proximity does not necessarily equate closeness, but there are a million stories in an anonymous mass.

title: Something to Really Talk About
description: Before they became lovers, Stephanie Segura and Becca Sicairos were nearly inseparable, friends with opposite outlooks and personalities, like Bert and Ernie from Sesame Street, Ms. Segura laughs, but without the thick eyebrows.

title: Movie Review: 'The Rocket'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Rocket."

title: Newly Released Files in the New Jersey Bridge Scandal
description: Hundreds of pages of communications related to the scheme to close several lanes leading onto the George Washington Bridge in September were released Friday.

title: Hugo Lindgren Named Acting Editor of Hollywood Reporter
description: Hugo Lindgren, who stepped down as editor of The New York Times Magazine in November, will become acting editor of The Hollywood Reporter for the next three months, according to a Twitter post by Janice Min, who held that job before being promoted.

title: Chicken Stew With Sweet Plantains
description: Melissa Clark transforms a traditional chicken stew into a dish hinting at the tropical with the addition of sweet plantains and citrus juices.

title: Its Bitesize Captain Kirk
description: William Shatner managed to fit a lot more than just Star Trek anecdotes into his did-that-actually-happen? Broadway solo show in 2012. But the epistemological underpinnings of art, science and contemporary civilization were somehow left underdeveloped amid the talk of Ben Folds and T. J. Hooker.

title: Women at the Pulpit
description: Nearly 20 years ago, when the Rev. Susie Elliott, 83, preached her first sermon at Mt. Paran Baptist Church on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, she was an anomaly in Brooklyns male-dominated world of Christian pastors.

title: Movie Review: 'In Bloom'
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "In Bloom."

title: This Birds Gone South
description: A bubbling pot of chicken stew with potatoes is a hearty, comforting thing. But substitute sweet plantains for the tubers, and suddenly your dinner leaps from familiar and predictable to unexpected and a whole lot more interesting  at least for someone who doesnt eat plantains very regularly.

title: Movie Review: 'Cold Comes the Night'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis "Cold Comes the Night."

title: BlackBerry Chief Drops Interim Label
description: OTTAWA  With little fanfare, John S. Chen has dropped interim from his title as chief executive of BlackBerry, the struggling smartphone maker .

title: A Musical and House of Scandal
description: Theres nothing like a scandal to attract an audience. Thats good news for Andrew Lloyd Webber, whose latest musical, Stephen Ward, is based on a British scandal so licentious that it resulted in the resignation of two government officials and the suicide of the shows title character.

title: Premier Urges Award for Boy Who Halted Pakistan Attack
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Friday recommended that a high civil award for bravery be bestowed on a teenager who was killed this week while stopping a suicide bomber from attacking his school in northwestern Pakistan.

title: SodaStream to Bring Some Heat to Super Bowl Ad With Scarlett Johansson
description: In the movie Her, Scarlett Johansson personifies new technology by providing the voice of an operating system. In a Super Bowl commercial, she will try something similar by providing a demonstration of a SodaStream home soda-making system.

title: Actors Union to Discuss Pay for Touring Musicals
description: In response to growing frustrations among some members, the Actors Equity union will hold a town hall meeting on Jan. 27 to discuss salaries and contracts for touring productions of musicals, an issue that also drew scores of actors to a regional Equity meeting in New York on Friday afternoon.

title: Luke Steyn Gives Zimbabwe Someone to Cheer for in Winter Olympics
description: In this weeks One-Page Magazine, I make note of Luke Steyn, an Alpine skier who will become the first athlete ever to represent the tropical African nation of Zimbabwe in the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia. In an email exchange over the holidays, Steyn said he knew that his nationality will make him something of a curiosity among competitors and the media.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Chelsea condo with full-time doormen; an Inwood postwar co-op; and a South Slope penthouse.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: In Cranbury Village, a 1861 Victorian; and a Westchester contemporary on one acre.

title: Fleeing a Backwater to Lunge at Happiness
description: There is something not quite normal about Paul, the teenager at the center of Willa Cathers 1905 short story Pauls Case, and everyone around him knows it. Cather memorably illuminates the outward manifestations of the boys dandyish disaffection: His eyes were remarkable for a certain hysterical brilliancy, and he continually used them in a conscious, theatrical sort of way, peculiarly offensive in a boy. Among his trespasses: a red carnation in his threadbare lapel.

title: Yo, Whats Shaking? Not These Movers
description: The main characters of Lucas Bros. Moving Co., a new addition to Foxs late-Saturday-night collection of 15-minute animated series, have a lot in common with their creators. Kenny and Keef, like Keith and Kenny Lucas (who are also the shows main writers and voice actors), are young black twins who live in a mythical place called Brooklyn.

title: A Central Park Ice Hockey Referee Shares Some Secrets
description: By the third period, Bill Marshall really regretted not putting those heat packets in his skates.

title: Is The Times Giving Proper Credit on the Christie-Bridge Story?
description: The explosive story surrounding Gov. Chris Christie this week is bringing well-deserved praise to The Record, the newspaper in northern New Jersey that has been chipping away at it for months.

title: A Hybrid Pioneer Is Back in the Hunt
description: You might assume that Honda and hybrids go together like Bordeaux and a juicy steak. But despite a reputation for practical and fuel-efficient cars, Honda has largely whiffed on the hybrid front. That has to be vexing for a company that pioneered the hybrid in America, with the two-seat, podlike Insight that beat the Toyota Prius to market in 1999.

title: Immigrants and Red Scare Case Studies
description: Some years ago, Dr. Gabor Nagy, chairman of the Budapest City Councils Committee on Human Rights and Minorities (the largest minority in his city was Gypsies), was shocked by what he viewed as the Balkanization of the New York City Council.

title: White House, in Gatess Telling, Restrained Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  In the early scorekeeping of winners and losers in Duty, Robert M. Gatess unsparing account of his days as defense secretary, Hillary Rodham Clinton has fared better than either President Obama or Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Sudan, the West Bank, Bangladesh and Jordan.

title: Tea Party Delays Spending, Beats Dead Horse
description: It will only cover three days, but once again next week Congress will have to pass a continuing resolution to keep the government open. The current resolution expires on Wednesday, and even though a budget agreement was reached last month, appropriators in both chambers still havent nailed down a plan to tell various agencies what they can spend.

title: Hondas Hybrid Do-Over
description: Honda has returned to the hybrid front with better technology that is fitted to the latest, acclaimed redesign of the Accord sedan.

title: Court Returns Stolen Renoir Painting to Baltimore Museum of Art
description: A Renoir painting said to have been bought at a Virginia flea market will be returned to the Baltimore Museum of Art, from where it was stolen more than 60 years ago, a federal judge ruled Friday.

title: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Traverse
description: Need practical wheels with room for the family? The spacious three-row Chevrolet Traverse is practically a family room on wheels.

title: A Fork? De Blasios Way of Eating Pizza Is Mocked
description: The pizza arrived, steaming and delectable, a smoked-mozzarella-and-sausage pie presented to Mayor Bill de Blasio like a gilded offering to a visiting caliph.

title: Seven Days of Style | Miley Cyruss Latest Drama, The Rows Seasoned Models and DVFs 40th Anniversary
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 4  10

title: Prada to Aid Restoration of Vasaris Last Supper
description: Giorgio Vasaris The Last Supper, an imposing wood-panel painting that was almost destroyed in a 1966 flood in Florence and has been undergoing restoration for more than four years, will be the beneficiary of a grant by the Prada company that conservators hope will allow them to bring the work back to public view.

title: As Shop Owner, Woman Sees Troubling Sides of Herself
description: Living in New York can curiously and frequently feel like an exercise played out on a narrow emotional field, a continual toggle between envy and guilt. You wish for more; so many others seem to have it, after all  more space, nicer furniture, a greater number of things from Lululemon. But you also harbor a discomfort at possessing plenty while legions havent nearly enough. In any given hour you might veer from feeling unduly blessed to woefully disadvantaged. It is not the job of politics to solve the problem of this kind of split perspective, but it remains one of the chief psychological byproducts of inequality for those who occupy a place in the citys vast and steeply tiered middle class.

title: American Freed From Prison in United Arab Emirates
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An American who was detained and sentenced to a year in prison in the United Arab Emirates after posting a video online that satirized Dubai youth culture has returned to the United States after being released.

title: Long-Eared Owls, Built for Stealth, Often Go Unnoticed
description: The long-eared owls plumage is a tapestry of warm and cool grays, tawny browns and chestnut highlights. Some of natures most lavish camouflage, it is as close to bark as a bird can produce.

title: A New Cultural Venue, Southampton Center, Hires Its First Director
description: The Southampton Center, a new cultural organization at the Parrish Art Museums former site, on Jobs Lane in Southampton Village, N.Y., has hired Michele Thompson as its first director.

title: Twitter Gears Up for Second Fiction Festival
description: Get ready for some #seriouslyshortstories. The second annual Twitter Fiction Festival is slated for March 12-16.

title: A Mix That, Unabashedly, Doesnt Really Mesh at All
description: Listeners can discern links between eclectic works on a program in various ways, often by style or nationality, or perhaps the way one composer influences another. But no obvious aesthetic threads wove through the polyglot lineup on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. In the New York Philharmonics program book, the music director, Alan Gilbert, described the offerings as a bouquet of varied masterpieces.

title: Determining New York Citys Record Wind Chill
description: Q. Tuesdays freeze was hideous. What was the lowest wind-chill temperature ever recorded in New York City?

title: Rethinking How Baseball's 'Greats' Are Chosen
A Coupling as Bizarre as the Murder
description: The success of HBOs new Sunday night crime drama, True Detective, depends on two pairs of men, a couple of veterans and a couple of relative rookies. Upfront, and drawing all the attention, are the movie stars Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, playing a mismatched team of Louisiana state cops.

title: Actor-Doctor
description: Clancy O'Connor, the understudy for the play "Buyer & Cellar," talks about the demands of his job.

title: The Power of Imagination
description: Clancy OConnor on his strategy for perfecting comedic timing while rehearsing on stage in front of an empty house.

title: Americans Traveling to Winter Games Cautioned
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department issued a travel advisory on Friday cautioning Americans planning to attend the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia, that terrorists have threatened to attack the Games. The advisory also expressed concern about the quality of medical care in the region, noting that it could differ substantially from Western standards.

title: Even Cheap Wine Can Work a Little Magic
description: Its unusual for a tragedy-obsessed art form, but for the last month or so, the fare at the Metropolitan Opera has been dominated by works that end happily and without too many bodies piled up. There have been runs of Strausss elegant Der Rosenkavalier and Mozarts sublime The Magic Flute, as well as new productions of Verdis merry Falstaff and Johann Strauss Jr.s frothy Die Fledermaus. (If you really needed death, Tosca and Eugene Onegin were there, too.)

title: Hope Under the Grip of Oppression
description: Paulo Brusckys career as an artist began in a difficult time and place: Recife, Brazil, a few years after the 1964 coup that led to a dictatorship lasting nearly 20 years. Like other artists  and anyone who came under government suspicion  Mr. Bruscky was arrested (more than once), interrogated and tortured. But focusing only on the violent context of his work undermines what it set out to prove, which is that radical art can flourish even in repressive circumstances, and that it can be a form of communication, liberation and optimism, as the title Paulo Bruscky: Art Is Our Last Hope suggests. Installed at the Bronx Museum, the exhibition includes 140 works of sculpture, performance documentation, mail art and photography made between 1971 and 2011.

title: Ethnic Segregation at a U.N. Camp in South Sudan
description: Reporting from South Sudan on Friday, the BBC correspondent Alastair Leithead discovered that civilians taking refuge from fighting at a United Nations base outside the town of Bentiu were being segregated along ethnic lines by the peacekeepers.

title: A Rising Tide of Record Sales May Not Lift All Boats
description: The cluster of six collector-car auctions that get underway in the Phoenix area this week  and a 3,000-car sale by Mecum Auctions a week later in Florida  come five years after a major market correction, possibly providing clarity and insight on the state of the recovery.

title: Measures of the Collectible-Car Market
description: Rob Sass looks at some of the cars to be offered in the Arizona auctions this week that may provide a gauge of value trends.

title: Tech Companies and White House Discuss Surveillance Reform
description: Representatives from tech companies including Google, Twitter, Yahoo and Microsoft met on Friday with White House staff members to discuss Internet surveillance reforms.

title: The F-150s Aluminum Diet
description: DETROIT  When Ford rolls out its redesigned F-150 pickup truck here on Monday morning to kick off two days of press previews for the 2014 North American International Auto Show, the automaker will be making one of the boldest product gambles in its 111-year history.

title: Ice Truck Starts, Moves and Melts, but No Heated Seats
description: OTTAWA  With no inkling that the polar vortex would freeze much of North America in January, executives at Canadian Tire, the countrys leading retailer of automotive and household goods, managed to hit on what proved a timely topic  ice  when they developed a winter advertising campaign for a new product.

title: At CES, Wired Cars Reach Out
description: LAS VEGAS  Not that long ago, a telephone meant a black two-piece unit with a handset and a rotary dial. Nowadays, the telephone has been completely redefined as a smartphone capable of performing an exponentially expanding array of tasks.

title: Magical Crockery, Pop Music Parody, a Hula Hoop and Other Experiments
description: American Realness, a small-scale annual performance festival of the Abrons Arts Center, began just after 7 on Thursday evening with the audience seated onstage at the centers playhouse. In a 45-minute solo show titled Wonder, a naked woman, Michelle Boul, briskly paced a figure-eight pattern around the space with a fixed smile for several minutes, to some mild rock music. Later she donned dancewear and, at one point, a full-length blue gown and matching wig.

title: Times Minute | Recognizing Gay Marriages
description: Also on the Minute, tabloid trouble in Paris for President Francois Hollande and monuments of the forgotten in New York City.

title: Times Minute | Recognizing Gay Marriages
description: In the Video

title: In Insider Case, Harvard Classmates on Different Sides of the Court
description: In May 1999, on the stately campus of Harvard Law School, Mathew Martoma was facing expulsion for doctoring his grades in the hopes of securing a coveted judicial clerkship.

title: Playing Bridge Onboard the Silver Whisper
description: Slow down, you play too fast. You got to make the winners last. Just kickin down the trump tricks. Looking for fun and feelin groovy.

title: In This Dance Performance, Love Takes a New Shape
description: The vibrant, convivial and unfussy American Realness performance festival, now in its fifth year, is at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side through January 19. Debuting last night was 13 Love Songs: dot dot dot, the first evening-length collaboration between friends Ishmael Houston-Jones, a downtown dance pillar in his 60s who still fearlessly puts his body through brutal and manic paces, and Emily Wexler, a big-boned, flame-haired 30-something who matches his self-flagellating bravado.

title: Moelis Is Said to Ready a Potential Public Offering
description: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has begun working with advisers on a potential initial public offering, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Stop Asking Me for My Email Address
description: Its hard out there for a paranoid cybersecurity reporter.

title: Contractor for Health Portal Replaced, but Says We Were Not Fired
description: OTTAWA  The contractor hired to build the computer enrollment system for President Obamas health care law said Friday that it would stop working on the troubled insurance exchange when its contract expires at the end of February.

title: Two Plays, Four Actors and One Company
description: The French military captain (who will shortly thereafter become an English earl) is at a loss as to why everybody is so smitten with this peasant girl whos suddenly shown up in their midst. Its not as if she were particularly pretty or intelligent or, heaven forbid, sexy.

title: Gender Politics Wiggles Into a World Guys Staked Out
description: Laura Jane Grace, the frontwoman of the punk band Against Me!, introduced all the new songs by name on Thursday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, as the singer of a band with a new album generally does, and should do.

title: The Next Data Privacy Battle May Be Waged Inside Your Car
description: Cars are becoming smarter than ever, with global positioning systems, Internet connections, data recorders and high-definition cameras. Drivers can barely make a left turn, put on their seatbelts or push 80 miles an hour without their actions somehow, somewhere being tracked or recorded.

title: An Invitation to Geneva Two
description: An international summit to address the conflict in Syria, called Geneva Two, is scheduled to begin on Jan. 22 in Montreux, Switzerland. (Hotels in Geneva were fully booked by attendees to a watch convention.) The United Nations this week began sending out invitations, and Ayman Abdel Nour, a dissident Syrian exile who was once a friend of President Bashar al-Assads, posted one Thursday on his popular Arabic-language blog, All4Syria.

title: Wrestlers in Leather: What More Is Required?
description: The Legend of Hercules, a new 3-D work of Classical beefcake scholarship, directed by Renny Harlin, is likely to be met with ridicule. At the crowded preview screening I attended on Thursday night in Manhattan, there were audible hoots of derision, which were, for the most part, well earned. But really, this movie, with its relatively modest running time and not-quite-household-name cast, is no more ridiculous than, lets say, the Thor movies, and a lot less pretentious. It delivers what it promises, which is muscular guys in skimpy clothes fighting and howling, as well as some large-scale digitally enhanced battle sequences.

title: Big Break? Well, Eyes Will Be on Him
description: The Off Broadway hit Buyer & Cellar has delivered a 200 percent return to its investors in just six months, and everyone involved knows the main reason: The star, Michael Urie (televisions Ugly Betty), who has received phenomenal reviews in the one-man play. But with Mr. Urie on vacation this weekend, a perennial dream of New York actors is coming true. The understudy is going on.

title: Video: An Updated Chevy Traverse That Can Fit the Family
description: Recently, I discovered that my older brother and his wife were interested in a Chevrolet Tahoe. Their reasoning was simple  its three rows of seating would be handy when chauffeuring my nieces soccer teammates and gear. And they love the S.U.V. look.

title: Two Power Options in One Small Package
description: LAS VEGAS  Ventev, a company that makes battery and charger products, has an extra-compact car charger that manages to squeeze in an auxiliary battery.

title: Searching for Philomenas Real Son
description: In the early-to-mid 1980s, if you were a gay man in Washington working in politics, chances are you ended up on L Street near Capitol Hill, at a bar called Lost & Found.

title: After Accidents, North Dakota Senators Want Stiffer Rail Safety Rules
description: After train accidents involving North Dakotan crude oil, the states political leaders are putting pressure on the Obama administration to improve railroad safety regulations, with some even urging a slowdown in drilling until safety solutions are found.

title: At a Bay Area Club, Exclusivity Is Tested
description: The game was called describe your superpower. Five men and women, who had met two hours earlier, lounged on shiny gold couches and boasted about their hidden talents.

title: Bill Cunningham | Thrills and Chills
description: As the temperature bounced around zero last week, people in need of cheering up could have viewed an array of exotic orchid blooms in markets.

title: Bill Cunningham | Thrills and Chills
description: Last Tuesday and Wednesday, some women and men paraded in fur coats from an earlier era. Others protected their faces by wrapping them in scarves. One woman, taking her cues from the early 1960s, stood out with bare legs as she walked to work.

title: A Strong Sense of Fashion
description: WHO Tina Fey

title: They Want Her on Their Side
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In 2007, Brandee Barker and a colleague drove to a Nordstrom in Palo Alto, Calif., and bought Mark Zuckerberg a black suit. Mr. Zuckerberg, a founder of Facebook, was embarking on his first trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, and Ms. Barker, then the head of public relations for his growing company, thought the occasion called for something more formal than his signature hooded sweatshirt.

title: Christies Efforts at Damage Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Evening Hours | Memorable Lanes
description: Bill Cunninghams 2013 in parties.

title: Obama Counts on Power of Convening People for Change
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama may have lost the power of persuasion with Congress, but he still has the underrated power of invitation to the White House. Since congressional Republicans remain hostile as ever to his agenda, next week Mr. Obama will begin hosting influential groups in the West Wing to try to spur specific action on national problems short of changes to federal law.

title: Violence in Football: Why Do We Tolerate It?
A Decision to Go to Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Views of the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: The Power of One
description: I love your dress tonight, gushed Ashlan Gorse, a correspondent for the E! network, thrusting a microphone toward Julianne Moore as the actress walked the red carpet to a Golden Globes after-party last year. How many did you have to try on?

title: Sexual Assault Charges Dropped at Annapolis
description: WASHINGTON  Charges in a sexual assault case have been dropped against a Naval Academy midshipman after his statements about the encounter were determined to be inadmissible because he had not been read his rights before questioning and, as a result, there were no reasonable grounds to prove a crime was committed, the Navy announced Friday.

title: The Rwandan Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: Toiling to Bring Rwanda Genocide Suspects to Justice
description: REIMS, France  ABOVE his desk in a peaceful and tidy townhouse with pots of geraniums hanging from the windowsills and walls covered with photos of his children, Alain Gauthier keeps 24 files labeled with the names of some of the men and women accused in one of the most appalling crimes of the 20th century.

title: Federal Consumer Agency Ponders Its Next Crusades
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which has already overcome considerable political resistance, has managed to pack some punches in the last few months on behalf of the purchasing public it represents.

title: Fury in Sri Lanka at U.S. Embassy Tweet on Killing of Tamils
description: The Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense expressed shock and anger on Friday at what it called a baseless allegation against the nations military in a photo caption posted on the official Twitter feed of the United States Embassy the day before.

title: SAC Trader Corrupted Doctors, Prosecutor Says
description: Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, corrupted doctors to get an illegal edge that helped him perpetrate the most lucrative insider trading scheme in history, a federal prosecutor said on Friday.

title: In Rhino Horn Case, Judge Sees a Criminal Instead of a Nave Kid
description: Michael Slattery Jr. stood in court with his hands clenched behind him as if they were still in the shackles that had just been removed. It was time for his sentencing on Friday, in federal court in Brooklyn, an often surreal setting in which very different versions of the same human are described for the judges careful consideration.

title: Thai Beer Loses Esteem After Heiresss Remarks
