description: A federal judge in Oklahoma ruled Tuesday that the states constitutional amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the federal Constitution, the latest in a string of legal victories for gay rights and one that occurred in the heart of the Bible Belt.

title: The Joys of Rambling, as Artists and Raconteurs
description: Perhaps someone suggested to all the recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Awards that they should stretch things out during Monday nights ceremony at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Allen Room. Or perhaps the nights first recipient, Jamey Aebersold, the pioneering developer of Play-A-Long books and recordings, did that simply because he felt compelled to, and the others  Anthony Braxton, Richard Davis and Keith Jarrett  played along, to some degree.

title: A Confused Boy Wants to Play, Even When Others Want to Fight
description: Though licking around the edges of almost every scene, war is never allowed to intrude on the rose-tinted uplift of When I Saw You, a gauzy lament on displacement and disruption.

title: Sea Salts Spiked With Chile, Italian Hot Chocolate and More
description: To Savor: Old Favorites, New Neighborhood

title: Hungers Unsatisfied: Mouths Full, but Only With Words
description: Im not sure if this is a spoiler, or simply stating the obvious, but there is no feast in Feast. The burnished table remains bare, the performers insatiable mouths empty, and wretchedly so.

title: A Fan-Financed Game With a Retro Feel
description: Perhaps because video games are often, and wrongly, viewed solely as technology, they are thought by many to be perpetually improving. And sure, the past few decades have brought changes. Visuals have shifted from ragged, chunky blocks to three-dimensional computer animation. Sounds have gone from either nonexistent  as in the text adventure games of the 1970s and 80s  or blips and beeps to fully recorded voice performances and orchestral scores that sometimes rival the best productions for film and television.

title: Ad Lauds Southerland as Health Law Foe
description: Americans for Prosperity is helping Republicans, like Representative Steve Southerland II of Florida, who opposed the Affordable Care Act.

title: Ad Lauds Mike Coffman as Health Law Foe
description: Americans for Prosperity is helping Republicans, like Representative Mike Coffman of Colorado, who opposed the Affordable Care Act.

title: Times Minute | Christie on New Jersey
description: Also on the Minute, the French president brushes off questions about an affair and a review of Michel Richard's new restaurant.

title: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
description: Between 4.4 million and 6.5 million immigrants illegally in the United States could gain an eventual pathway to citizenship under proposals being discussed by Republicans in the House of Representatives, according to an estimate published Tuesday by the National Foundation for American Policy, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

title: Times Minute | Christie on New Jersey
description: In the Video

title: The Embodiment of an Idea, and Some Indelible Hits
description: The physical dies. Ideas are forever.

title: Low-Key Impresario at High Altitude
description: LOS ANGELES  For a guy with one of the biggest jobs in movies, John Cooper keeps an extremely low profile. He is the director of the Sundance Film Festival, yet Robert Redford remains its public face. Mr. Cooper loathes red carpets, preferring a quiet life in suburban Los Angeles with his husband and three daughters.

title: Music Teacher Pleads Guilty to Molesting Girl, 9
description: A 71-year-old music teacher who ran a music school for children in Manhattan admitted in court on Thursday that he had molested a 9-year-old girl under his tutelage, pleading guilty to forcible sexual conduct against a child in return for a two-year sentence, the Manhattan district attorneys office said.

title: Three Microphones to Filter Out Ambient Noise
description: The German company Sennheiser has a long history of making headphones and microphones, and those two products have joined in a modernized twist: a Bluetooth ear piece that uses three microphones for noise cancellation.

title: Sony Prepares for Widespread Use of 4K TVs With a 4K Camcorder
description: The major TV manufacturers are making a line of new 4K televisions  sets with nearly four times the resolution of todays best mass market sets.

title: At Auto Show, Tesla Defends Safety Record
description: DETROIT  The North American International Auto Show has a familiar rhythm for automakers making a presentation  gather a crowd, announce new products and talk excitedly about the future.

title: Order Chinese, and Not by the Numbers
description: Here is one more thing the smartphone has now replaced: Your Chinese-reading friend you drag to restaurants to read the Chinese-only menus. Waygo, an app for the iPhone, is built to translate Chinese characters into English. (An Android version is being tested.)

title: When Rosanne Cash Is Among Your Close-Knit Friends
description: The blog Mason-Dixon Knitting exists as a series of letters between two friends, Kay Gardiner and Ann Shayne, who share stories about everything from sewing to denim yarn to their husbands and travels. Gardiner  who lives in Manhattan; Shayne is in Nashville  happens to belong to a sewing circle that includes Rosanne Cash, whose new album, The River and the Thread, was the occasion for an article about her in last weekends magazine.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Competing With North Korea on Credit Card Security
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Listen Up | The Lofty Ambitions of Communion Records
description: Last Tuesday, Ben Lovett, the London-born, New York-based co-founder of the record label and events company Communion, pondered the soon-to-be-packed floor of the Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side. It makes me feel quite old, the 27-year-old said. When youre 19, you just sort of have limitless energy. Thats how old he was in 2006, when he launched Communion in its earliest form as a club night in Notting Hill, London. A year later, he also co-founded the folk-rock band Mumford & Sons, which soon became a Grammy-winning touring juggernaut. Meanwhile, Communion has evolved into a promotions giant and global musical tastemaker with a presence in both London and New York. Its enough to make anyone feel stretched.

title: Regulators Ease Volcker Rule Provision on Smaller Banks
description: Updated, 7:26 p.m. | Federal regulators on Tuesday bent to the will of the banking industry and some lawmakers and revised a rule that would have forced community banks to take write-downs on a security that many had invested in before the financial crisis.

title: VL Automotive Destino Red Concept: A Convertible Pipe Dream?
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: VL Automotive Destino Red concept

title: Dozens Reportedly Arrested in Nigeria Amid Antigay Crackdown
description: Homosexual sex is illegal in Nigeria, where in some states ruled by Islamic law gay people can be legally stoned to death. Still, the government in recent weeks has decided to crack down on gay Nigerians both harshly and in secret, arresting dozens of suspected gay men in the countrys north and signing into law a sweeping measure that punishes gay marriage and even the formation of gay associations or clubs with as many as 14 years in prison.

title: Bailed-Out Bankia Is Symbol of Spain's Financial Revival
description: MADRID  Less than two years ago, Bankia looked like a Spanish version of Lehman Brothers: a big, troubled institution whose collapse threatened to take down a countrys financial system.

title: Mundane, Meet Dramatic
description: The gold-plated clich that a picture is worth a thousand words is flipped on its head in Brand New Ancients, the thrillingly good, genre-bending show from the young British writer and performer Kate Tempest, at St. Anns Warehouse through Sunday. As Ms. Tempests gorgeous streams of words flow out, they conjure a story so vivid its as if you had a state-of-the-art Blu-ray player stuffed into your brain, projecting image after image that sears itself into your consciousness. Both as writer and performer, Ms. Tempest stitches together words with such animate grace that language acquires an almost tactile quality, and the drama she unfolds  of betrayal, disappointment and violence among a handful of not especially special London dwellers  soars to operatic dimensions.

title: Different Ways of Confronting Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Slavery in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Diplomats and Their Help
description: To the Editor:

title: A Palestinian View of Mideast Prospects
Generations Blending: Better Dodge The Blades
description: The actor and comic John Hodgman removes the mask he regularly wears  of the complacently geeky, avuncular expert on everything whos really an expert on nothing  to reveal some of his personal anxieties in I Stole Your Dad, his new solo show at the Public Theater. In this agreeable if not particularly substantial monologue, the Under the Radar Festival edges toward more populist terrain than it usually occupies. The show is essentially standard stand-up comedy featuring a familiar performer.

title: Axe, Switching Gears, Strikes a More Earnest Tone
description: AXE, the mens fragrance and grooming brand, is known for broad humor in its advertising, but a commercial that will air during the Super Bowl strikes a decidedly somber note.

title: How the Poor Get Washed Away
description: WHEN Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines in November, killing more than 6,000 people and leaving more than four million homeless, one group was particularly hard hit: the landless poor. More than a thousand of the dead lived in a single squatter camp.

title: Eni Is Said to Abandon Polish Shale Aspirations
description: LONDON  Eni, the Italian oil giant, is giving up on producing natural gas from shale rock in Poland, not long ago considered the most promising country in Europe for the new fuel source.

title: Tobacco, Firearms and Food
description: Lets say your beliefs include the notion that hard work will bring good things to you, that the golden rule is a nice idea though it may occasionally have limits, and that its more or less every person for him or herself. Your overall guiding force is not altruism, but youre not immoral; youre a good citizen, and you dont break any major laws. This could describe many of us; most, maybe.

title: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency has implanted software in nearly 100,000 computers around the world that allows the United States to conduct surveillance on those machines and can also create a digital highway for launching cyberattacks.

title: The Nuts and Bolts of Network Neutrality
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected Federal Communications Commission rules that required Internet service providers to treat all traffic equally. The so-called network neutrality rules were championed by Internet companies worried that the carriers could start charging for preferential treatment to information carried on their networks.

title: The Man on the Wall
description: Ive always thought that the reason Ariel Sharon was such an enduring presence in Israeli political life is that he personally reflected three of the most important states of mind that the state of Israel has gone through since its founding. At key times, for better and for worse, Sharon expressed and embodied the feelings of the Israeli Everyman as much, if not more, than any Israeli leader.

title: World Bank Is Expecting Widespread (if Still Possibly Turbulent) Growth for 2014
description: WASHINGTON  After years of recession, financial crisis, fiscal wars and a patchwork recovery, there are relatively few dark clouds on the horizon for the global economy.

title: Europe Reaches Agreement on Trading of Derivatives
description: Updated, 3:07 p.m. |

title: Minnesota Orchestra Contract Ends Long Lockout
description: One of the most contentious labor battles in the classical music world ended on Tuesday when the musicians of the Minnesota Orchestra, who had been locked out for more than a year, agreed to a new contract with smaller pay cuts than management had initially sought.

title: Should Drug Enforcement Be Left to the States?
Under Investor Pressure, Utility to Study Emissions
description: FirstEnergy, one of the countrys largest electric companies, has agreed to work toward reducing its carbon emissions in response to pressure from shareholders including New York State and Connecticut pension funds, New York Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli said on Tuesday.

title: Small Deal for N.F.L. Games Has Major Implications and Potential
description: The N.F.L.s plan to sell a package of Thursday night games to a broadcast or cable network represents an unusually modest moment in its recent television history.

title: Seeking Clues to Obesity in Rare Hunger Disorder
description: Lisa Tremblay still recalls in horror the time her daughter Kristin pulled a hot dog crawling with ants from the garbage at a cookout and prepared to swallow it.

title: Training Fighters of Future Across Gaza
description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip  Dozens of high school students scrambled among the sand dunes here in recent days, learning how to shoot AK-47 rifles, crawl under barbed wire and jump over burning tires. Their bearded commanders barked at those who were too slow in hoisting iron bars overhead or those who hesitated around the thick flames.

title: (Not) Writing Click Bait Headlines for Fun and Profit
description: I love my baby rhinoceros.

title: 787s Battery Emits Smoke a Year After Jets Grounding
description: Nearly a year after Boeings 787 Dreamliners were grounded for three months because of hazards from their lithium-ion batteries, Japan Airlines said on Tuesday that one of its 787s vented smoke when a battery failed.

title: Ad Hits Mary Landrieu on Health Care
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

title: Tech Security Upstarts Enter Fray
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steve Bennett, the chief executive of the computer security company Symantec, is spoiling for a fight.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate
description: Recent Sale

title: Mexico Faces Obstacle in Curbing Vigilantes Fighting Drug Gang
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexican soldiers met fierce resistance on Tuesday as they began disarming vigilante groups that have been fighting drug gangs in the agricultural lowlands of the western state of Michoacn.

title: Fighting a McDonalds in Queens for the Right to Sit. And Sit. And Sit.
description: Shortly after New Years Day, Man Hyung Lee, 77, was nursing a coffee in his usual seat in a narrow booth at a McDonalds in Flushing, Queens, when two police officers stepped into the fluorescent light of the restaurant.

title: Testifying in SAC Case, Doctor Admits Sharing Data
description: When Mathew Martoma, a hedge fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors, met Joel S. Ross, a prominent physician specializing in Alzheimers research, for dinner at a Midtown Manhattan restaurant, Mr. Martoma shocked Dr. Ross with a prescient question.

title: $1.1 Trillion Bill to Avoid Federal Shutdown Covers Many Local Interests
description: WASHINGTON  A cryptic reference turns up on Page 399 of a six-inch-thick piece of legislation that congressional appropriators unveiled Monday night, calling for an extra $155 million worth of financing for the Department of Energy to promote its nuclear projects.

title: Joel S. Marcus
description: Mr. Marcus, 66, is the chairman and chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in Pasadena, Calif. The company, which Mr. Marcus also co-founded in 1994, owns and operates properties in the life science industry, totaling around 17 million square feet, including the Alexandria Center for Life Science on Manhattans Far East Side.

title: Nigeria: Rights Chief Assails Law as Roundup of Gays Begins
description: The United Nations human rights chief Navi Pillay sharply condemned as draconian an antigay marriage law that took effect in Nigeria last week, saying Tuesday it violated fundamental rights and risked provoking a surge of antigay violence. Nigeria had already criminalized same-sex relationships, but the new law makes an already bad situation even worse, she said in a statement. The law provides for jail terms of 14 years for anyone entering a same-sex union and 10 years for anyone who aids or witnesses such a union or who supports the operation of gay groups. Rarely have I seen a piece of legislation that in so few paragraphs directly violates so many basic, universal human rights, Ms. Pillay said.

title: Bulls, Built to Win Now, Decide to Disassemble
description: CHICAGO  Joakim Noah politely declined to address the news media for five days (including three games) after the Bulls traded the All-Star forward Luol Deng to the Cleveland Cavaliers. Noah, a genial center and often the Bulls de facto spokesman, needed to sift through the wreckage of his feelings and process the loss of his friend, my brother, as he called Deng.

title: Tines That Try Mens Souls
description: Far be it from me to defend what Jon Stewart has demolished.

title: Garnett Lives His Soccer Dream
description: LONDON  As his team acclimatized to London ahead of their game against the Atlanta Hawks on Thursday, the Nets Kevin Garnett tried another sports hot seat for size when he visited Chelsea F.C., long one of his sporting passions.

title: As Refinancing Wanes, Banks Are Wary of New Loans
description: The stars seem to be aligning in the housing market. Home prices have been rising for many months, and the federal government is providing immense support to bolster the mortgage market. The big banks that make home loans are strong enough to provide credit to borrowers, as seen in the fourth-quarter results reported Tuesday by JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo.

title: India-America Relations on Edge
description: The Indian diplomat charged with visa fraud and mistreating her domestic worker is back in Mumbai, and tensions between India and the United States have eased. But her case and the issues it raised are not resolved, and the damage to India-America relations is unlikely to dissipate soon. This unfortunate episode is a reminder that while both nations are democracies, neither can avoid the hard work necessary to make the relationship work.

title: Giants Hire Packers Assistant to Reconstruct Offense
description: The Giants on Tuesday named Ben McAdoo, an innovative Green Bay Packers assistant, as their new offensive coordinator, a move that signals the teams desire to move away from the system of Kevin Gilbride, who retired Jan. 2.

title: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
description: CAIRO  One is setting a standard for dialogue and democracy that is the envy of the Arab world. The other has become a study in the risks of revolution, on a violent path that seems to lead only in circles.

title: The Christie Way
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey tried to change the subject on Tuesday with his annual State of the State speech, talking about longer school days and reducing urban crime. But there is no diverting attention from the unanswered questions about how Mr. Christie and his close advisers have used his office to mete out rewards or punishment for political reasons.

title: Now Online, Diaries of British Soldiers Detail Horrors of World War I
description: LONDON  The British obsession with the centennial of World War I, the war that did not end all wars, heightened on Tuesday as the National Archives announced that it was putting diaries from British soldiers in the conflict online.

title: Finally, Congress Does Its Job
description: The last time Congress approved a series of spending bills to pay for the government  its most basic job  was in 2011. Since then, Republican lawmakers, determined to thwart the Obama administration at every step, have forced the government to subsist on stopgap measures that simply carry over or cut previous spending, with no accounting for growth, inflation or changing priorities.

title: Way Before Rodriguez, Another Yankee Gave Baseball Fits
description: In his written ruling on Alex Rodriguezs appeal of his 211-game suspension, baseballs impartial arbitrator raises the name and pathetic case of Steve Howe, the pitcher who was given more chances to play baseball than Billy Martin was given to manage the Yankees.

title: Christies State Address Opening Remarks
description: Gov. Chris Christie opened his 2014 State of the State address noting his administrations mistakes and its achievements, saying the state of New Jersey is good, and it is getting better.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 15, 2014
description: Mistakes were clearly made.

title: Corrections: January 15, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: On Camera, a Feminist Hero Gains Complexity
description: Are you an angry woman? Thats the first question James Day asks a smiling, ebullient Billie Jean King in She Is King, part of the Incubator Arts Projects Other Forces festival. Sure, she says, shes angry about certain things, but then, who isnt?

title: Location, Location, Location
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  First, the big news: todays constructor, Bernice Gordon of Philadelphia, turned 100 years young last Saturday. Lets let that sink in for a bit, shall we? Not only has Ms. Gordon made it to her 100th birthday, but she is still constructing crossword puzzles, and really good ones at that.

title: Mideast Strife Turns Trial on Beirut Assassination Into Another Fault Line
description: UNITED NATIONS  Perhaps it was wishful thinking from the start. The huge car bomb that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon nearly nine years ago led to an ambitious international investigation intended to bring about a new era of accountability to a country long splintered by political violence.

title: Cuomo Saying Little on Bridge Scandal
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is not one to shy away from a political fight. But in the case of the scandal engulfing Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey over retaliatory lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, Mr. Cuomo and his aides have kept to a simple mantra from the beginning: This was and remains a New Jersey issue.

title: Lobbying Picks Up Over Bill to Toughen Antinuclear Sanctions Against Iran
description: Partisans in the debate over a Senate bill that would threaten onerous new antinuclear sanctions on Iran escalated their lobbying on Tuesday, with critics submitting a letter to lawmakers signed by 62 multifaith organizations urging a delay and supporters pointing to what they called Irans insincerity.

title: Even Supporters Question Cuomos Marijuana Plan
description: ALBANY  When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this month that he would allow medical marijuana in New York, the news was greeted with great enthusiasm by those who champion the drug for patients with cancer, AIDS and other serious illnesses.

title: Bookstore May Have to Flee the Wrecking Ball, Again
description: Twenty-nine years ago, Rizzoli Bookstore, whose Old World charm, hand-wrought chandeliers and big storefront windows make it a favorite of noted authors, book lovers and tourists, fled Fifth Avenue two steps ahead of the wrecking ball.

title: France: Roma Evictions Increase
description: French authorities sharply accelerated the eviction of migrant Roma squatters in 2013, razing the unauthorized encampments of nearly 20,000 Roma, according to a report by rights groups on Tuesday. The evictions were double those of 2012, according to the French Human Rights League and the European Roma Rights Center. President Franois Hollande took office in 2012 pledging to break with the strict policies of his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy. But Mr. Hollande has reinforced those policies, demolishing at least 165 Roma camps last year, according to the report. French officials did not respond to requests for comment.

title: Congo: Fighters Quit, U.N. Says
description: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo said Tuesday that 8,000 fighters affiliated with a variety of armed factions had surrendered since the M23 rebel group was routed in November. Among them are the Hutu militias that Rwanda holds responsible for the genocide 20 years ago. Martin Kobler, the United Nations special representative for Congo, said about 50 members of a Hutu group, Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, had surrendered in each of the last two months alone, steadily diminishing what he said was a 1,800-strong force. He said his peacekeepers were focused on rooting out the rest, but warned that the group was not likely to be eliminated by military means alone.

title: American Weight Lifter Is Suspended
description: Sarah Robles, an American weight lifter who became a crowd favorite at the 2012 Summer Games in London, received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, Usada announced.

title: Court Weighs Police Role in Coercing Confessions
description: New York States highest court heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that plumbed the question of how far the police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations  even to the point of telling suspects a dead victim is still alive, but might survive if they confess to precise details of the crime.

title: In 9 Seconds, Rangers Watch Lead, Tie and Game Vanish
description: Nine costly seconds was all it took to scuttle the Rangers on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. In that lightning-quick stretch Tampa Bay scored twice for a 2-1 win.

title: New York Schools Chancellor Honed Blunt Style Over 40 Years
description: Carmen Faria was known for her meticulous demands.

title: Knicks Fall to Bobcats, and J. R. Smith Sits Again
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Knicks, making their way back to relevance in the Eastern Conferences Atlantic Division, arrived here on a five-game winning streak and facing a Bobcats team that had lost eight of its last nine games.

title: After Family Turmoil, a Commitment to Her Two Siblings
description: Never had the sound of snoring been such a comfort.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 14, 2014
Fire Kills 16 at Factory Making Shoes for Export
description: A fire tore through a shoe factory in eastern China, killing at least 16 people, and the state media said that the police on Wednesday took into custody the owners of the plant, which makes shoes for export around the world.

title: Teenager Is One of Australias Remaining Hopes
description: With a serve that can reach nearly 137 miles per hour and a powerful all-court game, Nick Kyrgios has been gaining attention for some time.

title: Burton R. Lifland, Bankruptcy Judge in Big Cases, Dies at 84
description: Burton R. Lifland, a pre-eminent federal bankruptcy judge who for three decades rode herd on some of the nations biggest corporate rescue efforts and presided over the financial chaos left by the swindler Bernard L. Madoff, died on Sunday in New Haven. He was 84.

title: Port Authoritys Chairman May Be the Next to Topple
description: It is starting to look as if this could be the traffic jam that ate New Jersey.

title: Thomas L. Chrystie, Bank Services Innovator on Wall St., Dies at 80
description: When Thomas L. Chrystie became a top executive in the early 1970s at Merrill Lynch & Company, it was a rocky time for Wall Street brokerage firms. A recession, a bear market, high inflation and stagflation, the fusion of rising prices and rising unemployment, had stock investors fleeing and taking with them the commissions and fees that brokerage houses lived on.

title: Return to Normal in Parts of West Virginia Is Marred by Distrust
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  The water was back on, but the anxiety had not shut off.

title: Ideas, Costs and the All-Volunteer Army
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: What Ultra-Marathons Do to Our Bodies
description: Ultra-runners are different from you and me. They run more. But a new study of these racers, who compete in events longer than marathons, joins other recent science in finding that they also tend to be older and have some different health concerns than most of us might expect, suggesting that some beliefs about how much activity the human body can manage, especially in middle age, may be too narrow.

title: Retired Police Captain Feared Attack Before Shooting in Theater, Officials Say
description: MIAMI  A retired police captain who killed a man after an argument over texting in a movie theater told detectives that he feared he was under attack when the victim hit him in the face with an unknown object, police records show.

title: Word of the Day | amphitheater
description: amphitheater \am(p)-f-the(-)-tr also am-p-the-\ noun

title: Christie's State of the State Address
description: The full remarks from Gov. Chris Christies speech.

title: Aide to Late Lawmaker Wins a House Primary in Florida
description: MIAMI  The first race in the 2014 battle for Congress took shape on Tuesday in one of the countrys quintessential swing districts as David Jolly, a former general counsel to the districts longtime Republican representative, the late C. W. Bill Young, defeated two opponents to win the Republican primary.

title: For Super Bowl, Its Back to Basics for Anheuser-Busch
description: The Anheuser-Busch division of Anheuser-Busch InBev, which typically buys the most commercial time during the Super Bowl each year, has a game plan for Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2 that is focused on its two core brands, Bud Light and Budweiser.

title: In Rare Video, Wife of Jailed Nobel Laureate Reads Poems While Under House Arrest
description: Liu Xia, the wife of the imprisoned Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo, was shown reading two of her poems in a short video aired at an event on Tuesday in New York. The two-minute video was filmed in December and obtained by the Friends of Liu Xiaobo and the Independent Chinese PEN Center, a free-speech advocacy group that Ms. Liu helped establish.

title: Suing to End Life Support for Woman and Fetus
description: HOUSTON  Lawyers for the husband of a pregnant woman being kept on life support at a Fort Worth hospital against her familys wishes sued hospital officials on Tuesday, asking a judge to order the doctors to remove her from the machines and declare the Texas law at the center of her case unconstitutional.

title: Ads Attacking Health Law Stagger Outspent Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats are increasingly anxious about an onslaught of television ads hitting vulnerable Senate and House candidates for their support of the new health law, since many lack the resources to fight back in the early stages of the midterm campaign.

title: Thousands March Against Thai Leader in 3rd Day of Protests
description: BANGKOK  With no sign of resolution to Thailands debilitating political power struggle, antigovernment protesters marched through Bangkok on Wednesday pledging to stop elections next month while the government vowed that they would take place.

title: Program to Cover Major Illnesses Is Extended
description: A special health insurance program for people with cancer, heart disease and other serious illnesses will be extended for two additional months, through March, so patients can continue treatment while they search for other coverage, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (FXX) HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON (2010) In this feature from DreamWorks Animation, a teenage Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) befriends Toothless, an injured dragon, on a windswept island; pleases his demanding father (Gerard Butler); and saves the world in the process. The airborne sequences, like the one above, are particularly compelling, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. When Hiccup first climbs on Toothlesss back and urges the dragon to take wing, the hearts of the audience soar with a primitive and durable delight, he said. The techniques that enabled this feeling may be dauntingly complicated, but the feeling could not be simpler. At the beginning and the end, How to Train Your Dragon is noisy and action-packed in the usual way, Mr. Scott added, with eye-straining, ear-popping large-scale effects. But they are worth sitting through, he wrote, for the tenderness, beauty and exhilaration that are the movies great strengths.

title: After Flurry of Changes, Some States Ease Up
description: LOS ANGELES  One year ago, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper, a Colorado Democrat, stood before a state legislature controlled by his party and laid out an aggressive agenda that included a sweeping expansion of gun-control laws after the mass shooting at an Aurora movie house. Why not have universal background checks for all gun sales? he asked.

title: Tussling Over a Name for Beijings New Airport
description: Whats in an airport name? In Beijing, a debate has begun over the name of a planned new international airport, the capitals second. The front-runners are Daxing, Jingji, Lixian, Yongding, Yufa and Zhuque, with the struggle between the two favorites, Daxing and Lixian, seeming to rest on this: What image does China want to present to the world? Money or virtue?

title: Danish Tourist Says She Was Gang-Raped in India
description: NEW DELHI  A 51-year-old Danish woman said she was gang-raped at knife point by seven or eight men in central New Delhi after she approached them to ask for directions to her hotel, the Delhi police reported on Wednesday.

title: Washington: More Money Sought for Schools and Wages
description: Gov. Jay Inslee asked lawmakers to increase spending on K-12 education and raise the state minimum wage as the Legislature began work on the first state budget in six years without a major financial shortfall. Mr. Inslee, a Democrat, said in his State of the State speech on Tuesday that improving finances made education spending a priority. The Washington Supreme Court has ruled that education spending does not meet constitutional requirements. Washington already has the nations highest statewide minimum wage, $9.32, and Mr. Inslee said there was ample evidence that an increase in the $1.50 to $2.50 range does not kill jobs.

title: Florida Governor Chooses Running Mate
description: MIAMI  Gov. Rick Scott named a South Florida property appraiser and former Republican legislator to be his running mate and lieutenant governor, filling a position that had been vacant for nearly a year.

title: Administration Is Seen as Retreating on Environment in Talks on Pacific Trade
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is retreating from previous demands of strong international environmental protections in order to reach agreement on a sweeping Pacific trade deal that is a pillar of President Obamas strategic shift to Asia, according to documents obtained by WikiLeaks, environmentalists and people close to the contentious trade talks.

title: With China Awash in Money, Leaders Start to Weigh Raising the Floodgates
description: HONG KONG  Move over, Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke. Step aside, Mario Draghi and Haruhiko Kuroda. When it comes to monetary stimulus, Zhou Xiaochuan, the longtime governor of the Peoples Bank of China, has no rivals.

title: Ambitious Art on Display at Mumbais New Airport Terminal
description: MUMBAI  Airports are normally places people want to rush in and out of, but the developers of the new Terminal 2 at Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai hope to change that. Among the many benefits for flyers coming through Terminal 2 is the opportunity to take in a vast amount of traditional and contemporary Indian art via an ambitious public arts program.

title: Hong Kong Leaders Speech Skirts Appeals for Democracy
description: HONG KONG  The chief executive of Hong Kong, in his annual policy address on Wednesday, called for greater government spending on education from kindergarten through college, but said little in response to appeals here for greater democracy.

title: Test Yourself, Math | Jan. 15, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The New Face of Polygamy?
description: In Polygamy as Lifestyle Choice, and a Reality TV Brand, John Schwartz reports on the Brown family of the reality show Sister Wives.

title: Spring Festival Gala Performance by Chinese Rock Icon in Doubt
description: An iconic Chinese rocker whose music is closely associated with the 1989 pro-democracy movement is unlikely to appear on this years Spring Festival gala on Chinese state television because of censorship concerns, his agent said.

title: Choosing Sides and a Camera
description: Builder Levy grew up thinking the world could be  had to be  a better place. How he would do his part was almost predetermined. He grew up in a family of what would now be called progressives. He called them Mom, Dad and Aunt Dolly. One day, bored, he put on one of his fathers records, Which Side Are You On? It entranced him.

title: Donors Offer $2.4 Billion to Aid Syrian Civilians, but U.N. Says More Is Needed
description: KUWAIT  Western nations, Arab states and others pledged more than $2.4 billion on Wednesday to help civilians who are suffering because of the civil war in Syria.

title: American Life Turns Off One Chinese Student
description: Disillusioned by rampant partying, illicit drugs and racial discrimination, one Chinese student in the United States has held nothing back in telling a Chinese news outlet why he is eager to return home.

title: Where in the World Would You Travel If You Could?
description: At the beginning of each year, the Times Travel section suggests the best places on the globe to visit. The 2014 edition includes photographs and short descriptions of 52 places.

title: State Television Airs Footage of Major Drug Raid
description: Chinese state television broadcast video on Tuesday of last months raid by 3,000 police officers on a village described as a center of methamphetamine production.

title: New York Today: Water Main Break Snarls Commute
description: Updated 12:06 p.m.

title: Times Minute | Environmental Compromise
description: Also on the Minute, early 2014 political ads and "Duck Dynasty" returns.

title: Times Minute | Compromising on the Environment
description: In the Video

title: Obama Announces Institute to Create Manufacturing Jobs
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  It was President Obamas first policy-related trip of 2014, but he used it to take care of some unfinished business from 2013.

title: Better Hearing Through Bluetooth
description: Like many men of his generation, Larry Faust, 61, of Seattle, went to a lot of rock concerts in his youth. And like many men of his generation, his hearing isnt what it used to be.

title: German Economy Grows at Modest Pace
description: FRANKFURT  The German economy registered only meager growth in the fourth quarter of 2013, according to early estimates released on Wednesday, as an improvement in consumption was not strong enough to compensate for a decline in investment by business and government and the effects of recession elsewhere in Europe.

title: Deutsche Bank Suspends Traders Amid Foreign Exchange Investigations
description: LONDON  Deutsche Bank has suspended several traders amid a series of investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Daily Report: Court Rejects F.C.C. Rules Barring Deals on Faster Streaming
description: Internet service providers are free to make deals with services like Netflix or Amazon allowing those companies to pay to stream their products to online viewers through a faster, express lane on the web, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 4: Parents at a Wedding
description: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

title: Bank of Americas Profit Exceeds Estimates
description: Updated, 12:18 a.m. | Bank of America has spent the last five years digging out from its mortgage problems, shoring up its capital levels and laying off employees.

title: For Some Ski Racers, an Advantage Before the Season Even Starts
description: LA GRAVE, France  In the fight for the World Cup overall title, Marcel Hirscher of Austria already has a 23-point lead over Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway. Unfortunately for Svindal, there might be an even bigger obstacle that he has no control over as he tries to close the gap before the season ends in March.

title: Militants Unleash Wave of Violence in Iraq, Killing Dozens
description: BAGHDAD  Militants launched lethal and coordinated car bombings in Baghdad on Wednesday, killed truck drivers outside the city and detonated explosives at a funeral tent in a village during one of the deadliest outbreaks of violence in Iraq so far this year, according to health and security officials.

title: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival
description: The 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival, now in its ninth edition, kicks off in the state capital of Rajasthan on Friday. Over the course of five days, celebrated writers from India and abroad will talk about not just their books but also about the two World Wars, Afghanistan after the withdrawal of American troops, Himalayan languages and the making of modern China.

title: Carson, Set Up the Universal Remote
description: There have been a lot of theories lately about why Americans like to watch Downton Abbey, but in my case its very simple: I like the stuff. I like the drawing room stuff, I like the bed linen stuff, I like the wine glass stuff. Its better than Pottery Barn.  I especially like the idea that if you dribble something on the stuff you have somebody to clean it up. Like this morning, at the gym, when I dribbled some coffee on my workout top, no one came over with a linen handkerchief, dabbing or even daubing. I had to, if you can believe it, do the elliptical trainer with a stain.

title: On Wall Street, a Generation Gap on Work-Life Issues
description: If you love what you do, its not work, David M. Rubenstein, co-founder and co-chief executive of the private equity giant Carlyle Group, told CNBCs Squawk Box on Tuesday.

title: Misunderstood Aboard the Intrepid
description: Dear Diary:

title: Sebastian Junger and the Complicated Obligations of Friendship
description: Three years ago, Restrepo, a documentary about American soldiers in Afghanistan directed by the American writer Sebastian Junger and the British photojournalist Tim Hetherington, was an Oscar nominee in the best feature documentary category. This year Mr. Junger is back, with another film shortlisted in the same category, but in extremely painful circumstances: Which Way Is the Front Line From Here? The Life and Time of Tim Hetherington addresses the death of Mr. Hetherington in 2012, at the age of 40, while covering the uprising in Libya that overthrew Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Today in Small Business: Economic Freedom
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Good News for Bank of America
description: Bank of America posted fourth-quarter results on Wednesday that exceeded Wall Street expectations, driven by decreasing expenses in its mortgage business. Earnings rose to $3.4 billion, or 29 cents a share, from $732 million, or 3 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook. Earnings exceeded the 26 cents a share that analysts had expected. Net revenue rose 15 percent, to $21.7 billion.

title: HarperCollins to Publish New Novels by James Frey
description: James Frey is once again venturing into young-adult literature with a new series, Endgame, that has been acquired by HarperCollins, the publisher said on Tuesday.

title: Fukushima Radiation (Still) Poses No California Risk
description: Im catching up with an incredibly helpful, and sadly necessary, article by Tony Barboza in the Los Angeles Times explaining why theres no scientific basis for the persistent stream of fear mongering about a radiation threat in American seafood and along California coasts from the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant calamity.

title: Riverbed Rejects Elliotts $3.2 Billion Takeover Bid
description: The networking equipment maker Riverbed Technology announced on Wednesday that it had rejected a $3.2 billion takeover bid by the activist hedge fund Elliott Management and reported preliminary fourth-quarter results that were better than expected.

title: Crafting the World of Saving Mr. Banks
description: The costume designer Daniel Orlandi and his staff sifted through hundreds of archival photos and online candids to recreate the 1961 world of Walt Disney and P. L. Travers for Saving Mr. Banks.

title: In Our Pages: January 16
description: 1964: Germany Wants United Europe

title: Living In a Gun Lobby Dystopia
description: The gun lobby says Americans would be safer if more good guys carried loaded guns in public places, and extols the benefits of an armed citizenry.

title: Art Installation at J.F.K. Faces Possible Destruction
description: Every year, more than seven million international air passengers are greeted gladly on their arrival in the United States  not by forbidding blank corridors or a blizzard of oversize advertising, but by billowing, cloudlike, buttercream-colored curtains stretching hundreds of feet along a periwinkle sky.

title: A Revival of Key West-to-Cuba Travel
description: For the first time in more than 50 years, a commercial passenger aircraft has flown from the island of Key West, Fla., to Havana, Cuba, reestablishing the direct connection the two cities shared in the early 1950s.

title: Want Better Hedge Fund Returns? Try One Led by a Woman
description: In the world of hedge funds, a relative few have a woman at the helm. And yet, these funds may be the standouts from the bunch, a new report argues.

title: Richard Parsonss New Restaurant Receives Accolades
description: Richard D. Parsons has held many titles during his career: media conglomerate chief, chairman of Citigroup, wearer of leather jackets.

title: Clothes and Character: Saving Mr. Banks
description: The movie business has its perks, and spending time at Disneyland is one of them.

title: Giving Vaccines Together Increases Fever Risk
description: Some children get a moderate fever after a vaccination for flu or pneumococcal disease. But when the vaccinations are given together, the risk of fever increases significantly.

title: Playing the Odds on Saving
description: Americans lack of savings has become a crisis. Our confidence that weve got enough saved for retirement is at historically low levels, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institutes annual Retirement Confidence Survey. More than a quarter of Americans have saved less than $1,000 for retirement. Only half of those surveyed say they could definitely find $2,000 if an emergency arose in the next month.

title: ScienceTake: Flying Jellyfish
description: Researchers have designed a flying machine that can stay aloft without fancy sensors or control mechanisms.

title: With Math as Inspiration, a New Form of Flyer
description: When the Wright brothers pioneered powered flight, said Leif Ristroph, they didnt solve a lift problem; they solved a stability problem.

title: Arbitrators Ruling on Rodriguez Gives Baseball a Disciplinary Hammer
description: Alex Rodriguez incurred the anger of many of his fellow players when he sued the players union on Monday, but over time, they may come to despise him even more for confirming Major League Baseballs sweeping powers of punishment.

title: Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Milan Mens Shows
description: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.

title: Image of the Day: January 15
Sports 2.0: Upgrade Your Game
description: App-enabled sports technology promises to put a coach in your pocket and help you improve your game in baseball, golf and basketball. Does it work?

title: Digital Coach Perched Right in Your Pocket
description: The tech worlds current obsession is with wearables  the idea being that you can stuff all manner of technology into increasingly tiny packages. So far, much of the attention has been on watches and glasses. But the same teeny sensors and smartphone brains that power those devices have other applications, too  for instance, in a new wave of smart sports equipment.

title: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
description: WASHINGTON  A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee released Wednesday concluded that the attack 16 months ago that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, could have been prevented, singling out the State Department for criticism for its failure to bolster security in response to intelligence warnings about a growing security crisis around the city.

title: Location, Location, Impersonation
description: Alongside winning the lottery and buying a gorgeous full-floor penthouse perched alongside Central Park, acquiring a Greenwich Village townhouse at a steal must rank among a New Yorkers real-estate fantasies. In The Tribute Artist, a new comedy by Charles Busch, known for his riotous, gender-bending farces, like Vampire Lesbians of Sodom and The Divine Sister, he plays a female impersonator whose landlady dies, leaving an opportunity to take on her identity  and her townhouse. The plan naturally hits some snags and leads to further nutty scheming.

title: G.M.s Dividend Hits the Right Spot
description: General Motors is hitting the right spot on several levels with its return to paying a common stock dividend.

title: Classical Playlist: Louis Lortie, Daniel Barenboim, the Hilliard Ensemble and More
description: LISZT AT THE OPERALouis Lortie, pianist(Chandos)Liszts transcriptions of, and fantasias on, excerpts from operas like Rigoletto and Faust  not to mention the works of his future son-in-law, Richard Wagner  are some of the most dazzling and complex piano works of the 19th century. Louis Lortie, a fantastic Lisztian, performs them with confidence and clarity. And his new version of the prelude to Wagners Tristan und Isolde, a companion to Liszts transcription of the Liebestod, stands comparison with the master. (Zachary Woolfe)

title: Handybook Buys Exec in a Deal for the On-Demand World
description: The rise of services like Uber, TaskRabbit, Seamless, Postmates and Shyp signals the beginnings of an on-demand world, where practically anything you want is available  and fast  with the tap of a button on your smartphone.

title: Flow of Westerners to Syria Prompts Security Concerns
description: FRANKFURT  A week before international peace talks on Syria are to begin in Switzerland, Western leaders and intelligence officials are reacting with alarm to what they say are the rising numbers of young people leaving Europe and the United States to wage jihad against President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Times Minute | Lawmakers' Pet Projects
description: Also on the Minute, American Idol premieres and a device that lets users hit like a pro.

title: Times Minute | Lawmakers Pet Projects
description: In the Video

title: Wheelies: The 2015 F-150 in a 2014 F-150s Clothing Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Life of Pie
description: When Diane Kochilas said we were making phyllo, I confess I was intimidated. But as Kochilas taught me, although phyllo means leaf, that leaf need not be the paper-thin type were accustomed to seeing in flaky Middle Eastern pastries. It may be, as it is here, a thin but readily made dough, rich in olive oil, smooth to the touch and easy to handle.

title: The Rollout: An Ikarian Greens Pie
description: Greek chef Diane Kochilas shows Mark Bittman how to prepare a traditional pie loaded with fresh greens. And in Greece, that means preparing a hand-rolled phyllo dough laced with olive oil.

title: New York Festival to Celebrate the Work of James Baldwin
description: New York Live Arts, the performance group based in Chelsea, describes its specialty as movement-based artistry. Given the groups history  it was founded after a merger between the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Dance Theater Workshop, and Mr. Jones is its executive artistic director  movement-based artistry is usually taken to mean dance. But last year, Live Arts expanded into multidisciplinary performance with its first Live Ideas Festival, built around the work of Dr. Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and author.

title: Memorable Oscar Moments
description: What is it really like to go the Academy Awards show? Melena Ryzik asked some annual Oscar attendees about their most memorable moments.

title: A Procrastinators Guide to the Super Bowl
description: Attending a Super Bowl is almost always a pricey proposition, and this years game, scheduled for Feb. 2 at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., definitely will be no exception. Still, there are plenty of ways to go to Super Bowl XLVIII, and not all of them are as costly as might be expected.

title: Telling the Olympic Story, Far From Sochi
description: As the worlds top athletes prepare to compete in Sochi, Russia, a revamped modern-day shrine to athleticism more than 2,000 miles away pays homage to the competitors, creators and engineers who came before.

title: Apple to Refund App Store Purchases Made Without Parental Consent
description: An agreement between federal regulators and Apple may make parents wince a little less at the sight of their children staring at an iPhone.

title: Facebook Revamps Ads to Compete With Google
description: Last June, Facebook released a tracking pixel, a snippet of code that allows advertisers to track customers who come to their websites from Facebook ads. For Amy Norman, co-chief executive officer of Little Passports, the pixel was a game-changer.

title: A Social Media Marketer Assesses Facebooks Advertising Platform
description: A guide we just published discusses ways small businesses can make the most of Facebooks revamped advertising programs. In a conversation that has been condensed and edited, we asked Jeff Gibbard, a social media marketer, to talk about whether small-business owners are likely to get the best return on investment on Facebook or on one of the many other options available. Mr. Gibbard is president of True Voice Media in Philadelphia, an agency that devises social media strategies for small and medium-size businesses. He is also the creator of Social Media Philanthropy, a social media marketing blog that, among other things, attempts to simplify social media concepts.

title: Rethinking an End-All, Be-All
description: Julia Noran Johnston and her husband, Ben Johnston, were die-hard Upper West Siders. Both had been living in rentals there when they met three years ago, and she later moved into his one-bedroom in the West 70s.

title: Songs From Home Greet Young Bosnian as He Faces Croatian on Foreign Court
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The shouts of delight on Court 13 at the Australian Open were never louder Wednesday than when an old man began to play his accordion.

title: Virginias Moran to Retire From House After 23 Years
description: Representative James P. Moran of Virginia announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election in November in the deeply Democratic district in Northern Virginia that he has represented for 23 years. His is the latest in a string of recent retirements in the House.

title: Memories of the Way They Were With Oscar
description: Early Thursday morning, the Oscar nominations will be announced, clarifying a race with a surfeit of contenders. The stars and filmmakers behind hopefuls like 12 Years a Slave, American Hustle and Gravity will know whether they are indeed front-runners or sudden underdogs; others will abruptly find themselves in the position of also-rans and step off the red-carpet circuit.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Adds More Ambiguity to His Position on Network Neutrality
description: Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, added further nuance to his already ambiguous position on network neutrality with a blog post late Tuesday, saying again that the F.C.C. will vigorously  but cautiously  exercise its authority to make sure broadband providers operate their networks in the public interest.

title: Testing the Waters: Investigating Questions About the West Virginia Chemical Spill
description: Last week, the spill of an industrial chemical into a West Virginia river contaminated the water supply for 300,000 people, setting off renewed debate over regulating the chemical industry.

title: Justices Seem Split on Abortion Clinic Buffer Zones, but Crucial Voice Is Silent
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court appeared evenly divided on Wednesday as it heard arguments in a First Amendment challenge to a Massachusetts law that created buffer zones around abortion clinics in the state.

title: A Harder Look at Welfare Rules as Europeans Flood Countries in Search of Jobs
description: LONDON  When she arrived in Britain a decade ago from Poland, Justyna Mikler worked hard to find cleaning jobs, studied English and, she says, never even thought of applying for welfare.

title: Bolshoi Names Cast for First Part of American Tour
description: The Bolshoi Ballet has announced principal casting for the first leg of its spring tour of North America, a week of performances of Giselle at the Kennedy Center (May 20 through 25). First cast (May 20 and 22) are the Bolshois prima, Svetlana Zakharova, and David Hallberg, the American star who joined the Bolshoi in 2011. Mr. Hallbergs debut performance then, broadcast live internationally, was as Ms. Zakharovas partner in The Sleeping Beauty. The April 20 performance will be his first performance on American soil as a member of the celebrated Russian company.

title: Snowboarder Danny Daviss Ambivalent Comeback
description: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo.  Danny Davis has been through it all before, and before that, too. As the top American snowboarders converge on the Mammoth Mountain ski area in California this week to decide who will compete next month in Sochi, Russia, the Winter Olympics are within Daviss reach for the third time.

title: Jo Nesbo to Write Updated Macbeth
description: Jo Nesbos best-selling series of thrillers has made the detective Harry Hole a famous name. Now Mr. Nesbo will turn his attention to a name with 400 years of history behind it: He will write a new version of Macbeth for Hogarth Shakespeare, a series that will feature contemporary authors retelling Shakespeare plays, beginning in 2016.

title: In a Gagosian Gallerists Personal Work, Cultures Collide
description: Every so often, boxes bedecked with Iranian postage and customs stamps arrive at Andisheh Avinis doorstep. He can instantly recognize the packages as containing handcrafted marquetry panels from a traditional woodworker in Iran, but, though he ordered them himself, couldnt tell you what they look like. Thats because when he commissions the works a month before they arrive, his only instructions are their dimensions. The rest  the size and pattern of the decorative inlay on the lacquered wood boards, which are typically used for interior decor  is left to the maker, whom Avini has never met in person. This inscrutability is an essential part of the artists process.

title: Who Moved My Cones?
description: Gail Collins: David, I have to ask you what you think about Chris Christie and the George Washington Bridge.

title: A Case of Mistaken Identity Sends a Worthless Stock Soaring
description: Nestor Inc. is a defunct shell of a company that once sold automated traffic enforcement equipment to state and local governments. Based in Providence, R.I., the company went into receivership in 2009, and all of its assets have been sold.

title: LAffaire Hollande
description: PARIS  The famously libertine French have long professed Gallic indifference over the sexual peccadilloes of their elected officials.

title: Sarasota Ballet Signs Artistic Director to 10-Year Contract
description: Iain Webb, the artistic director of the Sarasota Ballet, has signed a contract extending his appointment for 10 more years, the company announced on Tuesday.

title: Reforming a Picky Eater, Step One: Children Dont Control the Family Meal
description: What is a picky eater? Is it someone who wont taste new things? Someone who knows exactly what they like? Someone who loves the spotlight? Are picky eaters made, not born? I believe they are mostly, but not entirely, made. And if adults can make a picky eater, then it ought to be possible for them to help one change.

title: Program to End Homelessness Among Veterans Reaches a Milestone in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  Their descent into homelessness began almost as soon as they had closed a dignified chapter in their lives: their military service.

title: O.E.C.D. Encourages Labor Changes in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Russia will have to remake its labor practices for the countrys economy to pull out of its current doldrums.

title: Researcher Footage of Flying Ibises
description: Scientists have found that a V-formation helps birds conserve energy during flight and report their findings in this weeks Nature.

title: The Power of V: Conserving Energy
description: Birds of a feather may flock together, but why they fly together in V formations has never been known for certain.

title: Christie and Springsteen: A Tale of Devotion, and a Very Public Snub
description: This is a love story.

title: M.L.S. Set to Change Channels
description: Major League Soccer is expected to announce a new long-term television deal with ESPN and Fox this week, leaving NBC Sports Network after the 2014 season.

title: The Online Avengers
description: One day last April, a 25-year-old named Ash smoked a cigarette in the garden of his London workplace and scrolled through the Twitter feed on his phone. He stopped at the headline Who Failed Rehtaeh Parsons? and clicked on the link, which took him to the website of The Chronicle Herald, a Canadian newspaper. The article was an example of the kind of story, about a mistreated and suffering teenager, that Ash spends a considerable portion of his life searching for online, the kind that makes him feel, as he puts it, very rustled up.

title: Snowboarders Prepare for the Worst
description: Jeremy Jones has been exploring and snowboarding remote mountain ranges for over two decades. To minimize risk, Jones and his fellow athletes continually refine their mountaineering and rescue skills.

title: In Vermont, a Quick Course on Winter Sports
description: For those with Olympic fever  but not the foggiest notion of how to curl  Lake Morey Resort in Fairlee, Vt., will introduce its first Ice Sports University weekend, Jan. 24 to 26.

title: The Insider | Mark Duplass on Navigating the Sundance Film Festival
description: Those looking for a personal guide to the Sundance Film Festival, which begins tomorrow in Park City, Utah and runs through Jan. 26, could do a lot worse than Mark Duplass. The veteran actor and filmmaker, who is known for his roles in such films as Your Sisters Sister and Safety Not Guaranteed and is a founding father of the mumblecore genre with his brother, Jay, has been to the festival every year since 2003. This year, he returns to Park City with a pair of films he produced: the comedic drama The Skeleton Twins, starring Bill Hader and Kristen Wiig, and The One I Love, the debut film by the writer Charlie McDowell, in which Duplass also stars alongside the Mad Men actress Elisabeth Moss. Here, Duplass shares his tips for navigating the festival.

title: Norman Foster to Design Comcast Tower in Philadelphia
description: The British architect Norman Foster will design a $1.2 billion tower in Philadelphias Center City for the Comcast Corporation, the corporation announced Wednesday.

title: Robert Redford Would Like a Visitor or Two at Sundance
description: LOS ANGELES  Somehow, Robert Redford is a dark horse as a best actor candidate this season. Though his performance in All Is Lost drew some of the best reviews of his career, Mr. Redford was passed over for a nomination by his colleagues in the Screen Actors Guild (whose winners will be announced on Saturday), and lost the prize at the Golden Globes to Matthew McConaughey earlier this week. Whether he will get an Oscar nomination on Thursday is an open question among awards-watchers.

title: A Masterly Menagerie
description: Children ask illustrators to name their favorite animals at virtually every school and library visit. In some cases, the artists probably come up with something on the spot and then sketch the rabbit or dromedary in question. But the urge to answer more thoughtfully must weigh on them with a little bit of lesprit de lescalier.

title: Outkast to Headline Governors Ball Music Festival
description: Outkast is topping the bill at the fourth Governors Ball Music Festival, to be held at Randalls Island Park, June 6 through 8. The festival, which started as a single-day concert on Governors Island in 2011, then moved to Randalls Island Park, where it grew to two days in 2012 and three last year, has become an important event on the summertime popular music calendar. Among the nearly 70 bands and solo performers on this years roster are Jack White, Vampire Weekend, the Strokes, Neko Case, Phoenix, Skrillex, Jenny Lewis,TV on the Radio and Foster the People. Tickets go on sale Wednesday at 3 p.m. at govball.com.

title: Lawmakers Seek Curbs on Trading Commodities
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers pressed the Federal Reserve on Wednesday to act more forcefully, and quickly, to limit banks involvement in the commodities business, which has been blamed for inflating prices on everyday items like electricity and canned beverages.

title: Tensions Between Afghanistan and U.S. Increase as Airstrike Kills Civilians
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two Afghan villagers on Wednesday morning, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an official inquiry and escalating tensions yet again between the allies over civilian deaths.

title: Video: Blending Into Her Scenery
description: For Isis Miller, style is not just self-expression. Its her contribution to Wynwood. The Miami neighborhood is an area of concentrated creativity, where nearly every cafe, gallery and auto body shop displays elaborate and vivid street art.

title: Pope Names Cardinals to Oversee Vatican Bank
description: ROME  Pope Francis continued shaking up the Vatican on Wednesday as he named new cardinals to an oversight commission for the troubled Vatican Bank, replacing all but one of the appointees made by his predecessor, Benedict XVI, in another example of how the new pope is consolidating power.

title: The Gun Report: January 15, 2014
description: Yesterday morning, a seventh-grader at Berrendo Middle School in Roswell, N.M., opened fire with a sawed-off shotgun, gravely injuring a 11-year-old boy and a 13-year-old girl.

title: Consumers Can Check on Data Beyond Their Credit Reports
description: You most likely know the drill when it comes to the importance of checking the accuracy of your credit report, which lenders review before deciding to make a loan or issue a credit card. Federal law allows you to get a free copy of it once a year.

title: A Home in the Spanish Pyrenees
description: A property in the Val dAran, consisting of three traditional Pyrenean farm buildings, is on the market for $4.1 million.

title: House Hunting in ... the Spanish Pyrenees
description: A RENOVATED FARM COMPOUND IN THE VAL DARAN

title: If Old Humans Grew Like Old Trees, Stand Back
description: Theres a fascinating paper in Nature finding that big trees continue to grow fast even as they grow old. This makes them particularly valuable as carbon sinks, but it also leads to some fun what if thoughts, as summarized nicely by a United States Geological Survey news release, excerpted below.

title: On Abortion-Free Speech Case, Justices Pull Out Tape Measure
description: The First Amendment protects the speech of short, elderly women and large and intimidating men equally, but you would be forgiven for thinking otherwise after oral arguments before the Supreme Court Wednesday morning. The case was McCullen v. Coakley, a challenge to a Massachusetts law setting a 35-foot buffer zone around reproductive-health clinics where abortions are performed.

title: Governors Criticize Gridlock in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  The nations governors criticized Congress on Wednesday for the political gridlock that they said had stymied passage of almost every federal initiative most needed by the states, and reiterated their calls for help from Washington.

title: Video: Backcountry Snowboarders Prepare for the Worst
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: App Smart: Journals
description: Keep track of your doings in 2014 with a suite of iOS and Android apps, including My Wonderful Days, Moleskine Journal and 1 Second Everyday.

title: Take 2014 a Day at a Time, Chronicling Each One
description: After years of letting life fly by undocumented, Ive resolved to keep better track of my doings in 2014. The idea is to use an app to record what I did, how it felt, where I was and so on  more reminders than diary. If you like the idea, there are many apps that can help.

title: Skeptics Question Banks Bottom Lines
description: Some banks cheer an improvement to their bottom lines, but a debate is brewing over the calculations used to get there.

title: Another Florida Couples Possible Encounter With Movie-Theater Gunman
description: A Florida couple said they believe they encountered a 71-year-old retired police captain in December at the same movie theater where police said he shot and killed a man and injured the mans wife during an argument that began over texting.

title: Catholicism and Cognitive Dissonance
description: Im written a bit about the question of what kind of reforms liberal Catholics should be actually be hoping for from Pope Francis, besides the good feelings that the popes rhetorical focus on social justice has inspired. In a deliberate provocation, Damon Linker raises the possibility that the good feelings are really all that the churchs liberal dissenters really want, because many of them just dont think church teaching (or, for that matter, any kind of religious doctrine) matters anymore:

title: Video Shows U.S. Soldier Long Held by Afghans
description: WASHINGTON  A video of an American soldier held captive by Afghan insurgents for the past four and a half years is in the possession of the United States government, and officials said Wednesday that it showed the soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, alive but in declining health.

title: The Dress Heard Round the World
description: Edward Norton was just one in a throng of A-listers who arrived at the May Company Wilshire Building in Los Angeles last Friday, the scene of a party and exhibition celebrating the 40th birthday of Diane von Furstenbergs emblematic wrap dress.

title: Financier Says Hes Guilty of Everything but a Crime
description: FRANKFURT  Defense lawyers almost always give the same advice to clients facing charges: Dont say a word in public. That admonishment comes too late for Florian Homm.

title: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Mens Wear Shows in Milan
description: At the fall/winter 2014 mens shows in Milan, Italian tailoring continued to explore its softer side. Designers kept trousers trim and continued to show more casual wear, like the ones we saw in London last week. Here are the five best collections from the set.

title: At JPMorgans Health Care Conference, Deal Talk Abounds
description: Few events are bigger in the world of corporate health care than JPMorgan Chases annual conference in San Francisco. And this year, much of the buzz seems to surround the prospect of more deals.

title: Global Piracy Hits Lowest Level Since 2007, Report Says
description: Global piracy at sea fell to the lowest level in six years in 2013, largely because of an international crackdown on pirate gangs that once operated with impunity off the coast of Somalia, a maritime monitoring organization reported on Wednesday.

title: Frozen Soundtrack Is No. 1 as Album Sales Continue to Fall
description: The surprise and success of Beyoncs new album last month gave the music industry a feel-good story around the holidays. But now that the dust has settled, the hard reality of the state of music sales is clear once again.

title: Below the Line: Shooting Nebraska
description: From Sideways to The Descendants, Alexander Paynes movies have long created a strong sense of place. That trend continues in Mr. Paynes latest film, Nebraska. Nebraska is Mr. Paynes home state, and he has set four of his movies there.

title: Ex-SAC Traders Drug Data a Surprise, Doctor Testifies
description: Prosecutors may not have any recorded conversations showing how a former SAC Capital Advisors trader, Mathew Martoma, engineered what they have called the biggest insider trading scheme in history. But testimony from one doctor indicates that Mr. Martoma knew the specific results of a clinical drug trial before they were known publicly.

title: Cleaning Up Our E-Waste Mess
description: Traci Phillips of Tulsa, Okla., is in the business of recycling old cellphones, discarded laptops and other electronic waste, a fast-growing environmental problem.

title: Homes for $900,000
description: This weeks homes include a midcentury modern in Oregon, a cabin in Montana and a house on the Jersey Shore.

title: What You Get for... $900,000
description: PORTLAND, ORE.

title: Shoring Up Those Fitness Resolutions
description: January is the cruelest month, at least for those with good intentions to get fit. According to recent analyses of decades worth of exercise studies, many new exercise intenders will abandon their workout routines within two weeks of their New Years resolutions, and about half will quit by June. Even longtime exercisers feel the pull of physical entropy. In any given year, around a quarter of the people who had been working out dutifully will stop. (And about 2 percent of those who claim to have no intention of exercising actually start and continue, baffling researchers and possibly the exercisers themselves.)

title: AOL Finds a Partner to Run Its Troubled Patch Division
description: In May 2012, Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, promised restive investors that he would make Patch, the companys local news division, profitable by the end of 2013. When the deadline arrived and Patch was still losing money, Mr. Armstrong promised to take on partners to share the cost.

title: Should Mayor de Blasio Unravel Bloomberg's Reforms?
The Stars Quirks Come Out
description: Beverly Hills, Calif.  Security was viselike along the red carpet to the Beverly Hilton hotel last Sunday night, the setting of the Warner Brothers and InStyle Golden Globes after-party, which sped on at full throttle inside.

title: Walking on a Bigger Runway
description: The crowd in Central Park had swelled to 60,000 as Karolina Kurkova, the Czech fashion model and former Victorias Secret Angel, waited backstage at the second Global Citizens Festival, a star-studded concert last September. Scheduled to go on after Alicia Keys and her performance of Girl on Fire, Ms. Kurkova sang along with gusto from the wings.

title: Harnessing Celebrity to Civil Rights Cause
description: Ruth Feldsteins important new book, How It Feels to Be Free: Black Women Entertainers and the Civil Rights Movement, is an original exploration of the little-known but central role that black entertainers, especially black women, played in helping communicate and forward the movements goals. Lena Horne, Miriam Makeba, Nina Simone, Abbey Lincoln, Diahann Carroll and Cicely Tyson  the black women entertainers in this book  were popular at the height of an organized global struggle for black freedom, from around 1959 till the mid-1970s. They were influenced by this movement, even as they helped shape it.

title: Cheating Accusations Among Officers Overseeing Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Force said on Wednesday that 34 officers responsible for launching the nations nuclear missiles had been suspended, and their security clearances revoked, for cheating on monthly proficiency tests that assess their knowledge of how to operate the warheads.

title: City Opera Musicians and Singers to Play a Benefit Concert
description: The orchestra musicians and several of the principal singers of the New York City Opera have decided that the companys 70th anniversary should be commemorated, bankruptcy and closing notwithstanding. And besides, the companys demise has put its musicians out of work, and a concert honoring the anniversary seemed to them the proper way to address that.

title: Federal Judge Upholds Health Care Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge rejected a legal challenge on Wednesday to a central part of President Obamas health care law, ruling that millions of low- and moderate-income people could obtain health insurance subsidies regardless of whether they bought coverage through the federal insurance exchange or in marketplaces run by the states.

title: J.C. Penney to Close 33 Stores and Cut 2,000 Jobs
description: In yet another sign of its deep slump, J. C. Penney Company said on Wednesday that it would close 33 stores across the country and shed about 2,000 jobs.

title: In Advance of Oscar Nominations, What the Pundits Are Saying
description: LOS ANGELES  There are mere hours to go before the Oscar nominations are at last revealed, which means that the hopefuls are beginning to sweat and the punditocracy is in a tizzy, revising and refining predictions.

title: D.C. Lawmakers Advance Measure to Loosen Marijuana Law
description: WASHINGTON  The District of Columbia on Wednesday moved closer to easing restrictions on marijuana, as city lawmakers advanced a measure that would decriminalize possession of up to one ounce of the drug.

title: The Rube Goldberg Approach to Campaign Transparency
description: Myriad causes and crusades pursued by special interests on Capitol Hill are at stake in the fine print of the $1 trillion appropriations bill that Congress is finally managing to complete.
