description: The composer Jason Robert Brown is never happier than when surrounded by musicians. Kibitzing with the string section, directing the percussionist to feather in the high-hat more softly, poking fun at his own orchestrations, Mr. Brown, 43, was in his element on a recent Thursday at a musical theater ritual known as the sitzprobe, an evocative German term for the first time the full orchestra plays with the cast.

title: Redefining Gender Blueprints
description: For much of his adult career, Russell Tovey has been rather famously out. But hes built his reputation on playing it straight in British television roles like the werewolf George in Being Human and the slacker Steve in Him & Her, and as the jock Rudge in The History Boys, onstage in New York and London and on film.

title: One Part Rigor, Two Parts Whimsy
description: It started with a mountain.

title: Spreading Their Wings and Moving On
description: Stan Douglas

title: Veggies for the Blazer Set
description: It was midweek on the Upper East Side, and the matre d wore a calla lily speared through a tiny braid behind his head and garlands of amulets, including one draped across his brow.

title: Along Milans Streets, Color at Play
description: PHOTOS: In Milan, men battled the chill in everything from bright long coats to plaid vests and patterned wraps. For more images from street style during the Milan mens collections.

title: Corvex Turns Down CommonWealth Board Seat
description: A long, contentious spat between the activist hedge fund Corvex Management and CommonWealth REIT, a real estate investment trust, took another twist on Thursday, as the founder of Corvex, Keith Meister, declined an invitation to join the CommonWealth board.

title: A Sensor Guided by Voice or Gestures
description: Microsoft wants the Xbox One to be the center of a homes entertainment universe, providing Skype video calls and playing television shows, music and more.

title: Musical Titanic Headed Back to New York
description: Titanic, the grandly scaled Maury Yeston musical about the ill-fated luxury liner, had a rocky Broadway run in the late 1990s, finally sinking in 1999, despite having won five Tony Awards, including best musical. But the show is getting what its namesake never had: a second voyage. It is steaming back to Broadway in a new production, to be directed by Thom Southerland (who directed the show in London last year) in the fall. The casting, and production details have not been announced, but a six-week out-of-town run has been booked: the show will be staged at the Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto from July 22 to Aug. 31.

title: Czech Police Reveal Discovery of More Explosives in Envoys Residence
description: PRAGUE, Czech Republic  The police disclosed on Thursday that they had found additional explosives on Jan. 1 while investigating the explosion of a safe at a residence in Prague that  killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic.

title: You Sleep More Than You Claim You Do
description: A couple years ago I wrote about how people dont work nearly as many hours as they claim they do. That is, theres a big gap between how many hours people estimate they usually work versus how many hours they log when asked to keep a time diary, especially for people who already keep long hours. (The typical person who reported having worked 40 hours, for example, actually worked about 37; people who claimed a usual week of 75 hours worked 50.) This discrepancy could be due to fuzzy memories, or a desire to sound more industrious, or both.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: the obesity paradox, vaccines and probiotics. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: The Gun Report: January 16, 2014
description: Gun advocates argue that more guns means a safer society. Though successful defensive gun use is rare, we reported yesterday that a Good Samaritan intervened in a stabbing at an auto parts store and shot the perpetrator.

title: Hariri Son Discusses Assassination at Lebanon Tribunal
description: As my colleague Ben Hubbard reported, a suicide car bomber killed at least 3 people in a northeastern town in Lebanon, the latest in a string of attacks that many have interpreted as targeting groups backing opposite sides in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

title: Judge Disallows Plan by  Detroit to Pay Off Banks
description: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a deal that Detroit had negotiated to help it move forward in bankruptcy, but he did offer some hope, saying the city could borrow $120 million it says it urgently needs to provide services to its residents.

title: Apple and Samsung Widen Lead in U.S. Phone Market
description: Apple and Samsung Electronics, the two technology companies that make almost all the profit in the smartphone market, have grown even stronger in the United States.

title: For Goldman in Europe, a 3rd Way to Get Paid
description: Updated, 8:44 p.m. | To navigate bonus caps in Europe, Goldman Sachs will offer a new kind of pay class for bankers in Britain and on the Continent, a person briefed on the companys plans said.

title: What I Miss When Im in China (and Arizona)
description: My husband and I have a German shepherd mix named Raz that we rescued when he was a 9-month-old puppy. Today, Raz is always thrilled to go anywhere, whether its to the park or to visit the vet. I joke with my managers that I wish our employees jumped up and down and yodeled with joy upon arriving at our companys office the way Raz does.

title: Roundabout Theater Will Revive Noises Off on Broadway
description: Roundabout Theater Company announced plans on Thursday to mount a new Broadway revival of Noises Off, Michael Frayns backstage farce about blundering British actors, as well as the Off Broadway premiere of Tom Stoppards 1995 play Indian Ink.

title: American Idol Keeps Sliding; Ratings Fall 22 Percent for Premiere
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Fox executives were candid about their expectations for the ratings for the premiere of the new season of American Idol. Several of them said the same thing here this week: We expect to be down about 20 percent.

title: Obama Lauds Pledges to Expand College Opportunities
description: WASHINGTON  Mobilized by the Obama administration, and egged on by both the president and the first lady, scores of college presidents along with corporate and nonprofit leaders on Thursday promised initiatives and grants toward enrolling and graduating more low-income minority students.

title: Great Music for the Great War
description: If 2013 brought the music world bicentennial celebrations of Verdi and Wagner and the centenaries of Benjamin Brittens birth and the premiere of Stravinskys Rite of Spring, 2014 brings with it a far grimmer milestone: the 100th anniversary of the start of World War I.

title: Raf Simonss Colorful Collaboration With Sterling Ruby for Fall/Winter 2014
description: Last night, the Belgian designer Raf Simons and the Los Angeles artist Sterling Ruby presented their collaborative fall/winter 2014 collection in a gutted raw space just off the Place Vendome in Paris. We have done the whole thing together, Simons said backstage about creating the label Raf Simons/Sterling Ruby with his friend of nine years. The two met through a gallerist when Simons first purchased a piece of Rubys art, and collaborated several years ago on a capsule collection of denim jeans and jackets. For this one-off set of designs for the label, which was presented in place of Simonss eponymous line, Ruby decked out the runway with his signature large-scale sculptures. Shaped like red-white-and-blue fangs dripping from the ceilings, the artwork set the scene for the colorful clothes: khaki trench coats artfully appliqud with brightly colored fabric strips and various articles emblazoned with words like father and Abu Lang, which Ruby explained stood for the phrase abusive language. We loaded a lot of things into the clothing, both in terms of iconography and also our own path, Ruby added. The pieces spattered with color were the most literal references to their craft  a real artists wardrobe.

title: A Tire That Evolves as It Wears
description: DETROIT  As your tires wear, their ability to maintain grip on wet roads diminishes with reduced tread depth. Michelin has developed a tire that counters the effects of wear with channels that grow wider, and hidden rain grooves that emerge as the tire is used, along with a special rubber compound for wet conditions.

title: In Age of School Shootings, Lockdown Is the New Fire Drill
description: The bomb threat was just a hoax, but officials at Hebron High School near Dallas took no chances: School officials called the police and locked down the school this week. Separately, a middle school 2,000 miles away in Washington State went on lockdown after a student brought a toy gun to class.

title: Sluggish Economy Prompts Europe to Reconsider Its Intentions on Climate Change
description: The European Union, which for years has sought to lead the world in addressing climate change, is tempering its ambitions and considering turning mandatory targets for renewable energy into just goals.

title: With New Contract, Rex Ryan Has Security With Jets, to an Extent
description: Perhaps the most interesting aspect of Rex Ryans new contract with the Jets is not the extension, which was expected after management assured his return nearly three weeks ago, but rather its implications. The deal he signed on Thursday protects Ryan through at least the 2016 season. By then, the Jets will have not only made the playoffs again but won a few games there, too.

title: A Personal Pleasure, and Eager to Share It
description: It is tempting to open a review of The Surrender, the staged version of Toni Bentleys erotic memoir, with a bad joke.

title: Remembering Amiri Baraka
description: Ben Ratliff and Harmony Holiday discuss the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist.

title: Trips for Bikers  and Those Who Arent
description: Sacred Rides, a Canadian-based outfitter that focuses on single-track mountain bike tours for experienced riders, has introduced a line of Bring-Your-Partner trips that mountain bikers and their non-biking companions can enjoy together.

title: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 19-25
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Lawmakers Weigh Aid for Detroit on Pensions
description: Opening up the delicate question of how much help the State of Michigan ought to provide its ailing largest city, state leaders are weighing whether to devote hundreds of millions of dollars to help spare the pensions of Detroit retirees, while also saving the citys prized art collection from the risk of sale in bankruptcy.

title: Reader Comments in the New Design
description: As youve no doubt noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including The New Old Age. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of the post will discover that they have moved. You can find them now by clicking the icon above the headline of the post, next to the date and time. Alternatively, scroll down from the top of the post and click on the squarish balloon that appears at the top right corner of your browser next to the Share button.

title: Beach Weekend as Drill for a Double Root Canal
description: Theres nothing quite like the romance of a summer squall at the beach. An emotional hailstorm that erupts indoors is a different matter entirely.

title: On Times Language Use: Dwarfs, Indians and More
description: The Times is made up mostly of words (although video is coming on strong), so its not surprising that many of the complaints and questions that come to my office are about language use.

title: Milestones in Marissa Mayers Tenure as Yahoos C.E.O.
description: As Yahoos chief executive, Ms. Mayer acquired more than 20 companies, but ultimately struggled to turn around the web pioneer.

title: Disputing the Origins of Four-Legged Treasures
description: New York and Boston butt heads over more than sports teams: Try 18th-century walnut chairs whose origins are at the center of a controversy.

title: Monumental Cast, but Not Much Plot
description: ANDY WARHOL was a genius, but he could be mean. He loved to make his acolytes squabble. Hed torture visitors by blaring the same pop song over and over.

title: Baseballs Expanded Replay Adds to Managerial Strategy
description: Tony La Russa watched about 130 games last season in his role as a special assistant to Commissioner Bud Selig. With the sharp eyes of a Hall of Fame manager, he paid close attention to plays that would need to be reviewed by video.

title: Events in Westchester for Jan. 19-25
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: A Younger Christie and a Bridge He Wanted Kept Open
description: A crucial bridge. An anxious public. And Chris Christie at the center of it all.

title: The Mostly Mindful Parent
description: Mindful Parenting is having a moment.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza Strip and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Indonesia, California and Nepal.

title: Tortuous Trek to Something Like Normal
description: A Long Way Gone, Ishmael Beahs harrowing 2007 memoir of his years as a child soldier in Sierra Leones brutal civil war, turned him into not just a best-selling author but also, for many, a potent symbol of hope. Here was someone who had emerged from years of murderous frenzy to write a memoir of not just uncommon horror but uncommon tenderness, topped by a smiling, open-faced author photo one reviewer called welcome and timely reassurance of the enduring power of humanity.

title: Curtain Call | Men's Milan Fashion Week
description: We say goodbye to the fall/winter runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.

title: Daniel Radcliffe Returning to Broadway in Cripple of Inishmaan
description: In a last-minute arrival that will qualify for this years Tony Awards, Daniel Radcliffe will return to Broadway in April in the title role of The Cripple of Inishmaan, Martin McDonaghs black comedy about a young man with a sea of troubles who tries to become a movie star. The production, which was mounted in London last summer by the Tony Award-winning director Michael Grandage (Red), will begin running at the Cort Theater on April 12, less than two weeks after the closing performance of the Corts current double-bill, Waiting for Godot and No Mans Land.

title: Lingenfelters Custom Corvettes Blend Eras
description: Lingenfelter Performance Engineering is known for building General Motors vehicles  and occasionally some from Chrysler  that seem capable of breathing fire. The company also sells performance parts and upgrade packages.

title: Frozen Directors Take Divide-and-Conquer Approach
description: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | Disney heroines dont always ride off into the sunset on a silver steed with Prince Charming. Sometimes they actually come down with

title: Lounge Acts You Can Dance To
description: They may have started as homespun outfits operating off Off Broadway against long odds, but its now clear that institutions like Performance Space 122, Here and the Abrons Arts Center have secured their rightful place in New Yorks artistic firmament, staging high-profile festivals across Manhattan.

title: From Easy Mark to Street Fighter
description: MOVE slowly, the instructor cautioned as students of the Krav Maga Institute, grouped in twos, moved menacingly toward each other. We dont want to hit our partner.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Mens Fashion Week Take Their Bows
description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Mens Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 14 fashion visionaries.

title: Facts & Figures: Paper Books, Vinyl Records
description: Via Pew Internet: Only 4 percent of readers are e-book only. Print is still Americans preferred medium for reading books.

title: The Scramble: A Simple Greek Lunch
description: Mark Bittman and the Greek chef Diane Kochilas make strapatsada, an easy shredded-tomato-and-egg scramble.

title: 3 Campers Linked to Fire Are Arrested in California
description: GLENDORA, Calif.  A fast-moving brush fire that erupted Thursday morning has quickly burned at least 1,700 acres of land northeast of downtown Los Angeles, county fire officials said, and fire crews worked throughout the day to contain the blaze.

title: The Set and Its Designer, Ming Cho Lee, Take Center Stage
description: It is hard to overstate the impact Ming Cho Lee has had on the world of theater design.

title: Reader Comments in the New Design
description: As you may have noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including Youre the Boss. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of a post will discover that they have moved.

title: After Tina Browns Exit, Daily Beast Brings In Editing Help
description: The Daily Beast has hired Noah Shachtman, a former editor at Foreign Policy and Wired, as its new executive editor and has formally elevated John Avlon to editor in chief, according to a memo Mr. Avlon wrote to the websites staff on Thursday.

title: Russell Johnson, the Professor on Gilligans Island, Dies at 89
description: Russell Johnson, an actor who made a living by often playing villains in westerns until he was cast as the Professor, the brains of a bunch of sweetly clueless, self-involved, hopelessly nave island castaways, on the hit sitcom Gilligans Island, died on Thursday at his home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was 89.

title: Who Will Win the Foreign Language Oscar?
description: The Academy Award winners for the best foreign language film category have seemed preordained in past years, but the 2014 field has five strong nominees led by the Italian film The Great Beauty.

title: Oscar Snub Is Applauded by SeaWorld Investors
description: Fans of Blackfish, a documentary that casts SeaWorld in a harsh light, were dismayed to learn Thursday morning that the film had not been nominated for an Academy Award.

title: Target Tests Small Store for Urban Shoppers as Young People Pick Cities Over Suburbs
description: Target wants to be a bigger part of city living, by experimenting with going smaller.

title: Owen Pallett in the Moment
description: When Owen Pallett was working on the musical score to accompany The Times Magazines Hollywood feature Fourteen Actors Acting in 2010, I got to see him compose right on the spot. He was on set as Solve Sundsbo filmed Matt Damon, and in the interim until Michael Douglass shoot later that day, Pallett watched some of the other films that had already been shot and quickly began making notes. He played some short clips of music from the Internet to give us an idea of the kinds of melodies he was thinking of. I have this memory of Pallett pacing about in the dark, cavernous studio, his pad in hand as he came up with ideas for each of the shorts. That fast-working style was partly what inspired Miki Meek, former online editor of the magazine, to suggest we work with him (indeed, he wrote all 14 scores, which were subsequently recorded by the Czech FILMharmonic Orchestra, in less than two weeks).

title: Uptown Mingles With Downtown
description: They say the old culture-world distinction between uptown and downtown New York has vanished, but on Wednesday evening at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village basement club, it still felt like a meeting of two disparate domains. There was delicious incongruence between the sight of Mercedes Bass, the Metropolitan Operas elegantly coifed vice chairwoman, and the unmistakable scent of marijuana just a few feet away.

title: Clip: 'Visitors'
description: A scene from Godfrey Reggios film featuring a gorilla from the Bronx Zoo named Triska.

title: The Source | Doug Aitken
description: Doug Aitken interviews several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

title: Dutch Bonanza for the Frick
description: As soon as Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals: Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From Mauritshuis opened at the Frick Collection in October, lines began stretching around the corner to Fifth Avenue from the museums entrance on 70th Street.

title: A Salty, Sweet, Buttery Taste of Brittany
description: We didnt come for the miles of shoreline, the promise of seafood feasts or the many history-rich towns. Even the dramatic views and craggy cliffs werent a draw. There was only one thing that lured my husband, Mahir, and me to Brittany in northwestern France: salted butter caramel candies.

title: 1 Choreographer, 3 Works, 2 Premieres, 14 Feet and 2 Pianos (but 1 Pianist)
description: Ballet Next, the three-year-old company directed by the former American Ballet Theater principal Michele Wiles, is dedicated to presenting new choreography with live music. Thats a worthy goal, but whose choreography? The groups New York performances have been undermined by poor choices. But on Tuesday at New York Live Arts, the company unveiled a program of three works by one choreographer: Brian Reeder. This choice was good.

title: THE SOURCE
description: Doug Aitkens ongoing series of conversations with the creative individuals shaping contemporary culture.

title: A Few Pearls of the Grisly and the Mundane
description: Although its well-stocked with French, Dutch and Italian drawings, the Morgan Library & Museum does not have many from Spain, in part because some of the great Spanish painters, Velzquez included, worked out their ideas directly on canvas. So while the Morgan mounted a 100-piece exhibition last fall on the topic of Venetian drawings from the 18th century, its first-ever show of Spanish drawings whips through four centuries in just 25 objects.

title: Attention, Shoppers: Were Singing
description: The first thing you noticed was the smell. Lingering fumes attested to a black box theater at the Here Arts Center in the South Village freshly repainted white for the American premiere of Have a Good Day! The hourlong musical-theater work, presented on Wednesday evening as part of the Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival, was mounted by the Lithuanian company Operomanija, making its United States debut.

title: Brooklyn Abolitionists
description: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Historical Society.

title: Painting With Words, Writing With Color
description: Dahlia Elsayed thinks of the current exhibition of her paintings at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton as similar to a short-story collection. Titled Dahlia Elsayed: Hither and Yon, it culls a decades worth of work, and each has its own beginning, middle and end, she said, describing them as distinct narratives.

title: Clip: Like Father, Like Son
description: A scene from Hirokazu Kore-edas film.

title: Faith in the Early Age of Reason
description: Narrow windows sometimes afford expansive views. Consider, for example, Piero della Francesca: Personal Encounters at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an exhibition of four small paintings made for private devotion by one of the foundational artists of the Italian Renaissance.

title: New Snags for the Self-Employed
description: Borrowers who are self-employed may have a tougher time obtaining a mortgage under new federal regulations requiring lenders to verify applicants ability to repay.

title: Moira Dryer Project
description: Eleven Rivington

title: Julien Bismuth: An image as the _______ of a surface
description: Simone Subal

title: Stay in Love
description: Lisa Cooley

title: A Dealers Eye, and Life
description: When the history of galleries in postwar New York is written, there will most likely be a chapter devoted to Holly Solomon (1934-2002), the petite and feisty blonde who was a vivid art-world presence for nearly 40 years. In the meantime, her gallery is being revisited in Hooray for Hollywood!, a big, sumptuous exhibition spread between adjacent Chelsea galleries, Mixed Greens and Pavel Zoubok. The show has the added advantage of offering a relatively wide-angle view of the 1970s and the 80s, a period that recent curatorial habit  most prominently at the Museum of Modern Art  has reduced to a depressingly thin gruel of Post-Minimalism, Conceptual art and appropriation art.

title: After Old Mistakes, Hard Choices Must Be Made
description: The Japanese melodrama Like Father, Like Son turns on the kind of cruel twist  children switched at birth  thats the stuff of tear-wringing headlines and fiction. It begins with the revelation that two 6-year-old boys were given at birth to the wrong families, which now need to decide on the best thing to do. For one set of parents, Ryota (Masaharu Fukuyama) and Midorino (Machiko Ono), a comfortably middle-class couple nestled high in a glass tower, the revelation that their only son, Keita (Keita Ninomiya), isnt a blood relation is a blow to their tiny family. Its also a wedge that  day by day, hurt by hurt  transforms these loving parents into sparring partners.

title: Selling the Dwelling: The Books That Built Americas Houses, 1775-2000
description: Grolier Club

title: Nasreen Mohamedi: Becoming One
description: Talwar Gallery

title: Josephine Meckseper
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Most New York Voters Are Optimistic About the Mayor, a Poll Finds
description: Two weeks into a new administration at City Hall, New York City voters are highly optimistic about Mayor Bill de Blasio and overwhelmingly endorse his plan to raise taxes on the wealthy to pay for prekindergarten, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll.

title: No Is All You Need
description: I made a reservation for my wife and me at our favorite restaurant. We were really looking forward to it. I casually mentioned our plans to an acquaintance, and the next day, he told me he had called the restaurant, changed our reservation from two people to four. He then asked, Would it be O.K. if we joined you? I didnt know what to say. I was so astonished that I agreed. But we dont know this couple very well and soon began dreading a long night of stilted conversation. Was there any way around his maneuver? Anonymous, Louisville, Ky.

title: Adrift Too Long, Searching for a Navigator
description: I was hurtling toward Brooklyn on the Q train, wearing cherry-red pants that hugged my hips. He was tall, bald, in his early 30s, with pale skin, tired eyes and a thin nose over a goatee. His smile was bashful, but his legs, in baggy track pants, were spread confidently on the orange seat.

title: The Company They Kept
description: If you were young, gifted and odd, San Francisco was a good place to be in the years after World War II, when big changes were brewing in American art and culture. And that city is the setting for An Opening of the Field: Jess, Robert Duncan, and Their Circle, an exhibition that feels like a chunk of Bay Area turf lifted from the past and set down, untrimmed and buzzing, in New York Universitys Grey Art Gallery.

title: What the Writer Had to Edit From 12 Years a Slave
description: To celebrate his Oscar nod for 12 Years a Slave, the screenwriter John Ridley was visiting the White House on Thursday afternoon  not in a special capacity as, say, an honored guest who had penned a major film but rather as a tourist.

title: A Performers Life Story Leaps Over the Rainbow
description: The singer Sam Harris, who attracted the worlds attention 31 years ago when he won the television talent contest Star Search, belongs to a breed of hyperkinetic entertainer and vaudevillian who has been on since early childhood. He is still best known for his extravagantly flowery and emotional rendition of Over the Rainbow, the song that capped Wednesdays opening-night performance of his show Ham: Slices of a Life, at 54 Below. The shows title is also the name of Mr. Harriss just-published book of essays and stories.

title: A Spectral Compound of Strange and Familiar
description: Steve Lehman got a knowing laugh Wednesday night while introducing the last piece in his first set at the Stone, a stutter-stepping workout called Beyond All Limits. He began by pointing out that it shared a title with a tune by the post-bop trumpeter Woody Shaw. (Perhaps you know it from the classic 1965 album Unity, by Larry Young.) And so, Mr. Lehman suggested, this would be a tribute of sorts to Shaw, even though it sounds completely different. Ha-ha, replied the crowd, conspiratorially.

title: Model Casting Is as Distinctive to a House as Its Designs
description: It goes without saying that when putting together a fashion show, designers are as careful with casting as they are in designing their clothes. Nowhere is this more true than in Milan, where the models looks are as distinct as the Italian labels theyre representing.

title: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover
description: Also on the Minute, police officers sleeping on the job and playing tennis through the heat in Australia.

title: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover
description: In the Video

title: Adding Penthouses for Profit
description: In todays luxury real estate market, where more is more, and consequently better, developers and their architects have been busy designing penthouse additions to affix atop buildings that they are already converting into condos.

title: Youd Never Know the Kids Are Upstairs
description: If youre going to make a movie about four children who are locked in their room for years because their grandfather cant know theyre alive, the last thing you want to do is play it straight. Unfortunately, thats the only way Lifetime knows how to play it.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Tripped Up by Crises on the Path to His Opus
description: The Angola Project, a trilogy that unfolded on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Invisible Dog Art Center, is an intersection of places and cultures: a modern-day travelogue with stops in Lisbon, Vienna, Detroit, China, New York and, of course, Angola. Picture a tree, its leaves fallen away, to reveal a tangle of curling branches, each leading to a different story, or, in the cast of this trilogy, different sides to many stories.

title: Window Is Opening for Change in Tax Code
description: Could this be the year that a comprehensive tax reform law is passed by Congress and signed by President Obama?

title: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
description: Egyptian officials said on Thursday that journalists from the Al Jazeera English network detained on Dec. 29 had confessed to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, which has been declared a terrorist organization by the military-backed government that took power after the ouster in July of President Mohamed Morsi, a member of the group.

title: A Place Where Kitsch Gets All Dressed Up in Avant-Garde Clothing
description: Seventy-five years ago, the art critic Clement Greenberg wrote the lastingly celebrated essay Avant-Garde and Kitsch, defining them as two opposite poles in art. Although they have always overlapped, its depressing how far kitsch (mass-produced or widely popular art) now masquerades as avant-garde (challenging experimentalism in art). As proof, just check out the current American Realness festival.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Taking Brazils Rhythms and Stretching Them Out
description: Brazilian popular music has few rivals anywhere for structural sophistication. That hasnt prevented at least one cabal of experimenters from setting out to add even more intricacies. On Monday night, the third annual Brazilian Explorative Music, a concert organized and headlined by the songwriter Pedro S Moraes, brought all the members of Coletivo Chama (the Flame Collective) to S.O.B.s. They brandished advanced ways to construct, dismantle and sometimes disrupt a piece.

title: Advocates for Workers Raise the Ire of Business
description: As Americas labor unions have lost members and clout, new types of worker advocacy groups have sprouted nationwide, and they have started to get on businesses nerves  protesting low wages at Capital Grille restaurants, for instance, and demonstrating outside Austin City Hall in Texas against giving Apple tax breaks.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: On the Trail of a Vicious Killer, Eagerly Licking Their Chops
description: A foul tale foully told, the Israeli horror flick Big Bad Wolves begins on a dreamy, once-upon-a-time note with three children playing hide-and-seek. As a boy counts down, two girls, one dressed in red and the other in blue, enter a derelict building. One stays, the other leaves; one dies; the other, well, who knows, much less cares, what happens to her? Certainly not the writers and directors, Aharon Keshales and Navot Papushado, for whom murdered children are just an easy, conveniently blunt and effectively faceless (and headless) means to a self-satisfied, jokey and blood-slicked end.

title: An Exploratory Stroll Up Park Avenue
description: The proposed Park Avenue Historic District, running from 79th to 96th Street, breaks new ground in landmarks preservation. Instead of sweeping up all the little brownstones and townhouses on the side streets, the district ignores them entirely; this district is all about the multiple-family dwelling. These are the comfortable residences of the rich, just as the brownstones and townhouses were a century ago, but is that alone enough for landmark designation?

title: Small Plates Redolent of Both Sides of the Pyrenees
description: Walk into Alains Wine & Tapas in Nyack and you are likely to hear Spanish guitar music playing in the background. Yet the prominent piece of art in the room is an old map not of Madrid, but of Paris (oddly, with the northern part of the city on the bottom).

title: Exploring Emotions, Painful and Sincere
description: Longing, loving, leaving: Those are the boundaries of the melancholy, impeccable pop universe that London Grammar has built for itself. Its a realm of quietly tolling piano chords, modestly picked guitar parts and reticent drums, all deferring to Hannah Reids velvety, sustained voice. This one always makes me cry, Ms. Reid told the audience at Babys All Right, a club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night as the band started Stay Awake. But it was just one of the many lovelorn wishes she would sing during a set that never budged above midtempo and never had to.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Sea, Sky, Spray and a Love Triangle
description: Summer in February probably deserves some sort of award for its churning romantic atmosphere. This Edwardian period piece is set in the Lamorna artists colony in the southwest corner of Cornwall, England, in 1913. The painter Winslow Homer would have been hard put to match the majestic images of spindrift flying from crashing waves in a movie that might facetiously be subtitled Early Downton Abbey by the Sea, Manqu.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Wiki-Validation
description: Last week I wrote a piece for this section about trying to make it into Wikipedia. When I was rejected (for lacking references and, O.K., notability) there was an outpouring of outrage and emoticon frownie faces from friends. I also received many emails from people, several well-known, about their own Wiki trials. I have been at war with my P.R. agency over the fact that I dont have a Wikipedia page while it feels to me that every Tom, Dick and Harry does, said the designer Liz Lange.

title: Deception and Uncertainty Feed a Murky Justice
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 17-23
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Events on Long Island for Jan. 19-25
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Q. and A. | Doug Aitken Unveils the Source, a Collective Meditation on the Nature of Creativity
description: The last time we heard from the multidisciplinary artist Doug Aitken, he was hosting Station to Station, a nomadic happening aboard a passenger train traveling from New York to San Francisco, which saw a diverse group of artists, musicians, writers and thinkers stage events in cities across the country. At this years Sundance Film Festival, hes presenting the North American premiere of another group project that explores the nature of creativity, the Source. Several years in the making (an early version appeared in 2012 at the Tate Liverpool), its a series of candid four-minute video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

title: Italian Port Chosen as Transfer Point for Syrian Chemicals
description: The southern Italian port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, will be the transfer point for hundreds of tons of the most deadly Syrian chemical weapon compounds en route to their neutralization at sea, the organization responsible for helping oversee the destruction of the arsenal announced on Thursday.

title: Actions as Well as Prayers
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Fixed Income Drops at Some Big Banks, but Whos to Blame?
description: Bank executives may want to blame an uncertain economic climate for steep drops in fixed income, but some analysts are questioning that rationale.

title: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 19-25
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Both Ends of a Sculpture Spectrum
description: The sculpture exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington starts with two19th-century marble figures, each about two feet high, flanking the entranceway like sentinels. One, titled Industry, shows a man wearing a miners helmet and balancing an ax on his shoulder. The other, called Commerce, depicts a sailor leaning casually on a post. Both were made by Emma Stebbins, an American artist who also created the angel that stands atop Bethesda Fountain in Central Park.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 17-23
description: Still Awake Still!

title: Spare Times for Jan. 17-23
description: Second annual Black Comic Book Festival (Friday and Saturday) Commentary will be as abundant as illustrations when scholars, artists and collectors gather for this free symposium at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street, Hamilton Heights. One of the earliest black superheroes to appear in mainstream comics is thought to be the Black Panther, who made his debut in Marvels Fantastic Four in 1966. At last years festival, a costumed Black Panther and Superman mingled with Khalil Gibran Muhammad, the centers director.

title: These Criminals Are Throwbacks
description: Opens on Friday.

title: You Have the Right to Remain Funny
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Its His Move, This Time on the Right Side of the Law
description: Opens on Friday.

title: The 20th High School Reunion Rears Its Head
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Drifting Closer but Never Enough
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: A Teenager Finds Freedom on the Seas
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Back to the Digital Drawing Board
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  IN less than 20 years, ubiquitous, reliable high-speed Internet access has gone from a vision to a novelty to a fundamental part of the American economy  not to mention our civic, social and personal lives.

title: The New Midlife Crisis
description: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

title: Los Angeles Wildfire
description: Firefighters battled the Colby fire in Glendora, Calif., which broke out just before 6 a.m. in the Angeles National Forest, about 25 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Video From U.N. Panel Grilling Vatican Officials on Abuse of Children
description: The Vaticans former top sex crimes prosecutor told a United Nations committee on Thursday that the Holy See gets it when he was sharply questioned about the Roman Catholic Churchs slow response to handling cases involving clergy members sexual abuse of children.

title: Domestic Workers, Foreign Tensions
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasio, a Critic of Charter Schools, May Need Them for His Pre-K Agenda
description: As a candidate for mayor, Bill de Blasio positioned himself as a nemesis of New Yorks charter schools, arguing that they had a destructive impact on traditional schools and should have to pay to use public classrooms.

title: Israel and Holocaust Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk of Tighter Restrictions on Fishing Raises Questions
description: Catching spotted sea trout and flounder along the Gulf Coast is more than just a point of pride for outdoorsmen in Texas. The pastime attracts sporting fishermen from around the world, part of a renowned saltwater recreational fishing industry that adds $2 billion to the Texas economy each year.

title: An Abused Childs Death
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shout-Out to Family on the Menu
description: George Echeverria is a chef and restaurateur with a track record that includes Soign in Woodmere and Amicale in Huntington Station (both now closed); his latest venture, Erics Italian Bistro in Mineola, made its debut in May.

title: Asbestos Litigation
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanging Out at McDonalds
description: To the Editor:

title: The Leadership of Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: India: 3rd Arrest in Rape of Danish Tourist
description: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a 51-year-old Danish tourist, who was allegedly held at knife point for three hours by a group of men after she approached them to ask directions to her hotel in the citys downtown. The police described the man, Bhagat Singh, 23, as a vagabond and said that they were still seeking five other men implicated in the attack. The woman refused to submit to a medical examination before she left India on Wednesday, but two of the suspects were carrying property they had stolen from her, the police said.

title: Scandal in France
description: I havent paid much attention to Franois Hollande, the president of France, since it became clear that he wasnt going to break with Europes destructive, austerity-minded policy orthodoxy. But now he has done something truly scandalous.

title: Promoting Its Own Products, a Magazine Labels an Ad as News
description: CONTENT from advertisers that resembles editorial coverage, commonly called native advertising, is drawing heightened scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission, which wants to establish guidelines for labeling it clearly. Now Shape magazine has drawn a rebuke for such content from advertising regulators for an unusual case in which it served as both publisher and advertiser.

title: Sheriff and Judge Battle Over Medical Care in Jail
description: ATHENS  In November, David Conis Jr. sat in a Henderson County courtroom, vomiting repeatedly because of his vacillating blood-sugar levels, terrified that he was facing a diabetic coma.

title: Guys Guys
description: People love a man who tells it straight, the authentic stand-up guy who doesnt have to let you know hes that guy. Harry Truman, despite looking like the bank auditor from Bedford Falls, was that guy, and earned his nickname  Give Em Hell, Harry.

title: A Bistro Sparing Few Details
description: The name of West Hartfords shiny new brasserie,  Vert (rough translation: heres to green!), celebrates the freshness of locally sourced ingredients while wittily mirroring the name of Treva, the co-owner Dorjan Pukas superb Italian restaurant just around the corner. A restaurant thats half a palindrome  how cool is that?

title: You Can Look, but to Read, You Must Write
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: In South Sudan, Some Lessons of Rwanda Learned, Others Revisited
description: UNITED NATIONS  Twenty years after Rwanda, is the United Nations any better at preventing mass atrocities?

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: In Rare Visit, Nets Owner Offers His Support
description: LONDON  It took several weeks for him to break his silence, and when he did, it was in London, not New York or Moscow, where he makes his home for much of the year.

title: Reflections by Americas Buddha of Banking
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, seemed so calm during the worst hours of the 2008 financial crisis that Timothy F. Geithner, then the Treasury secretary, once described him as a central banking Buddha.

title: Climate Aids in Study Face Big Obstacles
description: Some of the technologies cited in the latest draft report by United Nations climate experts face significant obstacles before they can be widely put in effect to limit the impact of climate change.

title: Spending Plan Ignores Overhaul for I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday gave final approval to a $1.1 trillion spending bill for the current fiscal year, leaving behind what might have been the Obama administrations best chance to overhaul the International Monetary Fund and meet its obligations to the worlds other economic powers.

title: Under Gangs Rule, a Mexican City Loses Hope in the State
description: APATZINGN, Mexico  Like the shutters closing in an old Western, the metal gates on storefronts in this town slammed shut and their owners fled as first a powerful drug gang took hold and then the federal police and soldiers arrived to restore order, stirring fears of a bloody showdown.

title: Threes a Trend | Thick Soles for Sleek Silhouettes
description: The recent rise of the straightforward, unadorned black lace-up shoe has accompanied the growing turn toward minimalism in mens wear, helping to balance the proportions of an outfit. But its the simple shoes with a heavier, thicker sole  less a 70s revival and more a new platform style this season  that stand out this season. In Paris, Pierre Hardy presented a beautifully refined pair of double-soled shoes in two contrasting black leathers. He explained that they werent quite high enough during the first round of sampling, so he had to go back to the factory for a little retooling. We can all use a little bit of height, he said, smiling. In Milan, the platform lace-ups at Marni were a bit chunkier, giving a little extra lift. And monochromatic polka dots were applied to some of the thick soles at Jil Sander, adding some nice surface interest and texture.

title: Korean Community Leaders Urge McDonalds Boycott
description: Word ricocheted around the Korean enclaves of Queens, then onto the Internet, where it was picked up by Korean news media and sent in translation to the homeland. The situation inspired television news reports, an animated parody and on Thursday culminated in a summit on a Flushing street corner calling for a boycott: all because a McDonalds had appeared to disrespect several older Korean people who treat a neighborhood branch of the fast-food chain like their living room.

title: Ohio Execution Using Untested Drug Cocktail Renews the Debate Over Lethal Injections
description: Dennis McGuire took 15 minutes to die by lethal injection Thursday morning at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility in Lucasville for the 1989 rape and murder of a 22-year-old pregnant woman named Joy Stewart.

title: U.S. Steps Up Scrutiny of Freight Train Safety
description: After meeting with federal regulators on Thursday, officials from the rail and petroleum industries agreed to examine quick ways to improve the safety of freight trains carrying crude oil following a spate of fiery accidents in recent months.

title: Once Known for a Punch, Now for Smash-Mouth Running
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The coaches at East Mississippi Community College were not quite sure what to make of LeGarrette Blount when he showed up for football practice in 2006.

title: M.L.S. Draft: Red Bulls Select Two
description: Chris Duvall was at home in Duluth, Ga., sitting on the couch with his mother, father and grandmother when his name was called on Thursday during the second round of Major League Soccers draft in Philadelphia.

title: Banks Keep Their Mortgage Litigation Reserves a Secret
description: From JPMorgan Chases $13 billion settlement over mortgage securities to lawsuits brought by bondholders, a barrage of litigation has been raining down on Wall Street banks. Yet the banks are not disclosing a number that is crucial for assessing their ability to deal those legal costs. And, curiously, the regulator that has sway over companies disclosure practices has not called on the industry to reveal this important figure so that investors can weigh the institutions health.

title: Bumps on a Road to Revival for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It looks as if the Google pixie dust isnt so easy to spread around.

title: IBM Plans Big Spending for the Cloud
description: IBM is moving rapidly on its plans to spend heavily on cloud computing. It expects to spend $1.2 billion this year on increasing the number and quality of computing centers it has worldwide.

title: Converse All You Want, but Dont Expect Connection
description: It can get pretty lonely for a guy in the middle of an ocean. That proposition  being pursued with intensity on screen by Robert Redford in All Is Lost  is also under consideration in the American premiere of I Am the Wind, by the Norwegian playwright Jon Fosse, at 59E59 Theaters.

title: Goalkeeper Is Top Pick in M.L.S. Draft
description: Philadelphia, which had four picks in the first two rounds, swapped places with D.C. United to acquire the No. 1 selection over all in the M.L.S. draft and chose Andre Blake, Connecticuts goalkeeper. Blake is the first goalkeeper to be picked No. 1 in an M.L.S. draft. Chris Duvall, a defender from Wake Forest, was the top pick of the Red Bulls and the No. 22 pick over all. We like how he gets up and down the flank, Coach Mike Petke said.

title: Congress Restricts Drones Program Shift
description: WASHINGTON  In an unusual move, Congress is placing restrictions on the Obama administrations plan to shift responsibility for armed drones more toward the military and away from the C.I.A., congressional and administration officials said Thursday.

title: The Convention and the Damage Done
description: The Republican National Convention came to New York City in 2004. The event was mostly unmarred by chaos or violence, unless you count the damage inflicted by the New York Police Department to the constitutional rights of innocent people swept up in mass arrests.

title: Arizona Hopes New Charter Schools Can Lift Poor Phoenix Area
description: PHOENIX  In Arizona, the charter school movement has sold itself as a safe alternative for middle-class families looking to avoid the maze of underfunded neighborhood schools. The movement is now expanding into this citys most impoverished area for the first time, starting, in effect, an experiment in urban education.

title: Mae Young, Unladylike Wrestler Who Loved to Be Hated, Dies at 90
description: Mae Young  make that the Great Mae Young  who pulled hair and took cheap shots, who preferred actually fighting to pretending, who was, by her own account and that of many other female wrestlers, the greatest and dirtiest of them all, died on Tuesday in Columbia, S.C. She was 90, and her last round in the ring was in 2010.

title: Breach at Neiman Marcus Went Undetected From July to December
description: The computer network at Neiman Marcus was penetrated by hackers as far back as July, and the breach was not fully contained until Sunday, according to people briefed on the investigation.

title: Kerry Offers Assurances as Syria Talks Draw Near
description: WASHINGTON  As the Syrian opposition neared a decision on whether to attend an international peace conference next week, Secretary of State John Kerry offered a public assurance on Thursday that the Obama administration had not pulled back from its goal of establishing a transitional government that would not include President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Health Care Reform Survives a Lawsuit
description: A long-shot lawsuit that could have damaged the effectiveness of health care reform got a well-deserved brushoff from a federal district judge on Wednesday. The suit was brought with the help of conservative legal groups and cheered on by Congressional Republicans eager to disable the Affordable Care Act.

title: This Weeks Movies: Jan. 17, 2014
description: The New York Times movie critics on Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit, Generation War and Big Bad Wolves.

title: All That Remained of 100 Elephants: A Ton of Ivory, Turned Into Trinkets
description: On a winter day in 2012, a man named John C. Fitzpatrick made his way to the fourth floor of 7 West 45th Street, to the offices of Rajas Jewels, where he expected that he would find a cache of ivory.

title: Contaminated Water in West Virginia
description: The chemical spill that cut off water to more than 300,000 people in West Virginia for several days has exposed serious defects in state and federal environmental protections that allow many facilities and chemicals to escape scrutiny.

title: Blue and Gray Still in Conflict at a Battle Site
description: OLUSTEE, Fla.  There is an old saying in this state of seesawing sensibilities: The farther north you go, the farther south you get.

title: A Preventable Tragedy
description: The latest report on the 2012 debacle in Benghazi, Libya, where Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three others were killed in an attack on an American diplomatic mission, offers new detail and a chilling bottom line: the tragedy was preventable. Released in unclassified form by the Senate Intelligence Committee, the report reflects a bipartisan consensus about the tragedy that is broadly consistent with the findings of previous inquiries. Even so, it contributes to a better understanding of what happened and why and what must be done to mitigate the chances of its happening again.

title: The Inequality Problem
description: Suddenly the whole world is talking about income inequality. But, as this debate goes on, it is beginning to look as though the thing is being misconceived. The income inequality debate is confusing matters more than clarifying them, and it is leading us off in unhelpful directions.

title: Syrian Rebels Say Cease-Fire Deals Prove Deceptive
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  To the starving residents and rebel fighters in the bitterly contested suburbs of Damascus, the offer from the Syrian government can be tempting enough to overcome their deep mistrust: a cease-fire accompanied by the delivery of food supplies, if they agree to give up their heavy weapons and let state-run news media show the governments flag flying over their town.

title: Why We Like to Watch Rich People
Forbidden Zone for the Police: Places Ready-Made for a Nap
description: On a police station bulletin board in Queens, the officers of the 108th Precinct can see where their bosses do not want them to go. The auto body shop and the doughnut store, for example, because of suspicions that they offered police discounts. The Irish bar around the corner is forbidden as well, because the commanding officer was wary of drunken trouble.

title: A First Lady at 50, Finding Her Own Path
description: WASHINGTON  She has perfected a mean forehand, is working on her yoga poses, dishes with girlfriends over brussels sprouts and dirty martinis (one olive) at the Mediterranean hotspot Zaytinya, pushes her two daughters to play two sports  one of her choosing and one of theirs  and said this week that the wonders of modern dermatology, like Botox, are in the realm of possibility for her.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 17, 2014
description: Old grudges die hard.

title: Unspent MetroCard Money Means Millions for M.T.A.
description: Think of it as New Yorks biggest sock drawer, except that instead of nickels, dimes and quarters, what is squirreled away in its dark recesses are millions of lapsed yellow-and-blue MetroCards with digital loose change still dangling from their magnetic strips.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 16
De Blasio Names Ex-Bloomberg Official as Health Chief, but Vows New Approach
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who supported many of his predecessors health policies, from smoking bans to restrictions on the sale of large sugary drinks, on Thursday named a former top Bloomberg administration health official, Dr. Mary T. Bassett, as his health commissioner.

title: A Finale of Sorts for David Stern, Who Predicts a More Global N.B.A.
description: LONDON  The Nets-Hawks game here on Thursday was also the occasion for another N.B.A. landmark, the last news conference, as he pronounced it, of David Sterns 30-year tenure as commissioner, which will end with the 71-year-old Sterns retirement on Feb. 1.

title: A Bill Stokes Debate, and Doubt, on Iran Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Its Senate sponsors describe it as a diplomatic insurance policy that will help President Obama cut a better nuclear deal with Iran. The White House condemns it as a deal-killer that could put the United States on a path to war.

title: Corrections: January 17, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: With Rage, He Flails in a World Gone Deaf
description: Hey, who shut off the power?

title: Woman Trapped in Modern Times (1920s Edition)
description: A desperate life blazes amid devouring shadows in the Roundabout Theater Companys intensely stylish revival of Machinal, Sophie Treadwells fascinating play from 1928 about one womans captivity in a hell called New York City. That life is embodied by the charismatic British stage and film star Rebecca Hall, in her Broadway debut, so you can bet that its going to burn bright.

title: Now, Look Here
description: Because of a production error, the crossword puzzle that was published in Fridays print issue, by Ian Livengood, was published in error. The correct puzzle for this date, by Kevin G. Der, appeared online on Friday. The Livengood puzzle will be published online next Friday and the Der puzzle will appear in print that day.

title: Professors Detail Brutal Tangle With Police
description: The call was a routine medical emergency, a sick man having a bad reaction to medication. But before it was over, it involved the police and led to the wrongful arrest of a City University of New York professor on the Upper West Side. And it all started with a glass of wine.

title: Galloping Once Again Into a Rainbow Sunset
description: My Little Pony

title: Emerging From Dark Past, and Forgiving
description: She was just 12 when she was kicked out of her mothers house in the Bronx. She developed survival instincts, a brittle attitude and a willingness to engage in unsavory activities, for a price.

title: Despite a Guilty Plea, a Ruling Allows a Man to Sue New York City
description: A federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that a man whose 1998 conviction for the attempted murder and attempted robbery of a Bronx livery cab driver was reversed but who later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge could still sue the city for violating his rights.

title: British Police Arrest 2 Women in Terror Inquiry
description: British police officers, acting on intelligence information, arrested two women in London on Thursday on suspicion of terrorism offenses. One was arrested at Heathrow Airport as she was preparing to fly to Istanbul, carrying a large quantity of cash, the police said. The second was arrested in northwest London on charges of suspicion of being involved in the commission, preparation and instigation of acts of terrorism. The British are carefully monitoring citizens who are trying to travel to Syria to fight or get training with radical Islamic groups or who return from there, usually through Turkey.

title: China: Uighur Scholar Detained
description: A Uighur scholar known for his criticism of the discrimination against Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim ethnic group, has been detained by the police, his wife said Thursday. The scholar, Ilham Tohti, a professor at Minzu University of China, was taken into custody when 30 to 40 police officers raided his Beijing apartment on Wednesday, said his wife, Guzaili Nuer. Mr. Tohti, 44, has been one of a few intellectuals willing to speak publicly about what critics call shortcomings in the Communist Partys management of the Uighur homeland in northwest China. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hong Lei, said at a regular news briefing on Thursday that Mr. Tohti had been suspected of breaking the law, Reuters reported.

title: Turkey: Prosecutors in Corruption Inquiry Reassigned
description: The Turkish Supreme Board of Judges and Prosecutors on Thursday reassigned 20 high-ranking prosecutors working on a corruption inquiry that has targeted the inner circle of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The reassignments included the chief prosecutor of Istanbul, who has led the inquiry, the biggest threat to Mr. Erdogan since he came to power a decade ago. It was the latest move in Mr. Erdogans attempt to quash the inquiry. He has called the investigation a plot against him and his party, which faces three elections in the next 18 months.

title: Emptying a Building Long Home to Activists
description: The three-story brick building at 9 Bleecker Street in Lower Manhattan, long a celebrated bastion of countercultural activity, was in a state of transitional disarray.

title: Christie Lawyer Is Known for His Aggressive Tactics
description: The announcement on Thursday by Gov. Chris Christies office that it had hired a former veteran prosecutor to help conduct its own internal review into the George Washington Bridge lane closings raised more questions than it answered about how Mr. Christie and his staff will respond to the federal and legislative inquiries into the matter.

title: Zuccarello Provides the Difference in Another Tight Game vs. Detroit
description: The Detroit Red Wings have been rare guests at Madison Square Garden the past two decades. Now, with the Red Wings part of a revamped Eastern Conference, their red and white sweaters will appear at the Garden more often, pleasing hockey purists who relish games between Original Six opponents.

title: Unbending at Home, Pacers Rout the Knicks
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Coach Mike Woodson expected that the Knicks would need to play what he called a perfect game to compete with the Indiana Pacers on Thursday night. What Woodson got from his team was not the dream scenario. Far from it, in fact.

title: Deflating End to Last Season Inspires Ducks in Hot Start
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The roots of the Anaheim Ducks excellence this season penetrate deep into the soil of last years frustration.

title: Coburn to Leave Senate at Years End
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican known for his blunt personality and distaste for government spending, will leave office at the end of the year as he battles cancer.

title: The Times Hires a Technology Columnist
description: The New York Times has hired Farhad Manjoo, a technology columnist at The Wall Street Journal, to write the State of the Art technology column that reviews new software and devices.

title: The Real Health Care War on the Young
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Landscapes Tainted by Asbestos
description: For the past few years, Brenda Buck has been sampling the dust blowing across southern Nevada. Until recently, she focused on the risks of airborne elements such as arsenic. But then she started noticing an oddity in her samples, a sprinkling of tiny, hairlike mineral fibers.

title: Word of the Day | incorrigible
description: incorrigible \()in-kor--j-bl,\ adjective

title: Sabathia and Cano Reunite, via Jay Z
description: Pitcher C. C. Sabathia became the latest professional athlete to join Roc Nation Sports, the agency that represents Robinson Cano, Sabathias former teammate on the Yankees. Roc Nation announced the deal Thursday and sent out a photograph of Sabathia signing his contract with Jay Z, the head of the company, which negotiated a 10-year, $240 million contract for Cano with the Seattle Mariners in free agency last month. Sabathia, a left-hander who was 14-13 last season, is signed through 2016 with a vesting option for 2017 based on the health of his left shoulder.

title: Mayor and Speaker to Seek Further Expansion of Sick Pay
description: Mayor Bill de Blasioand Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the City Council, are set to outline planson Fridayto significantly expand the number of city businesses required to provide paid time off for sick employees, according to three people told directly of the plans.

title: Reid Indicates His Support for Medical Marijuana
description: WASHINGTON  The Senates majority leader, Harry Reid, said Thursday that lawmakers should ease their opposition to medical marijuana, telling The Las Vegas Sun, I think we need to take a real close look at this.

title: List of Smoking-Related Illnesses Grows Significantly in U.S. Report
description: WASHINGTON  In a broad review of scientific literature, the nations top doctor has concluded that cigarette smoking  long known to cause lung cancer and heart disease  also causes diabetes, colorectal and liver cancers, erectile dysfunction and ectopic pregnancy.

title: Super Bowl Ads Get Their Own Pregame Show (and Its an Early One)
description: For the last couple of years, Super Bowl advertisers have been drastically changing their decades-old strategy of keeping mum about their commercials until the spots are broadcast during the game. Instead of trying to surprise viewers, many sponsors are filling social-media platforms with previews, teasers and coming attractions in hopes of stimulating additional interest.

title: Sweeping New Restrictions Take Aim at Protesters Camped Out in Kiev
description: The Ukrainian Parliament on Thursday pushed through sweeping legislation outlawing the installation of unauthorized tents in public spaces and imposing other new restrictions on protests that seemed aimed at authorizing the government to clear hundreds of demonstrators occupying Independence Square in Kiev, the capital.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Disney) CLOUD 9 (2014) Two ace snowboarders  Kayla Morgan (Dove Cameron), who was dropped from her competition team, and Will Cloud (Luke Benward), a former champion trying to recover after the wipeout that ended his career  become unlikely friends and training partners when Kayla is forced to work at the dog grooming shop owned by Wills mother. Their mission: for Kayla to learn the Cloud 9, the maneuver that ended Wills reign. In I Didnt Do It, at 9:40, five teenagers  the supercompetitive twins Lindy (Olivia Holt) and Logan (Austin North, above with Ms. Holt), and their three best friends, Jasmine (Piper Curda), Garrett (Peyton Clark) and Delia (Sarah Gilman)  try to explain through flashbacks just how they wound up in weekly predicaments. The mayhem starts as the twins parents return from a night out to find their home covered in foam, with pizza falling from the ceiling, a goat in the living room and a missing 91-year-old babysitter.

title: A Womans Liberation, a Nations Past
description: The story line of Gloria, a drama from Chile directed by Sebastin Lelio that opens Friday, is straightforward enough: The title character, divorced and lonely, with self-absorbed adult children, yearns for a companion and frequents singles events looking for one. Gingerly, she begins a romance with Rodolfo, a retired Navy officer who turns out to be a jerk, and so she is forced to decide whether she is better off alone.

title: Cut Here, Cut There, but Its Still 3 Hours
description: What makes a movie long?

title: Marilyn Horne at 80, Celebrated by Fellow Stars
description: The formidable American mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne turned 80 on Thursday, and to honor her, Carnegie Hall presented a song celebration at Zankel Hall. During the prolonged ovation at the end of this sold-out event, Ms. Horne hugged and kissed all 13 artists who participated, an impressive group that featured both emerging and renowned singers, including the superstar soprano Rene  Fleming and the ageless songstress Barbara Cook.

title: Reluctant Action Hero, Reborn
description: Someone once said, Never trust a man with two first names, but that wit obviously was not referring to Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst and reluctant action hero of Tom Clancys series of spy novels. The closest thing pop culture may have to an American James Bond, the character has appeared in four films, which were collectively rereleased in December by Paramount Home Video as The Jack Ryan Collection. And now he is the focus of a fifth, Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit, which arrived in theaters on Friday. It turns out that every era gets a Jack Ryan to fit the times.

title: Use of Microblogs Drops Sharply Amid Crackdown
description: The number of users of Chinese microblogs saw a sharp drop last year, as a crackdown on online speech and competition from smartphone messaging apps curtailed the popularity of services like Sina Weibo.

title: A Conversation With: Summersalt, Band from Meghalaya
description: SHILLONG, Meghalaya  Theres no definitive theory on how Shillong, the capital of the northeastern state of Meghalaya, became known as the rock capital of India. Some say the Khasi culture of most Meghalayans has always celebrated music and is simply continuing to do so. Others cite the hymns brought by Welsh missionaries, while some point to the void created by the lack of Hindi cinema in this mostly Khasi-speaking state.

title: Facing Tough Race, a Gandhi Isnt Nominated for Premier
description: NEW DELHI  At a major gathering of the Indian National Congress party on Friday, Sonia Gandhi, the partys president, announced that her son, Rahul, would not be formally nominated for the post of prime minister ahead of general elections, a decision made after prolonged deliberation within a party braced for a punishing race.

title: Hiroo Onoda, Soldier Who Hid in Jungle for Decades, Dies at 91
description: Hiroo Onoda, an Imperial Japanese Army officer who remained at his jungle post on an island in the Philippines for 29 years, refusing to believe that World War II was over, and returned to a heros welcome in the all but unrecognizable Japan of 1974, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 91.

title: In Mumbai, One Day at the Stadium, Two Strains of Cricket
description: Last Saturday, Jan. 11, Mumbais cricket team lost its final match of the season. The 40,000-seat Wankhede Stadium had several hundred fans in attendance. I imagine that reading this news might befuddle a foreign visitor with an interest in cricket. After all, she might remember, Mumbais cricket team won it all last May, in a glitzy final watched by many thousands of screaming fans. What, theyve already run the course of another season?

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 17, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots
description: In Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots, Zach Schonbrun writes about the growing firepower of the ever-popular T-shirt cannon.

title: China Unveils New Native Operating System
description: Chinese researchers have developed a new mobile operating system intended to break the dominance in China of systems produced by Google, Apple and Microsoft.

title: Technology Is Not Driving Us Apart After All
description: In September 2008, two graduate students working for Keith Hampton, a professor at Rutgers, raised a camera atop a 16-foot tripod to film down into Bryant Park, the sprawling green space behind the main branch of the New York Public Library. They hit record, then milled about nearby pretending they had nothing to do with the rig, as it semi-surreptitiously filmed the comings and goings of hundreds of New Yorkers. The charade didnt last. After an hour, Lauren Sessions Goulet, the more senior of the pair, found herself talking to the parks private security force, which sent her to see their bosses, the Bryant Park Corporation. She was nervous.

title: Welcome to Watchington
description: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in full-screen mode.

title: What Were the Best Movies You Saw in the Past Year?
description: The nominations for this years Academy Awards were announced on Thursday, and the three films with the most nominations are American Hustle, Gravity and 12 Years a Slave.

title: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
description: Also on the Minute, smoking even worse than you thought and Michelle Obama's 50th birthday.

title: Shell Says Quarterly Earnings Will Fall 48%
description: LONDON  Roughly two weeks into his job, the chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell warned on Friday that the oil companys fourth-quarter results would be lower than financial markets had anticipated.

title: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
description: In the Video

title: A Muted Beginning to Sales of Apples iPhone Through China Mobile
description: Apple is counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the worlds largest cellular operator, to make major headway in China. But before Apple declares any major degree of success, the technology giant may need to overcome some significant hurdles.

title: Rise in Bird Flu Cases in China Stokes Worry Before Peak Travel Time
description: HONG KONG  China is disclosing a steadily growing number of cases of H7N9 bird flu, including four more cases announced on Friday, reviving concerns among health experts that the disease may be spreading and could pose a further threat as the worlds largest annual human migration begins ahead of Chinese New Year.

title: New York Today: Skate City
description: Updated 10:18 a.m.

title: Between China and Japan, a Tug-of-War Over Africa
description: Diplomatic tensions between China and Japan showed no signs of abating this past week as the two countries traded barbs over Africa.

title: N.F.L. Conference Championship Matchups
description: Patriots at Broncos

title: Suchitra Sen, Star of Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
description: KOLKATA, West Bengal  The Bengali actor Suchitra Sen, who was often called Indias Greta Garbo because of her iconic performances and her reclusive ways, died Friday morning at a Kolkata nursing home after a heart attack. She was 82.

title: Tension Rises Between Australia and Indonesia Over Migrant Patrols
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  An Indonesian government official said Friday that the country would increase maritime security patrols following an admission by Australia of breaching Indonesias territorial waters this week during operations to repel boats carrying migrants. The announcement is the latest diplomatic row between the two countries over asylum seekers.

title: British Regulator Steps Up Review of R.B.S. Loans
description: LONDON  A British financial regulator said on Friday that it had hired a consultant and an accounting firm to assist in its review of the Royal Bank of Scotlands lending practices, including claims that the bank pushed some business clients into serious financial difficulties.

title: Laughing 'Til Death Do You Part
description: A comedy writer, Lew Schneider, and his wife, Liz Abbe, talk about how theyve kept laughing over decades together in an interview with Dani Klein Modisett for her 2015 book Take My Spouse, Please.

title: Colorful Dries Van Noten
description: PARIS  How can we bring back color in mens wear? Dries Van Noten mused backstage, before sending out groups of men, tough, rough and street smart, wearing blocks of color. There were shades of pink from peony to purple; an Yves Klein blue, with inky shades; and absinthe and neon green trailing to a darker shade of moss.

title: Take My Spouse, Please
description: After a particularly bad fight with my husband that ended with me curled up in bed in the fetal position, I thought of something people used to say during my 10 years working as a stand-up comic: Honey, I could never do comedy. Thats the hardest thing in the world. Burying my head deeper in the pillow, I thought: Even the worst set is over in an hour; this marriage could last a lifetime.

title: Workers of the World, Faint!
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Just over two years ago, at the Anful Garments Factory in Kompong Speu Province, a young worker named Chanthul and 250 of her colleagues collapsed in a collective spell of fainting. They had to be hospitalized; the production line shut down.

title: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, acknowledging that high-tech surveillance poses a threat to civil liberties, announced significant changes on Friday to the way the government collects and uses telephone records, but left in place many other pillars of the nations intelligence programs.

title: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Meet Maria Contreras-Sweet: An S.B.A. Nominee With Lending Experience
description: Maria Contreras-Sweet, the woman chosen by President Obama to lead the Small Business Administration, has a long and varied rsum: corporate executive, public servant, ambassador for a host of causes.

title: Shire to Take Loss on Dermagraft Sale
