description: LONDON  The Irish biopharmaceutical company Shire has sold its skin substitute Dermagraft to Organogenesis and will record a $650 million loss on the sale.

title: Phillip Lim Draws Inspiration From Americas West
description: PARIS  A scarf at the neck, a dashing checked jacket and a horses-head print on a sweater. It looked like cowboy country.

title: Lady Gaga to Sing Again in China with Artpop
description: Lady Gaga can sing legally in China again, more than two years after her provocative lyrics and persona landed her on a government blacklist. The change of heart by the censors means her new album, Artpop, can be released in China.

title: Banks Keep Mouths Shut on Litigation Reserves
description: BANKS LITIGATION RESERVES KEPT SECRET | Bracing for a barrage of legal settlements for their roles in mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis, banks have been setting aside cash to fund impending payouts. But while understanding the size of these funds, called litigation reserves, is necessary for weighing the banks financial strength, many banks are continuing to keep this figure secret, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook.

title: At the Australian Open, Its Not the Heat, Its the Stupidity
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Australian Sauna Championships, disguised as a Grand Slam tennis tournament, finally ended Saturday. Advancement had depended on survival, on remaining upright, on shade and hydration and on the coolest accessory in sports, something called an ice vest.

title: General Electrics Industrial Segments Lift Earnings
description: General Electric is getting back to its industrial roots.

title: U.N. Says Climate Situation Is Critical
description: And nations are dragging their feet.

title: You Watch This Film as It Watches You
description: At the beginning of the new film Visitors, opening on Friday, an image fades up slowly from black. As Philip Glasss anticipatory strings play on the soundtrack, the figure dominating the screen is gradually revealed to be a gorilla. But shown in slow motion against a black background, the magnificent animal looks as if she is solemnly posing. Barely moving, she stares right into the lens, and seemingly right into the viewers eyes for moments on end.

title: Easy, Breezy, Trending
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Since 2011, when The Oprah Winfrey Show ended its stunning run, daytime TV has been on a desperate search for a new supreme ruler, a star capable of delivering more than enormous ratings (Dr. Phil can do that) and acting as more than a moral compass (bless you, Judge Judy). The job requires a person who can do those things while also serving as an arbiter of American pop culture.

title: A Debt-Related Charge of $1.2 Billion Puts a Dent in the Profit of Morgan Stanley
description: Updated, 8:38 p.m. |

title: Syria Proposes Aleppo Cease-Fire as Opposition Weighs Attending Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government on Friday proposed a cease-fire with rebel forces in the city of Aleppo and said it was willing to exchange detainee lists with the opposition to pave the way for a possible prisoner exchange.

title: Daily Report: Apples China Mobile Deal Gets Off to a Weak Start
description: Apple has been counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the worlds largest cellular operator, to reverse its fortunes in China. If the muted reception Friday, when customers were finally able to buy iPhones from China Mobile, is any indication, the companies may have to work harder to whip up enthusiasm, Eric Pfanner reports.

title: A Missing Comb-Over, a Miffed Actor and Other Surprises
description: LOS ANGELES  In the wake of the Oscar nominations on Thursday, there are snubs and then there are head-scratchers, like how, exactly, did American Hustle miss its chance for makeup and hairstyling? The opening minutes of the film are a long paean to the artifice and artfulness of Christian Bales comb-over.

title: Please Be Alert and Aware of Your Surroundings
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Case for a Better U
description: Unemployment has fallen a lot recently, but for a peculiar reason: not so much rising employment as a falling share of the population actively looking for work. This has sparked a debate over how much of the decline in labor force participation reflects a weak job market  why bother looking?  and how much demography, changing culture, and all that. And it looks like one of those debates that will go on, unresolved, for a long time  certainly past the point where a decisive win for one side or the other can inform policy.

title: Givenchy: Fall 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Mens Paris Fashion Week: Kolor Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: Skills Practice | Persuading an Audience Using Logos, Pathos and Ethos
description: Update: Jan. 22, 2014

title: The Glittering Crises
description: Many people have pointed out that the euro has ended up functioning a lot like the gold standard  and in so doing has replicated the gold fetters that many economic historians say played a big role in the propagation of the Great Depression.

title: Remains Examined for Link to Missing Boy With Autism
description: Nearly every morning for the past 104 mornings, Avonte Oquendos mother, Vanessa Fontaine, has woken up to the same nightmare. But each day, she wiped away tears and pressed on in the search for her missing son, a boy with severe autism who was last seen in early October. Surveillance video showed the 14-year-old darting out of his school in Long Island City, Queens, in the middle of the day.

title: In Our Pages: January 18
description: 1939: 25 Million Nickels Stolen

title: Why We Talk About the One Percent
description: Many people in Washington, even those willing to concede that inequality has been rising rapidly, are uncomfortable talking about the famous 1 percent  perhaps because it sounds too populist, too much like an invitation to crowds with pitchforks. For a long time respectable discussion focused on the top 20 percent; today I see my colleague David Brooks talking about the top 5 percent.

title: Givenchy: Basketball and Bauhaus
description: PARIS  The basketball court was framed by crisscross mesh; the lines were red neon strips. And from the first moment that a model in a tailored outfit stalked the court, followed by outfits with fiery colors licking across the chest, the result was clear: game to Givenchy.

title: Lost in the Gallery-Industrial Complex
description: A new year. A new New York mayor. Old problems with art in New York. I have a collection of complaints and a few (very few) ideas for change.

title: Pennsylvania Voter ID Law Struck Down as Judge Cites Burden on Citizens
description: In a strongly worded decision, a state judge on Friday struck down Pennsylvanias 2012 law requiring voters to produce a state-approved photo ID at the polls, setting up a potential Supreme Court confrontation that could have implications for other such laws across the country.

title: What They Said: Rahul Gandhis Speech at Congress Executive Meeting
description: NEW DELHI  In an unusually passionate speech at the Indian National Congresss national meeting on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the peoples will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.

title: Barkhad Abdi Breaks the Cool Rule
description: Few veteran actors might know how to react to Amy Poehlers admonition that theres such a beautiful life lesson here, everyone. Sleep with your limo driver tonight  before he gets famous. Or Tina Feys offer to come to her room: Im talking to you, Somali pirates. I am de captain now.

title: Citigroup Report Urges Deal-Making, Activist Thinking
description: Citigroup has a stark message for its corporate clients: They are going to have to justify those lofty valuations.

title: Where to Turn if Youre Shunning Sugar
description: Inspired by Daniel Engbers recent magazine article about the challenge of creating a natural sugar substitute, readers in the comments section swapped advice about how to satisfy a sweet tooth with fewer calories, including:

title: Reacting to a Clash Under the Golden Arches
description: Sarah Maslin Nir and Jiha Ham reported this week on a McDonalds in Flushing, Queens, that for months has been clashing with a group of older Korean patrons.

title: Hertzs New Model: Revamped Rental Offices
description: The car rental company Hertz, which has 8,800 worldwide locations, is in the process of revamping several hundred of its branches to make them more user-friendly.

title: Analysis of Obamas N.S.A. Speech
description: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the governments wide net of surveillance at home and abroad. Times reporters provided live analysis of the speech.

title: James Earl Jones on Darth Vader, Mufasa and, natch, Totes McGotes
description: Your new film, Gimme Shelter, is the latest of more than 65 features that youve acted in. Whats the secret to longevity? The secret is never forgetting that youre a journeyman actor and that nothing is your final thing, nothing is your greatest thing, nothing is your worst thing. I still consider myself a novice.

title: Who Made That Captcha?
description: Before the presidential election in 1996, a computer company called Digital Equipment Corporation set up a website for opinion polls. There was one problem, though: Partisan hackers could use bots to fill the site with useless spam. So D.E.C. put a pixelated image of the U.S. flag at a random spot on the screen that users had to click before they registered their votes.

title: Tough Sledding
description: There was plenty of snow in New York City for the first weekend of the year after a huge storm hit the Northeast, but sleds appear to have been in shorter supply. The best alternatives, according to the photographer Nolan Conway, who visited several parks in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens to capture the resourceful at play, were made of glossy things and included corrugated plastic and skateboards with their wheels removed. Laundry baskets, broken sleds and mats were O.K.; brown cardboard boxes, lunch trays and trash-can lids didnt work. And in the dangerous category: sheet metal. Some with real sleds, like Anyssa Mundle, 11, seemed to enjoy using found objects just as much. This is a check off my Christmas list, Anyssa said. Sledding and going in a magazine. Julie Bosman

title: The Mistress at the Funeral
description: My good friend just died. In the last weeks of his lucidity, he told me he absolutely wanted his mistress of many years to attend his memorial service. He relayed a few messages through me to her, as he lay dying. His wife did well in her role as caregiver, running an in-house hospice for him. But their marriage was  by his account and all available evidence  in shambles for years. His wife knew the mistress existed, and only in the waning months of his life did my friend sever the extramarital relationship (in order to die with less complexity at home). There will be a funeral, hosted by his family. The dilemma: Enact the expressed will of my friend and ensure the mistress is present or  given the wifes emotional fragility and proneness to angry outbursts  enact my friends constant goal of peace and simplicity for his child. NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK CITY

title: Reply All: The 1.5.14 Issue
description: A SPECK IN THE SEA

title: Members of a Very Small Club
description: Last summer, I rented a house from a stranger. Her name was Robin, and when I arrived to collect the keys, she gave me a quick tutorial on the washer-dryer and showed me how to restart the router. There was an uncomfortable intimacy in seeing her space, her cats, her belongings, which Id been hoping to avoid so I could more easily pretend the house was mine. But when she offered me a cup of tea, I accepted, mostly because I didnt want her to change her mind about renting the house to me.

title: Popcast: Hearing Amiri Baraka
description: Most would agree that the essence of the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist Amiri Baraka, who died last week at the age of 79, is words on paper, and the ideas resounding from the words about black art, memory, racism, class struggle and political power relationships. Theres more to it, though.

title: Hands and Mind: Raf Simons and Sterling Ruby
description: Raf Simons has good taste in art. Mike Kelley, Paul McCarthy, Cindy Sherman, Christopher Wool and Brian Calvin are among the artists whose work he admires and in some cases owns. About 15 years ago, Mr. Simons took a break from fashion to help a Belgian businessman expand his art collection. In more recent years, art has been a keystone of his fashion. He collaborated with Mr. Calvin on some T-shirts for his Antwerp-based Raf Simons mens label, and in February 2013, he paid brilliant homage to Surrealism in a collection for Dior, where he is creative director.

title: Why Renters Renovate
description: After finding a two-bedroom one-bath fixer-upper in the financial district last fall, Kelly and Brandon Michon went to work ripping out musty old carpets, dated kitchen appliances and damaged flooring; they scraped away layer upon layer of paint, wallpaper and plaster that had been slapped up over the years.

title: A Tabloid Bashing, and a Lost Job With the Mayor
description: To those following prospective appointments in City Hall, Lis Smith, a well-respected young political operative who had run Bill de Blasios communications effort for the last stretch of his mayoral campaign and throughout his transition, was the obvious choice to lead press operations in the new administration. In the days preceding Christmas, though, the tabloids revealed that Ms. Smith was dating Eliot Spitzer.

title: Yohji Yamamoto Embraces Pattern
description: PARIS  A splash of orchids brightening a coat, daffodils on an orange suit, blood-red roses enmeshed with snakes and flowers mingled with skulls.

title: Presidential Policy Directive on Signals Intelligence Activities
description: President Obama released a plan for overhauling the National Security Agencys bulk data collection program.

title: Remapping the Territory
description: In Our America, Felipe Fernndez-Armesto, a British historian of Spanish heritage at the University of Notre Dame, recasts the pilgrimage of Hispanics in the United States as a rich and moving chronicle for our very present. His book navigates five centuries of painful documents, atrocious statements and dubious literature to argue that the United States was, from its beginning, as much a Spanish colonial southern enterprise as an unending march westward. After long periods of migration, deportation and accommodation, the next United States could well be a pluricultural bilingual power, updating the American dream. Our America is perhaps the first history to make the case for this nations becoming a bright Latin American country.

title: An Evolving Field
description: Twenty years ago, Jonathan Weiner published The Beak of the Finch, his Pulitzer Prize-winning book about two biologists studying rapid changes in the birds on the Galpagos Islands, where Darwin observed the same creatures in the 1830s. In the Book Review, Douglas H. Chadwick called it an admirable and much-needed treatise that explains very complex scientific and philosophical concepts in lucid prose.

title: Darwins Arks
description: This book begins with a small struggle in an arroyo near the southern tip of Baja California. Its June 2000, and the author and his girlfriend, Tara, are trying to pull a snake from a hole. Shes gripping it by the neck. Hes reaching down the snakes body trying to gain purchase. The process is exhausting, Alan de Queiroz writes, not because its physically difficult, but because were fighting against the will of another being; with each pull I feel the snake resisting.

title: Inside the List
description: In the Mood: Christine Feehans new novel, Dark Wolf, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. Its the 25th book in her Dark series of paranormal romances, about a race of shape-shifters called the Carpathians  basically, kindhearted vampires who refuse to kill humans and often have energetic, soul-trembling sex with them. Feehan discovered her calling while she was still in middle school; speaking with the romance website RBL Romantica early in her career, she remembered sitting in math class and working on her first steamy love scene until the teacher confiscated her notebook. You should have seen his face, she said. I was about 13 at the time. I dont know which of us was more mortified. But despite her early start she delayed publishing for a long time, working more than 20 years as a martial arts instructor (she has a third-degree black belt in karate) and writing for herself while she and her husband raised 11 children. I can write with the entire household around me most of the time, she told another website in 2002. My husband reads all my books and had better love them  and if he doesnt, hed better lie like crazy with a smile on his face. The only thing I avoid while writing a love scene is my children. Children and writing love scenes dont mix; they get you out of the mood very, very fast.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE POWER OF HABIT: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business,  by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $16.) Duhigg, a Pulitzer-winning reporter for The New York Times, looks at the science behind how we form, and break, habits. In engrossing narratives that take us from corporate boardrooms to N.F.L. sidelines and the civil rights movement, he distills research from the fields of social psychology, clinical psychology and neuroscience.

title: Editors Choice
description: ANDREWS BRAIN,  by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $26.) A neuroscientist frustrated in his research, and with a messy personal life, explores his own oppressive consciousness in Doctorows cunning but serious novel.

title: No Resistance
description: What did you do in the war, Auntie?

title: Lupita Nyongos Elegant Silhouette
description: The Girl: The actress, who is nominated for an Academy Award for best supporting actress in 12 Years a Slave, wore an ivory silk crepe bandeau dress to accept aCritics Choice Movie Award in the same category at last nights ceremony in Santa Monica.

title: Fabled Lands
description: The River Danube, like a siren, has seduced at least three authors over the centuries. The first was Count Luigi Ferdinando Marsigli from Bologna, in the 17th century. His work grew into six wonderfully illustrated volumes, published in Latin in 1726. The second was Claudio Magris, from Trieste, in the 20th century. A professor, scholar and novelist, he completed a journey to the Black Sea in 1986, just before the fall of the old Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Like Marsigli, he had no very clear idea of what kind of book he wanted to write, yet in the end, Magris produced Danube, a masterpiece.

title: Austin City Limits
description: Feeling like a fraud or a con artist can be a hazard of the writing profession; theres a fine line, Balzac wrote, between the artist and the criminal. Thats certainly true of Frankie Abandonato  a New York grifter who makes the critical error of pulling a lottery scam on a mobster. Abandonato, the hero of James Magnusons novel Famous Writers I Have Known, slips town for Texas, holing up at a creative writing institute where hes mistaken for a J. D. Salingeresque recluse named V. S. Mohle. (The real Mohle was expected on campus to teach a seminar while either reconciling or settling an old score  its complicated  with the institutes fabulously successful founder, Rex Schoeninger, whose sprawling social novels are reminiscent of James Micheners; their feud culminated years ago in a brawl on The Dick Cavett Show, after which Mohle dropped out of society and never published again.)

title: Tales End
description: In the mid-1970s, the managing editor of The San Francisco Chronicle kept a chart in his office with two columns: heterosexual and homosexual. Whenever a new character appeared in Tales of the City  the newspapers fiction serial by Armistead Maupin, which begat a stack of popular novels  the name was slotted accordingly.

title: The Enemy Within
description: The subtitle of Jennifer Percys first book, Demon Camp, is A Soldiers Exorcism, and four of its five chapter titles contain the words kill or war. Despite appearances, though, this isnt really a book about soldiers or killing or war; its about a certain strain of American religious belief, and one writers transformation as she documents its effects on its adherents, several of them veterans, and on herself.

title: Ask Well: How Long Does a Flu Shot Last?
description: Question:

title: Hugh Jackman Returning to Broadway in The River
description: Hugh Jackman, who has become one of the theater worlds most lucrative draws, will return to Broadway next season starring in Jez Butterworths play The River, the producers and Mr. Jackman said on Friday.

title: In Sickness and in Health
description: Nancy Horans first novel, Loving Frank, explored the tangled personal life of Frank Lloyd Wright. Now, in her second, she takes a deep, long look at the intimate history of yet another creative man. This time, the action is viewed from two perspectives  those of Robert Louis Stevenson and (even more so) of his American wife, Fanny Van de Grift Osbourne, who hopes to be a painter or a writer herself. Under the Wide and Starry Sky is at once a classic artistic bildungsroman and a retort to the genre, a novel that shows how love and marriage can simultaneously offer inspiration and encumbrance, especially when the more successful partner believes that, as far as artists go, a family could tolerate only one. The Stevensons story is full of morbidity and sacrifice, chronicling losses and gains  and, of course, the writing of classics like Treasure Island, Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde and Kidnapped, none of which, Horan suggests, would have been possible without Fanny Stevensons careful nurturing of her husband.

title: Not Long for This World
description: John Rebus is the kind of cop who isnt afraid to think, and what hes thinking in Ian Rankins terrific new procedural, SAINTS OF THE SHADOW BIBLE (Little, Brown, $26), is that he and his ilk arent long for this brave new world. Having decided that retirement wasnt such a hot idea after all, the Edinburgh homicide detective is back on the job, but feeling increasingly out of step with his younger, more tech-savvy and ethics-bound colleagues.

title: The Not-So-Lonely City
description: Super-8 footage shot of the northwest corner of Bryant Park by Project for Public Spaces in 1980.

title: Obamas Speech on N.S.A. Phone Surveillance
description: Following is the text of President Obamas speech on National Security Agency data collection programs, as transcribed by the White House.

title: Reading and Writing
description: WHAT W. H. AUDEN CAN DO FOR YOU  By Alexander McCall Smith  Princeton University, $19.95.

title: Era of Cheap Apparel May Be Ending for U.S.
description: FOR decades, declining prices have helped American consumers spend less on one critical part of every familys budget: clothing. But those days may be ending.

title: Trial Begins Next Week for Human Rights Activist in China
description: HONG KONG  One of Chinas most prominent human rights activists, Xu Zhiyong, will stand trial next week and believes that his conviction is all but certain, although he will fight the charges, his lawyer said Friday.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Our America
description: This week, Felipe Fernndez-Armesto talks about Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Gabriel Sherman discusses his new book about Roger Ailes; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Rutgers to Test Its Spirit vs. No. 1 UConn
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Ariel Butts, a sophomore forward-center, worked to improve her conditioning by repeatedly running the length of the court after a recent practice at Rutgers Athletic Center. When the laps began to take their toll and the grimace on her face flashed fatigue bordering on exhaustion, her teammate Betnijah Laney helped talk her through the rest of the regimen.

title: Annoying Trends in Baby Names
description: Washingtons new culture war; Liz Cheney versus Lon Chaney Jr.; Matthew Crawley in context.

title: Concert to Re-Create Debut of Gershwins Rhapsody in Blue on 90th Anniversary
description: The stage setting was unconventional as the program, the New York Times music critic Olin Downes wrote of a concert he attended at Aeolian Hall, on West 43rd Street, on Feb. 12, 1924. He went on to describe a scene that would have curdled the blood of a Stokowski or a Mengelberg, two of the most revered conductors of the day, not least because the musicians drew on an instrumental arsenal that included pianos in various states of disassembly, an array of wind, brass and percussion, and frying pans, large tin utensils and a speaking trumpet, later stuck into the end of a trombone.

title: Critics Choice Movie Awards Red Carpet
description: Lupita Nyongo in Calvin Klein, and Cate Blanchett in Lanvin on Thursday in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Orange Is the New Green
description: Orange is the color of the week in my kitchen, as it has been since the fall and will be throughout the winter at my farmers market. Im making oven fries with sweet potatoes, roasting and simmering carrots and winter squash with seasonings I havent used before with these vegetables and finding new ways to enjoy grated carrot salads, which have always been a weakness of mine. Sometimes markets can look bleak in winter, but theres nothing drab about carrots, sweet potatoes and winter squash; Im finding that there is a lot I can do with these nutrient-dense vegetables.

title: From Street Smart to Safari Savvy
description: PARIS  Alexander Wang, 30, and Olivier Rousteing, 27, the designer of Balmain, are of the same generation. But the collections they offered for the winter 2014 mens season could not have looked more different.

title: Image of the Day: January 17
Times Minute | Examining Obamas Speech
description: In the Video

title: Times Minute | Examining Obama's Speech
description: In today's Minute, President Obama outlines new surveillance rules. What he said; his evolution from critic to overseer; and implications going forward.

title: Obama on Phone Data Collection
description: The president announced the end of the telephone metadata program, the way it exists now, after the disclosure of the practice by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden.

title: Spike Jonze Is Part of More Nominated Films Than You May Know
description: LOS ANGELES  Its a Spike Jonze world, and were just living in it. Thats true for any fan of the writer-director, whose films, like Being John Malkovich, Where the Wild Things Are and especially his latest, Her, conjure up their own, slightly-left-of-center universe.

title: Israel Summons 4 Envoys With Complaints About Bias
description: JERUSALEM  In the latest diplomatic confrontation over Israeli settlement building, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel took the unusual step of summoning four European ambassadors on Friday to complain about what he called their countries perpetual one-sided stance against Israel and in favor of the Palestinians.

title: Disneys Troubled Gaming Unit Finds Success With Infinity
description: Disneys new Infinity video game is a certified hit, an important win for what has been one of the entertainment conglomerates most troubled businesses.

title: In Praise of Depth
description: Many years ago, I realized that New Years resolutions dont work. This year, instead, I created a ritual. A resolution is a hope and a prayer. A ritual is a highly specific behavior done at a precise time, so that it becomes automatic over time.

title: Congress Moves Mountains
description: Even as an alarming chemical spill from coal-industry storage tanks cut off the water supply for Charleston, West Virginia, Congress moved blithely ahead this week to protect one of the industrys most toxic excesses  the massive dumping of rubble into valleys and streams from a strip-mine process euphemistically termed mountaintop removal.

title: Taliban Attack Kills 16 at Restaurant Favored by Westerners
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban struck a restaurant popular with Westerners in downtown Kabul on Friday in what appeared to be a well-coordinated assault, with a suicide bomber clearing a path for two gunmen, who rushed in and fired on diners, the police said. At least 16 people were killed, most of them foreigners.

title: Time for Doggy Daycare
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: A.P. Cameraman Released on Bail in Egypt
description: An Egyptian cameraman who was arrested this week while covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was released on bail on Friday, the news agency reported.

title: Today in Small Business: Target Goes Small
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Our America
description: This week, Felipe Fernndez-Armesto and Gabriel Sherman.

title: Food Matters | Maison Kitsuns Quaint New Parisian Cafe
description: Maison Kitsun, the French cool-kid company for turned-out fashion and electronic music, is adding an eponymous Parisian cafe to its stable. The label was founded in 2002 by Gildas Loac, former art-director and manager for Daft Punk, and Masaya Kuroki, an architecture student turned fashion designer. This is the duos second Caf Kitsun; the popular original opened in Tokyo last February.

title: Britain Scrambles to Fill Skills Gap
description: STAFFORD, England  For the last two years, Josh Younger, 19, has been learning how to fuse heavy steel pipes used in nuclear power plants, spending hours each day behind a welding helmet and surrounded by the acrid smell of burned metal.

title: A Long Way Home
description: What you fall for first, reading Ishmael Beahs new novel, is its setting  the small village of Imperi, in the rural grasslands of Sierra Leone. The sky above it is wide and colorful. A giant mango tree sits at its center. A river flows nearby. In better times, villagers farmed coffee behind their homes. In the evenings, schoolchildren shucked their uniforms on the riverbank and noisily splashed around.

title: Book Review Podcast: Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Julio Ortega reviews Felipe Fernndez-Armestos Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States. Mr. Ortega writes:

title: Civil War in the Senate
description: No word was more hotly contested during the Civil War than loyalty. Republicans persistently accused Democrats of disloyalty and treason for opposing Republican war measures, and no Democrat was immune from accusations of disloyalty, even at the highest levels of the government.

title: A Conversation With Steven Moffat, a Sherlock Co-Creator
description: Steven Moffat is the co-creator of the BBC hit Sherlock and the lead writer and executive producer of Doctor Who, the classic sci-fi series about a time-traveling alien that celebrated its 50th anniversary in November. He also created, in 2000, Coupling, a saucy sitcom about the sexual misadventures of 30-something Londoners that was based loosely on his marriage to the television producer Sue Vertue. All this makes the 52-year-old Scotsman one of the most influential figures in British television, and also a target for legions of fans who bombard the Internet with theories about how Holmes could have possibly faked his suicide or whether a woman should play the next Doctor. Its very dangerous for me to venture onto social media, Mr. Moffat said by phone from London.

title: Burke in America
description: Ive been following with great interest the discussion surrounding Yuval Levins new book, The Great Debate, which offers an overview of the competing worldviews of Thomas Paine and Edmund Burke in an effort to explain what the subtitle calls the birth of right and left. And Ive been particularly interested in the liberal critiques of Levins argument, which have taken an interesting (if perhaps unsurprising) form: Very few reviewers have questioned his interpretation of his subjects long-running late-18th century argument, but Ive noticed repeated attempts to deny their relevance to present-day American conservatism, which a number of left-of-center reviewers have argued owes little-or-nothing to any kind of Burkean worldview. In a later post I want to take up Sheri Bermans version of this argument, in the liberal journal Democracy, but here let me say something aboutWilliam Galstons response to Levin, in his Wall Street Journal column, which Ill quote at length:

title: Comme des Garonss Holey Suit
description: PARIS  Holy suit were the two mysterious words spoken by Rei Kawakubo before her Comme des Garons show kicked off Friday with smart tailoring.

title: Helping Catholics by Teaching Priests How to Be the Boss
description: ST. JOHNS, Fla.  They came for prayer and fellowship, naturally. They gave confession to other priests, too. But mostly they came for lectures. Lectures on employment law. And on best practices in hiring and firing. And accounting and auditing. It was five days with hardly any theology.

title: Sundance: The Politics of Picking an Opening-Night Film
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Opening night at the Sundance Film Festival, always on a Thursday, has recently been reserved for the premiere of an extra-arty film. One longtime attendee calls it the gay Eskimo slot: a picture that tries so hard to be original that it ends up being completely uncommercial.

title: Victoria and Albert Museum to Publish Nazi-Era Degenerate Art Inventory Online
description: BERLIN  Britains Victoria and Albert Museum, the holder of the only known complete inventory of modern works reviled by the Nazis and confiscated from German museums in 1937 to 1938, will make a copy of the list available online starting at the end of January.

title: A Reunion That Was a Long Time Coming
description: Sundays were the hardest day of the week for Peter Tiboris.

title: Hilary Mantels Next Book Is a Story Collection
description: Hilary Mantel, the author of the bestselling historical novels Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, has written a collection of short stories that will be released in September, her publisher said. The book, The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher, was acquired by Henry Holt in the United States and 4th Estate in Britain. Nicholas Pearson, the publishing director of 4th Estate, said in a statement: A new book from Hilary Mantel is a treat. Where her last two novels explore how modern England was forged, The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher shows us the country we have become.' Ms. Mantel won the Man Booker Prize in both 2012 and 2009.

title: Exclusive | 165 East 73rd Street
description: The Upper East Side building, priced at $14.5 million, features arched doorways and an oak balustrade, carry-overs from the its era as a stable.

title: Long on Horsepower
description: A historic Beaux-Arts-style Upper East Side carriage house that has remained in the same family for its entire 110-year existence  morphing from a repository for horses and carriages belonging to the owner of a Fifth Avenue mansion, to a garage and chauffeurs digs, to a single-family home, to a quaint rental  is about to enter the market at $14.5 million.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Saving Mr. Banks'
description: John Lee Hancock narrates a scene from his film about the making of Mary Poppins.

title: Does the P.&G. Olympics Ad Have You Dreaming of Glory by Proxy? Dont.
description: Has Procter & Gambles Pick Them Back Up campaign brought a tear to your eye yet? Its a powerful combination of exhilarating sports imagery, dramatic music and tender moments between mothers and kids. Moms encourage their kids to get back up after various athletic setbacks, from faceplanting on the ice rink as tots to recovering from injuries as teens, then finally sharing the sweet taste of victory with their adult daughters and sons.

title: HSBC and Citigroup Suspend Currency Traders
description: LONDON  HSBC and Citigroup each suspended currency traders on Friday amid ongoing investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

title: Blast at Antigovernment March Raises Tensions in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK  An attack on antigovernment protesters in Bangkok on Friday, most likely with a grenade, killed one person and injured more than 30, intensifying tensions in the city as a dwindling but dedicated core of protesters continues to block access to a number of government buildings and major intersections.

title: The No More Tears Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde
description: SKILLMAN, N.J.  The only hint that something is different inside millions of bottles of Johnsons Baby Shampoo arriving on store shelves are two words: Improved Formula.

title: A Top U.N. Rights Official Describes Horror in South Sudan
description: UNITED NATIONS  A top United Nations human rights official visiting South Sudan described horror on Friday, with bodies on the streets and reports of mass killings, sexual violence and the recruitment of children into battle.

title: Obama Signals Change to N.S.A. Practices
description: The president, in response to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, highlighted changes to the National Security Administrations practices.

title: Apollos Rush to Get the Chuck E. Cheese Deal Done
description: Apollo Global Management is sprinting to acquire Chuck E. Cheese.

title: Comme des Garons: Fall 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Sex, Scandal and Soccer, the Italian Way
description: The filmmakers Marco and Mauro La Villa conceived of their forthcoming documentary, Black and White Stripes: the Juventus Story, shortly after their father, Giovanni, died in 2001. He had rooted for Juventus, Italys most storied soccer club, his entire life. In Pietramilar, the tiny village were Giovanni was born and raised, priests moonlighted as scouts for professional soccer clubs, and at a young age Giovanni was offered a scholarship to go to school in Turin to play for Juventuss junior squad. His mother disapproved, though, and forced him into the familys gravestone-painting business. His lifes great regret was that he didnt get to chase his dream, Marco says. The brothers, however, chased theirs, and are currently at Sundance, not screening their movie but rather promoting it with The Art of Black and White Stripes, a traveling art exhibition they co-curated with Lapo Elkann, a scion of the Agnelli family, which has owned the team since 1923.

title: Dangers of Giving In to Impulse for Revenge
description: I found the machinations in the Netflix political series House of Cards to be immensely entertaining but a little over the top  until, that is, the traffic jam scandal in New Jersey.

title: Marine Corps Apologizes for Gunman Reference in Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday Tweet
description: On Friday the official Twitter account of the Marine Corps Special Operations Command posted a picture and message that appeared to make light of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at the start of the long holiday weekend to commemorate his birth.

title: Time for More Competitiveness at Citigroup
description: Citigroups boss, Michael L. Corbat, needs to channel some of the aggression from his boardroom.

title: Gays Can Be Relaxed and Calm at the Olympics, Putin Says
description: MOSCOW  Seeking to head off one of several simmering controversies ahead of next months Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Friday that no one would be targeted at the Games under a federal law banning homosexual propaganda among minors, even as he defended the law as a way to protect children from exposure to nontraditional relationships.

title: Obamas Changes to Government Surveillance
description: President Obama announced that he would place new limits on intelligence agencies bulk collection of phone call records. But he rejected some other recommendations to rein in surveillance made by a panel of outside advisers.

title: Why Are the Intelligence Budgets a State Secret?
description: You can dig all you want through the trillion-dollar spending bill just approved by Congress and still not learn how much the country is spending on each of the intelligence agencies. Thats because those amounts are a state secret, and nowhere in President Obamas call for greater oversight and transparency on Friday did he propose changing that status.

title: A Continent on Her Musical Map
description: Anglique Kidjo, the songwriter and singer from Benin, was in Kenya being a do-gooder when the concept of her new album, Eve, came to her, she said, like a light bulb blowing up in your head.

title: Severe Drought Grows Worse in California
description: NORDEN, Calif.  Cattle ranchers have had to sell portions of their herd for lack of water. Sacramento and other municipalities have imposed severe water restrictions. Wildfires broke out this week in forests that are usually too wet to ignite. Ski resorts that normally open in December are still closed; at one here in the Sierra Nevada that is open, a bear wandered onto a slope full of skiers last week, apparently not hibernating because of the balmy weather.

title: At the Critics Choice Awards, Fine-Tuning Stump Speeches
description: LOS ANGELES  Held on the same day that many of the Oscar hopefuls became nominees, and anointing largely the same bunch, the Critics Choice Awards  given by the Broadcast Film Critics Association and televised on the CW  are as relaxed and joyful as an awards show gets.

title: On the Market in Scottsdale, Ariz.
description: Contemporary and traditional homes with southwestern flair. Prices range from $729,000 to $6.975 million.

title: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
description: Last Updated, Sunday, Jan. 19 | Several Twitter accounts used by the military wing of Hamas have been suspended by the social network in recent days, angering the Islamist militants and delighting Israels military.

title: Doctor Tells of Leaking Data to Friend at SAC
description: The largest insider trading scheme on record started with an attempt at friendship.

title: Ford Recalls Edge, Explorer and Vans; N.H.T.S.A. Upgrades Jeep Investigation
description: Ford recalled about 28,000 of its 2012-13 Edge crossover utility vehicles for possible fuel leaks on models equipped with the 2-liter 4-cylinder EcoBoost engine, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website. The automaker said the fuel line pulse damper was not manufactured properly by a Michigan supplier, which could allow fuel odor, seepage or a small fuel leak.

title: Calling It Art, Not Native American Art
description: One is a picture of a jaunty red bra  just a bra  distilled to its basic geometric elements, including the little white tag peeking out from behind one strap. The other still life, by the same artist, depicts the simplified form of a pair of thick-rimmed eyeglasses.

title: Movie Review: Jack Ryan Shadow Recruit
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit.

title: Movie Review: 'Big Bad Wolves'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Big Bad Wolves.

title: Movie Review: 'Generation War'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Generation War.

title: Having Enough, but Hungry for More
description: THREE recent stories got me thinking about a concept that is central to money, wealth and ultimately contentment but that is overlooked this time of year: knowing how much is enough.

title: Mens Paris Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Hotel Spa Treatments, Day and, Now, Night
description: Hotel spas are usually open only during the day, but some properties around the world are breaking from tradition by offering nighttime treatments. Chi, the spa at Shangri-Las Fijian Resort and Spa, has a Dusk Till Dawn experience ($514) for couples where they actually sleep in the spa treatment villa. The service begins with an outdoor bath followed by a body polish, massage and dinner and ends in the morning with a facial and breakfast.

title: Stop Trusting Yourself
description: TRUST is a double-edged sword. Though you can accomplish more in life if you put your faith in others, doing so also leaves you vulnerable. If your friend, business partner or political ally betrays you, he benefits  in terms of money, power or some other resource  at your expense. This risk is the drawback of trust, and it leads many people to prefer self-reliance, an arrangement that seems more secure because the only person you have to count on is yourself.

title: Artkick Wants to Be the Spotify of Art
description: Pandora and Spotify are businesses that sort through digital music and figure out your likes. Netflix does the same for movies. Theres even Yelp, doing something like that for food. Meantime, fine art just hangs there on the wall.

title: Navigating a New Health Plan, After the Surge
description: YOUVE no doubt heard about problems some people are encountering when they try to use the health insurance theyve bought through the federal and state exchanges. A backlog of applications, the result of a surge in enrollments at years end for coverage starting this month, has resulted in many people experiencing delays in getting insurance cards, policy numbers or authorization for treatment.

title: Sex? Yes. The City? Yes. But Things Have Changed.
description: Fourteen years apart, Cynthia Nixon and Allison Williams created roles in two groundbreaking series, both on HBO, that captured for their respective generations the confounding experience of being a young single woman in New York: Miranda Hobbes on Sex and the City, which aired from 1998 to 2004, and Marnie Michaels on Girls, which had its debut in 2012 and began its third season last week.

title: Big Ticket: 7 Fireplaces and a Hot View for $27.5 Million
description: An exquisitely restored and renovated co-op at the Dakota that enjoys 100 feet of unobstructed Central Park vistas just above the tree canopy sold for $27.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Two Broncos Quarterbacks, Sparkling in the Twilight
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  In an upstairs conference room at the Denver Broncos practice complex, John Elway rocked back and forth in his black leather seat and swiveled from side to side. Three days before his Broncos were to play for a berth in Super Bowl XLVIII, Elway was like a big kid in a darkened theater waiting for an absorbing double feature to light up the giant screen.

title: The Source | Tilda Swinton
description: Doug Aitken interviews the actress Tilda Swinton.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Red Herrings Solved!
description: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to take the case of a 29-year-old woman with an injured groin, a swollen foot and other abnormalities. Many of you found it as challenging as the doctors who saw her. I asked for the right test as well as the right diagnosis. More than 200 answers were posted.

title: Rapture for Valentines: Blondie in Miami Beach
description: Blondie, the new wave rock group started by Debbie Harry and Chris Stein on the Lower East Side of New York in the mid-70s, is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year (thats right, 40th). But theyre far from being over the hill.

title: The Gun Report: January 17, 2014
description: Today marks the final day of the worlds largest gun exhibition, the SHOT Show in Las Vegas, which features 12 miles of guns and outdoor gear offered by 1,600 exhibitors. Sponsored by the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the show, which hosted 60,000 commercial buyers and sellers of military, law enforcement and tactical products, is the primary marketing opportunity for firearms companies to hawk their new products to gun dealersproducts like assault rifles, high-capacity ammunition magazines and silencers.

title: Years Before His Bipartisan Luster, a Rough Reception for Gates
description: WASHINGTON  Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates startled Washington with a withering critique of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. when he said in his new memoir that Mr. Biden had been wrong on nearly every major foreign policy and national security issue over the past four decades.

title: Weekend Reading: Bank Earnings Quiz
description: How well do you know your earnings reports? Most of the Wall Street giants released fourth quarter results this week, including Bank of America, BlackRock, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo. Match the financial company with the quote about its latest earnings report. Answers below.

title: What I Love | Gwynne Duncan
description: A child of Westbeth the first subsidized artists housing complex of its type in the United States, returns.

title: A Kinship With Westbeth
description: Decades before the elevated train tracks on the Lower West Side of Manhattan were transformed into a global tourist attraction called the High Line, they were Gwynne Duncans playground.

title: Supreme Court Will Consider Whether Police Need Warrants to Search Cellphones
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a pair of cases about whether the police need a warrant to search the cellphones of people they arrest, presenting a major test of the meaning of the Fourth Amendment in the digital age.

title: In the Future, Your Fridge Could Get Hacked
description: The next great advance in technology may well be the Internet of Things. Simply put, many more devices and appliances that you use every day, like refrigerators, thermostats, garage doors and so on will be connected to the Internet, will adapt to your behavior and will be available to do your bidding even when you are not near them.

title: Where a Storied Classical Label Embraces Rockers
description: More evidence, if any were needed, that the boundary between classical music and rock continues to erode: Deutsche Grammophon, once the most staid of the worlds classical music labels, is releasing St. Carolyn by the Sea, a collection of works by Bryce Dessner, best known as a guitarist in the National, and Jonny Greenwood, the lead guitarist in Radiohead. The album, recorded by the Copenhagen Philharmonic, led by Andr de Ridder, is due out March 3.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Announces First Concert After Lockout
description: With the 15-month lockout of its musicians now behind it, the Minnesota Orchestra announced Friday that its first concert back in Orchestra Hall would be given Feb. 7 and would be conducted by Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, its music director from 1960 to 1979.

title: Russians: Still the Go-To Bad Guys
description: THE movie Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit, which opens in theaters this weekend, revolves around an American C.I.A. analyst first introduced in Tom Clancys 1984 novel The Hunt for Red October. The source material isnt the only thing thats a little creaky. Ryans destination is Moscow, his target a Russian businessman plotting to crash the American economy through a terrorist attack. In portraying the diabolical oligarch Viktor Cherevin, Kenneth Branagh delivers his lines in the thick, menacingly slow accent that defines Eastern European baddies on screen: You think this is game, Jack?

title: A.P.C. and Bonton Design Childrens Wear Thats Too Cool for School
description: The A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou believes that children are never too young to be exposed to good design. He founded a creativity-centered Paris school, Atelier de la Petite Enfance (A.P.E. for short), to educate his now-9-year-old daughter Lily; the space, designed by the architect and frequent A.P.C. collaborator Laurent Deroo, features tiny Alvar Aalto chairs and building blocks created by the art director Mathias Augustyniak of M/M Paris. When the schools art department needed uniforms for the children to wear while painting, Touitou turned to Bonton, the hip French childrens clothier  whose founders, Thomas and Irne Cohen, are the son and daughter-in-law of the owners ofBonpointandhave a daughter in Lilys class. The uniforms also ended up in Bontons five retail outlets, where they became a best seller. The design was the right balance between playful and straight, Touitou says. I sort of knew that wed have kids together one day, so to speak.

title: Review: Jeep Grand Cherokee EcoDiesel
description: If your commute includes mud, boulders and steep grades, the Jeep Grand Cherokee can tame it. The 2014 model is available with a clean diesel engine for an extra $4,500. Torque lovers will rejoice.

title: From Classical Giant to Clearance Bins
description: For classical music lovers with old-fashioned ideas about buying recordings in Manhattan  in stores, on compact discs  the choices have dwindled. Tower Records near Lincoln Center closed in 2006. The Virgin Megastore in Times Square shut down in 2009. And in 2011, Barnes & Noble, which had devoted one level to CDs and videos in a large store across the street from the former Tower space, moved out.

title: The Source | Paolo Soleri
description: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Paolo Soleri.

title: An App for Cultural Goings-On in New York City
description: Listings apps have proliferated ever since developers realized how desperate users were for suggestions about what to do. Apps like YPlan and Sosh have muscled into that space, with dazzling displays and a huge number of events available. Those apps, while functional, can seem faux local, the app version of your corner Starbucks, a global chain that tries its best to feel homey.

title: Upbeat Again, but Not Overconfident
description: DETROIT  Twenty-five years ago, the Detroit Lions biblical trials of football futility coincided with a familiar economic slump  the kind that often seemed to save its worst for Detroit.

title: If Your Car Could Talk, Would It Speak Sensual Clarity?
description: DETROIT  The native languages of automobile designers ceased to matter years ago. In studios around the world, Germans work for Americans, Japanese for Germans, and so on.

title: In Search of an Uncommon Language
description: Examples of the interplay between design and phraseology abound at the North American International Auto Show this year.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Sudan, Egypt, Bahrain and Britain.

title: A Met Debut as That Besotted Geisha, Adamant That He Will Be True
description: In many ways, Anthony Minghellas production of Puccinis Madama Butterfly, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, resembles an insect collection in which colorful, exotic specimens are fixed on a neutral background and bathed in a sharp, bright light. Its a fitting way to present this ever-popular opera about a caddish American naval officer who enters into a nonbinding marriage with a teenage Japanese geisha and then abandons her, pregnant, lovesick and cast out from her community. Featuring innovative puppetry by Blind Summit Theater, its also an uncomfortable production that introduces multiple perspectives in ways that illuminate and alienate in equal measure.

title: At Ease, Low-Key and High Profile
description: WHO Julia Roberts

title: Red Carpet Watch: Julia Robertss Style
description: Ms. Robertss style on the red carpet is very easy and low-key.

title: Jeep Thirst Quenched by Diesel
description: TESTED 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee EcoDiesel

title: A Stew Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: IT HAD BEEN DARK and dismal all day. Bitter cold. Snowing. I would not be going to the store to fetch groceries; the weather in New York was far too brutal for any kind of shopping. Just getting home from the subway stop was a slippery, treacherous ordeal.

title: A Crucial Caveat in Obamas Vow on Phone Data
description: WASHINGTON  In overhauling the nations spy programs, President Obama vowed on Friday that he will end the bulk telephone data program that has caused so much consternation  as it currently exists.

title: Underground London
description: The British capitals evolving skyline is as impressive as it is unusual. Consider the Shard, the 1,016-foot vertical city that topped out as Western Europes tallest building when it was completed in 2012, and 20 Fenchurch Street (a.k.a the Walkie-Talkie), which made headlines last summer when the glare from its cartoonishly flaring facade warped the panels of a Jaguar parked outside.

title: James Baldwins Paris
description: One bright afternoon in Paris, on the terrace of the cafe Deux Magots, in St.-Germain-des-Prs, I found myself engaged in an increasingly animated conversation about the writer James Baldwin and the notorious feud that broke out between him and his fellow African-American expatriate Richard Wright.

title: The Overlooked Travel Agent, Now Starring Off Broadway
description: Consider the hapless travel agent. Undercut by Expedia. Ignored by app-reliant consumers. Overlooked, thanks to the digital revolution.

title: Hotel Review: The Thief in Oslo
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Oaxen Krog & Slip in Stockholm
description: Though Copenhagen gets most of the regional limelight, Stockholm has quietly emerged as a gastronomic destination on par with the Danish capital. One of the strongest sets of players in that mix is the chef Magnus Ek and his wife, Agneta Green, who closed Oaxen, the restaurant theyd founded in 1994 on its namesake island in the southern part of the Stockholm archipelago, and moved to a striking new waters-edge location on Djurgarden, an island in central Stockholm, last May.

title: A Humble Meal to Pair With Pinot Grigios
description: Before we tasted these pinot grigios, I anticipated pairing them with local bay scallops. But wines that are not profound, yet pleasant enough and reasonably priced, call for a sense of proportion. Ill save the scallops, at $30 a pound, for more impressive bottles and opt instead for humbler satisfaction.

title: The Enemy Is Not Pinot Grigio
description: Can a wine be too popular for its own good? Apparently so. Exhibit A: pinot grigio from Italy.

title: Submit Your Summer Vacation Rental Questions
description: It may be in the 40s in New York City, but its nonetheless prime season for solidifying summer plans if yours include renting a vacation home. Do you have questions about East Coast summer vacation rentals? Whats the best way to find a house? What should you expect to pay? Whats the etiquette in a share house? Whether youre dreaming of sunbathing in the Hamptons or on Marthas Vineyard, nows the time to get real about what that might entail.

title: Mens Paris Fashion Week: Givenchy Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: As Smooth as a Martini
description: Ive got more style than a Rolex watch/Ive got more style than a Rolls-Royce car, Devin Bing, a Long Island blue-eyed soul crooner declared in his original ballad Smooth in the opening of his show on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. Accompanying Mr. Bing, who played piano, was his four-member band, the Secret Service (Michael Feinberg on bass, Blaise Lanzetta on drums, Gavi Grodsky on guitar and Mark Bader on percussion), who churned out the kind of sleek, generic pop-soul grooves with jazz flavoring that are associated with hits by the likes of Robin Thicke.

title: Oatmeal Sandwich Cookies
description: In a twist on an old classic, Melissa Clark adds soft dates and toasted coconut to oatmeal cookies, then sandwiches a thin layer of sweetened mascarpone between them.

title: A Fight Over Horses
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has vowed to banish Central Park carriage horses, but the drivers reject the charge of animal cruelty and say the horses health is their biggest concern.

title: If You Give A Cookie Some Stuffing
description: Forget all the bad, soggy oatmeal cookies youve ever had.

title: Who Speaks for the Carriage Horses?
description: If only Teddy could talk. Then we would know what he thinks of the politicians and activists and drivers who argue about his future. He could expound on Manhattan traffic, its pollution, the cold, the heat, the hay and the shrieking girls clutching dolls who pet his nose on Grand Army Plaza.

title: A Bit of Bush and bin Laden
description: In BigMouth, his one-man show in the Under the Radar Festival, the Belgian stage veteran Valentijn Dhaenens takes the long view. Centuries long: In this spare, thought-provoking production, which he directed, Mr. Dhaenens quotes speeches from luminaries across millenniums. Some, like Pericles and George S. Patton, were military commanders; others, like Ronald Reagan and  King Baudouin I of Belgium, national rulers; and still others, like Socrates and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., philosophical leaders. Several, like Nicola Sacco and Ann Coulter, could be called political radicals.

title: Sharing Web Links Without Cutting and Pasting
description: Q. Is there an easier way to email a web page link on the Nexus 7 than copying and pasting the link from the browser into the mail app?

title: Bloomberg to Press Republicans on Immigration Overhaul
description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in Washington next Friday, along with members of the United States Chamber of Commerce and several prominent Republicans, to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up an overhaul of the nations immigration laws before the end of the current Congress.

title: Shes Having My Baby, Satan Croons
description: From Rosemarys Baby (1968) to The Brood (1979), demon spawn has been erupting from innocent wombs, to the surprise of mothers who unaccountably fail to greet this vile emission with a pillow to the face  presuming it has one, of course.

title: Pop on Those Prada Shades, Puff Out Your Lips and Say, Puh-leeeze!
description: The Statler and Waldorf of 90210 are Dorothy Wang and Morgan Stewart, longtime friends with shared passions  expensive nights out, expensive clothes and shoes  paid for with Mommy and Daddys money.

title: Lets Put On a Show! Ill Make ...
description: The deeply inessential HitRECord on TV, which begins Saturday on Pivot, is a variety-show outgrowth of a website started by the actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt and his brother in which contributions from various creative types are crowdsourced to make short films and songs and other things. On the show, all of the contributors are identified by the screen names they use at hitrecord.org. Mr. Gordon-Levitts is RegularJoe.

title: Clothier Outfits New Yorks Clergy and Judges in Robes
description: That measuring tape dangling from Marvin Goldmans neck is almost a formality: Even at 85, he can size you up at 10 paces for your height, weight and sleeve length.

title: A Photographers Artful Images of African Agriculture
description: In 1997, Jackie Nickerson set out for a farm in Zimbabwe to visit a friend, intending to stay for just a few weeks. But the landscapes, people and agricultural practices of sub-Saharan Africa captivated her, so she ended up staying for four years. At the beginning of her time in Africa, the former fashion photographer documented the rural scenes around the southern part of the continent. The more she traveled, the more her portfolio of alluring portraits and landscapes grew, photographs which she eventually compiled into Farm, her first body of work outside of fashion, which was released as a book in 2002.

title: Mets General Manager to Take Over Labor Talks
description: One of the more unusual duo acts in opera is breaking up.

title: Times Minute | Turmoil in Thailand
description: Also on the Minute, Pennsylvania's voter identification law is struck down and the quarterback matchup of the season takes place on Sunday.

title: If You See Something, Say Something
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  THE overwhelming consensus among climate scientists is that human-caused climate change is happening. Yet a fringe minority of our populace clings to an irrational rejection of well-established science. This virulent strain of anti-science infects the halls of Congress, the pages of leading newspapers and what we see on TV, leading to the appearance of a debate where none should exist.

title: Pulled Down From the Sky, Still Lethal
description: The heroine of Grounded, a solo play by George Brant, feels most alive when shes up in the air. A fighter pilot in the Air Force, she loves everything about her job  the suit, the speed, the danger, the respect  but most of all the blue, as she calls the wide expanses of sky through which she steers her plane, searching out the bad guys in sorties over Iraq.

title: Kurt Masur Conducting Seminar Is Postponed
description: Kurt Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic (he now holds an emeritus title) was to have spent next week leading what has become an annual conducting seminar at the Manhattan School of Music. But late Friday afternoon the school announced that Mr. Masur, 86, was hospitalized to be treated for anemia, and that the seminar would be postponed until next year.

title: Times Minute | Turmoil in Thailand
description: In the Video

title: An Aromatic Experience
description: McNultys Tea & Coffee, on Christopher Street, has been selling bags of coffee and tea since 1895.

title: Stalking Heritage Far From Home
description: LOS ANGELES  It is odd to see an eight-foot-long stucco statue of a man in a jaguar mask slinking along the floor of the Convention Center here, as if stalking unsuspecting prey. Over 1,400 years ago, royal accouterments would have accompanied him: The yellow and black discolorations we see on his carved skirt, now faded, would have been potently vivid  evoking animal pelts worn by the Maya elite. Jaguars, in some respects, were Maya lords of the underworld; this representation  formal and monumental  is coiled with menace, threatening death.

title: The Sweet Smell of Longevity at McNultys
description: You can smell the store from the sidewalk: the warm, dark aroma of coffee beans.

title: Intel Plans to Cut 5,000 Jobs in 2014
description: Intel expects to shed about 5 percent of its work force, or 5,000 jobs, in 2014, as it tries to change the company with the times, according to a company official.

title: Not Just a Ride in the Park
Armond White, Ousted Critic, Has Words on Expulsion
description: Black Swan was called a ridiculous psychological thriller.

title: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, The Count
description: Im trying to fight back a cold, plus make good on promises to editors, so not much of substance since early today. But I did promise San Fermin to more or less premiere their latest live video  another really striking performance that wont be to everyones taste but which has been rattling around in my head, growing on me, since I first listened to it. Id recommend their Feb. 7 show at the Bowery Ballroom, but its sold out. Heres what youll be missing:

title: Anheuser-Busch InBev Said to Be Near $4.5 Billion Deal for Korean Brewer
description: Anheuser-Busch InBev is closing in on a deal to reacquire Oriental Brewery from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Affinity Equity Partners for more than $4.5 billion, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: The Scenic Route to Nebraska
description: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif.  June Squibb, 84, was nominated for an Oscar on Thursday for playing a way-past-giving-a-hoot Montanan in Nebraska. What does her character think of her dead sister-in-law? While standing over the womans grave, Ms. Squibbs foul-mouthed Kate gives her hilariously matter-of-fact answer: What a whore.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 17
description: Subjects include Gov. Chris Christie at the State of the State address, a water main break on Fifth Avenue, and a vaporium in Lower Manhattan.

title: De Blasio, Citing Horrible Death of Abused Boy, Unveils Plans for Reforms
description: After an inquiry into the death of a 4-year-old boy uncovered several holes in New York Citys safety net, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday proposed a raft of changes to close some of the gaps and improve communication between the criminal justice system and the agency charged with preventing child abuse.

title: Filmmaker Ira Sachss Sundance Stories
description: The director Ira Sachs has shown five of his films at the Sundance Film Festival since 1994. This week, he returns with his sixth, the much-anticipated Love Is Strange, with a cast including John Lithgow, Alfred Molina and Marisa Tomei. Sachs, whose childhood was partly spent in Park City, Utah, has been attending the festival since its earliest days  even before it was called Sundance  and was present at many of its most famous premieres. Here, he recounts his pivotal festival memories and the lessons hes learned about the industry along the way.

title: Company in West Virginia Spill Files for Bankruptcy
description: Freedom Industries, the West Virginia company whose chemical spill last week tainted the drinking water of more than 300,000 residents in and around Charleston, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Friday.

title: The Scene After a Bombing in Kabul
description: Three Taliban suicide bombers struck a restaurant popular with Westerners in downtown Kabul, setting off a blast that killed more than 20 people.

title: Industry City, the SoHo of Sunset Park
description: In October, more than 200 artists combined forces in a former warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to create Come Together: Surviving Sandy, Year 1, a sprawling exhibition of painting, sculpture and photography. Critics raved about the show, a mix of established names and relative unknowns that verified that New York is as alive and brilliant as ever, according to New York magazine, with artists spread out into all the boroughs.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 17
Trials for World Youth Teams Championships in Bridge
description: At the trials to select the United States entries for the World Youth Teams Championships in August in Istanbul, six teams entered the under-21 open division. After a round robin and semifinals, two teams played 48 boards to select USA-1.

title: Bill Cunningham | Check Mates
description: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat is a winter highlight.

title: The Logical Sherlock for Our Time
description: Its not too late.

title: Jos. A. Bank Rejects Mens Wearhouse Bid, Again
description: In the seemingly never-ending takeover war between two of the countrys largest mens suit retailers, Jos. A. Bank on Friday rejected the latest unsolicited bid from Mens Wearhouse.

title: Detroit Officials Scramble on Financing
description: Detroit officials spent Friday reshuffling legal and financial plans, a day after a federal bankruptcy judge barred the city from paying $165 million to end some troublesome interest-rate swaps that have been tying up money the city needs.

title: Let Curators Be Curators, MOCAs New Chief Says
description: The New York office of Philippe Vergne, the Dia Art Foundation director, who was named on Wednesday to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, looks out onto a brick vista of Chelsea art galleries. But hanging on the wall next to the windows is a photograph of Walter De Marias New Mexico land-art work The Lightning Field, showing a vast sweep of Western plateau.

title: Secret Histories
description: After Itzhak Goldbergs father died in 1995, at age 86, his mother gave him a watch in a red case. The 18-karat gold Patek Philippe was a rare indulgence for his father, a Polish Holocaust survivor who married, moved to Israel and ran a produce business.

title: Bill Cunningham | Check Mates
description: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat are a winter highlight. Above, houndstooth check, a gray flannel back and a leather accent on the sleeve for women, and a similar mix of fabrics on mens coats, bottom left. And for some people, shades of gray were an alternative to black.

title: Shepherding the Coney Island Polar Bear Club
description: After three decades, Dennis Thomass winter Sundays are no longer shocking. They are just cold. From November to April, Mr. Thomas, 59, charges into the Atlantic Ocean, along with other members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club; he has been the groups president for five years. This year, the clubs premier event on New Years Day drew 2,000 swimmers and 6,000 spectators and raised $65,000 for children with serious illnesses. On any given Sunday, 80 to 100 members show up at the New York Aquarium for the frosty frolic  neoprene bootees allowed. The lowest water temperature recorded for a swim was 32 degrees one February. Mr. Thomas, the director of global branding for the technology company SAP, lives alone in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. He suspects that his 25-year-old daughter thinks he is crazy.

title: Evening Hours
description: Events for young artists, an old dynasty, finance, football and ice skating.

title: Weighing the Need for a Landline in a Cellphone World
description: As I was hooking up a new phone in my living room, the kind where you plug a jack into the wall, I wondered why I was holding onto what had largely become a relic. It rarely rings, and even when it does, its usually the dentist or a robocaller.

title: Seven Days of Style | Anna Wintour Gets a Building Named After Her, Victoria Beckham Opens a Store and Amy Adams Wears Some Pricey Bling
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 11  17

title: A Superintendents Personal Space
description: Gesche Wurfel has been documenting basements in Upper Manhattan that have been decorated by the building superintendents, often with items discarded by tenants.

title: Live-In Superintendents Create Basement Sanctuaries
description: As many New York City apartment dwellers know, some live-in superintendents love to decorate the basements of their buildings. Whether this urge to adorn stems from a proprietary sensibility  whats near the boiler room is mine!  or is simply the result of too many personal knickknacks spilling out of tiny living spaces, the super cave, with its birds, potted plants and blinking religious icons, is a phenomenon you have surely seen before.

title: Standstill on Farm Bill May Revive 1949 Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Pressure is mounting on lawmakers working on a farm bill to come up with a deal before the end of the month, when the Agriculture Department is to begin enforcing a series of decades-old laws that could cause the price of milk and other agricultural products to double.

title: Eating Pigs Head (Terrine), Talking Nascar
description: If you are ever looking for the worlds best airport food court, you could do worse than to visit the Gotham West Market, the blocklong complex that opened on 11th Avenue by 44th Street in November. There youll find high-end branded ramen, upmarket coffee, a kiosk named for the borough of Brooklyn and another named for one of the boroughs streets, where workers and other slurpers from the Far West Side circulate in predatory patterns through the cavernous, music-filled mall or take their places at counters or communal tables. The market joins Eataly and the Todd English Food Hall at the Plaza Hotel in making culinary New York more amenable to people who  no names, please  cant make up their minds about where to eat. Next up are food courts in Battery Park City and Hudson Yards, and a proposed food mall by Anthony Bourdain.

title: Video: Papua New Guinea, Where Violence Can Seem Like the Norm for Women
description: Papua New Guinea, a developing country of seven million people with a growing market in the mining of natural resources, is one of the most violent places in the world for women, according to the United Nations. In the countrys remote Highlands, the Australian government found that nearly every woman has experienced some form of physical violence, including sexual violence. After decades of abuse from her husband, Agnes, who is now living in a safe house said: I thought that that was normal for a woman to be beaten by her husband. I never thought it wasnt right.

title: Unusual Chrysler Fix for Jeep Fires Wins Approval
description: Chrysler can go ahead with an unusual recall plan affecting 1.6 million Jeeps, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said late Friday. The plan involves the use of a trailer hitch intended for towing to reduce the danger of gas tank fires in rear-impact crashes.

title: Child Rape in Kenya
description: To the Editor:

title: More Details in Mistaken Landing of a Plane
description: Federal investigators said that the pilots of a Southwest Airlines flight that landed at the wrong airport this week realized their mistake only after they were on the runway, forcing them to brake heavily to bring the plane to a stop.

title: Defendant Admits Sending Letter With Ricin to Obama
description: More than nine months after he mailed ricin-laced letters to public officials as part of a brazen and unconventional plot to incriminate a longtime adversary, a Mississippi man pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that were likely to send him to prison for decades.

title: Yahoos No. 2 Executive Made More Than His Boss (and Virtually Everyone Else)
description: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | Clarified that Mr. de Castro has not responded to requests for comment on his departure.

title: Sanctions Eased, Iran Gets Feelers From Old Trading Partners
description: TEHRAN  For critics of the interim nuclear agreement with Iran, Hossein Sheikholeslami might seem to embody their worst fears.

title: Typography Partners Part Ways in Money Fight
description: Tobias Frere-Jones and Jonathan Hoefler are the closest thing to superstars in the arcane world of typography. Their renowned studio has created fonts for Fortune 500 companies and reaped numerous design honors. A signature typeface, Gotham, originally created for GQ Magazine, gave Barack Obamas hope and change presidential campaign its distinctive look.

title: The Source | Tilda Swinton in Conversation With Doug Aitken
description: The thing that keeps me being a performer, Tilda Swinton says, is my interest in societys obsession with identity. Swinton, who will appear in the upcoming Wes Anderson film, The Grand Budapest Hotel, and is known for her roles in I Am Love, Michael Clayton and Adaptation, talks to the artist Doug Aitken about what drives her as an actress. (She appeared in the 2007 Aitken film installation Sleepwalkers.) The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: The Forgotten Virtues of Tammany Hall
