Since the late 1970s real wages for the bottom half of the work force have stagnated or fallen, while the incomes of the top 1 percent have nearly quadrupled (and the incomes of the top 0.1 percent have risen even more). While we can and should have a serious debate about what to do about this situation, the simple fact  American capitalism as currently constituted is undermining the foundations of middle-class society  shouldnt be up for argument.

title: Crowded Out of Ivory Tower, Adjuncts See a Life Less Lofty
description: His students call him Prof, and in the classroom James D. Hoff looks like any other English professor, circulating among the undergraduates and urging them to recite, savor and interrogate the texts of writers as varied as James Baldwin, Stephen Crane and the Beat poets.

title: Egypt Says Twitter Post by Liberal Was Crime
description: CAIRO  A prosecutor on Sunday charged one of Egypts most prominent liberal intellectuals with insulting the judiciary because he posted a message on Twitter criticizing a court ruling against three American nonprofits that promote democracy.

title: Tortorellas Temper Lands Him in Trouble Again
description: John Tortorella had kept his temper in check remarkably well this season, but in an explosion of fury Saturday night, his inability to ignore provocation got the better of him. Now Tortorella, the Vancouver coach, almost certainly faces a substantial fine and may be suspended.

title: When Children Become Criminals
description: New York is one of two states, the other being North Carolina, in which 16-year-olds are automatically tried as adults. This is the case despite overwhelming evidence that sending children into adult courts, rather than the juvenile justice system, needlessly destroys lives and further endangers the public by turning nonviolent youngsters into hardened criminals.

title: Dangerous Inaction by the Election Commission
description: For all its signature dysfunction, the Federal Election Commission has a staff of professionals working to track big money and shady behavior in the nations congressional and presidential campaigns.

title: Undefeated Connecticut Leaves No Doubts at Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  C. Vivian Stringer, the womens basketball coach at Rutgers, appeared on the video scoreboard before Sundays game against Connecticut in a film clip intended to stoke her players and the announced 6,480 fans at Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: A-Rods Drug Testing
description: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez took testosterone lozenges before games. He applied testosterone cream every evening and injected H.G.H. regularly. And yet he never failed a drug test. Evidence that he broke antidoping rules surfaced through other channels. In January 2013, The Miami New Times linked a rejuvenation clinic  Biogenesis of America  to Rodriguez and other players, putting in motion an investigation by Major League Baseball, which culminated in a 162-game suspension for Rodriguez and an official report, released last week, detailing his regimen.

title: Arkansas Towns New Owner Has Visions of Its Renaissance
description: WILSON, Ark.  The little farm towns here in Delta cotton country spin by, each rusting grain silo and boarded-up discount store fading into the next.

title: Whats Happening With the Air Force?
description: If the Air Force cheating scandal disclosed last week were a singular event, it would be easier to accept Pentagon assurances that Americas nuclear deterrence and military readiness have not been compromised. But it is the latest in a series of breaches that have raised alarms about discipline and competency in the Air Force.

title: An Attack on Westerners Helps Bridge a Divide in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  His suicide vest packed with steel pellets the size of musket balls, the Taliban bomber walked down the potholed street to the entrance of the Taverna du Liban. Behind the thin steel door, in a small guardroom, three men huddled for warmth from the cold Kabul winter.

title: U.S. Snowboarding Olympians Include Siblings
description: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif.  Arielle Gold began snowboarding at age 7 to be more like Taylor, her older brother. These days, Arielle, 17, and Taylor, 20, spend much of their summers training together in the gym and their winters riding together, pushing each other to be better.

title: Publisher Struggles in Chase for Growth
description: Timing matters when it comes to news. I had been reading about Aaron Kushners audacious strategy to invest in journalism ever since he bought The Orange County Register in 2012 for about $50 million and the assumption of $110 million in pension obligations. After years of covering layoffs, I wanted to write a different kind of tale about newspapers.

title: Juveniles Facing Lifelong Terms Despite Rulings
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  In decisions widely hailed as milestones, the United States Supreme Court in 2010 and 2012 acted to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, accepting the argument that children, even those who are convicted of murder, are less culpable than adults and usually deserve a chance at redemption.

title: For Super Bowl Jet-and-Helicopter Set, Urging Buses and Rail
description: It can seem like an impossible math problem, packed with variables that include the reliability of famously fussy rail systems, conditions at the regions oldest operating airport and the whims of Mother Nature in the dead of winter.

title: U.N. Invites Iran to Syria Talks, Raising Objections From the U.S.
description: The announcement by Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, that he had invited Iran to a peace conference to end the war in Syria drew strong objections on Sunday from American officials, who suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending and that the invitation might need to be withdrawn.

title: Nonprofit Clinic Offers Bridges of Health to Philadelphias Illegal Immigrants
description: PHILADELPHIA  Like many other immigrants, Mery Martinez has no legal status in the United States, no health insurance and no money.

title: Influence in Paradise: An Annotated Tour
description: Lawmakers from Washington travel to resorts across the United States for multiday fund-raising events that often mix business and pleasure.

title: On Downton Abbey': the First Black Character Makes an Appearance
description: While it was shocking and sad to see such a likable character as Anna suffer, the fact is that women  in those days and even today in many parts of the world  were subjected to this horrible crime as well as the shame and long-term damage in its aftermath.  The show took a unique opportunity to portray an important reality and I thought it was done appropriately.  Steven Feinstein, Massachusetts

title: An Unsung Hero of Civil Rights
description: This year America will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, a candidate for the greatest legislative accomplishment of the last century. We will recall the presidents who launched (J.F.K.) and landed (L.B.J.) this profound if incomplete attempt to repair the damage racism had done to our democracy and our humanity. We will esteem the leaders and martyrs of the movement that forced the issue onto our national conscience, including the man we honor on this holiday. We will recall, too, the Southern Democrats who stood  and stalled  in defense of segregation, and the Republicans who later capitalized on the outcome with a cynical appeal to white resentment. We will lament the current attempts by several states, with the Supreme Courts blessing, to roll back the basic franchise promised in the Civil Rights Act (and reinforced by the Voting Rights Act the following year). And we will probably invoke the legacy of this great law many times as we debate the status of millions of undocumented residents and the rights of gay Americans.

title: A Loophole Allows Lawmakers to Reel In Trips and Donations
description: VAIL, Colo.  After some time in the hot tub, an evening cocktail reception and a two-and-a-half-hour dinner in a private dining room named Out of Bounds, Representative Adrian Smith, Republican of Nebraska, made one last stop, visiting the lounge at the Four Seasons Resort hotel here to spend more time with the lobbyists and other donors who had jetted in from Washington, D.C., to join him for the weekend getaway.

title: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
description: BAGHDAD  At a command center in western Anbar Province, Iraqi military officials are handing out guns and cash to local Sunni tribal fighters who are battling militants for control of Iraqs largest province.

title: Lucrative Getaways
description: Here is a look at some fund-raising events that lawmakers hosted, often far from their home states. The charges represent the hotel and meal costs that lawmakers or their leadership PACs paid.

title: Tijuana Airport Parking, Just Over the Border
description: SAN DIEGO  In the barren Southwest, a good portion of the 1,900-mile border between the United States and Mexico is being fortified with walls, electronic surveillance and trenches.

title: A New Character, and a New Crazy,  on Girls
description: All right! Theres a new girl on the block!

title: Common Gripes Greet Common Man Party, Now Running Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  You could hardly blame Arvind Kejriwal, Delhis new chief executive, for looking dour as he drove to work this week, barely 20 days after his anticorruption Aam Aadmi, or Common Man, party upended Indian politics and took control of one of the worlds most populous cities.

title: The Significance of Winning One for Welker
description: DENVER  Wes Welker gave a speech. Then he sent a message, the contents of which were unavoidably mixed.

title: For Christie and MSNBC, a Messy Divorce Plays Out in Public View
description: It was a match made in moderately minded Northeast Corridor heaven.

title: Corrections: January 20, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Community Center Honoring 2 Slain Nuns, Forced Out of Its Home
description: Faith demands sacrifice. Maura Clarke and Ita Ford, two Maryknoll nuns, understood that when they went to work among the poor in Central America. The Cold War turned white-hot in El Salvador when they, along with Jean Donovan and Sister Dorothy Kazel, were raped, tortured and murdered by the Salvadoran military on December 2, 1980.

title: Thunderous Defense and Crowd Lift Seahawks to Super Bowl
description: SEATTLE  It was loud, so, so loud at CenturyLink Field on Sunday. The press box shook and the crowd rumbled and heaved and Pete Carroll, the Seahawks coach, paced the sideline raising his arms, pleading the crowd for more, more, more.

title: Building Toward the Home of Tomorrow
description: The home of the future  complete with helper bots and automated appliances  has long been the stuff of science fiction. The tech world is determined to make it a reality.

title: Surging Rangers Overwhelm Capitals
description: The Rangers are on a roll. With Henrik Lundqvist stopping pucks with aplomb and multiple goals from Rick Nash, the team is skating with as much confidence as it has displayed all season.

title: China Reports Cooling Down of Economy
description: HONG KONG  Chinas economy expanded 7.7 percent in the final three months of 2013, compared with a year earlier, underlining that the worlds second-largest economy has continued to lose the supercharged momentum of recent decades.

title: A Colossal Bridge Will Rise Across the Hudson
description: David Capobianco was a toddler in 1964 when the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge slowly soared over his neighborhood of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and tethered it to Staten Island. As he grew up, the improbable notion of assembling something so big and of such gossamer design propelled him to become a civil engineer.

title: Lady Liberty and Love
description: Dear Diary:

title: Governor Tells Donors: Come See Me Next Year
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told top Republican donors on Sunday that his presidential ambitions were on hold until next year, amid a widening state investigation into a bridge closing ordered by his aides, and further allegations that he has bullied local officials.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 12-18
description: Often at sports events, the mix of action, location, light and atmospherics can create hypnotic visuals that complement the lure of competition.

title: Debate on Photo Retouching Flares Online, With Roles Reversed
description: Last week, two publications that consider themselves champions of women faced off  with an unexpected outcome.

title: Tappan Zee Bridge Opens for Business in 1955
description: A December 1955 article in The New York Times on the opening of the Tappan Zee bridge.

title: Bryan Brothers Upset in Australian Open
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The top-seeded American team of Bob and Mike Bryan fell with surprising speed, 7-6 (9), 6-4 in 78 minutes, in the third round of mens doubles to an unheralded pair, Eric Butorac of Boston and Raven Klaasen of Cape Town.

title: The Weeks Mens College Basketball Games to Watch
description: TEXAS A&M at No. 14 KENTUCKY

title: The Limits of Marriage as a Path Out of Poverty
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Coming a Long Way on Smoking, With a Way to Go
description: Fifty years ago this month, Dr. Luther L. Terry issued the first Surgeon Generals Report on Smoking and Health, which cited smoking as a cause of lung cancer in men. The hefty report landed like a bombshell on a complacent public, bombarded daily by tobacco advertising and surrounded at work, home and play by people who smoked.

title: U.S. Attorney Said to Meet With Hoboken Mayor
description: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., Dawn Zimmer, said that she met on Sunday afternoon with federal prosecutors who are investigating her allegation that Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno threatened to withhold federal funds that could have helped her city recover from Hurricane Sandy.

title: Cuomos Budget Is Said to Include Ethics and Campaign Finance Reforms
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to prod recalcitrant lawmakers to take action after a rash of embarrassing corruption scandals in Albany, plans to use his budget proposal this week to push for approval of new ethics laws and a public financing system for state political campaigns, administration officials said.

title: Swindlers Use Telephones, With Internets Tactics
description: SEATTLE  Phone swindles are practically as old as the telephone itself. But new technology has led to an onslaught of Internet-inspired fraud tactics that try to use telephone calls to dupe millions of people or to overwhelm switchboards for essential public services, causing deep concern among law enforcement and other groups.

title: Lynchs Third-Quarter Blast Breaks Pacific Northwest Logjam
description: SEATTLE  The showdown between Beast Mode and the Inconvenient Truth, the nicknames for Marshawn Lynch and Frank Gore, the star running backs of the Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers, was one of many subplots expected to emerge from the N.F.C. championship game.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 20, 2014
description: Fake emails are usually pretty easy to spot because you can look and see if it came from Bank of America or from FreeEmailAddressInEgypt.com. With the phone, you dont have that option of researching.

title: In New Country, Mother Sacrifices Precious Family Time to Pay Bills
description: Antonia Caba did not have any tissues so she used a paper towel to dab away her tears, taking care not to smudge her meticulously applied makeup as she described how she had tried to provide for her children in this new country.

title: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
description: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.

title: Sharapova Follows Williams Out the Door
description: One day after the heavy favorite Serena Williams lost to Ana Ivanovic, another multiple Grand Slam champion crashed out in the fourth round at the Australian Open.

title: With Universitys Help, New Park on Harlem River Is a Marshland Sanctuary
description: Muscota means place in the reeds in the language of the Lenape, Manhattans original Native American inhabitants, and a new park that opened quietly in mid-January at the northern tip of the island appropriately bears the name.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 19, 2014
Citing Costs, N.H.L. Injury Study Urges More Safety
description: An author of a new medical study said the high cost of paying injured N.H.L. players should push the league to stiffen what he described as inadequate measures to prevent brain trauma, including rules that still allow fighting.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8:10 A.M. (Starz) CHARLIE BARTLETT (2008) After being kicked out of private school for making fake IDs, Charlie (Anton Yelchin, above) goes the public route, arriving at a high school in a chauffeured limousine, wearing a navy blazer with a Latin insignia and toting a briefcase. An instant pariah, he discovers a road to popularity paved with prescription drugs. Soon, he has become a sort of therapist, dispensing advice and medication to classmates. Hope Davis plays his flaky, depressed mother; Robert Downey Jr. is the high schools alcoholic principal, whose relationship with Charlie turns into warfare, once he learns that Charlie is dating his rebellious daughter (Kat Dennings). In the movies funniest scene, Charlie and his business partner, Murphy, the school bully who beat him up and dunked his head in the toilet when he first arrived, dispense Ritalin to the students and turn a dance into a frenzied free-for-all with bare-breasted girls running down the halls, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The movie, directed by Jon Poll from a screenplay by Gustin Nash, is never more amusingly subversive than in this scene, which suggests the hypocrisy of American attitudes toward drugs without putting it in words. Still, he said, as the movie dashes from one base to the next, it never coalesces into the character-driven, serious comedy with heart that you want it be.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Martin Luther Kings Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Juan Gelman, Argentine Poet Who Challenged Junta, Dies at 83
description: Juan Gelman, an Argentine poet who challenged the petty and profound tyrannies of his countrys military junta  including those directed against his family  in works that established him as a formidable presence in the Spanish-language literary canon, died on Tuesday at his home in Mexico City, where he had lived for many years. He was 83.

title: Dr. Donald Morton Dies at 79; Melanoma Expert Pioneered a Cancer Technique
description: Dr. Donald L. Morton, a son of an Appalachian coal miner who gained renown as a surgeon for helping to develop a widely used technique for detecting and treating certain kinds of cancer, died on Jan. 10 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Defense Becomes Issue as Warriors Try to Keep Pace
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Popular Demand
description: Album sales declined again this year. Total sales, a figure that includes CDs, cassettes, digital albums and LPs, fell 8 percent from 2012 to 2013, to 289 million.

title: Gravity and 12 Years in Unprecedented Tie for Producers Guild Award
description: LOS ANGELES  In an indication of how highly competitive this year is for film, the Producers Guild of America announced a tie for its best feature award on Sunday. Gravity and 12 Years a Slave both took the top honors, the first time there has been a tie for the award. The producers prize is considered a good forecaster for the eventual Oscar best picture winner; the two prizes have matched up for the last six years.

title: China Growth Figures Show Rapidly Narrowing Gap With U.S. Economy
description: Chinas economic growth figures released Monday morning may show a slowdown, but they still indicate that China is growing almost four times as fast as the United States in dollar terms, rapidly closing the gap in the size of the two countries economies.

title: Work on New Chinese Aircraft Carrier Reportedly Underway
description: A senior Communist Party official in northeastern China said that China was at work on a home-built aircraft carrier and had plans to operate a fleet of at least four of the vessels, a Hong Kong newspaper reported.

title: A Conversation With: Anthropologist Mukulika Banerjee
description: Voting in elections is considered sacrosanct by a large majority of Indians, Mukulika Banerjee writes in the introduction to her new book, Why India Votes. That observation forms the backbone of the anthropology professors work, an ethnographic study of 12 sites in India during the 2009 general elections, which explores the motivations and opinions of Indian voters on a range of issues related to the electoral process.

title: Deutsche Loss Underlines European Economys Dependence on Banks
description: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks  raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

title: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
description: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.

title: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery
description: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Nintendo Shares Recover Slightly After Plunge
description: TOKYO  Nintendo shares plunged on Monday, then recovered much of their losses as investors focused on indications that the company was softening its resistance to mobile video gaming.

title: South Korean Trade Official Abducted in Libyan Capital
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Gunmen have kidnapped a South Korean trade official in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, according to the South Korean government, which advised its citizens Monday to leave the country.

title: From Chinese Students in Germany, a Technology Promise to the Motherland
description: Illustrating the grip the Communist Party and government try to maintain on overseas Chinese students, researchers and businesspeople, an exchange of letters between President Xi Jinping and Chinese students in Germany has produced passionate promises from the students to serve the motherland  and deliver advanced technology back to China, the state news media reported.

title: The Photographer and His Printer, Partners in Art and Love
description: Leonard Freeds photos from Harlem, Brooklyn and the historic 1963 March on Washington lay on a workroom table in the home he shared with his wife, Brigitte. She stood over the images  as she has over his reputation  with a slight smile of pride.

title: Celebrating Martin Luther Kings Birthday
description: Like most schools across the United States, were off today in observance of the life and legacy of Martin Luther King. The weekly News Quiz will be published on Tuesday, and a new edition of Whats Going On in This Picture? will be available early next Monday.

title: A Conversation With: Jonathan Shainin, Newyorker.com News Editor
description: Jonathan Shainin was the senior editor at The Caravan, an English-language long-form journalism magazine, for three years before leaving India in October to become the news editor at The New Yorkers website, where he commissions and edits both domestic and international news stories. He sat with India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend to discuss the possibilities and pitfalls of foreign correspondence in India and Indias evolving media landscape.

title: At Versace, Grace Jones Meets Lady Gaga
description: PARIS  It was Lady Gagas ode to Donatella Versace from her Artpop album come to life. The performing artist sat front row, her waterfall of blond hair looking so like her designer mentors that the two might have been soul sisters.

title: Claudio Abbado, an Italian Conductor With a Global Reach, Is Dead at 80
description: Claudio Abbado, a conductor whose refined interpretations of a large symphonic and operatic repertory won him the directorships of several of the worlds most revered musical institutions  including La Scala, the London Symphony Orchestra, the Vienna State Opera and the Berlin Philharmonic  died on Monday at his home in Bologna, Italy. He was 80.

title: Saint Laurents Rock Kids Grow Up
description: PARIS  As Salma Hayek walked into the Saint Laurent mens show wearing a feminized black tuxedo that traced her curves, she looked like a poster girl for the companys rebirth.

title: Majority of New York Voters Say They Would Re-elect Cuomo, Poll Finds
description: With his re-election campaign looming, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has enviable approval ratings from New York voters and general support for many of his newest proposals, including legalizing medical marijuana, according to a new poll released on Monday. But his specific plan for the drug  to use an obscure law, and not new action by the State Legislature, to provide it to patients  is much less popular.

title: Suicide Blast in Pakistan Kills at Least 13
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber struck Monday morning near the Pakistani militarys general headquarters in Rawalpindi, killing at least 13 people, including six soldiers, officials said.

title: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery for $5.8 Billion
description: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Blinkx Founder to Join Venture Firm Balderton Capital
description: LONDON  Suranga Chandratillake, the founder of the British Internet media company Blinkx, is joining the European venture capital firm Balderton Capital.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Emily Bazelon on Anonymouss Brand of Vigilante Justice
description: Emily Bazelon, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about efforts by Anonymous, the online collective, to push law enforcement to reopen rape cases that they believe have been mishandled. Bazelon, who is the Truman Capote Fellow for Creative Writing and Law at Yale Law School, is the author of Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy.

title: Temporary Nuclear Deal With Iran Takes Effect
description: The first orchestrated rollback in Western antinuclear economic sanctions against Iran took effect on Monday under Tehrans temporary agreement with world powers, as all sides reported that the steps initially promised had been fulfilled.

title: In Letter, Former Premier Denies Using Office for Personal Gain
description: In a letter to a Hong Kong newspaper columnist, former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said he had a clean conscience about his time in office.

title: British Financial Services Sector Optimistic, Survey Finds
description: LONDON  Financial services firms in Britain are increasingly optimistic about the business environment heading into the first quarter and are prepared to add as many as 15,000 new jobs in the quarter, according to a survey released on Monday.

title: A Trophy Hunt Thats Good for Rhinos
description: Lets stipulate up front that there is no great sport in hunting a black rhinoceros, especially not in Namibias open countryside. The first morning we went out tracking in the northern desert there, we nosed around in vehicles for several hours until our guides spotted a rhino a half mile off. Then we hiked quietly up into a high valley. There, a rhino mom with two huge horns stood calmly in front of us next to her calf, as if triceratops had come back to life, at a distance of 200 yards. We shot them, relentlessly, with our cameras.

title: Venezuela May Meet New Reality, and New Price, at the Pump
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela has the worlds cheapest gasoline, about 6 cents a gallon, a price so low that drivers often fill their tanks for less than a dollar and tip the gas station attendant more than the cost of the fuel pumped into their cars.

title: Police and Protesters in Ukraine Escalate Use of Force
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The catapult that went up on a central street of this city on Monday was a clear sign that the protests that have been going on here for more than two months were taking a darker turn.

title: 3-D Printing Moves Closer to the Mainstream
description: You know that inkjet printer sitting under your desk? The one with the old, crusty ink cartridges that are collecting dust because you no longer use it? Well, you can move it aside now and buy a fancy, new 3-D printer.

title: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
description: WASHINGTON  American and other Western diplomats on Monday managed to salvage the long-awaited peace conference on Syria, which had seemed on the verge of unraveling before it even began when Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, issued an unexpected invitation to Iran to attend.

title: Daily Report: Closing In on the Internet-Enabled Home
description: The concept of outfitting everyday objects  from garden products to bathroom fixtures  with sensors and connecting them to the web, often called the Internet of Things, has been brewing for several years. But the announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market, Jenna Wortham reports.

title: Federers Revival Faces Crucible, Starting With Murray in Quarterfinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  New racket, new coach, old Federer.

title: Pel Backs Frenchman for FIFA Presidency
description: LONDON  When Jrme Champagne announced Monday that he would run for the presidency of FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, few outside the world of soccer administration had heard his name before. But Champagne, a former diplomat and FIFA adviser, can count on the backing of someone with a much more recognized name: Pel.

title: A Conversation With: Author Antony Beevor
description: Since 1998, the British military historian Antony Beevor has written six books on the Second World War Crete, Berlin, Stalingrad, D-Day, Paris and The Second World War,  in which he re-creates the military strategies and the on-the-ground military conflict. At the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend, Mr. Beevor talked to India Ink about how he wrote his 2012 book, The Second World War, the treatment of the conflicts gruesome aspects and why the war still interests readers.

title: Electra Partners to Take Majority Stake in British Shoemaker
description: LONDON  The British private equity firm Electra Partners said on Monday that its funds would take a majority stake in the British shoemaker Hotter Shoes.

title: After the Times Redesign, Complaints and Changes
description: Ive seldom had as much response to any post as to one earlier this month  from the first day of the redesign of The Timess website: about 1,000 comments on this blog, in addition to hundreds of emails to my office.

title: Missionary Jailed in North Korea Asks U.S. to Help Free Him
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A Korean-American missionary who has been jailed in North Korea for more than a year appeared at a news conference in Pyongyang on Monday and appealed to the United States government to negotiate with Pyongyang to secure his release.

title: In Paris, Schiaparelli Returns to Couture
description: PARIS  I loved the trousers, Carla Bruni said in her seductive whisper as she hitched up her jeans, referring to pajamas patterned with miniature tribal warriors. It was an outfit from Schiaparelli, reintroduced as a couture house on Monday after a 60-year hiatus.

title: Woman Chosen to Lead Central African Republic Out of Mayhem
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  Cheers broke out in the National Assembly building here on Monday as representatives chose the mayor of this beleaguered capital to serve as the interim president of the Central African Republic, a country in the grip of a sectarian civil war.

title: Bike Trips With a Boost
description: If the thought of cycling in the Alps or even keeping up with your more buff partner in the rolling hills of Tuscany exhausts you, consider taking an electric bike, newly offered by the Britain-based outfitter Inntravel.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Dior Homme Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: In Our Pages: January 21
description: 1939: Trans-Atlantic Flights To Start

title: Roasted Cauliflower Gratin With Tomatoes and Goat Cheese
description: Roasting is one of my favorite ways to prepare cauliflower, and I have always loved preparations that pair the vegetable with coriander seeds. I use coriander seeds and cinnamon to season the tomato sauce that I toss with the roasted cauliflower and sauted red onions, then add a couple of eggs beaten with goat cheese.

title: Potato and Sorrel Gratin
description: When a friend offered me sorrel from her garden I accepted gladly. I love the tangy flavor of this green leafy vegetable and will always buy it if I see it in my farmers market. You dont need much to contribute lots of lemony flavor and vitamins C, A, iron, calcium and magnesium. The gratin is not a typical creamy sliced potato gratin; its more like a potato pie. I cook the potatoes first, then slice or dice and toss with the wilted sorrel, eggs, milk and cheese.

title: Roasted Eggplant and Red Pepper Gratin
description: Roasting eggplant requires less oil than frying. It is important to let the roasted eggplant and roasted peppers drain in a strainer, otherwise the gratin will be watery. I recommend roasting the vegetables several hours or a day before you wish to make this. Adding cooked rice to the mixture will result in a firmer gratin.

title: Fennel, Kale and Rice Gratin
description: I like the contrast of pale and dark green in this gratin, and the sweet anisy fennel flavor against the more intense cruciferous flavor of the kale.

title: Roasted Squash and Red Onion Gratin With Quinoa
description: I have given you several winter squash gratins over the years; this is my favorite to date, because of the sweet layer of flavor of the roasted squash and the texture of the black quinoa.

title: A Queen Bees Secret, Pinpointed
description: In the highly organized colonies of bees, wasps and ants, the queen has a monopoly on breeding; workers do not reproduce when a fertile queen is present. Just how she accomplishes that has been something of a mystery. Previous studies have shown that queens use chemical signals to keep workers sterile, but the few chemicals identified so far did not appear to be related to one another.

title: Screen Actors Guild Awards Red Carpet
description: Stars including Lupita Nyongo in Gucci and Jennifer Lawrence in Dior attended the SAG awards.

title: Three-Piece Suits, Breakfast Meetings, and Overwork
description: No, this isnt more about American Hustle; its a commentary on James Surowieckis interesting piece on the cult of long hours. I dont exactly disagree with his argument, but Id place the emphasis a bit differently.

title: Objectively Pro-Unemployment
description: Jonathan Chait makes a good point about the deficit scolds: whatever they may say, they have in practice played a key role in promoting short-run fiscal austerity and therefore in keeping unemployment high.

title: Interview: June Squibb
description: At the Critics Choice awards, June Squibb speaks with Melena Ryzik about her role in Alexander Paynes black and white film Nebraska.

title: Thom Browne and Donatella Versace Both Put on a Show
description: PARIS  Its somehow fitting that Sunday marked the end of the fall mens shows here in Paris, with Thom Browne among the last to show his collection, as well as the beginning of couture week, with Donatella Versace getting a jump on her fellow designers with a show on Sunday night.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 20
Video: The Roots of Nebraskas Feisty Wife
description: LOS ANGELES  At 84, June Squibb is one of the unlikely ingnues of this Oscar season, lauded for her feisty performance in Alexander Paynes Nebraska. Of course, Ms. Squibb has put the work in, starting with her big break, onstage in Ethel Mermans Gypsy in 1959. Since then, as the Baggers colleague Brooks Barnes writes, Ms. Squibb has kept plugging away and plugging away and plugging away, taking acting classes and auditioning. Though she had worked with Mr. Payne before, she still put herself on tape to play the foul-mouthed Kate, the wife of Bruce Derns sullen patriarch in Nebraska.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Mens Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: In the Matter of Kim Guadagno
description: One of the interesting and bittersweet aspects of the burgeoning Bridgegate-plus scandal in New Jersey has been the centrality of local newspapers. The original story wasnt broken by the crack investigative reporters at the New York Times, or the fake-scandal-chasers at 60 Minutes. It was broken by the transportation reporter of the Bergen Record.

title: The Source | Liz Diller
description: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Liz Diller of Diller Scofidio + Renfro.

title: More Monster and Hats
description: Our challenge this week was suggested by Chris Roat, who calls it one of my favorite puzzles of the year. And Dr. Roat sees a lot of puzzles  hes an active participant in Bay Area puzzle competitions and a longtime Google employee currently up to something top-secret at Google X. His suggestion for this week is a continuation of our recent Andrew Luck Monster Problem. Put on your headgear and get ready for

title: Hyundai to Sponsor Artworks in Turbine Hall at Tate Modern
description: Since 2012, when Unilever stopped funding art installations at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance to the Tate Modern in

title: Lieutenant Governor Calls Hoboken Mayors Claims Illogical
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  The fenced-off piles of rubble at the northern end of this city bear no resemblance to the limestone towers of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. But the connection between the two plots on opposite sides of the Hudson River is at the core of Gov. Chris Christies latest political headache.

title: Taliban Attack Kills G.I. at an Afghan-U.S. Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Behind a truck bomb, Taliban gunmen in military fatigues staged a brazen raid on Monday against a sprawling base shared by American and Afghan forces in southern Afghanistan. Afghan officials said an American soldier was killed in the attack, which took place a few miles from where the Taliban movement was founded nearly 20 years ago.

title: Casting Nebraska Via Radio and Other Producing Secrets
description: LOS ANGELES  June Squibb, an actress for more than 50 years, had to audition on tape to play Bruce Derns feisty wife in Nebraska, but much of the rest of the cast came from wide open calls in the Midwest.

title: Failed Talks With Militants Prompt Many to Flee in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Thousands of residents have fled Falluja in recent days, fearing worsening violence after the failure of negotiations between local leaders and jihadist militants to end a standoff that has lasted weeks, leaders from the city said Monday.

title: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 Couture
description: Paris

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Thom Browne Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Mens Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Oil Industry Nears a Big Asset Sell-Off
description: LONDON  Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it would sell its minority interest in an Australian liquefied natural gas project to the Kuwait Foreign Petroleum Exploration Company for about $1.1 billion.

title: Peugeot Shares Tumble as Capital Plan Comes into Focus
description: PARIS  Shares of PSA Peugeot Citron, the largest French automaker, fell sharply on Monday as the outline of a proposed tie-up with a Chinese partner became clearer.

title: Aam Aadmi Protest Shuts Down Central Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  The heart of Indias capital came to a standstill on Monday after Arvind Kejriwal, the Delhi chief minister, and members of his Aam Aadmi Party squared off with the central government in a public demonstration to demand that the Delhi police should be under state, not federal, control.

title: Some Alluring Sex Ideas For Dolphins in Your Life
description: Isabella Rossellinis fascination with sex makes for an odd, occasionally endearing evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Fishman Space, one that suggests a class by a high school biology teacher who is angling for a suspension. And lecherous types take note: Although the show is about sex, its not at all sexy. If anything, it is likely to cause you to be creeped out by the very thought of such activity any time soon.

title: In Paris, The Start of Summer Couture
description: The couture season opened with drape from Versace, cutouts from Dior and a splash of color from the newly revived house of Schiaparelli.

title: Carnal Carnivals of Song and Dance
description: LONDON  Theres no accounting, it seems, for the unspeakable places a man might be driven by a wayward libido. On my first morning on British soil this month, I opened the newspaper to discover not one but three accounts of eminent entertainment personalities  a soap opera star, a disc jockey, a broadcaster  charged with molesting girls and women. (Roache assaulted me in Coronation Street toilets when I was 14, woman tells court, one headline read.)

title: Sundance: A Food Documentary That Hopes to Start a Movement
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Stephanie Soechtigs Fed Up, as one might guess from the title, is not a cheery little documentary. While not quite delivering a Michael Moore-style vituperation, Ms. Soechtig and her executive producers  among them Katie Couric and Laurie David  make their exasperation extremely clear.

title: Video of New Jersey Lt. Governor Denying Hoboken Mayors Allegation
description: Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno of New Jersey flatly denied allegations made over the weekend that she linked federal aid to support of the Christie administration, as my colleague Alan Feuer reports.

title: Department of Corrections, and Not
description: So Bret Stephens of the WSJ has contacted the Times to protest my remark, in todays column, that his error in using nominal incomes has not been corrected on the WSJs website. I actually anticipated something like this, and saved a copy of his original column as it appeared yesterday, just in case a correction suddenly appeared.

title: Crystal Bridges Museum Buys a Frank Lloyd Wright House
description: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art is fast becoming more than a place to see a historic sweep of paintings by masters like Gilbert Stuart, Asher B. Durand, Norman Rockwell and Andy Warhol. An architecturally historic house will soon be relocated to the museums 120-acre campus in Bentonville, Ark.

title: Delhis Leader Holds Protest Over Police
description: NEW DELHI  This citys most vocal protest leader once again shut down the heart of downtown, snarling traffic for tens of thousands while he and his supporters shouted slogans denouncing police corruption.

title: W.H.O. May Begin Webcast of Health Ministers Meeting
description: The World Health Organization, responding to an angry letter to a British medical journal, says it may soon start streaming its annual meeting of the worlds health ministers on the web.

title: The Source | Liz Diller in Conversation With Doug Aitken
description: We like to take impossible things and actually make them happen, Liz Diller says. A partner at the multidisciplinary architecture firm of Diller Scofidio + Renfro, which has been celebrated for its recent work on the High Line and Lincoln Center, as well as on numerous other projects in New York City and beyond, Diller also discusses being a problem maker and the unique opportunity shes had as an architect to build in her own city. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: The Problem With Science, Civil War Medicine, Inside Thyroid Supplements
description: A new column on science in the raw  data, that is; a historical view of battlefield fallout, as seen through a new collection at the Mtter Museum in Philadelphia; that supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

title: Inside Thyroid Supplements
description: That supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

title: Laws Expanded Medicaid Coverage Brings a Surge in Sign-Ups
description: WELCH, W.Va.  Sharon Mills, a disabled nurse, long depended on other peoples kindness to manage her diabetes. She scrounged free samples from doctors offices, signed up for drug company discounts and asked for money from her parents and friends. Her church often helped, but last month used its charitable funds to help repair other members furnaces.

title: Thyroid Supplements With a Kick
description: Feeling sluggish? Having a hard time getting out of bed in the morning? Gaining weight?

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Saint Laurent Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Mens Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: A Risk in Caring for Abusive Parents
description: Who could condemn someone for staying far away from a parent, even an ailing or dying parent, who mistreated him or her as a child? The last time I wrote about this emotional subject, most readers understood that response. Many who had suffered through similar experiences said they had taken the same stance.

title: Hes Traveling in First Class, but Hell Still Look at Your Recipe
description: SINCE Im in the food and entertainment business, practically all my flights are business-related, flying from Atlanta to either New York City or Los Angeles. I am a pilot and have my own eight-seater Cessna, and when I fly my own plane its spectacular. But there are positives when flying commercial.

title: A Taste of My Own Manners
description: When I started my internship, in 1986, I was given a beeper, which was handed over with a certain sense of ceremony and a certain yoke of obligation. Before cellphones were omnipresent, the beeper was a badge of professional importance: Im a doctor  life and death depend on my instant availability.

title: Airline Hits Sour Notes With the Wait Times on Customer Calls
description: AFTER George Gershwins Rhapsody in Blue was born, it became a classic of the Jazz Age. But if you ask me, it died this month. The cause was overwork. Rhapsody would have been 90 years old on Feb. 12, the anniversary of its first performance in 1924.

title: China Exports Pollution to U.S., Study Finds
description: BEIJING  Filthy emissions from Chinas export industries are carried across the Pacific Ocean and contribute to air pollution in the Western United States, according to a paper published Monday by a prominent American science journal.

title: $28,000 a Night: Hotels Race to Attract Superrich Clientele
description: In most hotels, luxury is measured by the thread count of the linens (minimum 400, please) or the brand of the bathroom toiletries. But for those at the highest end of the market, where the only restraint on consumption is how conspicuous they want to be, a race to the top has broken out, with hotels outdoing one another to serve this tiny, if highly visible, niche.

title: Fighting a Cold
description: Q. Whats the best remedy for a cold?

title: What Does the Producers Tie Mean for the Season?
description: TIE AT THE PGA AWARDS! went the alarm-bell tweet from Kris Tapley, a chronicler of the Oscar race at Hitfixs In Contention blog. Since the news Sunday that 12 Years a Slave and Gravity took home the Producers Guild top prize, awards prognosticators have been busy dissecting what it means for the season.

title: Sundance Q. and A. | Astrid Bergs-Frisbey
description: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Canada Chooses Three Sisters for Its Olympic Skiing Team
description: The Dufour-Lapointe sisters grew up chasing one another down the ski slopes near Montreal, their hometown. But next month they will be chasing one another down the slopes at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as the three sisters  Maxime, Chlo and Justine  will all be members of Canadas freestyle ski team.

title: Yogurt Joins Super Bowl Snack Parade
description: WHO would have thought X Super Bowls ago, or even V, that there could be as many commercials for yogurt during a game as for candy?

title: She. Herself. Naked.': The Art of He Chengyao
description: Wearing only underpants, He Chengyao faces the camera, the long acupuncture needles sticking out of her body making her look somewhat like a human porcupine. The performance art piece, now a video and a photograph, is titled 99 Needles.

title: Texas Company, Alone in U.S., Cashes In on Nuclear Waste
description: ANDREWS, Tex.  Standing at the lip of what might be Americas most valuable hole in the ground, Rodney A. Baltzer cataloged the features that he said would isolate the radioactive waste to be buried here for thousands of years.

title: Paris Couture Week: Atelier Versace Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: For Spot in Artists Loft, Impress a Critic: The City
description: About every other month, an obscure mini-committee of two artists meets behind closed doors at New Yorks Department of Cultural Affairs on Chambers Street. In their hands are stacks of applications from self-described artists seeking formal certification from the city, giving the panel influence over millions of dollars in lucrative real estate deals.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and the Philippines.

title: Familiar Silhouette Is Quick to Dispel Shadow of Doubt
description: TAMPA, Fla.  On the back fields of the Yankees minor league complex Monday, the familiar silhouette of Derek Jeter was suddenly apparent, a sign that spring training could not be far away.

title: The Final Frontiers Financial Limits
description: A decade after swinging into orbit around Saturn, NASAs venerable Cassini spacecraft is still working, well beyond the four years of science the space agency had hoped to get. But the spacecraft is running low on maneuvering fuel, and its managers want to end with a scientific bang  an ambitious agenda that includes 22 orbits through a gap between the planet and its innermost ring before sending the craft on a death plunge into Saturn in 2017.

title: Treat Humans, Too
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: An Outdated Solution
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Costs of Climate Change
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Art Matters | The Mothership Lands in Downtown Los Angeles
description: Currently eight and a half months pregnant with her first child, the artist and curator Carly Jo Morgan has been exploring themes of motherhood since long before her own was imminent. Years ago, she designed a tribal-futurist Mothership collection for her jewelry line, All for the Mountain, that led to a commission from Sonia Rykiel. And recently, she became a certified birth doula. Now Morgan is co-curating a womens art show, called The Mothership, which opened last Thursday at Dilettante, a creative incubator and event space at the edge of the Arts District in Downtown L.A. I started thinking about the idea of a force that is guiding these vessels  these women and artists, explains Morgan, who lives in a cabin in Topanga Canyon, of the shows concept. Being pregnant, I do feel very connected to the divine feminine. But growing a baby is also very sci-fi.

title: Longer Life Span Tied to Energy Use in Primates
description: Most mammals reach adulthood within months and die in their teens or 20s. Not so with humans and other primates, which take years to become adults, then live for decades and reproduce infrequently.

title: Manning Fans Swing Early Betting Line to Favor Broncos
description: LAS VEGAS  Who will win Super Bowl XLVIII? We will know in less than two weeks. Who should be the betting favorite? The oddsmakers and early bettors have differing opinions. Soon after the Seattle Seahawks dispatched the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game, they were made the favorites, by up to 2  points, by a majority of sports books here.

title: Giambattista Valli: Spring 2014 Couture
description: Paris

title: New Truths That Only One Can See
description: Since 1955, The Journal of Irreproducible Results has offered spoofs, parodies, whimsies, burlesques, lampoons and satires about life in the laboratory. Among its greatest hits: Acoustic Oscillations in Jell-O, With and Without Fruit, Subjected to Varying Levels of Stress and Utilizing Infinite Loops to Compute an Approximate Value of Infinity. The good-natured jibes are a backhanded celebration of science. What really goes on in the lab is, by implication, of a loftier, more serious nature.

title: Betting on the Handicappers, Not the Horses
description: Could it be that where mighty HBO failed, the fledgling Esquire Network has succeeded?

title: For Revered Concertmaster, the Start of a Long Goodbye
description: When you have served as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic for 34 years, it is only appropriate that your farewell should be a drawn-out affair. Glenn Dicterow, who will retire from this post in June to take up a teaching position at the University of Southern California, is being celebrated with star billing throughout the Philharmonics season.

title: Extinct Shark Reappears, and Sochi Awaits Snow
description: There is no certainty in science, only knowns and unknowns. Last week, researchers reversed some conventional wisdom about trees. A shark species thought to be extinct turned up in a fish market  48 times. And no one seemed sure how much to fear the chemical spilled into West Virginia drinking water. Just imagine what we wont know next week.

title: Knicks Are Baffled in Blowout Loss to Nets
description: The Nets began to set screens in the games opening minutes, and they never stopped. They set screens at the top of the key. They set screens near the left elbow. They set screens on Raymond Felton and Iman Shumpert, and the Knicks switched and scrambled. They could never figure it out.

title: Bolshois Balanchine, From Stage to Screen
description: Sundays HD broadcast of George Balanchines pure-dance and full-length Jewels, live from the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, was  though by no means without drawbacks  both newsworthy and artistically noteworthy. One historic aspect occurred not in the dancing but at intermission.

title: A Five-Band Countdown to Goodbye
description: Hold on, I just want to Instagram this, a young woman said to her friend as they stepped outside of 285 Kent on Sunday night for some fresh air, then stopped to regard the nondescript exterior of the building.

title: Stark Reminders of How Uncivil a War It Was
description: PHILADELPHIA  More than 40 years after losing his right arm in the Civil War, Henry S. Huidekoper, a lieutenant colonel in the Union Army, had long since adjusted, and no longer found himself trying to reach for things or write with his missing hand.

title: Guggenheim Is to Show Rare Murals by a Futurist
description: As a capstone to its coming show Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe, the Guggenheim Museum has managed a rare coup: securing the first loan of five major Futurist murals from the central post office in Palermo, Sicily, where they have hung since being commissioned for the space in the 1930s.

title: Trying On the Ties That Bind
description: Nothing better than being trapped in a house with your love, right? The extreme intimacy, the disintegration of private space, the presumption of omnipresence  those are the building blocks of a lasting relationship, no?

title: An Attempt to Outdream a Surrealist
description: Kafkaesque has become a strangely fuzzy and elastic adjective. It can be taken to mean anything from the vaguely surreal to the deeply anxiety-inducing, from the psychologically disorienting to the bureaucratically complex  anything that summons any sort of association with such classic Kafka works as The Trial, The Castle or The Metamorphosis.

title: A Great Big World and Linnea Olsson Release Albums
description: A GREAT BIG WORLD

title: Seeing X Chromosomes in a New Light
description: The term X chromosome has an air of mystery to it, and rightly so. It got its name in 1891 from a baffled biologist named Hermann Henking. To investigate the nature of chromosomes, Henking examined cells under a simple microscope. All the chromosomes in the cells came in pairs.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,292 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: IBM Restarts Talks on Low-End Server Business
description: IBM has restarted efforts to sell its low-end server business and is in talks with companies including Dell and Lenovo, two people briefed on the process said Monday.

title: Poets Archive Goes to University of Texas
description: Billy Collins, a former United States poet laureate and the rare poet to send books onto the best-seller list, can now claim another feather in his cap: a sale of his archive to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin, where his papers will sit beside collections of such greats as E. E. Cummings and T. S. Eliot. They include dozens of notebooks containing observations, notes, doodles, clippings and extensive drafts of poems, published and unpublished. There is also wide correspondence, audio and video recordings, childhood writings and diaries. Mr. Collins, 72, said by email that he had decided to sell his papers when he started making a mental pile and realized just how much material there was, including more than a few jottings on cocktail napkins, envelopes and other scraps. I remember one occasion when the lines of a poem occurred to me while I was walking around the city with no pen and nothing to write on, he said. So I ducked into a bank and started writing the poem, standing up, on the backs of deposit slips. I used the bank pen that was attached to a desk with a chain, all of which made for a rather short poem. I tried to look very serious as if I were making a monster deposit.

title: In Performance: Peggy Shaw
description: The Obie-winning performer and writer Peggy Shaw performs a scene from her solo piece Ruff, about her life before and after a stroke. The show is at La MaMa.

title: U.N. Dispute Brings West Bank Differences to the Fore
description: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank  The children roaming the alleys of this Palestinian refugee camp north of Ramallah have been out of school for seven weeks. Food distribution is at a standstill, as are the camps regular health services. This crowded, concrete warren of roughly 15,000 residents is seething with anger.

title: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defectors Photographs Direct Evidence of Assads Killing Machine
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, Jan. 22 | Thousands of post-mortem photographs of scarred, emaciated corpses, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from the security forces of President Bashar al-Assad, appear to offer direct evidence of torture and execution on a mass scale, a team of legal and forensic experts concluded in a report made public on Monday.

title: At Least 2 Die in Omaha After Explosion and Fire
description: OMAHA  At least two people were killed and more than a dozen injured here on Monday after part of a plant that manufactures food supplements for animals collapsed, burst into flames and set off a struggle for survival for those trying to escape the crushing debris.

title: A Popular Chinese Social Networking App Blazes Its Own Path
description: SHANGHAI  Every half-hour or so, Jenny Zhao, young and wired, unlocks her iPhone 5 to connect with friends using Weixin, Chinas wildly popular social messaging app.

title: Deutsche Bank Loss Underlines European Economys Dependence on Banks
description: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks  raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

title: At Midway Point, Sundance Lacks Bidding Wars
description: PARK CITY, Utah  By Monday, the fifth day of the 10-day Sundance Film Festival here, distributors had sampled about 50 films and decided  so far, at least  that none required an instant bidding war and a Brinks truck.

title: Theft of Data Fuels Worries in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A string of senior executives at three credit card companies in South Korea offered to resign on Monday after a huge theft of client data that may have affected 20 million people in this nation of 50 million.

title: Syria: 14 Companies Bid to Destroy Chemical Weapons
description: Fourteen private companies, including four from the United States, have bid for contracts to eradicate 500 tons of chemicals in Syrias munitions stockpile, as well as to destroy the residue from the most dangerous poisons that are to be neutralized at sea, the organization responsible for helping to oversee the elimination of the arsenal said Monday.

title: Boston Feds Latest Role: Community Organizer
description: BOSTON  Economists do not tend to be social activists. And that is especially true if they work for the Federal Reserve, let alone run one of its 12 regional banks.

title: Japan: New Leak Detected at Crippled Reactor
description: Highly radioactive water found in a reactor building at the destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant offers new evidence that the reactors containment vessel was breached during the accident, the plants operator said Monday. The operator, the Tokyo Electric Power Company, said a remote-controlled robot had found water on the floor of the heavily contaminated No. 3 reactor building that was even more radioactive than expected. The high radiation level suggests that the water had leaked from inside the reactor itself, where it would have come in contact with the melted-down fuel core. Nearly three years after the accident, the exact condition of the plants three damaged reactors remains unclear since high radiation levels and flooding make it impossible for workers to inspect them.

title: When One Party Controls the Day
A Globe-Trotting Serial Entrepreneur Finds Roots in Chinas Start-Up Scene
description: Richard Robinson tended bar in the Virgin Islands, taught English in Prague, picked grapes in France, painted houses in Norway and toiled at a BMW factory in Munich. But little prepared him for the adventure that awaited him in Hong Kong.

title: Obstacles on the Road to Mideast Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece: Prison Escapee Vows to Fight Again
description: A leftist Greek guerrilla who walked away from a prison while on furlough this month announced his return to terrorism on Monday. The fugitive, Christodoulos Xiros, did so in an online video and letter, in which he called on comrades of armed action to unite to protest the repercussions of three years of economic austerity in Greece. Once again I have taken the decision to thunder the guerrilla rifle against those who stole our lives and sold our dreams for a profit, the letter said. It was dated Jan. 14 and signed by Mr. Xiros, who described himself as a free member of November 17, once considered Greeces deadliest terrorist organization. Mr. Xiros, 55, was serving multiple life terms at the Korydallos Prison near Athens for a series of attacks carried out by the group, chiefly against Greek, British and American business and political targets over nearly three decades. He has been at large since failing to return from a nine-day furlough that began on Jan. 1.

title: U.S. Plans Naval Backup for Olympics
description: The American militarys European Command is drawing up plans to have two Navy warships in the Black Sea at the time of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next month, should they be needed to evacuate Americans in the event of a terrorist attack or any other emergency, a Pentagon official said Monday. American transport planes would also be on the call in the region. So far, the Pentagon has not put the plans into effect, although that order could come in a matter of days, the official said. The ships are to be passing through the region as part of a regularly scheduled deployment, and the planes would remain at their bases, probably in Europe, until ordered to help. The planning was first reported by CNN on Monday. The State Department would coordinate any evacuation of Americans. Any plans to use the American ships or planes would be done in coordination with and with permission from Russia, American officials said.

title: Cuomo and Attorney General Agree on Division of JPMorgan Funds
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Eric T. Schneiderman, New York States attorney general, have reached an agreement on how to divide a big piece of the $613 million the state received as part of a securities settlement with JPMorgan Chase.

title: Monday Motorsports: Racers Unhappy With a 1-2-3 Finish by Mini at the Dakar Rally
description: Nani Roma of Spain celebrated an anticlimactic and controversial victory in the two-week-long Dakar Rally, which ended Saturday near Valparaso, Chile. Roma had taken the lead in the rally during the first week, but his teammate, Stephane Peterhansel, the 11-time Dakar winner and defending champion, gradually cut Romas lead from 39 minutes to just two minutes by Wednesday. Another teammate, Nassar Al-Attiyah, ran in third place.

title: Treatment for Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan: Study Disputes Stray Dog Numbers
description: Preliminary findings from a survey of Detroits stray dog population estimated that the city has fewer than 3,000 loose dogs on its streets on any given day. The count was made public on Monday by the World Animal Awareness Society, which used volunteers to collect data from around the city last year. It challenges previous reports that as many as 50,000 abandoned dogs live in vacant homes in Detroit. Tom McPhee, the executive director of the survey group, said more attention should be focused on responsible pet ownership.

title: Still Committed to Haiti
School Lockdown Drills
description: To the Editor:

title: Make Legal Memos Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Demand Grows for Hogs That Are Raised Humanely Outdoors
description: SHUSHAN, N.Y.  Turn down the road to Flying Pigs Farm here, and two or three of Michael Yezzis pigs are probably standing in the middle of it.

title: The Obama-Bush Nexus
description: Our current president and his predecessor in the Oval Office are typically cast as opposites, antonyms, not just far apart on an ideological spectrum but cats of wholly different stripes.

title: Notable in Their Absence From Davos
description: The annual parade of boldface names at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is always striking. This years attendees at the meeting, which begins Wednesday, will include Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe; the billionaire Bill Gates; JPMorgan Chases chief executive, Jamie Dimon; and the movie star-philanthropist Matt Damon.

title: Burke and Hardaway Gone, Yet Michigan Rolls On
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  Trey Burkes Michigan homecoming Friday night began with pregame jitters, followed by a lonely walk onto the court and then an early exit to the bench.

title: Scottsdale Classic Car Auctions Total $249 Million, Improving on 2013 Results
description: Scottsdale, Ariz.  The opening sales of the 2014 classic-car auction season, which took place here last week, often set the market direction for the year. This years sales, according to a tally compiled by Hagerty, an insurer of vintage vehicles, totalled $249 million, up from $224 million in 2013 (2,815 lots sold, compared with 2,699 last year). The average sale was $107,096, up from $100,176 a year ago.

title: Canadian Company Behind Bike-Sharing Programs Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian company that designs and builds the bicycles and supporting technology for bike-sharing systems around the world, including those in New York and London, sought bankruptcy protection on Monday.

title: Does Brazil Have the Answer?
description: Not long after I got back from my recent trip to Brazil, I called some economists to gain a better understanding of where the country stood economically. To me, Rio de Janeiro felt a little like Shanghai: there was plenty of high-end shopping in neighborhoods like Ipanema  and plenty of poverty in the favelas, or slums. There was also a lot in between. What is most striking to a visitor is how many middle-class citizens there seem to be. Cars were everywhere; traffic jams, Ive come to believe, are a sign of a growing middle class. It means people have enough money to buy automobiles.

title: A Tragedy on 10th Avenue
description: Firefighters, coming up the same stairwell the victims were using to descend from above, entered the fire floor, and opened the stair doors and the apartment door, sending the smoke up as if through a chimney.

title: Pre-K on the Starting Blocks
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios plan to offer full-day preschool to every New York City 4-year-old hasnt yet rounded the corner from election slogan to classroom reality. But its moving: a public-relations campaign on Friday started blitzing the city with leaflets and emails to drum up support for the tax to pay for it.

title: Manning Is on the Verge of the Sublime
description: DENVER  Peyton Manning may not need another Super Bowl victory to solidify his place in football history, although his lingering detractors might suggest otherwise. But if there is debate about whether Mannings legacy could use a boost, there is no doubt that a defeat of the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl XLVIII will elevate him to an unparalleled position in the game.

title: Counterintuitive Advice When You Hear Fire! in a High-Rise: Stay Put
description: The first clang of the alarm came as many residents of the modern high-rise in Hells Kitchen, Manhattan, were sitting down to brunch or opening the Sunday paper. Quickly came the screams  Fire! and an acrid smoke that blackened windows and seeped under doors and through air vents. Few knew exactly where in the 42-story building the fire was. Some tried and failed to reach 911 operators, who were overwhelmed by calls. Many decided to flee.

title: A Potentially Harmful Merger
description: A proposed merger between two of the largest suppliers of food to restaurants, hotels and school cafeterias could significantly reduce competition and drive up prices of the meals Americans eat outside their homes. Of all the money consumers spend on food, nearly half is spent at restaurants.

title: The Art of Presence
description: Tragedy has twice visited the Woodiwiss family. In 2008, Anna Woodiwiss, then 27, was working for a service organization in Afghanistan. On April 1, she went horseback riding and was thrown, dying from her injuries. In 2013, her younger sister Catherine, then 26, was biking to work from her home in Washington. She was hit by a car and her face was severely smashed up. She has endured and will continue to endure a series of operations. For a time, she breathed and ate through a tube, unable to speak. The recovery is slow.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 20, 2014
Detention Must Be Paid
description: Millions of Americans cant find work and have lost their unemployment benefits because Congressional Republicans insist the government cant afford to help them. But there is no shortage of money when it comes to hunting down unauthorized immigrants.

title: Saratoga Springs Doesnt Need a Casino
description: Early this summer, New Yorkers can expect to see proposals for four new casinos upstate. Some communities in the Catskills and Western New York are ready to welcome these gambling meccas, especially if they come with good jobs, as promised.

title: Otis G. Pike, 92, Dies; Long Island Congressman Took On C.I.A.
description: Otis G. Pike, a longtime congressman from New York who spearheaded an inquiry in the 1970s into accusations that the intelligence establishment had abused its power, died on Monday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 92.

title: How to Compensate Victims of Terrorism
Hollandes Romances Turn Into a Political Spectacle in France
description: PARIS  As a candidate for the French presidency in 2012, Franois Hollande promised to be more boring spouse than flamboyant seducer.

title: An Athlete for Two Seasons Can Double Up on Games
description: With the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, set to begin in less than three weeks, Olympic human interest tales are beginning to pile up almost as fast as security concerns.

title: A Widow Finds Solace in Rescuing Kittens
description: Maureen Brown can tell stories about kittens. Happy stories, sad stories, funny stories.

title: Carroll Addresses the Tension Over Shermans Postgame Actions
description: RENTON, Wash.  Before their game against the Giants on Dec. 15, the Seattle Seahawks stayed at a Westin hotel in Jersey City. That is where the N.F.C. representative will be staying for the Super Bowl, and Coach Pete Carroll wanted his players to get acclimated for their return.

title: Corrections: January 21, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: What This Puzzle Forms
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Looking for your theme in all the usual places? Try again.

title: In New Jersey, Leader of an Agency Under Investigation Is Given a Judges Robe
description: Gov. Chris Christie recently paused in his war over traffic cones, gargantuan traffic jams and accusations of political retribution to nominate a few men as judges on the states Superior Court.

title: 2 Birthdays and 2 Ends of the Income Spectrum
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has pledged to use the remainder of his presidency to address income inequality, which he calls the defining challenge of our time. This holiday weekend, Mr. Obama had an intimate look at how vast wealth disparities in America have become.

title: Elderly Patrons End Dispute With a McDonalds in Queens
description: A group of elderly Korean patrons has reached an agreement with the owner of a McDonalds in Queens to avoid the restaurant during busy lunch hours, ending a dispute over whether they were spending too much time seated at tables drinking coffee.

title: Old Job Is Hurdle for Napolitano on Campuses
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  The choice sounded ingenious: Take a high-profile political figure  a former governor and cabinet member  and have her apply her acumen to the task of rebuilding one of the great public university systems ravaged by decades of eroding state support.

title: Schools Deputy to Run Bank Street College
description: Shael Polakow-Suransky, who helped lead an overhaul of city schools under former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and became an advocate of more rigorous and routine testing, will become the next president of Bank Street College of Education, the school will announce on Tuesday.

title: Super Sunday, and the Crowd Goes, Um, Silent
description: Fans of the Seattle Seahawks collectively call themselves the 12th Man, an extra player with a noise level so pounding at their home stadium that seismologists have recorded minor earthquakes during big plays.

title: Johnsons Versatility Is Driving the Nets
description: The last basket that Joe Johnson sank on Monday afternoon  a wide-open, 27-foot 3-pointer  spurred the first faint Brooklyn chants inside Madison Square Garden as the Nets flagellated the Knicks, 103-80.

title: Parties Seize on Abortion Issues in Midterm Race
description: WASHINGTON  When the Republican National Committee gathers for its winter meeting here on Wednesday, the action will start a few hours late to accommodate anyone who wants to stop first at the March for Life, the annual anti-abortion demonstration on the National Mall. And if they need a lift to the meeting afterward, they can hop on a free shuttle, courtesy of the Republican Party.

title: As Community Mourns, Police Search for Father of 2 Dead Toddlers
description: Deisy Garcia was not just a member of her church, Iglesia Naciones Unidas en Cristo. She was one of its pearls  one of 11 dancers in the group Rosas de Sarn, a team of women who performed five dances eachSunday.

title: For New York Citys First Lady, a Chief of Staff but Still No Defined Role
description: A top aide to the Rev. Al Sharpton will serve as the chief of staff to Mayor Bill de Blasios wife, Chirlane McCray, as the couple finalizes plans for Ms. McCray to take an unusually active role in her husbands administration.

title: Accused of Blurring Facts of Stirring Life Story, Texas Lawmaker Offers Chronology
description: HOUSTON  Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who has shaped her campaign for governor largely around her story of rising from a teenage single mother to a Harvard law graduate, released a chronology of her life on Monday after a Dallas newspaper said that she had blurred some details about her past.

title: Japan Defends Dolphin Hunt After Criticism From U.S. Ambassador
description: HONG KONG  The Japanese government Monday defended the practice of dolphin hunting off its coastline, taking issue with the new American ambassador, Caroline Kennedy, who pointedly criticized its inhumaneness in a recent Twitter post.

title: You Dont Have to Be Jewish to Love a Kosher Prison Meal
description: MIAMI  Captive diners know that a good meal is hard to find.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 21, 2014
description: Is bread and water considered kosher? Just a thought. Just a thought.

title: The Roots of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, Part I
