Reason alone is sufficient to recognize the inviolable value of each single human life, he declared in his recent apostolic exhortation, Evangelii Gaudium, adding: Precisely because this involves the internal consistency of our message about the value of the human person, the church cannot be expected to change her position on this question.I want to explore the possibility, however, that the pope might be open to significant revision of the absolute ban on abortion by asking what happens if we take seriously his claim that reason alone is sufficient to adjudicate this issue. What actually follows regarding abortion once we accept the inviolable value of each single human life? This appeal to rational reflection has been a central feature of the tradition of Catholic moral teaching. I put forward the following reflections in the spirit of this tradition.There is considerable rational basis for moral concern about abortions. In many (probably most) cases, it would be immoral to abort a pregnancy. (Note, however, that this by no means implies that most abortions actually performed are immoral.) Late-term fetuses, for example, are no different biologically or psychologically from babies born prematurely at the same stage of development. Its hard to see how killing a premature baby is immoral but killing an identical late-term fetus isnt. At a minimum, aborting a healthy late-term fetus would, except when the mothers life is at risk, be immoral  which is no doubt why it is seldom, if ever, done.

title: In a Teenage Snake Pit, a Chance to Be Trendy
description: Never in the history of North Gateway High had any student admitted out loud to being an honest-to-goodness, proud or even slightly modest homosexual, including me and my best friend, announces Tanner (Michael J. Willett), the gay teenager who narrates the satirical farce G.B.F. Tanner and his best friend, Brent (Paul Iacono), are classmates in an upscale suburban hotbed of adolescent social warfare that might as well be on Planet Q, for all its resemblance to an actual high school.

title: Sundance Diary | The Sun Sets Early on Park City
description: The 2014 Sundance Film Festival may not be over yet, but with most of its high-profile premieres wrapped up and a large portion of the celebrity contingent already back in their L.A. and New York enclaves, Park City, Utah, certainly has the feel of a circus ready to leave town. The festival, which officially concludes on Sunday, had a strong lineup this year and featured a total of 118 feature-length films from 37 different countries and 54 first-time filmmakers. And while film sales have been relatively quiet  the reported $3 million that Sony Pictures Classics paid for the opening-night film, Whiplash, pales in comparison to the $9.75 million that Fox Searchlight shelled out for The Way, Way Back last year  the creative output has been promising.

title: An Off the Wall Experience at Don Pedro
description: By 11 p.m. on a recent Wednesday, it looked as if Don Pedro was pretty much done for the night. A group of maybe a dozen people were scattered around the place, watching the credits roll on American Horror Story. The bartender took the opportunity to head outside for a smoke. Sitting at a table with drinks and a couple of friends was Joe Kennedy, 24, who moved to New York five months ago from a college town in Missouri. A friend recommended that he check out the place (90 Manhattan Avenue in Brooklyn; there was some debate at the table whether this was East Williamsburg or Bushwick). Mr. Kennedy had been assured that Wednesdays at Don Pedro were off the wall.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 24-30
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Pregnant Teenager Finds Her Way, in Spite of Her Parents
description: Gimme Shelter, written and directed by Ronald Krauss, begins with the familiar based on a true story note and ends with side-by-side photographs of actors from the movie and some of the real-life characters they portray. What comes in between is a crude, earnest parable that uses some of the techniques of indie filmmaking to deliver a culturally conservative message.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 24-30
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Rock & Pop Listings for Jan. 24-30
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 24-30
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Books About Builders, Bootleggers and Bosses
description: Aside from some overlooked plaques in the City Hall subway station and elsewhere, names like Barclay, Hewitt, McDonald, Parsons, Pearson, Sprague, Steinway, even Belmont  much less the Whitney brothers  have been all but forgotten. Doug Most, an editor at The Boston Globe, remedies that oversight in The Race Underground: Boston, New York and the Incredible Rivalry That Built Americas First Subway (St. Martins Press).

title: How Love Survives Altered Expectations
description: Vanetia Casey (Maxine Peake), the plucky, flame-haired central character of Run & Jump, infuses this Irish family drama with a snapping, whooshing electricity. The wife of Conor (Edward MacLiam), a 38-year-old carpenter who was seriously disabled by a stroke, she is a sexy, spirited dynamo who has all she can handle raising their two children while Conor lumbers around the house in a partial fog.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 24-30
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dinesh DSouza Is Charged With Using Straw Donors
description: Dinesh DSouza, a best-selling conservative author and filmmaker, was indicted on Thursday on charges that he used straw donors to illegally donate to a 2012 Senate campaign.

title: A Skylark Who Sang Truth to Power in Argentina
description: Bereaved but resilient, the sound of the monumental Argentine folk singer heard in Rodrigo H. Vilas biographical documentary Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America conveys eons of suffering and survival. You dont have to understand Spanish, Sosas primary language, to be moved by an instrument that expressed the sorrows and hopes of the worlds poor and downtrodden with a profound empathy.

title: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 26 to Feb. 1
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Number of Darfurs Displaced Surged in 2013
description: An estimated 400,000 people fled violence afflicting the Darfur region of Sudan last year, more than the number of those displaced in the previous two years combined, the top United Nations peacekeeping official said Thursday in an appraisal that suggested the decade-old conflict there had taken a turn for the worse.

title: Whos the Bad Guy Here? It Depends
description: Opens on Friday.

title: Starting to Build a Credit History
description: Katie Brown, a 25-year-old horse trainer in Parkland, Fla., had never given much thought to whether she needed to establish credit. With her parents help, she avoided student loans. And she used a checking account and debit card to pay for what she needed.

title: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 26 to Feb. 1
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Lifes Rhythms in Finnish Lapland
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: 70 Years on, Magic Concocted in Exile
description: If you are one of those people who, on looking up at the heavens, wonder whether a sheep on a particular asteroid has eaten a certain flower, or if you already know the foxs solemn secret  Anything essential is invisible to the eyes  then no new incentives will be required to visit the exhibition that opens Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum, The Little Prince: A New York Story. You are already an initiate.

description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tech Companies Fight Back Against Patent Lawsuits
description: The general counsel of Rackspace, a web-hosting company in San Antonio, does not mince words when he discusses patent litigation.

description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Indictment Against Dinesh DSouza
description: Dinesh DSouza, a conservative author and filmmaker, was indicted on charges that he used straw donors to illegally donate to a 2012 Senate campaign.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 24-30
description: Putting It All on the Table (through next Friday) When is candy corn not just a sugary morsel to pop in your mouth? When it is the building block for Caught in a Maize, below, an art piece by Gina Kim focusing on the prominence of corn  good and bad  in our diets. It is among the 24 works by graduate students in the School of Visual Arts Design for Social Innovation Program that are currently on view at the schools Gramercy Gallery, 209 East 23rd Street, Manhattan.

title: Pentagon Study Finds Agencies Ill Equipped to Detect Foreign Nuclear Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  A three-year study by the Pentagon has concluded that American intelligence agencies are not yet organized or fully equipped to detect when foreign powers are developing nuclear weapons or ramping up their existing arsenals, and calls for using some of the same techniques that the National Security Agency has developed against terrorists.

title: Its a Guy Thing
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: More Hearings in New Attempt to Fix Schools
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: The Sun Is Setting, but Dont Let Them Hear You Say That
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: The Holocaust Lives on in a Fractured Family
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Gun Maker Will Limit Sales in Protest of California Law
description: LOS ANGELES  Smith & Wesson, the firearms manufacturer, announcedThursdaythat it would not sell new semiautomatic pistols in California because of its objections to a gun safety law that took effect in the state last May.

title: Bill OReilly to Interview President Obama Before Super Bowl
description: In what has now become a Super Bowl tradition, President Obama will sit for an interview to be broadcast during Foxs pregame coverage on Feb. 2. And for the second time he will speak with Bill OReilly of the Fox News Channel.

title: Michael Sporn, 67, Dies; Film Animator Adapted Beloved Childrens Books
description: Michael Sporn, an animation artist whose award-winning work included film adaptations of beloved childrens books like Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile and Goodnight Moon as well as stories he conceived, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: Speeding Up G.M.s Comeback
description: DETROIT  No matter how much attention she draws as the auto industrys first female chief executive, Mary T. Barra is determined to keep the focus on cars and trucks at General Motors.

title: Greetings, From Around the World
On Moroccan Hill, Villagers Make Stand Against a Mine
description: IMIDER, Morocco  On a hilltop nearly 5,000 feet high in the Atlas Mountains here, a tiny outpost has taken shape over the past two years. The small stone buildings are decorated gaily with graffiti, and there is an open-air gallery. Many doors bear inspirational inscriptions from people like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Mother Teresa. On the dam of a nearby reservoir, someone has painted the face of a local activist, now in jail on what the locals regard as trumped-up charges.

description: For Detroit, a city that has watched a population in free fall, officials have a new antidote: immigrants.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Ads to Help Start Busy Season
description: IN a world where television viewers routinely zip through or zap commercials, advertisers crave big-event television  live events that viewers watch in real time. And the power of those big events is now on display as perhaps never before.

title: Billionaires and Boasts
description: SEATTLE  My city is famous for its retail exports: coffee and Costco, Microsoft and Macklemore, Boeings jetliners and Jeff Bezoss business model. This week, a boast by a man with number 25 on his chest turned all eyes to Seattle. But it should have been the claim by the citys most famous billionaire that got more attention.

title: Hospital Chain Said to Scheme to Inflate Bills
description: Every day the scorecards went up, where they could be seen by all of the hospitals emergency room doctors.

title: Tea Party Donors Exploit Followers, Schumer Says
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Charles E. Schumer on Thursday called on Democrats to try to reduce the Tea Partys political influence by driving a wedge between the movements elite leaders and its middle-income followers who depend on popular government programs like Medicare.

title: Perverse Primaries
description: OBSERVERS of our polarized democracy often blame party primaries for producing some of our most extreme politicians. Its well known that the most vociferous and partisan activists have a disproportionate influence in primaries.

title: The Populist Imperative
description: The outstanding faults of the economic society in which we live are its failure to provide for full employment and its arbitrary and inequitable distribution of wealth and incomes.

title: Politics on the Strip
Mars Rover Marks an Unexpected Anniversary With a Mysterious Discovery
description: Ten years ago, NASAs Opportunity rover bounded to the surface of Mars for what was planned to be a three-month exploration.

title: Progress on Predatory Lending
description: Rules issued in November to stop banks from emulating predatory payday lenders have yielded promising results. The rules, issued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, have led several banks to discontinue deposit advance loans that are specifically designed to trap people in debt. But consumers will remain vulnerable to versions of the debt trap until another agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, issues rules of its own to protect consumers of small loans from excessive and unaffordable costs.

title: Still Surging, Stanislas Wawrinka Reaches Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  More than an hour after Stanislas Wawrinkas match ended, after he had advanced to his first Grand Slam final, he sat down in front of reporters. He was smiling. He kept smiling.

title: Cuban Vendors, in Rare Move, Stage a Protest
description: MEXICO CITY  In a rare demonstration of public dissent, dozens of Cuban artisans and vendors protested in the city of Holgun this week, marching to local government offices and demanding the right to work without government harassment, witnesses said.

title: An Unassuming Liberal Makes a Rapid Ascent to Power Broker
description: Brad Lander, a cerebral and unassuming city councilman from Brooklyn with a degree in anthropology, has abruptly become the sort of person who endlessly fascinates scholars of the modern metropolis: a power broker.

title: Even More Addictive Cigarettes
description: It was a shock to learn from the latest surgeon generals report that, because of changes in the design and composition of cigarettes, smokers today face a higher risk of lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease than smokers in 1964, despite smoking fewer cigarettes. It is equally shocking to learn now that some of todays cigarettes may be more addictive than those smoked in past years, most likely because the manufacturers are designing them to deliver more nicotine to the lungs to induce and sustain addiction. That devious tactic requires a strong response by regulators.

title: Quick Work on Paid Sick Leave
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, swiftly delivering on a campaign promise, joined the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, last week in offering a bill to revise New York Citys law on paid sick leave. Their bill is broader than one that passed last year after much delay and political spatting. Its also better.

title: End the Phone Data Sweeps
description: Once again, a thorough and independent analysis of the governments dragnet surveillance of Americans phone records has found the bulk data collection to be illegal and probably unconstitutional. Just as troubling, the program was found to be virtually useless at stopping terrorism, raising the obvious question: Why does President Obama insist on continuing a costly, legally dubious program when his own appointees repeatedly find that it doesnt work?

title: It Takes a Generation
description: Over the past decade weve had a rich debate on how to expand opportunity for underprivileged children. But weve probably made two mistakes.

title: Industry Awakens to Threat of Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  Coca-Cola has always been more focused on its economic bottom line than on global warming, but when the company lost a lucrative operating license in India because of a serious water shortage there in 2004, things began to change.

title: In Halfpipe and Slopestyle, Freeskiing Challenges Snowboarding
description: David Wise may be the best halfpipe skier in the world. He is a favorite to win a gold medal in the events debut in Sochi, Russia, where it will be compared with the better-known version performed by snowboarders like Shaun White.

title: U.S. Warns Against Business With Iran
description: The Obama administration intensified efforts on Thursday to counter what officials called a misimpression that the six-month nuclear agreement with Iran had opened the door to new economic opportunities with the country, emphasizing that nearly all sanctions remained in force and warning businesses not to engage in any deals still pending after the accords July 20 expiration.

title: Dead Developers Accounts Missing $2 Million
description: As detectives pressed their search for culprits in the kidnapping and killing of a Brooklyn real estate developer this month, filings this week in a bankruptcy case in Brooklyn revealed that nearly $2 million had been improperly removed from accounts in the developers name.

title: Metro-North Grinds to Halt for 2 Hours
description: A power failure at Metro-North Railroads control center at Grand Central Terminal cut service to its three main lines on Thursday night, stranding thousands of passengers across the metropolitan region for nearly two hours and setting off a chaotic scene as the hub swelled with bemused commuters.

title: A Case of Innocence, With Missteps Seemingly at Every Turn
description: It began in September 2005 with a man in a hospital bed, just out of a coma but floating on a lake of morphine for the pain from the bullets he took in the stomach during a push-in robbery. A detective asked the man to check his cellphone records because the robbers had made some calls before he was shot.

title: New York City Sanitation Chief Finds That When It Snows, It Pours
description: John J. Doherty, New York Citys sanitation commissioner, has had better weeks.

title: Scarlett Johanssons SodaStream Endorsement Deal Conflicts With Charity Work, Aid Group Says
description: The international aid and development group Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its own global ambassadors, the actress Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli company that makes products in a settlement built on West Bank territory Israel has occupied since 1967.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 23, 2014
U.S. Olympic Outfits Worthy of Stares, if Not Medals
description: The most passive-aggressive reviews of the United States Olympic teams new gear from Ralph Lauren were probably those directed at Zach Parise by his Minnesota Wild teammates. They stashed dozens of 8-by-10-inch photos of Parise wearing the Olympic teams garish new sweater around the Wilds locker room before he arrived for work Thursday. I got a lot of requests, Parise said with a sheepish smile, from guys who want to get that sweater. The best part of his public  at least on Twitter  humiliation? He may never get another chance to wear the outfit. The United States hockey team will arrive at the Sochi Olympics after the opening ceremony, at which the sweater will make its runway debut, and will depart before the Games end. But since Parises teammates are only amateur critics, The New York Times asked some professionals to weigh in.

title: In Rural Jails, E-Cigarettes Are a Calming Vapor
description: LAFAYETTE, Tenn.  As city governments and schools across the country move to ban or restrict the use of electronic cigarettes, one place increasingly welcomes the devices: the rural county jail.

title: Corrections: January 24, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Weary, Brooding and Made for Each Other
description: The rain pours down in steady streams, shrouding in gloom the Irish countryside of Outside Mullingar, the new play by John Patrick Shanley that opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Gloomy, too, is the talk of lost loves, deaths and other grim subjects dear to the hearts of the Irish, or at least those who populate Broadway stages. As is also regularly the case in plays set there, the reaper will pay a house call before the curtain has fallen.

title: Instruments Played With Mizraabs
description: Administrivial Alert! Because of a production error last Friday, the crossword puzzle that was published in the Jan. 17 print issue, by Ian Livengood, was published in error. The correct puzzle for this date, by Kevin G. Der, appeared online that day. The Livengood puzzle appears online today and the Der puzzle will appear in print. If you would like to join in the Wordplay discussion for the Der puzzle, please click here.

title: Erased Answers on Tests in Philadelphia Lead to a Three-Year Cheating Scandal
description: The first sign that something was wrong appeared more than two years ago when a company grading student tests from Philadelphia noticed that erasures from wrong to right answers showed what investigators delicately called statistical evidence of improbable results.

title: Not Living in the Past, but Going for Visits
description: If youve ever been curious about the motivations of the people who spend their weekends  and sometimes healthy chunks of their lives  participating in meticulous re-enactments of famous Civil War battles, revelations can be found at City Center, where Row After Row, a new play by Jessica Dickey, is being presented by the Womens Project. Ms. Dickeys likable comedy-drama reveals that these hyperactive history buffs are just normal folk like the rest of us, with job troubles, love troubles, life troubles  but with a predictable quirk or two.

title: Soldiers Family Found Dead in Apparent Murder-Suicide
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  An apparent murder-suicide involving the husband and the two children of a soldier who had recently returned froma deployment to Afghanistan is providing a new twist to a persistent problem at the sprawling Fort Hood Army base here.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 24, 2014
description: I look at this as something to control their moods. And so if theyre not a good boy or girl, Im going to take them away, just like I do with the TVs.

title: Samsungs Profit Drops as Apple Squeezes Mobile Sales
description: TOKYO  Samsung Electronics, the largest maker of smartphones, confirmed on Friday that growth in sales and earnings slowed sharply in the fourth quarter of 2013, and the company said business conditions would remain challenging in the first few months of the year.

title: Address May Hint at Compromise on Ways to Fight Inequality
description: WASHINGTON  More than he might have imagined just a month ago, President Obama has an opening with Tuesdays State of the Union address to advance his argument to Congress that the rising inequality of economic opportunities is Americas defining challenge of our time.

title: Legal Marijuana Businesses Should Have Access to Banks, Holder Says
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that lawful marijuana businesses should have access to the American banking system and that the government would soon offer rules to help them gain it. The rules are not expected to give banks a green light to accept deposits and provide other services, but would tell prosecutors not to prioritize cases involving legal marijuana businesses that use banks.

title: Phil Mickelsons Toughness Tested at Hometown Event
description: SAN DIEGO  Phil Mickelson talked on Wednesday about the extra attention he must pay to his diet, his workouts and his health  particularly his psoriatic arthritis  now that he is a golfer of a certain age. On Thursday, he endured five hours of backtalk from his 43-year-old body.

title: Reports of Cheating Prompt Review of U.S. Nuclear Launch Crews
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Thursday ordered an independent review of the militarys nuclear force and summoned top officials to the Pentagon to discuss personnel issues after reports of cheating and low morale among Air Force nuclear launch officers.

title: Missouri Obstructing Health Law, Judge Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A federal district judge declared Thursday that the State of Missouri was illegally obstructing the activities of insurance counselors appointed by the federal government to inform consumers of their options under the Affordable Care Act.

title: De Blasio Urges Mayors to Forge an Urban Consensus
description: WASHINGTON  Bill de Blasio was the mayor of the moment on Thursday.

title: Bargnanis Injury Adds to Knicks Frustration
description: Andrea Bargnani attempted to dunk over two defenders late in the third quarter of Wednesdays game against the Philadelphia 76ers, and it did not go well. Bargnani was fouled and fell about three feet short of the basket, with his left arm absorbing the brunt of the blow.

title: Hoping to Leave Loved Ones With Only Memories, Not Debt
description: Troublesome hearts run in Frank Costanzas family.

title: Colorado: Columbine High Takes Precautions After Threats
description: Columbine High School, where 13 people were killed in a shooting in 1999, was sealed off for several hours on Thursday after receiving three phone threats, school and law enforcement officials said. As the authorities investigated the threats, the suburban Denver school and seven others in the area were put on a lockout for about four hours, meaning that classes continued inside the schools, but outside doors were locked and people were not allowed to enter or leave. Officials with the Jefferson County sheriffs office did not describe the threats, but said they did not appear to be local or credible. School officials said in a Facebook message to parents that all students were safe inside the school. The lockout was lifted about 2 p.m.

title: Rangers Enter Outdoor Series on Down Note
description: The Rangers are headed to Yankee Stadium to play their next two games, but Thursdays match did not end well, a 2-1 loss to the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden.

title: Fined Billions, JPMorgan Chase Will Give Dimon a Raise
description: A year after an embarrassing trading blowup led to millions of dollars being docked from Jamie Dimons paycheck, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase is getting a raise.

title: Chet Curtis, Half of Married News Team Whose Divorce Made News, Dies at 74
description: Chet Curtis, for decades half of a high-wattage husband-and-wife news anchor team in Boston whose personal and professional breakup caused wide distress in the city, died there on Wednesday. He was 74.

title: U.S. Willing to Hold Talks if Snowden Pleads Guilty
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that the United States was willing to discuss how the criminal case against Edward J. Snowden would be handled, but only if Mr. Snowden pleaded guilty first.

title: Japans Leader Compares Strain With China to Germany and Britain in 1914
description: BEIJING  Relations between Asias two biggest powers, Japan and China, have been strained for months, with near-constant sniping over a territorial dispute and the two countries fraught history.

title: Al Qaeda Calls for Rebel Unity in Syria
description: In an audio recording released Thursday, the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, called on Islamist brigades in northern Syria to stop fighting one another, to focus on toppling President Bashar al-Assad and to form an Islamic court to arbitrate disputes. Fifteen days of infighting between rebel brigades and fighters from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which is inspired by Al Qaeda, had killed nearly 1,400 people as of Wednesday, according to a count kept by the opposition Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Mr. Zawahri has little sway over most of the groups fighting in Syria.

title: Deadly Fire at a Nursing Home in Canada
description: Five people were confirmed dead and 30 were missing after a fire destroyed much of a nursing home in LIsle-Verte, Quebec, early Thursday morning. The missing and dead are all believed to be 80 or older, many with limited mobility, and were residents of the home, which is in a village of about 1,400 northeast of the city of Quebec. We can keep a bit of hope, but in reality there seems to have been a considerable loss of life, Prime Minister Stephen Harper said. The fire destroyed the three-story, wooden portion of the home, La Rsidence du Havre, which opened in 1997. A newer wing of the building that was equipped with sprinklers remained standing. Unusually cold weather hampered firefighters and restricted fire investigators.

title: Artist Testifies That a Reproduction of a Famous Work Wasnt Authorized
description: It was not quite a lecture on contemporary art or postmodern sensibility, but in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday, the painter and sculptor Jasper Johns discussed his methodology, corrected a lawyer on the pronunciation of the artist Robert Rauschenbergs name and said, quite firmly, that he had never authorized a foundry owner to reproduce one of his famous works depicting the American flag.

title: New York Citys Jobless Rate Falls to 8.1%
description: New York Citys unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, the lowest it has been in five years, the state Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: The Younger the Child, the More Educational the Screen. Maybe.
description: Two- to 10-year-old children spend about two hours interacting with various screens on an average day. According to a new survey from the Joan Ganz Cooney Center, a nonprofit research institute affiliated with the Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit producer of Sesame Street, and reported on for The Times by Motoko Rich, we parents at least think some of that time is spent on educational games and programming.

title: Ask Well: Stairs and Knee Pain
description: Question:

title: Word of the Day | hermitage
description: hermitage \hr-m-tij\ noun

title: Huckabee Criticizes Required Coverage of Birth Control
description: WASHINGTON  Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas minced no words on Thursday in criticizing requirements that health insurance pay for birth control. The reasoning behind the idea, he said, was that women cannot control their libidos or their reproductive systems without the help of the government.

title: Screen Time Study Finds Education Drop-Off
description: With children spending more time in front of screens than ever, parents sometimes try to convince themselves that playing Angry Birds teaches physics, or that assembling outfits on a shopping app like Polyvore fires creativity.

title: Report on Unrest Is at Odds With Account of Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  The United Nations report this week that rampaging mobs in western Myanmar killed at least four dozen people, mostly Muslims, did more than contradict the governments official stance. It also put a spotlight on the countrys continuing religious and ethnic strife  and what some say is a flawed government response  even as Myanmar tries to burnish its international image.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 11:45 A.M. (Starz) FINDING NEVERLAND (2004) Johnny Depp, in an Oscar-nominated role, portrays J. M. Barrie, the author of Peter Pan, or the Boy Who Wouldnt Grow Up, and Kate Winslet (above, with Mr. Depp) is Sylvia Llewelyn Davies, the widow whose four young sons inspired the masterpiece in this best picture nominee directed by Marc Forster. The problem isnt the liberties the filmmakers take with reality, but that this isnt an engaging bowdlerization, Manhola Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Barrie and Sylvia dont have to tussle like Halle Berry and Billy Bob Thornton in Monsters Ball, Mr. Forsters last feature, but it would have been nice if they trembled once or twice. She added: Only once does Finding Neverland grasp both the writer and his plays dark undertow, when the wonderful Scottish actress Kelly Macdonald, in the role of Peter, realizes that Tinker Bell may die. Rousing all the heartbreak and deep feeling in Barries world, she entreats us to believe and, for one glorious moment, you do.

title: Vanska to Conduct Minnesota Orchestra Concerts
description: There is no word as to whether Osmo Vanska will be returning as music director to help nurse the Minnesota Orchestra back to artistic health now that its 15-month lockout is over, but the orchestra announced on Friday that Mr. Vanska would conduct several concerts this spring.

title: The Journey of Miss Lovely from Cannes to the Censors
description: BANGALORE  For the director Ashim Ahluwalia, Miss Lovely, his movie about the soft-core pornography business in Mumbai, has led to a series of delightful surprises: Last year, it won the award for the best film at the 14th Mumbai International Film Festival, the award for best feature film at the 11th Indian Film Festival of Los Angeles and was included in the Un Certain Regard section at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Investment by Alibaba Creates Frenzy Over Chinese Pharmaceutical Data Firm
description: HONG KONG  Shares in the state-backed company Citic 21CN soared as much as 500 percent in Hong Kong on Friday after it said that the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet behemoth, had acquired a controlling stake in it for 1.3 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $170 million.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Jan. 24, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules
description: In Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules, Michael Paulson writes about a wave of firings and forced resignations of gay men and lesbians from Roman Catholic institutions across the country.

title: Planet Hillary
description: Hillary Clinton was nodding solemnly to the mother of a 9/11 victim when Huma Abedin, standing across the room, called out, Lets load! to the staff members and bodyguards. The former secretary of state had yet to pick up her award from the Voices of September 11th, but her entourage was already preparing to shuttle her off to the next event, a benefit for Gods Love We Deliver, which was co-hosted by the designer Michael Kors and where she would sit next to the Vogue editor and former Obama bundler Anna Wintour. It was just another hectic fall evening in Manhattan for Clinton, and she was keeping herself busy as usual in the is she or isnt she interim. There were paid speeches to give (at $200,000 a pop) to the American Society of Travel Agents and the National Association of Realtors, filled with the wisdom gleaned from being the nations top diplomat (leadership is a team sport was one favorite; you cant win if you dont show up was another). There were awards to receive, like the one from Chatham House, a think tank in London, to which Clinton traveled on a commercial 757 like the one she used to command while working at the State Department. (That was fun! she said of the flight.) And there were Beverly Hills galas to attend, which soon turned into schmooze sessions, like the ones with Harvey Weinstein and Richard Plepler and Jeffrey Katzenberg, yet another major Obama bundler.

title: Do Laws That Ban Offensive Words Make the World a Better Place?
description: Israeli politicians are considering a ban on the word Nazi in any setting except for educational purposes. Backers of the law say they want to combat everything from rising anti-Semitism to teenage trash talk. But should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?

title: Exposing the Legacy of Operation Condor
description: In 1975, six South American military dictatorships conspired to concoct a secret plan to eliminate their left-wing opponents. Not only would the intelligence services of Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay trade information with each other and kidnap, disappear and kill their own domestic foes, they would also cooperate in identifying and killing exiles from partner countries who had taken refuge elsewhere.

title: A New Vionnet
description: Suzy Menkes speaks with Hussein Chalayan and Goga Ashkenazi about the designers first collection for Vionnet.

title: When It Comes to Nymphs and Princes, Water and Earth Dont Mix
description: Dvoraks Rusalka, about a water nymph doomed by her love for a human prince, is a fairy tale. But is it polite and placid, or savage and strange?

title: Times Minute | Jamie Dimon's Raise
description: Also on the Minute, e-cigarettes in county jails and a Carrie Mae Weems retrospective.

title: Defying Economy, Chinese Hit the Road
description: Joe Tsoi Chun-Kin, a 17-year-old student from the southern Chinese city of Dongguan, visits Hong Kong about every two weeks to shop for clothes and other items, spending a few thousand renminbi per trip.

title: Times Minute | Jamie Dimons Raise
description: In the Video

title: New York Today: Waiting Out the Cold
description: Updated, 10:32 a.m.

title: Prolonged Fight Feared in Egypt After Bombings
description: CAIRO  Three years after the start of its revolt for democracy, the capital was shaken Friday by four deadly bombings, in the clearest sign yet that Egypt is entering a prolonged and violent struggle between the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency.

title: North Korea Agrees to Proposal to Resume Family Reunions, Reversing Stance
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Reversing its earlier stance, North Korea on Friday agreed to a South Korean proposal to resume a long-suspended humanitarian program that arranges reunions of elderly relatives separated six decades ago by the Korean War.

title: How Long Have I Got Left?
description: AS soon as the CT scan was done, I began reviewing the images. The diagnosis was immediate: Masses matting the lungs and deforming the spine. Cancer. In my neurosurgical training, I had reviewed hundreds of scans for fellow doctors to see if surgery offered any hope. Id scribble in the chart Widely metastatic disease  no role for surgery, and move on. But this scan was different: It was my own.

title: Violent Protests in Ukraine
description: The European Union weighs in.

title: Chip Profits Help Soften Other Losses at Samsung
description: In the marketplace, Samsung Electronics and Apple battle for customers. In the courts, they fight over patents. Yet every time Apple sells an iPhone, Samsung quietly cheers, too.

title: A Racist Turn in India
description: NEW DELHI  The Africans  Nigerians, Ghanaians, Ugandans  began leaving my neighborhood in New Delhi around December. Each week, more and more families exited. Some went to parts of Delhi considered more accepting of Africans; others to areas where the residents were thought to be less interfering in general. I have heard that some of the Ghanaian families had gone back to Africa, but I dont know that for sure.

title: Daily Report: Microsofts Earnings Indicate a Shift to Devices and Services
description: A picture of the new Microsoft, one transformed from a software factory into a maker of devices and online services, came into sharper focus on Thursday, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: Lunch-Hour I Dos, and Theyre Working Together Still
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together for more than two decades.

title: 10 Reasons Performance Reviews Dont Work
description: Most business owners think they should do performance reviews. Often, though, they fail to find the time and they question the value of the reviews. Employees rarely like the process, which typically feels more like an evaluation than a constructive conversation.

title: Rafael Nadal Dismantles Roger Federer Once Again to Advance to Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For all of Roger Federers accomplishments, for the 17 Grand Slam singles titles and the 302 weeks spent atop the rankings, there remains one serious issue with his greatest-of-all-time rsum. That issue is Rafael Nadal.

title: JPMorgans Chief Gets a Pay Raise
description: JPMORGANS DIMON TO GET RAISE | Despite the legal troubles that JPMorgan Chases faced in 2013, which amounted to more than $20 billion in fines, Jamie Dimon, the banks chairman and chief executive, is getting a raise, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig write in DealBook. The pay increase follows the boards move last year to cut Mr. Dimons compensation in half, to $11.5 million as reprimand for allowing a multibillion-dollar trading mistake known as the London Whale.

title: Jana Partners Presses Juniper Networks to Cut Costs and  Make Other Changes
description: The activist hedge fund Jana Partners has set its sights on Juniper Networks, calling on the networking company to tighten its belt and give more money back to shareholders.

title: New Law to Ban Manual Removal of Human Waste Disappoints
description: NEW DELHI  Last month, human rights advocates should have rejoiced after the central government enacted the most stringent law against what is euphemistically called manual scavenging, which is the removal of human waste with bare hands.

title: Apollo Tyres Open to Transactions Despite Cooper Tire Deal Collapse
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Apollo Tyres of India remains open to future strategic acquisitions despite the collapse last year of a potential $2.5 billion deal with the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, its vice chairman said Friday.

title: U.N. Leader Says Banks Should Finance More Sustainable Businesses
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, on Friday called on banks and other financial companies to increase financing for development of sustainable energy sources and businesses with low carbon footprints.

title: A Man Without a Nation, in Italy
description: Whats missing from movies nowadays is the beauty of the moving wind in the trees, D. W. Griffith told The American Mercury, not long before he died in 1948. Griffith made his reputation with blockbusters like The Birth of a Nation and Intolerance, but in the end, his sense of the medium was founded on the sense of physical reality that the first motion pictures afforded.

title: In a Blizzard of Sounds, the Intuitive Maestro
description: BURBANK, Calif.  On Sundays Grammy Awards ballot for producer of the year, next to four names that have been well known and well rewarded for 10 to 15 years  Pharrell Williams, Dr. Luke, Jeff Tweedy, Rob Cavallo  is Ariel Rechtshaid. He is pops sudden question mark, both for his profusion of good-to-great work over the last year or two and for the dissociative confusion you might experience when scanning the list of albums hes worked on as a producer or a songwriter in that period.

title: 2 Sides in Syria Peace Talks Agree to Meet in the Same Room, Averting a Breakdown
description: GENEVA  The participants in the fragile Syrian peace conference agreed on Friday to meet in the same room for the first time, in a last ditch agreement that averted a potential collapse.

title: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The World Economic Forum is usually considered a big networking event, where high-powered people schmooze in relatively cozy comfort.

title: In Our Pages: January 25
description: 1914: Liner Set for 3rd-Class Traffic

title: Thai Court Says Delay of Elections Is Constitutional
description: BANGKOK  A Thai court ruled Friday that a postponement of coming elections, which protesters have worked feverishly to block, is lawful under the countrys Constitution.

title: A Spilled Cup on the No. 1 Train
description: Dear Diary:

title: Financial Companies in Street Fight With Cybercriminals
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Financial companies are engaged in a escalating battle with increasingly sophisticated criminal organizations and some governments trying to hack into electronic payment systems, MasterCards top executive said Friday.

title: Sundance: The Plastic Surgeon and the Actor, a new Comedy Team
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Did you like our movie? Earl Lynn Nelson boomed point-blank from the stage, after a screening of the comedy Land Ho! in which he stars. The audience in the Egyptian Theater here on Wednesday evening cheered and applauded, then lined up to pose for photos with him.

title: Victoire de Castellanes Blinged-Out Sculptures at Gagosian
description: As the head of Diors haute joaillerie division since 1998, Victoire de Castellane has infused the luxury brands precious offerings with a signature pop whimsy. In 2007, she began toying with sculpture in the form of small-scale works festooned with jewels and anchored by sand-cast silver bases. Beginning January 28, they will be on display at Gagosians London gallery in her latest fine-art exhibition, animalvegetablemineral, which takes its name from a parlor game. The works incorporate flora and fauna motifs, as well as rough, unpolished geodes  the raw material for the precious stones de Castellane knows and loves. Each is presented beneath a glass globe (as they would in a natural history museum, she explains) and christened with a girlish name (Cana Glitter Night Baby, Lunae Lumen Holly Clorum). And although the pieces are art, de Castellane couldnt help but incorporate a sparkling bauble, to be detached and worn, into each one. Creating jewelry is my way of expressing myself, she says. Its like a language.

title: Treat Reckless Driving Like Drunk Driving
description: On a rainy, foggy night earlier this month, a New York City taxi driver making a left turn at a light apparently did not see my 9-year-old nephew and his 6-foot-3 father crossing the street at a crosswalk, beckoned by a lighted walk sign. Whether because of haste, inattention, cellphone use or perhaps the poor weather conditions, the cab driver drove directly into them.My beloved nephew, Cooper Stock, died instantly.His father suffered minor injuries. The Manhattan District Attorneys office is investigating the circumstances of Coopers death.

title: U.N. Sounds Alarm as Iraqis Flee Violence
description: GENEVA  The United Nations sounded an alarm Friday over the deepening conflict involving militants linked to Al Qaeda in Iraqs Anbar Province, saying the number of people forced to flee their homes was the highest since the sectarian violence of 2006-8, during the American-led occupation.

title: Umit Benans Homage and Thom Brownes Nature Trail
description: PARIS  With heads down and shoulders hunched, the models trooped across an earthen floor behind a wire mesh screen.

title: Kris Van Assche: A Bolt of Lightning
description: PARIS  At the Krisvanassche show, the designer put what looked like a bolt of lightning on the lapel of a jacket or at the breast of a coat  which could have been a reminder of the arrow-straight tailoring in which he excels.

title: Seeing My Friend Depicted in Lone Survivor
description: I dreaded the idea of seeing my old roommates death depicted on screen in the movie Lone Survivor. But when I saw a pair of Birkenstocks walking away from the camera on the big screen, I knew someone had taken the time to get the details right. Someone really cared about this story.

title: Germanys Finance Minister Praises Progress Made in Crisis Countries
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  One of Germanys top political leaders on Friday offered unusually generous praise for Greeces efforts to deal with its economic crisis, and said that other European countries should help Greece deal with an influx of immigrants to prevent them from becoming fodder for right-wing parties.

title: U.S. Oil Production Keeps Rising Beyond the Forecasts
description: OIL production in the United States rose by a record 992,000 barrels a day in 2013, the International Energy Agency estimated this week.

title: Skills Practice | Creating Character Recipes
description: Onion, tomatoes and ground beef are a few of the many ingredients Adam Nagourney includes in his recipe for meatballs with marinara sauce. Pretty straightforward. But what if you wanted to take the recipe format and use it to illustrate how to cook up a character like Huckleberry Finn or Lady Macbeth? What ingredients would you need? A dash of courage for Huck? A pinch of paranoia and a pint of blood for Lady Macbeth?

title: Sharing an Android Tablet
description: Q. Is it possible for two people to use one Android tablet and keep their apps and settings separate?

title: Aftermath of Explosions in Egypt
description: Scenes from Cairo, where at least six people were killed in four bombings. Demonstrations broke out in support of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi and against the Muslim Brotherhood hours later.

title: Is It Immoral to Watch the Super Bowl?
description: In the summer of 1978, during a preseason game, a wide receiver for the New England Patriots named Darryl Stingley lunged for a pass just out of his reach. Before he could regain his balance, he was hit by Jack Tatum, an Oakland Raiders defensive back. It was clear at once that Stingley was, in gridiron parlance, shaken up on the play. Team doctors rushed to his side.

title: After Private Speech on Israel, de Blasio Is Pressed on Openness Pledge
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an unannounced speech at a Manhattan gala of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the leading pro-Israel lobbying group, assuring its members that part of my job description is to be a defender of Israel.

title: Photographs of the Old Penn Station
description: The razing of New Yorks Penn Station in 1963 still ranks as one of the citys great architectural disasters. At the time, The New York Times wrote, We will probably be judged not by the monuments we build but by those we have destroyed. Walter Chandoha, a photographer who is now 93, remembers the old train station fondly. He was living in New York in the late 1940s and studying at N.Y.U. on the G.I. Bill when he would duck out between classes, Rolleiflex in hand, and wander around the city. Penn Station was a cherished spot, even before it was slated for demolition. When I look at the pictures now and I see the magnificence of it, I think, How could anybody knock this thing down? Chandoha says. Its like knocking down the Colosseum or the Brandenburg Gate. Its impossible to imagine. Julie Bosman

title: The Buyback
description: On a rainy Saturday afternoon, my husband and I finally gave up our guns. How we came to possess a small arsenal speaks to a past, though, not a predilection. Were neither hunters nor collectors; we sign petitions demanding stricter controls and call our congressmen to do likewise. But throughout the years of my husbands career as a diplomat, spent mostly in chaotic corners of Africa and Latin America, we acquired guns: mementos of the often-turbulent history that we witnessed. Strange as it was to have the weapons among our possessions, we could no more part with them than, say, burn an old photo album.

title: Reply All: The 1.12.14 Issue
description: FUTURE BOY GROWS UP

title: Discrimination at the Barber Shop?
description: I am a woman with a short, boyish hairstyle. Is it unfair that I am charged more for a haircut than a man with similarly short hair? Different prices for different genders seems to me like a sexist relic from a less enlightened time. When I called local salons to find a new stylist (mine moved away), many of them balked when I said I should be charged the mens rate because I have short hair. Many salons claim that it has always been done that way. This seems like a very bad excuse for an antiquated and discriminatory policy. YUKI MURATA, SANTA FE, N.M.

title: Magnus Carlsen, Chess Champion: My Moves Speak for Themselves
description: You became the world chess champion after a win in November. How did you go about training for the big match? The most important thing to study is opening theory, but I also study the latest trends to try to stay ahead, discovering new schemes and doing tactical exercises. I try to get into a chess mood.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Couture Collections Take Their Bows
description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of the Spring 2014 Paris Couture Collections, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 11 fashion visionaries.

title: The Guns of the Hudson
description: The sleepy Hudson River Valley community of Cold Spring, N.Y., is arguably one of the most idyllic villages in the state. Sitting on the east bank of the Hudson, it offers spectacular views of the Highlands across the river, including the United States Military Academy at West Point. Its art galleries, antique shops, and fine restaurants make for a delightful weekend getaway for residents of New York City, an hour to the south.

title: The Year in Adaptation
description: Cinematic book adaptations dominated 2012, with Life of Pi, Silver Linings Playbook and Anna Karenina springing from novels, and Lincoln and Argo drawing their stories from the nonfiction shelves. There was plenty of bookish inspiration in 2013, but the results elicited less enthusiasm. Martin Scorseses Oscar contender, The Wolf of Wall Street, was adapted from a memoir by Jordan Belfort. (The book begins: Youre lower than pond scum.) The movies leading man, Leonardo DiCaprio, also played the most famous literary character brought to the screen in 2013: Jay Gatsby. In The New Republic, David Thomson wrote his review in the form of a letter from Jay himself, who judged: Its stupefying, its vulgar, its demeaning.

title: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
description: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | The ascent of developing countries over the last decade has been fueled by two global trends: the steady rise of China and the willingness of the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy.

title: There Must Be Some Misunderstanding
description: Ben Marcus achieved the startling visions of his first story collection, The Age of Wire and String, and the novels Notable American Women and The Flame Alphabet largely by placing the reader in strange and unfamiliar worlds that turned out to be our world after all. The stories of his new collection, Leaving the Sea, still contain peculiar linguistic and perceptual tics, but he has added to his arsenal narratives that are less relentlessly unfamiliar, less rigorously dis-enchanted, populated by characters full of longing and visible regret, though for what is not always clear. For fans of the old style, like me, there are still plenty of messed-up points of view, and we can be reassured that while most of the work in this collection begins on familiar ground, it happily disintegrates into confusion and dread. In the end Marcus presents a deeper range of identification for the reader, more emotional complexity, but still plenty of the chair-gripping alienation that marked his previous books.

title: Writer of a Certain Age
description: When I started out as a television dramatist in the 60s, it was a truism that the more fanciable the female lead, the higher the ratings. Casting was a simple matter of sitting by the director while he flipped through acting photo directories and selected his preference. Theater was no different. When I took to writing plays in the 70s, it was understood that if two mature women were talking onstage, audience members would cough and shift in their seats, but if two men of any age were talking, the audience would pay some attention. And if a man of any age and a young woman were alone onstage, you could hear a pin drop.

title: Possession
description: If, as the Shaker lyrics suggest, it truly is a gift to be simple, consider the emotional intricacies of Rachel Urquharts transfixing debut novel, The Visionist. Urquharts characters, many of them Shakers or Shakers-to-be, lead lives gifted with devastating complexity. Their paths resemble not the austere angles of a Shaker meetinghouse but rather the rapturous choreography of the dances Shakers were known for and named after.

title: Taking Flight
description: Unlikely alliances are a staple of fiction, and the unlikelier the better, from Huck and Jim floating down the Mississippi to Frodo and Gollum creeping toward Mordor  because the real drama lies in watching how dissimilar characters turn out to be brothers (or sisters) under the skin. Sue Monk Kidd followed this principle in her best-selling first novel, The Secret Life of Bees, in which a 14-year-old white girl and her familys black servant join in fleeing abuse in the South Carolina of the civil rights era. Kidds latest novel, The Invention of Wings, also set largely in South Carolina, involves another unusual duo, in this case a slave and a daughter of the family that owns her.

title: The Vanishing
description: On Dec. 4, 1872, the brigantine Mary Celeste was discovered abandoned, adrift in the North Atlantic near the Azores. The ship was empty and its crew missing, although its cargo and provisions were intact, as were the crews possessions. The weather was calm and the ship was seaworthy, but no trace of the crew  or of the captains wife and 2-year-old child  was ever found. Newspapers around the world carried the story, and it inspired one of Arthur Conan Doyles first published pieces of fiction, J. Habakuk Jephsons Statement, printed anonymously in the British journal Cornhill. From then until the present, dozens of other investigations, novels, historical accounts, television documentaries and movies have been devoted to what has become the prototypical ghost ship. Given this background, what could Valerie Martin possibly contribute to the story in her new novel?

title: The Anti-Snuggle Task Force
description: The funny side of Sandy; Agatha Christie vs. Chris Christie.

title: Unreconciled
description: Given the extraordinary truth of Las Vegas, a city that began after all as a glint in a mobsters eye, you might wonder what possible iniquities are stored up in a novel purporting to tell its secret history. Is it, perhaps, a double-bluff, in which the real life of the city is one of stable communities and spiritual growth  Marilynne Robinsons Gilead with slot machines?

title: Commitment
description: Roddy Doyles new novel, The Guts, begins with a conversation about Facebook. Jimmy Rabbitte, the hero of Doyles 1987 novel, The Commitments, and a key figure in that books two successors, The Snapper and The Van, sits in a pub with his father, Jimmy Sr. The two men are arguing (or simply talking; it can be difficult to tell in Doyles starkly profane dialect), and the son explains social networking thus to his dad: Its like a club but yeh have your own room, for the people yeh want to meet. Except theres no room an yeh meet no one. Unless yeh want to. For a moment, perhaps, we think we know what to expect: a rambunctious comedy about aging musicians, working-class life, rock n roll, something fundamentally upbeat, because thats what Doyle does. Even his darker books  The Woman Who Walked Into Doors, say, that raw tale of a womans abuse at the hands of her alcoholic husband  have a way of seeming spry, sunny underneath their patina of hardscrabble realism. So were ready for the comedy of crusty middle-aged Jimmy and his father navigating the dubious world of text messaging and mobile phones (after all, we havent seen them fleshed out in a novel since the 1990 of The Van). But the younger Jimmy has something else on his mind.

title: Under the Covers
description: For writers, literature is a talent show: Those with the most talent win. Readers are more fortunate: Everybody wins. Quality reading exercises the crucial dialogue with yourself, the dialogue you must undergo to become yourself, to know where on the vista of existence you can place your own identity and awareness.

title: Private Life
description: Oh, how taxing it is to be Nol Coward in his declining years, trundling between two homes in Jamaica with only one servant to pour the brandy. (The other, alas, is off for the week.)

title: Grand Illusions
description: The story could hardly be simpler. Five young Frenchmen leave their village to fight in the Great War. Some will be grievously injured, some wont return.

title: Albees Death of Bessie Smith Is Extended in Brooklyn Run
description: A community theater in Brooklyn has extended its run of Edward Albees early play, The Death of Bessie Smith, which is being staged inside the Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital in Bedford-Stuyvesant that is on the verge of closing.

title: Then We Came to the End
description: Nonfiction books about death tend to skew toward self-help (grieving, coping), spirituality (is heaven real?) and last lessons (Tuesdays With Morrie). In The New York Times Book Review last summer, Meghan ORourke noted a surge of writers chronicling their own decline and suggested that the trend represents a natural outgrowth of significant social changes in how we experience disease and death.

title: A Sense of Snow
description: Winter and discontent. The future Richard III pairs those elements in the first line of Shakespeares play, and they are also paired, with piercing chill, in James Scotts debut novel, The Kept. It is 1897. Elspeth Howell is making her way to an isolated cabin in upstate New York. Elspeth is pursued by cruel weather and her past as a sinner, a woman besieged by anger, covetousness, thievery. Unlike false and treacherous Richard, she believes she has conquered her worst impulses. She bears gifts for her five children and her husband, Jorah. She longs for the comforts of home. What she discovers, instead, is the worst kind of retribution  a slaughter of innocents triggered by her own compulsive history.

title: Ex-Governor of Virginia Is Released After Arraignment
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The former governor of Virginia, Bob McDonnell, and his wife, Maureen, will remain free pending their trial on corruption charges after being arraigned Friday in Federal District Court in Richmond.

title: What I Love | Anna Netrebko
description: The sopranos brightly painted Upper West Side apartment has commanding views of the Hudson River.

title: Anna Netrebko Decorates
description: The Russian-born soprano Anna Netrebko lives with her son, Tiago (and sometimes with her sister, Natalia), in a condominium high above Lincoln Square. The terraces, the high ceilings, the line of windows with sweeping views of the Hudson River, the quick walk to work at the Metropolitan Opera, the gym and swimming pool on-site  all are worth singing about.

title: Who Made That Tricycle?
description: In March 1877, James Starley, a sewing-machine maker in Coventry, England, unveiled a strange offshoot of the tricycle. It had one large wheel on the left and two much smaller ones on the right. The rider sat between the wheels, driving with a pair of levers and steering on a crank. A few years later, Starleys new designs had grown so popular that the queen bought two for herself.

title: Pipeline Fight Lifts Environmental Movement
description: WASHINGTON  Environmentalists have spent the past two years fighting the Keystone XL pipeline: They have built a human chain around the White House, clogged the State Departments public comment system with more than a million emails and letters, and gotten themselves arrested at protests across the country.

title: Image of the Day: January 24
The Doctor-Go-Round
description: When each new test finds a new problem.

title: In Russia, Couriers Halt Parcel Delivery
description: MOSCOW  Russia has never been an easy country in which to deliver packages because of its vast size. The government just made it a lot harder for anyone buying things online.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: My Life in Middlemarch
description: This week, Rebecca Mead discusses My Life in Middlemarch; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Scott Stossel talks about My Age of Anxiety; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: My Age of Anxiety
description: This week, Rebecca Mead and Scott Stossel.

title: On the Right
description: THE GREAT DEBATE  Edmund Burke, Thomas Paine, and the Birth of Right and Left  By Yuval Levin Basic Books, $27.99.

title: Inside the List
description: Roger and Me: Gabriel Shermans unauthorized biography of Roger Ailes, The Loudest Voice in the Room, saunters onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 9. The book doesnt arrive without controversy: Ailes, the founder and president of Fox News Channel, refused to cooperate with Sherman and went so far as to grant exclusive access to a rival journalist, the Rush Limbaugh biographer Zev Chafets, in evident hopes of pre-empting Sherman with a friendlier account. (Chafetss book, Roger Ailes: Off Camera, was published in March 2013 and spent a week on the e-book nonfiction list.) On NPRs Fresh Air last month, Sherman described his efforts to interview Ailes in terms that called to mind Michael Moores early documentary Roger and Me, about the General Motors chief executive Roger Smith. I reached out to Roger Ailes more than a dozen times in the two and a half years I was doing the researching and writing, both in person and in writing, he said. I traveled to different states to see him at public events to tell him I was eager to sit down and discuss every fact in the book. Ultimately, it was his decision not to participate. Ailess opposition, he continued, had provided a crash course in what it must be like to be involved in a political campaign. . . . Im not the story. Roger Ailes is the story. But he has elevated me to a place where its this kind of me-versus-him dynamic.

title: Lessons From a Master Cat Photographer
description: Walter Chandoha, who has been mastering the art of cat and dog photography for more than 60 years, shares some of his secrets.

title: Sundance: A Dark Mood Pervades This Edition
description: PARK CITY, Utah  As always, cineastes spent Sundance on a cloud. They marveled at Calvary, a blackly comedic exploration of religion, and lit up over emerging talents like Alex Ross Perry, director of the acerbic Listen Up Philip.

title: Bitcoin Is Not Yet Ready for the Real World
description: Mark T. Williams, a former commodities trading floor senior executive and Federal Reserve Bank examiner, teaches banking, finance and risk management at Boston University School of Management.

title: Movie Review: 'Gloria'
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "Gloria."

title: The 30-Year-Old Macintosh and a Lost Conversation With Steve Jobs
description: On a late-November day in 1983, Steven Levy, then a freelance journalist for Rolling Stone, got into a car outside10460 Bandley Drive, in Cupertino, Calif.

title: In the Alps, a Walk in the Sky
description: Visitors will feel like theyre floating above the Alps with Step Into the Void, a new five-sided tempered-glass enclosure located at the tip of the Aiguille du Midi mountain peak. The enclosure lies at one end of the worlds tallest skywalk structure, which stands at 3,842 meters (12,605 feet) and overlooks the French commune of Chamonix.

title: Truth and Consequences for a War Photographer
description: The ethical commandments on the digital manipulation of photographs in journalism are simple and direct: you do not add or subtract any element of an image in post processing. Ever. If a photo didnt turn out exactly how you had imagined, there is no laptop digital do-over.

title: Movie Review: 'Stranger by the Lake'
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "Stranger by the Lake."

title: Russia Plans to Extend Snowden Asylum, Lawmaker Says
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Russia plans to extend its offer of asylum to Edward J. Snowden beyond August, a Russian lawmaker said Friday at the World Economic Forum here.

title: Some States Are Moving to Loosen Their Estate Taxes
description: FOR most of the United States, the estate tax is now something only the very wealthy have to plan for. The federal exemption for an individual this year is now $5.34 million, or $10.68 million for a married couple. And that amount is indexed to inflation, so it will continue to rise.

title: Following Your Dream Brings Bliss, but Not Always Money
description: WHEN Trent Brown was laid off from his job as a sales representative in 2010, he chose to view it as an opportunity to make a life change. Instead of searching for some other company job, he decided to help his wife, Janell, expand her cupcake and cake-making hobby into a business. Just six months after he lost his job, they opened One Sweet Slice in the Salt Lake City area where they lived.

title: Times Minute | Deadly Blasts in Cairo
description: Also on the Minute, the economics of climate change and a look at the tricycle.

title: Video Reviews of Visitors, Gloria and Stranger by the Lake
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the wordless film Visitors, the French drama Stranger by the Lake and the Chilean film Gloria. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Times Minute | Deadly Blasts in Cairo
description: In the Video

title: Recommended Reading
description: NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

title: Cameron Sees Technology as Unlikely Ally of Western Workers
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The specter of rich countries losing jobs to cheaper workers in emerging economies and increasingly to smart machines has been an important theme at the World Economic Forum this week. As Eric Schmidt of Google put it: The jobs problem is going to be the defining problem of the next two to three decades.

title: Decoding Ariel Rechtshaid
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Ariel Rechtshaid, the Grammy-nominated producer of songs by Sky Ferreira, Vampire Weekend, Justin Bieber and others.

title: More Views on Nuclear Power, Waste, Safety and Cost
description: Heres another round in a continuing exploration of views on next steps for nuclear power. Earlier this week, I received a letter arguing for a fresh push on nuclear technologies, building on the argument of James Hansen and three other climate researchers that I wrote about last fall.

title: Today in Small Business: Clam Diggers and Worm Harvesters
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Former Interpreter for The Times Is Killed in Afghanistan
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Noor Ahmad Noori, an Afghan interpreter who formerly worked for The New York Times in Afghanistan, was found beaten and stabbed to death, wrapped in a sack and dumped on a roadside late Thursday outside Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, where he lived, government officials and family members reported.

title: Big Raise for JPMorgans Dimon Despite a Rough Year
description: Updated, 9:09 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase, after a year marred by scandal and stiff regulatory penalties, has decided to award its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, $20 million in compensation for 2013, an amount that will further inflame the debate over the accountability of senior bank executives.

title: Paperback Row
description: LOVE IS A CANOE,  by Ben Schrank. (Picador/Sarah Crichton, $16.) Her marriage in trouble, the heroine of Schranks novel  a crackling sendup of the New York publishing industry and an inquiry into the fragility of human relationships  turns for help to the author of Marriage Is a Canoe, a classic self-help book she read as a child.

title: The Source | Aaron Koblin
description: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Aaron Koblin.

title: Popcast: Decoding Ariel Rechtshaid
description: Among the A-list names in this years Grammy ballot for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical, is Ariel Rechtshaid, who has been a pop pro since his teenage years but has only recently and suddenly, at 34, become a subject of great interest.

title: Editors Choice
description: DUTY: Memoirs of a Secretary at War,  by Robert M. Gates. (Knopf, $35.) One of the few Obama administration members who come off well in this frank account  probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever  is Hillary Clinton.

title: Co-ops Chill, Condos Dont
description: The phrase white-glove Manhattan co-op has invariably conjured the image of a fortresslike residence whose precincts could be stormed only via a gantlet distinguished by mountains of paperwork and a daunting personal interview. The New York condominium, the relatively new kid on the block, has seemed the opposite: laissez-faire in everything, from rules governing pets and smoking to regulations determining who could rent an apartment.

title: Matsuev Postpones Carnegie Hall Concert
description: Updated, 1:17 p.m. | The pianist Denis Matsuev has postponed a Carnegie Hall concert scheduled for Thursday, Jan. 30, because he is being treated for pneumonia, the hall announced. It said in a statement that Mr. Matsuev is currently in Moscow under doctors care and not permitted to travel, and that he had been forced to cancel or reschedule a number of concerts in the United States, Israel and Russia. Mr. Matsuev, who has been active in cultural preparations for the Winter Olympics in Sochi, is scheduled to play a concert there on Feb. 6 at the Zimniy Theater. One of his representatives, Silke Zimmermann, said that we firmly count on his participation at the Sochi games. Mr. Matsuevs Carnegie Hall appearance  which was to feature the music of Schumann, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky  has been rescheduled for June 15.

title: Movie Review: 'Visitors'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Visitors."

title: Big Ticket | At $14 Million, Two Are Better Than One
description: Two condominiums high in the north tower of the venerable Century at 25 Central Park West that were marketed as a single entity  to assemble a full-floor residence with panoramic views  sold for $14 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: At BP, Theres Optimism in the Corner Office
description: LONDON  It has been nearly four years since the oil drilling disaster in the Gulf of Mexico killed 11 people and brought the wrath of the United States government and legal system down on the British energy giant BP.

title: Goldman May Restrict Employees Use of Chat Services
description: Updated, 2:43 p.m. |

title: Mike Huckabees War for Women
description: Im not a doctor, but Ive figured out that the birth control pill is a form of contraception. Take the pill daily; dont get pregnant.

title: After Controversy, Duck Dynasty Draws a Smaller Audience
description: Duck season is proving a bit hit and miss so far this year.

title: Claudio Abbado Commemoration at La Scala to Be Live Streamed
description: A public commemoration of the conductor Claudio Abbado, who died on Monday at 80, will be live-streamed from Milans La Scala Opera House on Jan. 27 to allow the global audience of the web to participate, the theater announced on Monday. Daniel Barenboim will conduct the Funeral March from Beethovens third Symphony at 6 P.M. in Milan, noon Eastern Standard Time, and the event will be streamed on the theaters website and on Youtube.

title: Paris Couture Week: Maison Martin Margiela Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Requiem for a Minivan
description: Stella, my 8-year-old, was crying. Her little shoulders heaved with sobs. Her face, buried into my belly, left streaks of tears on my T-shirt. Her grief was acute. I helplessly rubbed her back, murmuring soothing sounds.

title: Banker Says Letting Banks Fail Is Essential to Rebuilding Public Trust
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Rules enacted since the financial crisis have eliminated the need to designate banks as too big to fail in a number of countries in the next economic disruption, said Urs Rohner, the chairman of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse.

title: Homies in Verona, Gangstas in Elsinore
description: In 1848, a reviewer for Grahams Magazine described Wuthering Heights as a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors, such as we might suppose a person, inspired by a mixture of brandy and gunpowder, might write for the edification of fifth-rate blackguards. Presumably, this grumpy writer would have cared even less for the Thug Notes version.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: My Age of Anxiety
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Nathan Heller reviews My Age of Anxiety, Scott Stossels memoir about his own incapacitating nerves and the larger legacy of the disorder. Mr. Heller writes:

title: A Lawyer and Partner, and Also Bankrupt
description: Anyone who wonders why law school applications are plunging and theres widespread malaise in many big law firms might consider the case of Gregory M. Owens.

title: Shulamit Aloni, Outspoken Israeli Lawmaker, Dies at 86
description: Shulamit Aloni, a longtime left-wing Israeli minister and Parliament member who was an early champion of civil liberties, challenger of religious hegemony and outspoken opponent of Israels occupation of the Palestinian territories, died Friday at her home in Kfar Shmaryahu, a Tel Aviv suburb. She was 86.

title: Aide Arrested in Child Pornography Case Is Found Dead
