description: WASHINGTON  A former chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, who was arrested last month on charges stemming from his possession of child pornography was found dead on Thursday in the basement of his parents home in Maryland, apparently in a suicide, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Gates and Summers Push Global Health Drive as Moral Imperative
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Pouring money into improving health care in developing countries is a profound moral mission, according to Bill Gates and Lawrence H. Summers  and huge achievements are well in reach.

title: Alfonso Cuarn May Be a DGA Favorite, but Philomena Is Rising Fast
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild Awards, to be held here on Saturday, are usually a reliable barometer of which way the wind is blowing, best picture-wise. Even last year, when the guild saw fit to give its top prize to Ben Affleck, who had been famously snubbed in the directing category by the Academy, it was an indication of how much love there was for his movie Argo, which went on to win best picture.

title: Opossums Are Unloved, Yet Hard to Resist
description: The Virginia opossum is more closely related to kangaroos and koalas than to the rats and rodents with which it is frequently compared. North Americas only native marsupial, the opossum is probably more frequently observed in New York City trash cans than in New York City parks.

title: Erosion of Argentine Peso Sends a Shudder Through Latin America
description: BUENOS AIRES  Cities across Argentina are still unnerved by all the looting that broke out last month after police officers went on strike, protesting salaries eroded by rampant inflation. Residents fumed over blackouts that left them sweltering during a recent heat wave. Then the currency plunged this week, the steepest decline since the nations economic collapse in 2002, stirring fears that another major financial crisis could be around the corner.

title: The Gun Report: January 24, 2014
description: As regular readers of this blog know, Chicago has the highest toll of gun violence in the nation. Which is why a billboard there equating an AR-15 with baseball and apple pie strikes many as tone-deaf.

title: Review: 2014 Land Rover Range Rover HSE
description: Land Rovers fourth-generation Range Rover has an familiar silhouette, a sumptuous interior and a price as steep as the hills it can conquer.

title: Not Your Grandmothers Gratin
description: In my kitchen, leftovers often become the inspiration for a week of Recipes for Health. This happened last week. If you had opened my refrigerator on Sunday you would have found a selection of roasted vegetables, which I had prepared over the weekend for various dinners and recipe tests. By Tuesday those vegetables had found their way into three winter gratins.

title: Grace of Monaco Will Open the Cannes Film Festival
description: Olivier Dahans film Grace of Monaco, featuring Nicole Kidman as the actress Grace Kelly, is the opening-night selection for the 67th Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced today.

title: How to Take a Perfect Cat Photo (or at Least Make a Living as an Artist)
description: The Look pages in this weekends magazine feature Walter Chandohas pictures of the old Penn Station, which he took in the late 1940s in between classes at N.Y.U.s School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance (now the Stern School of Business). After one of these photographic excursions, Chandoha found a stray kitten in the Village and took it back to his home in Astoria, Queens.

title: Video: Range Rover Offers Off-Road Capability in an Opulent Package
description: The luxury off-road mission of Jaguar Land Rovers Range Rover is a curious thing. Last time I checked, polar fleece formal wear never made it big, not even in Seattle. And yet, everywhere I go, people fawn over this opulent S.U.V.

title: After a Long Trip, a Good Predators Debut for Del Zotto
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Michael Del Zotto made his debut with the Nashville Predators on a good note with a 2-1 road win over the Vancouver Canucks on Thursday night. A former Rangers defenseman, Del Zotto is hoping to tune up his N.H.L. career in Music City after being traded on Wednesday for Kevin Klein.

title: Running Wild, Wheelies to the Wind
description: They gather usually once a week on dirt bikes of all varieties, cruising down the road, engines revved, wheelies popped as they turn the streets of Baltimore into an urban playground. They are called the 12 oclock boys, and they are the subject of a new documentary of the same name opening Friday. They are also seen as a menace by some in the citys Police Department and as a danger by some residents.

title: A Template 007 Named Fleming
description: Everything I write has a precedent in truth, Ian Fleming once said, and next to James Bond, his greatest creation may have been himself. A failed stockbroker, the rakish Fleming imbibed drink, women and the family fortune as he tried to escape the shadow of his adventurous older brother Peter and the disappointment of his formidable mother. Then the Naval Intelligence Division cornered him, using his talent for spinning a tale in the World War II effort.

title: Hardware Shop Owner Sculpts Art From Odds and Ends
description: DeLuca General Store, an old-style hardware shop on Bay Street in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, has a Norman Rockwell-looking storefront with windows displaying garden tools and plumbing supplies.

title: Bragging Rights of an Up-and-Comer
description: Martin Garrix became dance musics boy wonder last year, thanks to Animals, a springy and chipper slice of progressive house with just a touch of attitude. It made him, at 17, the youngest D.J. with a No. 1 chart hit at Beatport, the online electronic music store.

title: Like John Wayne, but in Anoraks
description: The doldrums of winter in the city can really get to you. What could be worse? The filmmaker Jessica Oreck, with her Kickstarter-financed documentary Aatsinki: The Story of Arctic Cowboys (at IFC Center through Thursday), has an idea. Her film follows the brothers Aarne and Lasse Aatsinki and their crew over one year as they herd reindeer in Finnish Lapland, inside the Arctic Circle.

title: Star-Crossed Meets Hip-Hop
description: A decade has passed since Rennie Harris Puremovement graced the stage of the Joyce Theater. In dance, thats practically forever. Beginning on Tuesday, the company, led by the astute and poetic hip-hop choreographer Mr. Harris, is back with a selection of repertory favorites, including a newly excerpted and remounted version of Rome and Jewels. That Bessie Award-winning work from 2000  created in collaboration with the dramaturge Ozzie Jonesand the composer Darin Ross  transfers Shakespeares Romeo and Juliet and West Side Story to a captivating b-boy world pitting the Monster Qs (the Montagues) against the Caps (the Capulets). Mr. Jones reprises his role as narrator, while the astonishing Rodney Mason returns to star as Rome.

title: Art of Collision, Sticks to Cymbals
description: Steven Schick, a star in the world of solo percussion music and the author of The Percussionists Art, celebrates his 60th birthday with two concerts at Miller Theater that trace the trajectory of this repertory.

title: Before and After, Paris in the 1800s
description: Two exhibitions opening this week sample opposite ends of the history of photography. First is Charles Marville, appointed official photographer of Paris in 1862. Over the next eight years, he documented old parts of the city destined for a drastic makeover, then photographed the new boulevards, gas lamps, pissoirs and other amenities that transformed Paris into a modern metropolis. Charles Marville: Photographer of Paris, opening Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents about 100 of his lucid and evocative photographs. (Through May 4, 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

title: The Source | Aaron Koblin in Conversation With Doug Aitken
description: Theres all this invisible infrastructure thats surrounding us, says the digital media artist Aaron Koblin, who serves as the Creative Director of the Data Arts Team at Google. With visualization projects such as Flight Patterns, he has sought to bring that hidden world to light. Koblin speaks with the artist Doug Aitken about the intersection of art and technology as part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: Making Waves at Sea, and in the Studio
description: The frontwomen of Warpaint agree: In the event of an apocalypse, they would outfit themselves more sensibly than Beyonc. Youre not going to be wearing a shirt that is just barely covering your nipples, Theresa Wayman said of the futuristic video for the recent Beyonc song Superpower. Emily Kokal added, Youre going to be covering yourself from the elements.

title: Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi
description: The co-directors and co-writers discuss their vampire film "What We Do in the Shadows" at Sundance.

title: Love That Dare Not Sing Its Name
description: In the acclaimed 2005 film Brokeback Mountain, based on the short story by Annie Proulx, Heath Ledger played Ennis Del Mar, a Wyoming ranch hand in a furtive, decades-long gay affair. He kept his words gravelly, mumbling and few, as if hed been blocked up by a life of secrets. It was a voice powerfully affecting in the quiet close-ups possible in the movies, but it wouldnt register in the grandeur of an opera house.

title: Draghi Sees Progress in Euro Zone, but Puts Banks on Notice
description: DAVOS, SWITZERLAND  Some banks in the euro zone could go out of business as a result of intense official scrutiny they will face this year, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday as he presented a generally upbeat view of the European economy that was, however, laced with warnings.

title: Old Democratic Name (Nunn) Stakes Bid on Shifting Georgia
description: PERRY, Ga.  As a little girl, Michelle Nunn clutched her fathers hand as they strolled the pecan groves of the familys 2,400-acre farm, a moment captured in a black-and-white photograph that Sam Nunn used to help win election to the Senate. It hangs in a Sam Nunn exhibit in this small city south of Macon, where the main thoroughfare is Sam Nunn Boulevard.

title: An Old-Style Jazzman, and Voices of Irans Past
description: George Cables

title: Sundance Video:  Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi Are Onto Something
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Vampires have finally descended on Sundance. In its 30th year the festival may be, as Manohla Dargis writes more vital than ever to the indie film scene. But that doesnt mean its immune to the lure of big thrill entertainment that the undead provide. This years festival had not one but three vampire flicks: the high-profile Only Lovers Left Alive, from Jim Jarmusch, starring Tilda Swinton and Tom Hiddleston; Girl Walks Home Alone at Night, billed as cinemas first Iranian vampire western; and What We Do in the Shadows, from writer-director-stars Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement.

title: Small-Town Crank Finds His Following
description: Americas love affair with British TV may have reached a peak with Downton Abbey, but viewers are also finding plenty of room in their hearts for the decidedly different Doc Martin, a decade-old series about a cantankerous doctor and the ensemble of quirky neighbors and patients he looks down on in the fictional Cornwall coastal village of Portwenn.

title: Gestures of a Hot Hand
description: Ooooooh! shrieked the New York City Ballet dancer Tiler Peck, held high in the air, her body bent into a backward arch, her feet almost touching her head, as her partner, Robert Fairchild, ran across the studio. Ooooooh! shrieked the dancers in the room, half-laughing, some hiding their faces in their hands, as Ms. Peck rocked dangerously forward, almost toppling over his head.

title: The 2015 Lincoln Navigator: A Familiar Shape With a New Face
description: The Lincoln Navigator first appeared in 1998 as an upscale Ford Expedition, which in turn was a larger version of that eras Ford Explorer. If you saw the 2015 model coming from far away, or in low light, you might not be able to tell that anything had changed over the last decade and a half. But the Lincoln Motor Company assures us that the Navigator, familiar in profile as it is, is better than ever.

title: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
description: Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow.

title: Dismay for Pay at JPMorgan Chase
description: Jamie Dimons bonus represents another whale of a fail for JPMorgan Chase. The boards decision to give its chairman and chief executive a 73 percent raise, to $20 million, is unjustifiable after last years performance. Shareholders should have a loud say against this pay  and the lead director, Lee Raymond.

title: Portrait of a Wily Holocaust Survivor
description: Theresienstadt was called Hitlers gift to the Jews. In an 18th-century military town some 40 miles north of Prague, this model ghetto was established to show the world that life in a concentration camp was practically halcyon. Grown-ups lingered over delicious meals between fulfilling workdays and evening concerts or lectures. Children devoured sweets. Soccer matches were played in the town square.

title: Republicans Vote to Streamline Nominating Process
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican National Committee moved Friday to consolidate its presidential nominating process in 2016, a pre-emptive effort to avoid a drawn-out campaign that many in the party say could imperil their effort to reclaim the White House.

title: All Together Now, Eyes on the Screen
description: You start off a brash outsider, testing the limits of acceptability, and if youre good enough and lucky enough, you eventually become the Establishment, explaining to your children why the things youre passionate about arent too boring for words. Such is the trajectory of Michael Dorf, who founded the edgy music club Knitting Factory in 1986 and, 22 years later, City Winery, where middle-aged singer-songwriter types pluck and warble for patrons having braised rabbit and merlot-cabernet blends. Mr. Dorf, 51, plans to open City Winery outposts this year in Nashville and Napa Valley, Calif. On March 31 he will present his 10th annual benefit concert at Carnegie Hall to raise money for music education, this one dedicated to the songs of Paul Simon. He lives in TriBeCa with his wife, Sarah Connors, 49, a film producer, and their children, Sophia, 10, and 15-year-old twins, Eli and Zachary (who was away on a recent Sunday). The family has a rescue mutt and a rabbit.

title: Wheelies: The Muppet Toyota Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Cowboy Poetry and Rodeos
description: Next week marks the 30th anniversary of the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering, in Elko, Nev., a tradition sponsored by the Western Folklife Center in that city. Poets, storytellers, musicians, radio personalities and now even bloggers come together to promote the occupational and artistic traditions of the rural West.

title: Seven Days of Style | Diors Didactic Runway, Chanels Couture Sneakers and Kanyes Latest Designs
description: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 18  24

title: Dont Blame the Maps
description: DO the Republicans owe their current congressional majority to gerrymandering? At first glance, it seems self-evident that they do. In the 2012 election, the Democrats won the popular votes for the presidency, the Senate and the House of Representatives. But somehow in the House  for whose seats Republicans controlled the redistricting process in many crucial states  the Republicans managed to end up with a 16-seat majority despite losing the popular vote.

title: Pasta With Parsnips and Bacon
description: Parsnips add a certain sweetness to a cozy winter pasta dish thick with cream and bacon.

title: Mutually Beneficial to Pasta and Parsnip
description: PAIRING PASTA WITH PARSNIPS is not one of the more obvious matches. Their starchy natures make them seem too similar, the kind of couple that finishes each others sentences, which can be dull company indeed.

title: Washington Theaters to Produce Womens Theater Festival
description: Nearly four dozen theaters in the Washington D.C. area are joining forces to produce the Womens Voices Theater Festival, a celebration of contemporary female playwrights that will take over the Washington theater world for eight weeks starting on September 14, 2015. The festival is being organized by Molly Smith, the artistic director of Arena Stage, and Eric Schaeffer, the artistic director of Signature Theater, who announced the project on Thursday.

title: Bach Inventions and a Monk Tribute, Using All of the Piano
description: Bach wrote his set of 15 Two-Part Inventions as teaching pieces for amateurs of the keyboard, as he put it in a preface. Each work unfolds as just two contrapuntal lines, two voices, one for each hand.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Midtown co-op with a fireplace in every room; an Upper West Side condo in a full-service building; and a Midwood Park home with a circular staircase.

title: Serendipity: 1. Spreadsheet: 0.
description: Wherever she goes, Jennifer Lee Illes carries a big, black North Face backpack bulging with items like workout clothes, mint tea bags, sheet music from her a cappella singing group and aviation cards from the flying lessons she has been taking. Ms. Illes, a strategy and operations manager for Google in Ann Arbor, Mich., likes to be overprepared.

title: In the Ghost With the Most, Drivers May Haunt the Back Seat
description: Its a great time to sell fancy cars. At the Hilton Head Island Concours dElegance last fall, I met a Rolls-Royce salesman who was on his way to Atlanta to deliver a Wraith to a customer. The factor that limits sales of Rollses, he told me, is the factory itself: It literally cant build them fast enough to satisfy demand.

title: Duel at the Old Fulton Fish Market
description: Robert LaValvas epiphany came early one February morning in 2005, as he watched Londons Borough Market come alive.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A colonial in Syosset, N.Y., with four bedrooms, each with a bath; and a Hillsborough, N.J., home built around the core of a 1920 farmhouse.

title: Chinatown Revisited
description: My mother is the oldest of five siblings, most of whom grew up in New Yorks Chinatown. They are voracious eaters and bargain hunters, and lifelong visitors to Chinese neighborhoods everywhere. When we talk about a good Chinatown, we point to certain signs: live fish for sale, dragon eyes in sidewalk produce displays, smokers, crowds.

title: Amy Tans Evolving Sense of China
description: In 1949, Amy Tans mother boarded one of the last ships heading from Shanghai to San Francisco before China became Red China and the bamboo curtain descended. There, her mother reunited with her husband and the couple relocated to Oakland, where a couple of years later she was born.

title: The Ecstasy of Excess, the Agony of the Sticker
description: BIG SUR, Calif.  Every carmaker makes compromises. Feature enhancements, like a little more legroom or a touch more horsepower, are weighed against the effect on a models sticker price. But what if, in an alternative universe, money could bend the laws of physics, and vehicles were created only to transport mortals to the highest state of driving satisfaction?

title: Not Your Average Spirit
description: The Wraith, named for a soul-sucking ghost that casts spells and cannot be vanquished, is the most powerful Rolls-Royce ever produced.

title: Kiev Truce Falls Apart, and Unrest Resurges
description: KIEV, Ukraine  With President Viktor F. Yanukovych and antigovernment demonstrators at an impasse here, a cease-fire disintegrated on Friday night as the Ukrainian capital convulsed in renewed violence and fire bombs lit up the night sky.

title: Modern Civility, Retail Division
description: Retail is not without its dark alleys. As with those other public areas prone to a high incidence of bad manners (airplanes and restaurants), stores can be breeding grounds for the impulsive and the exigent. Enter the customer who greets unexpected delays with donkeylike braying. Enter the salespeople who clump idly in lush profusion but who then atomize upon approach.

title: Weekend Reading: Looking Back at Our View From the Alps
description: As the World Economic Forum concludes in Davos, Switzerland, were looking back at some of our past coverage of the elite gathering.

title: Loehmanns, Out of Step and Closing Down
description: Whenever a store, bar, restaurant or other institution closes in New York after decades, theres a tendency to mourn the loss of an entire way of life, a vanished style of inhabiting the city that can no longer flourish in the context of new economies with new people too young, too preoccupied, too cavalier to appreciate the old and intrinsically superior, more genuine folkways. It is hard to mine the same kind of resonance from the closing of Loehmanns, now shutting down after 94 years, if only because the hunger for discount would seem to be eternal. And yet the end of Loehmanns still says something about our altered expectations of the retail experience.

title: Goldmans Cautious Approach to Hiring the Well-Connected
description: Goldman Sachs, like other big banks, has been scrutinized for its hiring practices in China. The question federal authorities are investigating is whether banks hired the children of powerful Chinese officials in an attempt to win lucrative business.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Jeep Struggles to Repair Vehicles 14 Months After Recall
description: Fourteen months after Chrysler said it would recall about 745,000 Jeep Grand Cherokee and Jeep Liberty sport utility vehicles because the front or side air bags might deploy without the vehicle being in a crash, about 94 percent of them had not been repaired, leaving some owners angry and scared.

title: Officials Blame Human Error for the Latest Blow to the Reputation of Metro-North
description: The sprawling shutdown that halted commutes for nearly two hours across Metro-North Railroad on Thursday night was traced to a simple disconnected wire  overlooked by technicians who were trying to replace a power supply unit, transportation officials said.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Egypt, Central African Republic and Thailand.

title: Emery Roth Lived Here
description: Renowned for elegant prewar Manhattan apartment buildings like the Beresford and the San Remo, Emery Roth, the prolific New York City architect, designed many distinctive buildings in the 1920s and 30s. His body of work is so rich that today an apartment listing in an Emery Roth-designed building invokes a certain cachet that is not lost on brokers.

title: After a Sons Death, Parents Channel Their Grief Into Activism
description: They had not been like this. They rarely signed petitions or spoke at public hearings. They did not write imploring letters to elected officials, push to see the mayor, go before legislative bodies to speak. They did not do those sorts of things.

title: Humor, Locked and Loaded
description: Is this the year the Academy Awards finally gave comedy some respect?

title: Evening Hours | Out in the Snow
description: The weather didnt keep partygoers at home.

title: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
description: Topping Up Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow. Early last week, men on their way to work started out with no hats, no scarves and coats flapping open. By Friday, you could only see their eyes. One man wore fur trousers, top left. Another wrapped himself in a carpet, while the garment district tailor continued to stitch away. In Bryant Park, a man stood over the open fire pit. For some, a fedora was enough, and a black topcoat set off red kid gloves.

title: Martin Marietta Materials in Merger Talks With Texas Industries
description: Martin Marietta Materials, a big producer of sand and gravel, is in late-stage talks to acquire Texas Industries, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Fruit Fly Brothers Tend to Cooperate
description: In pursuit of a mate, male fruit flies often engage in combat, battling one another with their front legs.

title: For Sea Scallops, the Bare Minimum
description: Sea scallops are one of winters divine treats, and one of the best places to enjoy them is Paris. In every fish market there, you see great piles of them on display, still in the shell, ready to be shucked to order.

title: Submerging Markets
description: Currencies in formerly fast-growing emerging markets have been falling sharply this week. The Argentine peso and the Turkish lira, for example, were each down more than 1 percent against the dollar on Friday afternoon.

title: That Positive Feeling, and Why Its Shared
description: AFTER READING Maria Konnikovas fascinating post in The New Yorker about what makes stories go viral, I wondered if designers were thinking more and more along the lines she described when they create collections.

title: Flood Ebbs, Insurance Woes Dont
description: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., isnt the only one complaining that her Hurricane Sandy relief money has been held hostage.

title: Architect Goes Home, to Recall and to Work
description: Richard Meier is returning to his roots with two new developments in New Jersey, where he grew up.

title: In Nuns Suit, Justices Block Key Mandate in Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday extended a temporary order from Justice Sonia Sotomayor barring the Obama administration from enforcing the contraception coverage requirement of the Affordable Care Act against an order of Roman Catholic nuns.

title: How Henry Hudson Got His Perch
description: In the Jan. 12 Metropolitan section, Lisa W. Foderaro wrote a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot New York City. We asked readers to post their comments and questions about New York monuments on the City Room blog, and enlisted Jonathan Kuhn, NYC Parks director of art and antiquities, to answer the queries. Here, a selection from the online conversation, edited and condensed.

title: The Sexual Healer
description: On the subject of sex, a subject that makes so many stammer, clam up or crack wise, Esther Perel, a couples therapist and author, is uncommonly eloquent, even rhapsodic. That particular rhetorical gift is apparently in high demand: Last July, Ms. Perel gave an opening talk at Summit Outside, a three-day meeting of 900 entrepreneurs and creative types held on Powder Mountain in Eden, Utah.

title: A Firebird, a Mermaid and a Bit of Mozart
description: The Russian conductor Andrey Boreykos stock is evidently riding high at the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Boreyko, 56, who made his debut with the orchestra in 2007 and has since returned regularly, is about to complete his second consecutive subscription week at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Lets Change the World. Cheers!
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Around midnight on Wednesday, Nicolas Berggruen, the billionaire investor, philanthropist and art collector, walked into a loud party in a cozy Swiss chalet co-hosted by Jimmy Wales, a founder of Wikipedia. As dance music blared and colored lights played on the ceiling, Mr. Berggruen greeted Boris Johnson, the mayor of London.

title: The Hillary Clinton Covers Planetary Disruption
description: For The Times, the good news is that its magazine cover featuring Hillary Rodham Clinton as a planet is generating all kinds of buzz even before its distribution with Sundays paper.

title: After Hours | An Opera Finds Pathos in the Milli Vanilli Saga
description: The deconstructed, multiroom opera Wow (Work in Progress) at BRIC Arts in Brooklyn, about the late-80s rise and fall of Milli Vanilli, isnt the first to wring classical tragedy from modern-day cultural calamity  the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage did it with pieces about Anna Nicole Smith and Jerry Springer  but it might be the strangest. The creative trio of Joe Diebes, Christian Hawkey and David Levine cast the story of the braided European pop duo, who fell from grace when it was revealed that theyd been lip-syncing all along, as a postmodern tragedy about two handsome nafs devoured by the pop-culture machine.

title: Unreleased Miles Davis Performances to Be Released
description: Two hours of previously unreleased performances by Miles Davis, leading a band that included Chick Corea, Keith Jarrett, Dave Holland, Airto Moreira and Steve Grossman, will be included in Miles at the Fillmore  Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 3, a four-CD set to be released by Columbia/Legacy on March 25.

title: Ales of The Times: Belgian Pale Ales
description: The Belgians make a lot of beers that defy categorization. The tasting panel gathered 23 that have one thing in common: they are excellent summer quenchers.

title: Pastoral Icon or Woolly Menace?
description: YOU dont have to look far to see the woolly influence of sheep on our cultural lives. They turn up as symbols of peace and a vaguely remembered pastoral way of life in our poetry, our art and our Christmas pageants. Wolves also rank high among our cultural icons, usually in connection with the words big and bad. And yet there is now a debate underway about substituting the wolf for the sheep on the (also iconic) green hills of Britain.

title: Judge Orders Hospital to Remove Pregnant Woman From Life Support
description: FORT WORTH  A Texas judge ruled Friday that a Fort Worth hospital may not keep a brain-dead pregnant woman on life support against her familys wishes, and ordered doctors to take her off the machines by 5 p.m. on Monday.

title: For Banking Group, Australian Open Becomes a Marketing Opportunity in China
description: An avid tennis fan and amateur player, Katrina Taylor was watching the fourth-seeded Li Na at the Australian Open when she noticed something odd: The courtside signage was in Chinese.

title: Everyone Wants a Piece of This Wandering Monster
description: Mary Shelleys famous motherless child enters the angels-and-demons world of an apparent franchise bid in I, Frankenstein. Stuart Beatties solemn, ho-hum film largely shuns Shelleys anguished creator as a character and turns his lonely monster into a football between the forces of good and evil: protective gargoyles and demons who covet his secret to immortality.

title: Quietly Ascending Rocks Peaks
description: How things become popular is never less than a mystery, and in the age of the post-genre ecosystem, of the YouTube sensation, what becomes popular isnt nearly as legible as it once was. What was once fringe is now mainstream, what was mainstream is now fringe.

title: Collector Auctions Suggest Recovery Is Nearly Complete
description: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ.  The classic-car auctions here last week were remarkable for not being especially remarkable: No bubbles burst, and neither did the market make another vertical leap.

title: Needs Some T.L.C. Proves a Powerful Boost to Prices
description: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ.  The sales results from the major collector-car auctions that wrapped up here last week included a long list of record prices and strong indications that the recovery of a market battered by the recession was nearly complete.

title: Revelatory Archive of a Giant of Jazz
description: WASHINGTON  Max Roach, the great drummer and bandleader and paradigm-shifter of jazz, though he disliked that word, never finished an autobiography.

title: Desert Stars
description: This years Arizona auctions offered no huge surprises, though the high prices realized by a few barn finds proved that originality is becoming an ever more prized attribute.

title: Versatility on Screen and Off
description: NAME Amy Adams

title: Red Carpet Watch: Amy Adamss Fashion
description: Ms. Adams, who was in three films last year, has a style that is versatile on and off the screen.

title: Museums Follow the Call of a Clooney Movie
description: Theres nothing like the advent of a George Clooney movie to put historical institutions on a war footing. Timed to coincide with the Feb. 7 release of The Monuments Men, about the heroics of the soldiers and scholars who chased after European cultural treasures plundered by the Nazis, both the Smithsonian Institution and the National WWII Museum in New Orleans announced new ventures. The New Orleans museum said it would open a permanent gallery about the unit in 2016. It will show, among other things, how the soldiers descended into an Austrian salt mine to recover masterpieces hoarded there by Germans. The exhibition will highlight the recovery of works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Picasso and Leonardo da Vinci and the continuing search for works like Raphaels Portrait of a Young Man and Michelangelos marble Mask of a Faun. Meanwhile in Washington on Feb. 7, the Smithsonian Institutions Archives of American Art will open an exhibition called Monuments Men: On the Frontline to Save Europes Art, 1942-1946. It will showcase the work of the scholars in the original unit, one of whom is played by Mr. Clooney.

title: The District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.
description: The District 3 Winter Regional took place at the Hilton hotel in Rye Brook, N.Y., from Jan. 14 through last Monday.

title: Times Minute | Markets Take a Hit
description: Also on the Minute, Bob McDonnell's fall and Thug-Notes for the classics.

title: Times Minute | Markets Take a Hit
description: In the Video

title: The Company I Keep
description: The very title of this blog suggests the continual shifting of ground underneath all of us of a certain age. Whatever we thought old age meant yesterday, it means something different today.

title: By the Numbers: Oscars Track Record With Black Filmmakers
description: By the numbers, the Oscars are still a tough game for black filmmakers.

title: On the Horizon: Berlin International Film Festival; This Is Not a Silent Movie
description: Film On Feb. 6, the 64th Berlin International Film Festival, or Berlinale, will begin . The film festival will award lifetime honors to the British director Ken Loach and feature over 400 films, including the world premiere of The Monuments Men, about an Allied group who recovered stolen artworks from the Nazis, with George Clooney and Matt Damon.

title: Sympathy for the Toffs
description: Last year, we turned on the plutocrats. Everyone from Pope Francis to Bill de Blasio denounced them. Even Bill and Hillary Clinton, erstwhile champions of pro-business centrism and donor sleepovers at the White House, decided it was prudent to jump on the populist bandwagon. So why are we still smitten with the toffs of Downton Abbey?

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 24
description: Subjects include carriage horses in Central Park, the swearing-in ceremony for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and sledding in a Queens park.

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 24
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include carriage horses in Central Park, the swearing-in ceremony for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and sledding in a Queens park.

title: The Collections | The Top 10 Items from Fall/Winter 2014 Mens Trade Shows
description: The polar vortexs return this week was a nuisance to most New Yorkers, but it provided optimal conditions for appreciating the Fall/Winter 2014 wares on offer at the mens clothing and lifestyle trade showsMAN, Capsule and Project. Among the heritage and camping-supply items that usually abound at these events, a few new lines stood out. Below are the 10 best pieces  some basic, some inclement-weather specific, but all refreshingly new.

title: Google Pushes Back Against Data Localization
description: The big tech companies have put forth a united front when it comes to pushing back against the government after revelations of mass surveillance. But their cooperation goes only so far.

title: Letter to Obama From American Detained in Egypt
description: Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen whose Egyptian father belongs to the Muslim Brotherhood, was detained in Cairo in August, as our colleague David Kirkpatrick reported last year.

title: Distrust in America, War in Syria and Protests in Ukraine
description: In a speech on Jan. 17, President Obama spoke of the challenge of a world that is remaking itself at a dizzying speed. The subject of his address at the Justice Department was the complex issues of security, privacy and the limits of government power raised by revelations about the National Security Agencys spying. That debate continued to rage through the last week. But Mr. Obama could have been speaking as well about conflicts in places like Syria and Ukraine, which seemed to become more intractable with every effort at resolution.

title: Video of Deadly Bombing in Cairo
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, at least six people were killed and 70 injured in a string of four bombings that targeted police installations across Cairo on Friday. A closed-circuit television camera captured video of the largest blast, a car bomb, which exploded outside the citys main police headquarters, killing four and badly damaging a museum and library. The bombers responsible for the attack were also briefly captured on video.

title: Natural Gas Prices Soar as Mercury Plummets
description: HOUSTON  Natural gas prices spiked by nearly 10 percent on Friday to levels not seen since 2010 as another wave of freezing weather brought surges of heating and electricity demand.

title: The Politics of How to Pay for Pre-K
To Stop Another Snowden
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Prices in 20 Cities
description: An interactive graphic showing how home prices have changed since you bought your home.

title: A Spike in Options Trading Before Herbalifes Stock Fell
description: Last week, before a senator released letters that sent the shares of Herbalife into a tailspin, certain investors were positioning themselves to make money if the stock fell.

description: To the Editor:

title: Congress and the Climate
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
