description: To the Editor:

title: Klinsmann Tweaks Roster for South Korea Game
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States mens national team, on Friday dropped five players and added one to the roster for the final week of the teams winter training camp.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Tempest
description: No, I havent forgotten  but I wasnt going to post until I finished that single-malt.

title: Walmart Will Lay Off 2,300 Sams Club Workers
description: Walmart announced on Friday that about 2,300 Sams Club employees would be laid off, the latest in a drumbeat of retail job cuts to start off the new year.

title: What Money Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Endangered Elephants
description: To the Editor:

title: House G.O.P. Leaders Aim to Bridge Partys Divisions to Avoid Debt Limit Face-Off
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner will seek to emerge from a three-day House Republican retreat next week with a diminished opposition inside his party to avoid a showdown in the 11 legislative days that remain before the federal government exhausts its borrowing authority.

title: Kasparov Discloses Election Contracts
description: Garry Kasparov, a former chess world champion who is running for president of the World Chess Federation, released previously confidential agreements Friday involving himself and one of the officials who is part of his slate of candidates to lead the organization.

title: Writer Tells Africa What He Couldnt Tell Mum
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  WHEN the Kenyan author Binyavanga Wainaina published his acclaimed memoir three years ago, he concealed an important part of his life from the public eye. Last Saturday, he unveiled a lost chapter of the book on the Internet titled, I am a homosexual, mum.

title: White House Comeback for Political Affairs Office
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has decided to bring politics back into the White House.

title: The Elders of Organic Farming
description: BIG SUR, Calif.  Among the sleek guests who meditate and do Downward Facing Dog here at the Esalen Institute, the farmers appeared to be out of place. They wore baggy jeans, suspenders and work boots and had long ago let their hair go gray.

title: New Commissioner Has Ties to Sherlock, via Barbados
description: Stacey Cumberbatch, New Yorks new commissioner of citywide administrative services, is great at untangling bureaucratic knots and a proud granddaughter of Caribbean immigrants, Mayor Bill de Blasio said in naming her to the job on Friday.

title: Northwestern Coach Returns to His Roots
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  On the morning after he earned his first Big Ten Conference win last week, Northwestern Coach Chris Collins sat in his office, a sparsely decorated room that overlooks a practice court inside Welsh-Ryan Arena.

title: South Sudanese Rebels Accuse Government of Ignoring Day-Old Cease-Fire
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  South Sudanese rebels said that government forces had attacked several of their positions on Friday, a day after a cease-fire was signed that was supposed to bring an end to a monthlong conflict that shook the new country and displaced hundreds of thousands of its citizens.

title: On Childrens Website, N.S.A. Puts a Furry, Smiley Face on Its Mission
description: WASHINGTON  The turtle wearing a hat backward, baggy jeans and purple sunglasses looks just like other cartoon characters that marketers use to make products like cereal and toys appealing to children.

title: Do Not Adjust Your Set: Super Bowl Snow May Be Real
description: For months, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell has urged football fans to embrace the cold and has all but dared the weather gods to make it snow on Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Irans Message at Davos Has Eerie Echo
description: WASHINGTON  When President Hassan Rouhani of Iran commandeered the spotlight this week in Davos, Switzerland, with a message of peaceful intentions and a desire for dialogue, it was an eerie echo of 10 years ago, when Irans last would-be change agent, Mohammad Khatami, delivered the very same message at the World Economic Forum.

title: Ex-Governor of Virginia and Wife Plead Not Guilty to Corruption
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, emerged hand in hand from federal court after pleading not guilty on Friday to corruption charges that could send them to prison for more than 20 years if they are convicted.

title: When Long-Form Is Bad Form
description: LAST week, the sports and pop culture website Grantland published a story called Dr. Vs Magical Putter  a piece of long-form, as we now call multi-thousand-word, narrative-driven reported articles  about a woman named Essay Anne Vanderbilt, who claimed to have invented a golf putter of unsurpassed excellence.

title: F.B.I. Audit of Database That Indexes DNA Finds Errors in Profiles
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in a review of a national DNA database, has identified nearly 170 profiles that probably contain errors, some the result of handwriting mistakes or interpretation errors by lab technicians, while New York State authorities have turned up mistakes in DNA profiles in New Yorks database.

title: Kerry Presses Iranians to Prove Nuclear Work Is for Peaceful Purposes
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  One day after Irans president took the stage here seeking to assure the world that his country did not aspire to develop nuclear weapons, Secretary of State John Kerry pushed back on Friday, challenging him to demonstrate that the Iranian nuclear program was peaceful.

title: Greek Orthodox Rally Support for Troubled Home
description: Dosed up on Tylenol and Advil after three days in bed with the flu, Valerie Markou paced the terrazzo floor of a catering hall in Queens. She carried a gold paper shopping bag, selling the raffle tickets it contained and tucking away the $20 bills she received in return.

title: Michigan: University Names New President
description: The University of Michigan regents on Friday named the universitys next president, Mark S. Schlissel, the provost of Brown University and a former dean of biological sciences at the University of California, Berkeley. Dr. Schlissel, 56, a biomedical researcher specializing in immunology, will take over one of the nations largest and most prestigious universities, which ranks second in research spending, behind only Johns Hopkins University. He will succeed Mary Sue Coleman, who is retiring after 12 years as president, on July 1. Dr. Schlissel graduated from Princeton and earned M.D. and Ph.D. degrees at Johns Hopkins.

title: Huckabee Spills the Beans
description: Its not often we think about Mike Huckabee. True, he has a talk show. But so does half the world. Kelly Ripa has a talk show. Geraldo Rivera has a talk show. How often do they come up in conversation?

title: Star Envoys Frankness Puts Kennedy Mystique to Test in Japan
description: TOKYO  Japan went into a collective swoon two months ago when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States ambassador. The appointment of someone with such celebrity appeal  who offered a living link to a golden age when America was still reassuringly strong and confident  appeared to be proof that Washington was finally giving Japan the embrace it craved.

title: Arizona: Challenge to Housing for the Deaf Is Dropped
description: The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development ended a two-year legal dispute on Friday with the state and a private developer of subsidized housing, which it had accused of discrimination for favoring the deaf and the hard-of-hearing over others seeking to live in a 75-unit complex for the elderly built to fit the needs of the deaf. In a letter, HUD officials said that the type of federal funding used to build the complex, Apache ASL Trails, in Tempe, did not prevent it from giving preference to a specific group of disabled individuals. The agency closed its investigation and removed its legal challenges against the development, which was designed by a deaf architect and offers video phones and lights that flash when the phone or doorbell rings at each unit, among other features.

title: Kiev Cease-Fire Ends
description: David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, Ukraine, where fighting has resumed between antigovernment protestors and the riot police, not far from the Dynamo soccer stadium.

title: The Song Remains the Same (and Kind of Blue)
description: If you grew up in the 1970s and you loved 70s rock as much as I did, then there is a good chance you saw the Led Zeppelin concert film, The Song Remains the Same. The film documents a 1973 Zeppelin concert at Madison Square Garden and played in theaters throughout the late 70s and after. It became an almost instant cult classic, bringing my favorite rock band ever to life, with only a trip to the local theater.

title: Irans Charm Offensive
description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran made his debut this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he expanded on his governments charm offensive by wooing investors and reassuring political leaders of his determination to complete a comprehensive nuclear deal with the major powers. But his benign image and deft political skills could not erase or excuse the ugly fact that Iran remains the main ally of Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, in the destruction of Syria and its people.

title: Dividing the Bank Settlement
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has deservedly lost Round 1 of the unnecessary fight he picked recently with the New York State attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, over the distribution of proceeds from a bank settlement. To persist in his pique could hurt all New Yorkers.

title: A Hidden Threat in the Farm Bill
description: The mammoth farm bill is reportedly near a conference compromise in Congress, bristling with more tragic cuts in the food stamp program for the needy and a revision of lucrative commodity subsidies for mostly big farmers. Running below the radar is a dangerous, broadly written amendment that would threaten states current powers to enact their own agricultural standards  standards that can extend far beyond farmyards to consumer, worker and environmental safety.

title: Carmelo Anthony Scores 62 Points, Setting a Knicks Record
description: Carmelo Anthony did not need to scream, dance, pump his fists or point skyward after his 45-foot heave at the halftime buzzer went through the net at Madison Square Garden on Friday. His expression  eyes staring ahead, lips slightly puckered, nostrils flaring  said enough about his emotions on this night.

title: Zero Traffic Fatalities
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to bring the number of traffic deaths in New York City from just short of 300 a year to zero, or close to zero, in 10 years. Thats a laudable and ambitious goal, and hes willing to change lots of things to get there: lower speed limits, more rigorous enforcement of existing laws, better street engineering to slow traffic.

title: Spread the Happy
description: Administrivial Alert! If you thought the Kevin G. Der puzzle that ran on the web on January 17 and in print on January 24 was just any old themeless puzzle, guess again. Mr. Ders puzzle was part of a much larger puzzle in the M.I.T. Mystery Hunt, and the idea behind it was quite elegant. You can read about his nefarious plans here.

title: Gaza Man Shot to Death in Border Clash With Israeli Military, Palestinians Say
description: GAZA  Palestinian officials said that the Israeli military killed a 20-year-old Gaza man and wounded six others near the border fence on Friday evening, the latest in a series of violent exchanges that have frayed a fragile 14-month-old cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, the militant Islamic faction that rules the Gaza Strip.

title: A Mob Life, on the Margins and Out of Favor
description: You think youve got problems?

title: Olympic Fears Rattle Athletes and Families
description: Athletes and their families are becoming increasingly anxious about possible terrorist attacks at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, so much so that some families have decided not to attend and others plan to curtail their activities once they get to the Games in Russia.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 25, 2014
description: The timing is a message that the third anniversary of the revolution will not be a celebration; they want to color it with blood.

title: The Penance of Glenn Beck
description: This week Glenn Beck said something I agree with. (Now, theres a line I never thought Id write.) During an interview on Tuesday with Megyn Kelly of Fox News, Beck reflected on his time at Fox this way:

title: Welcome or Not, 4,000 Football Fans Will Be Afloat at a Hudson River Pier
description: For five days next week  before, during and after Super Bowl XLVIII  the roster of hotels in New York will grow by one. The citys newest hotel will have almost as many rooms for guests as the New York Hilton or the Marriott Marquis, two of the largest hotels in the city.

title: For the Mentally Ill, Its Worse
description: Last week, one of the landmark nonfiction books of the last 50 years was reissued by Vintage Books. Is There No Place on Earth for Me? by Susan Sheehan began in 1981 as a four-part series in The New Yorker; in 1982, it came out as a book, winning the Pulitzer Prize.

title: U.S. Catholics Hope for 2015 Papal Visit
description: Pope Francis may make his first trip as pope to the United States in September 2015 to attend the Roman Catholic Churchs World Meeting of Families in Philadelphia. Popes traditionally attend these events, which have been held every three years since 1994. We are planning as if Pope Francis will be with us and have no indication that he will not attend, said Kenneth A. Gavin, a spokesman for the archdiocese of Philadelphia. But he added that any reports that Francis would make the trip are not official. There is speculation that Francis would stop in New York on that same trip to speak to the United Nations General Assembly, but Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese of New York, said the archdiocese had not heard anything from the Vatican. The last papal visit to the United States was in April 2008, when Pope Benedict XVI traveled to Washington and New York.

title: Corrections: January 25, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: N.H.L. Expanding Outdoor Boundaries With Game at Dodger Stadium
description: LOS ANGELES  In the N.H.L.s latest outdoor affair, there will be few tuques on heads and plenty of sweaters tied around waists when the Los Angeles Kings and the Anaheim Ducks square off at Dodger Stadium on Saturday night.

title: At Yankee Stadium, Rangers Will Share Glamour With Rivals
description: A giant New York City subway map adorns the outfield grass. A childrens hockey rink bounded by blocks of ice covers the home-plate area. Large crests of the Rangers and Devils rest atop the two dugouts. Stretching between first base and third is the rink itself, glinting bright under a cold winter sun.

title: In the Absence of Their Owner, the Nets Hang On
description: Early Friday night, Mark Cuban, the outspoken and seemingly omnipresent owner of the Dallas Mavericks, directed some thinly veiled criticisms toward Mikhail D. Prokhorov, his Nets counterpart, saying he could not imagine how anyone could manage a team from thousands of miles away.

title: Simmering Tension on a Corner, and Then a Fire
description: The potter opened the door of her studio in Gowanus, Brooklyn, one morning eight months ago, as she had for decades, but this time she stopped short. Something was wrong  black smudges marked her wooden floor, and a thick stench hung in the big room.

title: Rangers on Road in the Bronx? Money May Be Why
description: An unusual aspect of the N.H.L.s two outdoor games at Yankee Stadium is that the Rangers have been designated the road team for both games, even though their opponents, the Devils and the Islanders, come from outside New York City.

title: Golf Trade Show Bounces Back With the Economy
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When six salesmen arrived for the 1954 P.G.A. Senior Championship in Dunedin, Fla., they lined up their products around a practice green for the pros to see. They had no idea that what they were doing would someday become the worlds largest annual golf trade show.

title: A Fit of Jealousy, a Lack of Child Car Seats, and Then Three Deadly Stabbings
description: After killing his wife in a jealous rage, officials said, Miguel Mejia-Ramos went over to his two young daughters, still lying in their beds at the familys home in Queens. His intention, he would tell detectives, was to spare the children.

title: The Mets Sign Matsuzaka to a Minor League Deal
description: Two days after the Yankees snared Masahiro Tanaka with a seven-year, $155 million contract, the Mets announced Friday that they, too, had signed a Japanese right-hander, but for a lot less money.

title: Breaking It Down: Nadal vs. Federer
description: Rafael Nadal would make an excellent stone cutter. He is incredibly gifted at first finding a crack and then unceasingly hammering away at it until he finally breaks the stone in victory.

title: Bicyclist Killed by a Bus Rose Above Usual Anonymity of Deliverymen in the City
description: In life, he was another anonymous bicycle deliveryman who traveled the streets of New York City. To many pedestrians he was no more than a nuisance, and to his customers, never fast enough.

title: U.S. Cites Evidence of Anti-Semitism in School District
description: Federal authorities say evidence collected in a lawsuit filed by three Jewish families against an upstate New York school district is sufficient for a jury to find that the district failed to respond to pervasive anti-Semitic harassment in its schools by taking required action under a civil rights law.

title: South Bronx Students May Have Found Site of Slave Burial Ground
description: In a snow-covered park in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx, an enclosed cemetery in the parks center evokes a much different neighborhood from the one now jammed with auto-glass shops and wholesale produce markets. Headstones engraved with Hunt and Leggett hark back to the 18th and 19th centuries, when prominent New York families had mansions in the still-rural Bronx.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 24, 2014
Pictures From the Week in Business
description: An unexpected loss at Deutsche Bank, new safety guidelines for transporting crude oil by rail and states cutting extended unemployment benefits.

title: Ed Hookstratten, Forceful Advocate for the Stars, Dies at 83
description: Ed Hookstratten, an unapologetically aggressive lawyer and agent for entertainers and sports figures including Elvis Presley, Johnny Carson, Tom Brokaw and the football coach George Allen, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

title: Sarah Marshall, Actress in Twilight Zone and Star Trek, Dies at 80
description: Sarah Marshall, an actress who was born into show business and worked on Broadway, in film and on television, perhaps most memorably in episodes of The Twilight Zone and Star Trek, died on Jan. 18 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 7 P.M. (Starz) THIS IS THE END (2013) A group of funny guys  among them, from left above, James Franco, Jonah Hill, Craig Robinson, Seth Rogen, Jay Baruchel and Danny McBride, each playing himself gather at a party at Mr. Francos house in Los Angeles, during which events foretold in the Book of Revelation occur. The righteous are raptured up to heaven; the rest, including many of the most famous people in Hollywood, are swallowed into fiery pits or pursued by horned demons. The movie, written and directed by Mr. Rogen and Evan Goldberg, at its phoned-in worst and also at its riotous best, has a terminal feeling, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. It suggests that a comic subgenre based on the immaturity, sexual panic and self-mocking tendencies of men who should be old enough to know better has reached its expiration date. But, as crude as the movies humor often is, its spirit is sweet, sensitive and innocuous. In their script for Superbad, Mr. Rogen and Mr. Goldberg zeroed in on the tenderness and vulnerability that lie at the heart of male friendship, and here they go even further, using the prospect of global annihilation as an occasion for some touchy-feely relationship workshopping.

title: A Scene to Warm a Penguins Heart
Wawrinka Savors Advance to Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  On Friday, the day after Stanislas Wawrinka advanced to his first-ever Grand Slam final, he visited a museum here. He sought out one exhibit: Designing 007, Fifty Years of Bond Style.

title: Clashes Kill 49 Egyptians on Uprisings Anniversary
description: CAIRO  Thousands of Egyptians celebrated the third anniversary of their revolt against autocracy on Saturday by holding a rally for the military leader who ousted the countrys first democratically elected president. Elsewhere, at least 49 people died in clashes with security forces at rival antigovernment protests organized by Islamists and left-leaning activists.

title: Li Wins Australian Title in Battle of Baseline, Then Serves Up Punch Lines
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In the immediate aftermath of most Grand Slam championships, the winners spout the usual clichs, shed a few tears and thank everyone they ever met and some people they do not know. There must be a manual for such occasions: thank, cry, clich, repeat.

title: China Accuses Uighur Intellectual of Separatism for His Advocacy Work
description: BEIJING  In an ominous sign of the fate awaiting one of Chinas best-known Uighur intellectuals, security officials in the far western region of Xinjiang issued a statement on Saturday that accused him of separatism and inciting ethnic hatred.

title: Valley of the Blahs: How Justin Biebers Troubles Exposed Twitters Achilles Heel
description: At some point, Twitter and the rest of social media became less about wanting to share the news and more about wanting to be the news.

title: Lonnie Holley, in His Alabama Yard-Art Element
description: For 18 years, the Atlanta-based documentary filmmaker George King has been shooting Lonnie Holley, an artist and musician that I write about in this weekends magazine. King has mined the footage to make a video for Looking for All (All Rendered Truth), a song from Holleys 2012 debut album, Just Before Music. If, like me, youve met Holley only recently, the footage is fascinating to watch, offering glimpses of the artist as a young man: showing off his intricate sandstone sculptures or wandering amid the scavenged materials  a baby doll, a Dead End sign, a lawn jockey, a wrecked car, a childs dress  in his Alabama yard-art environment. (There are also shots of a bulldozer tearing the place down, after it was condemned by the airport authority.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: January 24, 2014
description: Digital currency is inching its way onto Wall Street, with a new Bitcoin center next door to the New York Stock Exchange. As the currency gains prominence and popularity, regulatorslike New Yorks Department of Financial Services, which is holding hearings next weekare trying to work out where they figure in. Joe talks about the future of Bitcoin, while Rana Foroohar of Time magazine reports from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Variety: A Surprising Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  My goodness, what a surprising quote. The next time I go to buy a silk blouse, Ill have to remember to check to see if it smells like goat.

title: Syrias Shaky Peace Talks Move Toward Solid Ground in Effort to Aid Homs
description: GENEVA  The Syrian government and opposition moved their fragile peace talks to a newly concrete phase on Saturday, meeting face to face here for the first time in an attempt to win government approval for an aid convoy to neighborhoods in the city of Homs long blockaded by the army.

title: In a Transition Game, David Stern Is Passing the N.B.A. Commissioners Hat to Adam Silver
description: David Stern stepped into a conference room through a side door from his office. He carried a can of soda and a small plate of tortilla chips.

title: Doctors Abusing Medicare Face Fines and Expulsion
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is cracking down on doctors who repeatedly overcharge Medicare patients, and for the first time in more than 30 years the government may disclose how much is paid to individual doctors treating Medicare patients.

title: A Different Game, but the Knicks Present Resembles Its Past
description: On Christmas night 1984, Bernard King set a Knicks record by scoring 60 points against the New Jersey Nets at Madison Square Garden. The N.B.A. game then was quite different from the one Carmelo Anthony toyed with while breaking Kings mark with 62 points in Friday nights victory against Charlotte.

title: Three Dead in Shooting at Maryland Mall; Police Call the Episode Isolated
description: COLUMBIA, Md.  Shots rang out at a popular shopping mall in this suburb between Washington and Baltimore on Saturday morning, sending shoppers running from stores and hiding under tables in the food court.

title: The Tale of a House, and an Entire Market
description: In 1990, almost a million houses were built in the United States. One of them, at 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., was a four-bedroom colonial with a bay window. The average home price that year was $150,000; this house, in a desirable middle-class suburb of Washington, sold for $227,140.

title: In Six Houses, a Market Mirror
description: All over the country, house prices are rising. But in some regions, prices are recovering from much deeper troughs. Below are six houses that were sold several times in the last few years, reflecting the overall market trends in their metropolitan areas.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 26
description: For a nine-month-old company to buy a 93-year-old one is a lot to bite off.

title: The Insufferable Colleague
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Ill Be Your Billboard
A Super Bowl Estimate With a Life of Its Own
description: The Super Bowl will be just great for New York and New Jersey! Thats what the National Football League and local tourism officials and politicians say, anyway.

title: Noreen Beaman of Brinker Capital, on Accountability
description: This interview with  Noreen D. Beaman, chief executive of Brinker Capital, based in Berwyn, Pa., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Seahawks Richard Sherman Is Much More Than Just Talk
description: COMPTON, Calif.  Darryl Smith was dividing the pizzas among the boys track and field athletes of Dominguez High School when he first heard the voice he would never forget. It belonged to this scrawny, knock-kneed eighth grader who had tagged along with his older brother, who was eating all the slices and dominating all the conversations and somehow, it seemed, doing both at once.

title: Asking Banks to Reveal Where Their High Rollers Are
description: For investors who held stakes in large and complex financial institutions in 2008, the perils lurking inside these behemoths came as a costly shock.

title: Caption This Photo: Richard Sherman
description: After the N.F.C. Championship game, Richard Shermans postgame rant drew comparisons to the sports worlds biggest talkers, from John McEnroe to Muhammad Ali. If Sherman truly is one of the greats in that category, he has probably been honing the skill his entire life. Help us conjure what Sherman the toddler, shown in this photo, was saying as the photographer took the shot.

title: The Gadfly of Greenwich Real Estate
description: As he drives his white pickup truck past the manors that crowd the hills and meadows along Round Hill Road in Greenwich, Conn.  a town that has long signified what it means to be rich in America  Christopher Fountain snorts.

title: The Tale of the $8 Million Bargain House in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  In the always fraught market for over-the-top mansions in Greenwich, one mans pain can quickly become another mans gain.

title: In Housing, Big Is Back (Not Counting the Extras)
description: Katie Sleep and her husband, Jonathan, lived in the same four-bedroom home in a Washington suburb for 23 years. After Ms. Sleep decided to retire, they began looking for a new house, and, after viewing a model home in a new development, decided to move to Leesburg, Va., about 40 miles from the city. In having their new home built, they saw an opportunity  not to downsize, but to create a far larger home catering to their every need.

title: A Lawyer Who Lets the Funkiness In
description: A study in orange

title: Video and Tweets on Maryland Shopping Mall Shooting
description: Updated, 4:48 p.m. As my colleagues, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jada F. Smith, reported, the police say three people died in a shooting, including the gunman, at a shopping mall in Columbia, Md.

title: Delivering Passes, if Not Wins, at L.I.U. Brooklyn
description: Jason Brickman, a 5-foot-11 senior point guard for Long Island University Brooklyn, burst toward midcourt and bounced a perfect diagonal pass to D. J. Griggs between two Fairleigh Dickinson defenders running full speed. Griggs, surprised when the basketball reached his hands just outside the lane, made a layup. But he was called for traveling, negating the basket.

title: Rand Paul Making Headlines
description: Senator Rand Paul has established himself as a national figure over the past 12 months, raising the question of whether he will campaign for the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

title: Opposition Says No to Ukraine on Power Share
description: KIEV, Ukraine  In a striking concession aimed at defusing Ukraines civil uprising and preserving his own grip on power, President Viktor F. Yanukovych on Saturday offered to install opposition leaders in top posts in a reshaped government, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street craving a fuller victory in the days ahead.

title: Once Successful as a Player, but More Fulfilled as a Father
description: SAN DIEGO  After his opening round at the Farmers Insurance Open, Chris Riley joked that he felt like the San Diego Chargers backup quarterback Charlie Whitehurst being thrust into action in the postseason. If Riley felt rusty, and a little rattled, it was understandable. Before Thursday, his last PGA Tour start was in August.

title: Social Responsibility Weighs Heavy on Economic Chieftains at Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  With all that vexing talk about inequality, do the worlds plutocrats need a cuddle?

title: Preventing the Next Data Breach
description: The alarming discovery that hackers stole the credit card and personal information of tens of millions of Americans from Targets computers is yet another reminder of human vulnerability in the digital age. The more practical and immediate lesson, however, is that retailers, banks and other corporations can do far more than they have done so far to protect customers from identity theft and financial fraud.

title: More Imperfect Unions
description: WHENEVER the subject turns to inequality and opportunity in America, the same political conversation repeats itself.

title: Talking Sexual Violence Without Giving Offense
description: Its rare to hear politicians at the national level discuss sexual violence. Its even rarer to hear them discuss it with real sensitivity. Yet President Obama and Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. managed exactly that last Wednesday, when they announced a task force on campus rape  an area of particular concern. A 2007 study found that one in five women had been sexually assaulted in college.

title: Yancey Strickler
description: Yancey Strickler is the chief executive of the crowdfunding site Kickstarter, which raises more than $1 million a day to pay for various posted projects.
IF youre confused about all the turmoil in the Arab world and asking how the United States should respond, I find it useful to consider three questions:

title: Just the Facts, Maam No More
description: ITS a Monday morning in mid-January. Your print edition of The Times is at hand, along with your coffee. You scan it for news. But, for the most part, you scan in vain.

title: The Koch Party
description: Only a few weeks into this midterm election year, the right-wing political zeppelin is fully inflated with secret cash and is firing malicious falsehoods at supporters of health care reform.

title: 3 Enemas Later, Still No Drugs
description: IF you think that protests about overzealous law enforcement are over the top, listen to what unfolded when the police suspected that David Eckert, 54, was hiding drugs in his rectum.

title: The Myth of Industrial Rebound
description: WITH metronomic regularity, gauzy accounts extol the return of manufacturing jobs to the United States.

title: Revealed: The Actual Fort Lee Traffic Study
Too Many Slackers?
description: Readers respond to a column that said many students today dont make the effort to excel.

title: Now Playing in Denver: Reefer Gladness
description: DENVER  SO you want to get high in a high-end way in the Mile High City.

title: The Franchising of Al Qaeda
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  THE letter bore the corporate tone of a C.E.O. resolving a turf dispute between two middle managers. In formal prose and numbered lists, Ayman al-Zawahri, the leader of Al Qaeda, directed one of the groups affiliates in Syria to withdraw to Iraq and leave operations in Syria to someone else.

title: The Shopping List as Policy Tool
description: WASHINGTON  THE federal government spends around $500 billion annually on goods and services. So when Uncle Sam throws his weight around, markets move.

title: Having the Right Size, Not the Most Size, Fuels the Nets
description: Last season, no factor correlated more to Nets victories than whether Brook Lopez played. On both sides of the court, the Nets never found a way to suitably replace him. When Lopez was injured last December, the Nets lost five straight and Coach Avery Johnson was fired.

title: Chinas New Obsession: French Wine
description: BORDEAUX, France  WHEN the Bordeaux International Wine Institute, which offers business management training in the oenological arts, opened its doors in 2004, it had 20 students, mostly from domestic French wineries. Today it has 105.

title: None So Blind, Macroeconomics Division
description: Noah Smith reminds us of a quarter-century-old diatribe by Robert Barro against the New Keynesian economics, which is notable for its bitterness. You can sort of see why: people like Barro had triumphantly declared Keynes dead a decade earlier, and were evidently horrified to see even a mild version of Keynesian ideas making a comeback.

title: With Some Investing Help, Huffington Unveils a New International Venture
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Arianna Huffington has long labored to make her online media empire a truly global one. Now she has enlisted an old friend with deep pockets to make a big step in that direction.

title: Red Bulls Stay the Same, for a Change
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Given their past record of tumult and turnover, the Red Bulls off-season was most unlikely.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 26
description: President Obama will deliver his sixth State of the Union address on Tuesday, most likely tackling agenda-setting topics for 2014, like income inequality and immigration. Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican of Washington, will give the official Republican response following the presidents speech. Senators Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, and Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, will each give their own rebuttals.

title: A Met Who Can Reach Base Is Trying to Stretch
description: After last season, the Mets did not define Josh Satins role. Not that he was surprised. A sixth-round draft pick in 2008, he hit for average but not for power in the minor leagues and never really seemed to be in the Mets plans.

title: Sufficient Financing to Aid Troubled Banks, European Officials Say
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  There will be enough money to recapitalize banks that fail a review by the European Central Bank later this year, top European leaders said on Saturday, seeking to assuage lingering doubts whether policy makers will succeed in cleaning up the financial system and restoring the flow of credit.

title: On Comeback Trail in Downhill, Miller Is Third but Disappointed
description: KITZBHEL, Austria  Less than two weeks before the Winter Olympics, Bode Miller continued his comeback from a knee injury by placing third Saturday in the Hahnenkamm downhill, his best result in a World Cup speed event in almost two years.

title: A Blow to the N.H.L.s Positive Buzz
description: The N.H.L.s slate of six outdoor games this season, including two at Yankee Stadium, should be a good indication of fans receptiveness to expanding the format.

title: False Claims in Afghan Accusations on U.S. Raid Add to Doubts on Karzai
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was the kind of dossier that the Taliban often publish, purporting to show the carnage inflicted during a raid by American forces: photographs of shattered houses and bloodied, broken bodies, and video images of anguish at a village funeral, all with gut-churning impact and no proof of authenticity.

title: Michaels Stores Is Investigating Data Breach
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In what may be the latest in a continuing spate of cyberattacks on American retailers, Michaels Stores said Saturday that it was investigating a potential security breach involving customers credit card information.

title: Seahawks Mania Bigger Than U.S. Can Contain
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  During the N.F.C. championship game last Sunday, die-hard fans draped in navy blue and neon green, part of a group collectively known as the 12th Man, stood, yelled and chanted their Seahawks on to another victory, reaching excruciatingly high decibel levels in the process.

title: An Outpouring of Support as Avonte Oquendo Is Laid to Rest
description: Avonte Oquendos smiling school portrait was on display next to the white coffin, decorated with four carved angels, that held his remains during his funeral on Saturday. It was also on the mourners lapels and the screens of cellphones clutched by the scores of New Yorkers who came to pay their respects but who had never met him.

title: New York Area Weather Has a History with the Super Bowl
description: In the countdowns to each of the previous 47 Super Bowls, the primary question was, quite simply, Which team will win? But as Denver and Seattle await XLVIII next Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., questions about the weather for the first outdoor cold-climate Super Bowl have upstaged even the point spread.

title: Extra Virgin Suicide
description: The adulteration of Italian olive oil.

title: Russians With Deep Pockets Adopt Teams Going for Gold
description: Not long ago, Russias once-heralded biathlon program was in tatters. The team was plagued with doping violations. It was losing big competitions to countries it expected to beat, like Belarus and Kazakhstan. A top biathlon official was convicted of trying to arrange the murder of a local governor.

title: Readers, Enemas and Inequality
description: My Sunday column is about a man whom the police thought might be hiding drugs internally. After a series of forced rectal exams, x-rays, enemas and a colonoscopy, the police decided their hunch had been wrong. But more broadly, the column is about the way society has drawn tradeoffs in the last few decades so as to empower security over liberty, even when (as in the drug war and mass incarceration missteps) they havent done much to boost security. And in the final analysis, this seems to me to be a matter of profound social inequality. With President Obamas State of the Union Address reportedly planning to focus on economic inequality, we tend to see the issue through the prism of wealth and income, and obviously thats important. But inequality in America has other dimensions, not least how were treated by the criminal justice system.

title: Snowballs at Giants Stadium, and Then Arrests
description: The elaborate plans for snow removal before or during Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium, if necessary, stem from a dangerous and embarrassing scene at Giants Stadium on Dec. 23, 1995, during the Giants 27-17 loss to the San Diego Chargers.

title: Venture Capitalist: Tech Activists Are Like Nazis
description: Tensions between the techno-elite and activists in San Francisco are racheting up every day.

title: What Drives Success?
description: A SEEMINGLY un-American fact about America today is that for some groups, much more than others, upward mobility and the American dream are alive and well. It may be taboo to say it, but certain ethnic, religious and national-origin groups are doing strikingly better than Americans overall.

title: Rand Pauls Mixed Inheritance
description: The libertarian faithful  antitax activists and war protesters, John Birch Society members and a smattering of truthers who suspect the governments hand in the 2001 terrorist attacks  gathered last September, eager to see the rising star of their movement.

title: Its All Relative
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  It took me a while to get the theme in this very clever puzzle by Daniel A. Finan, but when I did I was really impressed. You always have to really work for the good things in life, have you noticed that?

title: Street Scenes From a Very Different Jan. 25 in Cairo
description: As my colleague David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, the third anniversary of Egypts uprising against autocracy was marked by a rally in favor of the new military leader, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, in Tahrir Square, while the security forces cracked down with deadly violence on protesters elsewhere.

title: Beijings Bad Air Would Be Step Up for Smoggy Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  In mid-January, air pollution in Beijing was so bad that the government issued urgent health warnings and closed four major highways, prompting the panicked buying of air filters and donning of face masks. But in New Delhi, where pea-soup smog created what was by some measurements even more dangerous air, there were few signs of alarm in the countrys boisterous news media, or on its effervescent Twittersphere.

title: Frances President Announces Split With His Companion
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande announced Saturday that he and his companion, Valrie Trierweiler, had formally ended their relationship, bringing to a close a two-week-long melodrama that began with a glossy magazines report of an affair with an actress and Ms. Trierweilers emotional collapse over the disclosure.

title: Carmelo Anthony Hopes His 62-Point Explosion Propels the Knicks
description: A day after scoring 62 points, Carmelo Anthony rested.

title: Rival Candidates Go After the Education Vote Differently
description: Less than two months before the March primary, Attorney General Greg Abbott of Texas, the leading Republican candidate for governor, can often be found on the campaign trail discussing an issue other statewide Republican candidates have mostly avoided: an overhaul of public education.

title: House Republicans to Offer Broad Immigration Plan
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans are preparing to unveil their own broad template for overhauling the nations immigration system this week, potentially offering a small opening for President Obama and congressional Democrats to pass bipartisan legislation before the end of the year.

title: Alex Shear, Owner of 100,000 Pieces of American Kitsch, Dies at 73
description: They were all his Rosebuds: the vacuum cleaner shaped like a rocket ship, the toaster shaped like a piece of toast, the suitcase with an electric iron in the handle, the potato mashers (he owned about 500), the tin soldiers, the fallout-shelter sign and the gasoline-powered pogo stick.

title: Looking Back at 2013 State of Union
description: Times reporters review the State of the Union address from 2013 and preview this years speech.

title: Obama Pursuing a Modest Agenda in State of Union
description: WASHINGTON  His ambitions in check and his eye on the calendar, President Obama intends to use his State of the Union address to put a difficult year behind him and reassert command before the capital is consumed with election-year politics.

title: Philippines and Rebels Agree on Peace Accord to End Insurgency
description: MANILA  The Philippine government and the countrys largest Muslim insurgency group negotiated the final details of a peace accord on Saturday that many hope will end more than 40 years of violence that has killed tens of thousands of people and helped nurture Islamic extremism in Southeast Asia.

title: In North Dakota Town, Virtual Pipelines Prompt Concern
description: What was first seen as a stopgap measure in the absence of pipelines has become a fixture in the nations energy landscape.

title: Romance of F.A. Cup, and the Reality
description: STOKE-ON-TRENT, England  Soccer fans in England like to talk about the magic of the F.A. Cup, a single-elimination tournament that allows virtually every team in the land, from veritable pub teams to oligarch-owned monoliths, the chance to rise and fall in the same brackets. Some label it charming. Others call it romantic.

title: Accidents Surge as Oil Industry Takes the Train
description: CASSELTON, N.D.  Kerrys Kitchen is where Casselton residents gather for gossip and comfort food, especially the caramel rolls baked fresh every morning. But a fiery rail accident last month only a half mile down the tracks, which prompted residents to evacuate the town, has shattered this calm, along with peoples confidence in the crude-oil convoys that rumble past Kerrys seven times a day.

title: On a Trip to Boston, Unfolding Memories for Nets Players
description: With the Nets visiting the Celtics on Sunday night, Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett were expecting their return to Boston to be an emotional one.

title: Holocaust Told in One Word, 6 Million Times
description: JERUSALEM  There is no plot to speak of, and the characters are woefully undeveloped. On the upside, it can be a quick read  especially considering its 1,250 pages.

title: Changes in the Cattle Business
description: Cattle ranchers at the National Western Stock Show in Denver say their way of life is changing  and they have no choice but to keep up.

title: A Harder Outlook for Todays Cowboy
description: DENVER  Just a few miles from the midday bustle of this citys hip downtown, a pen of black-hided yearlings trotted into a dusty arena, as a crowd of burly men in cowboy hats looked on silently.

title: Nepal Lawmakers Move Closer to Choosing a Prime Minister
description: NEW DELHI  Nepals new Constituent Assembly is expected to begin the process of choosing a prime minister this week after the countrys Supreme Court dismissed calls for an immediate election to choose a president.

title: India Dismisses Charges Against Soldiers in Killings
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian Army last week dismissed charges against five soldiers in a long-running, infamous case in which soldiers were accused of rounding up five Kashmiri men, dressing them in fatigues, then shooting and burning them. The soldiers said the men were Pakistani militants, but locals have insisted for years that they were innocent civilians  a claim lent support by an Indian government investigation.

title: It Only Seems That Political Corruption Is Rampant
description: With the indictment last week of the former Virginia governor Bob McDonnell on fraud and conspiracy charges, one might surmise that high-level political scandal is breaking out all over. And in a way, one would be right: It has been a good year, or perhaps a bad one, for hauling politicians before judges.

title: Fissures in G.O.P. as Some Conservatives Embrace Renewable Energy
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  In conservative politics, solar power is often dismissed as an affectation, part of a liberal agenda to funnel money to solar cronies of the Obama administration and further the global warming hoax.

title: Race Becomes an Exercise in Language
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: The Mayor Went Vegan, Then Spread the Word
description: The side of Vicki VanDeCarrs tote bag reads, Only kale can save us now.

title: Are You Getting Married on Super Bowl Sunday? Or Did You?
description: Wedding planners will tell you that they plan other events for Yom Kippur, Thanksgiving and Christmas, three holidays during which few couples, if any, get married. The fourth holiday where vows are rarely exchanged is Super Bowl Sunday, but wouldnt it be interesting to find a couple who will tie the knot on the day of the big game, if for no other reason than to ask them what were you thinking?

title: Three Killed in Maryland Mall Shooting
description: A shooting at The Mall in Columbia in suburban Maryland left three dead including the suspected assailant.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 26, 2014
description: The reality is that this came out of nowhere. Rail has gone from near-obsolescence to being critical to oil supplies. Its as if the buggy-whips were back in style.

title: Borrowing Crisis Tactics to Aid Uninsured in Texas
description: HOUSTON  In an effort to coordinate education and outreach efforts associated with the Affordable Care Act, the Houston Department of Health and Human Services is taking an approach that mirrors how the Federal Emergency Management Agency might react to a catastrophe.

title: China Sentences Legal Activist to 4 Years for Role in Protests
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court sentenced a prominent legal activist to four years in prison Sunday in a case widely seen as a demonstration of the Communist Party leaderships determination to quell any challenges to its hold on power.

title: Millard L. Midonick, Surrogate to Children and Auden, Dies at 99
description: Millard L. Midonick, a former Manhattan Family Court judge and surrogate who decided numerous celebrated estate cases, including those of the poet W. H. Auden and the painter Mark Rothko, died on Jan. 18 in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: From Novice Prison Player to Hero of the Big Screen
description: Eugene Browns life was made for the movies.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 25, 2014
Rangers and Devils Practice on Yankee Stadium Ice
description: Jaromir Jagr strolled toward the rink in a parka to take pictures, his feet shod in flip-flops.

title: Corrections: January 26, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Whiplash Wins Sundances Top Prizes
description: It started Sundance with a bang and ended the festival with one: Whiplash, a drama about a drummer pushed to extremes by his deeply abusive teacher, won the top two prizes Saturday night in an off-kilter ceremony in Park City, Utah.

title: Lauren Schneider, Michael Calantone
description: Lauren Phyllis Schneider, a daughter of Harriet R. Weinberger and Frederic P. Schneider of Brooklyn, is to be married Sunday afternoon to Michael Raymond Calantone, a son of Joan G. Calantone and Dr. Raymond B. Calantone of Paramus, N.J. Judge A. Gail Prudenti, who sits in Manhattan as the chief administrative judge of the Courts of New York State, is to officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop, an events venue in Manhattan.

title: Justine Lupo, David Robertson
description: Justine Elizabeth Lupo and David James Robertson were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. William J. Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Meghan Irrgang, Thomas Egan
description: Meghan Elizabeth Irrgang, a daughter of Mary E. Irrgang and Richard T. Irrgang of Marietta, Ga., was married Saturday to Thomas Ignatius Egan, a son of Cathleen Egan and Thomas F. Egan of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald E. Murray, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Spirit Catholic Church in Atlanta.

title: Melissa Bordin, Jonathan Stopol
description: Melissa Lynn Bordin and Jonathan Marc Stopol were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Victor Appell officiated.

title: Lori Fradkin and Benjamin Lilien
description: Lori Michelle Fradkin and Benjamin Aaron Lilien were married Saturday evening at the Omni Houston Hotel in Houston. Rabbi Brian A. Strauss officiated, with Cantor David M. Propis participating.

title: Mary Bartos and Richard Falotico
description: Mary Meghan Bartos and Richard William Falotico were married Saturday evening at Gotham Hall, an event space in Manhattan. Stephen A. Coke, a friend of the family who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

title: Nicole Eshaghpour and Ariya Waxman
description: Nicole Shamcy Eshaghpour, the daughter of Jacqueline Neman Eshaghpour and Hilbert Eshaghpour of Great Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Ariya Mayer Waxman, a son of Shohreh Waxman and Hillel S. Waxman, also of Great Neck. Rabbi Howard Stecker officiated with Rabbi Jonathan Waxman, an uncle of the groom, assisting at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Kirstin Abraham and Paul Mojica
description: Kirstin Ross Abraham, the daughter of Gail D. Abraham and Kurt F. Abraham of Cape Coral, Fla., was married Saturday to Paul Andrews Romero Mojica, a son of Jocelyn Mojica and Earnway Barber of Gainesville, Fla. April A. Kelly, a Florida notary, officiated at the Casa Ybel Resort in Sanibel Island, Fla.

title: Kaitlyn Johnson, Joseph Gilston
description: Kaitlyn Ann Johnson, the daughter of Katharine R. Johnson and Kenneth C. Johnson of Cape Elizabeth, Me., was married Saturday to Joseph Raymond Gilston, a son of Nancy S. Gilston and Bruce J. Gilston of New York. C. William Mercer, a United Divine Science minister, officiated at the studio of Cedar Lake, a contemporary dance company in New York.

title: Anna Kaminskaya and Ryan Browning
description: Anna Sergeyevna Kaminskaya and Ryan Rafael Browning were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerks office, officiated. On Sunday, Shannon Drysdale, an officiant working for the Paradisus Resort in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, is to lead a Christian ceremony there that will include a reading from Ecclesiastes and also a sand-pouring ritual.

title: Emily Sedlis and Christopher Russo
description: Emily Angle Sedlis and Christopher Tugwell Russo were married Saturday in New York. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the Conrad New York hotel.

title: And Their Beat Goes On
description: Margaret Mary Ocampo and Benjamin Paul Scheck were married Saturday at St. Andrew Avellino Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens. Msgr. Michael J. Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Ducks Triumph at Dodger Stadium as Volleyballs and Frisbees Fly
description: LOS ANGELES  Outdoor hockey, Southern California-style, debuted Saturday night with face-offs and Frisbees, spiked volleyballs and a stuffed penalty shot, Bob Miller partnering with Vin Scully and the iconoclastic pitcher Brian Wilson mingling with the icon Wayne Gretzky.

title: Whats On Today?
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 56TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock, and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Jay Z leads the pack with nine nominations; Kendrick Lamar, Macklemore (above) & Ryan Lewis, Justin Timberlake and Pharrell Williams follow with seven apiece; and Drake and the mastering engineer Bob Ludwig have five each. A Grammy Moment will feature Merle Haggard; Kris Kristofferson, a recipient of the 2014 Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Award; Willie Nelson; and Blake Shelton. Billie Joe Armstrong and Miranda Lambert will perform a tribute to Phil Everly, who died on Jan. 3. Other sets will feature Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, who will also receive lifetime achievement awards; Nile Rodgers, Mr. Williams and Stevie Wonder with Daft Punk; Pink and Nate Ruess; Metallica and Lang Lang; Madonna, Lorde, Katy Perry, John Legend, Kacey Musgraves, Taylor Swift and Keith Urban. Nine Inch Nails, Queens of the Stone Age, Dave Grohl and Lindsey Buckingham will rock the finale. Pre-event coverage begins at 4 on E!; TV Guide joins the red carpet at 5; and E! moves to the after-party at 11:30.

title: Suicide Bomber Targets Afghan Army Vehicle
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide attack Sunday morning on a shuttle bus transporting soldiers through Kabul killed at least four people, including two civilians, the first deadly assault in the Afghan capital since 21 civilians were killed in an attack at a popular restaurant on Jan. 17.

title: A Little Less Tech Luster in Cambridge
description: LONDON  On the streets of East London, signs of the citys blossoming tech scene are hard to miss.

title: Thai Protesters Disrupt Early Voting in South
description: BANGKOK  Hundreds of thousands of people were blocked from voting on Sunday as antigovernment demonstrators obstructed polling places in Bangkok and southern Thailand in a campaign to suspend democracy and replace Parliament with an unelected peoples council.

title: A Bizarrely Fitting Finale Yields a Most Unexpected Champion
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  After two weeks of madness that included extreme temperatures, a player who hallucinated and saw Snoopy, a lightning strike, a rain delay, a prominent blister and back injury, new rackets, celebrity coaches and upsets galore, the Australian Open ended Sunday.

title: China Sentences Xu Zhiyong, Legal Activist, to 4 Years in Prison
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court sentenced a prominent legal activist to four years in prison Sunday in a case widely seen as a demonstration of the Communist Party leaderships determination to quell any challenges to its hold on power.

title: Freezing Eggs, and Hoarding My Fertility
description: When I awoke in my fertility clinics recovery room after having nine eggs extracted and frozen, I felt a profound calm settle over my body. I could not make the man I had fallen in love with at the time want kids. But at age 36, I could soften the fallout. By stashing away some good eggs, I had found a way to keep alive my dream of having a family.

title: Grammys to Feature On-Air Weddings of 34 Couples
description: Updated, 5:20 p.m. | LOS ANGELES  At the Grammy Awards on Sunday night, pops megastars will compete for the music industrys most prestigious trophy, and put on flashy performances that are sure to ricochet through social media.

title: Cuarn Wins Directors Guild Award
description: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild of America awarded its top feature film prize to Alfonso Cuarn, for Gravity, here on Saturday.

title: Video from Police Briefing on Maryland Mall Shooting
description: The gunman in the shooting at a mall in Maryland Saturday was identified on Sunday as Darion Marcus Aguilar, 19, of College Park, Md.

title: In Our Pages: January 27
description: 1889: New York Herald Opens London Edition

title: Motive Still Unclear, Details on Maryland Shooting Suspect Emerge
description: As the police investigated the shooting at a shopping mall in Maryland where three people died on Saturday to try to determine what prompted the violence, more information came to light on Sunday about the suspected gunman.

title: Disruptions: The Holodeck Begins to Take Shape
description: Isaac Newton, Albert Einstein and Stephen Hawking are playing poker together.

title: My First Bagel
description: Dear Diary:

title: Obama and the One Percent
description: Another week, another outburst by a one-percenter comparing progressive taxation to Nazi atrocities. I particularly liked the end:

title: I, Frankenstein Disappoints at the Box Office
description: Talk about a corpse. Moviegoers this weekend largely stayed away from the newly released I, Frankenstein (Lionsgate), which generated just $8.3 million in ticket sales, for sixth place  a terrible result for a movie that cost $65 million to make and tens of millions more to advertise. Lakeshore Entertainment and Hopscotch Features shouldered almost all costs. Box office analysts posited on Sunday that the target audience, young men, simply had little interest in seeing Mary Shelleys undead monster re-imagined as an action hero; abysmal reviews didnt help.

title: Thai Protesters Block Polling Stations
description: In Bangkok, protesters padlocked gates and intimidated polling officials in an effort to prevent voting.

title: Himmler Papers Shed Light on Personal Life of a Nazi
description: JERUSALEM  When Germany invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941, the wife of Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Nazi Gestapo and the SS and one of the main orchestrators of the Holocaust, sent him a message: There is a can of caviar in the ice box. Take it.

title: Texas Woman Is Taken Off Life Support After Order
description: HOUSTON  A Fort Worth hospital that kept a pregnant, brain-dead woman on life support for two months followed a judges order on Sunday and removed her from the machines, ending her familys legal fight to have her pronounced dead and to challenge a Texas law that prohibits medical officials from cutting off life support to a pregnant woman.

title: With Near-Misses, Miller Shows He's Back and Primed for the Olympics
description: KITZBHEL, Austria  Bode Miller of the United States rose from the ashes of his defeat in the downhill race here Saturday and skied a nearly flawless run to notch the runner-up position in the super-G on Sunday, his second top-three finish in two days.

title: Maryland Shooting News Conference
description: The Howard County police chief, William J. McMahon, addressed the news media about the deadly shootings at the Mall in Columbia.

title: Taking on Beethoven, With an Assist
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra has a way with Beethoven, which makes it surprising that some people once thought the group should steer clear of his works.

title: HSBC Apologizes After Cash Withdrawal Issue in Britain
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC has apologized after reports thatsome customers were prevented from withdrawing large sums of cash from their accounts.

title: Aides Say Obama Is Willing to Work With or Without Congress to Meet Goals
description: WASHINGTON  Aides to President Obama on Sunday offered a preview of the strategy of the presidents State of the Union address, emphasizing Mr. Obamas willingness to bypass a gridlocked Congress to achieve his goals.

title: Meditations on Sadness and Solace
description: The international career of the Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu began after Stravinsky heard one of his works in the late 50s and began championing his music. Although Takemitsu initially resisted traditional music because of its association with Japanese militarism, which he loathed, he later included indigenous instruments and folk music in his understated, eloquent and coloristic works scores, influenced by European modernism and French composers like Debussy.

title: Grammy Parties Aplenty Before the Big Party
description: LOS ANGELES  Music, as you might expect, is everywhere in the parties, showcases and music-industry hobnobs leading up to the Grammy Awards. And while the sight of a person singing into a microphone is sometimes the cue for executives to reach for their smartphones, there were some extraordinary musical events over the last few days.

title: My Kids Idle for a Second? Oh, Horrors!
description: Jennifer Seniors astute book about parents and children, All Joy and No Fun, is especially eye opening about how many prejudices are usually built into such studies. Take parenting, a word that invariably makes its way into books about parent-child dynamics: Ms. Senior would like to remind us that this was not always a verb, and that the emphasis on parents need to devote themselves 24/7 to their offspring is a relative novelty.

title: Looking Inward, and Finding Inspiration
description: A central problem with the choreographer Sarah Michelson is that the admirer who surrounds her with the greatest claims for Sarah Michelsons greatness is Sarah Michelson herself. In the four works of hers Ive seen since 2009, her dances strike me as obviously limited, largely unoriginal, though not devoid of interest. But as theater works, especially in their use of recorded speech and music, theyre vexing. And in 4, her new piece now showing at the Whitney Museum of American Art, she emerges as the most pretentious artist of my entire experience, and among the most self-infatuated.

title: Feeling Squeamish? Maybe You Shouldnt Read Any Further
description: The Fox series The Following is essentially a cheap horror story tricked out with a laughable literary framework, and it likes to traffic in patterns and symbols, the more obvious the better.

title: Open Swiss Teams at District 3 Winter Regional
description: The Thursday Open Swiss Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye, N.Y., on Jan. 16 was won by Jane Dillenberg, Jerry Goldberg, Gail Greenberg and Susan Picus of New York City.

title: Gyrating His Way Through Country Beats
description: Here are Luke Bryans moves: He waves his right hand in the air as if hes riding a bull while his left hand caresses his rear end; he flattens his arms against himself and pumps his shoulders up and down; he stands firm, feet spread shoulderwide, and lets his waist go liquid, thrusting himself into the cheap seats.

title: Shakespeares Raging Monarch as a Modern-Day Dictator
description: LONDON  Could you ever find it in your heart to pity a mass-murdering dictator? What if you suddenly came upon Stalin, say, or Ceausescu in a storm-swept wilderness, and he had been stripped of his power, his sanity and most of his clothes? Might you muster a tiny tear of compassion, even knowing all you know about him?

title: Daft Punk, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis and Lorde Prevail at the Grammys
description: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the ceremony, which saw major awards go to the French dance music duo Daft Punk and the upstarts Macklemore & Ryan Lewis and Lorde.

title: Countdown to Kickoff
description: The run-up this week to the Super Bowl, on Feb. 2, will include events around New Jersey like cooking demonstrations, concerts and appearances by football players past and present.

title: With Previews, Super Bowl Advertisers Borrow From Hollywood
description: ADVERTISERS that want commercials to be perceived as more than product pitches like to call them films. When it comes to Super Bowl commercials, the term may be appropriate rather than pretentious.

title: A Troupe Without a Home Provides a Stage to Works in Search of One
description: New York Theater Ballet recently lost its home, when the building where its studios and offices had been since 1980 was sold. The search for a new space continues, but on Friday at Florence Gould Hall, the company mounted a program that in its variety and quality made a good advertisement for why the troupe merits support.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 27
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: On the Road, Actors Seek Higher Pay
description: Actors call them luxury tours: the road productions of Wicked, The Lion King and other blockbuster hit musicals with the money to bring Broadway across America in style. No tours pay better for Actors Equity union members  at least $1,807 a week, with leads earning up to $6,000  and none have better perks, like physical therapy at a moments notice.

title: Vacation Lodging Purchase
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Have a seat. Im just going to put on a short presentation before we talk about the puzzle. No, youll love it, really. Well, if I have to be perfectly honest, its about these exclusive condos that you will absolutely l  hey, wheres everybody going?

title: Chinas Corruption Crackdown?
description: Xi Jinping has vowed to end corruption among Chinas elite, but a report said that the countrys wealthy are storing billions of dollars abroad.

title: In the Cold at Yankee Stadium, the Rangers Are in Their Element
description: Maybe it was the midwinter cold. Or maybe it was the chipped ice, or even the jovial atmosphere among the fans.

title: Dresden Ballet Dancer Wins Lead Role in New Starz Series
description: Flesh and Bone, a new drama series produced by Starz, starts shooting this spring and has the ballet world buzzing, especially since the cancellations of ABC Familys Bunheads and, more recently, Breaking Pointe, the CW reality show about Ballet West. After an extensive search, the creator and writer Moira Walley-Beckett and the executive producers Lawrence Bender, Kevin Brown and John Melfi have found the shows lead. Sarah Hay, an American member of the Semperoper Ballet in Dresden, Germany, won the part of Claire, a talented, emotionally troubled dancer from Pittsburgh who ends up in a New York City ballet company. At an open audition last fall, Ms. Walley-Beckett described the character as coming from an abusive family life.

title: Ezra Klein Is Joining Vox Media as Web Journalism Asserts Itself
description: After a week of speculation, it turns out that Ezra Klein, the prolific creator of The Washington Posts Wonkblog, will be going to Vox Media, the online home of SB Nation, a sports site, and The Verge, a fast-growing technology site.

title: This Time, Anthony Has Just Enough to Carry the Shaky Knicks
description: Carmelo Anthony got an early indication that Sundays game was not going to be like his last one. He was trying to work his way to the basket late in the second quarter when the Los Angeles Lakers Ryan Kelly used his 6-foot-11, 230-pound frame to impede Anthonys progress like a cement-filled traffic barrier.

title: Chairwoman of Universal Expands Her Portfolio
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  A drained Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, sat down for lunch in the studios executive dining room here last month and let loose a dramatic sigh. Who could blame her?

title: The Age of Infopolitics
description: We are in the midst of a flood of alarming revelations about information sweeps conducted by government agencies and private corporations concerning the activities and habits of ordinary Americans. After the initial alarm that accompanies every leak and news report, many of us retreat to the status quo, quieting ourselves with the thought that these new surveillance strategies are not all that sinister, especially if, as we like to say, we have nothing to hide.

title: Past Glories Resound in UMass Revival
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Shortly after Derek Kellogg was hired at Massachusetts in the summer of 2008, he toured the surrounding countryside, popping into restaurants, coffee shops and bars across the Pioneer Valley to shake hands, and to promote and reminisce about the Minutemen.

title: U.N. Inquiry Criticizes Qatars Justice System
description: A United Nations investigator permitted by Qatar to examine its justice system delivered a blunt critique on Sunday, saying that prosecutors and judges need more autonomy and training, defense lawyers should have access to the evidence against their clients, and foreign suspects may be vulnerable to discrimination.

A Race for a New Mayor; a Trial for an Old One
description: NEW ORLEANS  Him again.
