title: K.K.R. to Buy Sedgwick, an Insurance Claims Processor, for $2.4 Billion
description: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Monday to buy Sedgwick Claims Management Services, a provider of insurance claims processing, for $2.4 billion.

title: Daily Report: Ubers Challenge to Taxis Runs Afoul of Lawsuits and Regulators
description: Travis Kalanick, who is brash and aggressive even by the standards of Silicon Valley, created Uber four years ago to blow up the traditional taxi business. In more than 60 cities, from San Francisco to Berlin, it is doing just that, David Streitfeld reports.

title: AT&T Denies Pursuit of Vodafone
description: LONDON  AT&T announced on Monday that it was not in talks to buy the European telecommunications giant Vodafone.

title: Paul Smith: Its About Effort
description: Suzy Menkes talks to designer Paul Smith about his latest collection and his recent museum exhibit.

title: Anger Over Venture Capitalists Letter
description: The San Francisco techno-elite and local activists have not been on good terms in recent weeks, but it may be wise to tread carefully when writing about the latest tensions. In a letter published in The Wall Street Journal on Saturday, Tom Perkins, a founder of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, wondered if progressive radicalism indicated the possibility of a new Kristallnacht.

title: Finding a Place in the Hip-Hop Ecosystem
description: A couple of hours after the Grammys on Sunday night, Macklemore sent a text to Kendrick Lamar, whom he had just beaten for best rap album.

title: Two Relief Camps in Uttar Pradesh Settle Into Permanency
description: BHURA CAMP, Uttar Pradesh  The Bhura relief camp set up for Muslims who were fleeing violent clashes with Hindu-Jats in western Uttar Pradesh over four months ago is starting to look more like permanent settlements, despite the local authorities efforts to force residents to move out. Residents here say this is the first camp to become a colony.

title: BG Group Warns of Gas Problems in Egypt
description: LONDON  The BG Group, the large British oil and gas producer, shocked financial markets on Monday by announcing that it was breaking contracts with customers and lenders because it was unable to export enough liquefied natural gas from Egypt, its largest producing area.

title: Journalists on the Environment Beat Look Ahead
description: I was invited by the Wilson Center to participate on Friday in a discussion with other journalists of environmental issues that will be in the headlines this year and going forward. (The session was co-sponsored by the Society of Environmental Journalists.)

title: Sundance Q. and A. | Alex Ross Perry
description: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.

title: Study Puts Price Tag on Too Big to Fail
description: LONDON  An analysis commissioned by the Green Party in the European Parliament estimates that the cost of the implicit guarantee that governments will back large financial institutions, known as too big to fail, was about 234 billion euros in 2012.

title: Syria Talks Appear Deadlocked as Sides Disagree Over Goals
description: GENEVA  The first face-to-face peace talks by antagonists in the Syria conflict appeared to deadlock on Monday, with enormous differences over the basic purpose of negotiations as well as a government relief gesture for civilians that the opposition denounced as a ploy. But both sides expressed willingness to resume talking.

title: Dancers at Their Feet
description: City Ballet fans posed with their favorite dancers in a giant photo installation on the floor of the David H. Koch Theater.

title: 2014 Grammy Awards: Big Winners
description: Times reporter Jon Pareles discusses the 56th annual Grammy Awards ceremony.

title: Bitcoin and the Fictions of Money
description: How should we think about a currency like Bitcoin? The first thing to remember is this: Money is a sort of collective fiction. What money we choose to trust says much about how we see the world.

title: New G.M. Chief Vows to Support Opel
description: RSSELSHEIM, Germany  In her first trip abroad since becoming chief executive of General Motors in mid-January, Mary T. Barra on Monday underscored the companys commitment to its troubled Opel unit. She promised to invest in the flagship factory in this city near Frankfurt by adding a third, unspecified, model line.

title: Ukraines Leader to Revoke Curbs on Dissent, but Opposition Remains Wary
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Still struggling to contain a national civil uprising, President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine agreed late Monday to revoke a package of new laws severely restricting political dissent, but a wider accord to defuse the crisis remained out of reach, officials said.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Stan Adler Associates, New York, part of the CHR Group, opened an office in Toronto.

title: Congressman in Drug Case Resigns Seat in Florida
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, who pleaded guilty in November to a misdemeanor charge of buying 3.5 grams of cocaine and was sentenced to a year of probation, resigned from Congress effective Monday evening.

title: Cabbage and Pepper Chakchoukah
description: I love the spicy Tunisian pepper stew with eggs poached in it, called chakchoukah. I substituted cabbage for some of the peppers and love this new version.

title: Bruschetta With Cabbage Braised in Wine
description: The wine-braised cabbage is adapted from a recipe in Cooking From an Italian Garden, by Paola Scaravelli and Jon Cohen. If you dont cook with wine, substitute vegetable stock, chicken stock or water for the wine. You could also top the bruschetta with a simpler cabbage saut, but I love the sweet flavor of the long-simmered cabbage.

title: Cabbage and Parmesan Soup With Barley
description: Parmesan rinds, simmered here in the same way that a ham bone might be used in France or Italy, contribute great depth of flavor to this wonderful, comforting soup. I love the added texture and bulk provided by the barley.

title: Cabbage Pirozhki
description: Of all the different fillings for the small oval Russian pies called pirozhki, cabbage has always been my favorite. The filling is a simple mixture of onions and cabbage, cooked in butter (traditionally in much more than I use here), until soft and sweet but not browned, then seasoned with dill, salt and pepper, and enriched with chopped hard-boiled eggs. I sometimes add a little ricotta to the mix. Traditional pirozhki dough is a rich pastry made with butter and sour cream. I tried my yeasted whole wheat olive oil pastry and it worked beautifully.

title: Cabbage and Ricotta Timbale
description: I use the same filling that I used for pirozhkis in this light timbale. You can make the timbales in individual molds or make one larger mold.

title: Jane Lynch on the Delicate Art of Awards Humor
description: LOS ANGELES  All season long, awards show hosts, tasked with being flip about this years cinematic hopefuls, have faced the major comedic stumbling block of 12 Years a Slave. How to make light of one of the most grotesque periods of humanity? Amy Poehler, at the Golden Globes, quipped that after seeing the movie, she would never look at slavery the same way again. (Tina Fey: Wait, how were you looking at it?) At the Directors Guild awards on Saturday, the M.C., Jane Lynch, handled it this way: 12 Years a Slave, she said, is the story of an educated black man trying to prove his real identity to those that wanted to bring him down  or as Barack Obama calls it, Tuesday.

title: Goodbye to the Doctors White Coat?
description: New recommendations on what health care workers should wear may mean an end to the doctors white coat.

title: Even With Changes, Pro Bowl Is Tough to Watch. And Commentate.
description: Late in Sundays Pro Bowl broadcast, NBCs Cris Collinsworth credited the intensity of Deion Sanders and Jerry Rice, who selected the teams in a draft on the NFL Network, for the better-than-usual level of play in a game often known for minimal effort.

title: Irving Milchberg, Who Smuggled Guns Under Nazis Noses, Dies at 86
description: Irving Milchberg, who as a plucky Jewish street urchin escaped transport to concentration camps three times and sold cigarettes to Nazis in the heart of occupied Warsaw while smuggling guns and food to resistance fighters, died on Sunday in Toronto. He was 86.

title: Egypts Ruler Eyes Riskier Role: The Presidency
description: CAIRO  When Egypts first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, named Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi defense minister, the officer pledged to keep the military out of politics and make way for civilian democracy.

title: Tale of Magical Squirrel Takes Newbery Medal
description: Kate DiCamillo, who was recently named the national ambassador for young peoples literature, received another one of the fields highest honors on Monday: The John Newbery Medal went to her book Flora and Ulysses (Candlewick Press), the story of a girl who befriends a squirrel with magical powers.

title: Directors Guild of America Red Carpet
description: See Kerry Washington in Oscar de la Renta, Sandra Bullock in Roland Mouret and others from Saturday.

title: In Our Pages: January 28
description: 1889: The General Wins

title: Profits Up, Wages Down: What Economics Has to Say
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Image of the Day: January 27
German at Center of Looted-Art Case Is Said to Consider Restitution Claims
description: BERLIN  Cornelius Gurlitt, the elderly German owner of a trove of artworks that include works by Chagall, Picasso and Munch, is willing to consider restitution claims for pieces in the collection that may have been stolen by the Nazis, his lawyer said.

title: Egyptian Journalist Explains Hunger Strike in Prison Letter
description: Abdullah Elshamy, an Egyptian journalist for Al Jazeera who was detained in August while covering the bloody crackdown on an Islamist sit-in in Cairo, has embarked on a hunger strike, according to a letter from prison that was posted online by his family on Monday.

title: The Read Around: Jennifer Senior
description: In All Joy and No Fun, Jennifer Senior looks at the finding that children do not improve their parents happiness.

title: The Source | Alice Waters
description: Doug Aitken interviews Alice Waters.

title: Nazi Remarks Make Perkins Persona Non Grata in Silicon Valley
description: Thomas J. Perkins, an elite investor in Silicon Valley, provoked outrage and shock over the weekend when he compared criticism of the wealthy to Nazi attacks on Jews.

title: Age-Appropriate Chores for Children (and Why Theyre Not Doing Them)
description: This Montessori chart of Age-Appropriate Chores for Children is making the Facebook rounds. (The shares on my page came from  the Facebook page of Maria Montessori.) With it, the commentary. Apparently, a lot of other parents have complained about this list. Those other parents say things like children arent slaves and carrying firewood is dangerous! Scroll down, and you do find those parents, noting that the label on the cleaning supplies says to keep away from children, and so they do, and what 10-year-old can mow the lawn? Who would trust a 12-year-old with hedge clippers?

title: The Source | Alice Waters in Conversation With Doug Aitken
description: I think if you buy from people who are taking care of the land, Alice Waters says, youre supporting the future of this country. The chef activist speaks to Doug Aitken in Berkeley, Calif., at an Edible Schoolyard, her project to educate students about agriculture, economy and the environment. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: Wawrinkas Title Shakes Up the Rankings, but Not the Hierarchy
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For nine years now, four players have defined an era of mens tennis, their play so consistent the rest of the ATP World Tour seemed to exist on another planet. There was Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, and then there was everybody else.

title: Monday Motorsports: Corvettes Sweep Top Four Spots at Daytona 24-Hour
description: Chevrolet Corvettes in the Daytona Prototype class swept the top four positions in the Rolex 24 endurance race, which ended Sunday at Daytona Beach, Fla. Joo Barbosa managed to hold off Max Angelelli to take the checkered flag by just 1.5 seconds after 695 laps in 24 hours.

title: Senior Justice Department Attorney to Join Morrison & Foerster
description: Charles Duross, a senior attorney at the Justice Department who once prosecuted a congressman who hid $90,000 in his freezer, has decided to join the law firm of Morrison & Foerster as head of its global anticorruption practice.

title: Tom Gola, a Philadelphia Basketball Legend, Dies at 81
description: Tom Gola, a virtual folk hero in Philadelphia for his basketball exploits there in high school, college and the pros in the 1950s, died on Sunday in Meadowbrook, Pa. He was 81.

title: De Blasio, on Cuomos Turf, Stands By Pre-K Strategy
description: ALBANY  He did not plead for money. He did not seek to extract promises about a long list of legislation. And he was not interested in picking a fight.

title: Bair, Critic of the Revolving Door, Joins Board of Santander
description: Updated, 3:37 p.m. | Sheila C. Bair, a former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation who once argued that former regulators should be barred from joining the banks they oversaw, is joining the board of Banco Santander, the Spanish bank said on Monday.

title: The Princess Problem
description: This weeks puzzle was suggested by Dave Penneys, a mathematics postdoctoral fellow at the University of Toronto.

title: Of Course the Condo Has a Gym, but What About a Personal Shopper?
description: On Central Park South, a luxury building is offering its residents direct access to Bergdorf Goodmans buyers, who can find them that special accessory from Paris. In TriBeCa, a developer hired educators from the 92nd Street Y to design the basement playroom.

title: A Discredited Supreme Court Ruling That Still, Technically, Stands
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Courts 1944 decision in Korematsu v. United States was a disaster. In endorsing an executive order that required 110,000 Americans of Japanese ancestry to be removed from their homes and confined in detention camps, the court relied on wartime hysteria streaked with racism, sullying its reputation and damaging the constitutional principles it was meant to uphold.

title: The Read Around: Video of Jennifer Senior
description: In The Read Around, a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Jennifer Senior discusses All Joy and No Fun, her investigation into how children affect their parents happiness.

title: Times Minute | New York's Water Tanks
description: Also on the Minute, the U.S. drone mission at risk and the cost of the Sochi Games.

title: Times Minute | Questionable Water in New York
description: In the Video

title: At New York Hotel, a Crowd-Sourced Lego Project
description: In a lemonade-from-lemons move, Yotel New York, the capsule hotel near Times Square, has turned a construction-masking wall into a 30-foot collaborative art project using Lego building blocks.

title: New Running Shoe Line Says, Come Fly With Me
description: Once upon a time, phrases like ultimate plush ride, smooth ride and softest ride were routinely found in ads for luxury automobiles. Now, a leading brand of running shoe is borrowing them for a campaign for a new product line.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

title: The Stealth Saturday Night Live Oscar Campaign
description: Comedy may only get respect at the Academy Awards when its dressed up as drama, but the most memorable moments in American Hustle and The Wolf of Wall Street are the ones played for laughs. And the savviest awards players know that poking fun at themselves is a surefire way to endear themselves to audiences (and Academy voters).

title: Artistic Director Extends Contract for Mozart Week in Salzburg
description: The French conductor Marc Minkowski has renewed his term as artistic director of Mozart Week, the annual celebration of Mozarts music presented by the Salzburg Mozarteum Foundation, the foundation announced on Monday. The festival typically runs during the week that includes Mozarts birthday (Jan. 27) in Salzburg, the Austrian city where he was born. Mr. Minkowskis term will run through the 2017 festival.

title: Spy Agencies Tap Data Streaming From Phone Apps
description: When a smartphone user opens Angry Birds, the popular game application, and starts slinging birds at chortling green pigs, spies could be lurking in the background to snatch data revealing the players location, age, sex and other personal information, according to secret British intelligence documents.

title: In Recruiting Game, Wall Street Still Competes
description: Despite the refrain that the financial crisis has discouraged students from pursuing jobs in finance, the number of elite students who continue to seek lucrative positions at financial firms indicates that Wall Street has not yet lost its luster.

title: A Fed Policy Maker, Changing His Mind, Urges More Stimulus
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Narayana R. Kocherlakota, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, was once a leading opponent of the Federal Reserves efforts to stimulate the economy. Today, he has emerged as the only senior official arguing publicly that the Fed should do even more.

title: European Telecommunications Companies May Follow Cables Lead
description: European telecommunications companies may well follow cables lead on acquisitions. The latest in a string of cable tie-ups involved Liberty Global, John Malones consolidator, which took full control of its Dutch rival Ziggo for 10 billion euros, or $13.7 billion, including debt. Among telecommunications companies, deal-making has proved trickier. But here, too, activity should start to rise.

title: Afghanistan Moves Closer to Freeing 37 Detainees
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite American protests, the Afghan government has issued formal release orders for 37 prisoners who are regarded by the NATO-led coalition as dangerous insurgents responsible for the deaths of Americans and Afghans. The release orders set the stage for a renewed confrontation between President Hamid Karzai and the United States.

title: Today in Small Business: Data Breaches
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: For the Unemployed, State Help Isnt Enough
description: Congressional Republicans who oppose extending federal unemployment benefits are saying, in effect, that state-provided jobless benefits are adequate.

title: U.N. Council Resolution Urges No Ransom to Terrorists
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations Security Council on Monday pressed governments around the world not to pay ransom money to terrorist kidnappers. The resolution, submitted by Britain and unanimously passed by the 15-member Council, is not enforceable, nor does it resolve the longstanding dispute at the United Nations over the definition of a terrorist. The British ambassador to the United Nations, Mark Lyall Grant, told reporters the resolution was intended to send a message to terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda that rely on ransom payments as a major source of financing. We need to be honest about the impact ransoms have in sustaining terrorist activity, the ambassador said. Governments rarely confirm, let alone publicly discuss, the details of ransom payments to kidnappers. The resolution applies only to payments to terrorist organizations, not other types of kidnappers.

title: With Flowers and Security, Maryland Mall Reopens
description: COLUMBIA, Md.  Shoppers returned on Monday to the Maryland mall where a shooting two days earlier in a skateboard and apparel store left three people dead.

title: Past Sins Haunting Royal Bank of Scotland
description: Nearly six years after the financial crisis, the sins of the past still weigh heavily on the Royal Bank of Scotland.

title: Why I Use Snapchat: Its Fast, Ugly and Ephemeral
description: Question: Do you use Snapchat? a friend asked me in a text message last week. I cant find anyone that actually uses it.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Amy Chozick on Her Adventures in Hillaryland
description: Amy Chozick, a political reporter for The Times, wrote this weeks cover story about the people who are readying themselves forHillary Clintons possible run for the presidency in 2016.Since July, your full-time beat at The Times has been the Clintons. How did you choose this aspect of Hillary Clintons political future for lengthier treatment?When I moved onto this beat, friends and colleagues said, Youre going to cover one person for the next four years?! But with Hillary Clinton, its never just one person (or even three people, with President Clinton and Chelsea). I found out that there is a huge cast of characters the Clintons have collected over the years. Their perspective and place in this world is an essential part of who Hillary is and what her future might look like. A person who went to Georgetown with Bill Clinton told me lots of his classmates were thinking about running for president, but only Clinton was building his cabinet. Theyre unique in American politics in that theyve collected so many people over the years  from Arkansas to the White House and to whatever she does in the future. I wanted to explore that dynamic, and the benefits of having such an enormous brain trust, but also the downside to having so many voices who all have a stake in 2016.

title: Portraits at Sundance
description: The photographer Henny Garfunkel worked with actors and directors at this years film festival.

title: Judge Throws Out Racketeering Claims Filed by Cohens Ex-Wife
description: A legal battle between the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen and his ex-wife, Patricia, will continue for a while longer, but a federal judge considerably narrowed the scope of a civil lawsuit filed by the former Mrs. Cohen, who is seeking millions of dollars in damages.

title: Grammys Broadcast Draws More Than 28 Million Viewers
description: Live events continue to defy the general drift of viewers away from network television as this years edition of the Grammy Awards proved convincingly.

title: The Endless Interview Process
description: In my Its the Economyon Sunday, I mentioned that the job application process has dragged on and on for many Americans. This is a subject I wrote aboutlast year. Ive heard anecdotes about very long hoop-jumping processes, and so I asked Glassdoor, a site that collects user-submitted information on hiring at different companies, to check for any discernible trends in the duration of the job application gantlet.

title: Holocaust Scholar Returns Top Award to Hungary in Protest
description: PARIS  A prominent Hungarian-American Holocaust scholar, Randolph L. Braham, said on Sunday he is returning a high state award to Hungary to protest what he called the governments efforts to whitewash the countrys collusion in the murder of hundreds of thousands of Jews during the Second World War.

title: Google Acquires British Artificial Intelligence Developer
description: LONDON  As it aims to build driverless cars and the next generation of robots, Google said on Monday that it had acquired the British artificial intelligence developer DeepMind.

title: Photos, Fun and a Free Lunch
description: Theres no such thing as a free lunch, you say?

title: Weekend Gun Report: January 24-26, 2014
description: On Saturday morning, Brianna Benlolo, 21, and Tyler Johnson, 25, were shot and killed as they worked at a skate shop at the Mall in Columbia in suburban Baltimore, Md. The suspected shooter, Darion Marcus Aguilar, 19, then killed himself.

title: Seen on the Street | High-Altitude Style at the Sundance Film Festival
description: This years event brought a preponderance of rugged looks, including burly boots and Western-style outerwear.

title: The Strange (and Welcome) Case of a Political Story With No Anonymity
description: The profile of Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky in Sundays Times was notable for many reasons. It was a fascinating and well-researched read on the libertarian Republican who could prove to be an important figure as 2016 nears. It quotes Mitt Romney as calling him a serious contender for the Republican nomination.

title: Au Revoir, Valrie
description: PARIS  Just hours after President Franois Hollande announced over the weekend that he had split up with Valrie Trierweiler, de facto first lady of France, Ms. Trierweiler arrived in the Indian city of Mumbai on Sunday, looking composed, perfectly coiffed and resolute, even as she was swarmed by paparazzi.

title: Scarlett Johanssons Defense of SodaStream Factory in Occupied West Bank Fails to Sway Critics
description: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | In a statement released late Friday, the actress Scarlett Johansson rejected criticism of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, which manufactures home carbonation systems in an Israeli settlement, from opponents of Israels continued occupation of the West Bank territory it seized in 1967.

title: Scientists Anxieties and Sonic Wonders
description: Events and reading matter at the intersection of science and culture.

title: Behind the Poster: Yentl
description: Gender and Judaism clash in Isaac Bashevis Singers story Yentl the Yeshiva Boy, about a young Jewish girl who cuts off her hair and disguises herself as a boy to study. But gender and Judaism come together in a bold statement in the Cleveland Play Houses poster for its new production of the stage adaptation, written by Leah Napolin and Mr. Singer.

title: In Assad Government Communiqu, a Clue to Syria Peace Talks Hurdles
description: GENEVA  As we reported, a tenuous peace conference in Geneva between the Syrian opposition and the government has yet to produce concrete results, and on Monday, the third day of face-to-face talks, a communiqu released by President Bashar al-Assads government showed just how far apart they are from any agreement.

title: Bitcoin Figure Is Accused of Conspiring to Launder Money
description: One of the most prominent players in the Bitcoin universe, Charles Shrem, was arrested by federal authorities on Sunday and accused of helping smooth the way for drug transactions on the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 21-Jan. 27, 2014
description: Technology, sports, politics and Justin Bieber: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

title: Q&A: A Voice for an Activist Fed
description: The Federal Reserve is often described as if it were a person  just one person  but it actually makes decisions by committee, and that committee is in flux. Only six of the 12 officials who voted on policy last January will still be voting when the Federal Open Market Committee holds its first meeting of 2014 this week.

title: Stealth Oscar Campaigns, Grammy Edition
description: LOS ANGELES  Julia Roberts introduced a musical number on her first-ever appearance at the Oscars (for which she was deathly nervous) and on Sunday night she reprised that awards gig, introducing some little-known fellows called Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr at the Grammys.

title: 1846 by Ferran Adri
description: A video of each of the dishes Adri and his team created over the six-year run of his restaurant El Bulli.

title: Why Chris Christie Could Have Been an Entrepreneur
description: What I see in the rise of Chris Christie, and now his recent crisis, is the same thing that I have long seen in the rise and fall (and often rise again) of fast-growth entrepreneurs. Through sheer force of personality, they rise up and get market-changing results over people, over bureaucracies, over anything that gets in their way.

title: United Technologies Considers Sale or Spin-Off of Sikorsky
description: The United Technologies Corporation is considering a spin-off or sale of Sikorsky, the maker of the Black Hawk helicopters favored by the United States military, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: An Extra Step Worth Taking
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

title: Nevadas Argument Against Same-Sex Marriage No Longer Tenable
description: On Jan. 21, Nevadas Attorney General, Catherine Cortez Masto, filed a brief strongly defending the states ban on same-sex marriage, which is being challenged in federal court by a group of same-sex couples.

title: Trusting a Baby to Know How to Eat
description: You need a class to tell you how to feed your baby? my dad laughed down the line to London, where I live. I was en route to a workshop on introducing my six-month-old daughter to solid food and was hoping to find clarity on which approach to use: traditional pures or this thing called baby-led weaning Id heard English moms chatting about. Some swore by it, but others derided it as just another silly offshoot of bohemian urban parenting. It was like breast versus bottle 2.0, and I wanted to know more.

title: Budget-Friendly and (Almost) Dracula-Free Transylvania
description: Our ways are not your ways, and there shall be to you many strange things, said a certain sharp-fanged count to his English visitor, freshly arrived by train to Transylvania.

title: From the National Security Agency
description: This document from 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A. contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.

title: Charlie Brown and the Gang Take Shape
description: Part of an occasional series on vintage comics.

title: Your Mars Training Program, a Three-Toed Ecosystem, Memory as We Age
description: Michael J. Massimino, a NASA astronaut, talks about how space changes our bodies and minds; we look at the (slowly) moveable habitat known as the sloth; a new study uses the web to model our brains memory  and why it appears to fail as we age.

title: Tiger Global to Invest in Brazilian Online Retailer
description: SAO PAULO  Tiger Global Management will invest nearly $520 million in Brazilian online retailer B2W Companhia Digital, the New York investment fund said, a sign that it continues to see promise in Brazils vibrant Internet sector.

title: From Britains Government Communications Headquarters
description: This document from May 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.

title: The Older Mind May Just Be a Fuller Mind
description: People of a certain age (and we know who we are) dont spend much leisure time reviewing the research into cognitive performance and aging. The story is grim, for one thing: Memorys speed and accuracy begin to slip around age 25 and keep on slipping.

title: Sundance Fashion
description: Stars from the film festival who pushed the style envelope past snow boots and beanies.

title: The Sloths Busy Inner Life
description: Spare a minute from your frenetically busy day to consider the quite different life of the three-toed sloth.

title: Yes, We Believe That Pizza Is Meh
description: As expected, some people were furious about pizzas inclusion on this past weekends Meh List, a much-beloved and -maligned part of the One-Page Magazine. Even our own colleagues rethought their opinions of Samantha Henig, fellow Meh Lister, and me. But now that weve said it, were standing by it. Pizza is meh. This was not a mistake. My own philosophy of the mehness of pizza has been brewing for a long time. Lets start with a mental exercise.

title: Beings Not Made for Space
description: HOUSTON  In space, heads swell.

title: Thousands Pay Tribute to Abbado in Front of La Scala
description: MILAN  Thousands of people packed into the square in front of La Scala on Monday to pay silent but heartfelt homage to one of the opera theaters most revered musical directors, Claudio Abbado, who died on Jan. 20 at the age of 80.

title: Scene City: After the Grammys, Dancing All Night
description: Warner Music Group held its annual post-award-ceremony party at the Sunset Tower Hotel in Los Angeles.

title: Europe Puts Pressure on Greece to Meet Budget Targets
description: BRUSSELS  European officials sought on Monday to keep the pressure on Greece to honor its previously agreed spending and privatization targets as they wrestled with the need to help Athens bridge a funding gap that could reach 15 billion over the next two years.

title: Q&A: An Advocate for a Quicker Taper
description: As the voting membership of the Federal Reserves policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, turns over at a meeting this week, one of the new votes will be cast by Richard W. Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

title: China Appears Set to Force Times Reporter to Leave
description: BEIJING  Despite objections raised by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in meetings with its top leaders, China appears set to force a correspondent for The New York Times to leave the country this week. It is also continuing to block a number of other journalists working for The Times and for Bloomberg News from taking up assignments in Beijing.

title: Outbreak Brings Royal Caribbean Cruise to an Early End
description: An outbreak of gastrointestinal illness suspected to be the norovirus has forced a Royal Caribbean cruise ship to return to port two days before the end of its scheduled 10-day voyage.

title: At an Exhibition From the Master of El Bulli, Food Becomes Art
description: Ferran Adri made food into art at El Bulli, his renowned, now-shuttered restaurant near the town of Roses on the Catalan coast of Spain. Now, Ferran Adri: Notes on Creativity at the Drawing Center in New York offers a peek behind the curtain of the worlds most celebrated culinary laboratory, and a glimpse at what Adri is cooking up next.

title: Shedding Light on a Vast Toll of Jews Killed Away From the Death Camps
description: OSWIECIM, Poland  As one gazes out from the main watchtower at the grim desert that is the crumbling chimneys and crematories, vanished prisoners huts, barbed wire and ditches of Auschwitz-Birkenau, it is hard to fathom that there were corners of the Nazi realm where, collectively, more killing occurred than at Auschwitz.

title: Examining the Square Root of Doh!
description: Did you know that Homer Simpson disproved Fermats last theorem? He did, or so it seemed, when he scribbled 398712+436512=447212 on a blackboard in a 1998 episode of The Simpsons.

title: Its Not Just a Job, Its an Adventure. In a Dying Industry, Sure. But Still.
description: Considering what a lightweight piece of twaddle it is, Craving for Travel, at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, sure gives you a lot to think about. Can a piece so blatantly promotional rightly be called theater? If I laugh at any of it, should I feel guilty? If this play succeeds, can similar works about elevator operators, owners of independent bookstores and other imperiled jobs be far behind?

title: Foundry Owner Accused of Forging Johnss Sculptures Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud
description: A Queens foundry owner who was accused of trying to sell fake Jasper Johns works for millions of dollars pleaded guilty on Monday to three counts of wire fraud in Manhattan federal court, according to The Associated Press. In 1990, Mr. Johns had entrusted Brian Ramnarine, the owner of Empire Bronze Art Foundry, to make a wax cast of the mold for his 1960 metallic collage Flag. Mr. Ramnarine kept the mold and was accused of secretly creating copies of Mr. Johnss work that he later tried to sell as originals. Mr. Ramnarine, who was in the middle of a trial, made a deal with federal prosecutors that he would not challenge any sentence of 10 years or less in prison. Last week, Mr. Johns took a turn on the witness stand, testifying that he had cut ties with Mr. Ramnarine after seeing a copy of his sculpture. I was shown the cast of a flag I had never authorized, he told the court. And it had come from Brian.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, the Philippines, Thailand and Syria.

title: Taking a Restful Position
description: Q. Is it best to sleep on your back, side or stomach?

title: Former JPMorgan Executive Said to Settle Hiring Dispute
description: JPMorgan Chase appears to have settled a dispute with a former close confidant of its chairman, Jamie Dimon, the latest reminder that the inner circle that helped the bank weather the financial crisis is no more.

title: Me Versus the Scale
description: The scale and I have reached dtente. That is: I leave it alone, and it affords me the same courtesy. I rarely step on it, and were both better off.

title: Bill to Offer an Option to Give Vouchers
description: Senator Lamar Alexander, who served as secretary of education under President George Bush in the early 1990s, plans to introduce a bill on Tuesday that would give 11 million children from low-income families federal money to spend on any kind of schooling their parents choose, as long as it is in an accredited institution.

title: After Complaints, Millie Gets Thoroughly Modern Makeover for Dalton School
description: Leaders of the Dalton School, one of Manhattans top private schools, this month canceled a student production of the musical Thoroughly Modern Millie over concerns about the shows use of Asian stereotypes and a subplot involving a white slavery ring in China, planning to replace it with a revue of the shows songs instead.

title: Second Grand Jury Indicts Officer in Shooting Death
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Three times since a police officer fired 10 bullets into her son Jonathan last September, Georgia Ferrell has made the long journey from the family home in Tallahassee, Fla. Each time, she sought to understand why her son, a former Florida A&M football star and a homebody who wanted to take his mother with him to the junior prom, was gunned down when he was just asking for help.

title: Looking for Insight Among the Worlds Irks and Quirks
description: In one of the longer entries in his very funny debut collection of stories, B. J. Novak describes a writer and translator named J. C. Audetat, who has a gift for the off-the-cuff vernacular of his day  or what might be called the poetry of everyday conversations.

title: Soup Kitchens Caused the Great Depression, AFF Edition
description: Thats AFF for Austrian founding fathers.

title: Sales of iPhones Set Record for Quarter: 51 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apples iPhone is still defying a long-held rule of the cellphone business: What goes up must come down.

title: Giants Hire Danny Langsdorf to Coach Quarterbacks
description: For the third time this month, the Giants have hired an assistant coach with a background as an offensive coordinator or quarterbacks coach, another indication that the resurrection of the teams offense  and the rejuvenation of quarterback Eli Manning  is an off-season priority.

title: U.S. Relaxes Some Data Disclosure Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration says it will allow Internet companies to give customers a better idea of how often the government demands their information, but will not allow companies to disclose what is being collected or how much.

title: Forget Market Timing, and Stick to a Balanced Fund
description: Investors were stung, badly, by the financial crisis of 2008. No one wants to go through an experience like that again, which has led to renewed interest in an investing approach called tactical asset allocation.

title: Martin Marietta Materials Reaches Deal to Acquire Texas Industries
description: Martin Marietta Materials has agreed to acquire Texas Industries in an all stock deal worth more than $2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: In Performance: Okwui Okpokwasili
description: The actress performs a scene from her solo show Bronx Gothic, which grew out of a series of notes passed between two 11-year-old girls. The show is at Danspace Project at St. Marks Church.

title: From Warheads to Cheap Energy
description: As the Cold War ended in the late 1980s and early 90s, a new fear arose amid the rejoicing and relief: that atomic security might fail in the disintegrating Soviet Union, allowing its huge stockpile of nuclear warheads to fall into unfriendly hands.

title: MSNBC Makes Room for Ronan Farrow, Rearranging the Schedule
description: MSNBC revised its daytime lineup on Monday, opening up an hour for its much-talked about recent hire, Ronan Farrow.

title: The Realities of Class Begin To Sink In
description: One of the odd things about America has long been the immense range of people who consider themselves middle class  and are deluding themselves. Low-paid workers who would be considered poor by international standards, say with incomes below half the median, nonetheless considered themselves lower-middle class; people with incomes four or five times the median considered themselves, at most, upper-middle class.

title: Justices Allow a Bit of License in Choice of Words During a Possible Air Emergency
description: WASHINGTON  Airlines may not be held liable for minor falsehoods in warning the authorities about potential threats to air security, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday. The court also issued decisions on whether workers must be paid for time spent changing into protective gear and on enhanced sentences for drug dealers whose products result in death.

title: Low-Status Symbols for One and All
description: A lot of odd inventions are featured in Billy Bobs Gags to Riches, but none are what the world really needs. What it really needs is a television filter that automatically blocks any show using the word redneck more than once per episode.

title: Income Inequality in the U.S. Means Princes Dont Go After Cinderellas
description: You can tax the rich, you can educate the poor, but there is another way to reduce the nations growing income inequality: Marry your scullery maid.

title: Flitting Through Fleeting Encounters
description: The installation by the artist JR at the David H. Koch Theater has transformed that buildings greatest glory, its tall, spacious first-floor foyer. Unlike the 2013 cartoon tower by the Brooklyn art collective Faile, it doesnt spoil or invade the space; it both deepens and teases it. Go up to the fourth ring, and, from above, it looks like a Baroque ceiling. Virtually life-size images of New York City Ballet dancers are arrayed in rings, whorls and patterns around the floor in various trompe loeil effects.

title: Minnesota Orchestra, Rebuilding After Lockout, Celebrates a Grammy Win
description: The Minnesota Orchestra, which just ended a bitter 16-month lockout and plans to get back to business next month, won the Grammy Award for best orchestral performance on Sunday for a recording of Sibelius symphonies with its former music director, Osmo Vanska.

title: As Loehmanns Liquidates, Bargains Get Bigger as Shelves Get Emptier
description: The Bronx-based department store Loehmanns may be in the process of a fire sale, but when, oh when, will the deep discounts begin?

title: Dum Dum Girls, Peggy Sue and Helen Sung Release Albums
description: DUM DUM GIRLS

title: It All Started With a 12-Year-Old Cousin
description: In 2008, Salman Khan, then a young hedge-fund analyst with a masters in computer science from M.I.T., started the Khan Academy, offering free online courses mainly in the STEM subjects  science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

title: All This and a Bag of Chips
description: The Super Bowl, to be played this year with the Seattle Seahawks facing the Denver Broncos on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium, is for all intents and purposes a national holiday.

title: So Much for Mayor de Blasios Transparency Pledge
description: For a guy who ran on a platform of transparency, inclusiveness and progressive new thinking, it hasnt taken New York Mayor Bill de Blasio long to clam up. On Thursday night he spoke to a closed-door meeting of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the leading pro-Israel lobbying group. The event, at the New York Hilton in Manhattan, was not listed on the mayors public schedule and a reporter who tried to attend was escorted away by AIPAC security staff.

title: Slavery as New Focus for a Game
description: In what sounds like a joke by a stand-up comic  Chris Rock? Dave Chappelle?  with a fondness for PlayStation, the greatest black heroine in the history of video games was forced to live for more than a year in the ghetto of Sonys faltering hand-held console, the Vita.

title: Beyond Early Childhood Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Moment in the Sun for Each and Every Instrument
description: In the program notes for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers concert on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, the Adagio of Spohrs Grand Nonetto in F is described as beautiful and attractive without stirring any deep emotions. That observation could easily have been applied to all the genial works in this lineup of cocktail party pleasantries.

title: Polar Bears Turn to Snow-Goose Egg Diet
description: As a warming climate causes sea ice in the Arctic to melt earlier each year, polar bears are spending more time on land  and changing their diets accordingly. A new study shows that the bears, whose traditional prey is ringed seal pups, are now eating more snow-goose eggs and caribou.

title: Artifacts | The Sensual, Suggestive Appeal of Keith Sonniers Neon Sculptures
description: When the sculptor Keith Sonnier arrived in the late 1960s, he was identified with other young radicals like Richard Serra, Eva Hesse, Bruce Nauman and Lynda Benglis as Post-Minimalist, a catchall term that immediately wrote them into history books. The label was meant to distinguish them from their slightly older, Minimalist contemporaries, including Sol Lewitt, Carl Andre, Donald Judd and Dan Flavin, all of whom used inflexible materials for impersonal, geometric objects manufactured by others.

title: Aid to Syrian Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: A High-Priced Rhino Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Up in the Air on Sunday? JetBlue Has a Super Bowl Plan
description: Any true football fan wouldnt be caught anywhere near an airport on Super Bowl Sunday, but just in case, JetBlue Airways is at the ready, with in-flight viewing options to watch the game, cheap beer and a snack that tastes like wings.

title: New Lead in Honeybee Deaths and Another Hot Year on Earth
description: In a satisfying twist, meteorologists called out the public last week for being inaccurate. Weeks after introducing us to polar vortex  the term for a weather pattern that typically swirls above northern Canada or Siberia and sometimes sends cold air south  the nations forecasters grew tired of hearing it. The Weather Channel meteorologists Chris Dolce and Nick Wiltgen complained on their Weather Underground blog that the word had become a catchphrase, mistakenly used to refer to the cold air itself, and not the vortex, which never really moves through the atmosphere above the United States. So please, everybody. Chill.

title: Times Minute | Hacking Angry Birds
description: Also on the Minute, three years in space and interactive art at the ballet.

title: Times Minute | Hacking Angry Birds
description: In the Video

title: Despite Spate of Deals, Vodafone Faces an Uncertain Future
description: The British telecommunications giant Vodafone is at a crossroads.

title: Clinton Calls Benghazi Her Biggest Regret as Secretary
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday called the deadly attack on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012 her biggest regret in the four years she served as secretary of state.

title: Herbalife Shares Rise After Bullish Analyst Takes New Job
description: Shares of Herbalife rose 6.7 percent on Monday after a report that an analyst covering the stock had gone to work for a major shareholder.

title: Distressed Debt Hedge Fund Commits $530 Million to Europe
description: Marathon Asset Management has gained a reputation for being a rag-and-bone picker, finding opportunities in the aftermath of financial disaster.

title: No Longer Leading Killer, Plague Still Raises Fears
description: Bubonic plague, caused by the rodent-borne bacterium Yersinia pestis, has killed a large fraction of the earths population at least twice  most famously in the medieval Black Death, but before that in the Plague of Justinian, which began in A.D. 541. That pandemic, named for the Byzantine emperor, may have killed half of Europe and Asia; it hastened the collapse of the Roman Empires remnants and ushered in the Dark Ages.

title: As Gunmen Kill 45 in Nigeria, Suspicion Falls on Militants
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  Gunmen stormed a village in northeastern Nigeria late Sunday afternoon, shooting down traders and shoppers and killing at least 45 people on a busy market day, the police and witnesses said on Monday. The attack was one of the deadliest yet to be attributed to the militant Islamist group Boko Haram.

title: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments in Spring 2014 Paris Couture Week
description: Last week, on the heels of Paris Mens Fashion Week, the City of Light set the scene for the spring 2014 womens couture shows. From the fashion to thehaute joaillerie to off-the-runway hilarity, these are some of the seasons most memorable moments.

title: Farm Bill Compromise Will Change Programs and Reduce Spending
description: WASHINGTON  House and Senate negotiators on Monday agreed on a new five-year farm bill that will eliminate or consolidate dozens of agriculture subsidy programs, expand government-subsidized crop insurance and cut about $8 billion from the food stamp program over the next decade.

title: Jersey City, Where Seahawks and Broncos Roam
Betting on Conversation With the Person in the Window Seat
description: I ENJOY business travel when it gives me the opportunity to visit with other cultures. Those cultures dont have to be found in foreign lands. In the United States, there are so many different and wonderful cultural experiences you can have just traveling between Washington, Michigan and Kentucky, for example.

title: Airport Forecast for 2014: More Guns, Faster Security
description: THE T.S.A. Blog, a chatty official newsletter run by a small group of Transportation Security Administration employees, offers a nice window into what is most likely ahead in air travel.

title: Emilios Great Race
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  The campaign for student body president at the University of North Carolina here has just begun, and theres nothing unusual in the number of candidates  five  or the fact that two are Morehead-Cain scholars, an elite designation.

title: Socratic View of Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Businesses See Scant Benefit From the Game That Cant Be Named
description: LYNDHURST, N.J.  The Cigar Emporium here is popular with Jets and Giants fans on game days at MetLife Stadium, in neighboring East Rutherford.

title: Lebanese Cringe as a Breakdown in Government Wafts Uphill
description: BAAOUARTA, Lebanon  Standing near his home in this hilltop village, a local real estate agent angrily listed the drawbacks of living uphill  and downwind  from Lebanons largest landfill.

title: Tom Perkins Again Discusses Nazis, Class Warfare and Now, Watches
description: Tom Perkins certainly has taken heat for his recent letter to the editor in The Wall Street Journal. If he was trying to turn down the temperature, however, his interview with Bloomberg Television on Monday did not quite cut it.

title: Immigrants in Detroit
description: To the Editor:

title: Actors Equity Members Discuss Tour Wages
description: The Actors Equity union, which represents thousands of theater performers, laid groundwork on Monday afternoon for its next round of contract negotiations with producers, in 2015, by holding a town hall meeting about rank-and-file concerns over low salaries for several Equity tours of Broadway musicals.

title: Think Back: The State of the Response
description: The presidents State of the Union address may look the same on television year after year, but the responses usually offer more variety and entertainment, says The Timess Sam Tanenhaus.

title: With Better Security Technology, Hotels Shore Up Blind Spots
description: At a poker tournament in Barcelona last September, Jens Kyllnen, a professional player, said that his room at Hotel Arts was broken into and malware was installed on his computer to transmit anything he saw on his screen as he played. Despite video camera systems and electronic key card entry logs, no one was caught.

title: Former Exit Port for a Wave of Cubans Hopes to Attract Global Shipping
description: MARIEL, Cuba  The images of desperate refugees crammed onto boats have defined this bay outside Havana for decades. About 125,000 Cubans left from here in 1980 after Fidel Castro, facing growing discontent, announced that anyone who wanted to leave should just go to Mariel and get out.

title: California Denies Scorned Journalist Stephen Glass Right to Practice Law
description: In 1998, Stephen Glass was all but banished from the profession of journalism. On Monday, the California Supreme Court ruled that he was not welcome as a lawyer, either.

title: The Friendly Derby? Well, Everton-Liverpool Is Friendlier
description: LIVERPOOL, England  European soccer rivalries have long been blamed for a variety of extreme circumstances, from deaths and vandalism to the lobbing of flares and the occasional appearance of a pigs severed head. Rarely, however, do they split a family at Sunday dinner. Except here.

title: Activists Try to Hijack Promotions by Sponsors of Sochi Olympics
description: IT is the closest thing to a sure bet in advertising  associating with the Olympic athletes who train for years with the chance of winning a gold medal. And corporations are paying big money to align themselves with the Olympians competing at next months Winter Olympics in Sochi.

title: Addicted to I.V.F., or Addicted to Hope?
description: You know, some people here get addicted to I.V.F., a friend of a friend said when I mentioned to her that I was going to be doing fertility treatments in Israel, after my attempts in America.

title: Company Struggles to Keep U.S. in the Uranium Enrichment Game
description: EUNICE, N.M.  While the only American-owned company that enriches uranium prepares for bankruptcy, its competitor is zooming ahead with construction of what it describes as a cluster of far more economical and efficient new centrifuges.

title: Stewart Is Back, With Confidence and Pain
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Aerosmiths Back in the Saddle was playing over the loudspeaker during introductions as Tony Stewart strode into a news conference at the Charlotte Convention Center on Monday with a noticeable limp. No, he is not 100 percent after fracturing the tibia and fibula in his right leg in a racing accident last August.

title: Alone, Yet Not Alone
description: There is a strong vein of hostility against orthodox religious believers in America today, especially among the young. When secular or mostly secular people are asked by researchers to give their impression of the devoutly faithful, whether Jewish, Christian or other, the words that come up commonly include judgmental, hypocritical, old-fashioned and out of touch.

title: Ticket Prices Fall on the Resale Market, Brokers Say
description: New York is filled with firsts and superlatives, and this years Super Bowl is providing more. The first outdoor Super Bowl in a cold climate. The first mass transit Super Bowl. A fanfest staged in the heart of Manhattan.

title: From Your Friends at the N.R.A.
description: The following are verbatim excerpts from emails sent by the National Rifle Association.

title: Translation as a Performing Art
description: Thirty years ago I moved to Milan to work for an Italian art magazine called FMR. It was an odd and ambitious enterprise: FMR started publishing in the United States a year later with the slogan the most beautiful magazine in the world. The offices hardly seemed like offices at all: they were located in Palazzo Visconti di Modrone, an exceptionally fine piece of Milanese rococo architecture. The building was Luchino Viscontis childhood home, and it was a gorgeous and dramatic workplace. When it was time for coffee, we ordered in rounds of espressos, which were brought by a white-coated young man carrying a silver trayful of demitasse thermoses. Every few months, one of the magazines production managers would take orders for prosciutto from his hometown, Parma  the whole ham, what they thin-slice in an Italian gastronomia. Price: about $20.

title: West to East Coast: Voyage of a Crane
description: On its 6,000-mile journey from San Francisco to New York, the 328-foot Left Coast Lifter crane traveled through the Panama Canal on its way to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

title: Muscular West Coast Worker Is on Way to Build New Tappan Zee
description: PANAMA  The Left Coast Lifter is the Superman of floating cranes.

title: Job Aid Zones Face a New Test in Coal Country
description: HAZARD, Ky.  Joseph Nantz still looks back fondly at his job as a heavy machinery operator at the mountaintop coal mine here, helping to blast and cart away layers of rock to reveal seams of coal and then restore the rubble for a handsome $24 an hour.

title: The House Targets Superfund
description: Earlier this month, the House approved a package of bills that could undercut an environmental law that has helped clean some of the most polluted places in the nation. The measures would allow states to apply their own standards to the cleanup of hazardous waste sites  standards that in most cases are likely to be considerably weaker than those governing the federal Superfund program, the 1980 program that has identified thousands of toxic waste sites and cleaned up many of them.

title: Contraception Before the Court
description: In a disappointing order on Friday, the Supreme Court extended a temporary injunction barring the Obama administration from enforcing paperwork rules against a Colorado nuns group in connection with a federal law that requires employer health plans to cover birth control without a co-payment.

title: Genetic Weapon Against Insects Raises Hope and Fear in Farming
description: Scientists and biotechnology companies are developing what could become the next powerful weapon in the war on pests  one that harnesses a Nobel Prize-winning discovery to kill insects and pathogens by disabling their genes.

title: Syria Talks Fail to Yield Pact to Lift Aid Blockade
description: GENEVA  The Syrian government on Monday failed to authorize an international aid convoy to enter blockaded areas in the city of Homs, as the oppositions Western backers declared that if the delivery was not allowed by next week they would be likely to challenge the government in the United Nations Security Council.

title: At Neutral Site, Syrians Feel Free to Confront the Other Side
description: GENEVA  For Syrian officials, a lakeside idyll here, far from their countrys war, has been marred by what plainly feels to them like an endless stream of impertinent questions.

title: Two Islanders Who Keep the Hits Coming
description: They glide in from all angles seeking crashes and pileups, a human demolition derby in blue. Wherever they go, bodies go tumbling, hockey sticks go flying through the air, and the Plexiglas panels atop the boards undulate in concussive waves from the collisions they engineer.

title: Anxiety Rising Over Relations Between Japan and China
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Even with all the optimism about the global economy here last week at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, there was a remarkable economic and political risk that appeared to have been largely overlooked: The long-simmering battle between China and Japan may be close to boiling over. One top executive went so far as to describe the nations relationship as a stealth war.

title: The Mayor Pushes Back, for Pre-K
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio went to Albany on Monday to answer the naysayers and skeptics  chief among them, Gov. Andrew Cuomo  who want him to abandon his prekindergarten plan and his tax on wealthy residents. Mr. de Blasio was there to make an ambitious case: to extend free, full-day, high-quality pre-K across the city in two years, eventually to reach more than 73,000 4-year-olds.

title: Second Cargo of Chemical Agents Leaves Syria as Pace Is Criticized
description: The second cargo of Syrias most toxic chemical weapons was exported by ship on Monday for eventual destruction at sea, officials overseeing the effort reported. But the slow pace of removal, which is way behind schedule and has missed one deadline already, is causing increased concern and threatening to violate another deadline in less than two weeks.

title: Japan: Broadcast Chief Apologizes for Comment on Comfort Women
description: The new chairman of Japans public broadcaster apologized Monday after drawing sharp criticism for saying that his nation should not be singled out for forcing women into sexual servitude during World War II. Katsuto Momii, the newly appointed chairman of the public broadcaster, NHK, also was criticized for saying that the broadcaster would refrain from criticizing the government on such delicate issues as visits to a controversial shrine honoring war dead. On Monday, Mr. Momii said his comments on Sunday about the so-called comfort women forced to work in wartime military brothels were personal opinions that were not appropriate to say.

title: Iraq: United States to Deliver Helicopters
description: Congress has approved the delivery of six Apache attack helicopters to the Iraqi military, Pentagon and congressional officials said Monday. The leased Apaches will not arrive in Iraq until this summer after they have been equipped and Iraqi pilots have been trained. The transfer had been held up for months until members of Congress were assured that the helicopters would be used for national security purposes, and not for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to employ against his political enemies. Iraqi troops have been locked in a standoff with militants in the western province of Anbar in recent weeks, and insurgents in other parts of the country have been carrying out a campaign of attacks for months. The United States has also agreed to sell Iraq 24 new Apaches, but that delivery is still three years away.

title: Did Big Internet Companies Handicap Start-Ups in FISA Rule Changes?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A small but significant caveat in a new agreement brokered between the Obama administration and Google, Facebook, Yahoo and Microsoft could cast a long shadow over Americas technology start-ups.

title: Mexico: Gang Leader Is Arrested
description: Mexican authorities said Monday that they had arrested one of the top leaders of the Knights Templar, the organized crime gang that has spread such terror in the western state of Michoacn that citizens have formed vigilante groups to fight it. Dionisio Loya Plancarte, who is believed to handle the gangs public relations, was found hiding in a closet in Michoacn and arrested. He faces charges related to organized crime and drug trafficking, the Interior Ministry said. President Enrique Pea Nieto sent troops and more police officers into Michoacn two weeks ago, but the self-defense groups refused to lay down their arms. On Monday, they agreed to work under military command, but they will not disband.

title: Diamonds in Rough Shrug Off the Cut of Rejection
description: JERSEY CITY  Wes Welker of the Denver Broncos and Doug Baldwin of the Seattle Seahawks are productive wide receivers who have more than relative lack of size in common. Both are driven by rejection.

title: Stability Versus Democracy in Egypt
Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 28, 2014
description: By having these devices in our pockets and using them more and more, youre somehow becoming a sensor for the world intelligence community.

title: Court Grants Peru Ocean Territory Claimed by Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A six-year maritime dispute between Chile and Peru was settled on Monday when the International Court of Justice in The Hague ruled largely in favor of Peru, stripping Chile of economic rights over a swath of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Obamas Puzzle: Economy Rarely Better, Approval Rarely Worse
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will pronounce on the state of the union for the fifth time on Tuesday, and never during his time in office has the state of the economy been better  yet rarely has he gotten such low marks from the public for his handling of it.

title: The Food May Be Fast, but These Customers Wont Be Rushed
description: With its low coffee prices, plentiful tables and available bathrooms, McDonalds restaurants all over the country, and even all over the world, have been adopted by a cost-conscious set as a coffeehouse for the people, a sort of everymans Starbucks.

title: Corrections: January 28, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Rats Take the Nacho Cheese
description: A little bit of Las Vegas has splashed down on the campus of Lincoln Center, of all unlikely places. To enter the Claire Tow Theater, where Stop Hitting Yourself, the frisky new show from the adventurous theater collective Rude Mechs is being presented, feels like stepping into one of the gaudier suites at Caesars Palace.

title: Goddess of the Hunt
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  What word would you use to describe this debut by Jeff Stillman?

title: Antibiotics in Animals Tied to Risk of Human Infection
description: A federal analysis of 30 antibiotics used in animal feed found that the majority of them were likely to be contributing to the growing problem of bacterial infections that are resistant to treatment in people, according to documents released Monday by a health advocacy group.

title: A Lieutenant Governor, an Artist and a Portrait of a Smear
description: TRENTON  In her first year in office, Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno opened a frontal attack on an unlikely target, the New Jersey State Council on the Arts.

title: Judge Rejects Execution Delay Over Use of Compounded Drug
description: Lawyers for a Missouri inmate said Mondaythat they would appeal a decision not to grant a delay in his execution, arguing that the drug to be used was likely to be substandard, and thus could cause him severe pain, because it was produced in a compounding pharmacy not subject to federal drug safety regulations.

title: Advertisements for Death
description: The recently released images from a cache of 55,000 photographs depicting emaciated, strangled and beaten corpses  allegedly taken in the jails of the Syrian president Bashar al-Assad  are terrible to view. They are also bewildering. The photographs, which document the deaths of some 11,000 detainees, were taken not by the opposition but at the behest of Mr. Assads regime. Wouldnt such a government  wouldnt any government  want to hide its crimes rather than record them?

title: Midtown Attack Investigated as Hate Crime
description: Ten days after being attacked, Randy Gener can talk again. He also now recognizes his husband and his sister, seated at his hospital bedside.

title: De Blasio and Cuomo Team Up to Save Brooklyn Hospitals
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at odds over how to pay for prekindergarten, showed a unified front on Monday on helping distressed Brooklyn hospitals and said that without immediate federal support, there will be closures.

title: Stabbing Suspect Found to Be Unfit to Continue Case
description: Two court-appointed doctors found that a Chinese immigrant accused of stabbing his cousins wife and the couples four children to death in October was too mentally ill to continue with his criminal case. A judge is expected to commit him to a psychiatric facility for treatment, a spokeswoman for the Brooklyn district attorneys office said.

title: Motions Denied in Yonkers Corruption Case
description: A federal judge on Monday denied motions by two former Yonkers political figures to set aside their convictions in a 2012 corruption trial on grounds that a prosecution witness had not disclosed that he paid a $5,000 bribe to a municipal employee while he was assisting the authorities.

title: Pennsylvania Deaths of 22 Linked to Batch of Heroin
description: Pennsylvania officials warned residents on Monday about a dangerous batch of heroin that has caused 22 deaths.

title: In Las Vegas, Putting a Lot on the Line for the Super Bowl
description: LAS VEGAS  Johnny Avello has a big title, executive director of race and sports operations at Wynn Las Vegas  but in a town that talks about point spreads with the same intensity that farmers discuss the weather, he has an even bigger reputation. He isconsidered a Don in one of this towns most respected fraternities, the brotherhood of bookies. Call him a wizard, a Wizard of Odds.

description: Acrostic answer for January 26, 2014

title: The Wizards of Odds
description: An inside look at how oddsmakers in Las Vegas pull in $100 million on Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Nets Give Up Chance to Close Gap on Raptors
description: Deron Williams wiped his hands against his shorts before taking a bounce pass from the referee near midcourt. Williams toed the sideline, readying to inbound the ball as the Nets clung to a 1-point lead over the Toronto Raptors.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 27, 2014
Anthony Says Winning Title Is Sole Focus
description: Carmelo Anthony told reporters Monday that he wants to win an N.B.A. championship, which seemed like a totally reasonable thing for him to say. But given Anthonys stated plan to declare for free agency next summer, it instantly led to wild speculation about his future with the Knicks: Is he staying or going?

title: Luis valos, Actor on The Electric Company, Dies at 67
description: Luis valos, a Cuban-born actor known for his long tenure on The Electric Company, the popular PBS childrens program of the 1970s, died on Wednesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 67.

title: Jos Emilio Pacheco, Honored Writer Who Wrote of Social Ills, Dies at 74
description: Jos Emilio Pacheco, a Mexican poet and author who achieved renown throughout the Spanish-speaking world with highly literate poems, essays and novels that used an array of styles to explore profound questions, died on Sunday in Mexico City. He was 74.

title: Crackdowns on Live Poultry Sales Mar Holiday Season
description: As Chinese get ready for their Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, and the Hong Kong government started culling 20,000 of the birds on Tuesday as fears grew about the spread of avian influenza.

title: Archie Manning Envisions Peyton Playing Past Super Bowl
description: Peyton Mannings father, Archie Manning, said he expected his son to continue to play for the Denver Broncos beyond this season, even if he added a second Super Bowl championship to his long list of accomplishments.

title: More Delays and Rising Cost for Project Connecting L.I.R.R. to Grand Central Terminal
description: Commuters looking forward to the long-awaited project that will connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal may now have to wait until 2023.

title: Google Glass to Be Covered by Vision Care Insurer VSP
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and VSP, the nations biggest optical health insurance provider, have struck a deal to offer subsidized frames and prescription lenses for Google Glass, the Internet-connected eyewear.

title: Securities Class-Action Suits Up Slightly in 2013
description: Angry investors filed more federal class-action securities lawsuits last year than in 2012. But investors have been angrier.

title: The Roots of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, Part II
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

description: This must be the fastest-moving month in the history of new media. The latest entrant features yet one more familiar face.
