description: Related Article

title: Why the U.S. Embassy Releases Pollution Data in Beijing But Not in Delhi
description: NEW DELHI  The United States government measures air quality levels in both its Beijing and Delhi embassies, but it only publicizes the results from its Beijing monitor. Why?

title: In Motorola Purchase, Lenovo Gains Big Footprint in Smartphones
description: TOKYO  Apple and Samsung Electronics dominate the smartphone business, controlling about half of the sales and most of the profits. An ever-changing roster of also-rans has struggled to close the gap.

title: Google Sells Motorola Unit to Lenovo
description: Lenovo seems to be on a buying binge, and not even Google can escape. In its second deal in a week, the Chinese company, once best known for making personal computers, announced that it was buying Googles Motorola Mobility smartphone unit for $2.91 billion. Last week, Lenovo acquired IBMs low-end server business for $2.3 billion.

title: Wizard Who Made Art Jump Off the Page
description: TWENTY years ago, while browsing in an antiques store near Phoenix, Ellen G. K. Rubin, a book collector, spied something intriguing at the top of a rickety shelf. It was a pop-up book, Moko and Koko in the Jungle, that had been opened up to reveal a stand of banana trees, more than a foot tall, teeming with animal life.

title: Trapped by A.L.S., He Urged His Daughter to Fly Free
description: When I was 18 I watched my father perform what would be his final surgery.

title: Loot No Longer
description: PARIS  I worked nights from a leather chair in my living room, armed with an iPad, a telephone and a notebook. My mission was to see if I could reconnect Jewish families and others with fine art pillaged from their relatives during World War II.

title: Blackstone Earnings More Than Doubled in Fourth Quarter
description: Updated, 3:00 p.m. | The soaring stock market was a boon last year to private equity firms looking to sell their holdings to investors. For the Blackstone Group in particular, a series of well-timed sales helped the firm double its profit in the fourth quarter.

title: Reader Idea | Using Times Articles for Copy-Change Text Collaborations
description: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you have used The Times in your classroom and would like to see your idea on our blog, write in and tell us what youve done.

title: Former Chief of Akamai Joins General Catalyst as Partner
description: Paul Sagan, a former chief executive of Akamai Technologies, is starting a new chapter as a venture capitalist.

title: Gravity and the Directors Contest
description: Major industry awards like those handed out by the Screen Actors Guild and the Producers Guild usually offer clues to the eventual best picture Oscar winner. But with American Hustle, 12 Years a Slave and Gravity each collecting a big precursor prize, its turned into a three-way race. That was confirmed when the Directors Guild honored Gravity and its filmmaker, Alfonso Cuarn, a prize he couldnt have expected after one disastrous test screening.

title: A Passenger, a Cabdriver and a Missing $10 Bill
description: Dear Diary:

title: U.S. Envoy to Visit Sri Lanka as Pressure Builds for War Crimes Inquiry
description: NEW DELHI  A top State Department official is expected to arrive in Sri Lanka on Friday, just three days after the United States announced that it would again seek a resolution at the United Nations Human Rights Council pressing for an investigation into allegations of war crimes in Sri Lanka.

title: A Case for Cheaper Broadband in Schools
description: A nonprofit organization with its roots in the high-tech industry has gathered some 40 executives to demand that the Federal Communications Commission change how it is wiring Americas schools.

title: Economy Is Expanding, but Obamas Legacy May Be Slipping Away
description: Five years into the Obama presidency, the American economy is finally showing some momentum.

title: Mens Wearhouse Willing to Raise Offer for Jos. A. Bank
description: Mens Wearhouse may be willing to increase its bid for Jos. A. Bank in the continuing takeover battle between the two mens suit retailers.

title: Talking Talent | Sarah Jessica Parker, Star of the Off-Broadway Play The Commons of Pensacola
description: The Emmy Award-winning actress Sarah Jessica Parker is just a month away from seeing her new shoe line, SJP, hit Nordstrom stores on Feb. 28. She designed the 25 made-in-Italy styles alongside George Malkemus, the C.E.O. of Manolo Blahnik whose heels carried Carrie around Manhattan for the six seasons of Sex and the City but the SJP collection will fall at a more affordable price point, ranging from $195 to $500. Before she kicks off a multicity tour for SJP, Parker will take her final bow as Becca in the Manhattan Theatre Club production of The Commons of Pensacola, on Feb. 9. Last week, she chatted about the Lynne Meadow-directed play in which she stars alongside Blythe Danner, who plays her mother the much-anticipated heels and what she does when she sees the Sex and the City tour bus go by.

title: A Big Advocate of French in New Yorks Schools: France
description: In the fugue of tongues on New Yorks streets, French has never been a dominant voice. And as surging numbers of Asian and Latino immigrants continue to tip the balance of foreign languages toward Chinese and Spanish, the idea of learning French, to some, may seem kind of quaint, even anachronistic.

title: Militants Attack Transportation Ministry in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Militants attacked the Transportation Ministry compound in Baghdad on Thursday morning, killing seven people, according to security officials.

title: Amanda Knox Is Re-Convicted of Murder in Italy
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend were convicted on Thursday for a second time in the 2007 murder of Meredith Kercher, who shared an apartment with Ms. Knox in the university town of Perugia, where both women were exchange students. The presiding judge in the Florence court sentenced Ms. Knox to 28 years in prison and the boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, to 25 years.

title: Andhra Pradesh Assembly Rejects New Delhis Proposal to Create New State
description: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh  After two months of contentious debate, often interrupted by protests, the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assemblyon ThursdayrejectedNew Delhis proposalto create a new state of Telangana out of Andhra Pradesh.

title: Obama and G.O.P. Facing Opposition to Trade Pacts
description: WASHINGTON  For companies like General Electric and Honeywell, it would help open untapped global markets, lift exports and create middle-class American jobs. For labor groups like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters, it is a threat to American workers, bound to lead to lost jobs and lower wages, as well as rising corporate profits.

title: Low Vitamin D Tied to a Pregnancy Risk
description: Using preserved blood samples of pregnant women, researchers have found that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk for severe preeclampsia, a serious and sometimes fatal disorder of pregnancy.

title: Officials Remain in the Hot Seat as the South Thaws
description: ATLANTA  Parts of the Deep South sputtered slowly toward normalcy on Thursday, two days after a winter storm crippled vast stretches of the region and created unprecedented gridlock in its most populated areas.

title: Istanbearish
description: OK, did we need this? Turkey? Who was paying attention to Turkey?

title: This Star of England, in Person
description: LONDON  Along St. Martins Lane, the girls are lining up for their little touch of Harry in the night. No, that is not a snarky reference to another case of untoward groping by a member of Parliament, a subject of much conversation here. The exchange these young women are awaiting is something more, shall we say, celestial.

title: Gary Shteyngart: By the Book
description: The author of the novel Super Sad True Love Story and, most recently, the memoir Little Failure likes books in which people suffer. If theres no suffering, I kind of tune out.

title: Activists Solicit Shareholders to Replace Board at CommonWealth REIT
description: CommonWealth REIT, the embattled real estate trust, recently extended an olive branch to the activist shareholders pressing the company for change.

title: A Real-Life Wolf of Wall Street Reunion, Minus the Wolf
description: Moviegoers cringed at the many scenes of debauchery and dishonesty in The Wolf of Wall Street, a film based on the real-life shenanigans of the boiler room kingpin Jordan Belfort.

title: Image of the Day: January 30
Dawn Zier of Nutrisystem on When Your Company Is Adrift
description: This interview with Dawn M. Zier, chief executive of Nutrisystem, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Justice Dept. Starts Quest for Inmates to Be Freed
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department wants low-level drug criminals who were sentenced under tough laws from the days of the crack epidemic to ask the president for early release from prison.

title: Really Counting the Epithets in Wolf
description: LOS ANGELES  So just exactly how many four-letter epithets are there in The Wolf of Wall Street? (You know which one we mean.) For weeks, the number floating around the Internet has been 506: thats a count promoted by Variety and other outlets, and trumpeted as the highest number for an R-rated movie. But the sleuths at Slate did a little investigating and, as it turns out, that figure is based on  at best  a blog estimate amplified by Wikipedia. And whats more, its a lowball.

title: Broncos vs. Seahawks, Atop the Empire State Building
description: The worlds most colorful football debate began on Monday evening  at the top of the Empire State Building.

title: In Our Pages: January 31
description: 1889: Prince Rudolf Dead

title: Landed at the Wrong Airport? Imagining a P.R. Response
description: A Southwest Airlines jet touched down at the wrong Missouri airport this month, a mix-up that comes two months after a cargo jet landed at the wrong airport in Kansas. How will the industry bounce back from the embarrassing publicity? Herewith, some suggestions for an emergency P.R. campaign.

title: Why the Homeownership Rate Is Misleading
description: Jed Kolko is chief economist and vice president for analytics at Trulia, an online marketplace for residential real estate.

title: An Alibaba Rival Plans Its Own I.P.O. This Year
description: SHANGHAI  JD.com, one of Chinas biggest e-commerce companies, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it planned to raise $1.5 billion this year in an initial public offering in the United States.

title: Henry Waxman, Key Democrat and Force for Health Care Law, Is to Retire
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, a diminutive Democratic giant whose 40 years in the House produced some of the most important legislation of the era, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year.

title: Diageo Reports Slower Growth
description: LONDON  Selling beer and liquor in emerging markets has for a long time been investors main attraction to Diageo. On Thursday, some investors sold their shares because of it.

title: Viacom Quarterly Profit Rises 16%, Lifted by Cable Fees and Lower Costs
description: Lower costs at Paramount Pictures and higher subscriber fees at cable networks like Nickelodeon, Comedy Central and VH1 helped Viacom report a 16 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on Thursday.

title: Can You Tie Them in a Knot?
description: N.B.A. sneakers have become a way for players to express themselves within league guidelines. So try and match the player with his footwear.

title: When Doctors Give Patients Money
description: Recently a few of my colleagues were sitting together and one asked if any of us had ever given money to a patient. There was an awkward pause, and then the stories starting coming out  a few dollars for a co-pay, or to help a frail patient take a cab instead of a bus; a bag of food or an extra meal. How could I not, one doctor said, when my patients immediate need could be solved by the small change in my coat pocket?

title: Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld, Tiger Couple
description: Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother was Amy Chuas first real foray into pop-cultural polemics. Her new book, written with her husband Jed Rubenfeld, enters the same cultural minefield.

title: Bieber Faces Assault Charge in Toronto
description: In this weeks episode of the Justin Bieber Show, the 19-year-oldCanadian singer has returned to his homeland, only to find himself once more chatting with the police. This time, he went to the Toronto police voluntarily, a starkcontrast with last weeks installment, in which Mr. Bieber was arrested in Miami Beach and charged with driving under the influence, resisting arrest and driving without a valid license.

title: Mayor Says New York City Will Settle Suits on Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
description: New York City will settle its long-running legal battle over the Police Departments practice of stopping, questioning and often frisking people on the street  a divisive issue at the heart of the mayoral race last year  by agreeing to reforms that a judge ordered in August, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday.

title: Lauder Calls for New Panel to Resolve Nazi Art-Looting Restitution Issues
description: Ronald S. Lauder, an art collector and philanthropist who is president of the World Jewish Congress, called on Thursday for the establishment of a new commission, made up of German and foreign experts, that would resolve once and for all the issue of art looted from Jews by the Nazis. Some of these works, Mr. Lauder said, still hang in German museums and even government offices.

title: Today in Small Business: Joke Products
description: Here are seven policy initiatives fromthe presidents State of the Union address that could affect small businesses.

title: Southwest Will Begin Flights to Caribbean
description: Southwest Airlines took a step toward becoming an international carrier this week with the announcement that it would begin daily service to Aruba, the Bahamas and Jamaica this summer.

title: Playwright Sues to Salvage Play Deconstructing Threes Company
description: The New York playwright David Adjmi, best known for Off Broadway satirical works like Marie Antoinette, went to federal court on Thursday to try to salvage his play 3C, which has been tied up by the copyright owner of Threes Company, the landmark television comedy that Mr. Adjmi deconstructs through a dark lens in 3C.

title: Wheelies: The Retooling for the F-150 Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Quarterly Earnings Fall at Exxon Mobil and Shell
description: For the second quarter in a row, Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday reported sharply lower earnings because of a decrease in oil prices, declining production and soaring expenses for megaprojects around the globe.

title: Lenovos Merger Spree Challenges Investors Faith
description: Lenovo prides itself on being a modern multinational, but its approach to divulging information remains frustratingly old school.

title: A Copy of David Adjmis Legal Complaint Filed in Federal Court
description: The playwright David Adjmi asked the Southern District Court of New York to declare that his play 3C does not infringe on the copyright of Threes Company, the television comedy that ran from 1977 to 1984.

title: Showing Deaf Players They Fit In, Too
description: NEWARK  Hearing aids in, lip-reading skill at the ready, Derrick Coleman, a Seattle Seahawks fullback, fielded question after question from reporters at Super Bowl media day. Most of them were about his hearing loss.

title: Equality as Handout
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama endorsed a basic feminist concept that no national politician would dare contradict: A woman deserves equal pay for equal work.Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, who delivered the official Republican response to the presidents speech, didnt hesitate to endorse the principle in a Wednesday CNN interview: Republicans and I support equal pay for equal work, she said.

title: Another Super Bowl Ad Fest, This Time on the Cellphone
description: Want to see the Vince Lombardi Trophy that goes to the Super Bowl winner? Take a left in 15 feet. Looking to buy some Super Bowl merchandise? Try the fourth floor of Macys, straight ahead.

title: Times Minute | Henry Waxman Retires
description: In the Video

title: The Combination Drawing Club and Taco Bell
description: If the cold New York weather has you looking for indoor activities, a little-known (and free) drawing club is held most Wednesdays from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. at the Taco Bell on 14th Street just west of Union Square. The artist Jason Polan started the Taco Bell Drawing Club nine years ago and still attends many of the weekly meetings. Polan is a prolific artist; he has drawn every piece of art in the Museum of Modern Art (not once but twice) and is currently on a mission to draw every person in New York. The club meetings are open to anyone who wants to show up and draw. Having visited recently, I decided to ask Polan some questions about the group.

title: Times Minute | Henry Waxman Retires
description: Also on the Minute, an audit of U.S. aid to Afghanistan and Barneys New York launches a transgender ad campaign.

title: Libyan Investment Fund Sues Goldman Over Loss
description: Updated, 7:01 p.m. | Libyas sovereign investment fund has filed a lawsuit against Goldman Sachs in Londons High Court, claiming that the bank made more than $1 billion in derivatives trades that became worthless, but left Goldman with a profit of $350 million.

title: 18 Charged With Operating Prostitution and Drug Ring
description: Just days before the kickoff of Super Bowl XLVIII, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman on Thursday announced charges against 18 people for operating a high-end prostitution and drug trafficking ring.

title: Shopping Cart Injuries Remain Common
description: Shopping carts might not seem like a particularly dangerous place for a child, but from 1990 to 2011, an average of 66 children a day wound up in emergency rooms after injuries sustained in and near them.

title: Biathlete Leaves Russian Team After Testing Positive
description: Irina Starykh, a biathlete who was one of Russias brightest hopes for an Olympic medal in Sochi, announced Thursday that she was stepping down from the team because of a doping violation.

title: Delay in Chemical Arms Pledge Criticized
description: The United States sharply criticized Syria on Thursday over delays in the timetable for eliminating its chemical weapons, accusing the Syrian government of deliberately stalling their removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and  in a new complaint  reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

title: Dark Side of Capital in Emerging Markets
description: It is no fun to be a central banker in an emerging-market country when investors suddenly grow doubtful.

title: As Gaza Tunnels Closed, Hamas Lost Cash, Israeli Official Says
description: TEL AVIV  Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, is in severe economic straits, having lost a major source of income in recent months because of an Egyptian clampdown on hundreds of smuggling tunnels, a high-ranking Israeli military official told reporters at army headquarters here on Thursday.

title: Another Way to Think of Captain Phillips': 2 Guys at Work
description: LOS ANGELES  There arent too many quotable lines in movies this season, but one that could have legs is I am the captain now, from Captain Phillips. At a Writers Guild panel here this week, the Oscar- and guild-nominated screenwriter Billy Ray, whose credits include little flicks like The Hunger Games, discussed his approach to shaping the true story of the hostage situation aboard the Maersk Alabama.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Dallas Buyers Club
description: Jean-Marc Valle narrates a scene from his film featuring Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto.

title: Wintertime Bargains in Budapest
description: On a drizzly mid-January evening, I stood at the arches of the wall of Buda Castle, overlooking the Danube and the 19th-century Chain Bridge that links Buda with Pest. Beyond the bridge, the mist turned the Hungarian parliament into a glowworm.

title: Obama Once Disdained Clintons Small Steps and Now Takes His Own
description: NASHVILLE  In the summer of his first year in power, President Obama made clear that he envisioned a lofty mission. I wasnt sent here to do school uniforms, he told aides one day in the Oval Office. The implication was clear: He did not want to govern like Bill Clinton.

title: U.S. Is Seeking Death Penalty in Boston Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department said Thursday that it would seek the death penalty against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused of killing and maiming people with homemade bombs at the Boston Marathon finish line last year.

title: The Super Bowl of Sports Gambling
description: Vegas Runner strode into the sports book of the Las Vegas Hotel & Casino, a fat diamond stud glittering in his left earlobe. Moving through the cavernous room as though it belonged to him, he reached a bar table where his friend R. J. Bell was waiting and flashed a smile. My man! Vegas Runner bellowed.

title: The Power Breakfast Starts a New Day
description: NEW YORK is filled with enterprising women eager to turn up for breakfast at 8 a.m., decked out in eye shadow and Akris. They sip green tea and push a spoon around a bowl of oatmeal while speaking fervently of protecting the brand.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Delay Spike in Flood Insurance Rates
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday passed a bill to delay sharp increases in flood insurance rates for millions of property owners in coastal and flood-prone areas.

title: An Artistic Celebration of the Beauty, Spectacle and Masculinity of Soccer
description: This Sunday might be the big game, but the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) hasnt forgotten about the other football  orsoccer, as we refer to it in the United States. Opening the day of the Super Bowl, Ftbol: The Beautiful Game examines the sport through works of art ranging from video and photography to painting, sculpture and large-scale installation.

title: Fitness Trackers: Lifeline or Flatline?
description: In this weeks personal technology column, I reviewed the Fitbit Force, a sleek new personal fitness tracker that is worn on the wrist. My feelings were mixed. I thoroughly enjoyed tracking my daily and weekly activity levels, and looking at the pretty visualizations that the Fitbit software creates from that data, but it was hard to parse deep insights from that information. The software, which is fairly sophisticated, still seems like it is not quite smart enough to help me figure out how to change my personal habits to be more healthy. I couldnt recommend spending $130 on a rubber bracelet that tells me what I already know works  eat less, move more  to live well and stay in shape.

title: Celebrating Sestinas at Poets House
description: Followers of contemporary American poetry cant fail to notice that traditional forms, employing rhymes and recognizable meters, are pretty firmly out of fashion. Browsing through the January issue of Poetry magazine, an admittedly unscientific but fairly typical sampling, you find almost exclusively free verse. Most of todays poets, to paraphrase Robert Frost, seem to be quite happy playing tennis without a net.

title: The Gun Report: January 30, 2014
description: While President Obama spoke about the need for gun control in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, there was a shooting at Tennessee State University. A 20-year-old man was shot in the leg during an argument over a gambling debt following an intramural basketball game. Neither the shooter nor the victim were students.

title: Another Option for an Upgrade From Windows XP
description: Q. Im still running Windows XP on my computer; can I upgrade to Windows 7 instead of Windows 8?

title: South by Southwest Festival Adds a TV Section
description: LOS ANGELES  After dabbling with previews of TV series like Girls and Bates Motel, the South by Southwest festival will add a television tier to its annual film programming, the festival said on Thursday.

title: Banks Could Still Face Tougher Capital Requirements to Prevent Crises
description: FRANKFURT  Ever since the end of the 2008 financial crisis, the worlds leaders have searched for ways to shore up the banking system.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Dallas Buyers Club
description: In this video, the director Jean-Marc Valle narrates a scene from his period film about Ron Woodroof, a Texas rodeo rider who is diagnosed with H.I.V. The scene features Matthew McConaughey as Ron, Jared Leto as his business partner, Rayon, and Kevin Rankin as Rons old friend T. J. Dallas Buyers Club received six Oscar nominations and arrives on DVD Feb. 4.

title: A Dive Into the Arts for Black History Month
description: When Frank Owens, a seasoned Broadway pianist and onetime musical director for David Letterman, was invited to play music by the jazz composer Mary Lou Williams at a Hofstra University concert celebrating Black History Month, he saw it as a new challenge.

title: Problem In the Classroom? Tread Lightly
description: This weeks question is from a parent seeking advice on how to handle a conference with an ineffective teacher.

title: Boston Ballet to Conclude 50th Anniversary Tour at Lincoln Center
description: The Boston Ballet has chosen Lincoln Center as the place where it will wrap up its 50th anniversary tour. The program, which is scheduled to run from June 25 through June 29 at the David H. Koch Theater, will include a new work by Jos Martinez; Alexander Ekmans Cacti; and classics like Nijinskys Afternoon of a Faun, William Forsythes The Second Detail and George Balanchines Symphony in Three Movements. This tour will be the grand finale to our 50th season, said Mikko Nissinen, the companys artistic director. Many of the pieces were presenting are new to the United States.

title: Video Notebook: Russell Wilson
description: Seattle Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson spoke to the media about his teammate Derrick Coleman.

title: A Comedy That Plays to the Home Crowd
description: Its a good thing that Admit One is such a good-natured comedy. Otherwise, several prestigious American institutions of higher learning might sue.

title: Annual Profit Nearly Flat for Luxury Group LVMH
description: PARIS  LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the worlds largest luxury goods group, said Thursday that its profit was almost flat last year amid flagging demand for some of its core fashion brands in key markets like China and the impact of weaker currencies in its main overseas markets.

title: Shoulder Pads Slim Down in Faster, Sleeker N.F.L.
description: Terrance Knighton, a 6-foot-3, 335-pound defensive tackle for the Denver Broncos, has the sumptuous nickname of Pot Roast. Perched on such a massive frame, his shoulder pads appear almost decorative, as if they were tassels on a drum major.

title: Husband-and-Wife Chefs Split From Calliope
description: Nearly two years after opening Calliope, the popular country-French bistro in the East Village, Eric Korsh and his wife, Ginevra Iverson, the chefs and partners, have left the restaurant in a split with Eric Anderson, the other owner. The couple told Mr. Anderson of their departure Thursday morning.

title: With Disaster Near, Debating Gods Existence
description: Now, this is what a psychiatrists office should look like. The wall of books; the African art; the Greek, Roman and Egyptian artifacts on the desk; the Oriental rugs; and the imposing, tapestry-draped couch. This is the sunlit London study of Dr. Sigmund Freud in TheaterWorks Hartfords decidedly satisfying new production of Freuds Last Session, and what better place to debate the existence of God?

title: Lawsuit Questions Squares Start-Up Story
description: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Included comment from a spokesman from Square.

title: New Ambitions for the Symphony of Westchester
description: Whats in a name? Plenty, according to the conductor Barry Hoffman.

title: Super PAC Is Formed in Mississippi to Protect 6-Term Senator in G.O.P. Primary
description: WASHINGTON  A group of Mississippi Republicans, moving to counter spending from out-of-state conservative groups, have created a super PAC to help Senator Thad Cochran fend off a primary challenge and will begin airing a television ad on Friday.

title: Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
description: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

title: N.S.A. Choice Is Navy Expert on Cyberwar
description: WASHINGTON  In nominating Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers as the new director of the National Security Agencyon Thursday, President Obama chose a recognized expert in the new art of designing cyberweapons, but someonewith no public track record in addressing the kinds of privacy concerns that have put the agency under a harsh spotlight.

title: Human Rights Watch Shares Images of Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
description: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

title: Beatles 14: Two Hotels Celebrate an Anniversary
description: In February 1964, the Beatles made their first trip to the United States, igniting Beatlemania stateside from New York to Miami. Fifty years later, hotels the band visited then are marking the anniversary in ways small and large.

title: Homing In on a Couples Basquiat Drawings
description: Longtime collectors like Herbert and Lenore Schorr are luckier than most. In 1981, while visiting the Annina Nosei Gallery, which was then on Prince Street in SoHo, the couple met Jean-Michel Basquiat, fell in love with his work and bought one of his paintings. That purchase was quickly followed by others  drawings as well as canvases  and, over the years, the Schorrs amassed one of the most important Basquiat collections in the country. The Schorrs also became friends with the artist, who died of a drug overdose at 27 in 1988, and occasionally bought a painting or drawing right out of his Manhattan studio.

title: Gallery | The Pioneers of Graffiti Art, Through the Eyes of KAWS
description: When the painter Martin Wong moved to New York in the late 1970s, the colorful graffiti around his new hometown so enthralled him that he began collecting and archiving what he knew would soon become historically significant art. He spent the next decade gathering pictures of the artists and their now painted-over masterpieces from photographers like Martha Cooper, who famously documented the emerging art form. In the 80s, when gallerists began commissioning various mixed-media paintings from the graffiti artists  which were easier to display than tagged subway cars or building facades  Wong began to collect those too.

title: For the Super Bowl, a Cruise Ship Becomes a Shrine to Beer
description: When doors finally opened to the newly christened Bud Light Hotel on Thursday, visitors saw more than the luxurious inside of a new cruise ship. They entered a floating shrine to the beer.

title: What Republicans Say Versus What Republicans Mean
description: Now that the State-of-the-Union cameras are off, House Republicans are eager to discard their frozen smiles and return to their jobs of undermining virtually every goal President Obama set out in his speech on Tuesday night. They made that clear in a letter that the top four House officials sent to the president today, which purports to seek agreement on four points in the speech. It actually does quite the opposite.

title: Super Bowl Will Again Be a Showcase for Automakers
description: As the Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks get ready for the Super Bowl, automakers have also prepared for their own game-day competition: television ads.

title: Revenue and Profit Rise at Google, but Mobile Is a Persistent Challenge
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There is no denying that Google has become a mobile company. Now, Google  along with shareholders, industry partners and advertisers  is trying to figure out what that means.

title: With California Syrahs, an Asian-Accented Chili
description: Entering the room with a firm handshake, the enjoyably earthy and assertive California syrahs we tasted require food that will not back off.

title: The Real Challenge for Reform Conservatism
description: I wrote a post last week about whether a conservative reform project would necessitate a return to Bush-era deficit spending, or whether theres any space available between deficits dont matter Republicanism and Tea Party-era austerity. Since then, a number of writers have looked at the emerging conservative policy blueprints  which now include, mirabile dictu, an actual health care reform proposal!  and argued that their core weaknesses is an unwillingness to endorse new spending. Thus Danny Vinik, in a fair-minded post for Business Insider:

title: Republicans Immigration Blueprint Leaves Party at Odds and Democrats Hopeful
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  The House Republican leaderships call on Thursday to provide legal status for 11 million undocumented workers, and possible citizenship for those brought to this country as children, caused sharp division within the party even as it provided a starting point for negotiations with Democrats on overhauling the nations immigration system.

title: Text of Republicans Principles on Immigration
description: On Thursday, Congressional Republicans released a one-page document, obtained by The New York Times, outlining their blueprint for immigration overhaul.

title: Arahmaiani: Fertility of the Mind
description: Tyler Rollins

title: Sue Williams: WTC, WWIII, Couch Size
description: 303 Gallery

title: Guy Ben Ner: Soundtrack
description: Postmasters

title: Saul Fletcher
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: Amazon to Raise Fees as Revenue Disappoints
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon investors might have finally heard the news they have been waiting for: The retailer is raising shipping fees.

title: Senators Son, 26, Arrested in Colorado on Drug Charge
description: WASHINGTON  The son of Senator Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, was arrested this week on drug possession and trespassing charges, the Boulder County sheriffs office said Thursday.

title: It Started With Charcuterie
description: The mounted, tusked boars head on the wall immediately sets the Pass, Matthew Ridgways restaurant, apart. The table near the entrance with artisanal products for sale  honey, olive oil and what looked to be house-canned produce  takes it a step farther from the mainstream.

title: Obama on Job-Driven Training
description: At a General Electric plant in Wisconsin, the president spoke about finding better ways to help Americans learn skills and signed an executive order for a review of federal job-training programs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Syria and Afghanistan.

title: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | Where Food and Football Intersect
description: It was billed as an evening fusing football with flavors of New York, but the pastrami on rye could have been a monarchs take on that city signature  a jewel-like gobbet of meat with caraway-scented brown butter  the kegs were filled with wine, and the hot dogs (brace yourself, oh true New Yorkers) were of a variety from Puerto Rico.

title: Dave Pasternack to Open a Restaurant in Chelsea
description: Dave Pasternack, the chef and a partner at Esca, the Italian seafood restaurant in Hells Kitchen, is planning to open another restaurant come spring. This time its without B & B Hospitality, the Bastianich-Batali group, which owns Esca.

title: Saying Goodbye to a City and Its Characters
description: The hills are still firmly in place, the Golden Gate Bridge remains a bright symbol of welcome, but San Francisco has changed radically since Armistead Maupin began charting the interlocking lives of a handful of its colorful fictional denizens in 1976. The city that was once a beacon for people looking to escape the strictures of conformity  and the puritanical streak in American culture  has now become a high-amenity bedroom community for the epicenter of the tech universe, Silicon Valley. And so the bohemian aerie at the center of Mr. Maupins beloved Tales of the City novels, 28 Barbary Lane, has now passed from the hands of Anna Madrigal, the one-woman marijuana dispensary who presided over her tenants as both a spiritual guru and a surrogate mother. Now, the building belongs to dot-commers who, in the words of one of the characters from Mr. Maupins new novel, The Days of Anna Madrigal, have made it look like a five-star B and B.

title: My Invisible Head Not Talking Economics
description: Soundcheck on WNYC, talking musical tastes.

title: Beyond the Large TVs, a Dancing Dragon
description: Patrons at 2one2, a pan-Asian restaurant named for its address on Merrick Road in Rockville Centre, enter through the bar. And its quite a bar, too, taking up almost half the space, with five large televisions, a 90-inch screen on another wall and plenty of room for a mingling crowd.

title: Georgia Storm Response Not Fast Enough
description: Gov. Nathan Deal said that he was not satisfied with the response to this weeks winter storm and that an internal review would be conducted.

title: Scarlett Johansson Chooses SodaStream Over Oxfam After Dispute About West Bank Factory
description: Updated, 5:49 p.m. | Forced to choose between two endorsement deals, the actress Scarlett Johansson decided Wednesday to end her charitable work on behalf of Oxfam, an antipoverty group that opposes trade with Israeli settlements, and continue as a paid brand ambassador for SodaStream, a company that manufactures products in the occupied West Bank.

title: Williamstown Theater Festival to Feature Rene Fleming and Chita Rivera
description: The soprano Rene Fleming and the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera will be part of the 2014 main-stage season at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the company announced on Thursday.

title: For Blackstone, a Pot of Gold Remains Out of Reach
description: Eight years after its inception, the biggest private equity fund in history has yet to meet its own minimum expectations.

title: California Syrahs, on Such a Winters Day
description: California syrah seemed like a losing proposition back in 2010. Through the 1990s, growers had bet big on the grape. Plantings of syrah in California increased from fewer than 200 acres in 1990 to more than 17,000 by 2004. But sales of syrah wines crashed, and the pace of planting slowed to a trickle.

title: Race Gap on Conventional Loans
description: African-American and Hispanic borrowers have been largely shut out of the conventional mortgage market, according to a new report from Zillow and the National Urban League. Citing 2012 loan data reported under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, along with results from a Zillow poll of 700 mortgage applicants in December, the analysis found that whites accounted for about 69 percent of all conventional mortgage applications. The share of applications filed by blacks was under 3 percent; Hispanics represented only 5 percent.

title: Bette in Spokane Blogging
description: So, I wondered about Bette in Spokane, mentioned in the official GOP SOTU response. I wondered how she could face a $700 a month increase in premiums, and speculated that she must have had a really bare-bones policy offering hardly any protection.

title: Finding Common Ground on the State of the Union
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant Treasury secretary for economic policy from 2006 to 2009.

title: An Employer Tells Congress the Health Care Mandate Could Triple His Costs
description: On Tuesday, while many were preparing for President Obamas State of the Union address, Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee dived deep into the Affordable Care Acts employer mandate.

title: Goldman Awards Blankfein $14.7 Million in Stock Bonus
description: Updated, 8:20 p.m. | Goldman Sachss board granted its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, restricted shares worth $14.7 million as part of his pay package for 2013, according to a filing made public on Thursday.

title: Japanese Cuisine, From Scratch
description: On two different visits to RameNesque, a new Japanese cafe with a brisk takeout business in downtown Peekskill, we couldnt get our table to stand still. Despite our best efforts  jamming folded paper napkins under the stand, jostling the table this way and that  the wobbles won out. Chopsticks, water glasses, ramen bowls, ramekins  all skittered around on the high-gloss wooden table top like so many pointers on a Ouija board.

title: Maher Wants His Show to Decide a House Race
description: Bill Maher makes little effort to hide his own contempt for many politicians, most of them Republicans. Now, he wants to take it to the next level: finding one he might be able to help oust from office.

title: Two Takes on a Tiger Couple
description: The two photographs above, which accompany Jennifer Szalais article about Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld in this weekends magazine, werent made with mirrors or by changing their poses  they were produced by two separate cameras that fired at the same moment. The photographer Barbara Probst, who shot the couple (authors of the new book Triple Threat: How Three Unlikely Traits Explain the Rise and Fall of Cultural Groups in America) in her first effort for the magazine, is known for her simultaneous exposures. Recently, I asked her some questions about her work.

title: Vintage Auction Catalogs With Personal Provenance
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J.  Vintage auction catalogs, despite competition from growing online databases, still sell by the tens of thousands a year from the offices here of the specialist dealer Jeffrey Eger. Well, not quite offices.

title: Emerging Markets Inflow Numbers Point to Exit by Bond Investors
description: With investors on edge following the recent weeks of turmoil in emerging markets, the release this week of updated capital inflow data by the Institute of International Finance could not have been better timed.

title: When the Prescription Is Fresh Air
description: Can a tenement window be truly magnificent? Thats what the architect Dan Allen says about the newly installed windows at the 1912 Cherokee Apartments, just off York Avenue, between East 77th and East 78th Streets.

title: Godwin Help Us
description: Not my line, alas  Jonathan Chait uses it as the excerpt for his report on the WSJs editorial defending Tom Perkins, now famed for comparing criticism of the one percent to Kristallnacht. And boy, am I jealous.

title: Googles Sale of Motorola Could Help Samsung
description: Googles imminent sale of its handset business to the Chinese computer maker Lenovo could benefit Samsung Electronics more than Lenovo and make life more difficult for other Android manufacturers.

title: An Education in Indias Diverse Cuisines
description: In India, kolam is the decorative practice of stenciling rice-flour patterns on the ground. In Newtown, Kolam is a restaurant, one that evokes that art form in a combination of geometric designs that color its dark velour wall coverings and valances.

title: The Source | James Turrell
description: Doug Aitken interviews the artist James Turrell.

title: Tappan Zee Crane Arrives by Boat
description: A huge crane arrived in New York Harbor in January, after a 6,000-mile ocean journey from San Francisco. It will be used to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

title: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
description: Also on the Minute, Ukraine's president goes on sick leave and a 400-foot crane arrives in New York.

title: Whoever Ad
description: The organization Mississippi Conservatives released an attack ad against State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is running against Senator Thad Cochran in a Republican primary.

title: Oscar Shorts, From Surreal to Oh So Real
description: You may have seen the eye-popping 3-D animated Disney short Get a Horse! In this spicy visual appetizer, which accompanies the megahit Frozen, Mickey and Minnie Mouse and their friends Horace Horsecollar and Clarabelle Cow enjoy a hayride until the appearance of Peg-Leg Pete, who tries to run them off the road. As Mickey and Horace fight with Pete, these hand-drawn, black-and-white animated characters are forced through the screen, emerging as colorful CGI versions of themselves. A frantic battle royal ensues as a raft of Disney characters jump in and out of the screen and chase one another in circles.

title: The Mythic and Heroic, Just Inches Tall
description: In case you havent noticed, the Frick Collection has been on something of a bronze statuette kick over the last decade. During that time, it has mounted five monographic or survey shows of these small collectibles, all organized by the estimable curator Denise Allen.

title: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
description: In the Video

title: Southwest and JetBlue Buy Washington Airport Rights
description: Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways said on Thursday that they had bought the takeoff and landing rights at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington that the Justice Department required American Airlines and US Airways to sell as a condition of their merger.

title: Its Him, Not Her
description: I have a mostly sweet and fairly well-behaved 10-year-old son. But sometimes he is really mean to Siri (the simulated assistant on my phones operating system). Hell say things like, Youre a stupid idiot, Siri. Do you think we should punish him for statements like these? If he ever called an actual person a stupid idiot, he would be in huge trouble.

title: How Much Is Too Much to Pay for Jos. A. Bank?
description: Mens Wearhouse may be willing to raise its bid to buy its rival, the mens suit retailer Jos. A. Bank, but analysts on Wall Street are wondering: How much is too much?

title: Is It Love, or Stockholm Syndrome?
description: The heaving, bubbling euphemism driving Jason Reitmans Labor Day is a juicy homemade peach pie just out of the oven. Its creator, Frank (Josh Brolin), is an escaped prisoner who shows Adele (Kate Winslet), a single mother held captive in her own home, the secrets of baking. That lesson takes place over a sleepy holiday weekend in September 1987. Carefully noting every detail is her nerdy 13-year-old son, Henry (Gattlin Griffith).

title: Why Cant I Have a Washing Machine?
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: The Source | Liz Glynn
description: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Liz Glynn.

title: Dutch Masterwork, Under Reconstruction
description: Tims Vermeer is a little documentary that tracks how one mans love turned into revenge. The title figure  well, one, anyway  is Tim Jenison, a scientist, inventor and restless hobbyist with deep pockets and famous friends, including Penn Jillette, who produced the movie, and Teller, who directed. In the 1980s, Mr. Jenison founded NewTek, a hardware and software company that scored an early success with the creation of Video Toaster, an affordable desktop video-production tool. Since then, this autodidact, now in his late 50s, has done this and that, including embarking on a multiyear odyssey to discover whether the movies other, better-known, subject, the Dutch master Johannes Vermeer (1632-75), used any kind of optical tools when he created his extraordinary paintings.

title: It Started With a $2 Poster
description: The Japanese galleries at the Metropolitan Museum have been pulling crowds since John T. Carpenter became curator in 2011. He has taken the permanent collection, shaken it up, threaded it through with strategic loans and, like a good teacher, unfurled it logically around graspable themes. Who could resist a show that tells the art history of a complex culture, as Mr. Carpenter did last year, entirely in images of birds?

title: Box, an Online Storage Start-Up, Is Said to File for an I.P.O.
description: Updated, 7:21 p.m. | Box, an online storage and document-sharing provider, has filed confidential paperwork to go public, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Food Matters | The Godfather of Hipster American Dining Serves Up a Fresh Dish: Enlightenment
description: Its been almost a decade since Taavo Somer co-opened Freemans, the seminal Lower East Side gastropub that ushered in a new epoch of American comfort food and rustic, taxidermy-heavy restaurant design. Since then, hes launched several other restaurants and expanded his atavistic mens wear line, Freemans Sporting Club. The man once described as the patron saint of hipsters also became a dad, trimmed his beard, began spending more time at his farmhouse upstate and loudly proclaimed his distaste for the culture hed come to represent.

title: Crystalline Glory, Frozen in Time
description: Before she directed The Fabulous Ice Age, Keri Pickett was a photographer who had never contemplated making a film. Her uncle, the former figure skater Roy Blakey  an avid collector of ice-show memorabilia  changed all that.

title: Yahoo Reports Attack on Mail Accounts
description: Another day, another breach.

title: Do Not Look Down in This Class
description: The actors gift, according to the director and theatrical sage Peter Brook, is the connection between pure imagination and the body itself. For him, the technique of acting is at once physical and metaphysical, a discipline of the face, limbs, voice and spirit. Peter Brook: The Tightrope, a concise new documentary directed by Simon Brook, offers a rare glimpse behind the scenes as its subject (who happens to be the filmmakers father) instructs a group of actors in the rigor and simplicity of his method.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: childhood obesity, testosterone therapy and the amount of exercise that might save you from an early death.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Obama Reaches Out After Shooting of Nashville Student
description: NASHVILLE  President Obama sought on Thursday to comfort a high school community devastated by the death of a 15-year-old student who was killed with a handgun less than 48 hours before the presidents arrival here.

title: Gospel Without Hallelujahs
description: Anyone unfamiliar with the traditional African-American spirituals that the great operatic tenor Lawrence Brownlee performed on Wednesday at the Allen Room can be forgiven for mistaking them for concert art songs. If Mr. Brownlee and his accompanist and arranger Damien Sneed didnt tell you, you might not realize that beloved spirituals like There Is a Balm in Gilead, Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child and Down by the Riverside belong to an oral tradition of gospel music distinct from carefully notated classical art songs.

title: Super Bowl Fever Hits Midtown, but Many There Arent Catching It
description: The orchids are dying, and Cliff Jacobs blames the Super Bowl.

title: The Other Super Bowl Underdog
description: WHEN Bruno Mars takes the stage at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., this chilly Sunday evening to perform at the Super Bowl halftime show, in front of the biggest audience hes ever played to, he can take some solace that his set only needs to be about 12 minutes long.

title: A Clarinet Does Scenes
description: The formal and emotional crux of The Big Picture, David Krakauers 90-minute multimedia tribute to movie music at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, is Shoah Trilogy, a medley of themes from films about the Holocaust. Mr. Krakauers clarinet girded each with a piercing wail in the premiere on Wednesday night, communicating anguish, outrage and catharsis.

title: De Blasio to Settle Stop-and-Frisk Suit
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that the city had reached an agreement with civil rights lawyers who argued that the Police Departments policy violated minorities rights.

title: Need the Best for Your Next Occasion? Call Westminster Palace
description: LONDON  Overindulgence in food and drink has long been one of the hazards of political life for members of Britains Parliament. But no longer. Abstemiousness seems to be the order of the day.

title: Digital, Analog and Waterlogged
description: What Is a Photograph? asks the title of a disappointing exhibition at the International Center of Photography.

title: A Woman Whose Ecstasy Ignited a Riot
description: Nicely immersive if largely uninformative, Breaking the Frame is best appreciated as a chance to spend time with the painter, filmmaker, author, performance artist and epic cat lover Carolee Schneemann (born 1939). One of the leading female figures of American avant-garde cinema, Ms. Schneemann is best known for Fuses (1965), a gorgeous onetime scandal that features explicit images of her having sex with her partner, the composer James Tenney. I can consider Fuses, Ms. Schneemann once wrote, not simply as a film but in its revelatory cultural erotic intrusion  a vision (message) of genital sexuality and female pleasure which vitalized and agitated the art world.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Last Look at Old Paris, Before Demolition
description: In the massive construction site that was late-19th-century Paris, the photographer Charles Marville was just a few steps ahead of the wrecking ball. As an official city photographer working under Napoleon III and his controversial urban planner, Baron Haussmann, Marville recorded some 425 views of narrow, picturesque streets that were to be replaced by Haussmanns grand boulevards.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Casting a Documentarians Eye on Dances Past and Its Future
description: Dance class: Its a place that we rarely associate with political skirmishes, cultural upheavals or socioeconomic pressures. But two films in the 42nd Dance on Camera festival, which begins on Friday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, remind us that the studio, the ballet barre, the halls of college dance departments  just like any social space  are realms where all of these tensions play out, in both quiet and dramatic ways.

description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

description: You Make the Call

title: For One-Night Lotharios, Its Time to Face the Truth
description: Are you dating or just hooking up? According to Jason (Zac Efron), who narrates That Awkward Moment, a vile, witless sex comedy set in contemporary Manhattan, the dreaded word that signals danger to a smug, self-imagined stud is a post-coital So? Spoken by a woman wondering if their casual relationship will proceed to the next level  dating  it is a clear warning that the time has come to run for the hills.

title: Goldman Deal Threatens Danish Government
description: There are groundbreaking business deals. And then there are ones that threaten to break up governments.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
description: Lunar New Year Celebrations (Friday and Sunday) This weekend, not all the talk about the Year of the Horse will be referring to the Denver Broncos showdown with the Seattle Seahawks. For Friday is the first day of the Lunar New Year  this year in celebration of the horse  and events are scheduled all weekend in Lower Manhattan.

title: Charge Sheet Against Al Jazeera Journalists in Egypt
description: As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, Egyptian prosecutors said on Wednesday that they were charging 20 journalists working for Al Jazeera with conspiring with a terrorist group and broadcasting false images.

title: Thrilling to the Brrroom of a Renegade Cohort
description: 12 OClock Boys packs more life into its 72 minutes than many longer documentaries do. But in the movies compressed experience, the director, Lotfy Nathan, takes cues from his roving subjects: young dirt bike daredevils who pour into Baltimore streets en masse for the fleeting thrills of speed, danger and the perfect wheelie.

title: Former Chief of S.E.C. to Shift Consulting Job
description: Mary L. Schapiro spent four years as head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Her next act was far shorter.

title: Syria Talks May Yield Little, but Give Cover to Those Defying Hard-Liners
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The images from spotless, quiet Geneva were striking  Syrian government and opposition figures sitting down together for the first time to discuss ending their countrys war  but inside war-torn Syria, patience wore thin as the talks dragged on with few results.

title: Libya Says Goldman Didnt Explain Options
description: In early 2008  months before the financial crisis began  Goldman Sachs put $1.2 billion of Libyan money into leveraged bets that six stocks would rise over the next three years.

title: Some Toyota Model Sales Halted Over Seat Problem
description: Toyota has told its dealers to stop selling about 36,000 vehicles of its most popular models because a component on the heated seats does not comply with a federal safety standard for flame retardants, the automaker said on Thursday.

title: Your Child Is Choosing a College; Time to Tag Along
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Its Great Lake Shriveled, Iran Confronts Crisis of Water Supply
description: LAKE URMIA, Iran  After driving for 15 minutes over the bottom of what was once Irans largest lake, a local environmental official stepped out of his truck, pushed his hands deep into his pockets and silently wandered into the great dry plain, as if searching for water he knew he would never find.

title: The Road to Reinvention

title: Pulling Apart the Numbers on Women in the Texas Legislature
description: State Senator Wendy Davis has used her 11-hour filibuster against abortion-restricting legislation to propel a run for governor, and Texas hottest political race centers on whether her supporters can usher a Democratic woman into a governors mansion occupied by Republican men for two decades.

description: Opens on Friday.

title: Nassau County District Attorney Upends Race for House Seat
description: When Carolyn McCarthy, among the nations most recognizable champions of gun control, announced this month that she would be retiring from Congress after 18 years, a number of names of possible Democratic successors were floated in Nassau County political circles. But the woman who stepped into the race this week may be too formidable to stop.

title: Oil Takes Off as One-Firehouse County Plays Catch-Up
description: COTULLA  Richard Prado has learned a number of rules in his six years as a firefighter. Among the most important, he says, is to know your equipment.

title: Four Ignore the Election at Roads End
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

title: Hong Kong Paper Ousts Top Editor, Stirring Concern
description: HONG KONG  This citys Ming Pao newspaper has long stood for sober independence in a media market that is both brashly commercial and buffeted by political winds from China, its reporters pursuing and often breaking stories that irk the territorys overseers in Beijing.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

description: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

title: When Biography Trumps Substance
description: SPOKANE, Wa.  Only the snarkiest would not be open to the likable life story of Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, the Eastern Washington politician who gave the official Republican response to the presidents State of the Union speech. Shes a farm girl from a big empty county just north of here, first in her family to attend college, mother of three, a rare woman in the retrograde mens club of her partys leadership.

title: High Stakes for Agencies, and Products, at Super Bowl
description: REMEMBER the line from Animal Farm that all animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others? On Sunday, the stakes will be high for the sponsors of Super Bowl XLVIII, but for some the stakes are higher than for others.

title: 92 Air Force Officers Suspended for Cheating on Their Missile Exam
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Force said Thursday that it had now suspended 92 officers at Malmstrom Air Force Base  nearly half of the nuclear launch crew there  in a cheating scandal, and it acknowledged a systemic problem in the culture of the team that is entrusted to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: Panama: 32 of 35 Detained North Koreans to Be Freed
description: After months of investigation, Panamas chief prosecutor said Thursday that she would not file charges against 32 of 35 crew members of a North Korean freighter that was seized in July when Soviet-era jets, engines and antiaircraft missiles from Cuba were found on board. Immigration authorities are preparing to return most of the crew members to North Korea. But the captain, first officer and political officer will remain in Panama and face arms trafficking charges. Panamanian officials indicated in October that most of the crew would be released, but the prosecutors office completed its investigation only this week. The seizure of the freighter, the 450-foot Chong Chon Gang, near the Panama Canal caused a diplomatic quarrel among Panama, Cuba and North Korea. A United Nations Security Council committee has been investigating whether the shipment violated sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear weapons program.

description: The N.F.L. said that the number of concussions in the league had declined 13 percent this season thanks to improved medical diagnoses, stiffer penalties for striking with a helmet and fewer practices.

title: Dalton School Apologizes for Screening Slavery Satire
description: The Dalton School, one of New York Citys most prestigious private schools, has apologized after screening a satirical movie about a world in which the South won the Civil War.

description: After months of protest from doctors and patients, a professional group that certifies obstetrician-gynecologists has lifted a ban it imposed in September and now says its members are free to treat men.

title: Pete Burns, Rodeo Cowboy Who Coached Champions, Dies at 85
description: Pete Burns, a former professional rodeo cowboy and nationally known college rodeo coach who owned one of the most intractable bucking bulls of the 20th century, died on Sunday at his home in Laramie, Wyo. He was 85.

title: Scarlett Johansson and Oxfam, Torn Apart by Israeli Company Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Start with plain water and bubbles. Mix in the perfect flavor, suggests Scarlett Johansson in the ad that is part of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, the Israeli company that manufactures home carbonation systems.

title: The Young White Faces of Slavery
description: For Northern readers scanning the Jan. 30, 1864, issue of Harpers Weekly for news from the South, a large engraving on page 69 brought the war home in an unexpected way. Drawn from a photograph, it featured eight recently freed slaves from Union-occupied New Orleans. At the back of the portrait stood three adults, Wilson Chinn, Mary Johnson and Robert Whitehead. In the foreground were five children  Charles Taylor, Rebecca Huger, Rosa Downs, Augusta Broujey and Isaac White  ranging in age from 7 to 11. Their gaze was trained on the camera, but in the context of the magazine, the effect was that they all seemed to be looking at the reader.

title: Framework for Talks on Mideast in Progress
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to jump-start peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, the Obama administration hopes to complete a framework accord within a few weeks, which would set the terms for a final negotiation, a senior State Department official said in a conference call with Jewish leaders on Thursday.

title: Events on Long Island for Feb. 2-8
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Questions Fly in Storm That Stopped Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  Anyone who has listened to Kasim Reed, the former entertainment lawyer who became Atlantas mayor in 2010, knows the man who calls himself a street fighter likes to be forceful when he makes a point.

title: White House Urges China to Act on Journalists Visas
description: WASHINGTON  The White House said Thursday that it is deeply concerned with Chinas treatment of foreign journalists and expressed disappointment that Austin Ramzy, a New York Times reporter, had been forced to leave the country.

title: Second-Class Noncitizens
description: REPUBLICAN leaders in the House of Representatives on Thursday unveiled an agenda for immigration reform. It is a welcome sign that seven months after the Senate passed a comprehensive bill that included a path to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants now in the country illegally, there might be movement on the issue this year.

title: The Matrix of Manning
description: Peyton Manning is a cerebral leader who has more authority than any other N.F.L. quarterback to call his own plays. Even casual fans cannot fail to notice how he waves his arms, screams and points before each play to communicate with his teammates and simultaneously try to deceive defenses.

title: Prosecutors Lay Out List of Ex-Mayors Schemes
description: NEW ORLEANS  In the opening salvos of the trial of C. Ray Nagin, this citys former mayor, federal prosecutors described on Thursday a series of kickback schemes they say Mr. Nagin engaged in over the course of his two terms, setting up what promises to be a thorough dissection of the way business was done at City Hall during the Nagin years.

title: Hoboken Site Developer Dismisses Law Firm
description: Rockefeller Group, a real estate developer whose proposed office complex in Hoboken, N.J., is at the center of allegations that associates of Gov. Chris Christie threatened to withhold Hurricane Sandy relief money from the city unless the project received approval, has severed its connections with a law firm with close ties to the governor.

title: We Are Giving Ourselves Cancer
description: DESPITE great strides in prevention and treatment, cancer rates remain stubbornly high and may soon surpass heart disease as the leading cause of death in the United States. Increasingly, we and many other experts believe that an important culprit may be our own medical practices: We are silently irradiating ourselves to death.

title: Anti-Republican Group Digs Into Lane Closings
description: The roster of organizations seeking documents related to the scheme to tie up traffic near the George Washington Bridge includes many of the usual suspects: newspapers, local broadcasters and TV networks.

title: The Opportunity Coalition
description: President Obama can spend the remainder of his term planting a few more high-tech hubs, working on reforming the patent law and doing the other modest things he mentioned in his State of the Union address. And if he did that, he might do some marginal good, and he would manage the stately decline of his presidency during its final few years.

title: Gary Arlington, a Force in Underground Comic Books, Is Dead at 75
description: Gary Arlington, who died this month at 75, did not open the San Francisco Comic Book Company because he wanted to create a place where the citys underground comic artists could meet to mine one anothers unusual minds. He really just needed money, and he hoped to make some by selling thousands of comic books he had been hoarding in his parents basement since he was a little boy.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 30, 2014
Reliving the Invasion of the Beatles
description: Anthony Pomes, who performs John Lennons part in Mostly Moptop, the Long Island Beatles tribute band, started planning nearly a year ago for The Fab 64 Show, to take place Feb. 8 at Dix Hills Performing Arts Center.

title: Talking Troubled Turkey
description: O.K., who ordered that? With everything else going on, the last thing we needed was a new economic crisis in a country already racked by political turmoil. True, the direct global spillovers from Turkey, with its Los Angeles-sized economy, wont be large. But were hearing that dreaded word contagion  the kind of contagion that once caused a crisis in Thailand to spread across Asia, more recently caused a crisis in Greece to spread across Europe, and now, everyone worries, might cause Turkeys troubles to spread across the worlds emerging markets.

title: Wind Simulator? Fox Has Innovations Lined Up for Super Bowl Broadcast
description: Outside the 21st Century Fox building in Manhattan on Thursday, Terry Bradshaw and the Naked Cowboy were taping a commercial for Pizza Hut that will run Sunday before the Super Bowl.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 31, 2014
description: We kept waiting for the water to return, but it never did.

title: 50 Years Later, the Tributes to the Beatles Still Twist and Shout
description: The abundance of Rain in New Jerseys entertainment forecast this month is the result of a pop music milestone: Feb. 9, 2014, is the 50th anniversary of the Beatles first performance on The Ed Sullivan Show.

title: Bernanke Should Be Thanked
description: Ben S. Bernanke ascended to the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve eight years ago as a little-known  albeit distinguished  Princeton economics professor who had notched just three years of federal public service.

title: Beatles Music Without the Moptops
description: Next weekend will be the 50th anniversary of the Beatles invasion of America, and two camps of tribute bands are gearing up to celebrate: the look-alikes (like the Fab Four, who will perform in New Jersey and on Long Island) and those who evoke the sound and spirit but not necessarily the look of the four Liverpudlians (like Mostly Moptop, who will play a set on Long Island that focuses on the groups early years).

title: For Christie, a Governor Under Fire, Super Bowl Brings Glee
description: It took the Super Bowl to unleash the old Chris Christie.
