description: What you need to know now that House Republican leaders have unveiled a list of principles that have raised hopes for a breakthrough on immigration reform this year:

title: Salvage Drive for Rare Jewish Mural in Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  The mural was created inside a synagogue in 1910 by a sign painter named Ben Zion Black, who had just moved to this citys growing Jewish community from Lithuania. He was paid $200 by the Chai Adam congregation for what became a two-story artwork in a style that was common in Eastern Europes painted wooden synagogues. Most vanished in the Holocaust.

title: A New Day for New Yorkers
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio closed a divisive chapter in New York City history Thursday when he announced that his administration had reached an agreement with the civil rights lawyers who challenged the Police Departments abusive and racially discriminatory stop-and-frisk program in federal court.

title: Riding a Van to Soccer Practice, With a U.S. Player at the Wheel
description: CARSON, Calif.  One by one, they arrived, a fleet of minivans gliding around the corner and sliding neatly into the enormous parking lot with nary a skid mark. As the vehicles emptied, players in shorts, workout shirts and sweats shook out any kinks and walked down a ramp that led to the fields where they would spend most of the next two hours practicing.

title: In Boston, Mixed Reaction to Death Penalty Decision in Marathon Bombings Case
description: When he was a state lawmaker, Martin J. Walsh, the mayor of Boston, voted against the death penalty. On Thursday, he said that he would vote the same way today.

title: Football, Pain and Marijuana
description: The National Football League prohibits the use of marijuana as part of its broader, longstanding program to prevent substance abuse. It also imposes stiff penalties on players caught breaking the rules.

title: Corrections: January 31, 2014
description: NATIONAL: The Texas Tribune

title: Who Do You Think You Are? Wrong!
description: Galy Gay, the hapless protagonist of Bertolt Brechts 1925 play A Mans a Man, falls victim to several mind games during the course of his brainwashing at the hands of British soldiers stationed in India. But perhaps the most unhappily symbolic trick played upon him, in the Classic Stage Companys new production of this rarely seen play, is his coerced belief that a pile of barrels draped with a sari is actually an elephant, one that he is duped into trying to sell, thus falling into hot water with the authorities. For despite its often broadly comic tone, this hard-working but uninvolving production moves with the lumbering tread of a pachyderm in no hurry to get to the watering hole.

title: No More Wasting Time
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  You dont get much more rah-rah in a puzzle than this. Opening at 1 Across with LETS DO THIS THING is pretty motivating, so lets dive in and take a look at what Chris A. McGlothlin hath wrought.

title: A Year After a Sensational First Round, Mickelson Settles for a So-So One
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  He started on the 10th hole, same as last year, but little else about Phil Mickelsons par 71 in the first round of the Phoenix Open conjured memories of his sterling opening 60 a year ago.

title: A Violinists Triumph Is Ruined by Thieves
description: It should have been one of those nights musicians live for. Frank Almond, the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra for nearly two decades, had just closed a chamber concert in his own Frankly Music series with Messiaens hushed, eerily intense Quartet for the End of Time. Mr. Almond drew the graceful, ringing high notes of the finale from his prized 1715 Stradivarius violin, producing a tone so intensely focused that the audience in the Wisconsin Lutheran Colleges 388-seat auditorium sat in awed silence for 20 seconds before applauding.

title: In Search of Drama, Nascar Alters Playoff Race Again
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  In Nascars seemingly never-ending search for a playoff system that delivers Game 7 drama and resonates with fans, officials have once again decided to revamp the 10-race Chase for the Sprint Cup.

title: Half of Class Takes Holiday Off? Soon Whole City May
description: On Friday, Sui Ling Tsang, 49, plans to dress herself and her daughter, Xola, 7, in new red outfits, go out for a special dim sum brunch, and walk around their Chinatown neighborhood looking for the elaborate papier-mch lion puppets that neighborhood associations parade around from store to store.

title: In Landrieu Races, Obama Helps and Hinders
description: NEW ORLEANS  On a recent morning, Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana woke up in her childhood bedroom, drank coffee with her parents and headed downtown to help her little brother Mitch keep his job.

title: Super Bowl Performers Try to Keep Focus on Music
description: At a casual glance, Rene Fleming and Bruno Mars may not appear especially similar, but they share common ground in hoping their performances at Sundays Super Bowl are more about music and less about spectacle.

title: Citing Misconduct, Lawyer Seeks Review of Conviction in 03 Brooklyn Killing
description: The murder riveted New York City and stymied detectives for months: What chance meetings and turns of fate led Mark Fisher, a photogenic 19-year-old college football player from New Jersey, to end up shot dead on a quiet Brooklyn street, his body wrapped in a yellow blanket?

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Accusing Yeshiva University of Hiding Abuse
description: A federal lawsuit accusing Yeshiva University of covering up the sexual abuse of dozens of high school students has been thrown out by the judge hearing the case.

title: Only a Few Miles Separate Manhattan and Iona in a Special Rivalry
description: The bus ride has not changed since 1946: 8.6 miles, out of the Bronx and up into Westchester County, where one small Catholic university awaits another small Catholic university in perhaps the best basketball rivalry running in New York.

title: State Health Dept. Defers Action on Troubled Agency
description: The New York State Department of Health on Thursday abruptly withdrew its recommendation that a home health care agency with a checkered past be granted an expanded license, saying that new information had come to its attention and that officials needed more time to evaluate it before a vote on the license.

title: GoPro Sees Opportunity in Its Amateur Daredevils
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.  Inside the headquarters of GoPro, the video camera maker, there is a racing car, a collection of motorcycles, and drones outfitted with the companys products. All of them are reminders of the niche that GoPro has carved out as the camera of choice for recording skiing, surfing and other experiences too gnarly for dainty smartphones.

title: Ailing Knicks Prevail by Thinking Small
description: During a 40-second span earlyThursdaynight, Mike Woodson used the phrase day to day five times. It was a rapid-fire outpouring from the Knicks coach that symbolized the teams pervasive injuries.

title: Detroit Plan Is Said to Split Creditors Into 2 Groups
description: Detroit is preparing to resolve its bankruptcy case by splitting its unsecured creditors into two groups and treating them differently, according to people briefed on the citys plan.

title: Nets Blatche May Represent Philippines, a Nation Thats Foreign Even to Him
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The world of Andray Blatche  an often colorfully odd place  is expanding.

title: Thieves Steal $700,000 in Watches From Cartier
description: A gang of thieves used hammers to stage a jewelry theft at Cartiers flagship store in Midtown Manhattan in broad daylight on Wednesday, making off with more than a dozen luxury watches, the police said.

title: The Moral Hazard of the All-Volunteer Army
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Study Suggests That Some Football Helmets Are More Protective
description: As the scrutiny on head hits has increased in recent years, football helmet manufacturers, no doubt mindful of the potential for product liability suits, have made it clear that their products are designed mainly to prevent skull fractures, not concussions.

description: homespun \hom-spn\ adjective

title: Reissuing an Italian Renaissance
description: Once upon a time, in the decades after World War II, there were four cinematic superpowers: the United States, France, Japan and Italy. The last was hardly the least.

title: A Conversation with: Filmmaker Gyan Correa
description: Indias entry to the Oscars, The Good Road, didnt make the Academys list of nominees for best foreign-language film, but it has been showcased Jan. 6 at the Palm Springs International Film Festival and has had screenings in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Cuomos Talk of a Surplus Leaves Out a Big Caveat
description: There are budget tricks, and there are budget tricks.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) BARRYMORE In this Great Performances presentation, Christopher Plummer, above, recreates his 1997 Tony Award-winning portrayal of the actor John Barrymore as a boozy, physical wreck struggling in the final weeks of his life in 1942 to revive his Broadway triumph in Richard III from two decades earlier. Barrymores memory sometimes fails him, but the words never do, or rather he never fails them: He grabs at their prose and poetry with force, flinging away some, caressing others, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film adaptation by rik Canuel of the William Luce play. Mr. Plummer stumbles beautifully, poignantly and often, leering and searching through a haze of memory or, with concern edged with panic, calling for a line, a line much as Richard III calls for a horse. From smile to sneer, he captures Barrymores majesty and grandiloquence, recites his triumphs and humiliations.

title: Knocking Once Again on the Poets Door
description: Somber news comes with the territory I patrol as obituaries editor for this newspaper, and it was in that capacity that I learned that W.D. Snodgrass was dying.

title: Malaysian Admiral Plays Down Talk of Chinese Naval Incursion
description: The headline to the official news article left little doubt as to how China felt about certain territorial claims made by Malaysia in the disputed South China Sea: Chinese ships patrol southernmost territory, it read, on a story from Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

title: Telecom Firm Altice Raises $1.8 Billion in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Altice, the European cable and mobile operator, raised 1.3 billion euros in an initial public offering on Friday, as the telecommunications company pays down its debt and looks for potential acquisitions across the Continent.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Jan. 31, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Year of the Horse
description: To mark the beginning of the Year of the Horse, we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

title: Income Inequality in the U.S.
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama said that upward mobility has stalled.

title: Exclusive Preview: 'House of Cards'
description: Michael Kelly and Rachel Brosnahan in a scene from the first episode of Season 2.

title: What Are Your Secret Survival Strategies?
description: Three-toed sloths have some hidden survival strategies that you wouldnt know just by looking at them. After all, its not so easy to survive in the jungles of Central and South America. The same might be said about adolescence, which has its own share of dangers lurking in the complex world of school, friendships, social media and family.

title: I Am Hello Kitty
description: For a good part of 2012, smiling tourists surrounded Joana Toro in Times Square. Strangers hugged her. Some even gave her a few dollars. Talk about getting a big head. Actually, it was all because of her big head, an oversize Hello Kitty mask she wore while working among the costumed characters that have become familiar denizens of the Crossroads of the World.

title: The Post-Hope Politics of House of Cards
description: At 6:45 a.m. on a September day in Baltimore, when the heat was already loitering in the 80s and would eventually flirt with 100 degrees, Beau Willimon, the show runner for House of Cards, finished his first  or maybe second, or actually probably his third  cigarette of the day and stalked onto the shows outdoor set. Every set of a TV show is a little reminiscent of a ragged Civil War camp, with its provisional tents and huddled groups of conferring higher-ups and wandering assistants tending to disparate needs. But on the House of Cards set  temporarily erected in a small park adjacent to a block of Baltimore townhouses  this feeling was heightened by the presence of Willimon, with his facial hair that might be best described as sort-of mutton chops; his beeline intensity; and, of course, that name: Beau Willimon, which seems perfectly suited to a brass plaque in the South somewhere, commemorating a particularly brave or foolhardy general. His hair was an unkempt pompadour, and he wore an untucked work shirt, unlaced work boots and jeans with a back pocket so tattered that it barely cradled his wallet, a situation that at least three people, including me, felt moved to warn him about it, though he waved each of us off in turn. He had the haunted look of a man whos worried about something much more important, and hed only just arrived on set.

title: Bratton Says Rookies Role in Anticrime Effort Will End
description: In a sharp break with New Yorks crime-fighting policies of the last decade, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton has told his top chiefs that he intends to fundamentally alter a program that sent waves of rookie officers into crime-ridden neighborhoods, while also inflaming tensions in those communities.

title: Ireland and Child Abuse
description: For years, the government of Ireland has denied liability for child sexual abuse by teachers in state-financed schools managed by the Roman Catholic Church. The European Court of Human Rights punctured this denial Tuesday with a finding that the Irish government, in financing and regulating the education of youngsters, had an inherent obligation to protect them, and owed compensation to a victim whose case was rejected as groundless by Irelands highest court.

title: New York Today: Halftime Show, Locally Grown
description: Updated, 10:36 a.m.

title: Inflation in Euro Zone Falls, and a 12% Jobless Rate Doesnt Budge
description: BRUSSELS  Europes labor market remained in the doldrums in December, while the inflation rate ticked back down to the same level that recently led the European Central Bank to cut interest rates, official data showed on Friday. The reports suggested that the central bank would be under pressure to provide more monetary stimulus to keep a nascent recovery alive.

title: Times Minute | The N.S.A.'s New Chief
description: Background on Michael Rogers, the new NSA director. Also on the Minute, a serious water shortage in Iran and GoPro turns itself into a media company.

title: Times Minute | The N.S.A.s New Chief
description: In the Video

title: Why Israel Fears the Boycott
description: JERUSALEM  IF Secretary of State John Kerrys attempts to revive talks between Israel and the Palestinian Authority fail because of Israels continuing construction of illegal settlements, the Israeli government is likely to face an international boycott on steroids, as Mr. Kerry warned last August.

title: Daily Report: GoPro, Known for Extreme Videos, Aims to be a Media Company
description: Inside the headquarters of GoPro, the video camera maker, there is a racing car, a collection of motorcycles and drones outfitted with the companys products. All of them, Nick Wingfield reports, are reminders of the niche that GoPro has carved out as the camera of choice for recording skiing, surfing and other experiences too gnarly for dainty smartphones.

title: Losing the Propaganda War
description: JERUSALEM  ON Feb. 4, 1965, as a teenager, I left South Africa, the country of my birth, for a new home in a place Id never been  Israel.

title: Are You My Cousin?
description: I LOVE my family, but Im glad I dont have to buy birthday presents for all my cousins. Id be bankrupt within a week.

title: In Our Pages: February 1
description: 1914: Mystery of Russian Dancer

title: GoDaddy Introduces a Tool  and a Super Bowl Ad  Aimed at Small Businesses
description: Over the years,GoDaddys mildly pornographic commercials featuring a scantily clad Danica Patrick, the racecar driver and model, peddling web-hosting and domain-registration services have become something of a Super Bowl tradition. But thats about to change.

title: Reader Idea | Practicing Detective Skills With Infamous Local News Stories
description: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you have used The Times for teaching and learning and would like to see your idea in our blog, write in and tell us what you have done.

title: My Grandfathers Last Battle
description: RONSSOY, France  ABOUT 95 years ago, my grandfather spent the night near here. I doubt he slept much. For starters, he was probably in a trench. And by 4:30 a.m., he and other members of the United States Armys 106th Infantry were assembled along a strip of tape on the ground. They were facing the outer edge of the Hindenburg Line, one of the most fortified German positions on the Western Front of World War I.

title: All Quiet on the Amazon Front
description: Amazon is one of the most exciting companies in the country, redefining retail, web hosting, publishing and a bunch of other enterprises. When it says it is merely thinking of doing something  as it did Thursday with the first-ever price increase for Amazon Prime shipping service  it makes news. It also makes news when it talks about something that it is planning to do, maybe, a bunch of years from now, in the unlikely event everything works out. Yes, were talking drones.

title: Goldmans Chief Gets a Raise
description: GOLDMAN AWARDS ITS CHIEF WITH A RAISE | Goldman Sachss board decided to give Lloyd C. Blankfein, the banks chief executive, stock options worth $14.7 million as part of his 2013 pay package, eclipsing last years total.

title: GoPro Goes Amateur
description: The camera company is shifting from exclusively building hardware to focusing more on distributing the media that its cameras create.

title: Street Art Festival Brings Color to the Walls of Delhis Urban Villages
description: NEW DELHI  While looking out from a balcony in one of Delhis many urban villages  former villages that were swallowed up by the ever-expanding capital  more often than not, one is confronted by a boring, gray wall  the bare side of another building.

title: Rethinking the Indian War Memorial
description: Earlier this week, Narendra Modi, the Bharatiya Janata Partys candidate for the prime minister, stirred up his critics when he asserted in a speech to mostly military personnel that India does not have a war memorial.

title: Indonesian Militants Join Foreigners Fighting in Syria
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesians have joined the thousands of foreign fighters who have traveled to Syria to help extremist groups trying to create an Islamic state there, according to a new report, a finding that analysts said Friday could help revive a weakened jihadi movement in Indonesia and set off more attacks on minority Shiites in the Southeast Asian country.

title: Big Business Joins Obama Effort to Aid Long-Term Unemployed
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has persuaded some of the nations largest companies, including Walmart, Apple, General Motors and Ford, to revise their hiring practices to avoid discriminating against applicants who have been out of work for a long time.

title: Hindered by Geography but Surmounting It
description: The Timess chief film critics, A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, offer suggestions for renewing the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Ignore the Young at Your Peril
description: The Timess chief film critics, Manohla Dargis andA. O. Scott, offer suggestions for renewing the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Prescriptions for a Cinema Refuge
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center was born 45 years ago in an age when screenings of foreign and other nonstudio films werent easily found. It was given the task of overseeing the New York Film Festival, a fledgling annual event at the time, but also with fostering what were described as movie activities. In the decades since, that nebulous term has been interpreted to mean a lively variety of repertory programs, retrospectives and, in the last few years, even first-run releases. While the annual festival has thrived, the fortunes of this nonprofit society have ebbed and flowed. In 2011, the organization expanded its footprint with the addition of the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center. But the society also recently underwent a leadership shake-up, its second in three years, and its year-round offerings face stiff competition from other screens around the city and online. A new executive director has yet to be named, and in this interim period, it seemed like the time to ask what a 21st-century Film Society should look like.

title: Write What You Know, Especially if Its Difficult Family
description: LOS ANGELES  Violet Weston, the horrifying matriarch of August: Osage County who got Meryl Streep her 18th Oscar nomination, is famously based on the screenwriter Tracy Lettss own grandmother. Mr. Lettss characterization of her, he has said, was kinder than she was in real life.

title: A Jerk in the Subway
description: Dear Diary:

title: Verdict in March for 3 in France Accused of Intent to Fight in Syria
description: PARIS  The first trial of French citizens accused of trying to join the rebellion in Syria concluded Friday after lawyers for the government and the defendants presented their arguments in a Paris courtroom.

title: House G.O.P.s Immigration Plan Presents Tough Choices for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his allies may soon confront a difficult decision: whether to abandon the creation of a new path to citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants and accept tough border security and enforcement measures that they have long criticized.

title: Audit Planned in Fraud Case as Navy Reinstates Shipper
description: The Navy has quietly lifted the suspension of a shipping contractor under investigation for possible fraud, allowing the company to compete for new work. In exchange, the company has agreed to pay for an independent audit that could help the Justice Department determine how much it may have overcharged the government.

title: Determined Voters in Thailand Ready to Repel Protesters
description: BANGKOK  All of the extreme emotions, the fears of lawlessness and the concerns about violence breaking out in Sundays election in Thailand are on display in a community called Lat Krabang, a few minutes drive from the main international airport here.

title: The Source | Liz Glynn in Conversation With Doug Aitken
description: I think about functioning as somewhere between an architect and a scientist, says Liz Glynn. So I create the space and set up an experiment, but then I get out of the way and sort of see what happens. In conversation with Doug Aitken, the 32-year-old artist from Los Angeles talks about her work, which includes site-specific installations for performances and collective happenings as well as modern-day monuments and handmade sculptural objects. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: Elaine Stritch, Broadway Legend: Entertaining Is Hard
description: After years of vowing to retire, you gave up your cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle and your apartment at the Carlyle Hotel and moved to Birmingham, Mich. What made you finally take the leap? I wasnt getting the quality of work that I wanted to get. Im a funny age  funny ha-ha, funny peculiar, funny, funny. I could hardly open my mouth on the stage without getting a laugh. Thats a pretty sensational thing to brag about, but its also dangerous. I had a great time, and Im very glad its over. Oh, my God, its hard. Entertaining is hard.

title: Our Young-Adult Dystopia
description: I sometimes wonder what Dante or Milton or any of those guys would make of the modern appetite for the young-adult epic. It wasnt always a lucrative thing, writing grand, sweeping, fantastical stories, you know. It was a job for nose-to-the-grindstone, writing-for-the-ages types, and worldly rewards were low. Milton died in penury, blind and obscure; Dante met his maker in literal exile. Would they look with envy upon their celebrated and moneyed modern analogues  your J. K. Rowlings, your Suzanne Collinses?

title: Reply All: The 1.19.14 Issue
description: THE ONLINE AVENGERS

title: Grown-Up Clothes
description: When I was 19, I went to New York City, my first trip East. Id won a Mademoiselle contest and would be one of 20 young women working at the magazine for a month in the summer. It was 1953, and I was excited but also frightened and daunted; I hadnt been on an airliner before, and no one I knew had been to New York except my Sioux Falls uncle, Bill, a buyer for a department store. In case of difficulties, I was to call my Uncle Bills New York friend, Mr. Herbert Solomon.

title: Who Made That First-Person-Shooter Game?
description: It was like playing with dolls, says the video-game designer and 3-D graphics creator John Carmack, thinking back to the computer entertainments before Call of Duty, Halo, Doom and all the other first-person-shooter games. In a typical game of that time, your character was maybe 16-by-16 pixels in an overhead view. Maybe it did some cute things that made you smile. But you were still controlling a tiny little thing on the screen.

title: Breaking: Kids Are Obnoxious
description: Rachael Ray violates the Third Commandment; Richard Sherman takes on Peanuts.

title: Get Out of My Subconscious!
description: Our subconscious beliefs, which we cannot easily understand or change, motivate many of the decisions we make. Some companies use manipulative branding techniques that create untrue associations between their products and some deep human desires      like sex or social status      with the goal of having the viewer establish this connection unconsciously. The desired result, presumably, is that the consumer will then buy the product with the misguided intent of fulfilling said desire. Is this practice unethical? ADAM GIDDING, NEW YORK

title: Theres a Reason That Rye Is Having a Moment
description: If we were playing a round of word association a few years ago and you said, Rye, I wouldnt have skipped a beat before saying, Pastrami. For most of my drinking life, rye whiskey seemed like tough-guy stuff, cowboy stuff. And to drink as they drank (or at least as I imagined they did) seemed affected or unduly performative. Why would I replace my everyday Irish whiskey with rye? Why trade the bourbon in my manhattan for another brown American spirit?

title: The Empire State Building in Ice
description: Every winter, hundreds of thousands of tourists visit the Harbin Ice and Snow World in northeast China, near the Songhua River, to see its vast collection of elaborately carved ice structures, many of them illuminated with colorful LEDs. The arduous task of quickly collecting all that ice for an exhibition that opens in early January begins in mid-December, and the ice city has been getting bigger every year. This time around, 180,000 cubic meters of ice were used. Some of the finished sculptures this year, which remain in place until March, are a homage to structures around the world, from the Colosseum to the Empire State Building. Zengyu Wang, the executive manager of the event, says the local government in Harbin dreamed up the festival as a lure to promote winter tourism. When visitors see the ice for the first time, he says, they have one reaction: Very shocked. Julie Bosman

title: Japans Public Broadcaster Faces Accusations of Shift to the Right
description: TOKYO  First, there was the abrupt resignation of a president accused by governing party politicians of allowing an overly liberal tone to news coverage. Then, his newly appointed successor immediately drew public ire when he seemed to proclaim that he would loyally toe the line of the current conservative government.

title: Judges Family Denies Pride Was Behind Rejection of 3rd-Highest Award
description: NEW DELHI  The family of the late Jagdish Sharan Verma, the former Supreme Court chief justice whose report helped strengthen Indian sexual assault laws, said it had rejected one of Indias top awards for the judge because he would have never accepted it had he been alive.

title: Investors and Customers Yearn for an Apple iThingamajig
description: Lets play a little game. If you were Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, and you could have any gadget in the world that you wanted, what would it be? Forget that such a gadget doesnt exist yet. Remember, youre the chief executive. of Apple  you can just pick up your iPhone 10, scroll down to Jony Ives number and tell him to build you an iThingamajig.

title: Clamor Grows for Syria to Deliver on Chemical Arms Pledge
description: The head of the United Nations chemical weapons watchdog added his voice on Friday to calls on Syria to accelerate the elimination of its chemical weapons, a day after Washington accused the Syrian government of deliberately stalling the weapons removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and  in a new complaint  reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

title: Putting Prestige in Service of Comedy
description: LOS ANGELES  Before his name appeared, however incongruously, on a list of possible cast members for a new Fox comedy set in a fictional Brooklyn police precinct, Andre Braugher had an epiphany.

title: Oscar Shorts on View
description: What will take home the Oscar in the documentary short subject category? Will it be Cavedigger, Jeffrey Karoffs film about a cave artist in New Mexico? Or The Lady in Number 6, Malcolm Clarkes portrait of a 109-year old Holocaust survivor? For those looking to make an educated guess on their Oscar ballot, a series of programs featuring this years nominees is in theaters nationwide today. The series has become an annual event, with the shorts programs divided into three feature-length compilations: animated, live-action and documentary.

title: Walmart Trims Its Profit Forecast for the 4th Quarter
description: Walmart lowered its profit expectations for the latest quarter, citing cuts to food stamps and an especially tough winter.

title: Abuse Claims in Ukraine Rise Among Protesters
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Alarm mounted on Friday among Western diplomats and rights groups over the scale and severity of abuses during the civil unrest in Ukraine after an antigovernment protest leader who had been missing for a week stumbled out of a snowy forest to say he had been crucified.

title: The Force of Japanese Exports Is Weakening
description: JAPAN posted a third consecutive trade deficit in 2013, providing more evidence that the power of the Japanese export machine has faded.

title: With Persistence, He Caught the Girl Next Door
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more.

title: Under Pressure
description: Parenthood as we know it  predicated on the unconditional exaltation of our children  is no more than 70 years old, and it has gone through radical readjustments over the past two generations. As children went from helping on the farm to being the focus of relentless cosseting, they shifted from being our employees to our bosses, Jennifer Senior observes in her trenchant and engrossing first book, All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood. Senior, a contributing editor at New York magazine, examines what it means to be a parent, through interviews with a handful of families who are neither typical nor extraordinary. These are snapshots, not longitudinal documentaries, but in the way of good snapshots, they tell more than one might notice at first glance, and they allow for cautious universalizing. She supplements these vignettes with extremely impressive research, weaving in insights from philosophy, psychology and an occasionally overwhelming mlange of social science reports.

title: The Badger With a Comb-Over
description: LOS ANGELES  David O. Russell had a nickname for Christian Bales character in American Hustle, the combed-over, paunchy yet confident swindler Irving Rosenfeld.

title: He Accused
description: The Dreyfus Affair, which splintered French society of the fin de sicle and continued to divide it well into the 20th century, began on the morning of Oct. 15, 1894, with the arrest for high treason of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus. Dreyfus was a 35-year-old artillery officer, a high-ranking graduate of the elite cole Polytechnique and the cole de Guerre (the French Armys war college), and was chosen on the basis of his grades and overall performance to train with the armys general staff. Robert Harris, in his fine novel An Officer and a Spy, lucidly retells the famous, bizarrely complicated and chilling story. His narrator is Lt. Col. Georges Picquart, who was promoted to that grade six months after Dreyfuss arrest and put in charge of the general staffs statistical section (the coy sobriquet of a counterintelligence unit), and went on to become one of Dreyfuss improbable and indispensable saviors.

title: Parenthood
description: CUT IT OUT

title: A Brooklyn Artery in Transition
description: The dream of turning Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn into a grand residential boulevard is still just that  a dream. Even so, residential development along the thoroughfare took off about a decade ago when the area was rezoned, and now, after a recession-induced break, construction has begun again at a somewhat frenzied pace.

title: Affordable Housing Conundrum
description: New Yorkers in truly affordable apartments sometimes find their sweet deals come with sacrifices.

title: A Bookstore on the Brink
description: Last month, The Times reported that the Manhattan home of Rizzoli Bookstore, a visually stunning literary outpost in an old limestone mansion on 57th Street, was to make way for a high-rise development. The news galvanized two passionate and beleaguered groups: readers and preservationists.

title: The Truly Affordable New York Apartment
description: In a city of soaring real estate prices, New Yorkers love to hear the tales of people who found the Promised Land: a truly affordable apartment.

title: Letters: Robert Gatess Duty and More
description: Robert Gatess Duty

title: Editors Choice
description: MY LIFE IN MIDDLEMARCH,  by Rebecca Mead. (Crown, $25.) A beguilingly straightforward account of Meads lifelong admiration for George Eliot as a novelist and as a role model for bright, provincially born girls like herself.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE REAL JANE AUSTEN: A Life in Small Things,  by Paula Byrne. (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) Contrary to Virginia Woolfs pronouncement, in 1928, that we have lives enough of Jane Austen, Austens appeal has proved irresistible. Byrnes vividly persuasive biography shirks chronological constraints, using objects of special significance to Austen  an East Indian shawl, an ivory miniature, velvet cushions  to depict her as an exuberant, worldly woman of fierce convictions.

title: Inside the List
description: Healthy Distance: Sarah Addison Allens Lost Lake, about a young widow trying to recover from grief at a magical Georgia resort, is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 5. Its Allens fifth novel  or sixth, if you count the early romance she wrote under a pseudonym  but her first since announcing, in a 2011 Facebook post, that she had advanced-stage breast cancer. (For those of you who dont want to read the word boob, breast or bazookas a gazillion times, she wrote, Ill let you know how it ends: Im going to be fine. Now, for the rest of you, Im going to reveal more about my cleavage than I think Ive ever told anyone.)

title: Breaking In
description: On a March evening in 1971, eight antiwar protesters burglarized an F.B.I. office in Media, Pa., just outside Philadelphia, with astonishing ease. A few weeks of elementary surveillance had shown them the vulnerability of the target: There were no cameras to elude, no alarms to disconnect. Because the building contained residential apartments, the group chose the night of the first Joe Frazier-Muhammad Ali heavyweight championship fight, an ideal distraction. It turned out that the Pennsylvania office, like so many others across the country, had almost no physical protection. Security was largely symbolic, resting on the bureaus carefully buffed reputation for efficiency in tracking down Americas most wanted criminals, from bank robbers to atomic spies. Put simply, no one messed with J. Edgar Hoovers F.B.I.

title: Secrets of Success
description: Quanyu Huangs new book, The Hybrid Tiger: Secrets of the Extraordinary Success of Asian-American Kids, may sound like yet another flogging for hapless Western parents, but its not.

title: The Marriage Plod
description: How disgusting the British find themselves! Let me rephrase that. If you were to go by the output of a certain strand of young, male British fiction writer, you could easily be forgiven for thinking the main activity of British life is being disgusted by the physical form of oneself and ones fellows. Ian McEwan began a short story noting the peculiar smell asparagus lends the urine (it suggests sexual activity of some kind between exotic creatures). Martin Amis spent large parts of his early career detailing his characters bleeding gums and cracked molars. Will Selfs books come so awash in bodily fluids that if you were to throw them against a wall theyd most likely stick. Male self-disgust, rooted in the moist tumult of adolescence, and extended into ones 20s and 30s under cover of literary careers aping the clinical imperturbability of Nabokov and Joyce, has almost bequeathed us its own genre. We might call it, in the manner of those outraged letters to British broadsheets, Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells.

title: In the Grip of Madness
description: July 2006: Haya Tedeschi, 83, waits at her home in Gorizia, on the Italian-Slovenian border, northwest of Trieste, for the arrival of the son who was stolen from her 62 years earlier, during the war.

title: Winter Cabbage With a Mediterranean Flair
description: One of the things I appreciate about this produce-limited time of year is that it forces me to devote a week of Recipes for Health to cabbage. I love this nutrient-dense cruciferous vegetable for many reasons: the way it sweetens as it cooks in the pan; the price per pound; the way it is comfortable in a soup or a pie, a stew, a gratin or a salad, a stir-fry or a timbale. Yet I sometimes forget to pay attention to cabbage. It can be overshadowed by other winter vegetables like kale, its more fashionable cousin.

title: Start-Up Aims to Circumvent Rules on Private Stock Sales
description: You have likely heard of first world problems. But here is a Silicon Valley problem  and a company trying to solve it.

title: Lonely Hunter
description: At the Brooklyn Museum, an exhibit called War/Photography: Images of Armed Conflict and Its Aftermath, which went up in November, featured a photograph by Nina Berman of a young Marine sergeant, Ty Ziegel, who was horrifically injured and disfigured by a suicide bomb in Iraq in 2004. Returning home, he underwent scores of surgeries and in 2006 married his sweetheart in Illinois. The marriage didnt last, and Ziegel died in December 2012. But nobody who saw the Marine Wedding series will be able to forget him  or the damage wrought by war on his body, his life and his family. Joyce Carol Oatess new novel puts the homecoming of a similarly wounded warrior at its center, doing with words what the Berman portraits did with images.

title: Liberated and Unfree
description: As the 150th anniversary of the Civil War heads toward its conclusion, the anniversary of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed, looms on the horizon. Properly commemorating it poses a challenge, since for no period of American history does a wider gap exist between scholarly understanding and public consciousness.

title: The Unknown War
description: They called it the Aleutian stare. During World War II, American soldiers stationed in the remote, windswept archipelago stretching for 1,100 miles west of the Alaskan mainland fought a secret war against Japanese invaders. Driven mad by the cold, the isolation and the dim, colorless light, some were taken away in straitjackets, gazing into the distance, unfocused, unspeaking. The rest of the country didnt even know they were there.

title: Are We There Yet?
description: Just as Arthur Phillipss Prague follows a group of Americans living not in the title city but in less trendy Budapest, Mary Millers terrific first novel, The Last Days of California, never quite makes it to the Golden State. And I dont think its giving anything away to say it doesnt turn out to be the last days, either.

title: Limits of Endurance
description: Alvin Townley, the author of books about naval aviation and Eagle Scouts, has written a gripping account of the Alcatraz Eleven, a group of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam who formed a tough core of heroic resisters despite brutal and relentless efforts to break them and convert them into fodder for the Communist propaganda machine. Readers of even passing acquaintance with the Vietnam War will most likely know of Jeremiah Dentons televised 1966 interview  one of the first glimpses of the life of United States military pilots who had been shot down and captured. American viewers watched in horror and puzzlement as Denton, an emaciated, hunched figure dressed in gray prison garb, defiantly telegraphed the word t-o-r-t-u-r-e by blinking out the letters in Morse code. His brave act was followed by yet more torture, and some time later Vietnamese authorities bundled him along with 10 other men out of the infamous Hanoi Hilton, as Hoa Lo prison in the North Vietnamese capital was known (and where John McCain, probably the most famous P.O.W. of the war, would be held). The destination of the Eleven was an even filthier hellhole a few miles away, which they nicknamed Alcatraz.

title: At a Distance
description: Penelope Lively is writing from another country, a place she calls old age. She is 80, and so, she assures us, she is now a native of this territory, an authority. Dancing Fish and Ammonites is about growing old, about memory and history, about reading and writing and the way experiences become associated with certain objects  with a book, say, or a piece of pottery. Lively has explored these themes before, in her many novels and in a handful of previous memoirs. This time, though, she says she wants to address them more abstractly: I find myself thinking less about what has happened to me but interested in this lifetime context, in the times of my life. Shes not trying to tell us a story.

title: Stab in the Dark
description: Isabel Allende says that RIPPER (Harper, $28.99) is her first murder mystery, and that it was a lot of fun to write. Its probably more accurate to say that this ungainly but thoroughly charming book is the authors own eccentric notion of a murder mystery, and that its a lot of fun to read. Also, it features a teenage sleuth  idiosyncratic of appearance, timorous of character, but magnificent of mind, according to her besotted grandfather  who is pretty much irresistible.

title: Boy Trouble
description: Peter Huang, the worshiped son in a family of daughters, has just one wish: to be a girl. His father, a Chinese immigrant, has another: to erase completely, and by force if necessary, evidence of his Asian heritage. Father and son have almost nothing in common except for the belief that self-acceptance is anathema.

title: This Week's Movies: Jan. 31, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on "Tim's Vermeer," "That Awkward Moment" and "Labor Day."

title: De Blasio on Hot 97: New Sound for Mayoral Radio
description: The interview ended with a pulsating reggae track, its lyrics an ode to the pleasures of high-quality cannabis.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
description: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh discusses The Hybrid Tiger and The Triple Package; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Betty Medsger talks about The Burglary; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
description: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh and Betty Medsger.

title: When Buying Stock in Gluttony Is a Good Investment
description: ARTHUR LEVITT JR., the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acknowledged that he found The Seven Deadly Sins irresistible  so much so that he plunked down $5,000 as an initial investment and has since put in more.

title: Cheerios: Hard for Racists to Swallow
description: Never mind the point-spread, New Jersey weather, momentum shifts and Newtonian replays. Just keep an eye out for the Super Bowls first unscheduled time out, when the huge television audience can catch that famous Cheerios commercial family  the one that so enraged racist Americans several months ago, featuring a manly black actor as father, a serene white mother and their charming interracial seven-year-old, Gracie.

title: A Perfectionist Does Opera His Way
description: Every once in a while, the Russian stage director Dmitri Tcherniakov has a nightmare. Hes ready to go to the theater and run a rehearsal when he realizes he has forgotten what he is supposed to do there, what he wants to tell the performers.

title: Not Easygoing, and Not Sure About a Donkey
description: PARIS  The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky has created four ballets to music by Leonid Desyatnikov: Russian Seasons (New York City Ballet, 2006), Old Ladies Falling Out (Territory festival in Moscow, 2007), Lost Illusions (Bolshoi Ballet, 2011) and Opera (La Scala Ballet, 2013). Both men are Russian, and both have worked at the Bolshoi in Moscow, where Mr. Ratmansky, 45, now artist in residence at American Ballet Theater, was the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet from 2004 to 2008, and Mr. Desyatnikov, 58, was music director from 2009 to 2010.

title: A Songbird Finding Strength in Her Nest
description: While other students at Juilliard wanted to sing Verdi and Rossini, the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke, 31, gained a reputation as a quick study willing to learn new pieces written by her composer colleagues.

title: Beatle Fans Hear Yesterday Again
description: It was inevitable, time marching on as it does, and yet it also hard to believe: Half a century has passed since the Beatles touched down in New York for the first time, on Feb. 7, 1964, and seduced the country with three performances on The Ed Sullivan Show and three concerts, one at the Washington Coliseum and two at Carnegie Hall. Everything about them  their pudding basin haircuts, their Cardin suits and pointed boots, their sharp, irreverent sense of humor  seemed outlandish, compared with American pop groups. And though their music was firmly rooted  as they were always quick to point out  in American rhythm and blues, soul and rock, they produced a sound that was fresh, energetic and unmistakably their own.

title: Jelly vs. Need, Comparing Two New Social Q & A Apps
description: In case anyone was looking for further evidence that the five-star rating system is broken, I heard a horrific story the other day from someone who used Yelp to select a five-star-rated veterinarian when his vet was out of town, only to get stuck with a $10,000 vet bill and a dead pet.

title: Clothes and Character: Gravity
description: Updated, 10:26 a.m. | Jany Temime, the costume designer of Alfonso Cuarns space thriller Gravity, was scared. After a 40-year career packed with period pieces and one of the biggest fantasy franchises in movies (Harry Potter), she was facing the great unknown: space. In 3-D, no less.

title: Walter De Marias Grand and Gritty Home
description: A former Con Edison substation on the Lower East Side reimagined by the internationally renowned artist/sculptor/composer Walter De Maria as a cavernous home studio, storage facility, and dedicated laboratory for the gestation of his monumental works, is about to enter the market at $25 million.

title: Exclusive | 421 East 6th Street
description: The sculptor and artist Walter De Maria, who died last summer at age 77, was drawn to the building by its lofty ceiling heights, unusual windows, and absolute privacy.

title: Times Fashion Critic Cathy Horyn to Retire
description: Cathy Horyn, The New York Timess chief fashion critic, is retiring, the paper said Friday. Ms. Horyn has been with The Times since 1998 and has been in her current position since 1999.

title: Navigating an Informants Shadow World
description: BERLIN  Ten years ago, Yuval Adler, an aspiring Israeli filmmaker, chanced upon a video on a Middle East website that captured one of the most brutal moments of the Palestinian uprising. The footage showed a gang of militants dragging a suspected collaborator through the streets of Bethlehem, and shooting him dead before a crowd of onlookers. I remember thinking: What is going on there? How does somebody get into that situation? Mr. Adler said. If these are the stakes in becoming an informant, how would the Israelis manage to recruit somebody?

title: At a Concert Full of Musical Stars, a Spotlight on Their Teacher
description: Itll be 70 years this spring since a 17-year-old Gabriel Kosakoff shouldered his trombone and marched out of the High School of Music and Art, dreaming of fame and fortune in the worlds top concert halls.

title: An App to Search for Street Art
description: The destruction of the graffiti mecca 5Pointz, in Long Island City, last fall was a devastating blow to the community of street art in New York City and around the world.

title: As Facebook Turns 10, How Has It Transformed Your Life?
description: In February, Facebook will be 10 years old.

title: Accounting for Dimons Big Jump in Pay
description: The compensation and management development committee of JPMorgan Chases board has three members, all seasoned business luminaries in their own right. Lee R. Raymond, the chairman, is the former long-serving chairman and chief executive of Exxon Mobil. Stephen B. Burke is chief executive of NBCUniversal. William C. Weldon is the former chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson.

title: This Weeks Cover Accurately Predicts the Super Bowl Winner (Half of the Time)
description: The cover of the magazine that you get in your Sunday Times may not be the same as your neighbors. In an effort to be equally supportive of (or offensive to) Seahawks and Broncos fans, we printed two covers, which will be distributed randomly to Times subscribers.

title: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
description: Airlines remake the staid in-flight safety video. Also on the Minute, the immigration debate and the origin of the first, first-person shooter game.

title: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
description: In the Video

title: No Help for Farm Bill From Miffed Kansans in the House
description: Few states are as identified with farming as Kansas. Among its nicknames are the The Wheat State and Americans Bread Basket. And Kansass lawmakers are quick to point out the importance of agriculture to the states economy.

title: Days Before the Kickoff, a Timeout at Forty Ate
description: There were moments last week, during the run-up to Sundays Super Bowl, when the hordes of football fans thronging Broadway for the N.F.L.s pregame festivities appeared to outnumber even the characters handing out fliers and asking, Do you like comedy? During one such moment, as others rode toboggans down a snowless slope, a couple from Interlaken, N.J., made their way to the second floor of the Renaissance New York Times Square Hotel, overlooking the madness, to refuel over lunch at Forty Ate, a pop-up restaurant conceived by the football league and the restaurateur Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group. The hosts offered Thursday-to-Saturday ownership of choice tables for $50,000 (drinks not included), but found only four takers. The rest of the restaurants 72 seats went to ordinary reservation-makers and walk-ins.

title: Image of the Day: January 31
Bank of America Settlement on Bonds That Soured Is Approved
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice on Friday approved an $8.5 billion settlement between Bank of America and a group of mortgage securities investors, but the ruling contained a caveat that could create new problems for the bank.

title: Landrieu Patriarch Talks About Familys Political Prospects
description: In an interview for Fridays article about the fortunes of his political family business in Louisiana, Moon Landrieu, the former New Orleans mayor and patriarch of the Landrieu family, weighed in on its prospects. His son, Mayor Mitch Landrieu of New Orleans, has a Democratic primary on Saturday and his daughter, Senator Mary Landrieu, also a Democrat, is facing a grueling re-election race later this year in increasingly Republican Louisiana.

title: Art Reaches New Heights in Alps
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland  In the summer of 2012, the London-based artist Christian Marclay was scouting locations around this postcard-perfect ski resort town in the Swiss Alps, looking for inspiration.

title: Back to the Future Musical Planned for London Opening
description: Back to the Future, Robert Zemeckiss 1985 comedy starring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly, a teenager zapped from the 1980s back to the 1950s, is being transformed into a musical. It is expected to have its premiere in London in 2015, a spokesman for Colin Ingram, one of the shows producers, said on Friday.

title: Investing in Safety
description: An oil boom in La Salle County, Texas has created a growing need for emergency workers.

title: A Concession Worker Is Ready for Super Bowl Duty
description: Not everyone in a uniform at MetLife Stadium on Super Bowl Sunday will wear a helmet. Inez Keyes will wear a smile. High-fiving fans and co-workers while serving beer, she is the Peyton Manning of hospitality. (Go Beertenders!) Ms. Keyes, 55, one of nearly 3,000 concession workers for Delaware North Companies, has brought her A-game to Giants and Jets games in the Meadowlands for 22 years, going from counter worker to cashier to beertender on the 100 Concourse. (She also supervises a concession stand at the Izod Center.) Ms. Keyes commutes two hours from Canarsie, Brooklyn, taking two subways and two buses to New Jersey; her routine will vary slightly on Super Bowl Sunday, but despite the later kickoff, she will still leave the house early to be in place for the big game.

title: Big Ticket | Glass Aerie at a Record $50.9 Million
description: A stunning glass-sheathed penthouse at the pinnacle of Chelseas Walker Tower, the 1929 Art Deco skyscraper that underwent a ballyhooed conversion from iconic office building to 47 luxury condominiums, sold for $50,912,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price was $55 million; monthly carrying costs are $9,361.81.

title: Where the Hell Is Robert E. Lee
description: A song by Chelsea Crowell.

title: Prince Said to Drop Suit Against Fans
description: Prince has apparently thought better of the lawsuit he filed against 22 of his fans earlier this month, seeking $1 million from each for posting video recordings of his concert performances. Or perhaps the lawsuit was simply a shot across the bow, meant as a reminder that Prince  who has threatened his fans and collectors with legal action in the past  would not tolerate trading in unauthorized recordings of his work.

title: Obama Outlines Plan to Help Unemployed
description: President Obama announced initiatives to help the long-term unemployed get jobs from both the private and public sectors.

title: Today in Small Business: the Most Promising Companies
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Copenhagen Womens Shows
description: A glimpse at what guys and gals are wearing this season.

title: Artist Files Suit Over Missing Empire State Building Paintings
description: For many years, visitors to the concourse level of the Empire State Building walked by a series of large, lush paintings that seemed to be abstractions but that actually represented the atomic or molecular structure of the materials  brick, steel, cement, aluminum  used in the skyscrapers construction.

title: More Mindfulness, Less Meditation
description: Heres the promise: Meditation  and mindfulness meditation, in particular  will reduce your cortisol level, blood pressure, social anxiety and depression. It will increase your immune response, resilience and focus and improve your relationships  including with yourself. It will also bolster your performance at work and provide inner peace. It may even cure psoriasis.

title: Teacher and Troll Both Start With T
description: By all accounts, young people are gravitating away from watching television in the traditional way, but thats not stopping Nickelodeon from going after very young people. On Monday afternoon at 1, the channel unveils Wallykazam!, an animated series full of early literacy lessons for preschoolers. Its a Sesame Street approach transplanted to a land of magic and kid-friendly mythical beings.

title: Harmonic Requiem for a Genre
description: It wont be grand: no overtures or entractes or glossy souvenir programs for sale in the lobby. But Roadshow: The Fall of Film Musicals in the 1960s, through Friday, has five of those rare birds  Hollywood musicals  glittering and strutting across the screen at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: What Lives On After Death
description: Since it began organizing exhibitions in 2012, the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation has looked far and wide for artists, staying mostly clear of the career of its famous founder, who died in 2008 and wanted the foundation to serve as a home for idiosyncratic, politically vocal work.

title: Translations That Move
description: Ballet and modern dance once were bitter enemies. Yet because dancers tend to be blessed with curiosity, ballet dancers sneaked off to modern classes, and modern dancers turned up in ballet studios.

title: Three Composers Basking in Bach
description: Although the Miller Theater at Columbia University is indelibly tied to contemporary composers and early music, the voluminous canon of Johann Sebastian Bach has long formed a third pillar of that institutions programming. But this season, the theaters customary Bach series gets an intriguing overhaul with Bach, Revisited, a three-concert sequence in which prominent living composers pair selections by Bach with their own works to try to illuminate connections.

title: The Musical Trail of an Explorer
description: The Panamanian pianist Danilo Prez is an exceptional musician, even without much framework, as in the loosest, most intuitive moments of Wayne Shorters current band, of which hes been a member since 2000. But he puts a lot of framework in his own music: He wants to represent jazz within its broadest possible contexts of place and history. Hes about to release a new record, Panama 500 (Mack Avenue), which integrates Panamanian folklore, European classical music and jazz. Some of it describes the Spanish explorer Vasco Nez de Balboas crossing the isthmus of Panama in 1513.

title: Did George Washington Want to Burn New York City?
description: Q. As George Washingtons birthday nears, I recall a story that he tried to burn New York City during the Revolution. Really?

title: Orhan Pamuks Istanbul
description: On a windswept afternoon in mid-December, the writer Orhan Pamuk stood in a leafy square around the corner from Istanbul University, absorbed in a 40-year-old memory. He walked past parked motorcycles, sturdy oaks and a stone fountain, browsing through secondhand books in front of cluttered shops occupying the bottom floors of a quadrangle of pale yellow buildings. Sahaflar Carsisi, Istanbuls used-book bazaar, has been a magnet for literary types since the Byzantine era.

title: 36 Hours in Manchester, Vt.
description: Manchester may never be the ultimate Ski Town, U.S.A. Its gilded mansions and upscale factory outlets continue to draw more shoppers than ski bums. But this bucolic town in southern Vermont, blessed with two nearby ski resorts and backcountry trails that meander through the picturesque Battenkill Valley, is emerging as a popular winter getaway among Bostonians, New Yorkers and even Europeans looking to get acquainted with Vermonts unspoiled Green Mountains, while also exploring Manchesters bounty of local arts-and-crafts shops and artisanal restaurants. Its most recognizable property, the stately Equinox Hotel, underwent a major overhaul a few years ago. And the town just installed a pair of traffic roundabouts along the main strip to ease congestion. Dont expect Aspen, or even Stowe. But Manchester has its own relaxed, if sophisticated, ambience that is making it a popular four-season destination.

title: In East Africa, Safaris That Leave a Lighter Footprint
description: Want to have lunch with the elephants? That sounded like an offer we couldnt refuse  even if at least half the menu was bound to consist of hunks of grass and splintered acacia branches. Luckily, the human side of the invitation included gazpacho, zucchini frittata and salad. My husband and I did mind our manners, keeping our picnic well inside the Land Rover while a herd of our multi-ton hostesses grazed peacefully a few yards away, surrounded by children of all sizes. Introductions were made by our guide, Seronoi, and his spotter, Jackson, who identified our companions by the distinctive shape of their heads, ears and tusks. What better welcome to Samburu National Park, and to the sort of experience wed hoped to find on safari in East Africa.

title: Eclectic East Austin
description: A mile from downtown, East Austin has historically been a working-class neighborhood, a vibrant enclave heavily populated by African-Americans because of an earlier era of segregationist laws  and later, a home to Mexican-American residents. These days, its also the citys newly fashionable arts district, with studios, galleries, cocktail bars, cafes and all manner of food trucks popping up on most every block. Beloved taquerias and barbecue joints, ramshackle carwashes and Christian outreach ministries now jostle against shiny condos, fancy restaurants and, in refurbished bungalows, groovy hair salons with names like Peacock and Orbit.

title: A New Delhi Market for Savvy Shoppers
description: Mehar Chand Market, a bustling stretch of road in the heart of New Delhi, Indias capital, has recently emerged as the hottest shopping area in the city among cognoscenti on the hunt for one-of-a-kind finds. Gone are the longtime drugstores, tailors and small groceries that catered to nearby residents, many of them government workers. Today, young designers have opened boutiques along this half-mile strip on Lodhi Road, selling everything from home goods to the latest fashions. The wares all have a distinct Indian touch, whether its a silk sari fashioned in bright colors or a bright pillowcase shot through with an ethnic pattern. And their reasonable prices compared with other upscale retail districts in town stand out.

title: Russias Ice Skating Resurgence
description: After almost a decade without any top-level womens figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

title: In Russia, Skating Booms Again
description: MOSCOW  After almost a decade without any top-level womens figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

title: K.K.R. Buys Stake in German Soccer Club
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a private equity giant with its hands in a range of businesses, from natural gas to maritime finance, has bought into a new sector: German soccer.

title: Security Concerns on a Honduran Island
description: Honduras has the highest murder rate in the world, but the countrys idyllic Bay Islands have long been considered a safe haven, largely immune from the drug-fueled violence that has plagued the Honduran mainland. However, a string of recent crimes on Roatn, the largest of the Bay Islands, has prompted outrage, with some residents calling for greater autonomy and more effective policing for the islands.

title: A Bird Flies South, and Its News
description: DUXBURY, Mass.  The snowy owl seemed almost complacent, showing the confidence of a top predator whose bright yellow eyes suggested she might be sizing you up as a weaker combatant  or perhaps a large snack.

title: Renaming the Tappan Zee After Pete Seeger Is a Terrible Idea
description: Pete Seeger, who died this week at 94, was not only a folk singer of near-mythic status but also an ardent environmentalist who helped save the Hudson from turning into New Yorks Cuyahoga.

title: Powder in Letters Near Super Bowl Site Is Not Hazardous, Authorities Say
description: Several letters containing a suspicious substance sent to locations in New York City and New Jersey, causing a large-scale response by the authorities, have been found not to be hazardous after preliminary testing, according to a statement issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Giving Credit: A Work in Progress at The Times
description: Curtis Tate, a reporter for McClatchy Newss Washington bureau, spent a recent weekend generating spreadsheets from a database on hazardous materials for his story on the increasing amount of crude oil spilled in rail accidents.

title: A Leader Shows Vulnerability in Turkeys Cash Crisis
description: ISTANBUL  First, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan criticized the bold move by Turkeys central bank this week to raise interest rates sharply to halt the decline in the countrys currency, telling reporters that higher borrowing costs would lead to inflation  an argument that contravenes accepted economic logic.

title: Need Tax Help? I.R.S. May Not Be the Best Place to Go
description: IF youre ready to file your 2013 federal income tax return, you can do so starting now. The official start of tax-filing season arrived later than anticipated because of a delay caused by last years government shutdown.

title: A Parting Gift as Ben Bernanke Hangs Up His Cleats
description: Ben S. Bernanke now has his own baseball card.

title: New York Court Archivist Isnt Letting Retirement Stop Him
description: It was just another day at the old grind on Wednesday for Bruce Abrams, 66, an archivist at the Division of Old Records in Manhattan: the rat race commute, a brown-bag lunch and eight hours retrieving files and organizing archival material, as he has done for 30 years.

title: What I Love | Dan Kainen
description: The artist, author and inventor lives in an East 12th Street apartment featuring his custom designs and furnishings.

title: Space-Saving D.I.Y. in the DNA
description: Dan Kainens pride and joy is his broom closet. Its an amenity thats not normally found in a 750-square-foot apartment, but Mr. Kainen has cleverly created and camouflaged storage units throughout his miniloft in Greenwich Village.

title: Classically Trained
description: WHOSally Hawkins

title: Red Carpet Watch: Sally Hawkinss Fashion Choices
description: The English actress, who is nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress, has an eclectic style.

title: When the Master Calls the Roll
description: A song by Rosanne Cash.

title: Petite Crevette, the House of the Flying Lobster
description: On a mild night in January, Neil Ganic, wearing a white chefs coat, his signature porkpie hat tilted low, greeted customers at his restaurant, Petite Crevette. The room appears to be the foyer or staging area of a larger place, but this is pretty much it: maritime curios, tight tables, original artwork and framed photos below an aqua-green ceiling. Two line chefs, sequestered in the minuscule kitchen behind a barricade of coolers and counter space and hanging bric-a-brac, conjure aromas of grilled fish and saffron amid the soft sound of Latin jazz. Most who enter either know Mr. Ganic personally or know of him and his rather formidable reputation.

title: First, You Must Kill Your Inner Movie Star
description: When dance artists share an evening, its natural to want to know what theyre doing in the same place. Who put them together and why? On Thursday, the choreographers Niv Acosta and Tess Dworman presented new works at New York Live Arts, and the junction was worrying: They brought out the superficial in each other.

title: I Am Not A Wise Man
description: A wise guy, yes. And maybe  I like to think so  someone with a pretty good though by no means error-free track record on depression economics. But Chris House is right, even though he refuses to say what nutty things Ive said that come remotely close to Ed Prescott.

title: New York Hotels Have Rooms for Super Bowl Weekend
description: Its not too late to book a room in New York for Super Bowl weekend. In fact, many hotels are still advertising availability, attempting to entice last-minute travelers with tailgate party packages and post-game detox deals.

title: The Policy Lapsed, but No One Knew
description: Sometimes you do everything right and it still goes wrong.

title: Report Opens Way to Approval for Keystone Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department released a reporton Fridayconcluding that the Keystone XL pipeline would not substantially worsen carbon pollution, leaving an opening for President Obama to approve the politically divisive project.

title: The Best Special Effects of the Last 35 Years
description: We hardly need proof of how quickly technology is moving, but sometimes its nice to get a refresher.

title: Microsoft Said to Be Close to Naming a New Chief
description: SEATTLE  Microsoft has spent five months looking for a new face to help the company evolve along with the mobile age. Turns out, it seems to be choosing a familiar face and largely sticking to its current path.

title: Lone Fan Tackles the N.F.L. Over Super Bowl Ticket Prices
description: Josh Finkelmans quest for Super Bowl justice began on a Monday in December with the click of a computer mouse. The day before, a busy football Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks had demolished the St. Louis Rams and the sports postseason landscape was finally shaping up.

title: Signs Point to a Seinfeld Reunion, if Ever So Brief
description: It may be all about nothing, but that would only be appropriate.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Googles Stock Split Comes as Shares Hit Record Highs
description: Remember when Google announced plans to split its stock, creating a third class of shares? No worries if you couldnt; the technology titan announced it in the spring of 2012.

title: Winter Olympians to Follow on Instagram
description: The Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are bound to include plenty of Howd they do that? moments. Athletes have perfected moves that demand a double-take: gravity-defying ski jumps, jaw-dropping snowboarding tricks on the halfpipe, flawless ice dancing routines.

title: After Meeting, Republicans Seem Unsure of Way Forward
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md.  House Republicans ended a three-day retreat here united in their division. They agreed they wanted to go big with a midterm election agenda that would give voters a clear choice, and not simply be a campaign focused on their criticism of President Obama.

title: The Gun Report: January 31, 2014
description: On Jan. 6, Todd Kuchman and his brother, Jaye, founders of the Denver-based Advanced Ballistic Concepts, launched the multiple impact bullet, a 3-shots-in-1 round that splits into several fragments. Meant for self-defense, the shrapnel is held together by a Y-shaped ballistic-strength fiber, which makes for better accuracy than a shotguns blast of pellets, thus minimizing the chances of hitting unintended people or things. The companys slogans include, Because you cant afford to miss and First hit advantage is everything!

title: Book Review Podcast: Secrets of Success
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Sandra Tsing Loh reviews two new books about success in America: The Hybrid Tiger by Quanyu Huang and The Triple Package by Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld. Ms. Loh writes:

title: The Low-inflationary Trap
description: Dean Baker is, of course, completely right here. There isnt a red line you cross when going from positive to negative inflation, with all sorts of bad things suddenly happening. What matters is inflation relative to the rate that best suits your circumstances. Since the euro area would clearly be best off with an inflation rate well above current levels, this is a disastrous report:

title: A Campaign for Mayor, and for a Mate
description: When Chris Coffey talks about love, he often talks about New York.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
description: Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

title: About That Coin
description: Some comments Ive seen indicate that people still think the trillion-dollar platinum coin idea was self-evidently ridiculous. Guys, you missed the memo  literally. From last month:

title: Video Reviews of Tims Vermeer, That Awkward Moment and Labor Day
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the documentary Tims Vermeer, the romantic comedy That Awkward Moment and the drama Labor Day. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Are They Selling Sex or Beer? Its Super Bowl Media Literacy Bingo!
description: My children (12, 9, 8 and 7) all fully understand that one watches the Super Bowl as much for the advertisements as for the game, especially when ones team isnt playing. And here on the East Coast, Super Bowl watching tends to be a family affair for people with young children. (As my husband said when I mentioned missing Super Bowl parties, You want to take the kids to a party at 6:30 on a school night?)

title: You Cant Beat These Wedding Singers
description: LOS ANGELES  My fiance, Robyn Monks, and I were standing in a row with 32 other couples at the Grammys last Sunday night in one of those cavernous entryways to the Staples Center arena (the kind through which beasts and fighters might have passed in Romes Colosseum), and we were about to enter and be married by Queen Latifah on live television.

title: From High Above Times Square, a Super Bowl Tease
description: The football carnival that has taken over 14 blocks of Broadway around Times Square may be fun for Super Bowl crowds, but those who work in the surrounding buildings are growing weary.

title: Passions in a Pastors Wake
description: At the Rev. Carmen Mason-Brownes farewell party in January, many supporters stood to give impassioned testimonials to the profound effect she had had on them in her two years as interim pastor at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. One spoke of her poetic sermons, another of her initiative to include children in the service, and another of her commitment to social justice.

title: Contender for Microsoft Helm Seen as Unlikely to Shake It Up
description: As Microsoft hunts for its new chief executive, the firm appears to have zeroed in on a true company man who has spearheaded Microsofts efforts to stay on the cutting edge.

title: Syrian Talks, Ending First Round, Fail Even to Agree on Easing Aid Blockade
description: GENEVA  The first round of the Syria peace talks ended on Friday without achieving even its most modest goal: easing the Syrian governments blockade on the delivery of food and medicine to besieged communities.

title: A Super Bowl Party Briefly Interrupted by I Dos
description: Most engaged couples who are planning a wedding date usually pass on Super Bowl Sunday, but Rachel Graham and Julian Ho have a different game plan, as do Shawna Cook and Brian Mascarelli.

title: Verizon Wireless Prepares Network for TV Broadcasting
description: Cord cutters, the people who cancel their cable TV subscriptions in favor of Internet-based alternatives, are a looming threat for the television industry. Verizon Wireless wants to capitalize on that.

title: A Couple of Contradictions
description: In the course of working on the profile of Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld that I wrote for this weekends magazine, I came across many things that had been written about the couple  some of them so contradictory that they almost canceled each other out. Chuas supporters see her as a courageous truth-teller, willing to sacrifice her good name to show how permissive parenting has put American children in peril; her critics see her as a cynical pop-cultural savant, exploiting stereotypes and anxieties to sell some books. Reactions to Rubenfeld have been similarly erratic, though less extreme. Here is a sliver of whats out there.

title: Jennifer Lawrences Big Dior Contract, Transgender and 62-Year-Old Models and the Next Dame of the British Empire
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.

title: Christie Linked to Knowledge of Shut Lanes
description: The former Port Authority official who personally oversaw the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, central to the scandal now swirling around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, said on Friday that evidence exists that the governor knew about the closings when they were happening.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.

title: Triage for Treasures After a Bomb Blast
description: CAIRO  A man in a white lab coat sat alone among piles of blown-off ceiling, mangled metal and splintered wood here on Thursday inside the Museum of Islamic Art  home to a world-renowned collection that covers centuries of art from countries across the Islamic world. He carefully separated ochre-tinted pieces of old glass from the clear shards of modern showcases.

title: Hardin Wouldnt Run
description: A song by Johnny Cash.

title: When Owning a Home Is Cold Comfort
description: The declining fortunes of the middle class in New York City are often most easily observed in the context of gentrification and soaring real estate valuations.
