There is an obvious doom that befalls anyone renting long-term in a neighborhood on a rapid trajectory to preciousness. This doom, or fear of it, in turn leads to an intensified idealization of homeownership  though the ownership rate in the city, at just over 30 percent, is less than half the figure for the country over all  a sense that there could be few problems immune to solution had one had the foresight (and resourcefulness) to a buy a brownstone in Brooklyn for $400,000 in 1995.

title: Letter From Wildsteins Lawyer on Lane Closings
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey knew about the lane closings as they were happening, a letter released on Friday by the lawyer of David Wildstein said.

title: A Cadillac That Says Achtung
description: Cadillac still has a ways to go to match the cachet of German luxury brands, but the third-generation CTS puts Cadillac firmly in the conversation.

title: Finally, Real Diva in Lineup for Game
description: Since 1967, the national anthem has been sung at the Super Bowl by a boy band and a college a cappella group. It has been belted by a morning-TV host and bugled by a trumpeter (four times!).

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Sri Lanka and China.

title: Lives of the After-Party
description: Got the boss coming! a security worker shouted.

title: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | A Near-Cigar With Mike Ditka
description: The air pooled with machine-generated smoke, wisps rising into the rafters of the cabaret bar, where the presently chic tropes of such places  taxidermy creatures like a fox and a crow  peered down into the audience. But onstage, flanked by velvet curtains, in place of a sultry singer was a very different sort of star: the septuagenarian former football coach Mike Ditka.

title: Weekend Reading: Super Bowl Quotes for Wall Street
description: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week were looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.

title: Since They Lost Sammy
description: In last Sundays Metropolitan section, N.R. Kleinfield wrote about Gary Eckstein and Amy Cohen, who became activists for safer streets after their son, Sammy, was struck and killed by a van in Brooklyn. A reader responded via email:

title: The Stakes Off the Field
Taking Aim at Android, After a Jilting at Nokia
description: HELSINKI, Finland  Marc Dillon still remembers the sick feeling that overcame him when Nokia announced it was scrapping a software project that he and hundreds of other developers had spent years creating.

title: A Break From Opera for Orchestra in Madrid
description: MADRID  In keeping with a long tradition in classical music, the Orquesta Sinfnica de Madrid is an ensemble with two identities. It is the official orchestra of the Teatro Real, this citys major opera company, and as such has been working hard of late, especially this week.

title: Good Enough? Thats Great
description: Whats the best way to recalibrate a marriage as the years pass? I wish I had the answer, because clearly millions of us would like to know.

title: Anti-Gay Policies Chill Viewers Interest
description: Outraged by a new Russian law that outlaws homosexual propaganda and by President Vladimir Putins recent remarks that gays who go to Sochi for the Olympic Winter Games should stay away from children, some gays and lesbians are planning to boycott watching the Olympics on TV.

title: At First, Love Runs Hot, but Then It Always Cools
description: During her recital at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote explored Les chemins de lamour (The Paths of Love), tracing a romantic arc of bliss, ambiguity and despair. Les Chemins, the title of the Poulenc song that opened the program, set the mood for an evening of mlodie, beautifully accompanied by the eminent British pianist Graham Johnson.

title: Scientific Pride and Prejudice
description: SCIENCE is in crisis, just when we need it most. Two years ago, C. Glenn Begley and Lee M. Ellis reported in Nature that they were able to replicate only six out of 53 landmark cancer studies. Scientists now worry that many published scientific results are simply not true. The natural sciences often offer themselves as a model to other disciplines. But this time science might look for help to the humanities, and to literary criticism in particular.

title: The Transformation of Lady Edith
description: Poor, sad Lady Edith. Early on in Downton Abbey, the PBS Masterpiece Classic family saga, it seemed that the much-overlooked, undervalued middle sister of the Crawley clan had been dealt a rough hand. Her assertive nose, wan manner and decorously dowdy wardrobe had apparently rendered her marriage prospects slim to nil. Be kind to her, she has so few advantages, Lady Cora, her mother, urges Ediths sister Mary. To which Mary peevishly replies that Edith has none at all.

title: Get Them While Theyre Green
description: The first time I went to Thailand, of the various unfamiliar items in the vegetable market, it was glossy bright green peppercorns, fresh ones, in juicy clusters, that were the most exciting.

title: The German Lessons Are Paying Off
description: When Cadillac set out to revive its arthritic cars and unfashionable image, beginning with the original CTS sedan of 2003, the brand seemed as retirement-ready as many of its customers.

title: CTS Vsport: The BMW Beater
description: A $60,000 sticker price rarely suggests a bargain among automobiles.

title: Cadillac Lays Its Wreath to Rest
description: Cadillac takes its insignia, which it calls the crest, very seriously. But that doesnt keep it from tinkering with the logo every now and then.

title: Review: 2014 Cadillac CTS
description: The last two generations of Cadillacs CTS have come close to running with the best Germany has to offer. G.M.s third try confidently drives to the front of the pack.

title: Musharrafs Request to Leave Pakistan for Treatment Is Rejected
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A special court on Friday rejected a request by the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf to leave Pakistan for medical treatment and instead issued arrest warrants in the treason case against him, according to lawyers in the case.

title: Critic of Online Ad Firm Blinkx Is Part of the Controversy
description: LONDON  A Harvard Business School professor has raised pointed questions in an article about an Internet advertising company, prompting a plunge in its stock price. He himself, though, is now a subject of controversy.

title: Bill Cunningham | Game On
description: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival.

title: Bill Cunningham | Game On
description: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival. For the well-bundled fans: marching bands, cheerleaders, uniforms of the Broncos and Seahawks. For thrill seekers: a toboggan slide. As cameras click everywhere, police and their mounts remain vigilant. The sharp-eyed spied an actual football player, on his way to a broadcast booth.

title: Movie Review: 'That Awkward Moment'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "That Awkward Moment."

title: Movie Review: 'Labor Day'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Labor Day."

title: "Building" by Steven and William Ladd
description: Steven and William Ladd's magical, whimsical worlds are the subject of a new show at the Mingei International Museum. This video illuminates the brothers inspirations and creative process.

title: Movie Review: 'Tim's Vermeer'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Tim's Vermeer."

title: Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

title: The Magical World of Steven and William Ladd
description: The magical, whimsical worlds created by the artists Steven and William Ladd are the subject of Function and Fantasy, a new exhibition at the Mingei International Museum in San Diego. The brothers, who work out of a studio in New York Citys Chelsea neighborhood, brought their individual practices together more than a decade ago, when Steven was designing clothes and William was making intricate beadwork. Soon Williams beadwork found its way onto Stevens clothes, and a deep collaboration began to evolve. They formed an accessories company, incorporating work so complex that it takes them up to three years to complete a single handbag. Ideas for packaging led them to the tower installations that now lie at the heart of their artistic practice.

title: In North Carolina, Sites That Honor Black History
description: Thirty-seven sites that highlight the contributions of African-Americans to the business, spiritual, educational and civic life of  Wilmington, N.C., are detailed in the recently published African American Heritage guide.

title: No Timetable for Relocating a Franchise to Los Angeles, Goodell Says
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that there was no timetable for putting a team in Los Angeles despite news reports that the owner of the St. Louis Rams, Stan Kroenke, had bought 60 acres in central Los Angeles, which presumably could hold a stadium.

title: Apple Executives Met With F.D.A. to Discuss Mobile Medical Applications
description: Apple has signaled strong interest in health-monitoring technology, which could wind up in a widely anticipated smartwatch.

title: $100,000 Reward Is Set for Stolen Stradivarius Violin
description: The Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra announced late Friday afternoon that a $100,000 reward was being offered to anyone who provides information that leads to the safe return of the 1715 Stradivarius violin stolen from the orchestras concertmaster, Frank Almond, after a chamber concert in Milwaukee on Monday evening. Susan Loris, a spokeswoman for the orchestra said she was unable to identify the source of the reward money. It could be the orchestra, the anonymous owner of the violin (it was given to Mr. Almond as a permanent loan in 2008) or others.

title: When Simplicity Trumps Complexity
description: The notion of stealing a show through simplicity and understatement may seem counterintuitive if not oxymoronic. But your intuition and mine are not Arvo Prts, and this is a feat Mr. Prt achieves with some regularity, as he did on Wednesday evening in the fourth program of the annual Focus! festival of contemporary music at the Juilliard School.

title: Parched, California Cuts Off Tap to Agencies
description: LOS ANGELES  Responding to one of the worst droughts in Californias history, state officials announced on Friday that they would cut off the water to local agencies serving 25 million residents and about 750,000 acres of farmland.

title: Going Off the Grid, and Being Showy About It
description: PHILADELPHIA  A newbie camper wanders off into the woods in Cherokee, the new play by Lisa DAmour having its premiere at the Wilma Theater here. His subsequent disappearance sparks a strange series of events, as his wife and the two friends joining him on a back-to-nature spree find themselves gradually acclimatizing to their radically altered lives as they spend days and weeks hoping for his return.

title: Red Carpet Project
description: Of all the fashionable events that take place during awards season, the red carpet at the Academy Awards remains the main attraction. Explore an archive of Oscar red carpet looks that spans 17 years by name, designer, color, silhouette and year.

title: Morgan Stanleys Stock Bet Yields Windfall on Paper
description: When Morgan Stanleys share price fell to $20 in 2011, the banks chief executive, James P. Gorman, and several of his top lieutenants tried to encourage investors by buying up stock with their own money. Now, that put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is approach appears to have paid off.

title: A Hand-Me-Down With a History
description: Rambling over the back roads that neighbor Duke Farms, a 2,700-acre estate and nature preserve in central New Jersey, the 1952 MG TD called to mind a little pooch eager to impress the big hounds at the dog park: The confident bark of its exhaust belied the timid 55-horsepower bite of its tiny 4-cylinder engine.

title: Keeping It in the Family
description: Randy Mehrbergs 1952 MG TD was a gift from his uncle Morty, who taught Randy to drive in the MG decades ago.

title: Injured Actor Is Suing Spider-Man Producers
description: Daniel Curry, a young actor who was seriously injured in August while performing in the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, filed a lawsuit this week accusing the shows producers, engineering consultants, and others of negligence in the design and operation of a mechanical lift that Mr. Curry was using onstage when he was hurt.

title: You Are Like the People These Guys Make Up
description: TJ and Dave, the hourlong improv show by the Second City veterans TJ Jagodowski and David Pasquesi, the premier improv duo working today, unfolds so seamlessly that it makes you wonder: Are these guys really making all this up on the spot?

title: Jointly Forging a Movement, Cheek by Jowl
description: She is a white Unitarian activist spinster from a good family in Brooklyn. He is one of the greatest African-American intellectuals of the 20th century. Dr. Du Bois and Miss Ovington finds them on aSundayafternoon in 1915, and the burning question is supposedly whether she can talk him out of resigning from the N.A.A.C.P., of which they are both founders.

title: Carmakers to Share Repair Data
description: There is good news for motorists who have been turned away from local independent repair shops with an explanation that only the automakers dealership can correct a particular problem.

title: Flitting Between Watery Dream and Reality
description: WASHINGTON  The consistent visual beauty of the Mariinsky Ballets production of Swan Lake, which opened at the Kennedy Center this week, is astonishing. No other staging today so perfectly locates this ballet in the medieval age of chivalry; no other sets, costumes and lighting are so ravishingly satisfying in terms of color, style, period, atmosphere.

title: Bridge at the District 3 Winter Regional
description: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Sunday A/X Swiss Teams were Jeff Aker of Briarcliff, N.Y., Victor King of Hartford, Conn., and Glenn Milgrim and Barry Rigal of New York City. They finished 8 victory points ahead of Dori Cohen of Woodbury, N.Y., Robert Gordon of Northport, N.Y., Kelley Hwang of New York City, and Richard Popper of Wilmington, Del. Third were Sue Picus, Alex Ornstein and Craig Ganzer of New York City, and Gene Saxe of Briarcliff, N.Y.

title: True South | New Orleans Dining
description: Ts contributing editor Sara Ruffin Costello recommends Martis, which is off North Rampart Street, and Killer Poboys in the Erin Rose Bar on Conti Street, both in the French Quarter.

title: For a Silky Hip-Hop Romeo, a Juliet of His Own Making
description: The beloved hip-hop choreographer Rennie Harris returned to the Joyce Theater for the first time in 10 years on Tuesday night, and the two-hour program  even one frustratingly made up of older dances and excerpts  was worth the wait. The prolific Mr. Harris works like a fiend. To all the nervous producers in the world: its O.K. to take a chance on Mr. Harriss sophisticated view of hip-hop. We could have handled something new, something untested.

title: BowlesSimpsonism
description: Jonathan Chait  whos been on a roll  has fun with the idea that the Bowles-Simpson commission is a model for, well, anything:

title: Evening Hours | Keeping Warm
description: Even frigid weather could not halt the party circuit.

title: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
description: A former aide claims that Gov. Chris Christie was aware of the lane closings while they were happening. Also on the Minute, the end of a rough month on Wall Street and this year's Super Bowl ads.

title: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
description: In the Video

title: Fashions Fertile Ground for Inspiration: Gardens
description: Seasons, colors, lighting and scale are no less important in building a good garden than they are in designing a good fashion collection. The two subjects, which have more crossover than some might realize, are explored in a show at the Garden Museum in London that opens Friday, aptly titled Fashion & Gardens. Our national obsession with gardens and landscape is the greatest contribution England has brought to the world of fashion, says the British writer and historian Nicola Shulman, a trustee of the Garden Museum in London, who leaped at the opportunity to curate the exhibition. Through art, historical photographs, artifacts and a look back at notable runways from designers like Yves Saint Laurent and Valentino, Shulman explores the intricate relationship between the two design genres from the days of Elizabeth I up to recent runway shows.

title: Super Bowl Sideshows Starring Puppies, Kittens and Fish
description: The Puppy Bowl has long been the big dog when it comes to alternative programming during the Super Bowl. When the stadium lights went out at the big game last year, more than a million viewers filled the time by flocking to the canine contest.

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Normal Person
description: I have to admit, I had a hard time warming up to Arcade Fires new album. It was a break from the previous sound, and its taken me a while to find the thread of continuity. But I have been listening, and am increasingly getting it. As I mentioned on WNYC (btw, I start at around the 25-minute mark) my appreciation of their music grows when I get a chance to hear them do stripped-down performances, like this one just up, which among other things shows that the intensity and commitment is undiminished. Also that theyre having fun:

title: As Argentine Peso Falters, President Keeps a Low Profile
description: BUENOS AIRES  As Argentines stew over a currency crisis that has shaken markets around the world, many residents here are asking the same question: Where is the president?

title: Dominos Delivery Workers Settle Suit for $1.3 Million
description: Carlos Rodriguez Herrera said he often worked 65 hours a week as a deliveryman for a Dominos pizza shop on East 89th Street in Manhattan but was paid for just 45 hours. A co-worker, Anatole Yameogo, remembers working from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. one Saturday, but his pay stub said he worked just five hours that day.
